verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:1
verses.text: Homilies of St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:2
verses.text: John Chrysostom,  archbishop of constantinople,  on the  first epistle of St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:3
verses.text: paul the apostle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:4
verses.text: to the  corinthians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:5
verses.text: Argument.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:6
verses.text: As Corinth is now the first city of Greece, so of old it prided itself on many temporal advantages, and more than all the rest, on excess of wealth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:7
verses.text: And on this account one of the heathen writers entitled the place "the rich".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:8
verses.text: For it lies on the isthmus of the Peloponnesus, and had great facilities for traffic.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:9
verses.text: The city was also full of numerous orators, and philosophers, and one, I think, of the seven called wise men, was of this city.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:10
verses.text: Now these things we have mentioned, not for ostentation's sake, nor to make, a display of great learning: (for indeed what is there in knowing these things?) but they are of use to us in the argument of the Epistle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:11
verses.text: Paul also himself suffered many things in this city; and Christ, too, in this city appears to him and says, (Acts xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:12
verses.text: ), "Be not silent, but speak; for I have much people in this city:" and he remained there two years.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:13
verses.text: In this city Acts xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:14
verses.text: Corinth put here, by lapse of memory, for Ephesus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:15
verses.text: also the devil went out, whom the Jews endeavoring to exorcise, suffered so grievously.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:16
verses.text: In this city did those of the magicians, who repented, collect together their books and burn them, and there appeared to be fifty thousand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:17
verses.text: (Acts xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:18
verses.text: ἀργυρίου omitted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:19
verses.text: ) In this city also, in the time of Gallio the Proconsul, Paul was beaten before the judgment seat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:20
verses.text: The devil, therefore, seeing that a great and populous city had laid hold of the truth, a city admired for wealth and wisdom, and the head of Greece; (for Athens and Lacedaemon were then and since in a miserable state, the dominion having long ago fallen away from them;) and seeing that with great readiness they had received the word of God; what doth he? He divides the men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:21
verses.text: For he knew that even the strongest kingdom of all, divided against itself, shall not stand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:22
verses.text: He had a vantage ground too, for this device in the wealth, the wisdom of the inhabitants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:23
verses.text: Hence certain men, having made parties of their own, and having become self-elected made themselves leaders of the people, and some sided with these, and some with those; with one sort, as being rich; with another, as wise and able to teach something out of the common.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:24
verses.text: Who on their part, receiving them, set themselves up forsooth to teach more than the Apostle did: at which he was hinting, when he said, "I was not able to speak unto you as unto spiritual" (ch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:25
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:26
verses.text: ); evidently not his inability, but their infirmity, was the cause of their not having been abundantly instructed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:27
verses.text: And this, (ch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:28
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:29
verses.text: ) "Ye are become rich without us," is the remark of one pointing that way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:30
verses.text: And this was no small matter, but of all things most pernicious; that the Church should be torn asunder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:31
verses.text: And another sin, too, besides these, was openly committed there: namely, a person who had had intercourse with his step-mother not only escaped rebuke, but was even a leader of the multitude, and gave occasion to his followers to be conceited.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:32
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, (ch) "And ye are puffed up, and have not rather mourned".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:33
verses.text: And after this again, certain of those who as they pretended were of the more perfect sort, and who for gluttony's sake used to eat of things offered unto idols, and sit at meat in the temples, were bringing all to ruin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:34
verses.text: Others again, having contentions and strifes about money, committed unto the heathen courts (τοῖς ἔξωθεν σικαδτηρίοις) all matters of that kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:35
verses.text: Many persons also wearing long hair used to go about among them; whom he ordereth to be shorn.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:36
verses.text: There was another fault besides, no trifling one; their eating in the churches apart by themselves, and giving no share to the needy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:37
verses.text: And again, they were erring in another point, being puffed up with the gifts; and hence jealous of one another; which was also the chief cause of the distraction of the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:38
verses.text: The doctrine of the Resurrection, too, was lame (ἐχώλευε) among them: for some of them had no strong belief that there is any resurrection of bodies, having still on them the disease of Grecian foolishness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:39
verses.text: For indeed all these things were the progeny of the madness which belongs to Heathen Philosophy, and she was the mother of all mischief.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:40
verses.text: Hence, likewise, they had become divided; in this respect also having learned of the philosophers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:41
verses.text: For these latter were no less at mutual variance, always, through love of rule and vain glory contradicting one another's opinions, and bent upon making some new discovery in addition to all that was before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:42
verses.text: And the cause of this was, their having begun to trust themselves to reasonings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:43
verses.text: They had written accordingly to him by the hand of Fortunatus and Stephanas and Achaicus, by whom also he himself writes; and this he has indicated in the end of the Epistle: not however upon all these subjects, but about marriage and virginity; wherefore also he said, (ch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:44
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:45
verses.text: ) "Now concerning the things whereof ye wrote" &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:46
verses.text: And he proceeds to give injunctions, both on the points about which they had written, and those about which they had not written; having learnt with accuracy all their failings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:47
verses.text: Timothy, too, he sends with the letters, knowing that letters indeed have great force, yet that not a little would be added to them by the presence of the disciple also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:48
verses.text: Now whereas those who had divided the Church among themselves, from a feeling of shame lest they should seem to have done so for ambition's sake, contrived cloaks for what had happened, their teaching (forsooth) more perfect doctrines, and being wiser than all others; Paul sets himself first against the disease itself, plucking up the root of the evils, and its offshoot, the spirit of separation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:49
verses.text: And he uses great boldness of speech: for these were his own disciples, more than all others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:50
verses.text: Wherefore he saith (ch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:51
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:52
verses.text: ) "If to others I be not an Apostle, yet at least I am unto you; for the seal of my apostleship are ye".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:53
verses.text: Moreover they were in a weaker condition (to say the least of it) than the others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:54
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, (ch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:55
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:57
verses.text: οὐδὲ for οὔτε).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:58
verses.text: "For I have not spoken unto you as unto spiritual; for hitherto ye were not able, neither yet even now are ye able".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:59
verses.text: (This he saith, that they might not suppose that he speaks thus in regard of the time past alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:60
verses.text: )  However, it was utterly improbable that all should have been corrupted; rather there were some among them who were very holy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:61
verses.text: And this he signified in the middle of the Epistle, where he says, (ch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:62
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:64
verses.text: ) "To me it is a very small thing that I should be judged of you:" and adds, "these things I have in a figure transferred unto myself and Apollos".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:65
verses.text: Since then from arrogance all these evils were springing, and from men's thinking that they knew something out of the common, this he purgeth away first of all, and in beginning saith,            Homily I.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:66
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:67
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:68
verses.text: –  Paul, called to be an Apostle of Jesus Christ, through the will of God, and Sosthenes our brother, unto the Church of God which is at Corinth, even them that are sanctified in Christ Jesus, called to be Saints, with all that call upon the name of our Lord Jesus Christ in every place, their Lord and ours: Grace unto you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:69
verses.text: See how immediately, from the very beginning, he casts down their pride, and dashes to the ground all their fond imagination, in that he speaks of himself as "called".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:70
verses.text: For what I have learnt, saith he, I discovered not myself, nor acquired by my own wisdom, but while I was persecuting and laying waste the Church I was called.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:71
verses.text: Now here of Him that calleth is everything: of him that is called, nothing, (so to speak,) but only to obey.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:72
verses.text: "Of Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:73
verses.text: Your teacher is Christ; and do you register the names of men, as patrons of your doctrine?  "Through the will of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:74
verses.text: For it was God who willed that you should be saved in this way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:75
verses.text: We ourselves have wrought no good thing, but by the will of God we have attained to this salvation; and because it seemed good to him, we were called, not because we were worthy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:76
verses.text: "And Sosthenes our brother".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:77
verses.text: Another instance of his modesty; he puts in the same rank with himself one inferior to Apollos; for great was the interval between Paul and Sosthenes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:78
verses.text: Now if where the interval was so wide he stations with himself one far beneath him, what can they have to say who despise their equals?  "Unto the Church of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:79
verses.text: Not "of this or of that man," but of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:80
verses.text: "Which is at Corinth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:81
verses.text: Seest thou how at each word he puts down their swelling pride; training their thoughts in every way for heaven? He calls it, too, the Church "of God;" shewing that it ought to be united.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:82
verses.text: For if it be "of God," it is united, and it is one, not in Corinth only, but also in all the world: for the Church's name (ἐκκλησία: properly an assembly) is not a name of separation, but of unity and concord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:83
verses.text: "To the sanctified in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:84
verses.text: Again the name of Jesus; the names of men he findeth no place for.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:85
verses.text: But what is Sanctification? The Laver, the Purification.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:86
verses.text: For he reminds them of their own uncleanness, from which he had freed them; and so persuades them to lowliness of mind; for not by their own good deeds, but by the loving-kindness of God, had they been sanctified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:87
verses.text: "Called to be Saints".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:88
verses.text: For even this, to be saved by faith, is not saith he, of yourselves; for ye did not first draw near, but were called; so that not even this small matter is yours altogether.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:89
verses.text: However, though you had drawn near, accountable as you are for innumerable wickednesses, not even so would the grace be yours, but God's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:90
verses.text: Hence also, writing to the Ephesians, he said, (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:91
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:92
verses.text: ) "By grace have ye been saved through faith, and this not of yourselves;" not even the faith is yours altogether; for ye were not first with your belief, but obeyed a call.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:93
verses.text: "With all who call upon the Name of our Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:94
verses.text: Not "of this or that man," but "the Name of the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:95
verses.text: "In every place, both theirs and ours".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:96
verses.text: For although the letter be written to the Corinthians only, yet he makes mention of all the faithful that are in all the earth; showing that the Church throughout the world must be one, however separate in divers places; and much more, that in Corinth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:97
verses.text: And though the place separate, the Lord binds them together, being common to all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:98
verses.text: Wherefore also uniting them he adds, "both theirs and ours".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:99
verses.text: And this is far more powerful to unite, than the other to separate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:100
verses.text: For as men in one place, having many and contrary masters, become distracted, and their one place helps them not to be of one mind, their masters giving orders at variance with each other, and drawing each their own way, according to what Christ says, (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:101
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:102
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:103
verses.text: ) "Ye cannot serve God and Mammon;" so those in different places, if they have not different lords but one only, are not by the places injured in respect of unanimity, the One Lord binding them together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:104
verses.text: "I say not then, (so he speaks,) that with Corinthians only, you being Corinthians ought to be of one mind, but with all that are in the whole world, inasmuch as you have a common Master".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:105
verses.text: This is also why he hath a second time added "our;" for since he had said, "the Name of Jesus Christ our Lord," lest he should appear to the inconsiderate to be making a distinction, he subjoins again, "both our Lord and theirs".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:106
verses.text: That my meaning may be clearer, I will read it according to its sense thus: "Paul and Sosthenes to the Church of God which is in Corinth and to all who call upon the Name of Him who is both our Lord and theirs in every place, whether in Rome or wheresoever else they may be: grace unto you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:107
verses.text: Or again thus; which I also believe to be rather more correct: "Paul and Sosthenes to those that are at Corinth, who have been sanctified, called to be Saints, together with all who call upon the Name of our Lord Jesus Christ in place, both theirs and ours;" that is to say, "grace unto you, and peace unto you, who are at Corinth, who have been sanctified and called;" not to you alone, but "with all who in every place call upon the Name of Jesus Christ, our Lord and theirs".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:108
verses.text: Now if our peace be of grace, why hast thou high thoughts? Why art Thou so puffed up, being saved by grace? And if thou hast peace with God, why wish to assign thyself to others? since this is what separation comes to.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:109
verses.text: For what if you be at "peace" with this man, and with the other even find "grace?" My prayer is that both these may be yours from God; both from Him I say, and towards Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:110
verses.text: For neither do they abide (μένει, Savile in marg.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:111
verses.text: ) secure except they enjoy the influence from above; nor unless God be their object will they aught avail you: for it profiteth us nothing, though we be peaceful towards all men, if we be at war with God; even as it is no harm to us, although by all men we are held as enemies, if with God we are at peace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:112
verses.text: And again it is no gain to us, if all men approve, and the Lord be offended; neither is there any danger, though all shun and hate us, if with God we have acceptance and love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:113
verses.text: For that which is verily grace, and verily peace, cometh of God, since he who finds grace in God's sight, though he suffer ten thousand horrors, feareth no one; I say not only, no man, but not even the devil himself; but he that hath offended God suspects all men, though he seem to be in security.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:114
verses.text: For human nature is unstable, and not friends only and brethren, but fathers also, before now, have been altogether changed and often for a little thing he whom they begat, the branch of their planting, hath been to them, more than all foes, an object of persecution.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:115
verses.text: Children, too, have cast off their fathers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:116
verses.text: Thus, if ye will mark it, David was in favor with God, Absalom was in favor with men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:117
verses.text: What was the end of each, and which of them gained most honor, ye know.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:118
verses.text: Abraham was in favor with God, Pharaoh with men; for to gratify him they gave up the just man's wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:119
verses.text: (See St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:120
verses.text: Chrys.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:121
verses.text: on Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:122
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:123
verses.text: ) Which then of the two was the more illustrious, and the happy man? every one knows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:124
verses.text: And why speak I of righteous men; The Israelites were in favor with God, but they were hated by men, the Egyptians; but nevertheless they prevailed against their haters and vanquished them, with how great triumph, is well known to you all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:125
verses.text: For this, therefore, let all of us labor earnestly; whether one be a slave, let him pray for this, that he may find grace with God rather than with his master; or a wife, let her seek grace from God her Saviour rather than from her husband; or a soldier, in preference to his king and commander let him seek that favor which cometh from above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:126
verses.text: For thus among men also wilt thou be an object of love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:127
verses.text: But how shall a man find grace with God? How else, except by lowliness of mind? "For God, "saith one, (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:128
verses.text: Jas.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:129
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:130
verses.text: ) "resisteth the proud, but giveth grace unto the humble; and, (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:131
verses.text: li.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:132
verses.text: τεταπεινωμένην.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:133
verses.text: ) the sacrifice of God is a broken spirit, and a heart that is brought low God will not despise".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:134
verses.text: For if with men humility is so lovely, much more with God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:135
verses.text: Thus both they of the Gentiles found grace and the Jews no other way fell from grace; (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:136
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:137
verses.text: ) "for they were not subject unto the righteousness of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:138
verses.text: The lowly man of whom I am speaking, is pleasing and delightful to all men, and dwells in continual peace, and hath in him no ground for contentions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:139
verses.text: For though you insult him, though you abuse him, whatsoever you say, he will be silent and will bear it meekly, and will have so great peace towards all men as one cannot even describe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:140
verses.text: Yea, and with God also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:141
verses.text: For the commandments of God are to be at peace with men: and thus our whole life is made prosperous, through peace one with another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:142
verses.text: For no man can injure God: His nature is imperishable, and above all suffering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:143
verses.text: Nothing makes the Christian so admirable as lowliness of mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:144
verses.text: Hear, for instance, Abraham saying, (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:145
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:146
verses.text: ) "But I am but dust and ashes;" and again, God saying of Moses, that (Numb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:147
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:148
verses.text: ) "he was the meekest of all men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:149
verses.text: For nothing was ever more humble than he; who, being leader of so great a people, and having overwhelmed in the sea the king and the host of all the Egyptians, as if they had been flies; and having wrought so many wonders both in Egypt and by the Red Sea and in the wilderness, and received such high testimony, yet felt exactly as if he had been an ordinary person, and as a son-in-law was humbler than his father-in-law, (Exodus xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:150
verses.text: ) and took advice from him, and was not indignant, nor did he say, "What is this? After such and so great achievements, art thou come to us with thy counsel?" This is what most people feel; though a man bring the best advice, despising it, because of the lowliness of the person.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:151
verses.text: But not so did he: rather through lowliness of mind he wrought all things well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:152
verses.text: Hence also he despised the courts of kings, (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:153
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:155
verses.text: ) since he was lowly indeed: for the sound mind and the high spirit are the fruit of humility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:156
verses.text: For of how great nobleness and magnanimity, thinkest thou, was it a token, to despise the kingly palace and table? since kings among the Egyptians are honored as gods, and enjoy wealth and treasures inexhaustible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:157
verses.text: But nevertheless, letting go all these and throwing away the very sceptres of Egypt, he hastened to join himself unto captives, and men worn down with toil, whose strength was spent in the clay and the making of bricks, men whom his own slaves abhorred, (for, saith he (ἐβδελύσσοντο, Sept.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:158
verses.text: Ex.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:159
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:160
verses.text: ) "The Egyptians abhorred them;") unto these he ran and preferred them before their masters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:161
verses.text: From whence it is plain, that whoso is lowly, the same is high and great of soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:162
verses.text: For pride cometh from an ordinary mind and an ignoble spirit, but moderation, from greatness of mind and a lofty soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:163
verses.text: And if you please, let us try each by examples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:164
verses.text: For tell me, what was there ever more exalted than Abraham? And yet it was he that said, "I am but dust and ashes;" it was he who said, (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:165
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:166
verses.text: ) "Let there be no strife between me and thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:167
verses.text: But this man, so humble, (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:168
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:170
verses.text: ) despised ("Persian," i-e: perhaps, "of Elam".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:171
verses.text: ) Persian spoils, and regarded not Barbaric trophies; and this he did of much highmindedness, and of a spirit nobly nurtured.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:172
verses.text: For he is indeed exalted who is truly humble; (not the flatterer nor the dissembler;) for true greatness is one thing, and arrogance another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:173
verses.text: And this is plain from hence; if one man esteem clay to be clay, and despise it, and another admire the clay as gold, and account it a great thing; which, I ask, is the man of exalted mind? Is it not he who refuses to admire the clay? And which, abject and mean? Is it not he who admires it, and set much store by it? Just so do thou esteem of this case also; that he who calls himself but dust and ashes is exalted, although he say it out of humility; but that he who does not consider himself dust and ashes, but treats himself lovingly and has high thoughts, this man for his part must be counted mean, esteeming little things to be great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:174
verses.text: Whence it is clear that out of great loftiness of thought the patriarch spoke that saying, "I am but dust and ashes;" from loftiness of thought, not from arrogance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:175
verses.text: For as in bodies it is one thing to be healthy and plump, (σφριγῶντα, firm and elastic.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:176
verses.text: ) and another thing to be swoln, although both indicate a full habit of flesh, (but in this case of unsound, in that of healthful flesh;) so also here: it is one thing to be arrogant, which is, as it were, to be swoln, and another thing to be high-souled, which is to be in a healthy state.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:177
verses.text: And again, one man is tall from the stature of his person; another, being short, by adding buskins becomes taller; now tell me, which of the two should we call tall and large? Is it not quite plain, him whose height is from himself? For the other has it as something not his own; and stepping upon things low in themselves, turns out a tall person.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:178
verses.text: Such is the case with many men who mount themselves up on wealth and glory; which is not exaltation, for he is exalted who wants none of these things, but despises them, and has his greatness from himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:179
verses.text: Let us therefore become humble that we may become exalted; (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:180
verses.text: Luke xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:181
verses.text: ) "For he that humbleth himself shall be exalted".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:182
verses.text: Now the self-willed man is not such as this; rather he is of all characters the most ordinary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:183
verses.text: For the bubble, too, is inflated, but the inflation is not sound; wherefore we call these persons "puffed up".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:184
verses.text: Whereas the sober-minded man has no high thoughts, not even in high fortunes, knowing his own low estate; but the vulgar even in his trifling concerns indulges a proud fancy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:185
verses.text: Let us then acquire that height which comes by humility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:186
verses.text: Let us look into the nature of human things, that we may kindle with the longing desire of the things to come; for in no other way is it possible to become humble, except by the love of what is divine and the contempt of what is present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:187
verses.text: For just as a man on the point of obtaining a kingdom, if instead of that purple robe one offer him some trivial compliment, will count it to be nothing; so shall we also laugh to scorn all things present, if we desire that other sort of honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:188
verses.text: Do ye not see the children, when in their play they make a band of soldiers, and heralds precede them and lictors, and a boy marches in the midst in the general's place, how childish it all is? Just such are all human affairs; yea and more worthless than these: to-day they are, and to-morrow they are not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:189
verses.text: Let us therefore be above these things; and let us not only not desire them, but even be ashamed if any one hold them forth to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:190
verses.text: For thus, casting out the love of these things, we shall possess that other love which is divine, and shall enjoy immortal glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 1:191
verses.text: Which may God grant us all to obtain, through the grace and loving-kindness of our Lord Jesus Christ; with whom be to the Father, together with the holy and good Spirit, the glory and the power for ever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:1
verses.text: Homily II.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:3
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:4
verses.text: ,  I thank my God always concerning you, for the Grace of God which was given you in Jesus Christ; that in every thing you were enriched in him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:5
verses.text: That which he exhorts others to do, saying, "(Phil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:6
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:7
verses.text: ) Let your requests with thanksgiving be made known unto God," the same also he used to do himself: teaching us to begin always from these words, and before all things to give thanks unto God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:8
verses.text: For nothing is so acceptable to God as that men should be thankful, both for themselves and for others: wherefore also he prefaces almost every Epistle with this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:9
verses.text: But the occasion for his doing so is even more urgent here than in the other Epistles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:10
verses.text: For he that gives thanks, does so, both as being well off, and as in acknowledgment of a favor: now a favor is not a debt nor a requital nor a payment: which indeed every where is important to be said, but much more in the case of the Corinthians who were gaping after the dividers of the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:11
verses.text: "Unto my God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:12
verses.text: Out of great affection he seizes on that which is common, and makes it his own; as the prophets also from time to time use to say, (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:13
verses.text: xliii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:14
verses.text: ; lxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:15
verses.text: ) "O God, my God;" and by way of encouragement he incites them to use the same language also themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:16
verses.text: For such expressions belong to one who is retiring from all secular things, and moving towards Him whom he calls on with so much earnestness: since he alone can truly say this, who from things of this life is ever mounting upwards unto God, and always preferring Him to all, and giving thanks continually, not only for the grace already given, but whatever blessing hath been since at any time bestowed, for this also he offereth unto Him the same praise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:17
verses.text: Wherefore he saith not merely, "I give thanks," but "at all times, concerning you;" instructing them to be thankful both always, and to no one else save God only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:18
verses.text: "For the grace of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:19
verses.text: Seest thou how from every quarter he draws topics for correcting them? For where "grace" is, "works" are not; where "works," it is no more "grace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:20
verses.text: If therefore it be "grace," why are ye high-minded? Whence is it that ye are puffed up?  "Which is given you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:21
verses.text: And by whom was it given? By me, or by another Apostle? Not at all, but "by Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:22
verses.text: For the expression, "In Jesus Christ," signifies this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:23
verses.text: Observe how in divers places he uses the word ἐν, "in," instead of δἰ οὗ, "through means of whom;" therefore its sense is no less.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:24
verses.text: "That in every thing ye were enriched".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:25
verses.text: Again, by whom? By Him, is the reply.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:26
verses.text: And not merely "ye were enriched," but "in every thing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:27
verses.text: Since then it is first of all, "riches" then, "riches of God," next, "in every thing," and lastly, "through the Only-Begotten," reflect on the ineffable treasure!  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:28
verses.text: "In all utterance, and all knowledge".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:29
verses.text: "Word" "or utterance," not such as the heathen, but that of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:30
verses.text: For there is knowledge without "word," and there is knowledge with "word".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:31
verses.text: For so there are many who possess knowledge, but have not the power of speech; as those who are uneducated and unable to exhibit clearly what they have in their mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:32
verses.text: Ye, saith he, are not such as these, but competent both to understand and to speak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:33
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:34
verses.text: "Even as the testimony of Christ was confirmed in you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:35
verses.text: Under the color of praises and thanksgiving he touches them sharply.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:36
verses.text: "For not by heathen philosophy," saith he, "neither by heathen discipline, but "the grace of God," and by the "riches," and the "knowledge," and the "word" given by Him, were you enabled to learn the doctrines of the truth, and to be confirmed unto the testimony of the Lord; that is, unto the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:37
verses.text: For ye had the benefit of many signs, many wonders, unspeakable grace, to make you receive the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:38
verses.text: If therefore ye were established by signs and grace, why do ye waver?" Now these are the words of one both reproving, and at the same time prepossessing them in his favor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:39
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:40
verses.text: "So that ye come behind in no gift".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:41
verses.text: A great question here arises.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:42
verses.text: They who had been "enriched in all utterance," so as in no respect to "come behind in any gift," are they carnal? For if they were such at the beginning, much more now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:43
verses.text: How then does he call them "carnal?" For, saith he, ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:44
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:45
verses.text: ) "I was not able to speak unto you as unto spiritual, but as unto carnal".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:46
verses.text: What must we say then? That having in the beginning believed, and obtained all gifts, (for indeed they sought them earnestly,) they became remiss afterwards.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:47
verses.text: Or, if not so, that not unto all are either these things said or those; but the one to such as were amenable to his censures, the other to such as were adorned with his praises.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:48
verses.text: For as to the fact that they still had gifts; ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:49
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:51
verses.text: ) "Each one," saith he, "hath a psalm, hath a revelation, hath a tongue, hath an interpretation; let all things be done unto edifying".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:52
verses.text: And, "Let the prophets speak two or three".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:53
verses.text: Or we may state it somewhat differently; that as it is usual with us to call the greater part the whole, so also he hath spoken in this place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:54
verses.text: Withal, I think he hints at his own proceedings; for he too had shewn forth signs; even as also he saith in the second Epistle to them, ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:55
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:57
verses.text: ) "Truly the signs of an Apostle were wrought among you in all patience:" and again, "For what is there wherein you were inferior to other churches?"  Or, as I was saying, he both reminds them of his own miracles and speaks thus with an eye to those who were still approved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:58
verses.text: For many holy men were there who had "set themselves to minister unto the saints," and had become "the first fruits of Achaia;" as he declareth (ch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:59
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:60
verses.text: ) towards the end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:61
verses.text: In any case, although the praises be not very close to the truth, still however they are inserted by way of precaution, (οἰκονομικῶς) preparing the way beforehand for his discourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:62
verses.text: For whoever at the very outset speaks things unpleasant, excludes his words from a hearing among the weaker: since if the hearers be his equals in degree they feel angry; if vastly inferior they will be vexed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:63
verses.text: To avoid this, he begins with what seem to be praises.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:64
verses.text: I say, seem; for not even did this praise belong to them, but to the grace of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:65
verses.text: For that they had remission of sins, and were justified, this was of the Gift from above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:66
verses.text: Wherefore also he dwells upon these points, which shew the loving-kindness of God, in order that he may the more fully purge out their malady.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:67
verses.text: "Waiting for the revelation (ἀποκάλυψιν.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:68
verses.text: ) of our Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:69
verses.text: "Why make ye much ado," saith he, "why are ye troubled that Christ is not come? Nay, he is come; and the Day is henceforth at the doors".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:70
verses.text: And consider his wisdom; how withdrawing them from human considerations he terrifies them by mention of the fearful judgment-seat, and thus implying that not only the beginnings must be good, but the end also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:71
verses.text: For with all these gifts, and with all else that is good, we must be mindful of that Day: and there is need of many labors to be able to come unto the end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:72
verses.text: "Revelation" is his word; implying that although He be not seen, yet He is, and is present even now, and then shall appear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:73
verses.text: Therefore there is need of patience: for to this end did ye receive the wonders, that ye may remain firm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:74
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:75
verses.text: "Who shall also confirm you unto the end, that ye may be unreprovable".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:76
verses.text: Here he seems to court them, but the saying is free from all flattery; for he knows also how to press them home; as when he saith, ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:77
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:79
verses.text: ) "Now some are puffed up as though I would not come to you:" and again, "What will ye? shall I come unto you with a rod, or in love, and in the spirit of meekness?" And, ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:80
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:81
verses.text: ) "Since ye seek a proof of Christ speaking in me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:82
verses.text: But he is also covertly accusing them: for, to say, "He shall confirm," and the word "unreprovable" marks them out as still wavering, and liable to reproof.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:83
verses.text: But do thou consider how he always fasteneth them as with nails to the Name of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:84
verses.text: And not any man nor teacher, but continually the Desired One Himself is remembered by him: setting himself, as it were to arouse those who were heavy-headed after some debauch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:85
verses.text: For no where in any other Epistle doth the Name of Christ occur so continually.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:86
verses.text: But here it is, many times in a few verses; and by means of it he weaves together, one may say, the whole of the proem.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:87
verses.text: Look at it from the beginning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:88
verses.text: "Paul called to be an Apostle of Jesus Christ, to them that have been sanctified in Jesus Christ, who call upon the Name of our Lord Jesus Christ, grace be unto you and peace from God the Father, and the Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:89
verses.text: I thank my God for the grace which hath been given you by Jesus Christ, even as the testimony of Christ hath been confirmed in you, waiting for the revelation of our Lord Jesus Christ, who shall confirm you unreprovable in the day of our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:90
verses.text: God is faithful, by whom ye have been called into the fellowship of His Son Jesus Christ our Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:91
verses.text: And I beseech you by the Name of our Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:92
verses.text: Seest thou the constant repetition of the Name of Christ? From whence it is plain even to the most unobservant, that not by chance nor unwittingly he doeth this, but in order that by incessant application of that glorious Name he may foment their inflammation, and purge out the corruption of the disease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:93
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:94
verses.text: "God is faithful, by whom ye were called unto the fellowship of His Son".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:95
verses.text: Wonderful! How great a thing saith he here! How vast in the magnitude of the gift which he declares! Into the fellowship of the Only-Begotten have ye been called, and do ye addict yourselves unto men? What can be worse than this wretchedness? And how have ye been called? By the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:96
verses.text: For since "through Him," and "in Him," were phrases which he was constantly employing in regard of the Son, lest men might suppose that he so mentioneth Him as being less, he ascribeth the same to the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:97
verses.text: For not by this one and that one, saith he, but "by the Father" have ye been called; by Him also have ye been "enriched".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:98
verses.text: Again, "ye have been called;" ye did not yourselves approach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:99
verses.text: But what means, "into the fellowship of His Son?" Hear him declaring this very thing more clearly elsewhere.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:100
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:101
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:102
verses.text: ) If we suffer, we shall also reign with Him; if we die with Him, we shall also live with Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:103
verses.text: Then, because it was a great thing which He had said, he adds an argument fraught with unanswerable conviction; for, saith he, "God is faithful," i-e: "true".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:104
verses.text: Now if "true," what things He hath promised He will also perform.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:105
verses.text: And He hath promised that He will make us partakers of His only-begotten Son; for to this end also did He call us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:106
verses.text: For (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:107
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:108
verses.text: ) "His gifts, and the calling of God," are without repentance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:109
verses.text: These things, by a kind of divine art he inserts thus early, lest after the vehemence of the reproofs they might fall into despair.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:110
verses.text: For assuredly God's part will ensue, if we be not quite impatient of His rein.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:111
verses.text: (ἀφηνιάσωμεν) As the Jews, being called, would not receive the blessings; but this was no longer of Him that called, but of their lack of sense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:112
verses.text: For He indeed was willing to give, but they, by refusing to receive, cast themselves away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:113
verses.text: For, had He called to a painful and toilsome undertaking, not even in that case were they pardonable in making excuse; however, they would have been able to say that so it was: but if the call be unto cleansing, (Comp.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:114
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:116
verses.text: ) and righteousness, and sanctification, and redemption, and grace, and a free gift, and the good things in store, which eye hath not seen, nor ear heard; and it be God that calls, and calls by Himself; what pardon can they deserve, who come not running to Him? Let no one therefore accuse God; for unbelief cometh not of Him that calleth, but of those who start away (ἀποπηδῶντας) from Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:117
verses.text: But some man will say, "He ought to bring men in, even against their will".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:118
verses.text: Away with this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:119
verses.text: He doth not use violence, nor compel; for who that bids to honors, and crowns, and banquets, and festivals, drags people, unwilling and bound? No one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:120
verses.text: For this is the part of one inflicting an insult.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:121
verses.text: Unto hell He sends men against their will, but unto the kingdom He calls willing minds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:122
verses.text: To the fire He brings men bound and bewailing themselves: to the endless state of blessings not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:123
verses.text: Else it is a reproach to the very blessings themselves, if their nature be not such as that men should run to them of their own accord and with many thanks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:124
verses.text: "Whence it is then," say you, "that all men do not choose them?" From their own infirmity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:125
verses.text: "And wherefore doth He not cut off their infirmity?" And how tell me—in what way—ought He to cut it off? Hath He not made a world that teacheth His loving-kindness and His power? For (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:126
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:127
verses.text: ) "the heavens," saith one, "declare the glory of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:128
verses.text: Hath He not also sent prophets? Hath He not both called and honored us? Hath He not done wonders? Hath He not given a law both written and natural? Hath He not sent His Son? Hath he not commissioned Apostles? Hath He not wrought sins? Hath He not threatened hell? Hath He not promised the kingdom? Doth He not every day make His sun to rise? Are not the things which He hath enjoined so simple and easy, that many transcend His commandments in the greatness of their self-denial? "What was there to do unto the vineyard and I have not done it?" (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:129
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:130
verses.text: )   "And why," say you, "did He not make knowledge and virtue natural to us?" Who speaketh thus? The Greek or the Christian? Both of them, indeed, but not about the same things: for the one raises his objection with a view to knowledge, the other with a view to conduct.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:131
verses.text: First, then, we will reply to him who is on our side; for I do not so much regard those without, as our own members.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:132
verses.text: What then saith the Christian? "It were meet to have implanted in us the knowledge itself of virtue".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:133
verses.text: He hath implanted it; for if he had not done so, whence should we have known what things are to be done, what left undone? Whence are the laws and the tribunals? But "God should have imparted not merely knowledge, but also the very doing of it virtue".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:134
verses.text: For what then wouldest thou have to be rewarded, if the whole were of God? For tell me, doth God punish in the same manner thee and the Greek upon committing sin? Surely not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:135
verses.text: For up to a certain point thou hast confidence, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:136
verses.text: that which ariseth from the true knowledge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:137
verses.text: What then, if any one should now say that on the score of knowledge thou and the Greek will be accounted of like desert? Would it not disgust thee? I think so, indeed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:138
verses.text: For thou wouldest say that the Greek, having of his own wherewith to attain knowledge, was not willing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:139
verses.text: If then the latter also should say that God ought to have implanted knowledge in us naturally, wilt thou not laugh him to scorn, and say to him, "But why didst thou not seek for it? why wast thou not in earnest even as I?" And thou wilt stand firm with much confidence, and say that it was extreme folly to blame God for not implanting knowledge by nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:140
verses.text: And this thou wilt say, because thou hast obtained what appertains to knowledge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:141
verses.text: So also hadst thou performed what appertains to practice, thou wouldest not have raised these questions: but thou art tired of virtuous practice, therefore thou shelterest thyself with these inconsiderate words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:142
verses.text: But how could it be at all right to cause that by necessity one should become good? Then shall we next have the brute beasts contending with us about virtue, seeing that some of them are more temperate than ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:143
verses.text: But thou sayest, "I had rather have been good by necessity, and so forfeited all rewards, than evil by deliberate choice, to be punished and suffer vengeance".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:144
verses.text: But it is impossible that one should ever be good by necessity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:145
verses.text: If therefore thou knowest not what ought to be done, shew it, and then we will tell you what is right to say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:146
verses.text: But if thou knowest that uncleanness is wicked, wherefore dost thou not fly from the evil thing?  "I cannot," thou sayest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:147
verses.text: But others who have done greater things than this will plead against thee, and will more than prevail to stop thy mouth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:148
verses.text: For thou, perhaps, though living with a wife, art not chaste; but another even without a wife keeps his chastity inviolate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:149
verses.text: Now what excuse hast thou for not keeping the rule, while another even leaps beyond the lines that have been drawn to mark it?  But thou sayest "I am not of this sort in my bodily frame, or my turn of mind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:150
verses.text: That is for want, not of power, but of will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:151
verses.text: For thus I prove that all have a certain aptness towards virtue: That which a man cannot do, neither will he be able to do though necessity be laid upon him; but, if, necessity being laid upon him, he is able, he that leaveth it undone, leaveth it undone out of choice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:152
verses.text: The kind of thing I mean is this: to fly up and be borne towards heaven, having a heavy body, is even simply impossible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:153
verses.text: What then, if a king should command one to do this, and threaten death, saying, "Those men who do not fly, I decree that they lose their heads, or be burnt, or some other such punishment:" would any one obey him? Surely not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:154
verses.text: For nature is not capable of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:155
verses.text: But if in the case of chastity this same thing were done, and he were to lay down laws that the unclean should be punished, be burnt, be scourged, should suffer the extremity of torture, would not many obey the law? "No" thou wilt say: "for there is appointed, even now, a law forbidding to commit adultery and all do not obey it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:156
verses.text: Not because the fear looses its power, but because the greater part expect to be unobserved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:157
verses.text: So that if when they were on the point of committing an unclean action the legislator and the judge came before them, the fear would be strong enough to cast out the lust.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:158
verses.text: Nay, were I to apply another kind of force inferior to this; were I to take the man and remove him from the beloved person, and shut him up close in chains, he will be able to bear it, without suffering any great harm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:159
verses.text: Let us not say then that such an one is by nature evil: for if a man were by nature good, he could never at any time become evil; and if he were by nature evil, he could never be good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:160
verses.text: But now we see that changes take place rapidly, and that men quickly shift from this side to the other, and from that fall back again into this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:161
verses.text: And these things we may see not in the Scriptures only, for instance, that publicans have become apostles; and disciples, traitors; and harlots, chaste; and robbers, men of good repute; and magicians have worshipped; and ungodly men passed over unto godliness, both in the New Testament and in the Old; but even every day a man may see many such things occurring.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:162
verses.text: Now if things were natural, they could not change.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:163
verses.text: For so we, being by nature susceptible, could never by any exertions become void of feeling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:164
verses.text: For that which is whatever it is by nature, can never fall away from such its natural condition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:165
verses.text: No one, for example, ever changed from sleeping to not sleeping: no one from a state of corruption unto incorruption: no one from hunger to the perpetual absence of that sensation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:166
verses.text: Wherefore neither are these things matters of accusation, nor do we reproach ourselves for them; nor ever did any one, meaning to blame another, say to him, "O thou, corruptible and subject to passion:" but either adultery or fornication, or something of that kind, we always lay to the charge of those who are responsible; and we bring them before judges, who blame and punish, and in the contrary cases award honors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:167
verses.text: Since then both from our conduct towards one another, and from others' conduct to us when judged, and from the things about which we have written laws, and from the things wherein we condemn ourselves, though there be no one to accuse us; and from the instances of our becoming worse through indolence, and better through fear; and from the cases wherein we see others doing well and arriving at the height of self-command, (φιλοσοφίας) it is quite clear that we also have it in our power to do well: why do we, the most part, deceive ourselves in vain with heartless pretexts and excuses, bringing not only no pardon, but even punishment intolerable? When we ought to keep before our eyes that fearful day, and to give heed to virtue; and after a little labor, obtain the incorruptible crowns? For these words will be no defence to us; rather our fellow-servants, and those who have practised the contrary virtues, will condemn all who continue in sin: the cruel man will be condemned by the merciful; the evil, by the good; the fierce, by the gentle; the grudging, by the courteous; the vain-glorious, by the self-denying; the indolent, by the serious; the intemperate, by the sober-minded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:168
verses.text: Thus will God pass judgment upon us, and will set in their place both companies; on one bestowing praise, on the other punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:169
verses.text: But God forbid that any of those present should be among the punished and dishonored, but rather among those who are crowned and the winners of the kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 2:170
verses.text: Which may God grant us all to obtain through the grace and loving-kindness of our Lord Jesus Christ; with Whom unto the Father and the Holy Ghost be glory, power, honor, now and ever, and unto everlasting ages, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:1
verses.text: Homily III.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:3
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:4
verses.text: Now I beseech you, brethren, through the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that ye all speak of the same thing, and that there be no divisions among you; but that ye be perfected together in the same mind and in the same judgment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:5
verses.text: What I have continually been saying, that we must frame our rebukes gently and gradually, this Paul doth here also; in that, being about to enter upon a subject full of many dangers and enough to tear up the Church from her foundations he uses very mild language.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:6
verses.text: His word is that he "beseeches" them, and beseeches them "through Christ;" as though not even he were sufficient alone to make this supplication, and to prevail.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:7
verses.text: But what is this, "I beseech you through Christ?" "I take Christ to fight on my side, and to aid me, His injured and insulted Name".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:8
verses.text: An awful way of speaking indeed! lest they should prove hard and shameless: for sin makes men restless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:9
verses.text: Wherefore if at once (ἄν μὲν εὐθέως ἐπιπλήξης Savil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:10
verses.text: ἄν μὴ Ben.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:11
verses.text: ) you sharply rebuke you make a man fierce and impudent: but if you put him to shame, you bow down his neck, you check his confidence, you make him hang down his head.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:12
verses.text: Which object being Paul's also, he is content for a while to beseech them through the Name of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:13
verses.text: And what, of all things, is the object of his request?  "That ye may all speak the same thing, and that there be no divisions schisms among you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:14
verses.text: The emphatic force of the word "schism," I mean the name itself, was a sufficient accusation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:15
verses.text: For it was not that they had become many parts, each entire within itself, but rather the One Body which originally existed had perished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:16
verses.text: For had they been entire Churches, there might be many of them; but if they were divisions, then that first One was gone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:17
verses.text: For that which is entire within itself not only does not become many by division into many parts, but even the original One is lost.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:18
verses.text: Such is the nature of divisions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:19
verses.text: In the next place, because he had sharply dealt with them by using the word "schism," he again softens and soothes them, saying, "That ye may be perfectly joined together in the same mind and in the same judgment".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:20
verses.text: That is; since he had said, "That ye may all speak the same thing;" "do not suppose," he adds, "that I said concord should be only in words; I seek for that harmony which is of the mind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:21
verses.text: But since there is such a thing as agreement in words, and that hearty, not however on all subjects, therefore he added this, "That ye may be perfected together".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:22
verses.text: For he that is united in one thing, but in another dissents, is no longer "perfected," nor fitted in to complete accordance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:23
verses.text: There is also such a thing as harmony of opinions, where there is not yet harmony of sentiment; for instance, when having the same faith we are not joined together in love: for thus, in opinions we are one, (for we think the same things,) but in sentiment not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:24
verses.text: And such was the case at that time; this person choosing one leader, and that, another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:25
verses.text: For this reason he saith it is necessary to agree both in "mind" and in "judgment".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:26
verses.text: For it was not from any difference in faith that the schisms arose, but from the division of their judgment through human contentiousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:27
verses.text: But seeing that whoso is blamed is unabashed so long as he hath no witnesses, observe how, not permitting them to deny the fact, he adduces some to bear witness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:28
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:29
verses.text: "For it hath been signified unto me concerning you, my brethren, by them which are of the household of Chloe".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:30
verses.text: Neither did he say this at the very beginning, but first he brought forward his charge; as one who put confidence in his informants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:31
verses.text: Because, had it not been so, he would not have found fault: for Paul was not a person to believe lightly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:32
verses.text: Neither then did he immediately say, "it hath been signified," lest he might seem to blame on their authority: neither does he omit all mention of them, lest he should seem to speak only from himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:33
verses.text: And again, he styles them "brethren;" for although the fault be plain, there is nothing against calling people brethren still.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:34
verses.text: Consider also his prudence in not speaking of any distinct person, but of the entire family; so as not to make them hostile towards the informer: for in this way he both protects him, and fearlessly opens the accusation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:35
verses.text: For he had an eye to the benefit not of the one side only, but of the other also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:36
verses.text: Wherefore he saith not, "It hath been declared to me by certain," but he indicates also the household, lest they might suppose that he was inventing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:37
verses.text: What was "declared? "That there are contentions among you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:38
verses.text: Thus, when he is rebuking them, he saith, "That there be no divisions among you;" but when he is reporting the statements of others, he doth it more gently; saying, "For it hath been declared unto me…that there are contentions among you; in order that he might not bring trouble upon the informants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:39
verses.text: Next he declares also the kind of contention.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:40
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:41
verses.text: "That each one of you saith, I am of Paul, and I of Apollos, and I of Cephas".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:42
verses.text: "I say, contentions," saith he, "I mean, not about private matters, but of the more grievous sort".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:43
verses.text: "That each one of you saith;" for the corruption pervaded not a part, but the whole of the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:44
verses.text: And yet they were not speaking about himself, nor about Peter, nor about Apollos; but he signifies that if these were not to be leaned on, much less others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:45
verses.text: For that they had not spoken about them, he saith further on: "And these things I have transferred in a figure unto myself and Apollos, that ye may learn in us not to go beyond the things which are written".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:46
verses.text: For if it were not right for them to call themselves by the name of Paul, and of Apollos, and of Cephas, much less of any others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:47
verses.text: If under the Teacher and the first of the Apostles, and one that had instructed so much people, it were not right to enroll themselves, much less under those who were nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:48
verses.text: By way of hyperbole then, seeking to withdraw them from their disease, he sets down these names.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:49
verses.text: Besides, he makes his argument less severe, not mentioning by name the rude dividers of the Church, but concealing them, as behind a sort of masks, with the names of the Apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:50
verses.text: "I am of Paul, and I of Apollos, and I of Cephas".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:51
verses.text: Not esteeming himself before Peter hath he set his name last, but preferring Peter to himself, and that greatly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:52
verses.text: He arranged his statement in the way of climax, (κατὰ αῦξησιν) that he might not be supposed to do this for envy; or, from jealousy, to be detracting from the honor of others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:53
verses.text: Wherefore also he put his own name first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:54
verses.text: For he who puts himself foremost to be rejected, doth so not for love of honor, but for extreme contempt of this sort of reputation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:55
verses.text: He puts himself, you see, in the way of the whole attack, and then mentions Apollos, and then Cephas.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:56
verses.text: Not therefore to magnify himself did he do this, but in speaking of wrong things he administers the requisite correction in his own person first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:57
verses.text: But that those who addicted themselves to this or that man were in error, is evident.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:58
verses.text: And rightly he rebukes them, saying, "Ye do not well in that ye say, 'I am of Paul, and I of Apollos, and I of Cephas.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:59
verses.text: '" But why did he add, "And I of Christ?" For although these who addicted themselves to men were in error, not surely (οὔδε που Bened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:60
verses.text: οὐ δήπου Savil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:61
verses.text: ) those who dedicated themselves unto Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:62
verses.text: But this was not his charge, that they called themselves by the Name of Christ, but that they did not all call themselves by that Name alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:63
verses.text: And I think that he added this of himself, wishing to make the accusation more grievous, and to point out that by this rule Christ must be considered as belonging to one party only: although they were not so using the Name themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:64
verses.text: For that this was what he hinted at he declared in the sequel, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:65
