verses.text: "Is Christ divided".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:66
verses.text: What he saith comes to this: "Ye have cut in pieces Christ, and distributed His body".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:67
verses.text: Here is anger! here is chiding! here are words full of indignation! For whenever instead of arguing he interrogates only, his doing so implies a confessed absurdity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:68
verses.text: But some say that he glanced at something else, in saying, "Christ is divided:" as if he had said, "He hath distributed to men and parted the Church, and taken one share Himself, giving them the other".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:69
verses.text: Then in what follows, he labors to overthrow this absurdity, saying, "Was Paul crucified for you, or were ye baptized into the name of Paul?" Observe his Christ-loving mind; how thenceforth he brings the whole matter to a point in his own name, shewing, and more than shewing, that this honor belongs to no one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:70
verses.text: And that no one might think it was envy which moved him to say these things, therefore he is constantly putting himself forward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:71
verses.text: Observe, too, his considerate way, in that he saith not, "Did Paul make the world? did Paul from nothing produce you into being?" But only those things which belonged as choice treasures to the faithful, and were regarded with great solicitude—those he specifies, the Cross, and Baptism, and the blessings following on these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:72
verses.text: For the loving-kindness of God towards men is shewn by the creation of the world also: in nothing, however, so much as by the (τῆς συγκαταβάσεως) condescension through the Cross.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:73
verses.text: And he said not, "did Paul die for you?" but, "was Paul crucified?" setting down also the kind of death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:74
verses.text: "Or were ye baptized into the name of Paul?" Again, he saith not, "did Paul baptize you?" For he did baptize many: but this was not the question, by whom they had been baptized, but, into whose name they had been baptized! For since this also was a cause of schisms, their being called after the name of those who baptized them, he corrects this error likewise saying, "Were ye baptized into the name of Paul?" "Tell me not," saith he, "who baptized, but into whose name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:75
verses.text: For not he that baptizeth, but he who is invoked in the Baptism, is the subject of enquiry.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:76
verses.text: For this is He who forgives our sins".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:77
verses.text: And at this point he stays the discourse, and does not pursue the subject any further.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:78
verses.text: For he saith not, "Did Paul declare to you the good things to come? Did Paul promise you the kingdom of heaven?" Why, then, I ask, doth he not add these questions also? Because it is not all as one, to promise a kingdom and to be crucified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:79
verses.text: For the former neither had danger nor brought shame; but the latter, all these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:80
verses.text: Moreover, he proves the former from the latter: for having said, (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:81
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:82
verses.text: ) "He that spared not His own Son," he adds, "How shall He not with Him also freely give us all things?" And again, (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:83
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:84
verses.text: ) "For if when we were enemies we were reconciled unto God by the death of His Son, much more bring reconciled, we shall be saved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:85
verses.text: This was one reason for his not adding what I just mentioned: and also because the one they had not as yet, but of the other they had already made trial.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:86
verses.text: The one were in promise; the other had already come to pass.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:87
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:88
verses.text: "I thank God that I baptized none of you but Crispus and Gaius".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:89
verses.text: "Why are you elate at having baptized, when I for my part even give thanks that I have not done so!" Thus saying, by a kind of divine art (οἰκονομικῶς) he does away with their swelling pride upon this point; not with the efficacy of the baptism, (God forbid,) but with the folly of those who were puffed up at having been baptizers: first, by showing that the Gift is not theirs; and, secondly, by thanking God therefore.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:90
verses.text: For Baptism truly is a great thing: but its greatness is not the work of the person baptizing, but of Him who is invoked in the Baptism: since to baptize is nothing as regards man's labor, but is much less than preaching the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:91
verses.text: Yea, again I say, great indeed is Baptism, and without baptism it is impossible to obtain the kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:92
verses.text: Still a man of no singular excellence is able to baptize, but to preach the Gospel there is need of great labor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:93
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:94
verses.text: He states also the reason, why he giveth thanks that he had baptized no one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:95
verses.text: What then is this reason? "Lest anyone should say that ye were baptized into my own name".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:96
verses.text: Why, did he mean that they said this in those other cases? Not at all; but, "I fear," saith he, "lest the disease should proceed even to that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:97
verses.text: For if, when insignificant persons and of little worth baptize, a heresy ariseth, had I, the first announcer of Baptism, baptized many, it was likely that they forming a party, would not only call themselves by my name, but also ascribe the Baptism to me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:98
verses.text: For if from the inferiors so great an evil arose, from those of higher order it would perhaps have gone on to something far more grievous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:99
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:100
verses.text: Then, having abashed those who were unsound in this respect and subjoining, "I baptized also the house of Stephanas," he again drags down their pride, saying besides, "I know not whether I baptized any other".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:101
verses.text: For by this he signifies that neither did he seek much to enjoy the honor accruing hereby from the multitude, nor did he set about this work for glory's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:102
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:103
verses.text: And not by these only, but also by the next words, he greatly represses their pride, saying, "Christ sent me not to baptize, but to preach the Gospel:" for the more laborious part, and that which needed much toil and a soul of iron, and that on which all depended, was this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:104
verses.text: And therefore it was that Paul had it put into his hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:105
verses.text: And why, not being sent to baptize, did he baptize? Not in contention with Him that sent him, but in this instance laboring beyond his task.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:106
verses.text: For he saith not, "I was forbidden," but, "I was not sent for this, but for that which was of the greatest necessity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:107
verses.text: For preaching the Gospel is a work perhaps for one or two; but baptizing, for everyone endowed with the priesthood.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:108
verses.text: For a man being instructed and convinced, to take and baptize him is what any one whatever might do: for the rest, it is all effected by the will of the person drawing near, and the grace of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:109
verses.text: But when unbelievers are to be instructed, there must be great labor, great wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:110
verses.text: And at that time there was danger also annexed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:111
verses.text: In the former case the whole thing is done, and he is convinced, who is on the point of initiation: and it is no great thing when a man is convinced, to baptize him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:112
verses.text: But in the later case the labor is great, to change the deliberate will, to alter the turn of mind, and to tear up error by the roots, and to plant the truth in its place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:113
verses.text: Not that he speaks out all this, neither doth he argue in so many words that Baptism has no labor, but that preaching has.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:114
verses.text: For he knows how always to subdue his tone, whereas in the comparison with heathen wisdom he is very earnest, the subject enabling him to use more vehemency of language.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:115
verses.text: Not therefore in opposition to Him that sent him did he baptize; but, as in the case of the widows, though the apostles had said, (Acts vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:116
verses.text: ) "it is not fit that we should leave the Word of God and serve tables," he discharged the office (Acts xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:117
verses.text: τὴν διακονίαν) of a deacon, not in opposition to them, but as something beyond his task: so also here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:118
verses.text: For even now, we commit this matter to the simpler sort of presbyters, but the word of doctrine unto the wiser: for there is the labor and the sweat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:119
verses.text: Wherefore he saith himself, ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:120
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:121
verses.text: ) "Let the Elders who rule well be counted worthy of double honor, especially they who labor in the word and in teaching".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:122
verses.text: For as to teach the wrestlers in the games is the part of a spirited and skilful trainer, but to place the crown on the conquerors head may be that of one who cannot even wrestle, (although it be the crown which adds splendor to the conqueror,) so also in Baptism.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:123
verses.text: It is impossible to be saved without it, yet it is no great thing which the baptizer doth, finding the will ready prepared.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:124
verses.text: "Not in wisdom of words, lest the Cross of Christ should be made of none effect".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:125
verses.text: Having brought down the swelling pride of those who were arrogant because of their baptizing, he changes his ground afterwards to meet those who boasted about heathen wisdom, and against them he puts on his armor with more vehemency.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:126
verses.text: For to those who were puffed up with baptizing he said, "I give thanks that I baptized no one;" and, "for Christ sent me not to baptize".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:127
verses.text: He speaks neither vehemently nor argumentatively, but, having just hinted his meaning in a few words, passeth on quickly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:128
verses.text: But here at the very outset he gives a severe blow, saying, "Lest the Cross of Christ be made void".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:129
verses.text: Why then pride thyself on a thing which ought to make thee hide thy face? Since, if this wisdom is at war with the Cross and fights with the Gospel, it is not meet to boast about it, but to retire with shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:130
verses.text: For this was the cause why the Apostles were not wise; not through any weakness of the Gift, but lest the Gospel preached suffer harm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:131
verses.text: The sort of people therefore above mentioned were not those employed in advocating the Word: rather they were among its defamers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:132
verses.text: The unlearned men were the establishers of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:133
verses.text: This was able to check vain glory, this to repress arrogance, this to enforce moderation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:134
verses.text: "But if it was 'not by wisdom of speech,' why did they send Apollos who was eloquent?" It was not, he replies, through confidence in his power of speech, but because he was (Acts xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:135
verses.text: , ) "mighty in the Scriptures," and "confuted the Jews".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:136
verses.text: And besides the point in question was that the leaders and first disseminators of the word were not eloquent; since these were the very persons to require some great power, for the expulsion of error in the first instance; and then, namely at the very outset, was the abundant strength needed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:137
verses.text: Now He who could do without educated persons at first, if afterwards some being eloquent were admitted by Him, He did so not because He wanted them, but because He would make no distinctions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:138
verses.text: For as He needed not wise men to effect whatever He would, so neither, if any were afterwards found such, did He reject them on that account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:139
verses.text: But prove to me that Peter and Paul were eloquent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:140
verses.text: Thou canst not: for they were "unlearned and ignorant men!" As therefore Christ, when He was sending out His disciples into the world, having shewn unto them His power in Palestine first, and said, (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:141
verses.text: Luke xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:142
verses.text: (ὑποδήμάτος, rec.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:143
verses.text: text ὑποδηματων.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:144
verses.text: ) "When I sent you forth without purse and wallet and shoe, lacked ye any thing?" permitted them from that time forward to possess both a wallet and a purse; so also He hath done here: for the point was the manifestation of Christ's power, not the rejection of persons from the Faith on account of their Gentile wisdom, if they were drawing nigh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:145
verses.text: When the Greeks then charge the disciples with being uneducated, let us be even more forward in the charge than they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:146
verses.text: Nor let anyone say, "Paul was wise;" but while we exalt those among them who were great in wisdom and admired for their excellency of speech, let us allow that all on our side were uneducated; for it will be no slight overthrow which they will sustain from us in that respect also: and so the victory will be brilliant indeed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:147
verses.text: I have said these things, because I once heard a Christian disputing in a ridiculous manner with a Greek, and both parties in their mutual fray ruining themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:148
verses.text: For what things the Christian ought to have said, these the Greek asserted; and what things it was natural to expect the Greek would say, these the Christian pleaded for himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:149
verses.text: As thus: the dispute being about Paul and Plato, the Greek endeavored to show that Paul was unlearned and ignorant; but the Christian, from simplicity, was anxious to prove that Paul was more eloquent than Plato.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:150
verses.text: And so the victory was on the side of the Greek, this argument being allowed to prevail.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:151
verses.text: For if Paul was a more considerable person than Plato, many probably would object that it was not by grace, but by excellency of speech that he prevailed; so that the Christian's assertion made for the Greek.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:152
verses.text: And what the Greek said made for the Christian's; for if Paul was uneducated and yet overcame Plato, the victory, as I was saying, was brilliant; the disciples of the latter, in a body, having been attracted by the former, unlearned as he was, and convinced, and brought over to his side.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:153
verses.text: From whence it is plain that the Gospel was a result not of human wisdom, but of the grace of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:154
verses.text: Wherefore, lest we fall into the same error, and be laughed to scorn, arguing thus with Greeks whenever we have a controversy with them; let us charge the Apostles with want of learning; for this same charge is praise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:155
verses.text: And when they say that the Apostles were rude, let us follow up the remark and say that they were also untaught, and unlettered, and poor, and vile, and stupid, and obscure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:156
verses.text: It is not a slander on the Apostles to say so, but it is even a glory that, being such, they should have outshone the whole world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:157
verses.text: For these untrained, and rude, and illiterate men, as completely vanquished the wise, and powerful, and the tyrants, and those who flourished in wealth and glory and all outward good things, as though they had not been men at all: from whence it is manifest that great is the power of the Cross; and that these things were done by no human strength.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:158
verses.text: For the results do not keep the course of nature, rather what was done was above all nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:159
verses.text: Now when any thing takes place above nature, and exceedingly above it, on the side of rectitude and utility; it is quite plain that these things are done by some Divine power and cooperation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:160
verses.text: And observe; the fisherman, the tentmaker, the publican, the ignorant, the unlettered, coming from the far distant country of Palestine, and having beaten off their own ground the philosophers, the masters of oratory, the skillful debaters, alone prevailed against them in a short space of time; in the midst of many perils; the opposition of peoples and kings, the striving of nature herself, length of time, the vehement resistance of inveterate custom, demons in arms, the devil in battle array and stirring up all, kings, rulers, peoples, nations, cities, barbarians, Greeks, philosophers, orators, sophists, historians, laws, tribunals, divers kinds of punishments, deaths innumerable and of all sorts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:161
verses.text: But nevertheless all these were confuted and gave way when the fisherman spake; just like the light dust which cannot bear the rush of violent winds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:162
verses.text: Now what I say is, let us learn thus to dispute with the Greeks; that we be not like beasts and cattle, but prepared concerning "the hope which is in us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:163
verses.text: ( St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:164
verses.text: Pet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:165
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:166
verses.text: ) And let us pause for a while to work out this topic, no unimportant one; and let us say to them, How did the weak overcome the strong; the twelve, the world? Not by using the same armor, but in nakedness contending with men in arms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:167
verses.text: For say, if twelve men, unskilled in matters of war, were to leap into an immense and armed host of soldiers, themselves not only unarmed but of weak frame also; and to receive no harm from them, nor yet be wounded, though assailed with ten thousand weapons; if while the darts were striking them, with bare naked body they overthrew all their foes using no weapons but striking with the hand, and in conclusion killed some, and others took captive and led away, themselves receiving not so much as a wound; would anyone have ever said that the thing was of man? And yet the trophy of the Apostles is much more wonderful than that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:168
verses.text: For a naked man's escaping a wound is not so wonderful by far as that the ordinary and unlettered person—that a fisherman—should overcome such a degree of talent: (δεινότητος) and neither for fewness, nor for poverty, nor for dangers, nor for prepossession of habit, nor for so great austerity of the precepts enjoined, nor for the daily deaths, nor for the multitude of those who were deceived, nor for the great reputation of the deceivers be turned from his purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:169
verses.text: Let this, I say, be our way of overpowering them, and of conducting our warfare against them; and let us astound them by our way of life rather than by words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:170
verses.text: For this is the main battle, this is the unanswerable argument, the argument from conduct.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:171
verses.text: For though we give ten thousand precepts of philosophy in words, if we do not exhibit a life better than theirs, the gain is nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:172
verses.text: For it is not what is said that draws their attention, but their enquiry is, what we do; and they say, "Do thou first obey thine own words, and then admonish others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:173
verses.text: But if while thou sayest, infinite are the blessings in the world to come, thou seem thyself nailed down to this world, just as if no such things existed, thy works to me are more credible than thy words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:174
verses.text: For when I see thee seizing other men's goods, weeping immoderately over the departed, doing ill in many other things, how shall I believe thee that there is a resurrection?" And what if men utter not this in words? they think it and turn it often in their minds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:175
verses.text: And this is what stays the unbelievers from becoming Christians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:176
verses.text: Let us win them therefore by our life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:177
verses.text: Many, even among the untaught, have in that way astounded the minds of philosophers, as having exhibited in themselves also that philosophy which lies in deeds, and uttered a voice clearer than a trumpet by their mode of life and self-denial.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:178
verses.text: For this is stronger than the tongue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:179
verses.text: But when I say, "one ought not to bear malice," and then do all manner of evils to the Greek, how shall I be able by words to win him, while by my deeds I am frightening him away? Let us catch them then by our mode of life; and by these souls let us build up the Church, and of these let us amass our wealth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:180
verses.text: There is nothing to weigh against a soul, not even the whole world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:181
verses.text: So that although thou give countless treasure unto the poor, thou wilt do no such work as he who converteth one soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:182
verses.text: (Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:183
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:184
verses.text: ) "For he that taketh forth the precious from the vile shall be as my mouth:" so He speaks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:185
verses.text: A great good it is, I grant, to have pity on the poor; but it is nothing equal to the withdrawing them from error.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:186
verses.text: For he that doth this resembles Paul and Peter: we being permitted to take up their Gospel, not with perils such as theirs;—with endurance of famines and pestilences, and all other evils, (for the present is a season of peace;)—but so as to display that diligence which cometh of zeal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:187
verses.text: For even while we sit at home we may practice this kind of fishery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:188
verses.text: Who hath a friend or relation or inmate of his house, these things let him say, these do; and he shall be like Peter and Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:189
verses.text: And why do I say Peter and Paul? He shall be the mouth of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:190
verses.text: For He saith, "He that taketh forth the precious from the vile shall be as My mouth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:191
verses.text: And though thou persuade not to-day, to-morrow thou shalt persuade.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:192
verses.text: And though thou never persuade, thou shalt have thine own reward in full.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:193
verses.text: And though thou persuade not all, a few out of many persuade all men; but still they discoursed with all, and for all they have their reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:194
verses.text: For not according to the result of the things that are well done, but according to the intention of the doers, is God wont to assign the crowns; though thou pay down but two farthings, He receiveth them; and what He did in the case of the widow, the same will He do also in the case of those who teach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:195
verses.text: Do not thou then, because thou canst not save the world, despise the few; nor through longing after great things, withdraw thyself from the lesser.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:196
verses.text: If thou canst not an hundred, take thou charge of ten; if thou canst not ten, despise not even five; if thou canst not five, do not overlook one; and if thou canst not one, neither so despair, nor keep back what may be done by thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:197
verses.text: Seest thou not how, in matters of trade, they who are so employed make their profit not only of gold but of silver also? For if we do not slight the little things, we shall keep hold also of the great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:198
verses.text: But if we despise the small, neither shall we easily lay hand upon the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:199
verses.text: Thus individuals become rich, gathering both small things and great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 3:200
verses.text: And so let us act; that in all things enriched, we may obtain the kingdom of heaven; through the grace and loving-kindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, through Whom and with Whom unto the Father together with the Holy Spirit be glory, power, honor, now and henceforth and for evermore, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:1
verses.text: Homily VI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:3
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:4
verses.text: ,  And I, brethren, when I came to you, came not with excellency of speech or of wisdom, declaring unto you the testimony of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:5
verses.text: For I determined not to know any thing among you, save Jesus Christ, and Him crucified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:6
verses.text: Nothing was ever more prepared for combat than the spirit of Paul; or rather, I should say, not his spirit, (for he was not himself the inventor of these things,) but, nothing was ever equal to the grace working within him, which overcometh all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:7
verses.text: For sufficient indeed is what had been said before to cast down the pride of the boasters about wisdom; nay, even a part of it had been enough.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:8
verses.text: But to enhance the splendor of the victory, he contends anew for the points which he had been affirming; trampling upon the prostrate foe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:9
verses.text: Look at it in this way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:10
verses.text: He had brought forward the prophecy which saith, "I will destroy the wisdom of the wise".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:11
verses.text: He had shewn the wisdom of God, in that by means of what seemed to be foolishness, He destroyed the philosophy of the Gentiles; he had shewn that the "foolishness of God is wiser than men;" he had shewn that not only did He teach by untaught persons, but also chose untaught persons to learn of Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:12
verses.text: Now he sheweth that both the thing itself which was preached, and the manner of preaching it, were enough to stagger people; and yet did not stagger them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:13
verses.text: As thus: "not only," saith he, "are the disciples uneducated, but I myself also, who am the preacher".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:14
verses.text: Therefore he saith, "And I, brethren," (again he useth the word "brethren," to smooth down the harshness of the utterance,) "came not with excellency of speech, declaring unto you the testimony of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:15
verses.text: "What then? tell me, hadst thou chosen to come 'with excellency,' wouldest thou have been able?" "I, indeed, had I chosen, should not have been able; but Christ, if He had chosen, was able.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:16
verses.text: But He would not, in order that He might render His trophy more brilliant".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:17
verses.text: Wherefore also in a former passage, shewing that it was His work which had been done, His will that the word should be preached in an unlearned manner, he said, "For Christ sent me not to baptize, but to preach the Gospel; not with wisdom of words".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:18
verses.text: But far greater, yea, infinitely greater, than Paul's willing this, is the fact that Christ willed it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:19
verses.text: "Not therefore," saith he, "by display of eloquence, neither armed with arguments from without, do I declare the testimony of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:20
verses.text: He saith not "the preaching," but "the testimony of God;" which word was itself sufficient to withhold him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:21
verses.text: For he went about preaching death: and for this reason he added, "for I determined not to know anything among you, save Jesus Christ, and Him crucified".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:22
verses.text: This was the meaning he meant to convey, that he is altogether destitute of the wisdom which is without; as indeed he was saying above, "I came not with excellency of speech:" for that he might have possessed this also is plain; for he whose garments raised the dead and whose shadow expelled diseases, much more was his soul capable of receiving eloquence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:23
verses.text: For this is a thing which may be taught: but the former transcendeth all art.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:24
verses.text: He then who knows things beyond the reach of art, much more must he have had strength for lesser things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:25
verses.text: But Christ permitted not; for it was not expedient.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:26
verses.text: Rightly therefore he saith, "For I determined not to know any thing: "for I, too, for my part have just the same will as Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:27
verses.text: And to me it seems that he speaks to them in a lower tone even than to any others, in order to repress their pride.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:28
verses.text: Thus, the expression, "I determined to know nothing," was spoken in contradistinction to the wisdom which is without.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:29
verses.text: "For I came not weaving syllogisms nor sophisms, nor saying unto you anything else than "Christ was crucified".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:30
verses.text: They indeed have ten thousand things to say, and concerning ten thousand things they speak, winding out long courses of words, framing arguments and syllogisms, compounding sophisms without end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:31
verses.text: But I came unto you saying no other thing than "Christ was crucified," and all of them I out-stripped: which is a sign such as no words can express of the power of Him whom I preach".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:32
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:33
verses.text: "And I was with you in weakness, and in fear, and in much trembling".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:34
verses.text: This again is another topic: for not only are the believers unlearned persons; not only is he that speaketh unlearned; not only is the manner of the teaching of an unlearned cast throughout; not only was the thing preached of itself enough to stagger people; (for the cross and death were the message brought;) but together with these there were also other hindrances, the dangers, and the plots, and the daily fear, and the being hunted about.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:35
verses.text: For the word "weakness," with him in many places stands for the persecutions: as also elsewhere.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:36
verses.text: "My weakness which I had in my flesh ye did not set at nought:" (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:37
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:39
verses.text: ) and again, "If I must needs glory, I will glory of the things which concern my weakness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:40
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:41
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:42
verses.text: ) What weakness? "The governor under Aretas the king guarded the city of the Damascenes, desirous to apprehend me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:43
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:44
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:45
verses.text: ) And again, "Wherefore I take pleasure in weakness:" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:46
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:47
verses.text: ) then, saying in what, he added, "In injuries, in necessities, in distresses".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:48
verses.text: And here he makes the same statement; for having said, "And I was in weakness," etc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:49
verses.text: he did not stop at this point, but explaining the word "weakness" makes mention of his dangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:50
verses.text: He adds again, "and in fear, and in much trembling, I was with you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:51
verses.text: "How sayest thou? Did Paul also fear dangers?" He did fear, and dreaded them excessively; for though he was Paul, yet he was a man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:52
verses.text: But this is no charge against Paul, but infirmity of human nature; and it is to the praise of his fixed purpose of mind that when he even dreaded death and stripes, he did nothing wrong because of this fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:53
verses.text: So that they who assert that he feared not stripes, not only do not honor him, but rather abridge greatly his praises.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:54
verses.text: For if he feared not, what endurance or what self-restraint was there in bearing the dangers? I, for my part, on this account admire him; because being in fear, and not simply in "fear," but even in "trembling" at his perils, he so ran as ever to keep his crown; and gave not in for any danger, in his task of purging out the world, and everywhere both by sea and land sowing the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:55
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:56
verses.text: "And my speech and my preaching was not in persuasive words of wisdom:" that is, had not the wisdom from without.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:57
verses.text: Now if the doctrine preached had nothing subtle, and they that were called were unlearned, and he that preached was of the same description, and thereto was added persecution, and trembling and fear; tell me, how did they overcome without Divine power? And this is why, having said, "My speech and my preaching was not in persuasive words of wisdom," he added, "but in demonstration of the Spirit and of power".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:58
verses.text: Dost thou perceive how "the foolishness of God is wiser than men, and the weakness stronger?" They for their part, being unlearned and preaching such a Gospel, in their chains and persecution overcame their persecutors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:59
verses.text: Whereby? was it not by their furnishing that evidence which is of the Spirit? For this indeed is confessed demonstration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:60
verses.text: For who, tell me, after he had seen dead men rising to life and devils cast out, could have helped admitting it?  But seeing that there are also deceiving wonders, such as those of sorcerers, he removes this suspicion also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:61
verses.text: For he said not simply "of power," but first, "of the Spirit," and then, "of power:" signifying that the things done were spiritual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:62
verses.text: It is no disparagement, therefore, that the Gospel was not declared by means of wisdom; rather it is a very great ornament.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:63
verses.text: For this, it will be allowed, is the clearest token of its being divine and having its roots from above, out of the heavens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:64
verses.text: Wherefore he added also,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:65
verses.text: "That your faith should not stand in the wisdom of men, but in the power of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:66
verses.text: Seest thou how clearly in every way he hath set forth the vast gain of this "ignorance," and the great loss of this "wisdom?" For the latter made void the Cross, but the former proclaimed the power of God: the latter, besides their failing to discover any of those things which they most needed, set them also upon boasting of themselves; the former, besides their receiving the truth, led them also to pride themselves in God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:67
verses.text: Again, wisdom would have persuaded many to suspect that the doctrine was of man: this clearly demonstrated it to be divine, and to have come down from heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:68
verses.text: Now when demonstration is made by wisdom of words, even the worse oftentimes overcome the better, having more skill in words; and falsehood outstrips the truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:69
verses.text: But in this case it is not so: for neither doth the Spirit enter into an unclean soul, nor, having entered in, can it ever be subdued; even though all possible cleverness of speech assail it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:70
verses.text: For the demonstration by works and signs is far more evident than that by words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:71
verses.text: But some one may say perhaps, "If the Gospel is to prevail and hath no need of words, lest the Cross be made of none effect; for what reason are signs withholden now?" For what reason? Speakest thou in unbelief and not allowing that they were done even in the times of the Apostles, or dost thou truly seek to know? If in unbelief, I will first make my stand against this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:72
verses.text: I say then, If signs were not done at that time, how did they, chased, and persecuted, and trembling, and in chains, and having become the common enemies of the world, and exposed to all as a mark for ill usage, and with nothing of their own to allure, neither speech, nor show, nor wealth, nor city, nor nation, nor family, nor pursuit (ἐπιτήδευμα,) nor glory, nor any such like thing; but with all things contrary, ignorance, meanness, poverty, hatred, enmity, and setting themselves against whole commonwealths, and with such a message to declare; how, I say, did they work conviction? For both the precepts brought much labor, and the doctrines many dangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:73
verses.text: And they that heard and were to obey, had been brought up in luxury and drunkenness, and in great wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:74
verses.text: Tell me then, how did they convince? Whence had they their credibility? For, as I have just said, If without signs they wrought conviction, far greater does the wonder appear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:75
verses.text: Do not then urge the fact that signs are not done now, as a proof that they were not done then.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:76
verses.text: For as then they were usefully wrought; so now are they no longer so wrought.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:77
verses.text: Nor doth it necessarily follow from discourse being the only instrument of conviction, that now the "preaching" is in "wisdom".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:78
verses.text: For both they who from the beginning sowed the word were unprofessional (ὶδιῶται) and unlearned, and spake nothing of themselves; but what things they received from God, these they distributed to the world: and we ourselves at this time introduce no inventions of our own; but the things which from them we have received, we speak unto all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:79
verses.text: And not even now persuade we by argumentation; but from the Divine Scriptures and from the miracles done at that time we produce the proof of what we say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:80
verses.text: On the other hand, even they at that time persuaded not by signs alone, but also by discoursing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:81
verses.text: And the signs and the testimonies out of the Old Scriptures, not the cleverness of the things said, made their words appear more powerful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:82
verses.text: How then, you will say, is it that signs were expedient then, and now inexpedient? Let us suppose a case, (for as yet I am contending against the Greek, and therefore I speak hypothetically of what must certainly come to pass,) let us, I say, suppose a case; and let the unbeliever consent to believe our affirmations, though it be only by way of concession: (κἄν κατὰ συνδρομήν) for instance, That Christ will come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:83
verses.text: When then Christ shall come and all the angels with Him, and be manifested as God, and all things made subject unto Him; will not even the Greek believe? It is quite plain that he will also fall down and worship, and confess Him God, though his stubbornness exceed all reckoning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:84
verses.text: For who, at sight of the heavens opened and Him coming upon the clouds, and all the congregation of the powers above spread around Him, and rivers of fire coming on, and all standing by and trembling, will not fall down before Him, and believe Him God? Tell me, then; shall that adoration and knowledge be accounted unto the Greek for faith? No, on no account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:85
verses.text: And why not? Because this is not faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:86
verses.text: For necessity hath done this, and the evidence of the things seen, and it is not of choice, but by the vastness of the spectacle the powers of the mind are dragged along.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:87
verses.text: It follows that by how much the more evident and overpowering the course of events, by so much is the part of faith abridged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:88
verses.text: For this reason miracles are not done now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:89
verses.text: And that this is the truth, hear what He saith unto Thomas (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:90
verses.text: John xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:91
verses.text: ) "Blessed are they who have not seen, and yet have believed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:92
verses.text: Therefore, in proportion to the evidence wherewith the miracle is set forth is the reward of faith lessened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:93
verses.text: So that if now also miracles were wrought, the same thing would ensue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:94
verses.text: For that then we shall no longer know Him by faith, Paul hath shewn, saying, "For now we walk by faith, not by sight".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:95
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:96
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:97
verses.text: νῦν not in the received text.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:98
verses.text: ) As at that time, although thou believe, it shall not be imputed unto thee, because the thing is so palpable; so also now, supposing that such miracles were done as were formerly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:99
verses.text: For when we admit things which in no degree and in no way can be made out by reasoning, then it is faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:100
verses.text: It is for this that hell is threatened, but is not shewn: for if it were shewn, the same would again ensue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:101
verses.text: Besides if signs be what thou seekest after, even now thou mayest see signs, although not of the same kind; the numberless predictions and on an endless variety of subject: the conversion of the world, the self-denying (φιλοσοφίαν) course of the Barbarians, the change from savage customs, the greater intenseness of piety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:102
verses.text: "What predictions?" you will say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:103
verses.text: "For all the things just mentioned were written after the present state of things had begun".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:104
verses.text: When? Where? By whom? Tell me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:105
verses.text: How many years ago? Will you have fifty, or an hundred? They had not then, a hundred years ago, anything written at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:106
verses.text: How then did the world retain the doctrines and all the rest, since memory would not be sufficient? How knew they that Peter was crucified? (ἀνεσκολοπίσθη) How could it have entered the minds of men who came after the events had taken place to foretell, for instance, that the Gospel should be preached in every part of the whole world? that the Jewish institutions should cease, and never return again? And they who gave up their lives for the Gospel, how would they have endured to see the Gospel adulterated? And how would the writers have won credit, miracles having ceased? And how could the writings have penetrated to the region of Barbarians, and of Indians, and unto the very bounds of the ocean, if the relators had not been worthy of credit? The writers, too, who were they? When, how, and why, did they write at all? Was it to gain glory to themselves? Why then inscribed they the books with other men's names? "Why, from a wish to recommend the doctrine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:107
verses.text: As true, or as false? For if you say, they stuck to it, as being false; their joining it at all was out of all likelihood: but if as being truth, there was no need of inventions such as you speak of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:108
verses.text: And besides, the prophecies are of such a kind, as that even until now time has been unable to force aside the predicted course of things: (ὡς μὴ δυνάσθαι βιαζὲσθαι χρόνῳ τα εἰρημένα) for the destruction indeed of Jerusalem took place many years ago; but there are also other predictions which extend along from that time until His coming; which examine as you please: for instance, this, "I am with you alway, even unto the end of the world: (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:109
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:110
verses.text: xxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:111
verses.text: ) and, "Upon this Rock I will build My Church, and the gates of hell shall not prevail against it:" (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:112
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:113
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:114
verses.text: ) and, "This Gospel shall be preached unto all nations:" (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:115
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:116
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:117
verses.text: ) and that which the woman which was an harlot did: and many others more than these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:118
verses.text: Whence then the truth of this prediction if indeed it were a forgery? How did "the gates of hell" not "prevail" against "the Church?" How is Christ always "with us?" For had He not been "with us," the Church would not have been victorious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:119
verses.text: How was the Gospel spread abroad in every part of the world? They also who have spoken against us are enough to testify the antiquity of the books; I mean, such as Celsus and he of Batanea, who came after him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:120
verses.text: For they, I suppose, were not speaking against books composed after their time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:121
verses.text: And besides, there is the whole world which with one consent hath received the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:122
verses.text: Now there could not have been so great agreement from one end of the earth to the other, unless it had been the Grace of the Spirit; but the authors of the forgery would have been quickly found out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:123
verses.text: Neither could so great excellencies have originated from inventions and falsehoods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:124
verses.text: Dost thou not see the whole world coming in; error extinguished; the austere wisdom (φιλοσυφίαν) of the old monks shining brighter than the sun; the choirs of the virgins; the piety among Barbarians; all men serving under one yoke? For neither by us alone were these things foretold, but also from the beginning, by the Prophets.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:125
verses.text: For you will not, I trow, cavil at their predictions also: for the books are with their enemies, and through the zeal of certain Greeks they have been transferred into the Greek tongue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:126
verses.text: Many things then do these also foretell concerning these matters, shewing that it was God who should come among us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:127
verses.text: Why then do not all believe now? Because things have degenerated: and for this we are to blame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:128
verses.text: (For from hence the discourse is addressed unto us also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:129
verses.text: ) For surely not even then did they trust to signs alone, but by the mode of life also many of the converts were attracted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:130
verses.text: For, "Let your light so shine before men," saith He, "that they may see your good works, and glorify your Father which is in heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:131
verses.text: (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:132
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:133
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:134
verses.text: ) And, "They were all of one heart and one soul, neither said any man that aught of the things which he possessed was his own, but they had all things common; and distribution was made unto every man, according as he had need;" (Acts iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:136
verses.text: ) and they lived an angelic life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:137
verses.text: And if the same were done now, we should convert the whole world, even without miracles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:138
verses.text: But in the meanwhile, let those who will be saved attend to the Scriptures; for they shall find there both these noble doings, and those which are greater than these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:139
verses.text: For it may be added that the Teachers themselves surpassed the deeds of the others; living in hunger, in thirst, and nakedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:140
verses.text: But we are desirous of enjoying great luxury, and rest, and ease; not so they: they cried aloud, "Even unto the present hour we both hunger, and thirst, and are naked, and are buffeted, and have no certain dwelling place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:141
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:142
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:143
verses.text: ) And some ran from Jerusalem unto Illyricum, (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:144
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:145
verses.text: ) and another unto the country of the Indians, and another unto that of the Moors, and this to one part of the world, that to another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:146
verses.text: Whereas we have not the courage to depart even out of our own country; but seek for luxurious living and splendid houses and all other superfluities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:147
verses.text: For which of us ever was famished for the word of God's sake? Which ever abode in a wilderness? Which ever set out on a distant peregrination? Which of our teachers lived by the labor of his hands to assist others? Which endured death daily? Hence it is that they also who are with us have become slothful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:148
verses.text: For suppose that one saw soldiers and generals struggling with hunger, and thirst, and death, and with all dreadful things, and bearing cold and dangers and all like lions, and so prospering; then afterwards, relaxing that strictness, and becoming enervated, and fond of wealth, and addicted to business and bargains, and then overcome by their enemies, it were extreme folly to seek for the cause of all this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:149
verses.text: Now let us reason thus in our own case and that of our ancestors; for we too have become weaker than all, and are nailed down unto this present life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:150
verses.text: And if one be found having a vestige of the ancient wisdom, leaving the cities and the market-places, and the society of the world, and the ordering of others, he betakes himself to the mountains: and if one ask the reason of that retirement, he invents a plea which cannot meet with allowance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:151
verses.text: For, saith he, "lest I perish too, and the edge of my goodness be taken off, I start aside".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:152
verses.text: Now how much better were it for thee to become less keen, and to gain others, than abiding on high to neglect thy perishing brethren?  When, however, the one sort are careless about virtue, and those who do regard it withdraw themselves far from our ranks, how are we to subdue our enemies? For even if miracles were wrought now, who would be persuaded? Or who of those without would give heed unto us, our iniquity being thus prevalent? For so it is, that our upright living seems unto the many the more trustworthy argument of the two: miracles admitting of a bad construction on the part of obstinate bad men: whereas a pure life will have abundant power to stop the mouth of the devil himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:153
verses.text: These things I say, both to governors and governed; and, before all others, unto myself; to the end that the way of life shown forth in us may be truly admirable, that taking our appropriate stations, we may look down on all things present; may despise wealth, and not despise hell; overlook glory, and not overlook salvation; endure toil and labor here, lest we fall into punishment there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:154
verses.text: Thus let us wage war with the Greeks; thus let us take them captive with a captivity better than liberty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:155
verses.text: But while we say these things without intermission, over and over, they occur very seldom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:156
verses.text: Howbeit, be they done or not, it is right to remind you of them continually.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:157
verses.text: For if some are engaged in deceiving by their fair speech, so much more is it the duty of those who allure back unto the truth, not to grow weary of speaking what is profitable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 4:158
verses.text: Again: if the deceivers make use of so many contrivances—spending as they do money, and applying arguments, and undergoing dangers, and making a parade of their patronage—much more should we, who are winning men from deceit, endure both dangers and deaths, and all things; that we may both gain ourselves and others, and become to our enemies irresistible, and so obtain the promised blessings, through the grace and loving-kindness, etc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:1
verses.text: Homily V.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:3
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:4
verses.text: ,  For behold your calling, brethren, that not many wise men after the flesh, not many mighty, not many noble, are called; but God chose the foolish things of the world, that he might put to shame them that are wise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:5
verses.text: He hath said that "the foolishness of God is wiser than men;" he hath shewed that human wisdom is cast out, both by the testimony of the Scriptures and by the issue of events; by the testimony, where he says, "I will destroy the wisdom of the wise;" by the event, putting his argument in the form of a question, and saying, "Where is the wise? Where the Scribe?" Again; he proved at the same time that the thing is not new, but ancient, as it was presignified and foretold from the beginning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:6
verses.text: For, "It is written," saith he, "I will destroy the wisdom of the wise".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:7
verses.text: Withal he shews that it was neither inexpedient nor unaccountable for things to take this course: (for, "seeing that in the wisdom of God the world," saith he, "knew not God, God was well pleased through the foolishness of preaching to save them which believe:") and that the Cross is a demonstration of ineffable power and wisdom, and that the foolishness of God is far mightier than the wisdom of man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:8
verses.text: And this again he proves not by means of the teachers, but by means of the disciples themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:9
verses.text: For, "Behold your calling," saith he: that not only teachers of an untrained sort, but disciples also of the like class, were objects of His choice; that He chose "not many wise men" (that is his word) "according to the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:10
verses.text: And so that of which he is speaking is proved to surpass both in strength and wisdom, in that it convinces both the many and the unwise: it being extremely hard to convince an ignorant person, especially when the discourse is concerning great and necessary things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:11
verses.text: However, they did work conviction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:12
verses.text: And of this he calls the Corinthians themselves as witnesses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:13
verses.text: For, "behold your calling, brethren," saith he: consider; examine: for that doctrines so wise, yea, wiser than all, should be received by ordinary men, testifies the greatest wisdom in the teacher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:14
verses.text: But what means, "according to the flesh?" According to what is in sight; according to the life that now is; according to the discipline of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:15
verses.text: Then, lest he should seem to be at variance with himself, (for he had convinced both the Proconsul, (Acts xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:16
verses.text: ) and the Areopagite, (Acts xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:17
verses.text: ) and Apollos; (Acts xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:18
verses.text: : through Aquila and Priscilla) and other wise men, too, we have seen coming over to the Gospel;) he said not, No wise man, but, "Not many wise men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:19
verses.text: For he did not designedly (ἀποκεκληρωμένως) call the ignorant and pass by the wise, but these also he received, yet the others in much larger number.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:20
verses.text: And why? Because the wise man according to the flesh is full of extreme folly; and it is he who especially answers to the term "foolish," when he will not cast away his corrupt doctrine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:21
verses.text: And as in the case of a physician who might wish to teach certain persons the secrets of his art, those who know a few things, having a bad and perverse mode of practicing the art which they make a point of retaining, would not endure to learn quietly, but they who knew nothing would most readily embrace what was said: even so it was here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:22
verses.text: The unlearned were more open to conviction, for they were free from the extreme madness of accounting themselves wise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:23
verses.text: For indeed the excess of folly is in these more than any, these, I say, who commit unto reasoning things which cannot be ascertained except by faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:24
verses.text: Thus, suppose the smith by means of the tongs drawing out the red-hot iron; if any one should insist on doing it with his hand, we should vote him guilty of extreme folly: so in like manner the philosophers who insisted on finding out these things for themselves disparaged the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:25
verses.text: And it was owing to this that they found none of the things they sought for.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:26
verses.text: "Not many mighty, not many noble;" for these also are filled with pride.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:27
verses.text: And nothing is so useless towards an accurate knowledge of God as arrogance, and being nailed down (προσηλῶσθαι) to wealth: for these dispose a man to admire things present, and make no account of the future; and they stop up the ears through the multitude of cares: but "the foolish things of the world God chose:" which thing is the greatest sign of victory, that they were uneducated by whom He conquers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:28
verses.text: For the Greeks feel not so much shame when they are defeated by means of the "wise," but are then confounded, when they see the artisan and the sort of person one meets in the market more of a philosopher than themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:29
verses.text: Wherefore also he said himself, "That He might put to shame the wise".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:30
verses.text: And not in this instance alone hath he done this, also in the case of the other advantages of life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:31
verses.text: For, to proceed, "the weak things of the world He chose that He might put to shame the strong".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:32
verses.text: For not unlearned persons only, but needy also, and contemptible and obscure He called, that He might humble those who were in high places.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:33
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:34
verses.text: "And the base things of the world, and the things that are despised, and the things that are not, that he might bring to naught the things that are".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:35
verses.text: Now what doth He call things "that are not?" Those persons who are considered to be nothing because of their great insignificance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:36
verses.text: Thus hath He shown forth His great power, casting down the great by those who seem to be nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:37
verses.text: The same elsewhere he thus expresses, ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:38
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:39
verses.text: ) "For my strength is made perfect in weakness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:40
verses.text: For a great power it is, to teach outcasts and such as never applied themselves to any branch of learning, how all at once to discourse wisely on the things which are above the heavens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:41
verses.text: For suppose a physician, an orator, or any one else: we then most admire him, when he convinces and instructs those completely uneducated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:42
verses.text: Now, if to instil into an uneducated man the rules of art be a very wonderful thing, much more things which pertain to so high philosophy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:43
verses.text: But not for the wonders sake only, neither to shew His own power, hath He done this, but to check also the arrogant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:44
verses.text: And therefore he both said before, "That he might confound the wise and the strong, that He might bring to nought the things which are," and here again,  V.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:45
verses.text: "That no flesh should glory in the presence of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:46
verses.text: For God doeth all things to this end, to repress vainglory and pride, to pull down boasting".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:47
verses.text: "Do you, too," saith he, "employ yourselves in that work".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:48
verses.text: He doth all, that we may put nothing to our own account; that we may ascribe all unto God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:49
verses.text: And have ye given yourselves over unto this person or to that? And what pardon will ye obtain?"  For God Himself hath shown that it is not possible we should be saved only by ourselves: and this He did from the beginning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:50
verses.text: For neither then could men be saved by themselves; but it required their compassing the beauty of the heaven, and the extent of the earth, and the mass of creation besides; if so they might be led by the hand to the great artificer of all the works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:51
verses.text: And He did this, repressing beforehand the self-conceit which was after to arise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:52
verses.text: Just as if a master who had given his scholar charge to follow wheresoever he might lead, when he sees him forestalling, and desiring to learn all things of himself, should permit him to go quite astray; and when he hath proved him incompetent to acquire the knowledge, should thereupon at length introduce to him what himself has to teach: so God also commanded in the beginning to trace Him by the idea which the creation gives; but since they would not, He, after showing by the experiment that they are not sufficient for themselves, conducts them again unto Him by another way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:53
verses.text: He gave for a tablet, the world; but the philosophers studied not in those things, neither were willing to obey Him, nor to approach unto Him by that way which Himself commanded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:54
verses.text: He introduces another way more evident than the former; one that might bring conviction that man is not of himself alone sufficient unto himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:55
verses.text: For then scruples of reasoning might be started, and the Gentile wisdom employed, on their part whom He through the creation was leading by the hand; but now, unless a man become a fool, that is, unless he dismiss all reasoning and all wisdom, and deliver up himself unto the faith, it is impossible to be saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:56
verses.text: You see that besides making the way easy, he hath rooted up hereby no trifling disease, namely, in forbidding to boast, and have high thoughts: "that no flesh should glory:" for hence came the sin, that men insisted on being wiser than the laws of God; not willing so to obtain knowledge as He had enacted: and therefore they did not obtain it at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:57
verses.text: So also was it from the beginning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:58
verses.text: He said unto Adam, "Do such a thing, and such another thou must not do".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:59
verses.text: He, as thinking to find out something more, disobeyed; and even what he had, he lost.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:60
verses.text: He spake unto those that came after, "Rest not in the creature; but by means of it contemplate the Creator".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:61
verses.text: They, forsooth, as if making out something wiser than what had been commanded, set in motion windings innumerable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:62
verses.text: Hence they kept dashing against themselves and one another, and neither found God, nor concerning the creature had any distinct knowledge; nor had any meet and true opinion about it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:63
verses.text: Wherefore again, with a very high hand, (ἐκ πολλοῦ τοῦ περίοντος) lowering their conceit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:64
verses.text: He admitted the uneducated first, showing thereby that all men need the wisdom from above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:65
verses.text: And not only in the matter of knowledge, but also in all other things, both men and all other creatures He hath constituted so as to be in great need of Him; that they might have this also as a most forcible motive of submission and attachment, lest turning away they should perish.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:66
verses.text: For this cause He did not suffer them to be sufficient unto themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:67
verses.text: For if even now many, for all their indigency, despise Him, were the case not so, whither would they not have wandered in haughtiness? So that He stayed them from boasting as they did, not from any grudge to them, but to draw them away from the destruction thence ensuing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:68
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:69
verses.text: "But of Him are ye in Christ Jesus, who was made unto us wisdom from God, and righteousness, and sanctification, and redemption".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:70
verses.text: The expression "of Him," I suppose he uses here, not of our introduction into being, but with reference to the faith: that is, to our having become children of God, "not of blood, nor of the will of the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:71
verses.text: (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:72
verses.text: John i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:73
verses.text: ) "Think not then, that having taken away our glorying, He left us so: for there is another, a greater glorying, His gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:74
verses.text: For ye are the children of Him in whose presence it is not meet to glory, having become so through Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:75
verses.text: And since he has said, "The foolish things of the world He chose, and the base," he signifies that they are nobler than all, having God for their Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:76
verses.text: And of this nobility of ours, not this person or that, but Christ is the cause, having made us wise, and righteous, and holy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:77
verses.text: For so mean the words, "He was made unto us wisdom".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:78
verses.text: Who then is wiser than we are who have not the wisdom of Plato, but Christ Himself, God having so willed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:79
verses.text: But what means, "of God?" Whenever he speaks great things concerning the Only-Begotten, he adds mention of the Father, lest any one should think that the Son is unbegotten.
