verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:80
verses.text: Since therefore he had affirmed His power to be so great, and had referred the whole unto the Son, saying that He had "become wisdom unto us, and righteousness, and sanctification and redemption;"—through the Son again referring the whole to the Father, he saith, "of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:81
verses.text: But why said he not, He hath made us wise, but "was made unto us wisdom?" To show the copiousness of the gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:82
verses.text: As if he had said, He gave unto us Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:83
verses.text: And observe how he goes on in order.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:84
verses.text: For first He made us wise by delivering from error, and then righteous and holy, by giving us the Spirit; and He hath so delivered us from all our evils as to be "of Him," and this is not meant to express communication of being, (οὐσιώσεως) but is spoken concerning the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:85
verses.text: Elsewhere we find him saying, "We were made righteousness in Him;" in these words, "Him who knew no sin He made to be sin for us that we might be made the righteousness of God in Him;" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:86
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:87
verses.text: ) but now he saith, "He hath been made righteousness unto us; so that whosoever will may partake plentifully".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:88
verses.text: For it is not this man or that who hath made us wise, but Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:89
verses.text: "He that glorieth," therefore, "let him glory in Him," not in such or such an one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:90
verses.text: From Christ have proceeded all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:91
verses.text: Wherefore, having said, "Who was made unto us wisdom, and righteousness, and sanctification, and redemption," he added, "that, according as it is written, he that glorieth, let him glory in the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:92
verses.text: For this cause also he had vehemently inveighed against the wisdom of the Greeks, to teach men this lesson, (τοῦτο αὐτὸ Savile; τούτῳ αὐτῶ Bened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:93
verses.text: ) and no other: that (as indeed is no more than just) they should boast themselves in the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:94
verses.text: For when of ourselves we seek the things which are above us, nothing is more foolish, nothing weaker than we are.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:95
verses.text: In such case, a tongue well whetted we may have; but stability of doctrine we cannot have.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:96
verses.text: Rather, reasonings, being alone, are like the webs of spider.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:97
verses.text: For unto such a point of madness have some advanced as to say that there is nothing real in the whole of being: yea, they maintain positively that all things are contrary to what appears.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:98
verses.text: Say not therefore that anything is from thyself, but in all things glory in God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:99
verses.text: Impute unto no man anything at any time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:100
verses.text: For if unto Paul nothing ought to be imputed much less unto any others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:101
verses.text: For, saith he, (ch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:102
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:103
verses.text: ) "I planted, Apollos watered, but God gave the increase".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:104
verses.text: He that hath learnt to make his boast in the Lord, will never be elated, but will be moderate at all times, and thankful under all circumstances.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:105
verses.text: But not such is the mind of the Greeks; they refer all to themselves; wherefore even of men they make gods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:106
verses.text: In so great shame hath desperate arrogance plunged them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:107
verses.text: (ἐξετραχήλισεν)   It is time then, in what remains, to go forth to battle against these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:108
verses.text: Recollect where we left our discourse on the former day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:109
verses.text: We were saying that it was not possible according to human cause and effect that fishermen should get the better of philosophers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:110
verses.text: But nevertheless it became possible: from whence it is clear that by grace it became so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:111
verses.text: We were saying that it was not possible for them even to conceive such great exploits: and we shewed that they not only conceived, but brought them to a conclusion with great ease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:112
verses.text: Let us handle, to-day, the same head of our argument: viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:113
verses.text: From whence did it enter their thoughts to expect to overcome the world, unless they had seen Christ after He was risen? What? Were they beside themselves, to reckon upon any such thing inconsiderately and at random? For it goes even beyond all madness, to look, without Divine grace, for success in so great an undertaking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:114
verses.text: How did they succeed in it, if they were insane and frenzied? But if they were in their sober senses, as indeed the events shewed, how, but on receiving credible pledges from the heavens and enjoying the influence which is from above, did they undertake to go forth to so great wars, and to make their venture against earth and sea, and to strip and stand their ground so nobly, for a change in the customs of the whole world which had been so long time fixed, they being but twelve men?  And, what is more, what made them expect to convince their hearers, by inviting them to heaven and the mansions above? Even had they been brought up in honor, and wealth, and power, and erudition, not even so would it have been at all likely that they should be roused to so burthensome an undertaking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:115
verses.text: However, there would have been somewhat more of reason in their expectation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:116
verses.text: But as the case now stands, some of them had been occupied about lakes, some about hides, some about the customs: than which pursuits nothing is more unprofitable towards philosophy, and the persuading men to have high imaginations: and especially when one hath no example to shew.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:117
verses.text: Nay, they had not only no examples to make their success likely, but they had examples against all likelihood of success, and those within their own doors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:118
verses.text: (ἔναυλα) For many for attempting innovations had been utterly extinguished, I say not among the Greeks, for all that was nothing, but among the Jews themselves at that very time; who not with twelve men, but with great numbers had applied themselves to the work.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:119
verses.text: Thus both Theudas and Judas, having great bodies of men, perished together with their disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:120
verses.text: And the fear arising from their examples was enough to control these, had they not been strongly persuaded that victory without divine power was out of the question.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:121
verses.text: Yea, even if they did expect to prevail, with what sort of hopes undertook they such great dangers, except they had an eye to the world to come? But let us suppose that they hoped for no less than victory; what did they expect to gain from the bringing all men unto Him, "who is not risen again," as ye say? For if now, men who believe concerning the kingdom of heaven and blessings unnumbered with reluctance encounter dangers, how could they have undergone so many for nothing, yea rather, for evil? For if the things which were done did not take place, if Christ did not ascend into heaven; surely in their obstinate zeal to invent these things, and convince all the world of them, they were offending God, and must expect ten thousand thunderbolts from on high.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:122
verses.text: Or, in another point of view; if they had felt this great zeal while Christ was living, yet on His death they would have let it go out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:123
verses.text: For He would have seemed to them, had He not risen, as a sort of deceiver and pretender.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:124
verses.text: Know ye not that armies while the general and king is alive, even though they be weak, keep together; but when those in such office have departed, however strong they may be, they are broken up?  Tell me then, what were the enticing arguments whereupon they acted, when about to take hold of the Gospel, and to go forth unto all the world? Was there any kind of impediment wanting to restrain them? If they had been mad, (for I will not cease repeating it,) they could not have succeeded at all; for no one follows the advice of madmen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:125
verses.text: But if they succeeded as in truth they did succeed, and the event proves, then none so wise as they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:126
verses.text: Now if none were so wise as they, it is quite plain, they would not lightly have entered upon the preaching.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:127
verses.text: Had they not seen Him after He was risen, what was there sufficient to draw them out unto this war? What which would not have turned them away from it? He said unto them, "After three days I will rise again," and He made promises concerning the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:128
verses.text: He said, they should master the whole world, after they had received the Holy Spirit; and ten thousand other things besides these, surpassing all nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:129
verses.text: So that if none of these things had come to pass, although they believed in Him while alive, after His death they would not have believed in Him, unless they had seen Him after He was risen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:130
verses.text: For they have said, "'After three days,' He said, 'I will rise again,' and He hath not arisen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:131
verses.text: He promised that He would give the Spirit, and He hath not sent Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:132
verses.text: How then shall His sayings about the other world find credit with us, when His sayings about this are tried and found wanting?"  And why, if He rose not again, did they preach that He was risen? "Because they loved Him," you will say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:133
verses.text: But surely, it was likely that they would hate Him afterwards, for deceiving and betraying them; and because, having lifted them up with innumerable hopes, and divorced them from house, and parents, and all things, and set in hostility against them the entire nation of Jews, He had betrayed them after all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:134
verses.text: And if indeed the thing were of weakness, they might have pardoned it; but now it would be deemed a result of exceeding malice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:135
verses.text: For He ought to have spoken the truth, and not have promised heaven, being a mortal man, as ye say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:136
verses.text: So that the very opposite was the likely line for them to take; to proclaim the deception, and declare Him a pretender and imposter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:137
verses.text: Thus again would they have been rid of all their perils; thus have put an end to the war.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:138
verses.text: Moreover, seeing that the Jews gave money unto the soldiers to say that they stole the body, if the disciples had come forward and said, "We stole Him, He is not risen again," what honor would they not have enjoyed? Thus it was in their power to be honored, nay, crowned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:139
verses.text: Why then did they for insults and dangers barter away these things, if it was not some Divine power which influenced them, and proved mightier than all these?   But if we do not yet convince, take this also into consideration; that had this not been so, though they were ever so well disposed, they would not have preached this Gospel in His name, but would have treated Him with abhorrence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:140
verses.text: For ye know that not even the names of those who deceive us in this sort are we willing to hear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:141
verses.text: But for what reason preached they also His name? Expecting to gain the mastery through Him? Truly the contrary was natural for them to expect; that even if they had been on the point of prevailing they were ruining themselves by bringing forward the name of a deceiver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:142
verses.text: But if they wished to throw into the shade former events, their line was to be silent; at any rate, to contend for them earnestly was to excite more and more both of serious hostility and of ridicule.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:143
verses.text: From whence then did it enter their thoughts to invent such things? I say, "invent:" for what they had heard, they had forgotten.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:144
verses.text: But if, when there was no fear, they forgot many things, and some did not even understand, (as also the Evangelist himself saith,) now that so great a danger came upon them, how could it be otherwise than that all should fleet away from them? Why speak I of words? when even their love towards their Master Himself began gradually to fade away, through fear of what was coming: wherewith also He upbraided them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:145
verses.text: For since, before this, they hung upon him, and were asking continually, "Whither goest Thou," but afterwards on His drawing out His discourse to so great length, and declaring the terrors which at the very time of the Cross, and after the Cross should befal them, they just continued speechless and frozen through fear;—hear how He alleges to them this very point saying, "None of you asketh Me, Whither goest Thou? But because I have said these things unto you, sorrow hath filled your heart".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:146
verses.text: (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:147
verses.text: John xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:149
verses.text: ) Now if the expectation that He would die and rise again was such a grief to them, had they failed to see Him after He was risen, how could it be less than annihilation? Yea, they would have been fain to sink into the depths of the earth, what with dejection at being so deceived, and what with dread of the future, feeling themselves sorely straightened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:150
verses.text: Again: from whence came their high doctrines? for the higher points, He said, they should hear afterwards.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:151
verses.text: For, saith He, (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:152
verses.text: John xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:153
verses.text: ) "I have many things to speak unto you, but ye cannot bear them now".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:154
verses.text: So that the things not spoken were higher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:155
verses.text: And one of the disciples was not even willing to depart with Him into Judea, when he heard of dangers, but said, "Let us also go that we may die with Him," (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:156
verses.text: John xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:157
verses.text: ) taking it hardly because he expected that he should die.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:158
verses.text: Now if that disciple, while he was with Him, expected to die and shrunk back on that account, what must he not have expected afterwards, when parted from Him and the other disciples, and when the exposure of their shameless conduct was so complete?   Besides, what had they to say when they went forth? For the passion indeed all the world knew: for He had been hanged on high, upon the frame of wood, (ἰκρίου) and in mid-day, and in a chief city, and at a principal feast and that from which it was least permitted that any should be absent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:159
verses.text: But the resurrection no man saw of those who were without: which was no small impediment to them in working conviction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:160
verses.text: Again, that He was buried, was the common talk of all: and that His disciples stole His body, the soldiers and all the Jews declared: but that He had risen again, no one of them who were without knew by sight.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:161
verses.text: Upon what ground then did they expect to convince the world? For if, while miracles were taking place, certain soldiers were persuaded to testify the contrary, upon what ground did these expect without miracles to do the work of preachers, and without having a farthing to convince land and sea concerning the resurrection? Again, if through desire of glory they attempted this, so much the rather would they have ascribed doctrines each one to himself, and not to Him that was dead and gone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:162
verses.text: Will it be said, men would not have believed them? And which of the two was the likelier, being preached, to win their belief? He that was apprehended and crucified, or those who had escaped the hands of the Jews?   Next, tell me with what view were they to take such a course? They did not immediately, leaving Judaea, go into the Gentile cities, but went up and down within its limit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:163
verses.text: But how, unless they worked miracles, did they convince? For if such they really wrought, (and work them they did,) it was the result of God's power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:164
verses.text: If on the other hand they wrought none and prevailed, much more wonderful was the event.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:165
verses.text: Knew they not the Jews—tell me—and their evil practice, and their soul full of grudgings? For they stoned even Moses, (Numb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:166
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:167
verses.text: comp.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:168
verses.text: Exod.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:169
verses.text: xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:170
verses.text: ) after the sea which they had crossed on foot; after the victory, and that marvellous trophy which they raised without blood, by means of his hands, over the Egyptians who had enslaved them; after the manna; after the rocks, and the fountains of rivers which break out thence; after ten thousand miracles in the land of Egypt and the Red Sea and the wilderness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:171
verses.text: Jeremiah they cast into a pit, and many of the prophets they slew.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:172
verses.text: Hear, for example, what saith Elias, after that fearful famine, and the marvellous rain, and the torch which he brought down from heaven, and the strange holocaust; driven, as he was, to the very extreme edge of their country: "Lord, thy prophets they have killed, thine altars they have digged down, and I am left alone, and they seek my life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:173
verses.text: ( Kings xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:174
verses.text: ) Yet were not those (who were so persecuted) disturbing any of the established rules.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:175
verses.text: Tell me then, what ground had men for attending to these of whom we are speaking? For, on one hand, they were meaner persons than any of the prophets; on the other, they were introducing just such novelties as had caused the Jews to nail even their Master to the Cross.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:176
verses.text: And in another way, too, it seemed less unaccountable for Christ to utter such things than for them; for He, they might suppose, acted thus to acquire glory for himself; but these they would have hated even the more, as waging war with them in behalf of another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:177
verses.text: But did the laws of the Romans help them? Nay, by these they were more involved in difficulties.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:178
verses.text: For their language was, (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:179
verses.text: John xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:180
verses.text: ) "Whosoever maketh himself a king is not Caesar's friend".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:181
verses.text: So that this alone was a sufficient impediment to them, that of Him who was accounted an usurper they were first disciples, and afterwards desirous to strengthen His cause.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:182
verses.text: What in the world then set them upon rushing into such great dangers? And by what statements about Him would they be likely to gain credit? that He was crucified? That He was born of a poor Jewish woman who had been betrothed to a Jewish carpenter? That He was of a nation hated by the world? Nay, all these things were enough not only to fail of persuading and attracting the hearers, but also to disgust every one; and especially when affirmed by the tent-maker and the fisherman.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:183
verses.text: Would not the disciples then bear all these things in mind? Timid nature can imagine more than the reality, and such were their natures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:184
verses.text: Upon what ground then did they hope to succeed? Nay, rather, they had no hope, there being things innumerable to draw them aside, if so be that Christ had not risen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:185
verses.text: Is it not quite plain even unto most thoughtless that unless they had enjoyed a copious and mighty grace, and had received pledges of the resurrection, they would have been unable, I say not, to do and undertake these things, but even so much as to have them in their minds? For if when there were so great hinderances, in the way of their planning, I say not of their succeeding, they yet both planned and brought to effect and accomplishing things greater than all expectation, every one, I suppose, can see that not by human power but by divine grace they wrought things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:186
verses.text: Now these arguments we ought to practice, not by ourselves only, but one with another; and thus also the discovery of what remains will be easier to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:187
verses.text: And do not, because thou art an artisan, suppose that this sort of exercise is out of your province; for even Paul was a tent-maker.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:188
verses.text: "Yes," saith some one, "but at that time he was also filled with abundant grace, and out of that he spake all things" Well; but before this grace, he was at the feet of Gamaliel; yea, moreover, and he received the grace, because of this, that he shewed a mind worthy of the grace; and after these things he again put his hand to his craft.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:189
verses.text: Let no one, therefore, of those who have trades be ashamed; but those, who are brought up to nothing and are idle, who employ many attendants, and are served by an immense retinue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:190
verses.text: For to be supported by continual hard work is a sort of asceticism.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:191
verses.text: (φιλοσοφίας ?ἶδος comp.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:192
verses.text: Hooker, E.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:193
verses.text: P.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:194
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:195
verses.text: lxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:196
verses.text: ) The souls of such men are clearer, and their minds better strung.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:197
verses.text: For the man who has nothing to do is apter to say many things at random, and do many things at random; and he is busy all day long about nothing, a huge lethargy taking him up entirely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:198
verses.text: But he that is employed will not lightly entertain in himself any thing useless, in deeds, in words, or in thoughts; for his whole soul is altogether intent upon his laborious way of livelihood.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:199
verses.text: Let us not therefore despise those who support themselves by the labor of their own hands; but let us rather call them happy on this account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:200
verses.text: For tell me, what thanks are due unto thee, when after having received thy portion from thy father, thou goest on not in any calling, but lavishing away the whole of it at random? Knowest thou not that we shall not all have to render the same account, but those who have enjoyed greater licence here a more exact one; those who were afflicted with labor, or poverty, or any thing else of this kind, one not so severe? And this is plain from Lazarus and the rich man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:201
verses.text: For as thou, for neglecting the right use of the leisure, art justly accused; so the poor man, who having full employment hath spent his remnant of time upon right objects, great will be the crowns which he shall receive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:202
verses.text: But dost thou urge that a soldier's duties should at least excuse thee; and dost thou charge them with thy want of leisure? The excuse cannot be founded in reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:203
verses.text: For Cornelius was a centurion, yet in no way did the soldier's belt impair his strict rule of life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:204
verses.text: But thou, when thou art keeping holiday with dancers and players, and making entire waste of thy life upon the stage, never thinkest of excusing thyself from such engagements by the necessity of military service or the fear of rulers: but when it is the Church to which we call you, then occur these endless impediments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:205
verses.text: And what wilt thou say in the day, when thou seest the flame, and the rivers of fire, and the chains never to be broken; and shalt hear the gnashing of teeth? Who shall stand up for thee in that day, when thou shalt see him that hath labored with his own hand and hath lived uprightly, enjoying all glory; but thyself, who art now in soft raiment and redolent of perfumes, in incurable woe? What good will thy wealth and superfluity do thee? And the artisan—what harm will his poverty do him?  Therefore that we may not suffer then, let us fear what is said now, and let all our time be spent in employment on things which are really indispensable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:206
verses.text: For so, having propitiated God in regard of our past sins, and adding good deeds for the future, we shall be able to attain unto the kingdom of heaven: through the favor and loving-kindness, etc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 5:207
verses.text: , etc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:1
verses.text: Homily VII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:3
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:4
verses.text: ,  Howbeit we speak wisdom among the perfect, yet a wisdom not of this world, nor of the rulers of this world, which are coming to naught; but we speak God's wisdom in a mystery, even the wisdom that hath been hidden, which God fore-ordained before the worlds unto our glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:5
verses.text: Darkness seems to be more suitable than light to those that are diseased in their eyesight: wherefore they betake themselves by preference to some room that is thoroughly shaded over.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:6
verses.text: This also is the case with the wisdom which is spiritual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:7
verses.text: As the wisdom which is of God seemed to be foolishness unto those without: so their own wisdom, being foolishness indeed, was accounted by them wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:8
verses.text: The result has been just as if a man having skill in navigation were to promise that without a ship or sails he would pass over a boundless tract of sea, and then endeavor by reasonings to prove that the thing is possible; but some other person, ignorant of it all, committing himself to a ship and a steersman and sailors, were thus to sail in safety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:9
verses.text: For the seeming ignorance of this man is wiser than the wisdom of the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:10
verses.text: For excellent is the art of managing a ship; but when it makes too great professions it is a kind of folly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:11
verses.text: And so is every art which is not contented with its own proper limits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:12
verses.text: Just so the wisdom which is without were wisdom indeed if it had had the benefit of the spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:13
verses.text: But since it trusted all to itself and supposed that it wanted none of that help, it became foolishness, although it seemed to be wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:14
verses.text: Wherefore having first exposed it by the facts, then and not till then he calls it foolishness; and having first called the wisdom of God folly, according to their reckoning, then and not till then he shews it to be wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:15
verses.text: (For after our proofs, not before, we are best able to abash the gainsayers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:16
verses.text: )  His words then are, "Howbeit we speak wisdom among the perfect:" for when I, accounted foolish and a preacher of follies, get the better of the wise, I overcome wisdom, not by foolishness but by a more perfect wisdom; a wisdom, too, so ample and so much greater, that the other appears foolishness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:17
verses.text: Wherefore having before called it by a name such as they named it at that time, and having both proved his victory from the facts, and shewn the extreme foolishness of the other side: he thenceforth bestows upon it its right name, saying, "Howbeit we speak wisdom among the perfect".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:18
verses.text: "Wisdom" is the name he gives to the Gospel, to the method of salvation, the being saved by the Cross.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:19
verses.text: "The perfect," are those who believe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:20
verses.text: For indeed they are "perfect," who know all human things to be utterly helpless, and who overlook them from the conviction that by such they are profited nothing: such were the true believers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:21
verses.text: "But not a wisdom of this world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:22
verses.text: For where is the use of the wisdom which is without, terminating here and proceeding no further, and not even here able to profit its possessors?  Now by the "rulers of the world," here, he means not certain demons, as some suspect, but those in authority, those in power, those who esteem the thing worth contending about, philosophers, rhetoricians and writers of speeches (λογογράφους).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:23
verses.text: For these were the dominant sort and often became leaders of the people.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:24
verses.text: "Rulers of the world" he calls them, because beyond the present world their dominion extends not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:25
verses.text: Wherefore, he adds further, "which are coming to nought;" disparaging it both on its own account, and from those who wield it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:26
verses.text: For having shewn that it is false, that it is foolish, that it can discover nothing, that it is weak, he shews moreover that it is but of short duration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:27
verses.text: "But we speak God's wisdom in a mystery".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:28
verses.text: What mystery? For surely Christ saith, (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:29
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:30
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:31
verses.text: ηκούσατε rec.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:32
verses.text: text ἀκούετε.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:33
verses.text: ) "What ye have heard in the ear, proclaim upon the housetops".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:34
verses.text: How then does he call it "a mystery?" Because that neither angel nor archangel, nor any other created power knew of it before it actually took place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:35
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, (Ephes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:36
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:37
verses.text: ) "That now unto the principalities and powers in heavenly places might be known by the Church the manifold wisdom of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:38
verses.text: And this hath God done in honor to us, so that they not without us should hear the mysteries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:39
verses.text: For we, too, ourselves, whomsoever we make our friends, use to speak of this as a sure proof of friendship towards them, that we tell our secrets to no one in preference to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:40
verses.text: Let those hear who expose to shame the secrets of the Gospel, and unto all indiscriminately display the "pearls" and the doctrine, and who cast "the holy things" unto "dogs," and "swine," and useless reasonings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:41
verses.text: For the Mystery wants no argumentation; but just what it is, that only is to be declared.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:42
verses.text: Since it will not be a mystery, divine and whole in all its parts, when thou addest any thing to it of thyself also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:43
verses.text: And in another sense, too, a mystery is so called; because we do not behold the things which we see, but some things we see and others we believe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:44
verses.text: For such is the nature of our Mysteries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:45
verses.text: I, for instance, feel differently upon these subjects from an unbeliever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:46
verses.text: I hear, "Christ was crucified;" and forthwith I admire His loving-kindness unto men: the other hears, and esteems it weakness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:47
verses.text: I hear, "He became a servant;" and I wonder at his care for us: the other hears, and counts it dishonor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:48
verses.text: I hear, "He died;" and am astonished at His might, that being in death He was not holden, but even broke the bands of death: the other hears, and surmises it to be helplessness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:49
verses.text: He hearing of the resurrection, saith, the thing is a legend; I, aware of the facts which demonstrate it, fall down and worship the dispensation of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:50
verses.text: He hearing of a laver, counts it merely as water: but I behold not simply the thing which is seen, but the purification of the soul which is by the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:51
verses.text: He considers only that my body hath been washed; but I have believed that the soul also hath become both pure and holy; and I count it the sepulchre, the resurrection, the sanctification, the righteousness, the redemption, the adoption, the inheritance, the kingdom of heaven, the plenary effusion (χορηγίαν) of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:52
verses.text: For not by the sight do I judge of the things that appear, but by the eyes of the mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:53
verses.text: I hear of the "Body of Christ:" in one sense I understand the expression, in another sense the unbeliever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:54
verses.text: And just as children, looking on their books, know not the meaning of the letters, neither know what they see; yea more, if even a grown man be unskilful in letters, the same thing will befall him; but the skilful will find much meaning stored up in the letters, even complete lives and histories: and an epistle in the hands of one that is unskilful will be accounted but paper and ink; but he that knows how to read will both hear a voice, and hold converse with the absent, and will reply whatsoever he chooses by means of writing: so it is also in regard of the Mystery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:55
verses.text: Unbelievers albeit they hear, seem not to hear: but the faithful, having the skill which is by the Spirit, behold the meaning of the things stored therein.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:56
verses.text: For instance, it is this very thing that Paul signified, when he said that even now the word preached is hidden: for "unto them that perish," he saith, "it is hidden".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:57
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:58
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:59
verses.text: )  In another point of view, the word indicates also the Gospel's being contrary to all expectation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:60
verses.text: By no other name is Scripture wont to call what happens beyond all hope and above all thought of men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:61
verses.text: Wherefore also in another place, "My mystery is for Me," and for Mine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:62
verses.text: And Paul again, ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:63
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:64
verses.text: ) "Behold, I shew you a mystery: we shall not all sleep, but we shall all be changed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:65
verses.text: And though it be everywhere preached, still is it a mystery; for as we have been commanded, "what things we have heard in the ear, to speak upon the house tops," so have we been also charged, "not to give the holy things unto dogs nor yet to cast our pearls before swine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:66
verses.text: (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:67
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:68
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:69
verses.text: ) For some are carnal and do not understand: others have a veil upon their hearts and do not see: wherefore that is above all things a mystery, which everywhere is preached, but is not known of those who have not a right mind; and is revealed not by wisdom but by the Holy Ghost, so far as is possible for us to receive it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:70
verses.text: And for this cause a man would not err, who in this respect also should entitle it a mystery, the utterance whereof is forbidden.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:71
verses.text: (ἀπόῤῥητον) For not even unto us, the faithful, hath been committed entire certainty and exactness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:72
verses.text: Wherefore Paul also said, (ch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:73
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:74
verses.text: ) "We know in part, and we prophesy in part: for now we see in a mirror darkly; but then face to face".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:75
verses.text: For this cause he saith, "We speak wisdom in a mystery, the hidden wisdom which God fore-ordained before the worlds unto our glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:76
verses.text: Hidden:" that is, that no one of the powers above hath learnt it before us; neither do the many know it now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:77
verses.text: "Which he fore-ordained unto our glory" and yet, elsewhere he saith, "unto his own glory," for he considereth our salvation to be His own glory: even as also He calleth it His own riches, (vid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:78
verses.text: Ephes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:79
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:80
verses.text: ) though He be Himself rich in good and need nothing in order that He may be rich.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:81
verses.text: "Fore-ordained," he saith, pointing out the care had of us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:82
verses.text: For so those are accounted most both to honor and to love us, whosoever shall have laid themselves out to do us good from the very beginning: which indeed is what fathers do in the case of children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:83
verses.text: For although they give not their goods until afterwards, yet at first and from the beginning they had predetermined this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:84
verses.text: And this is what Paul is earnest to point out now; that God always loved us even from the beginning and when as yet we were not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:85
verses.text: For unless He had loved us, He would not have fore-ordained our riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:86
verses.text: Consider not then the enmity which hath come between; for more ancient than that was the friendship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:87
verses.text: As to the words, "before the worlds," (πρὸ τῶν αἰώνων) they mean eternal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:88
verses.text: For in another place also He saith thus, "Who is before the worlds".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:89
verses.text: The Son also, if you mark it, will be found to be eternal in the same sense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:90
verses.text: For concerning Him he saith, (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:91
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:92
verses.text: ) "By Him He made the worlds;" which is equivalent to subsistence before the worlds; for it is plain that the maker is before the things which are made.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:93
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:94
verses.text: "Which none of the rulers of this world knew; for had they known, they would not have crucified the Lord of Glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:95
verses.text: Now if they knew not, how said He unto them, (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:96
verses.text: John vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:97
verses.text: ) "Ye both know Me, and ye know whence I am?" Indeed, concerning Pilate the Scripture saith, he knew not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:98
verses.text: (vid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:99
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:100
verses.text: John xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:101
verses.text: ) It is likely also that neither did Herod know.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:102
verses.text: These, one might say, are called rulers of this world: but if a man were to say that this is spoken concerning the Jews also and the Priests, he would not err.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:103
verses.text: For to these also He saith, (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:104
verses.text: John viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:105
verses.text: ) "Ye know neither Me nor My Father".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:106
verses.text: How then saith He a little before, "Ye both know Me, and ye know whence I am?" However, the manner of this way of knowledge and of that hath already been declared in the Gospel; (Hom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:107
verses.text: on St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:108
verses.text: John,) and, not to be continually handling the same topic, thither do we refer our readers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:109
verses.text: What then? was their sin in the matter of the Cross forgiven them? For He surely did say, "Forgive them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:110
verses.text: (Luke xxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:111
verses.text: ) If they repented, it was forgiven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:112
verses.text: For even he who set countless assailants on Stephen and persecuted the Church, even Paul, became the champion of the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:113
verses.text: Just so then, those others also who chose to repent, had forgiveness: and this indeed Paul himself meant, when he exclaims, (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:114
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:117
verses.text: "I say then, have they stumbled that they should fall? God forbid".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:118
verses.text: "I say then, hath God cast away His people whom He foreknew? God forbid".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:119
verses.text: Then, to shew that their repentance was not precluded, he brought forward as a decisive proof his own conversion, saying, "For I also am an Israelite".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:120
verses.text: As to the words, "They knew not;" they seem to me to be said here not concerning Christ's Person, but only concerning the dispensation hidden in that event: (περὶ αὐτῆς τοῦ πράγματος τῆς οἰκονομὶας) as if he had said, what meant "the death," and the "Cross," they knew not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:121
verses.text: For in that passage also He said not, "They know not Me," but, "They know not what they do;" that is, the dispensation which is being accomplished, and the mystery, they are ignorant of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:122
verses.text: For they knew not that the Cross is to shine forth so brightly; that it is made the salvation of the world, and the reconciliation of God unto men; that their city should be taken; and that they should suffer the extreme of wretchedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:123
verses.text: By the name of "wisdom," he calls both Christ, and the Cross and the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:124
verses.text: Opportunely also he called Him, "The Lord of glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:125
verses.text: For seeing that the Cross is counted a matter of ignominy, he signifies that the Cross was great glory: but that there was need of great wisdom in order not only to know God but also to learn this dispensation of God: and the wisdom which was without turned out an obstacle, not to the former only, but to the latter also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:126
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:127
verses.text: "But as it is written, Things which eye saw not and ear heard not, and which entered not into the heart of man, whatsoever things God prepared for them that love Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:128
verses.text: Where are these words written? Why, it is said to have been "written," then also, when it is set down, not in words, but in actual events, as in the historical books; or when the same meaning is expressed, but not in the very same words, as in this place: for the words, "They to whom it was not told about Him shall see, and they who have not heard shall understand," (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:129
verses.text: lii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:130
verses.text: ; Sept.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:131
verses.text: Comp.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:132
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:133
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:134
verses.text: ; Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:135
verses.text: lxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:136
verses.text: ) are the same with "the things which eye hath not seen, nor ear heard".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:137
verses.text: Either then this is his meaning, or probably it was actually written in some books, and the copies have perished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:138
verses.text: For indeed many books were destroyed, and few were preserved entire even in the first captivity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:139
verses.text: And this is plain, in those which remain to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:140
verses.text: For the Apostle saith (Acts iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:141
verses.text: ) "From Samuel and the Prophets which follow after they have all spoken concerning Him:" and these their words are not entirely extant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:142
verses.text: Paul, however, as being learned in the law and speaking by the Spirit, would of course know all with accuracy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:143
verses.text: And why speak I of the captivity? Even before the captivity many books had disappeared; the Jews having rushed headlong to the last degree of impiety: and this is plain from the end of the fourth book of Kings, ( Kings xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:144
verses.text: ;  Chron.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:145
verses.text: xxxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:146
verses.text: ) for the book of Deuteronomy could hardly be found, having been buried somewhere in a dunghill.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:147
verses.text: And besides, there are in many places double prophecies, easy to be apprehended by the wiser sort; from which we may find out many of the things which are obscure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:148
verses.text: What then, hath "eye not seen what God prepared?" No.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:149
verses.text: For who among men saw the things which were about to be dispensed? Neither then hath "the ear heard, nor hath it entered into the heart of man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:150
verses.text: How is this? For if the Prophets spoke of it, how saith he, "Ear hath not heard, neither hath it entered into the heart of man?" It did not enter; for not of himself alone is he speaking, but of the whole human race.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:151
verses.text: What then? The Prophets, did not they hear? Yes, they heard; but the prophetic ear was not the ear "of man:" for not as men heard they, but as Prophets.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:152
verses.text: Wherefore he said, (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:153
verses.text: l.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:154
verses.text: Sept.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:155
verses.text: ) "He hath added unto me an ear to hear," meaning by "addition" that which was from the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:156
verses.text: From whence it was plain that before hearing it had not entered into the heart of man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:157
verses.text: For after the gift of the Spirit the heart of the Prophets was not the heart of man, but a spiritual heart; as also he saith himself, "We have the mind of Christ" (v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:158
verses.text: ) as if he would say, "Before we had the blessing of the Spirit and learnt the things which no man can speak, no one of us nor yet of the Prophets conceived them in his mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:159
verses.text: How should we? since not even angels know them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:160
verses.text: For what need is there to speak," saith he, "concerning 'the rulers of this world,' seeing that no man knew them, nor yet the powers above?"  What kind of things then are these? That by what is esteemed to be the foolishness of preaching He shall overcome the world, and the nations shall be brought in, and there shall be reconciliation of God with men, and so great blessings shall come upon us! How then have we "known? Unto us," he saith, "God hath revealed them by His Spirit;" not by the wisdom which is without; for this like some dishonored handmaid hath not been permitted to enter in, and stoop down and look into (see St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:161
verses.text: John xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:162
verses.text: ) the mysteries pertaining to the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:163
verses.text: Seest thou how great is the difference between this wisdom and that? The things which angels knew not, these are what she hath taught us: but she that is without, hath done the contrary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:164
verses.text: Not only hath she failed to instruct, but she hindered and obstructed, and after the event sought to obscure His doings, making the Cross of none effect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:165
verses.text: Not then simply by our receiving the knowledge, does he describe the honor vouchsafed to us, nor by our receiving it with angels, but, what is more, by His Spirit conveying it to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:166
verses.text: Then to show its greatness, he saith, If the Spirit which knoweth the secret things of God had not revealed them, we should not have learned them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:167
verses.text: Such an object of care was this whole subject to God, as to be among His secrets.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:168
verses.text: Wherefore we needed also that Teacher who knoweth these things perfectly; for "the Spirit," (v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:170
verses.text: ) saith he, "searcheth all things, even the deep things of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:171
verses.text: For the word "to search" is here indicative not of ignorance, but of accurate knowledge: it is the very same mode of speaking which he used even of God, saying, "He that searcheth the hearts knoweth what is the mind of the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:172
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:173
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:174
verses.text: ) Then having spoken with exactness concerning the knowledge of the Spirit, and having pointed out that it is as fully equal to God's knowledge, as the knowledge of a man itself to itself; and also, that we have learned all things from it and necessarily from it; he added, "which things also we speak, not in words which man's wisdom teacheth, but which the Holy Ghost teacheth; comparing spiritual things with spiritual".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:175
verses.text: Seest thou to what point he exalted us because of the Teacher's dignity? For so much are we wiser than they as there is difference between Plato and the Holy Spirit; they having for masters the heathen rhetoricians but we, the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:176
verses.text: But what is this, "comparing spiritual things with spiritual?" When a thing is spiritual and of dubious meaning, we adduce testimonies from the things which are spiritual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:177
verses.text: For instance, I say, Christ rose again—was born of a Virgin; I adduce testimonies and types and demonstrations; the abode of Jonah in the whale and his deliverance afterwards; the child-bearing of the barren, Sarah, Rebecca, and the rest; the springing up of the trees which took place in paradise (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:178
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:179
verses.text: ) when there had been no seeds sown, no rains sent down, no furrow drawn along.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:180
verses.text: For the things to come were fashioned out and figured forth, as in shadow, by the former things, that these which are now might be believed when they came in.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:181
verses.text: And again we shew, how of the earth was man, and how of man alone the woman; and this without any intercourse whatever; how the earth itself of nothing, the power of the Great Artificer being every where sufficient for all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:182
verses.text: Thus "with spiritual things" do I "compare spiritual," and in no instance have I need of the Wisdom which is without—neither its reasonings nor its embellishments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:183
verses.text: For such persons do but agitate the weak understanding and confuse it; and are not able to demonstrate clearly any one of the things which they affirm, but even have the contrary effect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:184
verses.text: They rather disturb the mind and fill it with darkness and much perplexity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:185
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, "with spiritual things comparing spiritual".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:186
verses.text: Seest thou how superfluous he sheweth it to be? and not only superfluous, but even hostile and injurious: for this is meant by the expressions, "lest the Cross of Christ be made of none effect," and, "that our ('your faith,' rec.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:187
verses.text: text) faith should not stand in the wisdom of men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:188
verses.text: And he points out here, that it is impossible for those who confidently entrust every thing to it, to learn any useful thing: for   Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:189
verses.text: "The natural man receiveth not the things of the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:190
verses.text: It is necessary then to lay it aside first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:191
verses.text: "What then," some man will say; "is the wisdom from without stigmatized? And yet it is the work of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:192
verses.text: How is this clear? since He made it not, but it was an invention of thine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:193
verses.text: For in this place he calls by the term "wisdom" curious research and superfluous elegance of words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:194
verses.text: But should any one say that he means the human understanding; even in this sense the fault is thine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:195
verses.text: For thou bringest a bad name upon it, who makest a bad use of it; who to the injury and thwarting of God demandest from it things which indeed it never had.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:196
verses.text: Since then thou boastest therein and fightest with God, He hath exposed its weakness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:197
verses.text: For strength of body also is an excellent thing, but when Cain used it not as he ought, God disabled him and made him tremble (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:198
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:200
verses.text: Sept.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:201
verses.text: "sighing and trembling," rec.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:202
verses.text: ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:203
verses.text: "fugitive and vagabond".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:204
verses.text: ) Wine also is a good thing; but because the Jews indulged in it immoderately, God prohibited the priests entirely from the use of the fruit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:205
verses.text: And since thou also hast abused wisdom unto the rejecting of God, and hast demanded of it more than it can do of its own strength; in order to withdraw thee from human hope, he hath shewed thee its weakness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:206
verses.text: For (to proceed) he is "a natural man," who attributes every thing to reasonings of the mind and considers not that he needs help from above; which is a mark of sheer folly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:207
verses.text: For God bestowed it that it might learn and receive help from Him, not that it should consider itself sufficient unto itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:208
verses.text: For eyes are beautiful and useful, but should they choose to see without light, their beauty profits them nothing; nor yet their natural force, but even doth harm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:209
verses.text: So if you mark it, any soul also, if it choose to see without the Spirit, becomes even an impediment unto itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:210
verses.text: "How then, before this," it will be said, "did she see all things of herself?" Never at any time did she this of herself but she had creation for a book set before her in open view.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:211
verses.text: But when men having left off to walk in the way which God commanded them, and by the beauty of visible objects to know the Great Artificer, had entrusted to disputations the leading-staff of knowledge; they became weak and sank in a sea of ungodliness; for they presently brought in that which was the abyss of all evil, asserting that nothing was produced from things which were not, but from uncreated matter; and from this source they became the parents of ten thousand heresies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:212
verses.text: Moreover, in their extreme absurdities they agreed; but in those things wherein they seemed to dream out something wholesome, though it were only as in shadows, they fell out with one another; that on both sides they might be laughed to scorn.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:213
verses.text: For that out of things which are not nothing is produced, nearly all with one accord have asserted and written; and this with great zeal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:214
verses.text: In these absurdities then they were urged on by the Devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:215
verses.text: But in their profitable sayings, wherein they seemed, though it were but darkly, (ἐν αἰνίγματι,) to find some part of what they sought, in these they waged war with one another: for instance, that the soul is immortal; that virtue needs nothing external; and that the being good or the contrary is not of necessity nor of fate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:216
verses.text: Dost thou see the craft of the Devil? If any where he saw men speaking any thing corrupt, he made all to be of one mind; but if any where speaking any thing sound, he raised up others against them; so that the absurdities did not fail, being confirmed by the general consent, and the profitable parts died away, being variously understood.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:217
verses.text: Observe how in every respect the soul is unstrung, (ἄτονος) and is not sufficient unto herself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:218
verses.text: And this fell out as one might expect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:219
verses.text: For if, being such as she is, she aspire to have need of nothing and withdraw herself from God; suppose her not fallen into that condition, and into what extreme madness would she not have insensibly sunk? If, endowed with a mortal body, she expected greater things from the false promise of the Devil—(for, "Ye shall be," said he, "as gods" Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:220
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:221
verses.text: )—to what extent would she not have cast herself away, had she received her body also, from the beginning, immortal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:222
verses.text: For, even after that, she asserted herself to be unbegotten and of the essence of God, through the corrupt mouth of the Manicheans, and it was this distemperature which gave occasion to her invention of the Grecian gods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:223
verses.text: On this account, as it seems to me, God made virtue laborious, with a view to bow down the soul and to bring it to moderation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:224
verses.text: And that thou mayest convince thyself that this is true, (as far as from trifles ones may guess at any thing great,) let us learn it from the Israelites.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:225
verses.text: They, it is well known, when they led not a life of toil but indulged in relaxation, not being able to bear prosperity, fell away into ungodliness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:226
verses.text: What then did God upon this? He laid upon them a multitude of laws with a view to restrain their licence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:227
verses.text: And to convince you that these laws contribute not to any virtue, but were given to them as a sort of curb, providing them with an occasion of perpetual labor; hear what saith the prophet concerning them; "I gave them statutes which were not good".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:228
verses.text: Ezek.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:229
verses.text: xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:230
verses.text: What means, "not good?" Such as did not much contribute towards virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:231
verses.text: Wherefore he adds also, "and ordinances whereby they shall not live".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:232
verses.text: "But the natural man receiveth not the things of the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:233
verses.text: For as with these eyes no man could learn the things in the heavens; so neither the soul unaided the things of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:234
verses.text: And why speak I of the things in heaven? It receives not even those in earth, all of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:235
verses.text: For beholding afar off a square tower, we think it to be round; but such an opinion is mere deception of the eyes: so also we may be sure, when a man by means of his understanding alone examines the things which are afar off much ridicule will ensue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:236
verses.text: For not only will he not see them such as indeed they are, but will even account them the contraries of what they are.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:237
verses.text: Wherefore he added, "for they are foolishness unto him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:238
verses.text: But this comes not of the nature of the things, but of his infirmity, unable as he is to attain to their greatness through the eyes of his soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:239
verses.text: Next, pursuing his contrast, he states the cause of this, saying, "he knoweth not because they are spiritually discerned:" i-e: the things asserted require faith, and to apprehend them by reasonings is not possible, for their magnitude exceeds by a great deal the meanness of our understanding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:240
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, "but he that is spiritual judgeth all things, yet he himself is judged of no man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:241
verses.text: For he that has sight, beholds himself all things that appertain to the man that has no sight; but no sightless person discerns what the other is about.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:242
verses.text: So also in the case before us, our own matters and those of unbelievers, all of them we for our part know; but ours, they know not henceforth any more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:243
verses.text: We know what is the nature of things present, what the dignity of things to come; and what some day shall become of the world when this state of things shall be no more, and what sinners shall suffer, and the righteous shall enjoy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:244
verses.text: And that things present are nothing worth, we both know, and their meanness we expose; (for to "discern" is also to expose;) (ἀνακρίνειν, ἐλέγχειν) and that the things to come are immortal and immoveable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:245
verses.text: All these things are known to the spiritual man; and what the natural man shall suffer when he is departed into that world; and what the faithful shall enjoy when he hath fulfilled his journey from this: none of which are known to the natural man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:246
verses.text: Wherefore also, subjoining a plain demonstration of what had been affirmed, he saith, "For who hath known the mind of the Lord, that he may instruct Him? But we have the mind of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:247
verses.text: That is to say, the things which are in the mind of Christ, these we know, even the very things which He willeth and hath revealed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:248
verses.text: For since he had said, "the Spirit had revealed them;" lest any one should set aside the Son, he subjoins that Christ also shewed us these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:249
verses.text: Not meaning this, that all the things which He knoweth, we know; but that all the things which we know are not human so as to be open to suspicion, but of His mind and spiritual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:250
verses.text: For the mind which we have about these things we have of Christ; that is, the knowledge which we have concerning the things of the faith is spiritual; so that with reason we are "judged of no man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:251
verses.text: For it is not possible that a natural man should know divine things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:252
verses.text: Wherefore also he said, "For who hath known the mind of the Lord?" implying that our own mind which we have about these things, is His mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:253
verses.text: And this, "that he may instruct Him," he hath not added without reason, but with reference to what he had just now said, "the spiritual man no one discerneth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:254
verses.text: For if no man is able to know the mind of God, much less can he teach and correct it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:255
verses.text: For this is the meaning of, "that he may instruct Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:256
verses.text: Seest thou how from every quarter he repels the wisdom which is without, and shews that the spiritual man knoweth more things and greater? For seeing that those reasons, "That no flesh should glory;" and, "For this cause hath He chosen the foolish things, that He might confound the wise men;" and, "Lest the Cross of Christ should be made void:" seemed not to the unbelievers greatly worthy of credit, nor yet attractive, or necessary, or useful, he finishes by laying down the principal reason; because in this way we most easily see from Whom we may have the means of learning even high things, and things secret, and things which are above us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:257
verses.text: For reason was absolutely made of none effect by our inability to apprehend through Gentile wisdom the things above us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:258
verses.text: You may observe, too, that it was more advantageous to learn in this way from the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:259
verses.text: For that is the easiest and clearest of all teaching.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:260
verses.text: "But we have the mind of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:261
verses.text: That is, spiritual, divine, that which hath nothing human.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:262
verses.text: For it is not of Plato, nor of Pythagoras, but it is Christ Himself, putting His own things into our mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:263
verses.text: This then, if naught else, let us revere, O beloved, and let our life shine forth as most excellent; since He also Himself maketh this a sure proof of great friendship, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:264
verses.text: the revealing His secrets unto us: where He saith, (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:265
verses.text: John xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:266
verses.text: ) "Henceforth I call you not servants, for all ye are My friends; for all things which I have heard from My Father I have told unto you:" that is, I have had confidence towards you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:267
verses.text: Now if this by itself is a proof of friendship, namely, to have confidence: when it appears that He has not only confided to us the mysteries conveyed by words, (τὰ διὰ ῥημάτων μυστηρία) but also imparted to us the same conveyed by works, (διὰ τῶν ἔργων, i-e: sacramental actions) consider how vast the love of which this is the fruit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:268
verses.text: This, if nothing else, let us revere; even though we will not make any such great account of hell, yet let it be more fearful than hell to be thankless and ungrateful to such a friend and benefactor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:269
