verses.text: And not as hired servants, but as sons and freemen, let us do all things for the love of our Father; and let us at last cease from adhering to the world that we may put the Greeks also to shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:270
verses.text: For even now desiring to put out my strength against them, I shrink from so doing, lest haply, surpass them as we may by our arguments and the truth of what we teach, we bring upon ourselves much derision from the comparison of our way of life; seeing that they indeed, cleaving unto error and having no such conviction, abide by philosophy, but we do just the contrary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:271
verses.text: However, I will say it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:272
verses.text: For it may be, it may be that in practising how to contend against them, we shall long as rivals to become better than they in our mode of life also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:273
verses.text: I was saying not long ago, that it would not have entered the Apostles' thoughts to preach what they did preach, had they not enjoyed Divine Grace; and that so far from succeeding, they would not even have devised such a thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:274
verses.text: Well then, let us also to-day prosecute the same subject in our discourse; and let us shew that it was a thing impossible so much as to be chosen or thought of by them, if they had not had Christ among them: not because they were arrayed, the weak against the strong, not because few against many, not because poor against rich, not because unlearned against wise, but because the strength of their prejudice, too, was great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:275
verses.text: For ye know that nothing is so strong with men as the tyranny of ancient custom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:276
verses.text: So that although they had not been twelve only, and not so contemptible, and such as they really were, but another world as large as this, and with an equivalent number arrayed on their side, or even much greater; even in this case the result would have been hard to achieve.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:277
verses.text: For the other party had custom on their side, but to these their novelty was an obstacle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:278
verses.text: For nothing so much disturbs the mind, though it be done for some beneficial purpose, as to innovate and introduce strange things, and most of all when this is done in matters relating to divine worship and the glory of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:279
verses.text: And how great force there is in this circumstance I will now make plain; first having made the following statement that there was added also another difficulty with regard to the Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:280
verses.text: For in the case of the Greeks, they destroyed both their gods and their doctrines altogether; but not so did they dispute with the Jews, but many of their doctrines they abolished, while the God who had enacted the same they bade them worship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:281
verses.text: And affirming that men should honor the legislator, they said, "obey not in all respects the law which is of Him;" for instance, in the keeping the Sabbath, or observing circumcision, or offering sacrifices, or doing any other like thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:282
verses.text: So that not only was custom an impediment, but also the fact, that when they bade men worship God, they bade them break many of His laws.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:283
verses.text: But in the case of the Greeks great was the tyranny of custom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:284
verses.text: For if it had been a custom of ten years only, I say not of such a length of time, and if it had preoccupied but a few men, I say not the whole world, when these persons made their approaches; even in this case the revolution would have been hard to effect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:285
verses.text: But now sophists, and orators, and fathers, and grandfathers, and many more ancient than all these, had been preoccupied by the error: the very earth and sea, and mountains and groves, and all nations of Barbarians, and all tribes of the Greeks, and wise men and ignorant, rulers and subjects, women and men, young and old, masters and slaves, artificers and husbandmen, dwellers in cities and in the country; all of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:286
verses.text: And those who were instructed would naturally say, "What in the world is this? Have all that dwell in the world been deceived? both sophists and orators, philosophers and historians, the present generation and they who were before this, Pythagoreans, Platonists, generals, consuls, kings, they who in all cities from the beginning were citizens and colonists, both Barbarians and Greeks? And are the twelve fishermen and tent-makers and publicans wiser than all these? Why, who could endure such a statement?" However, they spake not so, nor had it in their mind, but did endure them, and owned that they were wiser than all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:287
verses.text: Wherefore they overcame even all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:288
verses.text: And custom was no impediment to this, though accounted invincible when she hath acquired her full swing by course of time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:289
verses.text: And that thou mayest learn how great is the strength of custom, it hath oftentimes prevailed over the commands of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:290
verses.text: And why do I say, commands? Even over very blessings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:291
verses.text: For so the Jews when they had manna, required garlic; enjoying liberty they were mindful of their slavery; and they were continually longing for Egypt, because they were accustomed to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:292
verses.text: Such a tyrannical thing is custom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:293
verses.text: If thou desire to hear of it from the heathens also; it is said that Plato, although well aware that all about the gods was a sort of imposture, condescended to all the feasts and all the rest of it, as being unable to contend with custom; and as having in fact learnt this from his master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:294
verses.text: For he, too, being suspected of some such innovation, was so far from succeeding in what he desired that he even lost his life; and this, too, after making his defence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:295
verses.text: And how many men do we see now by prejudice held in idolatry, and having nothing plausible to say, when they are charged with being Greeks, but alleging the fathers, and grandfathers, and great grandfathers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:296
verses.text: For no other reason did some of the heathens call custom, second nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:297
verses.text: But when doctrines are the subject-matter of the custom, it becomes yet more deeply rooted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:298
verses.text: For a man would change all things more easily than those pertaining to religion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:299
verses.text: The feeling of shame, too, coupled with custom, was enough to raise an obstacle; and the seeming to learn a new lesson in extreme old age, and that of those who were not so intelligent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:300
verses.text: And why wonder, should this happen in regard of the soul, seeing that even in the body custom hath great force?   In the Apostles' case, however, there was yet another obstacle, more powerful than these; it was not merely changing custom so ancient and primitive, but there were perils also under which the change was effected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:301
verses.text: For they were not simply drawing men from one custom to another, but from a custom, wherein was no fear to an undertaking which held out threats of danger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:302
verses.text: For the believer must immediately incur confiscation, persecution, exile from his country; must suffer the worst ills, be hated of all men, be a common enemy both to his own people and to strangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:303
verses.text: So that even if they had invited men to a customary thing out of novelty, even in this case it would have been a difficult matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:304
verses.text: But when it was from a custom to an innovation, and with all these terrors to boot, consider how vast was the obstacle!  And again, another thing, not less than those mentioned, was added to make the change difficult.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:305
verses.text: For besides the custom and the dangers, these precepts were both more burdensome, and those from which they withdrew men were easy and light.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:306
verses.text: For their call was from fornication unto chastity; from love of life unto sundry kinds of death; from drunkenness unto fasting; from laughter unto tears and compunction; from covetousness unto utter indigence; from safety unto dangers: and throughout all they required the strictest circumspection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:307
verses.text: For, "Filthiness," (Ephes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:308
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:309
verses.text: ) saith he, "and foolish talking, and jesting, let it not proceed out of your mouth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:310
verses.text: And these things they spake unto those who knew nothing else than how to be drunken and serve their bellies; who celebrated feasts made up of nothing but of "filthiness" and laughter and all manner of revellings (κωμῳδίας ἁπάσης.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:311
verses.text: ) So that not only from the matter pertaining to severity of life were the doctrines burthensome, but also from their being spoken unto men who had been brought up in careless ease, and "filthiness," and "foolish talking," and laughter and revellings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:312
verses.text: For who among those who had lived in these things, when he heard, (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:313
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:314
verses.text: ) "If a man take not up his cross and follow Me, he is not worthy of Me;" and, (Ibid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:315
verses.text: ) "I came not to send peace but a sword, and to set a man at variance with his father, and the daughter at variance with her mother," would not have felt himself chilled all over (ἐνάρκησε)? And who, when he heard, "If a man bid not farewell to home and country and possessions, he is not worthy of Me," would not have hesitated, would not have refused? And yet there were men, who not only felt no chill, neither shrunk away when they heard these things, but ran to meet them and rushed upon the hardships, and eagerly caught at the precepts enjoined.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:316
verses.text: Again, to be told, "For every idle word we shall give account;" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:317
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:318
verses.text: ) and, "whosoever looketh upon a woman to lust after her, hath committed adultery with her as soon as seen;" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:319
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:321
verses.text: ) and, "whosoever is angry without cause shall fall into hell;"—which of the men of that day would not these things have frightened off? And yet all came running in, and many even leaped over the boundaries of the course.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:322
verses.text: What then was their attraction? Was it not, plainly, the power of Him who was preached? For suppose that the case were not as it is, but just contrary, that this side was the other, and the other this; would it have been easy, let me ask, to hold fast and to drag on those who resisted? We cannot say so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:323
verses.text: So that in every way that power is proved divine which wrought so excellently.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:324
verses.text: Else how, tell me, did they prevail with the frivolous and the dissolute, urging them toward the severe and rough course of life?   Well; such was the nature of the precepts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:325
verses.text: But let us see whether the doctrine was attractive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:326
verses.text: Nay, in this respect also there was enough to frighten away the unbelievers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:327
verses.text: For what said the preachers? That we must worship the crucified, and count Him as God, who was born of a Jewish woman.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:328
verses.text: Now who would have been persuaded by these words, unless divine power had led the way? That indeed He had been crucified and buried, all men knew; but that He had risen again and ascended, no one save the Apostles had seen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:329
verses.text: But, you will say, they excited them by promises and deceived them by an empty sound of words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:330
verses.text: Nay, this very topic most particularly shews (even apart from all that has been said) that our doctrines are no deceit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:331
verses.text: For all its hardships took place here, but its consolations they were to promise after the resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:332
verses.text: This very thing then, for I repeat it, shews that our Gospel is divine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:333
verses.text: For why did no one of the believers say, "I close not with this, neither do I endure it? Thou threatenest me with hardships here, and the good things thou promisest after the resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:334
verses.text: Why, how is it plain that there will be a resurrection? Which of the departed hath returned? Which of those at rest hath risen again? Which of these hath said what shall be after our departure hence?" But none of these things entered into their minds; rather they gave up their very lives for the Crucified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:335
verses.text: So that this bare fact was more than anything a proof of great power; first, their working conviction at once, touching matters so important, in persons that had never in their lives before heard of any such thing; secondly, that they prevailed on them to take the difficulties upon trial, and to account the blessings as matter of hope.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:336
verses.text: Now if they had been deceivers they would have done the contrary: their good things they would have promised as of this world (ἐντεῦθεν, so St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:337
verses.text: John xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:338
verses.text: ); the fearful things they would not have mentioned, whether they related to the present life or the future.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:339
verses.text: For so deceivers and flatterers act.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:340
verses.text: Nothing harsh, nor galling, nor burdensome, do they hold out, but altogether the contrary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:341
verses.text: For this is the nature of deceit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:342
verses.text: But "the folly," it will be said, "of the greater part caused them to believe what they were told".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:343
verses.text: How sayest thou? When they were under Greeks, they were not foolish; but when they came over to us, did their folly then begin? And yet they were not men of another sort nor out of another world, that the Apostles took and persuaded: they were men too who simply held the opinions of the Greeks, but ours they received with the accompaniment of dangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:344
verses.text: So that if with better reason they had maintained the former, they would not have swerved from them, now that they had so long time been educated therein; and especially as not without danger was it possible to swerve.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:345
verses.text: But when they came to know from the very nature of the things that all on that side was mockery and delusion, upon this, even under menaces of sundry deaths, they sprang off (ἀπεπήδησαν) from their customary ways, and came over voluntarily unto the new; inasmuch as the latter doctrine was according to nature, but the other contrary to nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:346
verses.text: But "the persons convinced," it is said, "were slaves, and woman, and nurses, and midwives, and eunuchs".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:347
verses.text: Now in the first place, not of these alone doth our Church consist; and this is plain unto all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:348
verses.text: But be it of these; this is what especially makes the Gospel worthy of admiration; that such doctrines as Plato and his followers could not apprehend, the fishermen had power on a sudden to persuade the most ignorant sort of all to receive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:349
verses.text: For if they had persuaded wise men only, the result would not have been so wonderful; but in advancing slaves, and nurses, and eunuchs unto such great severity of life as to make them rivals to angels, they offered the greatest proof of their divine inspiration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:350
verses.text: Again; had they enjoined I know not what trifling matters, it were reasonable perhaps to bring forward the conviction wrought in these persons, to show the trifling nature of the things which were spoken: but if things great, and high, and almost transcending human nature, and requiring high thoughts, were the matter of their lessons of wisdom; the more foolishness thou showest in those who were convinced, by so much the more dost thou shew clearly that they who wrought the conviction were wise and filled with divine grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:351
verses.text: But, you will say, they prevailed on them through the excessive greatness of the promises.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:352
verses.text: But tell me, is not this very thing a wonder to thee, how they persuaded men to expect prizes and recompenses after death? For this, were there nothing else, is to me matter of amazement.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:353
verses.text: But this, too, it will be said, came of folly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:354
verses.text: Inform me wherein is the folly of these things: that the soul is immortal; that an impartial tribunal will receive us after the present life; that we shall render an account of our deeds and words and thoughts unto God that knoweth all secrets; that we shall see the evil undergoing punishment, and the good with crowns on their heads.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:355
verses.text: Nay, these things are not of folly, but the highest instruction of wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:356
verses.text: The folly is in the contrary opinions to these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:357
verses.text: Were this then the only thing, the despising of things present, the setting much by virtue, the not seeking rewards here, but advancing far beyond in hopes, and the keeping the soul so intent and faithful as by no present terror to be hindered in respect of the hope of what shall be; tell me, to what high philosophy must this belong? But would you also learn the force of the promises and predictions in themselves, and the truth of those uttered both before and after this present state of things? Behold, I shew you a golden chain, woven cunningly from the beginning! He spake some things to them about Himself, and about the churches, and about the things to come; and as He spake, He wrought mighty works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:358
verses.text: By the fulfilment therefore of what He said, it is plain that both the wonders wrought were real, and the future and promised things also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:359
verses.text: But that my meaning may be yet plainer, let me illustrate it from the actual case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:360
verses.text: He raised up Lazarus by a single word merely, and shewed him alive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:361
verses.text: Again, He said, "The gates of Hades shall not prevail against the Church (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:362
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:363
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:364
verses.text: ) and, "He that forsaketh father or mother, shall receive an hundred-fold in this life, and shall inherit everlasting life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:365
verses.text: (ib) The miracle then is one, the raising of Lazarus; but the predictions are two; made evident, the one here, the other in the world to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:366
verses.text: Consider now, how they are all proved by one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:367
verses.text: For if a man disbelieve the resurrection of Lazarus, from the prophecy uttered about the Church let him learn to believe the miracle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:368
verses.text: For the word spoken so many years before, came to pass then, and received accomplishment: for "the gates of Hades prevailed not against the Church".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:369
verses.text: You see that He who spake truth in the prophecy, it is clear that he also wrought the miracle: and He who both wrought the miracle and brings to accomplishment the words which He spake, it is clear that He speaks the truth also in the predictions of things yet to come, when He saith, "He who despiseth things present shall receive an hundred-fold, and shall inherit everlasting life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:370
verses.text: For the things which have been already done and spoken, He hath given as the surest pledges of those which shall hereafter come to pass.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:371
verses.text: Of all these things then, and the like to these, collecting them together out of the Gospels, let us tell them, and so stop their mouths.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:372
verses.text: But if any one say, Why then was not error completely extinguished? this may be our answer: Ye yourselves are to blame, who rebel against your own salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:373
verses.text: For God hath so ordered this matter (ᾠκονόμησεν,) that not even a remnant of the old impiety need be left.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:374
verses.text: Now, briefly to recount what has been said: What is the natural course of things? That the weak should be overcome by the strong, or the contrary? Those who speak things easy, or things of the harsher sort? those who attract men with dangers, or with security? innovators, or those who strengthen custom? those who lead into a rough, or into a smooth way? those who withdraw men from the institutions of their fathers, or those who lay down no strange laws? those who promise all their good things after our departure from this world, or those who flatter in the present life? the few to overcome the many, or the many the few?  But you, too, saith one, gave promises pertaining to this life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:375
verses.text: What then have we promised in this life? The forgiveness of sins and the laver of regeneration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:376
verses.text: Now in the first place, baptism itself hath its chief part in things to come; and Paul exclaims, saying, (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:377
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:378
verses.text: ) "For ye died, and your life is hid with Christ in God: when your life shall be manifested, then shall ye also with Him be manifested in glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:379
verses.text: But if in this life also it hath advantages, as indeed it hath, this also is more than all a matter of great wonder, that they had power to persuade men who had done innumerable evil deeds, yea such as no one else had done, that they should wash themselves clean of all, and they should give account of none of their offences.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:380
verses.text: So that on this very account it were most of all meet to wonder that they persuaded Barbarians to embrace such a faith as this, and to have good hopes concerning things to come; and having thrown off the former burden of their sins, to apply themselves with the greatest zeal for the time to come to those toils which virtue requires, and not to gape after any object of sense, but rising to a height above all bodily things, to receive gifts purely spiritual: yea, that the Persian, the Sarmatian, the Moor, and the Indian should be acquainted with the purification of the soul, and the power of God, and His unspeakable mercy to men, and the severe discipline of faith, and the visitation of the Holy Spirit, and the resurrection of bodies, and the doctrines of life eternal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:381
verses.text: For in all these things, and in whatever is more than these, the fishermen, initiating by Baptism divers races of Barbarians, persuaded them (φιλοσοφεῖν) to live on high principles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:382
verses.text: Of all these things then, having observed them accurately, let us speak unto the Gentiles, and again, let us shew them the evidence of our lives: that by both means we ourselves may be saved and they drawn over by our means unto the glory of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 6:383
verses.text: For unto Him be the glory for ever, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:1
verses.text: Homily VIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:3
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:4
verses.text: –  And I, brethren, could not speak unto you as unto spiritual, but as unto Carnal, as unto babes in Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:5
verses.text: I fed you with milk, and not with meat: for ye were not yet able to bear it; nay, not even now are ye able.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:6
verses.text: For ye are yet carnal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:7
verses.text: After having overturned the philosophy which is from without, and cast down all its arrogance, he comes unto another argument.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:8
verses.text: For it was likely that they would say, "If we were putting forth the opinions of Plato, or of Pythagoras, or any other of the philosophers, reason were thou shouldest draw out such a long discourse against us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:9
verses.text: But if we announce the things of the Spirit, for what reason dost thou turn and toss up and down (ἄνω καὶ κάτω στρέφεις) the wisdom which is from without?"  Hear then how he makes his stand against this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:10
verses.text: "And I, brethren, could not speak unto you as unto spiritual".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:11
verses.text: Why, in the first place, says he, though you had been perfect in spiritual things also, not even so ought you to be elated; for what you preach is not your own, nor such as yourselves have found from your own means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:12
verses.text: But now even these things ye know not as ye ought to know them, but ye are learners, and the last of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:13
verses.text: Whether therefore the Gentile wisdom be the occasion of your high imaginations; that hath been proved to be nothing, nay, in regard to spiritual things to be even contrary unto us: or if it be on account of things spiritual, in these, too, ye come short and have your place among the hindmost.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:14
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, "I could not speak unto you as unto spiritual".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:15
verses.text: He said not, "I did not speak," lest the thing might seem to proceed from his grudging them somewhat; but in two ways he brings down their high spirit; first, because they knew not the things that are perfect; next, because their ignorance was owing to themselves: yea, in a third way besides these, by pointing out that "not even now are they able to bear it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:16
verses.text: For as to their want of ability at first, that perhaps arose from the nature of the case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:17
verses.text: In fact, however, he does not leave them even this excuse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:18
verses.text: For not through any inability on their part to receive high doctrines, doth he say they received them not, but because they were "carnal".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:19
verses.text: However, in the beginning this was not so blame-worthy; but that after so long a time, they had not yet arrived at the more perfect knowledge, this was a symptom of most utter dulness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:20
verses.text: It may be observed, that he brings the same charge against the Hebrews, not however, with so much vehemence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:21
verses.text: For those, he saith, are such, partly because of tribulation: but these, because of some appetite for wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:22
verses.text: Now the two things are not the same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:23
verses.text: He implies too, that in the one case he was intending rebuke, in the other rather stirring them up, when he spake these words of truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:24
verses.text: For to these Corinthians he saith, "Neither yet now are ye able;" but unto the others (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:25
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:26
verses.text: ) "Wherefore let us cease to speak of the first principles of Christ, and press on unto perfection:" and again, (Ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:27
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:28
verses.text: ) "we are persuaded better things concerning you, and things which accompany salvation, though we thus speak".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:29
verses.text: And how calleth he those "carnal," who had attained so large a measure of the Spirit; and into whose praises, at the beginning he had entered so much at large? Because they also were carnal, unto whom the Lord saith, (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:30
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:31
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:33
verses.text: ) "Depart from Me, ye workers of iniquity, I know you not;" and yet they both cast out devils, and raised the dead, and uttered prophecies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:34
verses.text: So that it is possible even for one who wrought miracles to be carnal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:35
verses.text: For so God wrought by Balaam, and unto Pharaoh He revealed things to come, and unto Nebuchadnezzar; and Caiaphas prophesied, not knowing what he said; yea, and some others cast out devils in His name, though they were (Luke ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:36
verses.text: ) "not with Him;" since not for the doers' sake are these things done, but for others' sake: nor is it seldom, that those who were positively unworthy have been made instrumental to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:37
verses.text: Now why wonder, if in the case of unworthy men these things are done for others' sake, seeing that so it is, even when they are wrought by saints? For Paul saith, ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:38
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:39
verses.text: ) "All things are yours; whether Paul, or Apollos, or Cephas, or life, or death:" and again, (Ephes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:40
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:42
verses.text: ) "He gave some Apostles, and some Prophets, and some Pastors and Teachers, for the perfecting of the saints, unto the work of ministering".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:43
verses.text: For if it were not so, there would have been no security against universal corruption.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:44
verses.text: For it may be that rulers are wicked and polluted, and their subjects good and virtuous; that laymen may live in piety, and priests in wickedness; and there could not have been either baptism, or the body of Christ, or oblation, through such, if in every instance grace required merit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:45
verses.text: But as it is, God uses to work even by unworthy persons, and in no respect is the grace of baptism damaged by the conduct of the priest: else would the receiver suffer loss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:46
verses.text: Accordingly, though such things happen rarely, still, it must be owned, they do happen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:47
verses.text: Now these things I say, lest any one of the bystanders busying himself about the life of the priest, should be offended as concerning the things solemnized (τὰ τελούμενα).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:48
verses.text: "For man introduceth nothing into the things which are set before us, but the whole is a work of the power of God, and He it is who initiates (ὁ μυσταγωγῶν) you into the mysteries".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:49
verses.text: "And I, brethren, could not speak unto you as unto spiritual, but as unto carnal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:50
verses.text: I fed you with milk, and not with meat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:51
verses.text: For ye were not able to bear it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:52
verses.text: For lest he should seem to have spoken ambitiously (φιλοτιμίας ἕνεκα, to obtain favor) these things which he hath just spoken; "the spiritual man judgeth all things," and, "he himself is judged of no man," and, "we have the mind of Christ;" with a view also to repress their pride: observe what he saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:53
verses.text: "Not on this account," saith he, "was I silent, because I was not able to tell you more, but because 'ye are carnal: neither yet now are ye able.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:54
verses.text: '"  Why said he not, "ye are not willing," but "ye are not able?" Even because he put the latter for the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:55
verses.text: For as to the want of ability, it arises from the want of will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:56
verses.text: Which to them indeed is a matter of accusation, but to their teacher, of excuse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:57
verses.text: For if they had been unable by nature, one might perhaps have been forgiven them; but since it was from choice, they were bereft of all excuse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:58
verses.text: He then speaks of the particular point also which makes them carnal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:59
verses.text: "For whereas there is among you strife, and jealousy, and division, are ye not carnal and walk as men?" Although he had fornications also and uncleannesses of theirs to speak of, he sets down rather that offence which he had been a good while endeavoring to correct.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:60
verses.text: Now if "jealousy" makes men carnal, it is high time for us to bewail bitterly, and to clothe ourselves with sackcloth and lie in ashes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:61
verses.text: For who is pure from this passion? Except indeed I am but conjecturing the case of others from myself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:62
verses.text: If "jealousy" maketh men "carnal," and suffereth them not to be "spiritual," although they prophesy and show forth other wonderful works; now, when not even so much grace is with us, what place shall we find for our own doings; when not in this matter alone, but also in others of greater moment, we are convicted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:63
verses.text: From this place we learn that Christ had good reason for saying, (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:64
verses.text: John iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:65
verses.text: ) "He that doeth evil cometh not to light;" and that unclean life is an obstacle to high doctrines, not suffering the clear-sightedness of the understanding to shew itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:66
verses.text: As then it is not in any case possible for a person in error, but living uprightly, to remain in error; so it is not easy for one brought up in iniquity, speedily to look up to the height of the doctrines delivered to us, but he must be clean from all the passions who is to hunt after the truth: for whoso is freed from these shall be freed also from his error and attain unto the truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:67
verses.text: For do not, I beseech you, think that abstinence merely from covetousness or fornication may suffice thee for this purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:68
verses.text: Not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:69
verses.text: All must concur in him that seeketh the truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:70
verses.text: Wherefore saith Peter, (Acts x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:72
verses.text: ) "Of a truth I perceive that God is no respecter of persons; but in every nation he that feareth Him, and worketh righteousness, is acceptable to Him:" that is, He calls and attracts him unto the truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:73
verses.text: Seest thou not Paul, that he was more vehement than any one in warring and persecuting? yet because he led an irreproachable life, and did these things not through human passion, he was both received, and reached a mark beyond all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:74
verses.text: But if any one should say, "How doth such a one, a Greek, who is kind, and good, and humane, continue in error?" this would be my answer: He hath some other passion, vainglory, or indolence of mind, or want of carefulness about his own salvation, accounting that all things which concern him are drifted along loosely and at random.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:75
verses.text: Peter calls the man irreproachable in all things one that "worketh righteousness," and Paul says "touching the righteousness which is in the law found blameless".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:76
verses.text: Again, "I give thanks to God, whom I serve from my forefathers with a pure conscience," ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:77
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:78
verses.text: ) How then, you will say, were unclean persons considered worthy of the Gospel? Because they wished and longed for it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:79
verses.text: Thus the one sort, though in error, are attracted by Him, because they are clean from passions; the others, of their own accord approaching, are not thrust back.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:80
verses.text: Many also even from their ancestors have received the true religion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:81
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:82
verses.text: "For whereas there is among you jealousy and strife".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:83
verses.text: At this point he prepares himself to wrestle with those whose part was obedience: for in what went before he hath been casting down the rulers of the Church, where he said that wisdom of speech is nothing worth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:84
verses.text: But here he strikes at those in subjection, in the words,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:85
verses.text: "For when one saith, I am Paul, and I of Apollos, are ye not carnal?"  And he points out that this, so far from helping them at all or causing them to acquire any thing, had even become an obstacle to their profiting in the greater things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:86
verses.text: For this it was which brought forth jealousy, and jealousy had made them "carnal;" and the having become "carnal" left them not at liberty to hear truths of the sublimer sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:87
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:88
verses.text: "Who then is Paul, and who is Apollos?"  In this way, after producing and proving his facts, he makes his accusation henceforth more openly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:89
verses.text: Moreover, he employs his own name, doing away all harshness and not suffering them to be angry at what it is said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:90
verses.text: For if Paul is nothing and murmur not, much less ought they to think themselves ill used.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:91
verses.text: Two ways, you see, he has of soothing them; first by bringing forward his own person, then by not robbing them of all as if they contributed nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:92
verses.text: Rather he allows them some small portion: small though it be, he does allow it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:93
verses.text: For having said, "Who is Paul, and who Apollos," he adds, "but ministers by whom ye believed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:94
verses.text: Now this in itself is a great thing, and deserving of great rewards: although in regard of the archetype and the root of all good, it is nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:95
verses.text: (For not he that "ministers" to our blessings, but he that provides and gives them, he is our Benefactor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:96
verses.text: ) And he said not, "Evangelists," but "Ministers," which is more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:97
verses.text: For they had not merely preached the Gospel, but had also ministered unto us; the one being a matter of word only, while the other hath deed also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:98
verses.text: And so, if even Christ be a minister only of good things, and not the root Himself and the fountain, (I mean, of course, in that He is a Son,) observe to what an issue this matter is brought.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:99
verses.text: (ποῦ τὸ πρᾶγμα κατάγεται.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:100
verses.text: "how deep and high it is made to go".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:101
verses.text: ) How then, you will ask, doth he say that He "was made a Minister of Circumcision? (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:102
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:103
verses.text: ) He is speaking in that place of His secret dispensation in the Flesh, and not in the same sense which we have now mentioned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:104
verses.text: For there, by "Minister," he means "Fulfiller," (πληρωτὴν, i-e: of types), and not one that of his own store gives out the blessings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:105
verses.text: Further, he said not, "Those who guide you into the Faith," but "those by whom ye believed;" again attributing the greater share to themselves, and indicating by this also the subordinate class of ministers (τοὺς διακόνους κὰντεῦθεν δηλῶν).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:106
verses.text: Now if they were ministering to another, how come they to seize the authority for themselves? But I would have you consider how in no wise he lays the blame on them as seizing it for themselves, but on those who endow them with it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:107
verses.text: For the ground-work of the error lay in the multitude; since, had the one fallen away, the other would have been broken up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:108
verses.text: Here are two points which he has skilfully provided for: in that first he hath prepared, as by mining (ὑπορύξας,) in the quarter where it was necessary to overthrow the mischief; and next, on their side, in not attracting ill-will, nor yet making them more contentious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:109
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:110
verses.text: "Even as Christ (ὁ Κύριος, rec.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:111
verses.text: text.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:112
verses.text: ) gave to every man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:113
verses.text: For not even this small thing itself was of themselves, but of God, who put it into their hands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:114
verses.text: For lest they might say, What then? are we not to love those that minister unto us? Yea, saith he; but you should know to what extent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:115
verses.text: For not even this thing itself is of them, but of God who gave it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:116
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:117
verses.text: "I planted, Apollos watered, but God gave the increase".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:118
verses.text: That is, I first cast the word into the ground; but, in order that the seeds might not wither away through temptations, Apollos added his own part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:119
verses.text: But the whole was of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:120
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:121
verses.text: "So then, neither is he that planteth any thing, neither he that watereth, but God that giveth the increase".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:122
verses.text: Do you observe the manner in which he soothes them, so that they should not be too much irritated, on hearing, "Who is this person," and "Who is that?" "Nay, both are invidious, namely, both the saying, 'Who is this person? Who the other,'" and the saying, that "neither he that planteth nor he that watereth is any thing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:123
verses.text: How then does he soften these expressions? First, By attaching the contempt to his own person, "Who is Paul, and who Apollos?" and next, by referring the whole to God who gave all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:124
verses.text: For after he had said, "Such a person planted," and added, "He that planteth is nothing," he subjoined, "but God that giveth the increase".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:125
verses.text: Nor does he stop even here, but applies again another healing clause, in the words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:126
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:127
verses.text: "He that planteth and he that watereth, are one".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:128
verses.text: For by means of this he establishes another point also, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:129
verses.text: that they should not be exalted one against another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:130
verses.text: His assertion, that they are one, refers to their inability to do any thing without "God that giveth the increase".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:131
verses.text: And thus saying, he permitted not either those who labored much to lift themselves up against those who had contributed less; nor these again to envy the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:132
verses.text: In the next place, since this had a tendency to make men more indolent, I mean, all being esteemed as one, whether they have labored much or little; observe how he sets this right, saying, "But each shall receive his own reward according to his own labor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:133
verses.text: As if he said, "Fear not, because I said, Ye are one; for, compared with the work of God, they are one; howbeit, in regard to labors, they are not so, but "each shall receive his own reward".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:134
verses.text: Then he smooths it still more, having succeeded in what he wished; and gratifies them, where it is allowed, with liberality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:135
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:136
verses.text: For we are God's fellow-workers: "ye are God's husbandry, God's building".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:137
verses.text: Seest thou how to them also he hath assigned no small work, having before laid it down that the whole is of God? For since he is always persuading them to obey those that have the rule over them, on this account he abstains from making very light of their teachers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:138
verses.text: "Ye are God's husbandry".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:139
verses.text: For because he had said, "I planted," he kept to the metaphor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:140
verses.text: Now if ye be God's husbandry, it is right that you should be called not from those who cultivate you, but from God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:141
verses.text: For the field is not called the husbandman's, but the householder's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:142
verses.text: "Ye are God's building".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:143
verses.text: Again, the building is not the workman's, but the master's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:144
verses.text: Now if ye be a building, ye must not be forced asunder: since this were no building.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:145
verses.text: If ye be a farm, ye must not be divided, but be walled in with a single fence, namely, unanimity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:146
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:147
verses.text: "According to the Grace of God which was given unto me, as a wise master-builder I laid a foundation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:148
verses.text: In this place he calls himself wise, not exalting himself, but to give them an ensample, and to point out that this is a wise man's part, to lay a foundation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:149
verses.text: You may observe as one instance of his modest bearing, that in speaking of himself as wise, he allowed not this to stand as though it were something of his own; but first attributing himself entirely unto God, then and not till then calls himself by that name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:150
verses.text: For, "according to the Grace of God," saith he, "which was given unto me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:151
verses.text: Thus, at once he signifies both that the whole is of God; and that this most of all is Grace, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:152
verses.text: the not being divided, but resting on One Foundation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:153
verses.text: "Another buildeth thereon; but let each man take heed how he buildeth thereon".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:154
verses.text: Here, I think, and in what follows, he puts them upon their trial concerning practice, after that he had once for all knit them together and made them one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:155
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:156
verses.text: "For other foundation can no man lay than that is laid, which is Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:157
verses.text: I say, no man can lay it so long as he is a master-builder; but if he lay it, (τιθῃ conj.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:165
verses.text: See how even from men's common notions he proves the whole of his proposition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:166
verses.text: His meaning is this: "I have preached Christ, I have delivered unto you the foundation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:167
verses.text: Take heed how you build thereon, lest haply it be in vainglory, lest haply so as to draw away the disciples unto men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:168
verses.text: Let us not then give heed unto the heresies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:169
verses.text: "For other foundation can no man lay than that which is laid".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:170
verses.text: Upon this then let us build, and as a foundation let us cleave to it, as a branch to a vine; and let there be no interval between us and Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:171
verses.text: For if there be any interval, immediately we perish.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:172
verses.text: For the branch by its adherence draws in the fatness, and the building stands because it is cemented together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:173
verses.text: Since, if it stand apart it perishes, having nothing whereon to support itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:174
verses.text: Let us not then merely keep hold of Christ, but let us be cemented to Him, for if we stand apart, we perish.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:175
verses.text: "For they who withdraw themselves far from Thee, shall perish;" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:176
verses.text: lxxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:177
verses.text: Sept.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:178
verses.text: ) so it is said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:179
verses.text: Let us cleave then unto Him, and let us cleave by our works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:180
verses.text: "For he that keepeth my commandments, the same abideth in Me" (John xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:181
verses.text: in substance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:182
verses.text: ) And accordingly, there are many images whereby He brings us into union.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:183
verses.text: Thus, if you mark it, He is "the Head," we are "the body:" can there be any empty interval between the head and body? He is "a Foundation," we "a building:" He "a Vine," we "branches:" He "the Bridegroom," we "the bride:" He "the Shepherd," we "the sheep;" He is "the Way," we "they who walk therein".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:184
verses.text: Again, we are "a temple," He "the Indweller:" He "the First-Begotten," we "the brethren:" He "the Heir," we "the heirs together with Him:" He "the Life," we "the living:" He "the Resurrection," we "those who rise again:" He "the Light," we "the enlightened".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:185
verses.text: All these things indicate unity; and they allow no void interval, not even the smallest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:186
verses.text: For he that removes but to a little distance will go on till he has become very far distant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:187
verses.text: For so the body, receiving though it be but a small cut by a sword, perishes: and the building, though there be but a small chink, falls to decay: and the branch, though it be but a little while cut off from the root, becomes useless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:188
verses.text: So that this trifle is no trifle, but is even almost the whole.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:189
verses.text: Whensoever then we commit some little fault or even negligence, let us not overlook that little; since this, being disregarded, quickly becomes great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:190
verses.text: So also when a garment hath begun to be torn and is neglected, it is apt to prolong its rent all throughout; and a roof, when a few tiles have fallen, being disregarded, brings down the whole house.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:191
verses.text: These things then let us bear in mind, and never slight the small things, lest we fall into those which are great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:192
verses.text: But if so be that we have slighted them and are come into the abyss of evils, not even when we are come there let us despond, lest we fall into recklessness (καρηβαρίαν).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:193
verses.text: For to emerge from thence is hard ever after, for one who is not extremely watchful; not because of the distance alone, but of the very position, too, wherein we find ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:194
verses.text: For sin also is a deep, and is wont to bear down and crush.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:195
verses.text: And just as those who have fallen into a well cannot with ease get out, but will want others to draw them up; so also is he that is come into any depth of sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:196
verses.text: To such then we must lower ropes and draw them up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:197
verses.text: Nay rather, we need not others only, but ourselves also, that we for our part may fasten on ourselves and ascend, I say not so much as we have descended, but much further, if we be willing: for why? God also helpeth: for He willeth not the death of a sinner so much as his conversion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:198
verses.text: Let no one then despair; let no one have the feeling of the ungodly; for to them properly belongs this kind of sin: "an ungodly man having come into any depth of evils, makes light of it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:199
verses.text: So that it is not the multitude of men's sins which causes their despair, but their ungodly mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:200
verses.text: Shouldest thou then have gone all lengths in wickedness, yet say unto thyself, God is loving unto men and he desires our salvation: for "though your sins be as scarlet, I will whiten you as snow," (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:201

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:203
verses.text: ) saith He; and unto the contrary habit I will change you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:204
verses.text: Let us not therefore give up in despair; for to fall is not so grievous, as to lie where we have fallen; nor to be wounded so dreadful, as after wounds to refuse healing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:205
verses.text: "For who shall boast that he has his heart chaste? or who shall say confidently that he is pure from sin?" (Prov.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:206

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:208
verses.text: ) These things I say not to make you more negligent, but to prevent your despairing.

verses.text: Wouldest thou know how good our Master is? The Publican went up full of ten thousand wickednesses, and saying only, "Be merciful unto me," went down justified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:223
verses.text: But we do not even this: wherefore we especially provoke God to wrath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:224
verses.text: (For he, who by little things even is made propitious, when He meets not with so much as these, is of course indignant and exacts of us the last penalty; for this comes of exceeding contempt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:225
verses.text: ) Who is there, for instance, that hath ever become melancholy for his sins? Who hath bemoaned himself? Who hath beaten his breast? Who hath taken anxious thought? Not one, to my thinking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:226
verses.text: But days without number do men weep for dead servants; for the loss of money: while as to the soul which we are ruining day by day, we give it not a thought.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:227
verses.text: How then wilt thou be able to render God propitious, when thou knowest not even that thou hast sinned?  "Yea," saith some one, "I have sinned".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:228
verses.text: "Yea," is thy word to me with the tongue: say it to me with thy mind, and with the word mourn heavily, that thou mayest have continual cheerfulness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:229
verses.text: Since, if we did grieve for our sins, if we mourned heavily over our offences, nothing else could give us sorrow, this one pang would expel all kinds of dejection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:230
verses.text: Here then is another thing also which we should gain by our thorough confession; namely, the not being overwhelmed (βαπτίζεσθαι) with the pains of the present life, nor puffed up with its splendors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:231
verses.text: And in this way, again, we should more entirely propitiate God; just as by our present conduct we provoke Him to anger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:232
verses.text: For tell me, if thou hast a servant, and he, after suffering much evil at the hands of his fellow-servants, takes no account of any one of the rest, but is only anxious not to provoke his master; is he not able by this alone to do away thine anger? But what, if his offenses against thee are no manner of care to him, while on those against his fellow-servants he is full of thought; wilt thou not lay on him the heavier punishment? So also God doeth: when we neglect His wrath, He brings it upon us more heavily; but when we regard it, more gently.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:233
verses.text: Yea, rather, He lays it on us no more at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:234
verses.text: He wills that we should exact vengeance of ourselves for our offences, and thenceforth He doth not exact it Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:235
verses.text: For this is why He at all threatens punishment; that by fear He may destroy contempt; and when the threat alone is sufficient to cause fear in us, He doth not suffer us to undergo the actual trial.

verses.text: ) "Seest thou not what they do? Their fathers light a fire, their children gather sticks together, their women knead dough".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:242
verses.text: It is to be feared lest the same kind of thing be said also concerning us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:243
verses.text: "Seest thou not what they do? No one seeketh the things of Christ, but all their own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:244
verses.text: Their children run into uncleanness, their fathers into covetousness and rapine, their wives so far from keeping back their husbands from the pomps and vanities of life, do rather sharpen their appetites for them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:245
verses.text: Just take your stand in the market place; question the comers and goers, and not one wilt thou see hastening upon a spiritual errand, but all running after carnal things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:246
verses.text: How long ere we awake from our surfeiting? How long are we to keep sinking down into deep slumber? Have we not had our fill of evils?   And yet one might think that even without words experience itself is sufficient to teach you the nothingness of things present, and their utter meanness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:247
verses.text: At all events, there have been men, who, exercising mere heathen wisdom and knowing nothing of the future, because they had proved the great worthlessness of present things, have left them on this account alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:248
verses.text: What pardon then canst thou expect to obtain, grovelling on the ground and not despising the little things and transient for the sake of the great and everlasting: who also hearest God Himself declaring and revealing these things unto thee, and hast such promises from Him? For that things here have no sufficient power to detain a man, those have shewn who even without any promise of things greater have kept away from them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:249
verses.text: For what wealth did they expect that they came to poverty? There was none.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:250
verses.text: But it was from their knowing full well that such poverty is better than wealth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:251
verses.text: What sort of life did they hope for that they forsook luxury, and gave themselves up unto severe discipline? Not any.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:252
verses.text: But they had become aware of the very nature of things; and perceived that this of the two is more suitable, both for the strict training of the soul, and for the health of the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 7:253
verses.text: These things then duly estimating, and revolving with ourselves continually the future blessings, let us withdraw from this present world that we may obtain that other which is to come; through the favor and loving kindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father and the Holy Ghost &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:1
verses.text: Homily IX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:3

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:4
verses.text: –  If any man build upon this foundation gold, silver, costly stones, wood, hay, stubble; each man's work shall be made manifest: for the day shall declare it, because it is revealed in fire; and the fire shall prove each man's work of what sort it is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:5
verses.text: If any man's work abide which he built thereon, he shall receive a reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:6
verses.text: If any man's work shall be burned, he shall suffer loss: but he himself shall be saved; yet so as through fire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:7
verses.text: This is no small subject of enquiry which we propose, but rather about things which are of the first necessity and which all men enquire about; namely, whether hell fire have any end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:8
verses.text: For that it hath no end Christ indeed declared when he said, "Their fire shall not be quenched, and their worm shall not die".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:9
verses.text: Mark viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:11
verses.text: Well: I know that a chill comes over you (ναρκᾶτε) on hearing these things; but what am I to do? For this is God's own command, continually to sound these things in your ears, where He says, "Charge this people; (Fors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:12
verses.text: Exod.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:13
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:15
verses.text: διαμαρτύραι, Sept.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:16
verses.text: here διάστειλαι,) and ordained as we have been unto the ministry of the word, we must give pain to our hearers, not willingly but on compulsion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:17
verses.text: Nay rather, if you will, we shall avoid giving you pain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:18
verses.text: For saith He, (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:21

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:22
verses.text: As I said then; that it hath no end, Christ has declared.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:23
verses.text: Paul also saith, in pointing out the eternity of the punishment, that the sinners "shall pay the penalty of destruction, and that for ever" ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:28
verses.text: nor adulterers, nor effeminate, shall inherit the kingdom of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:29
verses.text: And also unto the Hebrews he saith, (Heb.
