verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:31
verses.text: ) "Follow peace with all men, and the sanctification without which no man shall see the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:32
verses.text: And Christ also, to those who said, "In thy Name we have done many wonderful works," saith, "Depart from Me, I know you not, ye workers of iniquity" (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:33
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:34
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:35
verses.text: ) And the virgins too who were shut out, entered in no more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:36
verses.text: And also about those who gave Him no food, He saith, (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:37
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:38
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:39
verses.text: ) "They shall go away into everlasting punishment".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:40
verses.text: And say not unto me, "where is the rule of justice preserved entire, if the punishment hath no end?" Rather, when God doeth any thing, obey His decisions and submit not what is said to human reasonings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:41
verses.text: But moreover, how can it be any thing else than just for one who hath experienced innumerable blessings from the beginning, and then committed deeds worthy of punishment, and neither by threat nor benefit improved at all, to suffer punishment? For if thou enquire what is absolute justice; it was meet that we should have perished immediately from the beginning, according to the definition of strict justice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:42
verses.text: Rather not even then according to the rule of justice only; for the result would have had in it kindness too, if we had suffered this also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:43
verses.text: For when any one insults him that hath done him no wrong, according to the rule of justice he suffers punishment: but when it is his benefactor, who, bound by no previous favor, bestowed innumerable kindnesses, who alone is the Author of his being, who is God, who breathed his soul into him, who gave ten thousand gifts of grace, whose will is to take him up into heaven;—when, I say, such an one, after so great blessings, is met by insult, daily insult, in the conduct of the other party; how can that other be thought worthy of pardon? Dost thou not see how He punished Adam for one single sin?  "Yes," you will say; "but He had given him Paradise and caused him to enjoy much favor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:44
verses.text: Nay, surely it is not all as one, for a man to sin in the enjoyment of security and ease, and in a state of great affliction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:45
verses.text: In fact, this is the dreadful circumstance that thy sins are the sins of one not in any Paradise but amid the innumerable evils of this life; that thou art not sobered even by affliction, as though one in prison should still practise his crime.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:46
verses.text: However, unto thee He hath promised things yet greater than Paradise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:47
verses.text: But neither hath He given them now, least He should unnerve thee in the season of conflicts; nor hath He been silent about them, lest He should quite cast thee down with thy labors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:48
verses.text: As for Adam, he committed but one sin and brought on himself certain death; whereas we commit ten thousand transgressions daily.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:49
verses.text: Now if he by that one act brought on himself so great an evil and introduced death; what shall not we suffer who continually live in sins, and instead of Paradise, have the expectation of heaven?  The argument is irksome and pains the hearer: were it only by my own feelings, I know this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:50
verses.text: For indeed my heart is troubled and throbs; and the more I see the account of hell confirmed, the more do I tremble and shrink through fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:51
verses.text: But it is necessary to say these things lest we fall into hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:52
verses.text: What thou didst receive was not paradise, nor trees and plants, but heaven and the good things in the heavens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:53
verses.text: Now if he that had received less was condemned, and no consideration exempted him, much more shall we who have sinned more abundantly, and have been called unto greater things, endure the woes without remedy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:54
verses.text: Consider, for example, how long a time, but for one single sin, our race abides in death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:55
verses.text: Five thousand years and more have passed, and death hath not yet been done away, on account of one single sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:56
verses.text: And we cannot even say that Adam had heard prophets, that he had seen others punished for sins, and it was meet that he should have been terrified thereby and corrected, were it only by the example.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:57
verses.text: For he was at that time first, and alone; but nevertheless he was punished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:58
verses.text: But thou canst not have anything of this sort to advance, who after so many examples art become worse; to whom so excellent a Spirit hath been vouch-safed, and yet thou drawest upon thyself not one sin, nor two, nor three, but sins without number! For do not, because the sin is committed in a small moment, calculate that therefore the punishment also must be a matter of a moment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:59
verses.text: Seest thou not those men, who for a single theft or a single act of adultery, committed in a small moment of time, oftentimes have spent their whole life in prisons, and in mines, struggling with continual hunger and every kind of death? And there was no one to set them at liberty, or to say, "The offence took place in a small moment of time; the punishment too should have its time equivalent to that of the sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:60
verses.text: But, "They are men," some one will say, "who do these things; as for God, He is loving unto men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:61
verses.text: Now, first of all, not even men do these things in cruelty, but in humanity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:62
verses.text: And God Himself, as "He is loving unto men," in the same character doth He punish sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:63
verses.text: (Sirac.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:64
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:65
verses.text: ) "For as His mercy is great, so also is His reproof".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:66
verses.text: When therefore thou sayest unto me, "God is loving unto men," then thou tellest me of so much the greater reason for punishing: namely, our sinning against such a Being.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:67
verses.text: Hence also Paul said, (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:68
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:69
verses.text: ) "It is a fearful thing to fall into the hands of the living God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:70
verses.text: Endure I beseech you, the fiery force of the words, for perhaps—perhaps you will have some consolation from hence! Who among men can punish as God has punished? when He caused a deluge and entire destruction of a race so numerous; and again, when, a little while after, He rained fire from above, and utterly destroyed them all? What punishment from men can be like that? Seest thou not that the punishment even in this world is almost eternal? Four thousand years have passed away, and the punishment of the Sodomites abideth at its height.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:71
verses.text: For as His mercy is great, so also is His punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:72
verses.text: Again: if He had imposed any burdensome or impossible things, one might perhaps have been able to urge difficulty of the laws: but if they be extremely easy, what can we say for our not regarding even these? Suppose thou art unable to fast or to practice virginity; although thou art able if thou wilt, and they who have been able are a condemnation to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:73
verses.text: But, however, God hath not used this strictness towards us; neither hath He enjoined these things nor laid them down as laws, but left the choice to be at the discretion of the hearers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:74
verses.text: Nevertheless, thou art able to be chaste in marriage; and thou art able to abstain from drunkenness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:75
verses.text: Art thou unable to empty thyself of all thy goods? Nay surely thou art able; and they who have done so prove it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:76
verses.text: But nevertheless He hath not enjoined this, but hath commanded not to be rapacious, and of our means to assist those who are in want.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:77
verses.text: But if a man say, I cannot even be content with a wife only, he deceiveth himself and reasoneth falsely; and they condemn him who without a wife lives in chastity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:78
verses.text: But how, tell me, canst thou help using abusive words? canst thou not help cursing? Why, the doing these things is irksome, not the refraining from them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:79
verses.text: What excuse then have we for not observing precepts so easy and light? We cannot name any at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:80
verses.text: That the punishment then is eternal is plain from all that hath been said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:81
verses.text: But since Paul's saying appears to some to tell the other way, come let us bring it forward also and search it out thoroughly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:82
verses.text: For having said, "If any man's work abide which he hath built thereon, he shall receive a reward; and if any man's work shall be burned, he shall suffer loss," he adds, "but himself shall be saved, yet so as through fire".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:83
verses.text: What shall we say then to this? Let us consider first what is "the Foundation," and what "the gold," and what "the precious stones," and what "the hay," and what the "stubble".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:84
verses.text: "The Foundation," then, he hath himself plainly signified to be Christ, saying, "For other foundation can no man lay than that which is laid, which," he saith "is Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:85
verses.text: Next, the building seems to me to be actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:86
verses.text: Although some maintain that this also is spoken concerning teachers and disciples and concerning corrupt heresies: but the reasoning doth not admit it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:87
verses.text: For if this be it, in what sense, while "the work is destroyed," is the "builder" to be "saved," though it be "through fire?" Of right, the author ought rather of the two to perish; but now it will be found that the severer penalty is assigned to him who hath been built into the work.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:88
verses.text: For if the teacher was the cause of the wickedness, he is worthy to suffer severer punishment: how then shall he be "saved?" If, on the contrary, he was not the cause but the disciples became such through their own perverseness, he is no whit deserving of punishment, no, nor yet of sustaining loss: he, I say, who builded so well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:89
verses.text: In what sense then doth he say, "he shall suffer loss?"  From this it is plain that the discourse is about actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:90
verses.text: For since he means next in course to put out his strength against the man who had committed fornication, he begins high up and long beforehand to lay down the preliminaries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:91
verses.text: For he knew how while discussing one subject, in the very discourse about that thing to prepare the grounds of another to which he intends to pass on.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:92
verses.text: For so in his rebuke for not awaiting one another at their meals, he laid the grounds of his discourse concerning the mysteries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:93
verses.text: And also because now he is hastening on towards the fornicator, while speaking about the "Foundation," he adds, "Know ye not that ye are the Temple of God? and that the Spirit of God dwelleth in you? If any man destroy (Φθείρη, rec.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:94
verses.text: version, "defile".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:95
verses.text: ) the Temple of God, him will God destroy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:96
verses.text: Now these things, he said, as beginning now to agitate with fears the soul of him that had been unchaste.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:97
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:98
verses.text: "If any man build upon this foundation, gold, silver, costly stones, wood, hay, stubble".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:99
verses.text: For after the faith there is need of edification: and therefore he saith elsewhere, "Edify one another with these words".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:100
verses.text: (perhaps  Thes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:101
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:102
verses.text: ; iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:103
verses.text: ) For both the artificer and the learner contribute to the edifying.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:104
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, "But let every man take heed how he buildeth thereon".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:105
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:106
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:107
verses.text: ) But if faith had been the subject of these sayings, the thing affirmed is not reasonable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:108
verses.text: For in the faith all ought to be equal, since "there is but one faith;" (Ephes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:109
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:110
verses.text: ) but in goodness of life it is not possible that all should be the same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:111
verses.text: Because the faith is not in one case less, in another more excellent, but the same in all those who truly believe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:112
verses.text: But in life there is room for some to be more diligent, others more slothful; some stricter, and others more ordinary; that some should have done well in greater things, others in less; that the errors of some should have been more grievous, of others less notable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:113
verses.text: On this account he saith, "Gold, silver, costly stones, wood, hay, stubble,—every man's work shall be made manifest:"—his conduct; that is what he speaks of here:—"If any man's work abide which he built thereupon, he shall receive a reward; if any man's work shall be burned, he shall suffer loss".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:114
verses.text: Whereas, if the saying related to disciples and teachers, he ought not to "suffer loss" for disciples refusing to hear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:115
verses.text: And therefore he saith, "Every man shall receive his own reward according to his own labor" not according to the result, but according to "the labor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:116
verses.text: For what if the hearers gave no heed? Wherefore this passage also proves that the saying is about actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:117
verses.text: Now his meaning is this: If any man have an ill life with a right faith, his faith shall not shelter him from punishment, his work being burnt up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:118
verses.text: The phrase, "shall be burned up," means, "shall not endure the violence of the fire".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:119
verses.text: But just as if a man having golden armor on were to pass through a river of fire, he comes from crossing it all the brighter; but if he were to pass through it with hay, so far from profiting, he destroys himself besides; so also is the case in regard of men's works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:120
verses.text: For he doth not say this as if he were discoursing of material things being burnt up, but with a view of making their fear more intense, and of shewing how naked of all defence he is who abides in wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:121
verses.text: Wherefore he said, "He shall suffer loss:" lo, here is one punishment: "but he himself shall be saved, but so as by fire;" lo, again, here is a second.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:122
verses.text: And his meaning is, "He himself shall not perish in the same way as his works, passing into nought, but he shall abide in the fire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:123
verses.text: "He calleth it, however, "Salvation," you will say; why, that is the cause of his adding, "so as by fire:" since we also used to say, "It is preserved in the fire," when we speak of those substances which do not immediately burn up and become ashes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:124
verses.text: For do not at sound of the word fire imagine that those who are burning pass into annihilation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:125
verses.text: And though he call such punishment Salvation, be not astonished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:126
verses.text: For his custom is in things which have an ill sound to use fair expressions, and in good things the contrary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:127
verses.text: For example, the word "Captivity" seems to be the name of an evil thing, but Paul has applied it in a good sense, when he says, "Bringing into captivity every thought to the obedience of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:128
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:129
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:130
verses.text: ) And again, to an evil thing he hath applied a good word, saying, "Sin reigned," (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:131
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:132
verses.text: ) here surely the term "reigning" is rather of auspicious sound.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:133
verses.text: And so here in saying, "he shall be saved," he hath but darkly hinted at the intensity of the penalty: as if he had said, "But himself shall remain forever in punishment".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:134
verses.text: He then makes an inference, saying,   Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:135
verses.text: "Know ye not that ye are the Temple of God?" For since he had discoursed in the section before, concerning those who were dividing the Church, he thenceforward attacks him also who had been guilty of uncleanness; not indeed as yet in plain terms but in a general way; hinting at his corrupt mode of life and enhancing the sin, by the Gift which had been already given to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:136
verses.text: Then also he puts all the rest to shame, arguing from these very blessings which they had already: for this is what he is ever doing, either from the future or from the past, whether grievous or encouraging.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:137
verses.text: First, from things future; "For the day shall declare it, because it is revealed by fire".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:138
verses.text: Again, from things already come to pass; "Know ye not that ye are the Temple of God, and the Spirit of God dwelleth in you?"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:139
verses.text: "If any man destroy the Temple of God, him will God destroy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:140
verses.text: Dost thou mark the sweeping vehemence of his words? However, so long as the person is unknown, what is spoken is not so invidious, all dividing among themselves the fear of rebuke.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:141
verses.text: "Him will God destroy," that is, will cause him to perish.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:142
verses.text: And this is not the word of one denouncing a curse, but of one that prophesieth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:143
verses.text: "For the Temple of God is holy:" but he that hath committed fornication is profane.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:144
verses.text: Then, in order that he might not seem to spend his earnestness upon that one, in saying, "for the Temple of God is holy," he addeth, "which ye are".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:145
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:146
verses.text: "Let no man deceive himself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:147
verses.text: This also is in reference to that person, as thinking himself to be somewhat and flattering himself on wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:148
verses.text: But that he might not seem to press on him at great length in a mere digression; he first throws him into a kind of agony and delivers him over unto fear, and then brings back his discourse to the common fault, saying, "If any man among you seemeth to be wise in this world, let him become a fool, that he may become (γένηται.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:149
verses.text: rec.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:150
verses.text: vers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:151
verses.text: "be".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:152
verses.text: ) wise".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:153
verses.text: And this he doth afterwards with great boldness of speech, as having sufficiently beaten them down, and shaken with that fear the mind not of that unclean person only, but of all the hearers also: so accurately does he measure the reach of what he has to say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:154
verses.text: For what if a man be rich, what if he be noble; he is viler than all the vile, when made captive by sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:155
verses.text: For as if a man were a king and enslaved to barbarians, he is of all men most wretched, so also is it in regard to sin: since sin is a barbarian, and the soul which hath been once taken captive she knoweth not how to spare, but plays the tyrant to the ruin of all those who admit her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:156
verses.text: For nothing is so inconsiderate as sin: nothing so senseless, so utterly foolish and outrageous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:157
verses.text: All is overturned and confounded and destroyed by it, wheresoever it may alight.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:158
verses.text: Unsightly to behold, disgusting and grievous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:159
verses.text: And should a painter draw her picture, he would not, methinks, err in fashioning her after this sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:160
verses.text: A woman with the form of a beast, savage, breathing flames, hideous, black; such as the heathen poets depict their Scyllas.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:161
verses.text: For with ten thousand hands she lays hold of our thoughts, and comes on unexpected, and tears everything in pieces, like those dogs that bite slily.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:162
verses.text: But rather, what need of the painter's art, when we should rather bring forward those who are made after sin's likeness?  Whom then will ye that we should portray first? The covetous and rapacious? And what more shameless than those eyes? What more immodest, more like a greedy dog? For no dog keeps his ground with such shameless impudence as he when he is grasping at all men's goods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:163
verses.text: What more polluted than those hands? What more audacious than that mouth, swallowing all down and not satisfied? Nay, look not on the countenance and the eyes as being a man's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:164
verses.text: For such looks belong not to the eyes of men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:165
verses.text: He seeth not men as men; he seeth not the heaven as heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:166
verses.text: He does not even lift up his head unto the Lord; but all is money in his account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:167
verses.text: The eyes of men are wont to look upon poor persons in affliction, and to be softened; but these of the rapacious man, at sight of the poor, glare like wild beasts'.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:168
verses.text: The eyes of men do not behold other men's goods as if they were their own, but rather their own as others; and they covet not the things given to others, but rather exhaust upon others their own means: but these are not content unless they take all men's property.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:169
verses.text: For it is not a man's eye which they have, but a wild beast's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:170
verses.text: The eyes of men endure not to see their own body stripped of clothing, (for it is their own, though in person it belong to others,) but these, unless they strip every one and lodge all men's property in their own home, are never cloyed; yea rather they never have enough.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:171
verses.text: Insomuch that one might say that their hands are not wild beasts' only, but even far more savage and cruel than these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:172
verses.text: For bears and wolves when they are satiated leave off their kind of eating: but these know not any satiety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:173
verses.text: And yet for this cause God made us hands, to assist others, not to plot against them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:174
verses.text: And if we were to use them for that purpose, better had they been cut off and we left without them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:175
verses.text: But thou, if a wild beast rend a sheep, art grieved; but when doing the same unto one of thine own flesh and blood, thinkest thou that thy deed is nothing atrocious? How then canst thou be a man? Seest thou not that we call a thing humane, when it is full of mercy and loving-kindness? But when a man doth any thing cruel or savage, inhuman is the title we give to such a one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:176
verses.text: You see then that the stamp of man as we portray him is his showing mercy; of a beast the contrary; according to constant saying, "Why, is a man a wild beast, or a dog?" (vid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:177
verses.text: Kings viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:178
verses.text: ) For men relieve poverty; they do not aggravate it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:179
verses.text: Again these men's mouths are the mouths of wild beasts; yea rather these are the fiercer of the two.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:180
verses.text: For the words also, which they utter, emit poison, more than the wild beasts' teeth, working slaughter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:181
verses.text: And if one were to go through all particulars, one should then see clearly how inhumanity turns those who practise it from men into beasts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:182
verses.text: But were he to search out the mind also of that sort of people, he would no longer call them beasts only, but demons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:183
verses.text: For first, they are full of great cruelty and of hatred against their "fellow-servant: (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:184
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:185
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:186
verses.text: ) and neither is love of the kingdom there, nor fear of hell; no reverence for men, no pity, no sympathy: but shamelessness and audacity, and contempt of all things to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:187
verses.text: And unto them the words of God concerning punishment seem to be a fable, and His threats mirth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:188
verses.text: For such is the mind of the covetous man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:189
verses.text: Since then within they are demons, and without, wild beasts; yea, worse than wild beasts; where are we to place such as they are? For that they are worse even than wild beasts, is plain from this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:190
verses.text: The beasts are such as they are by nature: but these, endowed by nature with gentleness, forcibly strive against nature to train themselves to that which is savage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:191
verses.text: The demons too have the plotters among men to help them, to such an extent that if they had no such aid, the greater part of their wiles against us would be done away: but these, when such as they have spitefully entreated are vying with them, still try to be more spiteful then they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:192
verses.text: Again, the devil wages war with man, not with the demons of his own kind: but he of whom we speak is urgent in all ways to do harm to his own kindred and family, and doth not even reverence nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:193
verses.text: I know that many hate us because of these words; but I feel no hatred towards them; rather I pity and bewail those who are so disposed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:194
verses.text: Even should they choose to strike, I would gladly endure it, if they would but abstain from this their savage mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:195
verses.text: For not I alone, but the prophet also with me, banisheth all such from the family of men saying, (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:196
verses.text: xlix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:197
verses.text: Sept.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:198
verses.text: τοῖς ἀνοήτοις) "Man being in honor hath no understanding, but is like unto the senseless beasts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:199
verses.text: Let us then become men at last, and let us look up unto heaven; and that which is according to His image, (Colos.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:200
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 8:201
verses.text: ) let us receive and recover: that we may obtain also the blessings to come through the grace and loving-kindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father and the Holy Spirit be glory, power, honor, now and always, and unto everlasting ages, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:1
verses.text: Homily X.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:3
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:4
verses.text: ,  Let no man deceive himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:5
verses.text: If any man (ἐνὗμῖν omitted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:6
verses.text: ) thinketh that he is wise in this world, let him become a fool, that he may become wise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:7
verses.text: For the wisdom of this world is foolishness with God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:8
verses.text: As I said before, having launched out before the proper time into accusation of the fornicator, and having half opened it obscurely in a few words, and made the man's conscience to quail, he hastens again to the battle with heathen wisdom, and to his accusations of those who were puffed up there-with, and who were dividing the Church: in order that having added what remained and completed the whole topic with accuracy, he might thenceforth suffer his tongue to be carried away with vehement impulse against the unclean person, having had but a preliminary skirmishing with him in what he had said before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:9
verses.text: For this, "Let no man deceive himself," is the expression of one aiming chiefly at him and quelling him beforehand by fear: and the saying about the "stubble," suits best with one hinting at him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:10
verses.text: And so does the phrase, "Know ye not that ye are the Temple of God, and the Spirit of God dwelleth in you?" For these two things are most apt to withdraw us from sin; when we have in mind the punishment appointed for the sin; and when we reckon up the amount of our true dignity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:11
verses.text: By bringing forward then "the hay" and "the stubble," he terrifies; but by speaking of the dignity of that noble birth which was theirs, he puts them to shame; by the former striving to amend the more insensible kind, by the latter the more considerate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:12
verses.text: "Let no man deceive himself; if any man thinketh that he is wise in this world, let him become a fool".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:13
verses.text: As he bids one become, as it were, dead unto the world;—and this deadness harms not at all, but rather profits, being made a cause of life:—so also he bids him become foolish unto this world, introducing to us hereby the true wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:14
verses.text: Now he becomes a fool unto the world, who slights the wisdom from without, and is persuaded that it contributes nothing towards his comprehension of the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:15
verses.text: As then that poverty which is according to God is the cause of wealth, and lowliness, of exaltation, and to despise glory is the cause of glory; so also the becoming a fool maketh a man wiser than all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:16
verses.text: For all, with us, goes by contraries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:17
verses.text: Further: why said he not, "Let him put off wisdom," but, "Let him become a fool?" That he might most exceedingly disparage the heathen instruction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:18
verses.text: For it was not the same thing to say, "Lay aside thy wisdom," and, "become a fool".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:19
verses.text: And besides, he is also training people not to be ashamed at the want of refinement among us; for he quite laughs to scorn all heathen things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:20
verses.text: And for the same sort of reason he shrinks not from the names, trusting as he does to the power of the things which he speaks of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:21
verses.text: Wherefore, as the Cross, though counted ignominious, became the author of innumerable blessings, and the foundation and root of glory unspeakable; so also that which was accounted to be foolishness became unto us the cause of wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:22
verses.text: For as he who hath learned anything ill, unless he put away the whole, and make his soul level and clear, and so offer it to him who is to write on it, will know no wholesome truth for certain; so also in regard of the wisdom from without.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:23
verses.text: Unless thou turn out the whole and sweep thy mind clear, and like one that is ignorant yield up thyself unto the faith, thou wilt know accurately nothing excellent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:24
verses.text: For so those also who see imperfectly if they will not shut their eyes and commit themselves unto others, but will be trusting their own matters to their own faulty eyesight, they will commit many more mistakes than those who see not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:25
verses.text: But how, you will say, are men to put off this wisdom? By not acting on its precepts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:26
verses.text: Then, seeing that he bade men so urgently withdraw themselves from it, he adds the cause, saying, "For the wisdom of this world is foolishness with God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:27
verses.text: For not only it contributes nothing, but it even hinders.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:28
verses.text: We must then withdraw ourselves from it, as doing harm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:29
verses.text: Dost thou mark with what a high hand he carries off the spoils of victory, having proved that so far from profiting us at all, it is even an opponent?  And he is not content with his own arguments, but he has also adduced testimony again, saying, "For it is written, (Job v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:30
verses.text: ) He taketh the wise in their own craftiness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:31
verses.text: By "craftiness," i-e: by their own arms getting the better of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:32
verses.text: For seeing that they made use of their wisdom to the doing away of all need of God, by it and no other thing He refuted them, shewing that they were specially in need of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:33
verses.text: How and by what method? Because having by it become fools, by it, as was meet, they were taken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:34
verses.text: For they who supposed that they needed not God, were reduced to so great a strait as to appear inferior to fishermen and unlettered persons; and from that time forth to be unable to do without them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:35
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, "In their own craftiness" He took them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:36
verses.text: For the saying "I will destroy their wisdom," was spoken in regard to its introducing nothing useful; but this, "who taketh the wise in their own craftiness, with a view of shewing the power of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:37
verses.text: Next, he declares also the mode in which God took them, adding another testimony:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:38
verses.text: "For the Lord," saith he, "knoweth the reasonings of men (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:39
verses.text: xciv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:40
verses.text: ἀνθρώπων Sept.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:41
verses.text: ) that they are vain".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:42
verses.text: Now when the Wisdom which is boundless pronounces this edict concerning them, and declares them to be such, what other proof dost thou seek of their extreme folly? For men's judgments, it is true, in many instances fail; but the decree of God is unexceptionable and uncorrupt in every case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:43
verses.text: Thus having set up so splendid a trophy of the judgment from on high, he employs in what follows a certain vehemence of style, turning it against those who were under his ministry, (ἀρχομένους) and speaking thus:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:44
verses.text: "Wherefore let no man glory in men; for all things are yours".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:45
verses.text: He comes again to the former topic, pointing out that not even for their spiritual things ought they to be highminded, as having nothing of themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:46
verses.text: "Since then the wisdom from without is hurtful, and the spiritual gifts were not given by you, what hast thou wherein to boast?" And in regard to the wisdom from without, "Let no man deceive himself," saith he, because they were conceited about a thing which in truth did more harm than good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:47
verses.text: But here, inasmuch as the thing spoken of was really advantageous, "Let no man glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:48
verses.text: And he orders his speech more gently: "for all things are yours".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:49
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:50
verses.text: "Whether Paul, or Apollos, or Cephas, or the world, or life, or death, or things present, or things to come, all are yours; and ye are Christ's and Christ is God's".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:51
verses.text: For because he had handled them sharply, he refreshes them again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:52
verses.text: And as above he had said, ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:53
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:54
verses.text: ) "We are fellow-workers with God;" and by many other expressions had soothed them: so here too he saith, "All things are yours;" taking down the pride of the teachers, and signifying that so far from bestowing any favor on them, they themselves ought to be grateful to the others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:55
verses.text: Since for their sake they were made such as they were, yea, moreover, had received grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:56
verses.text: But seeing that these also were sure to boast, on this account he cuts out beforehand this disease too, saying, "As God gave to every man," (Supr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:57
verses.text: vi) and, "God gave the increase:" to the end that neither the one party might be puffed up as bestowers of good; nor the others, on their hearing a second time, "All things are yours," be again elated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:58
verses.text: "For, indeed, though it were for your sakes, yet the whole was God's doing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:59
verses.text: And I wish you to observe how he hath kept on throughout, making suppositions in his own name and that of Peter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:60
verses.text: But what is, "or death?" That even though they die, for your sakes they die, encountering dangers for your salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:61
verses.text: Dost thou mark how he again takes down the high spirit of the disciples, and raises the spirit of the teachers? In fact, he talks with them as with children of high birth, who have preceptors, and who are to be heirs of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:62
verses.text: We may say also, in another sense, that both the death of Adam was for our sakes, that we might be corrected; and the death of Christ, that we might be saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:63
verses.text: "And ye are Christ's; and Christ is God's".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:64
verses.text: In one sense "we are Christ's," and in another sense "Christ is God's," and in a third sense is "the world ours".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:65
verses.text: For we indeed are Christ's, as his work: "Christ is God's," as a genuine Offspring, not as a work: in which sense neither is the world ours.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:66
verses.text: So that though the saying is the same, yet the meaning is different.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:67
verses.text: For "the world is ours," as being a thing made for our sakes: but "Christ is God's," as having Him the Author of his being, in that He is Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:68
verses.text: And "we are Christ's," as having been formed by Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:69
verses.text: Now "if they are yours," saith he, "why have ye done what is just contrary to this, in calling yourselves after their name, and not after Christ, and God?"   C.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:70
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:71
verses.text: ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:72
verses.text: "Let a man so account of us, as of ministers of Christ, and stewards of the mysteries of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:73
verses.text: After he had cast down their spirit, mark how again he refreshes it, saying, "as ministers of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:74
verses.text: Do not thou then, letting go the Master, receive a name from the servants and ministers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:75
verses.text: "Stewards;" saith he, indicating that we ought not to give these things unto all, but unto whom it is due, and to whom it is fitting we should minister.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:76
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:77
verses.text: "Moreover it is required in stewards, that a man be found faithful:" that is, that he do not appropriate to himself his master's goods, that he do not as a master lay claim for himself but administer as a steward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:78
verses.text: For a steward's part is to administer well the things committed to his charge: not to say that his master's things are his own; but, on the contrary, that his own are his master's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:79
verses.text: Let every one think on these things, both he that hath power in speech and he that possesses wealth, namely, that he hath been entrusted with a master's goods and that they are not his own; let him not keep them with himself, nor set them down to his own account; but let him impute them unto God who gave them all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:80
verses.text: Wouldest thou see faithful stewards? Hear what saith Peter, "Why look ye so earnestly on us, as though by our own power or godliness we had made this man to walk?" (Acts iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:81
verses.text: ) Unto Cornelius also he saith, "We also are men of like passions with you:" and unto Christ Himself, "Lo, we have left all, and followed Thee".

verses.text: (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:88
verses.text: Elsewhere also, setting himself strongly against the same persons, he said, "For what hast thou which thou didst not receive?" (C.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:91
verses.text: Wherefore, when necessity calls, do thou lay down this also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:92
verses.text: But if thou doatest on life, and being ordered to lay it down refusest, thou art no longer a faithful steward".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:93
verses.text: "And how is it possible, when God calls, to resist?" Well, that is just what I say too: and on this account do I chiefly admire the loving-kindness of God, that the things which He is able, even against thy will, to take from thee, these He willeth not to be paid in (εἰσενεχθῆναι) by thee unwillingly, that thou mayest have a reward besides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:94
verses.text: For instance, He can take away life without thy consent; but His will is to do so with thy consent, that thou mayest say with Paul, "I die daily," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:95
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:96
verses.text: ) He can take away thy glory without thy consent, and bring thee low: but He will have it from thee with thine own goodwill, that thou mayest have a recompense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:97
verses.text: He can make thee poor, though unwilling, but He will have thee willingly become such, that He may weave crowns for thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:98
verses.text: Seest thou God's mercy to man? Seest thou our own brutish stupidity?  What if thou art come to great dignity, and hast at any time obtained some office of Church government? Be not high-minded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:99
verses.text: Thou hast not acquired the glory, but God hath put it on thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:100
verses.text: As if it were another's, therefore, use it sparingly; neither abusing it nor using it upon unsuitable things, nor puffed up, nor appropriating it unto thyself; but esteem thyself to be poor and inglorious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:101
verses.text: For never,—hadst thou been entrusted with a king's purple to keep,—never would it have become thee to abuse the robe and spoil it, but with the more exactness to keep it for the giver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:102
verses.text: Is utterance given thee? Be not puffed up; be not arrogant; for the gracious gift is not thine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:103
verses.text: Be not grudging about thy Master's good, but distribute them among thy fellow-servants; and neither be thou elated with these things as if they were thine own, nor be sparing as to the distribution of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:104
verses.text: Again, if thou hast children, they are God's which thou hast.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:105
verses.text: If such be thy thought, thou wilt both be thankful for having them, and if bereft thou wilt not take it hard.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:106
verses.text: Such was Job when he said, (Job i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:107
verses.text: ) "The Lord gave, the Lord hath taken away".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:108
verses.text: For we have all things from Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:109
verses.text: Both existence itself we have through Him, and life, and breath, and light, and air, and earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:110
verses.text: And if He were to exclude us from any one of these, we are lost and undone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:111
verses.text: For ( S.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:112
verses.text: Pet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:113
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:114
verses.text: ) "we are sojourners and pilgrims".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:115
verses.text: And all this about "mine," and "thine," is bare words only, and doth not stand for things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:116
verses.text: For if thou do but say the house is thine, it is a word without a reality: since the very air, earth, matter, are the Creator's; and so art thou too thyself, who hast framed it; and all other things also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:117
verses.text: But supposing the use to be thine, even this is uncertain, not on account of death alone, but also before death, because of the instability of things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:118
verses.text: These things then continually picturing to ourselves, let us lead strict lives; and we shall gain two of the greatest advantages.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:119
verses.text: For first, we shall be thankful both when we have and when we are bereaved; and we shall not be enslaved to things which are fleeting by, and things not our own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:120
verses.text: For whether it be wealth that He taketh, He hath taken but His own; or honor, or glory, or the body, or the life itself: be it that He taketh away thy son, it is not thy son that He hath taken, but His own servant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:121
verses.text: For thou formedst him not, but He made him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:122
verses.text: Thou didst but minister to his appearing; the whole was God's own work.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:123
verses.text: Let us give thanks therefore that we have been counted worthy to be His ministers in this matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:124
verses.text: But what? Wouldest thou have had him for ever? This again proves thee grudging, and ignorant that it was another's child which thou hadst, and not thine own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:125
verses.text: As therefore those who part resignedly are but aware that they have what was not theirs; so whoever gives way to grief is in fact counting the King's property his own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:126
verses.text: For, if we are not our own, how can they be ours? I say, we: for in two ways we are His, both on account of our creation, and also on account of the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:127
verses.text: Wherefore David saith, "My substance is with Thee:" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:128
verses.text: xxxix.

verses.text: ὑπόστασις Sept.

verses.text: "hope" rec.

verses.text: of.

verses.text: ver.

verses.text: ; Ps.

verses.text: cxxxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:136
verses.text: ) and Paul too, "For in Him we live and move and have our being:" (Acts xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:137
verses.text: ) and plying the argument about the faith, he says, ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:138
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:140
verses.text: ) "Ye are not your own," and "ye were bought with a price".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:141
verses.text: For all things are God's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:142
verses.text: When then He calls and chooses to take, let us not, like grudging servants, fly from the reckoning, nor purloin our Master's goods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:143
verses.text: Thy soul is not thine; and how can thy wealth be thine? How is it then that thou spendest on what is unnecessary the things which are not thine? Knowest thou not that for this we are soon to be put on our trial, that is, if we have used them badly? But seeing that they are not our's but our Master's, it were right to expend them upon our fellow-servants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:144
verses.text: It is worth considering that the omission of this was the charge brought against that rich man: and against those also who had not given food to the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:145
verses.text: (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:146
verses.text: Luke xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:147
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:148
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:149
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:150
verses.text: )   Say not then, "I am but spending mine own, and of mine own I live delicately".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:151
verses.text: It is not of thine own, but of other men's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:152
verses.text: Other men's, I say, because such is thine own choice: for God's will is that those things should be thine, which have been entrusted unto thee on behalf of thy brethren.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:153
verses.text: Now the things which are not thine own become thine, if thou spend them upon others: but if thou spend on thyself unsparingly, thine own things become no longer thine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:154
verses.text: For since thou usest them cruelly, and sayest, "That my own things should be altogether spent on my own enjoyment is fair:" therefore I call them not thine own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:155
verses.text: For they are common to thee and thy fellow-servants; just as the sun is common, the air, the earth, and all the rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:156
verses.text: For as in the case of the body, each ministration belongs both to the whole body and to each several member; but when it is applied to one single member only, it destroys the proper function of that very member: so also it comes to pass in the case of wealth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:157
verses.text: And that what I say may be made plainer; the food of the body which is given in common to the members, should it pass into one member, even to that it turns out alien in the end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:158
verses.text: For when it cannot be digested nor afford nourishment, even to that part, I say, it turns out alien.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:159
verses.text: But if it be made common, both that part and all the rest have it as their own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:160
verses.text: So also in regard of wealth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:161
verses.text: If you enjoy it alone, you too have lost it: for you will not reap its reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:162
verses.text: But if you possess it jointly with the rest, then will it be more your own, and then will you reap the benefit of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:163
verses.text: Seest thou not that the hands minister, and the mouth softens, and the stomach receives? Doth the stomach say, Since I have received, I ought to keep it all? Then do not thou I pray, in regard to riches, use this language.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:164
verses.text: For it belongs to the receiver to impart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:165
verses.text: As then it is a vice in the stomach to retain the food and not to distribute it, (for it is injurious to the whole body,) so it is a vice in those that are rich to keep to themselves what they have.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:166
verses.text: For this destroys both themselves and others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:167
verses.text: Again, the eye receives all the light: but it doth not itself alone retain it, but enlightens the entire body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:168
verses.text: For it is not its nature to keep it to itself, so long as it is an eye.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:169
verses.text: Again, the nostrils are sensible of perfume; but they do not keep it all to themselves, but transmit it to the brain, and affect the stomach with a sweet savor, and by their means refresh the entire man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:170
verses.text: The feet alone walk; but they move not away themselves only, but transfer also the whole body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:171
verses.text: In like manner do thou, whatsoever thou hast been entrusted withal, keep it not to thyself alone, since thou art doing harm to the whole and to thyself more than all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:172
verses.text: And not in the case of the limbs only may one see this occuring: for the smith also, if he chose to impart of his craft to no one, ruins both himself and all other crafts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:173
verses.text: Likewise the cordwainer, the husbandman, the baker, and everyone of those who pursue any necessary calling; if he chose not to communicate to anyone of the results of his art, will ruin not the others only but himself also with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:174
verses.text: And why do I say, "the rich?" For the poor too, if they followed after the wickedness of you who are covetous and rich, would injure you very greatly and soon make you poor; yea rather, they would quite destroy you, were they in your want unwilling to impart of their own: the tiller of the ground, (for instance,) of the labor of his hands; the sailor, of the gain from his voyages; the soldier, of his distinction won in the wars.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:175
verses.text: Wherefore if nothing else can, yet let this at least put you to shame, and do you imitate their benevolence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:176
verses.text: Dost thou impart none of thy wealth unto any? Then shouldest thou not receive any thing from another: in which case, the world will be turned upside down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:177
verses.text: For in every thing to give and receive is the principle of numerous blessings: in seeds, in scholars, in arts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:178
verses.text: For if any one desire to keep his art to himself, he subverts both himself and the whole course of things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:179
verses.text: And the husbandman, if he bury and keep the seeds in his house, will bring about a grievous famine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:180
verses.text: So also the rich man, if he act thus in regard of his wealth, will destroy himself before the poor, heaping up the fire of hell more grievous upon his own head.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:181
verses.text: Therefore as teachers, however many scholars they have, impart some of their lore unto each; so let thy possession be, many to whom thou hast done good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:182
verses.text: And let all say, "such an one he freed from poverty, such an one from dangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:183
verses.text: Such an one would have perished, had he not, next to the grace of God, enjoyed thy patronage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:184
verses.text: This man's disease thou didst cure, another thou didst rid of false accusation, another being a stranger you took in, another being naked you clothed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:185
verses.text: Wealth inexhaustible and many treasures are not so good as such sayings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:186
verses.text: They draw all men's gaze more powerfully than your golden vestments, and horses, and slaves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:187
verses.text: For these make a man appear even odious: (φορτικόν, a conj.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:188
verses.text: of Saville's for φορτικά) they cause him to be hated as a common foe; but the former proclaim him as a common father and benefactor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:189
verses.text: And, what is greatest of all, Favor from God waits on thee in every part of thy proceedings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:190
verses.text: What I mean is, let one man say, He helped to portion out my daughter: another, And he afforded my son the means of taking his station among men: (εἰς ἄνδρας ἐμφανῆναι) another, He made my calamity to cease: another, He delivered me from dangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:191
verses.text: Better than golden crowns are words such as these, that a man should have in his city innumerable persons to proclaim his beneficence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:192
verses.text: Voices such as these are pleasanter far, and sweeter than the voices of the heralds marching before the archons; to be called saviour, benefactor, defender, (the very names of God;) and not, covetous, proud, insatiate, and mean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:193
verses.text: Let us not, I beseech you, let us not have a fancy for any of these titles, but the contrary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 9:194
verses.text: For if these, spoken on earth, make one so splendid and illustrious; when they are written in heaven, and God proclaims them on the day that shall come, think what renown, what splendor thou shalt enjoy! Which may it be the lot of us all to obtain, through the grace and loving-kindness of our Lord Jesus Christ; with Whom unto the Father and the Holy Spirit, be glory, power, honor, now and always and unto everlasting ages, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:1
verses.text: Homily XI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:3
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:4
verses.text: ,  But with me it is a very small thing that I should be judged of you, or of man's judgment: yea I judge not mine own self.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:5
verses.text: For I know nothing against myself, yet am I not hereby justified: but He that judgeth me is the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:6
verses.text: Together with all other ills, I know not how, there hath come upon man's nature the disease of restless prying and of unseasonable curiosity, which Christ Himself chastised, saying, (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:7
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:8
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:9
verses.text: ) "Judge not, that ye be not judged".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:10
verses.text: A kind of thing, which hath no pleasure as all other sins have, but only punishment and vengeance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:11
verses.text: For though we are ourselves full of ten thousand evils, and bearing the "beams" in our own eyes, we become exact inquisitors of the offences of our neighbor which are not at all bigger than "motes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:12
verses.text: And so this matter at Corinth was falling out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:13
verses.text: Religious men and dear to God were ridiculed and cast out for their want of learning; while others, brimful of evils innumerable, were classed highly because of their fluent speech.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:14
verses.text: Then like persons sitting in public to try causes, these were the sort of votes they kept rashly passing: "such an one is worthy: such an one is better than such another; this man is inferior to that; that, better than this".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:15
verses.text: And, leaving off to mourn for their own bad ways, they were become judges of others; and in this way again were kindling grievous warfare.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:16
verses.text: Mark then, how wisely Paul corrects them, doing away with this disease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:17
verses.text: For since he had said, "Moreover, it is required in stewards that a man be found faithful," and it seemed as if he were giving them an opening to judge and pry into each man's life, and this was aggravating the party feeling; lest such should be the effect on them, he draws them away from that kind of petty disputation, saying, "With me it is a very small thing that I should be judged of you;" again in his own person carrying on the discourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:18
verses.text: But what means, "With me it is a very small thing that I should be judged of you or of man's day?" (ἡμέρας) "I judge myself unworthy," saith he, "of being judged by you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:19
verses.text: And why say I, "by you?" I will add, "by (καὶ τὸ τοῦ) any one else".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:20
verses.text: Howbeit, let no one condemn Paul of arrogance; though he saith that no man is worthy to pass sentence concerning him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:21
verses.text: For first, he saith these things not for his own sake, but wishing to rescue others from the odium which they had incurred from the Corinthians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:22
verses.text: And in the next place, he limits not the matter to the Corinthians merely, but himself also he deposes from this right of judging; saying, that to decree such things was a matter beyond his decision.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:23
verses.text: At least he adds, "I judge not mine own self".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:24
verses.text: But besides what has been said, we must search out the ground upon which these expressions were uttered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:25
verses.text: For he knew well in many cases how to speak with high spirit: and that, not of pride or arrogance, but of a certain excellent management οἰκονομίας ἀρίστης seeing that in the present case also he saith this, not as lifting up himself, but as taking down other men's sails, and earnestly seeking to invest the saints with due honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:26
verses.text: For in proof that he was one of the very humble, hear what he saith, bringing forward the testimony of his enemies on this point; "His bodily presence is weak, and his speech of no account; ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:27
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:28
verses.text: ) and again, "Last of all, as to one born out of due time, He appeared unto me also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:29
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:30

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:31
verses.text: ) But notwithstanding, see this lowly man, when the time called on him, to what a pitch he raises the spirit of the disciples, not teaching pride but instilling a wholesome courage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:32
verses.text: For with these same discoursing he saith, "And if the world shall be judged by you, are ye unworthy to judge the smallest matters?  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:33
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:34
verses.text: For as the Christian ought to be far removed from arrogance, so also from flattery and a mean spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:35
verses.text: Thus, if any one says, "I count money as nothing, but all things here are to me as a shadow, and a dream, and child's play;" we are not at all to charge him as arrogant; since in this way we shall have to accuse Solomon himself of arrogance, for speaking austerely (φιλοσοφοῦντα) on these things, saying "Vanity of vanities (Eccles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:36
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:37
verses.text: ) all is vanity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:38
verses.text: But God forbid that we should call the strict rule of life by the name of arrogance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:39
verses.text: Wherefore to despise these things is not haughtiness, but greatness of soul; albeit we see kings, and rulers, and potentates, making much of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:40
verses.text: But many a poor man, leading a strict life despises them; and we are not therefore to call him arrogant but highminded: just as, on the other hand, if any be extremely addicted to them, we do not call him lowly of heart and moderate, but weak, and poor spirited, and ignoble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:41
verses.text: For so, should a son despise the pursuits which become his father and affect slavish ways, we should not commend him as lowly of heart, but as base and servile we should reproach him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:42
verses.text: What we should admire in him would be, his despising those meaner things and making much account of what came to him from his father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:43
verses.text: For this is arrogance, to think one's self better than one's fellow-servants: but to pass the true sentence on things cometh not of boasting, but of strictness of life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:44
verses.text: On this account Paul also, not to exalt himself, but to humble others, and to keep down those who were rising up out of their places, and to persuade them to be modest, said, "With me it is a very small thing that I should be judged of you or of man's day".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:45
verses.text: Observe how he soothes the other party also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:46
verses.text: For whosoever is told that he looks down on all alike, and deigns not to be judged of any one, will not thenceforth any more feel pain, as though himself were the only one excluded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:47
verses.text: For if he had said, "Of you," only, and so held his peace; this were enough to gall them as if treated contemptuously.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:48
verses.text: But now, by introducing, "nor yet of man's day," he brought alleviation to the blow; giving them partners in the contempt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:49
verses.text: Nay, he even softens this point again, saying, "not even do I judge myself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:50
verses.text: Mark the expression, how entirely free from arrogance: in that not even he himself, he saith, is capable of so great exactness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:51
verses.text: Then because this saying also seemed to be that of one extolling himself greatly, this too he corrects, saying, "Yet am I not hereby justified".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:52
verses.text: What then? Ought we not to judge ourselves and our own misdeeds? Yes surely: there is great need to do this when we sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:53
verses.text: But Paul said not this, "For I know nothing," saith he, "against myself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:54
verses.text: What misdeed then was he to judge, when he "knew nothing against himself?" Yet, saith he, "he was not justified".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:55
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:56
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:57
verses.text: ) We then who have our conscience filled with ten thousand wounds, and are conscious to ourselves of nothing good, but quite the contrary; what can we say?  And how could it be, if he knew nothing against himself that he was not justified? Because it was possible for him to have committed certain sins, not however, knowing that they were sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:58
verses.text: From this make thine estimate how great shall be the strictness of the future judgment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:59
verses.text: It is not, you see, as considering himself unblameable that he saith it is so unmeet for him to be judged by them, but to stop the mouths of those who were doing so unreasonably.
