verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:60
verses.text: At least in another place, even though men's sins be notorious, he permits not judgment unto others, because the occasion required it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:61
verses.text: "For why dost thou judge thy brother," saith he, (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:62
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:63
verses.text: ) or, "thou, why dost thou set at nought thy brother?" For thou wert not enjoined, O man, to judge others, but to test thine own doings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:64
verses.text: Why then dost thou seize upon the office of the Lord? Judgment is His, not thine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:65
verses.text: To which effect, he adds, "Therefore judge nothing before the time, until the Lord come; who will both bring to light the hidden things of darkness, and make manifest the counsels of the hearts, and then shall each man have his praise from God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:66
verses.text: What then? Is it not right that our teachers should do this? It is right in the case of open and confessed sins, and that with fitting opportunity, and even then with pain and inward vexation: not as these were acting at that time, of vain-glory and arrogance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:67
verses.text: For neither in this instance is he speaking of those sins which all own to be such, but about preferring one before another, and making comparisons of modes of life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:68
verses.text: For these things He alone knows how to judge with accuracy, who is to judge our secret doings, which of these be worthy of greater and which of less punishment and honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:69
verses.text: But we do all this according to what meets our eye.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:70
verses.text: "For if in mine own errors," saith he, "I know nothing clearly, how can I be worthy to pass sentence on other men? And how shall I who know not my own case with accuracy, be able to judge the state of others?" Now if Paul felt this, much more we.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:71
verses.text: For (to proceed) he spake these things, not to exhibit himself as faultless, but to shew that even should there be among them some such person, free from transgression, not even he would be worthy to judge the lives of others: and that if he, though conscious to himself of nothing declare himself guilty, much more they who have ten thousand sins to be conscious of in themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:72
verses.text: Having thus, you see, stopped the mouths of those who pass such sentences, he travails next with strong feeling ready to break out and come upon the unclean person.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:73
verses.text: And like as when a storm is coming on, some clouds fraught with darkness run before it; afterwards, when the crash of the thunders ariseth and works the whole heavens into one black cloud, then all at once the rain bursts down upon the earth: so also did it then happen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:74
verses.text: For though he might in deep indignation have dealt with the fornicator, he doth not so; but with fearful words he first represses the swelling pride of the man, since in truth, what had occurred was a twofold sin, fornication, and, that which is worse than fornication, the not grieving over the sin committed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:75
verses.text: For not so much does he bewail the sin, as him that committed it and did not as yet repent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:76
verses.text: Thus, "I shall bewail many of those," saith he, not simply "who have sinned heretofore," but he adds, "who have not repented of the uncleanness and impurity which they wrought".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:77
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:78
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:79
verses.text: ) For he who after sinning hath practised repentance, is a worthy object not of grief but of gratulations, having passed over into the choir of the righteous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:80
verses.text: For, (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:81
verses.text: xliii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:82
verses.text: ) "declare thou thine iniquities first, that thou mayest be justified:" but if after sinning one is void of shame, he is not so much to be pitied for falling as for lying where he is fallen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:83
verses.text: Now if it be a grievous fault not to repent after sins; to be puffed up because of sins, what sort of punishment doth it deserve? For if he who is elate for his good deeds is unclean, what pardon shall he meet with who has that feeling with regard to his sins?  Since then the fornicator was of this sort, and had rendered his mind so headstrong and unyielding through his sin, he of course begins by casting down his pride.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:84
verses.text: And he neither puts the charge first, for fear of making him hardened, as singled out for accusation before the rest; nor yet later, lest he should suppose that what related to him was but incidental.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:85
verses.text: But, having first excited great alarm in him by his plain speaking towards others, then, and not till then, he goes on to him, in the course of his rebuke to others giving the man's wilfulness a share beforehand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:86
verses.text: For these same words, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:87
verses.text: "I know nothing against myself, yet am I not hereby justified," and this, "He that judgeth me is the Lord, who will both bring to light the hidden things of darkness, and make manifest the counsels of the hearts," glance not lightly both upon that person, and upon such as act in concert with him and despise the saints.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:88
verses.text: "For what," saith he, "if any outwardly appear to be virtuous and admirable persons? He, the Judge, is not a discerner of externals only, but also brings to light all secrets".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:89
verses.text: On two accounts you see, or rather on three, correct judgement belongs not to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:90
verses.text: One, because, though we be conscious to ourselves of nothing, still we need one to reprove our sins with strictness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:91
verses.text: Another, because the most part of the things which are done escape us and are concealed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:92
verses.text: And for a third besides these, because many things which are done by others seem to us indeed fair, but they come not of a right mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:93
verses.text: Why say ye then, that no sin hath been committed by this or that person? That such an one is better than such another? Seeing that this we are not to pronounce, not even concerning him who knows nothing against himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:94
verses.text: For He who discerns secrets, He it is who with certainty judges.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:95
verses.text: Behold, for example; I for my part know nothing against myself: yet neither so am I justified, that is, I am not quit of accounts to be given, nor of charges to be answered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:96
verses.text: For he doth not say this, "I rank not among the righteous;" but "I am not pure from sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:97
verses.text: For elsewhere he saith also, (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:98
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:99
verses.text: , δεδικαίωται, τουτεστιν ἀπήλλακται.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:100
verses.text: ) "He that hath died is justified from sin," that is, "is liberated".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:101
verses.text: Again, many things we do, good indeed, but not of a right mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:102
verses.text: For so we commend many, not from a wish to render them conspicuous, but to wound others by means of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:103
verses.text: And the thing done indeed is right for the well-doer is praised; but the intention is corrupt: for it is done of a satanical purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:104
verses.text: For this one hath often done, not rejoicing with his brother, but desiring to wound the other party.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:105
verses.text: Again, a man hath committed a great error; some other person, wishing to supplant him, says that he hath done nothing, and comforts him forsooth in his error by recurring to the common frailty of nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:106
verses.text: But oftentimes he doth this from no mind to sympathize, but to make him more easy in his faults.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:107
verses.text: Again, a man rebukes oftentimes not so much to reprove and admonish, as publicly to (ἐκπομπεῦσαι καὶ ἐκτραγωδῆσαι) display and exaggerate his neighbor's sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:108
verses.text: Our counsels however themselves men do not know; but, (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:109
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:110
verses.text: ) "He that searcheth the hearts," knows them perfectly; and He will bring all such things into view at that time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:111
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, "Who will bring to light the secret things of darkness and make manifest the counsels of the hearts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:112
verses.text: Seeing then that not even where we "know nothing against ourselves," can we be clean from accusations, and where we do any thing good, but do it not of a right mind, we are liable to punishment; consider how vastly men are deceived in their judgments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:113
verses.text: For all these matters are not be come at by men, but by the unsleeping Eye alone: and though we may deceive men, our sophistry will never avail against Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:114
verses.text: Say not then, darkness is around me and walls; who seeth me? For He who by Himself formed our hearts, Himself knoweth all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:115
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:116
verses.text: cxxxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:117
verses.text: ) "For darkness is no darkness with Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:118
verses.text: And yet he who is committing sin, well saith, "Darkness is around me and walls;" for were there not a darkness in his mind he would not have cast out the fear of God and acted as he pleased.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:119
verses.text: For unless the ruling principle be first darkened, the entrance of sin without fear is a thing impossible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:120
verses.text: Say not then, who seeth me? For there is that (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:121
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:122
verses.text: ) "pierceth even unto soul and spirit, joints and marrow;" but thou seest not thyself nor canst thou pierce the cloud; but as if thou hadst a wall on all sides surrounding thee, thou art without power to look up unto the heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:123
verses.text: For whatsoever sin thou wilt, first let us examine, and thou shalt see that so it is engendered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:124
verses.text: For as robbers and they who dig through walls when they desire to carry off any valuable thing, put out the candle and then do their work; so also doth men's perverse reasoning in the case of those who are committing sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:125
verses.text: Since in us also surely there is a light, the light of reason, ever burning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:126
verses.text: But if the spirit of wickedness coming eagerly on with its strong blast quench that flame, it straightway darkens the soul and prevails against it, and despoils it straightway of all that is laid up therein.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:127
verses.text: For when by unclean desire the soul is made captive, even as a cloud and mist the eyes of the body, so that desire intercepts the foresight of the mind, and suffers it to see nothing at any distance, either precipice, or hell, or fear; but thenceforth, having that deceit as a tyrant over him, he comes to be easily vanquished by sin; and there is raised up before his eyes as it were a wall without windows, which suffers not the ray of righteousness to shine in upon the mind, the absurd conceits of lust enclosing it as with a rampart on all sides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:128
verses.text: And from that time forward the unchaste woman is everywhere meeting him: standing present before his eyes, before his mind, before his thoughts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:129
verses.text: And as the blind, although they stand at high noon beneath the very central point of the heaven, receive not the light, their eyes being fast closed up; just so these also, though ten thousand doctrines of salvation sound in their ears from all quarters, having their soul preoccupied with this passion stop their ears against such discourses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:130
verses.text: And they know it well who have made the trial.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:131
verses.text: But God forbid that you should know it from actual experience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:132
verses.text: And not only this sin hath these effects, but every misplaced affection as well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:133
verses.text: For let us transfer, if you please, the argument from the unchaste woman unto money, and we shall see here also thick and unbroken darkness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:134
verses.text: For in the former case, inasmuch as the beloved object is one and shut up in one place, the feeling is not so violent; but in the case of money which sheweth itself every where, in silversmiths' shops, in taverns, in foundries for gold, in the houses of the wealthy, the passion blows a vehement gale.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:135
verses.text: For when servants swaggering in the market place, horses with golden trappings, men decked with costly garments, are seen with desire by him who has that distemper, the darkness becomes intense which envelopes him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:136
verses.text: And why speak of houses and silversmiths' shops? for my part I think that such persons, though it be but in a picture and image that they see the wealth, are convulsed, and grow wild, and rave.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:137
verses.text: So that from all quarters the darkness gathers around them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:138
verses.text: And if they chance to behold a portraiture of a King, they admire not the beauty of the precious stones, nor yet the gold, nor the purple robe, but they pine away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:139
verses.text: And as the wretched lover before mentioned, though he see but the image of the woman beloved, cleaveth unto the lifeless thing; so this man also, beholding a lifeless image of wealth, is more strongly affected in the same way, as being holden of a more tyrannical passion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:140
verses.text: And he must henceforth either abide at home, or if he venture into the Forum, return home with innumerable hurts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:141
verses.text: For many are the objects which grieve his eyes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:142
verses.text: And just as the former seeth nothing else save the woman, even so the latter hastens by poor persons, and all things else, that he may not obtain so much as a slight alleviation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:143
verses.text: But upon the wealthy he steadily fixeth his eyes; by the sight of them introducing the fire into his own soul mightily and vehemently.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:144
verses.text: For it is a fire that miserably devours the person that falls into it; and if no hell were threatened nor yet punishment, this condition were itself punishment; to be continually tormented and never able to find an end to the malady.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:145
verses.text: Well: these things alone might suffice to recommend our fleeing from this distemper.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:146
verses.text: But there is no greater evil than inconsideration which causes men to be rivetted unto things that bring sorrow of heart and no advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:147
verses.text: Wherefore I exhort that you cut off the passion at its beginning: for just as a fever on its first attack, does not violently burn up the patients with thirst, but on its increase and the heightening of its fire causes from that time incurable thirst; and though one should let them fill themselves full of drink, it puts not out the furnace but makes it burn fiercer: so also it happens in regard to this passion; unless when it first invadeth our soul we stop it and shut the doors; having got in, from that time it makes the disease of those who have admitted it incurable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:148
verses.text: For so both good things and bad, the longer they abide in us, the more powerful they become.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:149
verses.text: And in all other things too, any one may see that this cometh to pass.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:150
verses.text: For so a plant but lately set in the ground is easily pulled up; but no more so when rooted for a long time; it then requires great strength in the lever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:151
verses.text: And a building newly put together is easily thrown down by those who push against it; but once well fixed, it gives great trouble to those who attempt to pull it down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:152
verses.text: And a wild beast that hath made his accustomed haunt in certain places for a long time is with difficulty driven away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:153
verses.text: Those therefore who are not yet possessed by the passion in question, I exhort not to be taken captive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:154
verses.text: For it is more easy to guard against falling into it, than having fallen to get away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:155
verses.text: But unto those who are seized by it and broken down, if they will consent to put themselves into the hands of the Word of healing, I promise large hope of salvation, by the Grace of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:156
verses.text: For if they will consider those who have suffered and fallen into that distemper and have recovered, they will have good hopes respecting the removal of the disease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:157
verses.text: Who then ever fell into this disease, and was easily rid of it? That well-known Zacchaeus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:158
verses.text: For who could be more fond of money than a publican? But all at once he became a man of strict life, (Φιλόσοφος) and put out all that blaze.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:159
verses.text: Matthew in like manner: for he too was a publican, living in continual rapine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:160
verses.text: But he likewise all at once stripped himself of the mischief, and quenched his thirst, and followed after spiritual gain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:161
verses.text: Considering therefore these, and the like to them, despair not even thou.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:162
verses.text: For if thou wilt, quickly thou shalt be able to recover.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:163
verses.text: And if you please, according to the rule of physicians, we will prescribe accurately what thou shouldest do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:164
verses.text: It is necessary then, before all other things, to be right in this, that we never despond, nor despair of our salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:165
verses.text: Next, we must look not only upon the examples of those who have done well, but also upon the sufferings of those who have persisted in sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:166
verses.text: For as we have considered Zacchaeus, and Matthew, even so ought we also to take account of Judas, and Gehazi, and Ahar, perhaps Achan, Josh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:167
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:168
verses.text: and Ahab, and Ananias, and Sapphira, in order that by the one, we may cast out all despair, and by the other cut off all indolence; and that the soul become not reckless of the remedies suggested.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:169
verses.text: And let us teach them of themselves to say what the Jews said on that day, approaching unto Peter, (Acts ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:170
verses.text: , cf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:171
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:172
verses.text: ) "What must we do to be saved?" And let them hear what they must do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:173
verses.text: What then must we do? We must know how worthless the things in question are, and that wealth is a run-away slave, and heartless, and encompasseth its possessors with ills innumerable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:174
verses.text: And such words, like charms, let us sound in their ears continually.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:175
verses.text: And as physicians soothe their patients when they ask for cold water, by saying that they will give it, making excuses about the spring, and the vessel, and the fit time, and many more such, (for should they refuse at once, they make them wild with phrensy,) so let us also act towards the lovers of money.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:176
verses.text: When they say we desire to be rich, let us not say immediately that wealth is an evil thing; but let us assent, and say that we also desire it; but in due time; yea, true wealth; yea, that which hath undying pleasure: yea, that which is gathered for thyself, and not for others, and those often our enemies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:177
verses.text: And let us produce the lessons of true wisdom, and say, we forbid not riches, but ill-gotten riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:178
verses.text: For it is lawful to be rich, but without covetousness, without rapine and violence, and an ill report from all men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:179
verses.text: With these arguments let us first smooth them down, and not as yet discourse of hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:180
verses.text: For the sick man endures not yet such sayings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:181
verses.text: Wherefore let us go to this world for all our arguments upon these matters; and say, "Why is it thy choice to be rich through covetousness? That the gold and the silver may be laid up for others, but for thee, curses and accusations innumerable? That he whom you have defrauded may be stung by want of the very necessaries of life, and bewail himself, and draw down upon thee the censure of thousands; and may go at fall of evening about the market place, encountering every one in the alleys, and in utter perplexity, and not knowing what to trust to even for that one night? For how is he to sleep after all, with pangs of the belly, restless famine besetting him, and that often while it is freezing, and the rain coming down on him? And while thou, having washed, returnest home from the bath, in a glow with soft raiment, merry of heart and rejoicing, and hastening unto a banquet prepared and costly: he, driven every where about the market place by cold and hunger, takes his round, stooping low and stretching out his hands; nor hath he even spirit without trembling to make his suit for his necessary food to one so full fed and so bent on taking his ease; nay, often he has to retire with insult.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:182
verses.text: When therefore thou hast returned home, when thou liest down on thy couch, when the lights round thine house shine bright, when the table is prepared and plentiful, at that time call to rememberance that poor miserable man wandering about, like the dogs in the alleys, in darkness and in mire; except indeed when, as is often the case, he has to depart thence, not unto house, nor wife, nor bed, but unto a pallet of straw; even as we see the dogs baying all through the night.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:183
verses.text: And thou, if thou seest but a little drop falling from the roof, throwest the whole house into confusion, calling thy slaves and disturbing every thing: while he, laid in rags, and straw, and dirt, has to bear all the cold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:184
verses.text: What wild beast would not be softened by these things? Who is there so savage and inhuman that these things should not make him mild? and yet there are some who are arrived at such a pitch of cruelty as even to say that they deserve what they suffer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:185
verses.text: Yea, when they ought to pity, and weep, and help to alleviate men's calamities, they on the contrary visit them with savage and inhuman censures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:186
verses.text: Of these I should be glad to ask, Tell me, why do they deserve what they suffer? Is it because they would be fed and not starve?  No, you will reply; but because they would be fed in idleness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:187
verses.text: And thou, dost not thou wanton in idleness? What say I? Art thou not oft-times toiling in an occupation more grievous than any idleness, grasping, and oppressing, and coveting? Better were it if thou too wert idle after this sort; for it is better to be idle in this way, than to be covetous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:188
verses.text: But now thou even tramplest on the calamities of others, not only idling, not only pursuing an occupation worse than idleness, but also maligning those who spend their days in misery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:189
verses.text: And let us farther narrate to them the disasters of others; the untimely bereavements, the dwellers in prison, those who are torn to pieces before tribunals, those who are trembling for life; the unlooked for widowhood of women; the sudden reverse of the rich: and with this let us soften their minds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:190
verses.text: For by our narrations concerning others, we shall induce them by all means to fear these evils in their own case too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:191
verses.text: For when they hear that the son of such an one who was a covetous and grasping man, or (ἠ τοῦ δεῖνος instead of ἦν; τοῦ δεῖνος) the wife of such an one who did many tyrannical actions, after the death of her husband endured afflictions without end; the injured persons setting upon the wife and the children, and a general war being raised from all quarters against his house; although a man be the most senseless of beings, yet expecting himself also to suffer the same, and fearing for his own lest they undergo the same fate, he will become more moderate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:192
verses.text: Now we find life full of many such histories, and we shall not be at a loss for correctives of this kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:193
verses.text: But when we speak these things, let us not speak them as giving advice or counsel, lest our discourse become too irksome: but as in the order of the narrative and by association with something else, let us proceed in each case unto that kind of conversation, and let us be constantly putting them upon stories of the kind, permitting them to speak of no subject except these which follow: How such an one's splendid and famous mansion fell down; How it is so entirely desolate that all things that were in it have come into the hands of others; How many trials have taken place daily about this same property, what a stir; How many of that man's relations (οἴκεται, probably οἰκεῖοι) have died either beggars, or inhabitants of a prison.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:194
verses.text: All these things let us speak as in pity for the deceased, and as depreciating things present; in order that by fear and by pity we may soften the cruel mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:195
verses.text: And when we see men shrinking into themselves at these narrations, then and not till then let us introduce to their notice also the doctrine of hell, not as terrifying these, but in compassion for others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:196
verses.text: And let us say, But why speak of things present? For far, indeed, will our concern be from ending with these; a yet more grievous punishment will await all such persons: even a river of fire, and a poisonous worm, and darkness interminable, and undying tortures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:197
verses.text: If with such addresses we succeed in throwing a spell over them, we shall correct both ourselves and them, and quickly get the better of our infirmity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:198
verses.text: And on that day we shall have God to praise us: as also Paul saith, "And then shall each man have praise from God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:199
verses.text: For that which cometh from men, is both fleeting, and sometimes it proceeds from no good intentions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:200
verses.text: But that which cometh from God both abideth continually, and shines out clearly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:201
verses.text: For when He who knew all things before their creation, and who is free from all passion, gives praise, then also the demonstration of our virtue is even unquestionable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 10:202
verses.text: Knowing these things therefore, let us act so as to be praised of God, and to acquire the greatest blessings; which God grant us all to obtain, through the grace and loving-kindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father and the Holy Spirit be glory, power, honor, now and always, and unto all the ages of eternity, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:1
verses.text: Homily XII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:3
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:4
verses.text: Now these things, brethren, I have in a figure transferred to myself and Apollos for your sakes; that in us ye might learn not to think of men above that which is written.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:5
verses.text: So long as there was need of expressions as harsh as these, he refrained from drawing up the curtain, and went on arguing as if he were himself the person to whom they were addressed; in order that the dignity of the persons censured tending to counteract the censurers, no room might be left for flying out in wrath at the charges.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:6
verses.text: But when the time came for a gentler process, then he strips it off, and removes the mask, and shows the persons concealed by the appellation of Paul and Apollos.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:7
verses.text: And on this account he said, "These things, brethren, I have transferred in a figure unto myself and Apollos".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:8
verses.text: And as in the case of the sick, when the child being out of health kicks and turns away from the food offered by the physicians, the attendants call the father or the tutor, and bid them take the food from the physician's hands and bring it, so that out of fear towards them he may take it and be quiet: so also Paul, intending to censure them about certain other persons, of whom some, he thought, were injured, others honored above measure, did not set down the persons themselves, but conducted the argument in his own name and that of Apollos, in order that reverencing these they might receive his mode of cure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:9
verses.text: But that once received, he presently makes known in whose behalf he was so expressing himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:10
verses.text: Now this was not hypocrisy, but condescension (συγκατάβασις) and tact (οἰκονομία).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:11
verses.text: For if he had said openly, "As for you, the men whom ye are judging are saints, and worthy of all admiration;" they might have taken it ill and (κἂν ἀπεπήδησαν) started back.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:12
verses.text: But now in saying, "But to me it is a very small thing that I should be judged of you:" and again, "Who is Paul, and who is Apollos?" he rendered his speech easy of reception.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:13
verses.text: This, if you mark it, is the reason why he says here, "These things have I transferred in a figure unto myself for your sakes, that in us ye may learn not to be wise above what is written," signifying that if he had applied his argument in their persons, they would not have learnt all that they needed to learn, nor would have admitted the correction, being vexed at what was said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:14
verses.text: But as it was, revering Paul, they bore the rebuke well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:15
verses.text: But what is the meaning of, "not to be wise above what is written?" It is written, (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:16
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:17
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:18
verses.text: ) "Why beholdest thou the mote that is in thy brothers's eye, but considerest not the beam that is in thine own eye?" and "Judge not, that ye be not judged".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:19
verses.text: For if we are one and are mutually bound together, it behooveth us not to rise up against one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:20
verses.text: For "he that humbleth himself shall be exalted," saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:21
verses.text: And (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:22
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:23
verses.text: xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:24
verses.text: , ; St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:25
verses.text: Mark x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:26
verses.text: ; not verbatim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:27
verses.text: ) "He that will be first of all, let him be the servant of all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:28
verses.text: These are the things which "are written".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:29
verses.text: "That no one of you be puffed up for one against another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:30
verses.text: Again, having dismissed the teachers, he rebukes the disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:31
verses.text: For it was they who caused the former to be elated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:32
verses.text: And besides, the leaders would not quietly receive that kind of speech because of their desire of outward glory: for they were even blinded with that passion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:33
verses.text: Whereas the disciples, as not reaping themselves the fruits of the glory, but procuring it for others, would both endure the chiding with more temper, and had it more in their power than the leading men to destroy the disease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:34
verses.text: It seems then, that this also is a symptom of being "puffed up," to be elated on another's account, even though a man have no such feeling in regard of what is his own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:35
verses.text: For as he who is proud of another's wealth, is so out of arrogance; so also in the case of another's glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:36
verses.text: And he hath well called it "being puffed up".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:37
verses.text: For when one particular member rises up over the rest, it is nothing else but inflammation and disease; since in no other way doth one member become higher than another, except when a swelling takes place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:38
verses.text: (So in English "proud flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:39
verses.text: ) And so in the body of the Church also; whoever is inflamed and puffed up, he must be the diseased one; for he is swollen above the proportion of the rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:40
verses.text: For this disproportion is what we mean by "swelling".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:41
verses.text: And so comes it to pass in the body, when some spurious and evil humor gathers, instead of the wonted nourishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:42
verses.text: So also arrogance is born; notions to which we have no right coming over us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:43
verses.text: And mark with what literal propriety he saith, be not "puffed up:" for that which is puffed up hath a certain tumor of spirit, from being filled with corrupt humor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:44
verses.text: These things, however, he saith, not to preclude all soothing, but such soothing as leads to harm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:45
verses.text: "Wouldest thou wait upon this or that person? I forbid thee not: but do it not to the injury of another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:46
verses.text: For not that we might array ourselves one against another were teachers given us, but that we might all be mutually united.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:47
verses.text: For so the general to this end is set over the host, that of those who are separate he may make one body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:48
verses.text: But if he is to break up the army, he stands in the place of an enemy rather than of a general.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:49
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:50
verses.text: "For who maketh thee to differ? For what hast thou which thou didst not receive?"  From this point, dismissing the governed, he turns to the governors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:51
verses.text: What he saith comes to this: From whence is evident that thou art worthy of being praised? Why, hath any judgment taken place? any inquiry proceeded? any essay? any severe testing? Nay, thou canst not say it: and if men give their votes, their judgment is not upright.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:52
verses.text: But let us suppose that thou really art worthy of praise and hast indeed the gracious gift, and that the judgment of men is not corrupt: yet not even in this case were it right to be high-minded; for thou hast nothing of thyself but from God didst receive it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:53
verses.text: Why then dost thou pretend to have that which thou hast not? Thou wilt say, "thou hast it:" and others have it with thee: well then, thou hast it upon receiving it: not merely this thing or that, but all things whatsoever thou hast.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:54
verses.text: For not to thee belong these excellencies, but to the grace of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:55
verses.text: Whether you name faith, it came of His calling; or whether it be the forgiveness of sins which you speak of, or spiritual gifts, or the word of teaching, or the miracles; thou didst receive all from thence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:56
verses.text: Now what hast thou, tell me, which thou hast not received, but hast rather achieved of thine own self? Thou hast nothing to say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:57
verses.text: Well: thou hast received; and does that make thee high-minded? Nay, it ought to make thee shrink back into thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:58
verses.text: For it is not thine, what hath been given, but the giver's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:59
verses.text: What if thou didst receive it? thou receivedst it of him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:60
verses.text: And if thou receivedst of him, it was not thine which thou receivedst: and if thou didst but receive what was not thine own, why art thou exalted as if thou hadst something of thine own? Wherefore he added also, "Now if thou didst receive it, why dost thou glory, as if thou hadst not received it?   Thus having, you see, made good his argument by concession, (κατὰ συνδρομὴν.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:61
verses.text: ) he indicates that they have their deficiencies; and those not a few: and saith, "In the first place, though ye had received all things, it were not meet to glory, for nothing is your own; but as the case really stands there are many things of which ye are destitute".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:62
verses.text: And in the beginning he did but hint at this, saying, "I could not speak unto you as unto spiritual:" and, "I determined to know nothing among you, save Jesus Christ and Him crucified".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:63
verses.text: But here he doth it in a way to abash them, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:64
verses.text: "Already ye are filled, already ye are rich:" that is, ye want nothing henceforth; ye are become perfect; ye have attained the very summit; ye stand, as ye think, in need of no one, either among Apostles or teachers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:65
verses.text: "Already ye are filled".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:66
verses.text: And well saith he "already;" pointing out, from the time, the incredibility of their statements and their unreasonable notion of themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:67
verses.text: It was therefore in mockery that he said to them, "So quickly have ye come to the end;" which thing was impossible in the time: for all the more perfect things wait long in futurity: but to be "full" with a little betokens a feeble soul; and from a little to imagine one's self "rich," a sick and miserable one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:68
verses.text: For piety is an insatiable thing; and it argues a childish mind to imagine from just the beginnings that you have obtained the whole: and for men who are not yet even in the prelude of a matter, to be high-minded as if they had laid hold of the end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:69
verses.text: Then also by means of what followeth he puts them yet more out of countenance; for having said, "Already ye are full," he added, "ye are become rich, ye have reigned without us: yea and I would to God ye did reign, that we also might reign with you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:70
verses.text: Full of great austerity is the speech: which is why it comes last, being introduced by him after that abundance of reproof.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:71
verses.text: For then is our admonition respected and easily received, when after our accusations we introduce our humiliating expressions, (τὰ ἐυτρεπτικὰ ῤήματα.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:72
verses.text: ) For this were enough to repress even the shameless soul and strike it more sharply than direct accusation, and correct the bitterness and hardened feeling likely to arise from the charge brought.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:73
verses.text: It being certain that this more than anything else is the admirable quality of those arguments which appeal to our sense of shame, that they possess two contrary advantages.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:74
verses.text: On the one hand, one cuts deeper than by open invective: on the other hand, it causes the person reprimanded to bear that severer stab with more entire patience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:75
verses.text: "Ye have reigned without us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:76
verses.text: Herein there is great force, as concerns both the teachers and the disciples: and their ignorance, too, of themselves (τὸ ἀσυνείδητον.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:77
verses.text: ) is pointed out, and their great inconsideration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:78
verses.text: For what he saith is this: "In labors indeed," saith he, "all things are common both to us and to you, but in the rewards and the crowns ye are first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:79
verses.text: Not that I say this in vexation:" wherefore he added also, "I would indeed that ye did reign:" then, lest there should seem to be some irony, he added, "that we also might reign with you;" for, saith he, we also should be in possession (ἐπιτύχοιμεν, ms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:80
verses.text: Reg.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:81
verses.text: , ἐπιτύχωμεν Edd.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:82
verses.text: ) of these blessings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:83
verses.text: Dost thou see how he shews in himself all at once his severity and his care over them and his self-denying mind? Dost thou see how he takes down their pride?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:84
verses.text: "For I think that God hath set forth us the Apostles last of all, as men doomed to death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:85
verses.text: There is great depth of meaning and severity implied again in his saying, "us:" and not even with this was he satisfied, but added also his dignity, hitting them vehemently: "us the Apostles;" who are enduring such innumerable ills; who are sowing the word of Godliness; who are leading you unto this severe rule of life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:86
verses.text: These "He hath set forth last, as doomed to death," that is, as condemned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:87
verses.text: For since he had said, "That we also might reign with you," and by that expression had relaxed his vehemency in order not to dispirit them; he takes it up again with greater gravity, and saith, "For I think that God hath set forth us the Apostles last, as men doomed to death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:88
verses.text: "For according to what I see," saith he, "and from what ye say, the most abject of all men and emphatically the condemned, are we who are put forward for continual suffering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:89
verses.text: But ye have already a kingdom and honors and great rewards in your fancy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:90
verses.text: And wishing to carry out their reasoning to still greater absurdity, and to exhibit it as incredible in the highest degree, he said not merely, "We are 'last,'" but, "God made us last;" nor was he satisfied with saying, "last," but he added also, "doomed to death:" to the end that even one quite void of understanding might feel the statement to be quite incredible, and his words to be the words of one vexed and vehemently abashing them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:91
verses.text: Observe too the good sense of Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:92
verses.text: The topics by which, when it is the proper time, he exalts and shews himself honorable and makes himself great; by these he now puts them to shame, calling himself "condemned".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:93
verses.text: Of so great consequence is it to do all things at the befitting season.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:94
verses.text: By "doomed to death," in this place he means "condemned," and deserving of ten thousand deaths.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:95
verses.text: "For we are made a spectacle unto the world, and to angels, and to men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:96
verses.text: What means, "We are become a spectacle unto the world?" "Not in a single corner nor yet in a small part of the world suffer we these things," saith he; "but every where and before all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:97
verses.text: But what means, "unto angels?" It is possible to "become a spectacle unto men," but not so unto angels, when the things done are ordinary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:98
verses.text: But our wrestlings are such as to be worthy even of angelic contemplation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:99
verses.text: Behold from the things by which he vilifies himself, how again he shows himself great; and from the things about which they are proud, how he displays their meanness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:100
verses.text: For since to be fools was accounted a meaner thing than to appear wise; to be weak, than to be made strong; and unhonored, than glorious and distinguished; and that he is about to cast on them the one set of epithets, while he himself accepted the other; he signifies that the latter are better than the former; if at least because of them he turned the throng I say not of men only, but also of the very angels unto the contemplation of themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:101
verses.text: For not with men only is our wrestling but also with incorporeal powers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:102
verses.text: Therefore also a mighty theatre is set (μέγα θέατρον κάθηται.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:103
verses.text: )  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:104
verses.text: "We are fools for Christ's sake, but ye are wise in Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:105
verses.text: Again, this also he spake in a way to abash them; implying that it is impossible for these contraries to agree, neither can things so distant from one another concur.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:106
verses.text: "For how can it be," saith he, "that you should be wise, but we fools in the things relating to Christ?" That is: the one sort beaten and despised and dishonored and esteemed as nothing; the others enjoying honor and looked up to by many as a wise and prudent kind of people; it gives him occasion to speak thus: as if he had said, "How can it be that they who preach such things should be looked upon as practically engaged in their contraries?"  "We are weak, but ye are strong".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:107
verses.text: That is, we are driven about and persecuted; but ye enjoy security and are much waited upon; howbeit the nature of the Gospel endureth it not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:108
verses.text: "We are despised, but ye are honorable".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:109
verses.text: Here he setteth himself against the noble and those who plumed themselves upon external advantages.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:110
verses.text: "Even unto this present hour we both hunger, and thirst, and are naked, and are buffeted, and have no certain dwelling place; and we toil, working with our own hands".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:111
verses.text: That is, "It is not an old story that I am telling but just what the very time present bears me witness of: that of human things we take no account nor yet of any outward pomp; but we look unto God only".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:112
verses.text: Which thing we too have need to practice in every place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:113
verses.text: For not only are angels looking on, but even more than they He that presides over the spectacle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:114
verses.text: Let us not then desire any others to applaud us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:115
verses.text: For this is to insult Him; hastening by Him, as if insufficient to admire us, we make the best of our way to our fellow servants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:116
verses.text: For just as they who contend in a small theatre seek a large one, as if this were insufficient for their display; so also do they, who contending in the sight of God afterwards seek the applause of men; giving up the greater praise and eager for the less, they draw upon themselves severe punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:117
verses.text: What but this hath turned every thing upside down? this puts the whole world into confusion, that we do all things with an eye to men, and even for our good things, we esteem it nothing to have God as an admirer, but seek the approbation which cometh from our fellow-servants: and for the contrary things again, despising Him we fear men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:118
verses.text: And yet surely they shall stand with us before that tribunal, doing us no good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:119
verses.text: But God whom we despise now shall Himself pass the sentence upon us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:120
verses.text: But yet, though we know these things, we still gape after men, which is the first of sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:121
verses.text: Thus were a man looking on no one would choose to commit fornication; but even though he be ten thousand times on fire with that plague, the tyranny of the passion is conquered by his reverence for men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:122
verses.text: But in God's sight men not only commit adultery and fornication; but other things also much more dreadful many have dared and still dare to do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:123
verses.text: This then alone, is it not enough to bring down from above ten thousand thunderbolts? Adulteries, did I say, and fornications? Nay, things even far less than these we fear to do before men: but in God's sight we fear no longer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:124
verses.text: From hence, in fact, all the world's evils have originated; because in things really bad we reverence not God but men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:125
verses.text: On this account, you see, both things which are truly good, not accounted such by the generality, become objects of our aversion, we not investigating the nature of the things, but having respect unto the opinion of the many: and again, in the case of evil things, acting on this same principle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:126
verses.text: Certain things therefore not really good, but seeming fair unto the many, we pursue, as goods, through the same habit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:127
verses.text: So that on either side we go to destruction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:128
verses.text: Perhaps many may find this remark somewhat obscure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:129
verses.text: Wherefore we must express it more clearly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:130
verses.text: When we commit uncleanness, (for we must begin from the instances alleged,) we fear men more than God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:131
verses.text: When therefore we have thus subjected ourselves unto them and made them lords over us; there are many other things also which seem unto these our lords to be evil, not being such; these also we flee for our part in like manner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:132
verses.text: For instance; To live in poverty, many account disgraceful: and we flee poverty, not because it is disgraceful nor because we are so persuaded, but because our masters count it disgraceful; and we fear them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:133
verses.text: Again, to be unhonored and contemptible, and void of all authority seems likewise unto the most part a matter of great shame and vileness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:134
verses.text: This again we flee; not condemning the thing itself, but because of the sentence of our masters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:135
verses.text: Again on the contrary side also we undergo the same mischief.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:136
verses.text: As wealth is counted a good thing, and pride, and pomp, and to be conspicuous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:137
verses.text: Accordingly this again we pursue, not either in this case from considering the nature of the things as good, but persuaded by the opinion of our masters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:138
verses.text: For the people is our master and the great mob (ὅ πολὺς όχλος); a savage master and a severe tyrant: not so much as a command being needed in order to make us listen to him; it is enough that we just know what he wills, and without a command we submit: so great good will do we bear towards him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:139
verses.text: Again, God threatening and admonishing day by day is not heard; but the common people, full of disorder, made up of all manner of dregs, has no occasion for one word of command; enough for it only to signify with what it is well pleased, and in all things we obey immediately.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:140
verses.text: "But how," says some one, "is a man to flee from these masters?" By getting a mind greater than their's; by looking into the nature of things; by condemning the voice of the multitude; before all, by training himself in things really disgraceful to fear not men, but the unsleeping Eye; and again, in all good things, to seek the crowns which come from Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:141
verses.text: For thus neither in other sort of things shall we be able to tolerate them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:142
verses.text: For whoso when he doeth right judges them unworthy to know his good deeds, and contents himself with the suffrage of God; neither will he take account of them in matters of the contrary sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:143
verses.text: "And how can this be?" you will say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:144
verses.text: Consider what man is, what God; whom thou desertest, and unto whom thou fliest for refuge; and thou wilt soon be right altogether.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:145
verses.text: Man lieth under the same sin as thyself, and the same condemnation, and the same punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:146
verses.text: "Man is like to vanity," (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:147
verses.text: cxliv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:148
verses.text: LXX,) and hath not correct judgment, and needs the correction from above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:149
verses.text: "Man is dust and ashes," and if he bestow praise, he will often bestow it at random, or out of favor, or ill will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:150
verses.text: And if he calumniate and accuse, this again will he do out of the same kind of purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:151
verses.text: But God doeth not so: rather irreprovable in His sentence, and pure His judgment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:152
verses.text: Wherefore we must always flee to Him for refuge; and not for these reasons alone, but because He both made, and more than all spares thee, and loves thee better than thou dost thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:153
verses.text: Why then, neglecting to have so admirable (θαυμαστόν) an approver, betake we ourselves unto man, who is nothing, all rashness, all at random? Doth he call thee wicked and polluted when thou art not so? So much the more do thou pity him, and weep because he is corrupt; and despise his opinion, because the eyes of his understanding are darkened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:154
verses.text: For even the Apostles were thus evil reported of; and they laughed to scorn their calumniators.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:155
verses.text: But doth he call thee good and kind? If such indeed thou art, yet be not at all puffed up by the opinion: but if thou art not such, despise it the more, and esteem the thing to be mockery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:156
verses.text: Wouldest thou know the judgments of the greater part of men, how corrupt they are, how useless, and worthy of ridicule; some of them coming only from raving and distracted persons, others from children at the breast? Hear what hath been from the beginning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:157
verses.text: I will tell thee of judgments, not of the people only, but also of those who passed for the wisest, of those who were legislators from the earliest period.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:158
verses.text: For who would be counted wiser among the multitude than the person considered worthy of legislating for cities and peoples? But yet to these wise men fornication seems to be nothing evil nor worthy of punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:159
verses.text: At least, no one of the heathen laws makes its penal or brings men to trial on account of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:160
verses.text: And should any one bring another into court for things of that kind, the multitude laughs it to scorn, and the judge will not suffer it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:161
verses.text: Dice-playing, again, is exempt from all their punishments: nor did any one among them ever incur penalty for it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:162
verses.text: Drunkenness and gluttony, so far from being a crime, are considered by many even as a fine thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:163
verses.text: And in military carousals it is a point of great emulation; and they who most of all need a sober mind and a strong body, these are most of all given over to the tyranny of drunkenness; both utterly weakening the body and darkening the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:164
verses.text: Yet of the lawgivers not one hath punished this fault.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:165
verses.text: What can be worse than this madness?  Is then the good word of men so disposed an object of desire to thee, and dost thou not hide thyself in the earth? For even though all such admired thee, oughtest thou not to feel ashamed and cover thy face, at being applauded by men of such corrupt judgment?  Again, blasphemy by legislators in general is accounted nothing terrible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:166
verses.text: At any rate, no one for having blasphemed God was ever brought to trial and punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:167
verses.text: But if a man steal another's garment, or cut his purse, his sides are flayed, and he is often given over unto death: while he that blasphemeth God hath nothing laid to his charge by the heathen legislators.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:168
verses.text: And if a man seduce a female servant when he hath a wife, it seems nothing to the heathen laws nor to men in general.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:169
verses.text: Wilt thou hear besides of some things of another class which shew their folly? For as they punish not these things, so there are others which they enforce by law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:170
verses.text: What then are these? They collect crowds to fill theatres, and there they introduce choirs of harlots and prostituted children, yea such as trample on nature herself; and they make the whole people sit on high, and so they captivate their city; so they crown these mighty kings whom they are perpetually admiring for their trophies and victories.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:171
verses.text: And yet, what can be more insipid than this honor? what more undelightful than this delight? From among these then seekest thou judges to applaud thy deeds? And is it in company with dancers, and effeminate, and buffoons, and harlots, that thou art fain to enjoy the sound of compliment? answer me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:172
verses.text: How can these things be other than proofs of extreme infatuation? For I should like to ask them, is it or is it not, a dreadful thing to subvert the laws of nature, and introduce unlawful intercourse? They will surely say, it is dreadful: at any rate, they make a show of inflicting a penalty on that crime.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:173
verses.text: Why then dost thou bring on the stage those abused wretches; and not only bring them in, but honor them also with honors innumerable, and gifts not to be told? In other places thou punishest those who dare such things; but here even as on common benefactors of the city, thou spendest money upon them and supportest them at the public expense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:174
verses.text: "However," thou wilt say, "they are (ἄτιμοι) infamous".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:175
verses.text: Why then train them up? (παιδοτριβεῖς) Why choose the infamous to pay honor to kings withal? And why ruin our (ἐκτραχηλίζεις, Plutarch, περὶ παίδων ἀγωγῆς, c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:176
verses.text: ) cities? Or why spend so much upon these persons? Since if they be infamous expulsion is properest for the infamous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:177
verses.text: For why didst thou render them infamous? in praise or in condemnation? Of course in condemnation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:178
verses.text: Is the next thing to be, that although as after condemnation you make them infamous, yet as if they were honorable you run to see them, and admire and praise and applaud? Why need I speak of the sort of charm which is found in the horse races? or in the contests of the wild beasts? For those places too being full of all senseless excitement train the populace to acquire a merciless and savage and inhuman kind of temper, and practise them in seeing men torn in pieces, and blood flowing, and the ferocity of wild beasts confounding all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:179
verses.text: Now all these our wise lawgivers from the beginning introduced, being so many plagues! and our cities applaud and admire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:180
verses.text: But, if thou wilt, dismissing these things which clearly and confessedly are abominable, but seemed (οὐκ ἐδοξεν.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:181
verses.text: perhaps "were not decreed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:182
verses.text: ) not so to the heathen legislators, let us proceed to their grave precepts; and thou shalt see these too corrupted through the opinion of the multitude.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:183
verses.text: Thus marriage is accounted an honorable thing (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:184
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:185
verses.text: ) both by us and by those without: and it is honorable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:186
verses.text: But when marriages are solemnized, such ridiculous things take place as ye shall hear of immediately: because the most part, possessed and beguiled by custom, are not even aware of their absurdity, but need others to teach them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:187
verses.text: For dancing, and cymbals, and flutes, and shameful words, and songs, and drunkenness, and revellings, and all the Devil's great heap (πολὺς ὁ τοῦ διαβόλου φορυτός) of garbage is then introduced.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:188
verses.text: I know indeed that I shall appear ridiculous in finding fault with these things; and shall incur the charge of great folly with the generality, as disturbing the ancient laws: for, as I said before, great is the deceptive power of custom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:189
verses.text: But nevertheless, I will not cease repeating these things: for there is, there is surely a chance, that although not all, yet some few will receive our saying and will choose to be laughed to scorn with us, rather than we laugh with them such a laughter as deserves tears and overflowing punishment and vengeance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:190
verses.text: For how can it be other than worthy of the utmost condemnation that a damsel who hath spent her life entirely at home and been schooled in modesty from earliest childhood, should be compelled on a sudden to cast off all shame, and from the very commencement of her marriage be instructed in imprudence; and find herself put forward in the midst of wanton and rude men, and unchaste, and effeminate? What evil will not be implanted in the bride from that day forth? Immodesty, petulance, insolence, the love of vain glory: since they will naturally go on and desire to have all their days such as these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:191
verses.text: Hence our women become expensive and profuse; hence are they void of modesty, hence proceed their unnumbered evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:192
verses.text: And tell me not of the custom: for if it be an evil thing, let it not be done even once: but if good, let it be done constantly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:193
verses.text: For tell me, is not committing fornication evil? Shall we then allow just once this to be done? By no means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:194
verses.text: Why? Because though it be done only once, it is evil all the same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:195
verses.text: So also that the bride be entertained in this way, if it be evil, let it not be done even once; but if it be not evil, let it even be done always.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:196
verses.text: "What then," saith one, "dost thou find fault with marriage? tell me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:197
verses.text: That be far from me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:198
verses.text: I am not so senseless: but the things which are so unworthily appended to marriage, the painting the face, the coloring the eyebrows, and all the other niceness of that kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:199
verses.text: For indeed from that day she will receive many lovers even before her destined consort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:200
verses.text: "But many will admire the woman for her beauty".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:201
verses.text: And what of that? Even if discreet, she will hardly avoid evil suspicion; but if careless, she will be quickly overtaken, having got that very day a starting point in dissolute behavior.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:202
verses.text: Yet though the evils are so great, the omission of these proceedings is called an insult, by certain who are no better than brute beasts, and they are indignant that the woman is not exhibited to a multitude, that she is not set forth as a stage spectacle, common to all beholders: whereas most assuredly they should rather count it insult when these things do take place; and a laughing stock, and a farce.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:203
verses.text: For even now I know that men will condemn me of much folly and make me a laughing stock: but the derision I can bear when any gain accrues from it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:204
verses.text: For I should indeed be worthy of derision, if while I was exhorting to contempt of the opinion of the many, I myself, of all men, were subdued by that feeling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:205
verses.text: Behold then what follows from all this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:206
verses.text: Not in the day only but also in the evening, they provide on purpose men that have well drunk, besotted, and inflamed with luxurious fare, to look upon the beauty of the damsel's countenance; nor yet in the house only but even through the market-place do they lead her in pomp to make an exhibition; conducting her with torches late in the evening so as that she may be seen of all: by their doings recommending nothing else than that henceforth she put off all modesty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:207
verses.text: And they do not even stop here; but with shameful words do they conduct her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:208
verses.text: And this with the multitude is a law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:209
verses.text: And runaway slaves and convicts, thousands of them and of desperate character, go on with impunity uttering whatever they please, both against her and against him who is going to take her to his home.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:210
verses.text: Nor is there any thing solemn, but all base and full of indecency.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:211
verses.text: Will it not be a fine lesson in chastity for the bride to see and hear such things? Savile reads this sentence with a question.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:212
verses.text: And there is a sort of diabolical rivalry among these profligates to outdo one another in their zealous use of reproaches and foul words, whereby they put the whole company out of countenance, and those go away victorious who have found the largest store of railings and the greatest indecencies to throw at their neighbors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:213
verses.text: Now I know that I am a troublesome, sort of person and disagreeable, and morose, as though I were curtailing life of some of its pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:214
verses.text: Why, this is the very cause of my mourning that things so displeasing are esteemed a sort of pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:215
