verses.text: For how, I ask, can it be other than displeasing to be insulted and reviled? to be reproached by all, together with your bride? If any one in the market place speak ill of thy wife, thou makest ado without end and countest life not worth living: and can it be that disgracing thyself with thy future consort in the presence of the whole city, thou art pleased and lookest gay on the matter? Why, what strange madness is this!  "But," saith one, "the thing is customary".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:216
verses.text: Nay, for this very reason we ought most to bewail it, because the devil hath hedged in the thing with custom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:217
verses.text: In fact, since marriage is a solemn thing and that which recruits our race and the cause of numerous blessings; that evil one, inwardly pining and knowing that it was ordained as a barrier against uncleanness, by a new device introduces into it all kinds of uncleanness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:218
verses.text: At any rate, in such assemblages many virgins have been even corrupted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:219
verses.text: And if not so in every case, it is because for the time the devil is content with those words and those songs, so flagitious; with making a show of the bride openly, and leading the bridegroom in triumph through the market-place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:220
verses.text: Moreover, because all this takes place in the evening, that not even the darkness may be a veil to these evils, many torches are brought in, suffering not the disgraceful scene to be concealed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:221
verses.text: For what means the vast throng, and what the wassail, and what the pipes? Most clearly to prevent even those who are in their houses and plunged βαπτιζόμενοι in deep sleep from remaining ignorant of these proceedings; that being wakened by the pipe and leaning to look out of the lattices, they may be witnesses of the comedy such as it is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:222
verses.text: What can one say of the songs themselves, crammed as they are with all uncleanness, introducing monstrous amours, and unlawful connections, and subversions of houses, and tragic scenes without end; and making continual mention of the titles of "friend and lover," "mistress and beloved?" And, what is still more grievous, that young women are present at these things, having divested themselves of all modesty; in honor of the bride, rather I should say to insult her, exposing even their own salvation, and in the midst of wanton young men acting a shameless part with their disorderly songs, with their foul words, with their devilish harmony.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:223
verses.text: Tell me then: dost thou still enquire, "Whence come adulteries? Whence fornications? Whence violations of marriage?"   "But they are not noble nor decent women," you will say, "who do these things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:224
verses.text: Why then laugh me to scorn for this remonstrance, having been thyself aware of this law, before I said any thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:225
verses.text: I say, if the proceedings are right, allow those well-born women also to enact them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:226
verses.text: For what if these others live in poverty? Are not they also virgins? ought not they also to be careful of chastity? But now here is a virgin dancing in a public theatre of licentious youths; and, I ask, seems she not unto thee more dishonored than a harlot?  But if you say, "Female servants do these things;" neither so do I acquit thee of my charge: for neither to these ought such things to have been permitted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:227
verses.text: For hence all these evils have their origin, that of our household we make no account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:228
verses.text: But it is enough in the way of contempt to say, "He is a slave," and, "They are handmaids".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:229
verses.text: And yet, day after day we hear, (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:230
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:231
verses.text: ) "In Christ Jesus there is neither bond nor free".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:232
verses.text: Again, were it a horse or an ass, thou dost not overlook it but takest all pains not to have it of an inferior kind; and thy slaves who have souls like thine own dost thou neglect? And why do I say slaves, when I might say sons and daughters? What then must follow? It cannot be but grief (λύπην, qu.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:233
verses.text: λύμην, "mischief".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:234
verses.text: ) must immediately enter in, when all these are going to ruin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:235
verses.text: And often also very great losses must ensue, valuable golden ornaments being lost in the crowd and the confusion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:236
verses.text: Then after the marriage if perchance a child is born, in this case again we shall see the same folly and many practices σύμβολα full of absurdity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:237
verses.text: For when the time is come for giving the infant a name, caring not to call it after the saints as the ancients at first did, they light lamps and give them names, and name the child after that one which continues burning the longest; from thence conjecturing that he will live a long time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:238
verses.text: After all, should there be many instances of the child's untimely death, (and there are many,) great laughter on the devil's part will ensue, at his having made sport of them as if they were silly children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:239
verses.text: What shall we say about the amulets and the bells which are hung upon the hand, and the scarlet woof, and the other things full of such extreme folly; when they ought to invest the child with nothing else save the protection of the Cross.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:240
verses.text: But now that is despised which hath converted the whole world and given the sore wound to the devil and overthrown all his power: while the thread, and the woof, and the other amulets of that kind are entrusted with the child's safety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:241
verses.text: May I mention another thing yet more ridiculous than this? Only let no one tax us with speaking out of season, should our argument proceed with that instance also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:242
verses.text: For he that would cleanse an ulcer will not hesitate first to pollute his own hands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:243
verses.text: What then is this so very ridiculous custom? It is counted indeed as nothing; (and this is why I grieve;) but it is the beginning of folly and madness in the extreme.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:244
verses.text: The women in the bath, nurses and waiting-maids, take up mud and smearing it with the finger make a mark on the child's forehead; and if one ask, What means the mud, and the clay? the answer is, "It turneth away an evil eye, witchcraft and envy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:245
verses.text: Astonishing! what power in the mud! what might in the clay! what mighty force is this which it has? It averts all the host of the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:246
verses.text: Tell me, can ye help hiding yourselves for shame? Will ye never come to understand the snares of the devil, how from earliest life he gradually brings in the several evils which he hath devised? For if the mud hath this effect, why dost thou not thyself also do the same to thine own forehead, when thou art a man and thy character is formed; and thou art likelier than the child to have such as envy thee? Why dost thou not as well bemire the whole body? I say, if on the forehead its virtue be so great, why not anoint thyself all over with mud? All this is mirth and stage-play to Satan, not mockery only but hell-fire being the consummation to which these deceived ones are tending.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:247
verses.text: Now that among Greeks such things should be done is no wonder: but among the worshippers of the Cross, (τὸν σταυρὸν προσκυνοῦσι) and partakers in unspeakable mysteries, and professors of such high morality, (τοσαῦτα φιλοσοφοῦσιν) that such unseemliness should prevail, this is especially to be deplored again and again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:248
verses.text: God hath honored thee with spiritual anointing; and dost thou defile thy child with mud? God hath honored thee, and dost thou dishonor thyself? And when thou shouldest inscribe on his forehead the Cross which affords invincible security; dost thou forego this, and cast thyself into the madness of Satan?  If any look on these things as trifles, let them know that they are the source of great evils; and that not even unto Paul did it seem right to overlook the lesser things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:249
verses.text: For, tell me, what can be less than a man's covering his head? Yet observe how great a matter he makes of this and with how great earnestness he forbids it; saying, among many things, "He dishonoreth his head".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:250
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:251
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:252
verses.text: ) Now if he that covers himself "dishonoreth his head"; he that besmears his child with mud, how can it be less than making it abominable? For how, I want to know, can he bring it to the hands of the priest? How canst thou require that on that forehead the seal should be placed by the hand of the presbyter, where thou hast been smearing the mud? Nay, my brethren, do not these things, but from earliest life encompass them with spiritual armor and instruct them to seal the forehead with the hand (τῇ χειρὶ παιδεύτε σφραγίζειν τὸ μέτωπον): and before they are able to do this with their own hand, do you imprint upon them the Cross.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:253
verses.text: Why should one speak of the other satanical observances in the case of travail-pangs and childbirths, which the midwives introduce with a mischief on their own heads? Of the outcries which take place at each person's death, and when he is carried to his burial; the irrational wailings, the folly enacted at the funerals; the zeal about men's monuments; the importunate and ridiculous swarm of the mourning women; the observances of days; the days, I mean, of entrance into the world and of departure?   Are these then, I beseech you, the persons whose good opinion thou followest after? And what can it be but the extreme of folly to seek earnestly the praise of men, so corrupt in their ideas, men whose conduct is all at random? when we ought always to resort to the unsleeping Eye, and look to His sentence in all that we do and speak? For these, even if they approve, will have no power to profit us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 11:254
verses.text: But He, should He accept our doings, will both here make us glorious, and in the future day will impart to us of the unspeakable good things: which may it be the lot of us all to obtain, through the grace and loving-kindness of our Lord Jesus Christ; with Whom to the Father and the Holy Spirit be glory, power, honor, now and always, and unto everlasting ages, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:1
verses.text: Homily XIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:3
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:4
verses.text: "We are fools for Christ's sake:" (For it is necessary from this point to resume our discourse:) "but ye are wise in Christ: we are weak, but ye are strong: ye have glory, but we have dishonor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:5
verses.text: Having filled his speech with much severity which conveys a sharper blow than any direct charge and having said, "Ye have reigned without us;" and "God hath set forth us last, as men doomed to death" he shows by what comes next how they are "doomed to death;" saying, We are fools, and weak, and despised, and hunger, and thirst, and are naked, and are buffeted, and have no certain dwelling place, and toil, working with our own hands:" which were very signs of genuine teachers and apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:6
verses.text: Whereas the others prided themselves on the things which are contrary to these, on wisdom, glory, wealth, consideration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:7
verses.text: Desiring therefore to take down their self-conceit and to point out that in respect of these things, so far from taking credit to themselves, they ought rather to be ashamed; he first of all mocks them, saying, "Ye have reigned without us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:8
verses.text: As if he had said, "My sentence is that the present is not a time of honor nor of glory, which kind of things you enjoy, but of persecution and insult, such as we are suffering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:9
verses.text: If however it be not so; if this rather be the time of remuneration: then as far as I see," (but this he saith in irony,) "ye, the disciples, for your part have become no less than kings: but we the teachers and apostles, and before all entitled to receive the reward, not only have fallen very far behind you, but even, as persons doomed to death, that is, condemned convicts, spend our lives entirely in dishonors, and dangers, and hunger: yea insulted as fools, and driven about, and enduring all intolerable things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:10
verses.text: Now these things he said that he might hereby cause them also to consider, that they should zealously seek the condition of the Apostles; their dangers and their indignities, not their honors and glories.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:11
verses.text: For these, not the other, are what the Gospel requires.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:12
verses.text: But to this effect he speaks not directly, not to shew himself disagreeable to them: rather in a way characteristic of himself he takes in hand this rebuke.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:13
verses.text: For if he had introduced his address in a direct manner, he would have spoken thus; "Ye err, and are beguiled, and have swerved far from the apostolical mode of instruction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:14
verses.text: For every apostle and minister of Christ ought to be esteemed a fool, ought to live in affliction and dishonor; which indeed is our state: whereas you are in the contrary case".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:15
verses.text: But thus might his expressions have offended them yet more, as containing but praises of the Apostles; and might have made them fiercer, censured as they were for indolence and vainglory and luxuriousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:16
verses.text: Wherefore he conducts not his statement in this way, but in another, more striking but less offensive; and this is why he proceeds with his address as follows, saying ironically, "But ye are strong and honorable;" since, if he had not used irony, he would have spoken to this effect; "It is not possible that one man should be esteemed foolish, and another wise; one strong, and another weak; the Gospel requiring both the one and the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:17
verses.text: For if it were in the nature of things that one should be this, and another that, perchance there might be some reason in what you say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:18
verses.text: But now it is not permitted, either to be counted wise, or honorable, or to be free from dangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:19
verses.text: If otherwise, it follows of necessity that you are preferred before us in the sight of God; you the disciples before us the teachers, and that after our endless hardships".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:20
verses.text: If this be too bad for anyone to say, it remains for you to make our condition your object.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:21
verses.text: And "let no one," saith he, "think that I speak only of the past:"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:22
verses.text: "Even unto this present hour we both hunger and thirst and are naked".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:23
verses.text: Seest thou that all the life of Christians must be such as this; and not merely a day or two? For though the wrestler who is victorious in a single contest only, be crowned, he is not crowned again if he suffer a fall.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:24
verses.text: "And hunger;" against the luxurious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:25
verses.text: "And are buffeted;" against those who are puffed up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:26
verses.text: "And have no certain dwelling-place;" for we are driven about.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:27
verses.text: "And are naked;" against the rich.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:28
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:29
verses.text: "And labor;" now against the false apostles who endure neither toil nor peril, while they themselves receive the fruits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:30
verses.text: "But not so are we," saith he: "but together with our perils from without, we also strain ourselves to the utmost with perpetual labor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:31
verses.text: And what is still more, no one can say that we fret at these things, for the contrary is our requital to them that so deal with us: this, I say, is the main point, not our suffering evil, for that is common to all, but our suffering without despondency or vexation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:32
verses.text: But we so far from desponding are full of exultation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:33
verses.text: And a sure proof of this is our requiting with the contrary those who do us wrong".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:34
verses.text: Now as to the fact that so they did, hear what follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:35
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:37
verses.text: "Being reviled, we bless; being persecuted, we endure; being defamed, we entreat; we are made as the filth of the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:38
verses.text: This is the meaning of "fools for Christ's sake".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:39
verses.text: For whoso suffers wrong and avenges not himself nor is vexed, is reckoned a fool by the heathen; and dishonored and weak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:40
verses.text: And in order that he might not render his speech too unpalatable by referring the sufferings he was speaking of to their city, what saith he? "We are made the filth," not, "of your city," but, "of the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:41
verses.text: And again, "the off-scouring of all men;" not of you alone, but of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:42
verses.text: As then when he is discoursing of the providential care of Christ, letting pass the earth, the heaven, the whole creation, the Cross is what he brings forward; so also when he desires to attract them to himself hurrying by all his miracles, he speaks of his sufferings on their account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:43
verses.text: So also it is our method when we be injured by any and despised, whatsoever we have endured for them, to bring the same forward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:44
verses.text: "The offscouring of all men, even until now".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:45
verses.text: This is a vigorous blow which he gave at the end, "of all men;" "not of the persecutors only," saith he, "but of those also for whom we suffer these things: Oh greatly am I obliged to them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:46
verses.text: It is the expression of one seriously concerned; not in pain himself, but desiring to make them feel, (πλῆξαι) that he who hath innumerable complaints to make should even salute them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:47
verses.text: And therefore did Christ command us to bear insults meekly that we might both exercise ourselves in a high strain of virtue, and put the other party to the more shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:48
verses.text: For that effect one produces not so well by reproach as by silence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:49
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:50
verses.text: Then since he saw that the blow could not well be borne, he speedily heals it; saying, "I write not these things to shame you, but to admonish you as my beloved children".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:51
verses.text: "For not as abashing you," saith he, "do I speak these things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:52
verses.text: The very thing which by his words he had done, this he says he had not done: rather he allows that he had done it, not however with an evil and spiteful mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:53
verses.text: Why, this mode of soothing is the very best, if we should say what we have to say and add the apology from our motive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:54
verses.text: For not to speak was impossible, since they would have remained uncorrected: on the other hand, after he had spoken, to leave the wound untended, were hard.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:55
verses.text: Wherefore along with his severity he apologizes: for this so far from destroying the effect of the knife, rather makes it sink deeper in, while it moderates the full pain of the wound.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:56
verses.text: Since when a man is told that not in reproach but in love are these things said, he the more readily receives correction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:57
verses.text: However, even here also is great severity, and a strong appeal to their sense of shame, (ἐντροπή) in that he said not, "As a master" nor yet "as an apostle," nor yet "as having you for my disciples;" (which had well suited his claims on them;) but, "as my beloved children I admonish you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:58
verses.text: And not simply, children; but, "longed after".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:59
verses.text: "Forgive me," saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:60
verses.text: "If anything disagreeable has been said, it all proceeds of love".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:61
verses.text: And he said not, "I rebuke," but "I admonish".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:62
verses.text: Now, who would not bear with a father in grief, and in the act of giving good advice? Wherefore he did not say this before, but after he had given the blow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:63
verses.text: "What then?" some might say; "Do not other teachers spare us?" "I say not so, but, they carry not their forbearance so far".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:64
verses.text: This however he spake not out at once, but by their professions and titles gave indication of it; "Tutor" and "Father" being the terms which he employs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:65
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:66
verses.text: "For though," saith he, "ye have ten thousand tutors in Christ, yet have ye not many fathers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:67
verses.text: He is not here setting forth his dignity, but the exceeding greatness of his love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:68
verses.text: Thus neither did he wound the other teachers: since he adds the clause, "in Christ:" but rather soothed them, designating not as parasites but as tutors those among them who were zealous and patient of labor: and also manifested his own anxious care of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:69
verses.text: On this account he said not, "Yet not many masters," but, "not many fathers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:70
verses.text: So little was it his object to set down any name of dignity, or to argue that of him they had received the greater benefit: but granting to the others the great pains they had taken for the Corinthians, (for that is the force of the word Tutor,) the superiority in love he reserves for his own portion: for that again is the force of the word Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:71
verses.text: And he saith not merely, No one loves you so much; a statement which admitted not of being called in question; but he also brings forward a real fact.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:72
verses.text: What then is this? "For in Christ Jesus I begat you through the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:73
verses.text: In Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:74
verses.text: Not unto myself do I impute this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:75
verses.text: Again, he strikes at those who gave their own names to their teaching.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:76
verses.text: For "ye," saith he, "are the seal of mine Apostleship".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:77
verses.text: And again, "I planted:" and in this place, "I begat".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:78
verses.text: He said not, "I preached the word," but, "I begat;" using the words of natural relationship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:79
verses.text: (τοῖς τῆς φύσεως ὀνόμασι) For his one care at the moment was, to shew forth the love which he had for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:80
verses.text: "For they indeed received you from me, and led you on; but that you are believers at all came to pass through me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:81
verses.text: Thus, because he had said, "as children;" lest you should suppose that the expression was flattery he produces also the matter of fact.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:82
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:83
verses.text: "I beseech you, be ye imitators of me, as I also am of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:84
verses.text: (κάθως κὰγὼ Χριστοῦ, omitted in our version: the Vulgate has it, see c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:85
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:86
verses.text: ) Astonishing! How great is our teacher's boldness of speech! How highly finished the image, when he can even exhort others hereunto! Not that in self-exaltation he doth so, but implying that virtue is an easy thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:87
verses.text: As if he had said, "Tell me not, 'I am not able to imitate thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:88
verses.text: Thou art a Teacher, and a great one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:89
verses.text: ' For the difference between me and you is not so great as between Christ and me: and yet I have imitated Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:90
verses.text: On the other hand, writing to the Ephesians, he interposes no mention of himself, but leads them all straight to the one point, "Be ye imitators of God," is his word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:91
verses.text: (Ephes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:92
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:93
verses.text: ) But in this place, since his discourse was addressed to weak persons, he puts himself in by the way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:94
verses.text: And besides, too, he signifies that it is possible even thus to imitate Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:95
verses.text: For he who copies the perfect impression of the seal, copies the original model.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:96
verses.text: Let us see then in what way he followed Christ: for this imitation needs not time and art, but a steady purpose alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:97
verses.text: Thus if we go into the study of a painter, we shall not be able to copy the portrait, though we see it ten thousand times.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:98
verses.text: But to copy him we are enabled by hearing alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:99
verses.text: Will ye then that we bring the tablet before you and sketch out for you Paul's manner of life? Well, let it be produced, that picture far brighter than all the images of Emperors: for its material is not boards glued together, nor canvass stretched out; but the material is the work of God: being as it is a soul and a body: a soul, the work of God, not of men; and a body again in like wise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:100
verses.text: Did you utter applause here? Nay, not here is the time for plaudits; but in what follows: for applauding, I say, and for imitating too: for so far we have but the material which is common to all without exception: inasmuch as soul differs not from soul in regard of its being a soul: but the purpose of heart shews the difference.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:101
verses.text: For as one body differs not from another in so far as it is a body, but Paul's body is like every one's else, only dangers make one body more brilliant than another: just so is it in the case of the soul also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:102
verses.text: Suppose then our tablet to be the soul of Paul: this tablet was lately lying covered with soot, full of spider's webs; (for nothing can be worse than blasphemy;) but when He came who transformeth all things, and saw that not through indolence or sluggishness were his lines so drawn but through inexperience and his not having the tints (τὰ ἄνθη) of true piety: (for zeal indeed he had, but the colors were not there; for he had not "the zeal according to knowledge:") He gives him the tint of the truth, that is, grace: and in a moment he exhibited the imperial image.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:103
verses.text: For having got the colors and learnt what he was ignorant of, he waited no time, but forthwith appeared a most excellent artist.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:104
verses.text: And first he shews the head of the king, preaching Christ; then also the remainder of the body; the body of a perfect Christian life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:105
verses.text: Now painters we know shut themselves up and execute all their works with great nicety and in quiet; not opening the doors to any one: but this man, setting forth his tablet in the view of the world, in the midst of universal opposition, clamor, disturbance, did under such circumstances work out this Royal Image, and was not hindered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:106
verses.text: And therefore he said, "We are made a spectacle unto the world;" in the midst of earth, and sea, and the heaven, and the whole habitable globe, and the world both material and intellectual, he was drawing that portrait of his.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:107
verses.text: Would you like to see the other parts also thereof from the head downwards? Or will ye that from below we carry our description upwards? Contemplate then a statue of gold or rather of something more costly than gold, and such as might stand in heaven; not fixed with lead nor placed in one spot, but hurrying from Jerusalem even unto Illyricum, (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:108
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:109
verses.text: ) and setting forth into Spain, and borne as it were on wings over every part of the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:110
verses.text: For what could be more "beautiful" than these "feet" which visited the whole earth under the sun? This same "beauty" the prophet also from of old proclaimeth, saying, (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:111
verses.text: lii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:112
verses.text: ) "How beautiful are the feet of them that preach the Gospel of peace!" Hast thou seen how fair are the feet? Wilt thou see the bosom too? Come, let me shew thee this also, and thou shalt behold it far more splendid than these beautiful, yea even than the bosom itself of the ancient lawgiver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:113
verses.text: For Moses indeed carried tablets of stone: but this man within him had Christ Himself: it was the very image of the King which he bore.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:114
verses.text: For this cause he was more awful than the Mercy Seat and the Cherubim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:115
verses.text: For no such voice went out from them as from hence; but from them it talked with men chiefly about things of sense, from the tongue of Paul on the other hand about the things above the heavens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:116
verses.text: Again, from the Mercy Seat it spake oracles to the Jews alone; but from hence to the whole world: and there it was by things without life; but here by a soul instinct with virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:117
verses.text: This Mercy Seat was brighter even than heaven, not shining forth with variety of stars nor with rays from the sun, but the very Sun of righteousness was there, and from hence He sent forth His rays.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:118
verses.text: Again, from time to time in this our heaven, any cloud coursing over at times makes it gloomy; but that bosom never had any such storm sweeping across it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:119
verses.text: Or rather there did sweep over it many storms and oft: but the light they darkened not; rather in the midst of the temptation and dangers the light shone out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:120
verses.text: Wherefore also he himself when bound with his chain kept exclaiming, ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:121
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:122
verses.text: ) "The word of God is not bound".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:123
verses.text: Thus continually by means of that tongue was It sending forth its rays.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:124
verses.text: And no fear, no danger made that bosom gloomy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:125
verses.text: Perhaps the bosom seems to outdo the feet; however, both they as feet are beautiful, and this as a bosom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:126
verses.text: Wilt thou see also the belly with its proper beauty? Hear what he saith about it, (ch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:127
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:128
verses.text: ) "If meat make my brother to stumble, I will eat no flesh while the world standeth: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:129
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:130
verses.text: ) It is good neither to eat flesh nor to drink wine, nor anything whereby thy brother stumbleth, or is offended, or is made weak: (ch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:131
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:132
verses.text: ) Meats for the belly and the belly for meats".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:133
verses.text: What can be more beautiful in its kind than this belly thus instructed to be quiet, and taught all temperance, and knowing how both to hunger and be famished, and also to suffer thirst? For as a well-trained horse with a golden bridle, so also did this walk with measured paces, having vanquished the necessity of nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:134
verses.text: For it was Christ walking in it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:135
verses.text: Now this being so temperate, it is quite plain that the whole body of vice besides was done away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:136
verses.text: Wouldst thou see the hands too? those which he now hath? Or wouldest thou rather behold first their former wickedness? (Acts viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:137
verses.text: ) "Entering (this very man) into the houses, he haled," of late, "men and women," with the hands not of man, but of some fierce wild beast.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:138
verses.text: But as soon as he had received the colors of the Truth and the spiritual experience, no longer were these the hands of a man, but spiritual; day by day being bound with chains.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:139
verses.text: And they never struck any one, but they were stricken times without number.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:140
verses.text: Once even a viper (Acts xxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:142
verses.text: ) reverenced those hands: for they were the hands of a human being no longer; and therefore it did not even fasten on them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:143
verses.text: And wilt thou see also the back, resembling as it does the other members? Hear what he saith about this also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:144
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:145
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:147
verses.text: ) "Five times I received of the Jews forty stripes save one; thrice was I beaten with rods, once was I stoned, thrice I suffered shipwreck, a night and a day I have been in the deep".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:148
verses.text: But lest we too should fall into an interminable deep, and be carried away far and wide, going over each of his members severally; come let us quit the body and look at another sort of beauty, that, namely, which proceeds from his garments; to which even devils shewed reverence; and therefore both they made off, and diseases took flight.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:149
verses.text: And wheresoever Paul happened to shew himself, they all retired and got out of the way, as if the champion of the whole world had appeared.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:150
verses.text: And as they who have been often wounded in war, should they see but some part of the armor of him that wounded them feel a shuddering; much in the same way the devils also, at sight of "handkerchiefs" only were astonied.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:151
verses.text: Where be now the rich, and they that have high thoughts about wealth? Where they who count over their own titles and their costly robes? With these things if they compare themselves, it will be clay in their sight and dirt, all they have of their own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:152
verses.text: And why speak I of garments and golden ornaments? Why, if one would grant me the whole world in possession, the mere nail of Paul I should esteem more powerful than all that dominion: his poverty than all luxury: his dishonor, than all glory: his nakedness than all riches: no security would I compare with the buffeting of that sacred head: no diadem, with the stones to which he was a mark.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:153
verses.text: This crown let us long for, beloved: and if persecution be not now, let us mean while prepare ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:154
verses.text: For neither was he of whom we speak glorious by persecutions alone: for he said also, ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:155
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:156
verses.text: ὑποπιέζω rec.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:157
verses.text: text, ὑπωπίαζω) "I keep under my body;" now in this one may attain excellence without persecutions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:158
verses.text: And he exhorted not to (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:159
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:160
verses.text: ) "make provision for the flesh to fulfill the lusts thereof".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:161
verses.text: And again, ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:162
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:163
verses.text: ) "Having food and covering, let us be therewith content".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:164
verses.text: For to these purposes we have no need of persecutions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:165
verses.text: And the wealthy too he sought to moderate, saying, (Ibid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:166
verses.text: ) "They that desire to be rich fall into temptation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:167
verses.text: If therefore we also thus exercise ourselves, when we enter into the contest we shall be crowned: and though there be no persecution before us, we shall receive for these things many rewards.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:168
verses.text: But if we pamper the body and live the life of a swine, even in peace we shall often sin and bear shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:169
verses.text: Seest thou not with whom we wrestle? With the incorporeal powers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:170
verses.text: How then, being ourselves flesh, are we to get the better of these? For if wrestling with men one have need to be temperate in diet, much more with evil spirits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:171
verses.text: But when together with fulness of flesh we are also bound down to wealth, whence are we to overcome our antagonists? For wealth is a chain, a grievous chain, to those who know not how to use it; a tyrant savage and inhuman, imposing all his commands by way of outrage on those who serve him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:172
verses.text: Howbeit, if we will, this bitter tyranny we shall depose from its throne, and make it yield to us, instead of commanding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:173
verses.text: How then shall this be? By distributing our wealth unto all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:174
verses.text: For so long as it stands against us, each single handed, like any robber in a wilderness it works all its bad ends: but when we bring it forth among others, it will master us no more, holden as it will be in chains, on all sides, by all men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:175
verses.text: And these things I say, not because riches are a sin: the sin is in not distributing them to the poor, and in the wrong use of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:176
verses.text: For God made nothing evil but all things very good; so that riches too are good; i-e: if they do not master their owners; if the wants of our neighbors be done away by them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:177
verses.text: For neither is that light good which instead of dissipating darkness rather makes it intense: nor should I call that wealth, which instead of doing away poverty rather increases it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:178
verses.text: For the rich man seeks not to take from others but to help others: but he that seeks to receive from others is no longer rich, but is emphatically poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:179
verses.text: So that it is not riches that are an evil, but the needy mind which turns wealth into poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:180
verses.text: These are more wretched than those who ask alms in the narrow streets, carrying a wallet and mutilated in body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:181
verses.text: I say, clothed in rags as they are, not so miserable as those in silks and shining garments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:182
verses.text: Those who strut in the market-place are more to be pitied than those who haunt the crossings of the streets, and enter into the courts, and cry from their cellars, and ask charity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:183
verses.text: For these for their part do utter praises to God, and speak words of mercy and a strict morality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:184
verses.text: And therefore we pity them, and stretch out the hand, and never find fault with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:185
verses.text: But those who are rich to bad purpose; cruelty and inhumanity, ravening and satanical lust, are in the words they belch out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:186
verses.text: And therefore by all are they detested and laughed to scorn.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:187
verses.text: Do but consider; which of the two among all men is reckoned disgraceful, to beg of the rich or the poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:188
verses.text: Every one, I suppose, sees it at once:—of the poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:189
verses.text: Now this, if you mark it, is what the rich do; for they durst not apply to those who are richer than themselves: whereas those who beg do so of the wealthy: for one beggar asks not alms of another, but of a rich man; but the rich man tears the poor in pieces.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:190
verses.text: Again tell me, which is the more dignified, to receive from those who are willing and are obliged to you, or when men are unwilling, to compel and tease them? Clearly not to trouble those who are unwilling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:191
verses.text: But this also the rich do: for the poor receive from willing hands, and such as are obliged to them; but the rich from persons unwilling and repugnant, which is an indication of greater poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:192
verses.text: For if no one would like so much as to go to a meal, unless the inviter were to feel obliged to the guest, how can it be honorable to take one's share of any property by compulsion? Do we not on this account get out of the way of dogs and fly from their baying, because by their much besetting they fairly force us off? This also our rich men do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:193
verses.text: "But, that fear should accompany the gift, is more dignified".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:194
verses.text: Nay, this is of all most disgraceful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:195
verses.text: For he who moves heaven and earth about his gains, who can be so laughed to scorn as he? For even unto dogs, not seldom, through fear, we throw whatever we had hold of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:196
verses.text: Which I ask again, is more disgraceful? that one clothed with rags should beg, or one who wears silk? Thus when a rich man pays court to old and poor persons, so as to get possession of their property, and this when there are children, what pardon can he deserve?  Further: If you will, let us examine the very words; what the rich beggars say, and what the poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:197
verses.text: What then saith the poor man? "That he who giveth alms will never have to give by measure (μετριάσει perhaps corrupt: conj.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:198
verses.text: πεινάσει, "will never hunger); that he is giving of what is God's: that God is loving unto men, and recompenses more abundantly; all which are words of high morality, and exhortation, and counsel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:199
verses.text: For he recommends thee to look unto the Lord, and he takes away thy fear of the poverty to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:200
verses.text: And one may perceive much instruction in the words of those who ask alms: but of what kind are those of the rich? Why, of swine, and dogs, and wolves, and all other wild beasts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:201
verses.text: For some of them discourse perpetually on banquets, and dishes, and delicacies, and wine of all sorts, and ointments, and vestures, and all the rest of that extravagance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:202
verses.text: And others about the interest of money and loans.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:203
verses.text: And making out accounts and increasing the mass of debts to an intolerable amount, as if it had begun in the time of men's fathers or grandfathers, one they rob of his house, another of his field, and another of his slave, and of all that he has.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:204
verses.text: Why should one speak of their wills, which are written in blood instead of ink? For either by surrounding them with some intolerable danger, or else bewitching them with some paltry promises, whomsoever they may see in possession of some small property, those they persuade to pass by all their relations, and that oftentimes when perishing through poverty, and instead of them to enter their own names.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:205
verses.text: Is there any madness and ferocity of wild beasts of any sort which these things do not throw into the shade?   Wherefore I beseech you, all such wealth as this let us flee, disgraceful as it is and in deaths abundant; and let us obtain that which is spiritual, and let us seek after the treasures in the heavens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:206
verses.text: For whoso possess these, they are the rich, they are the wealthy, both here and there enjoying things; even all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:207
verses.text: Since whoso will be poor, according to the word of God, has all men's houses opened to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:208
verses.text: For unto him that for God's sake has ceased to possess any thing, every one will contribute of his own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:209
verses.text: But whoso will hold a little with injustice, shutteth the doors of all against him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 12:210
verses.text: To the end, then, that we may attain both to the good things here and to those which are there, let us choose the wealth which cannot be removed, that immortal abundance: which may God grant us all to obtain, through the grace and loving-kindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:1
verses.text: Homily XIV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:3
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:4
verses.text: For this cause have I sent unto you Timothy, who is my beloved and faithful child in the Lord, who shall put you in remembrance of my ways which be in Christ Jesus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:5
verses.text: Consider here also, I entreat, the noble soul, the soul more glowing and keener than fire: how he was indeed especially desirous to be present himself with the Corinthians, thus distempered and broken into parties.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:6
verses.text: For he knew well what a help to the disciples his presence was and what a mischief his absence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:7
verses.text: And the former he declared in the Epistle to the Philippians, saying, (Phil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:8
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:9
verses.text: καὶ om.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:10
verses.text: in rec.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:11
verses.text: text.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:12
verses.text: ) "Not as in my presence only, but also now much more in my absence, work out your own salvation with fear and trembling".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:13
verses.text: The latter he signifies in this Epistle, saying, (ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:14
verses.text: ) "Now some are puffed up, as though I were not coming to you; but I will come".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:15
verses.text: He was urgent, it seems, and desirous to be present himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:16
verses.text: But as this was not possible for a time, he corrects them by the promise of his appearance; and not this only, but also by the sending of his disciple.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:17
verses.text: "For this," he saith, "I have sent unto you Timothy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:18
verses.text: "For this cause:" how is that? "Because I care for you as for children, and as having begotten you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:19
verses.text: And the message is accompanied with a recommendation of his person: "Who is my beloved and faithful child in the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:20
verses.text: Now this he said, both to shew his love of him, and to prepare them to look on him with respect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:21
verses.text: And not simply "faithful," but, "in the Lord;" that is, in the things pertaining to the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:22
verses.text: Now if in worldly things it is high praise for a man to be faithful, much more in things spiritual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:23
verses.text: If then he was his "beloved child," consider how great was Paul's love, in choosing to be separated from him for the Corinthian's sake, And if "faithful" also, he will be unexceptionable in his ministering to their affairs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:24
verses.text: "Who shall put you in remembrance".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:25
verses.text: He said not, "shall teach," lest they should take it ill, as being used to learn from himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:26
verses.text: Wherefore also towards the end he saith, ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:27
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:29
verses.text: ) "For he worketh the work of the Lord, as I also do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:30
verses.text: Let no man therefore despise him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:31
verses.text: For there was no envy among the Apostles, but they had an eye unto one thing, the edification of the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:32
verses.text: And if he that was employed was their inferior, they did as it were support (συνεκρότουν) him with all earnestness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:33
verses.text: Wherefore neither was he contented with saying, "He shall put you in remembrance;" but purposing to cut out their envy more completely,—for Timothy was young,—with this view, I say, he adds, "my ways;" not "his," but "mine;" that is, his methods, (τὰς οἰκονομίας.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:34
verses.text: ) his dangers, his customs, his laws, his ordinances, his Apostolical Canons, and all the rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:35
verses.text: For since he had said, "We are naked, and are buffered, and have no certain dwelling place: all these things," saith he, "he will remind you of;" and also of the laws of Christ; for destroying all heresies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:36
verses.text: Then, carrying his argument higher, he adds, "which be in Christ;" ascribing all, as was his wont, unto the Lord, and on that ground establishing the credibility of what is to follow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:37
verses.text: Wherefore he subjoins, "Even as I teach every where in every church".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:38
verses.text: "Nothing new have I spoken unto you: of these my proceedings all the other Churches are cognizant as well as you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:39
verses.text: Further: he calls them "ways in Christ," to shew that they have in them nothing human, and that with the aid from that source he doth all things well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:40
verses.text: And having said these things and so soothed them, and being just about to enter on his charge against the unclean person, he again utters words full of anger; not that in himself he felt so but in order to correct them: and giving over the fornicator, he directs his discourse to the rest, as not deeming him worthy even of words from himself; just as we act in regard to our servants when they have given us great offence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:41
verses.text: Next, after that he had said, "I send Timothy, lest they should thereupon take things too easily, mark what he saith:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:42
verses.text: "Now some are puffed up, as though I were not coming unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:43
verses.text: For there he glances both at them and at certain others, casting down their highmindedness: since the love of preeminence is in fault, when men abuse the absence of their teacher for their own self-will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:44
verses.text: For when he addresses himself unto the people, observe how he does it by way of appeal to their sense of shame; when unto the originators of the mischief, his manner is more vehement.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:45
verses.text: Thus unto the former he saith, "We are the offscouring of all:" and soothing them he saith, "Not to shame you I write these things;" but to the latter, "Now as though I were not coming to you, some are puffed up;" shewing that their self-will argued a childish turn of mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:46
verses.text: For so boys in the absence of their master wax more negligent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:47
verses.text: This then is one thing here indicated; and another is that his presence was sufficient for their correction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:48
verses.text: For as the presence of a lion makes all living creatures shrink away, so also does that of Paul the corrupters of the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:49
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:50
verses.text: And therefore he goes on, "But I will come to you shortly, if the Lord will".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:51
verses.text: Now to say this only would seem to be mere threatening.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:52
verses.text: But to promise himself and demand from them the requisite proof by actions also; this was a course for a truly high spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:53
verses.text: Accordingly he added this too, saying,  "And I will know, not the word of them which are puffed up, but the power".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:54
verses.text: For not from any excellencies of their own but from their teacher's absence, this self-will arose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:55
verses.text: Which again itself was a mark of a scornful mind towards him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:56
verses.text: And this is why, having said, "I have sent Timothy," he did not at once add, "I will come;" but waited until he had brought his charge against them of being "puffed up:" after that he saith, "I will come".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:57
verses.text: Since, had he put it before the charge, it would rather have been an apology for himself as not having been deficient, instead of a threat; nor even so (οὕτως so the King's ms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:58
verses.text: οὖτος the rec.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:59
verses.text: text.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:60
verses.text: ) would the statement have been convincing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:61
verses.text: But as it is, placing it after the accusation, he rendered himself such as they would both believe and fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:62
verses.text: Mark also how solid and secure he makes his ground: for he saith not simply, "I will come:" but, "If the Lord will:" and he appoints no set time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:63
verses.text: For since he might perhaps be tardy in coming, by that uncertainty he would fain keep them anxiously engaged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:64
verses.text: And, lest they should hereupon fall back again, he added, "shortly,"   "And I will know, not the word of them that are puffed up, but the power".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:65
verses.text: He said not, "I will know not the wisdom, nor the signs," but what? "not the word:" by the term he employs at the same time depressing the one and exalting the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:66
verses.text: And for a while he is setting himself against the generality of them who were countenancing the fornicator.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:67
verses.text: For if he were speaking of him, he would not say, "the power;" but, "the works," the corrupt works which he did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:68
verses.text: Now why seekest thou not after "the word?" "Not because I am wanting in word but because all our doings are 'in power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:69
verses.text: '" As therefore in war success is not for those who talk much but those who effect much; so also in this case, not speakers, but doers have the victory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:70
verses.text: "Thou," saith he, "art proud of this fine speaking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:71
verses.text: Well, if it were a contest and a time for orators, thou mightest reasonably be elated thereat: but if of Apostles preaching truth, and by signs confirming the same, why art thou puffed up for a thing superfluous and unreal, and to the present purpose utterly inefficient? For what could a display of words avail towards raising the dead, or expelling evil spirits, or working any other such deed of wonder? But these are what we want now, and by these our cause stands".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:72
verses.text: Whereupon also he adds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:73
verses.text: "For the kingdom of God is not in word, but in power".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:74
verses.text: By signs, saith he, not by fine speaking, we have prevailed: and that our teaching is divine and really announces the Kingdom of Heaven we give the greater proof, namely, our signs which we work by the power of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:75
verses.text: If those who are now puffed up desire to be some great ones; as soon as I am come, let them shew whether they have any such power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:76
verses.text: And let me not find them sheltering themselves behind a pomp of words: for that kind of art is nothing to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:77
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:78
verses.text: "What will ye? Shall I come unto you with a rod, or in love and a spirit of meekness?"  There is much both of terror and of gentleness in this saying.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:79
verses.text: For to say, "I will know," was the language of one as yet withholding himself: but to say, "What will ye? Must I come unto you with a rod?" are the words of one thenceforth ascending the teacher's seat, and from thence holding discourses with them and taking upon him all his authority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:80
verses.text: What means, "with a rod?" With punishment, with vengeance: that is, I will destroy; I will strike with blindness: the kind of thing which Peter did in the case of Sapphira, and himself in the case of Elymas the sorcerer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:81
verses.text: For henceforth he no longer speaks as bringing himself into a close comparison with the other teachers, but with authority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:82
verses.text: And in the second Epistle too he appears to say the same, when he writes, "Since ye seek a proof of Christ speaking in me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:83
verses.text: "Shall I come with a rod, or in love?" What then? to come with a rod, was it not an instance of love? Of love it was surely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:84
verses.text: But because through his great love he shrinks back in punishing, therefore he so expresses himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:85
verses.text: Further; when he spoke about punishment, he said not, "in a spirit of meekness," but, simply, "with a rod:" and yet of that too the Spirit was author.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:86
verses.text: For there is a spirit of meekness, and a spirit of severity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:87
verses.text: He doth not, however, choose so to call it, but from its milder aspect (ἀπὸ τῶν χρηστοτέρων.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:88
verses.text: ) And for a like reason also, God, although avenging Himself, has it often affirmed of Him that He is "gracious and long-suffering, and rich in mercy and pity:" but that He is apt to punish, once perhaps or twice, and sparingly, and that upon some urgent cause.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:89
verses.text: Consider then the wisdom of Paul; holding the authority in his own hands, he leaves both his and that in the power of others, saying, "What will ye?" "The matter is at your disposal".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:90
verses.text: For we too have depending on us both sides of the alternative; both falling into hell, and obtaining the kingdom: since God hath so willed it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:91
verses.text: For, "behold," saith he, "fire and water: whichever way thou wilt, thou mayest stretch forth thine hand" (Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:92
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:93
verses.text: ) And, "If ye be willing, and will hearken unto me, ye shall eat the good of the land; (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:94
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:95
verses.text: ,) but if ye be not willing, the sword shall devour you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:96
verses.text: But perhaps one will say, "I am willing; (and no one is so void of understanding as not to be willing;) but to will is not sufficient for me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:97
verses.text: Nay, but it is sufficient, if thou be duly willing, and do the deeds of one that is willing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:98
verses.text: But as it is, thou art not greatly willing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:99
verses.text: And let us try this in other things, if it seem good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:100
verses.text: For tell me, he that would marry a wife, is he content with wishing? By no means; but he looks out for women to advance his suit, and request friends to keep watch with him, and gets together money.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:101
verses.text: Again, the merchant is not content with sitting at home and wishing, but he first hires a vessel, then selects sailors and rowers, then takes up money on interest, and is inquisitive about a market and the price of merchandise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:102
verses.text: Is it not then strange for men to shew themselves so much in earnest about earthly things, but that when they are to make a venture for heaven, they should be content with wishing only? rather I should say, not even in this do they shew themselves properly in earnest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:103
verses.text: For he that wills a thing as he ought, puts also his hand unto the means which lead to the object of his desire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:104
verses.text: Thus, when hunger compels thee to take nourishment, thou waitest not for the viands to come unto thee of their own accord, but omittest nothing to gather victuals together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:105
verses.text: So in thirst, and cold and all other such things, thou art industrious and duly prepared to take care of the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:106
verses.text: Now do this in respect of God's kingdom also, and surely thou shalt obtain it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:107
verses.text: For to this end God made thee a free agent, that thou mightest not afterwards accuse God, as though some necessity had bound thee: but thou, in regard of those very things wherein thou hast been honored, dost murmur.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:108
verses.text: For in fact I have often heard people say, "But why did He then make my goodness depend on me?" Nay, but how was He to bring thee, slumbering and sleeping, and in love with all iniquity, and living delicately, and pampering thyself; how was He to bring thee up to heaven? If He had, thou wouldest not have abstained from vice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:109
verses.text: For if now, even in the face of threatening, thou dost not turn aside from thy wickedness; had he added no less than heaven as the end of thy race, when wouldest thou have ceased waxing more careless and worse by far? (χείρων πολλῷ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:110
verses.text: πολλῶν Bened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:111
verses.text: )  Neither again wilt thou be able to allege, He hath shewed me indeed what things were good but gave no help, for abundant also is His promise to thee of aid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:112
verses.text: "But," say you, "Virtue is burdensome and distasteful; while with vice great pleasure is blended; and the one is wide and broad, but the other strait and narrow".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:113
verses.text: Tell me then, are they respectively such throughout, or only from the beginning? For in fact what thou here sayest, thou sayest, not intending it, in behalf of virtue; so potent a thing is truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:114
verses.text: For suppose there were two roads, the one leading to a furnace, and the other to a Paradise; and that the one unto the furnace were broad, the other unto Paradise, narrow; which road wouldest thou take in preference? For although you may now gainsay for contradiction's sake, yet things which are plainly allowed on all hands, however shameless, you will not be able to gainsay.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:115
verses.text: Now that that way is rather to be chosen which hath its beginning difficult but not its end, I will endeavor to teach you from what is quite obvious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:116
verses.text: And, if you please, let us first take in hand the arts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:117
verses.text: For these have their beginning full of toil, but the end gainful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:118
verses.text: "But," say you, "no one applies himself to an art without some one to compel him; for," you add, "so long as the boy is his own master, he will choose rather to take his ease at first, and in the end to endure the evil, how great soever, than to live hardly at the outset, and afterwards reap the fruit of those labors".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:119
verses.text: Well then, to make such a choice comes of a mind left to itself, (ὀρφανικῆς διανοίας) and of childish idleness: but the contrary choice, of sense and manliness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:120
verses.text: And so it is with us: were we not children in mind, we should not be like the child aforesaid, forsaken (ὀρφάνῳ) as he is and thoughtless, but like him that hath a father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:121
verses.text: We must cast out then our own childish mind, and not find fault with the things themselves; and we must set a charioteer over our conscience, who will not allow us to indulge our appetite, but make us run and strive mightily.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:122
verses.text: For what else but absurdity is it to inure our children with pains at first unto pursuits which have laborious beginnings, but their end good and pleasant; while we ourselves in spiritual things take just the contrary turn?  And yet even in those earthly things it is not quite plain that the end will be good and pleasant: since before now untimely death, or poverty, or false accusation, or reverse of fortune, or other such things, of which there are many, have caused men after their long toil to be deprived of all its fruits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:123
verses.text: What is more, those who have such pursuits, though they succeed, it is no great gain which they will reap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:124
verses.text: For with the present life all those things are dissolved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:125
verses.text: But here, not for such fruitless and perishable things is our race, neither have we fears about the end; but greater and more secure is our hope after our departure hence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:126
verses.text: What pardon then can there be, what excuse for those who will not strip themselves for the evils to be endured for virtue's sake?  And do they yet ask, "Wherefore is the way narrow?" Why, thou dost not deem it right that any fornicator or lewd or drunken (και τῶν μεθυόντων inserted from the King's ms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:127
verses.text: ) person should enter into the courts of earthly kings; and claimest thou for men to be let into heaven itself with licentiousness, and luxury, and drunkenness, and covetousness, and all manner of iniquity? And how can these things be pardonable?   "Nay," you reply, "I say not that, but why has not virtue a "broad way?" In good truth if we be willing, its way is very easy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:128
verses.text: For whether is easier, tell me; to dig through a wall and take other men's goods and so be cast into prison; or to be content with what you have and freed from all fear? I have not however said all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:129
