verses.text: For whether is easier, tell me; to steal all men's goods and revel in few of them for a short time, and then to be racked and scourged eternally; or having lived in righteous poverty for a short time, to live ever after in delights? (For let us not enquire as yet which is the more profitable, but for the present, which is the more easy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:130
verses.text: ) Whether again is it pleasanter, to see a good dream and to be punished in reality; or after having had a disagreeable dream to be really in enjoyment? Of course the latter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:131
verses.text: Tell me then, In what sense dost thou call virtue harsh? I grant, it is harsh, tried by comparison with our carelessness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:132
verses.text: However, that it is really easy and smooth, hear what Christ saith, (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:133
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:134
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:135
verses.text: ) "My yoke is easy, and My burden is light".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:136
verses.text: But if thou perceivest not the lightness, plainly it is for want of courageous zeal; since where that is, even heavy things are light; and by the same rule where it is not, even light things are heavy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:137
verses.text: For tell me, what could be sweeter and more easily obtained than the banquet of manna? Yet the Jews were discontented, though enjoying such delightful fare.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:138
verses.text: What more bitter than hunger and all the other hardships which Paul endured? Yet he leaped up, and rejoiced, and said, (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:139
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:140
verses.text: ) "Now I rejoice in my sufferings".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:141
verses.text: What then is the cause? The difference of the mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:142
verses.text: If then you frame this as it ought to be, you will see the easiness of virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:143
verses.text: "What then," say you, "does she only become such through the mind of those who pursue her?" She is such, not from their mind alone, but by nature as well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:144
verses.text: Which I thus prove: If the one had been throughout a thing painful, the other throughout of the contrary sort, then with some plausibility might some fallen persons have said that the latter was easier than the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:145
verses.text: But if they have their beginnings, the one in hardship, the other in pleasure, but their respective ends again just opposite to these; and if those ends be both infinite, in the one the pleasure, in the other the burthen; tell me, which is the more easy to choose?  "Why then do many not choose that which is easy?" Because some disbelieve; and others, who believe, have their judgment corrupt, and would prefer pleasure for a season to that which is everlasting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:146
verses.text: "Is not this then easy?" Not so: but this cometh of a sick soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:147
verses.text: And as the reason why persons in a fever long after cool drink is not upon calculation that the momentary luxury is pleasanter than being burned up from beginning to end, but because they cannot restrain their inordinate desire; so also these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:148
verses.text: Since if one brought them to their punishment at the very moment of their pleasure, assuredly they never would have chosen it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:149
verses.text: Thus you see in what sense vice is not an easy thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:150
verses.text: But if you will, let us try this same point over again by an example in the proper subject matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:151
verses.text: Tell me, for instance, which is pleasanter and easier? (only let us not take again the desire of the many for our rule in the matter; since one ought to decide, not by the sick, but by the whole; just as you might show me ten thousand men in a fever, seeking things unwholesome upon choice to suffer for it afterwards; but I should not allow such choice;) which, I repeat, brings more ease, tell me; to desire much wealth, or to be above that desire? For I, for my part, think the latter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:152
verses.text: If thou disbelieve it, let the argument be brought to the facts themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:153
verses.text: Let us then suppose one man desiring much, another nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:154
verses.text: Which now is the better state, tell me, and which the more respectable? However, let that pass.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:155
verses.text: For this is agreed upon, that the latter is a finer character than the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:156
verses.text: And we are making no enquiry about this at present, but which lives the easier and pleasanter life? Well then: the lover of money will not enjoy even what he has: for that which he loves he cannot choose to spend; but would gladly even carve (κατακόψειε) himself out, and part with his flesh rather than with his gold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:157
verses.text: But he that despises wealth, gains this the while, that he enjoys what he has quietly and with great security, and that he values himself more than it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:158
verses.text: Which then is the pleasanter; to enjoy what one has with freedom, or to live under a master, namely wealth, and not dare to touch a single thing even of one's own? Why, it seemeth to me to be much the same as if any two men, having wives and loving them exceedingly, were not upon the same terms with them; but the one were allowed the presence and intercourse of his wife, the other not even permitted to come near his.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:159
verses.text: There is another thing which I wish to mention, indicating the pleasure of the one and the discomfort of the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:160
verses.text: He that is greedy of gain will never be stayed in that desire, not only because it is impossible, for him to obtain all men's goods, but also because whatever he may have compassed, he counts himself to have nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:161
verses.text: But the despiser of riches will deem it all superfluous, and will not have to punish his soul with endless desires.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:162
verses.text: I say, punish; for nothing so completely answers the definition of punishment as desire deprived of gratification; a thing too which especially marks his perverse mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:163
verses.text: Look at it in this way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:164
verses.text: He that lusts after riches and hath increased his store, he is the sort of person to feel as if he had nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:165
verses.text: I ask then, what more complicated than this disease? And the strange thing is not this only, but that although having, he thinks he has not the very things which are in his hold, and as though he had them not he bewails himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:166
verses.text: If he even get all men's goods, his pain is but greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:167
verses.text: And should he gain an hundred talents, he is vexed that he hath not received a thousand: and if he received a thousand; he is stung to the quick that it is not ten thousand: and if he receive ten thousand, he utterly bemoans himself (κατακόπτεται) because it is not ten times as much.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:168
verses.text: And the acquisition of more to him becomes so much more poverty; for the more he receives so much the more he desires.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:169
verses.text: So then, the more he receives, the more he becomes poor: since whoso desires more, is more truly poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:170
verses.text: When then he hath an hundred talents, is he not very poor? for he desires a thousand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:171
verses.text: When he hath got a thousand, then he becomes yet poorer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:172
verses.text: For it is no longer a thousand as before, but ten thousand that he professes himself to want.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:173
verses.text: Now if you say that to wish and not to obtain is pleasure, you seem to me to be very ignorant of the nature of pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:174
verses.text: To shew that this sort of thing is not pleasure but punishment, take another case, and so let us search it out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:175
verses.text: When we are thirsty, do we not therefore feel pleasure in drinking because we quench our thirst; and is it not therefore a pleasure to drink because it relieves us from a great torment, the desire, I mean, of drinking? Every one, I suppose, can tell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:176
verses.text: But were we always to remain in such a state of desire, we should be as badly off as the rich man in the parable of Lazarus for the matter of punishment; for his punishment was just this that vehemently desiring one little drop, he obtained it not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:177
verses.text: And this very thing all covetous persons seem to me continually to suffer, and to resemble him where he begs that he may obtain that drop, and obtains it not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:178
verses.text: For their soul is more on fire than his.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:179
verses.text: Well indeed hath one said, that all lovers of money are in a sort of dropsy; for as they, bearing much water in their bodies, are the more burnt up: so also the covetous, bearing about with them great wealth, are greedy of more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:180
verses.text: The reason is that neither do the one keep the water in the parts of the body where it should be, nor the other their desire in the limits of becoming thought.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:181
verses.text: Let us then flee this strange and craving (ξένην καὶ κενὴν: a play on the sound of the words,) disease; let us flee the root of all evils; let us flee that which is present hell; for it is a hell, the desire of these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:182
verses.text: Only just lay open the soul of each, of him who despises wealth and of him who does not so; and you will see that the one is like the distracted, choosing neither to hear nor see any thing: the other, like a harbor free from waves: and he is the friend of all, as the other is the enemy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:183
verses.text: For whether one take any thing of his, it gives him no annoyance; or if whether, on the contrary, one give him aught, it puffs him not up; but there is a certain freedom about him with entire security.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:184
verses.text: The one is forced to flatter and feign before all; the other, to no man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:185
verses.text: If now to be fond of money is to be both poor and timid and a dissembler and a hypocrite and to be full of fears and great penal anguish and chastisement: while he that despises wealth has all the contrary enjoyments: is it not quite plain that virtue is the more pleasant?  Now we might have gone through all the other evils also whereby it is shewn that there is no vice which hath pleasure in it, had we not spoken before so much at large.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 13:186
verses.text: Wherefore knowing these things, let us choose virtue; to the end that we may both enjoy such pleasure as is here, and may attain unto the blessings which are to come, through the grace and loving-kindness, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:1
verses.text: Homily XV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:3
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:4
verses.text: ,  It is actually reported that there is fornication among you, and such fornication as is not even named among the Gentiles, that one of you hath his father's wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:5
verses.text: And ye are puffed up, and did not rather mourn, that he that had done this deed might be taken away from among you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:6
verses.text: When he was discoursing about their divisions, he did not indeed at once address them vehemently, but more gently at first; and afterwards, he ended in accusation, saying thus, (c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:7
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:8
verses.text: ) "For it hath been signified unto me concerning you, my brethren, by them which are of the household of Chloe, that there are contentions among you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:9
verses.text: But in this place, not so; but he lays about him immediately and makes the reproach of the accusation as general as possible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:10
verses.text: For he said not, "Why did such an one commit fornication?" but, "It is reported that there is fornication among you;" that they might as persons altogether aloof from his charge take it easily; but might be filled with such anxiety as was natural when the whole body was wounded, and the Church had incurred reproach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:11
verses.text: "For no one," saith he, "will state it thus, 'such an one hath committed fornication,' but, 'in the Church of Corinthians that sin hath been committed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:12
verses.text: '"  And he said not, "Fornication is perpetrated," but, "Is reported,—such as is not even named among the Gentiles".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:13
verses.text: For so continually he makes the Gentiles a topic of reproach to the believers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:14
verses.text: Thus writing to the Thessalonians, he said, ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:15
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:16
verses.text: , , καὶ τιμῆ om.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:17
verses.text: τὰ λοιπὰ inserted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:18
verses.text: ) "Let every one possess himself of his own vessel in sanctification, not in the passion of lust, even as the rest of the Gentiles".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:19
verses.text: And to the Colossians and Ephesians, (Ephes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:20
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:21
verses.text: cf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:22
verses.text: Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:23
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:25
verses.text: ) "That you should no longer walk, as the other Gentiles walk".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:26
verses.text: Now if their committing the same sins was unpardonable, when they even outdid the Gentiles, what place can we find for them? tell me: "inasmuch as among the Gentiles," so he speaks, "not only they dare no such thing, but they do not even give it a name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:27
verses.text: Do you see to what point he aggravated his charge? For when they are convicted of inventing such modes of uncleanness as the unbelievers, so far from venturing on them, do not even know of, the sin must be exceeding great, beyond all words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:28
verses.text: And the clause, "among you," is spoken also emphatically; that is, "Among you, the faithful, who have been favored with so high mysteries, the partakers of secrets, the guests invited to heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:29
verses.text: Dost thou mark with what indignant feeling his works overflow? with what anger against all? For had it not been for the great wrath of which he was full, had he not been setting himself against them all, he would have spoken thus: "Having heard that such and such a person hath committed fornication, I charge you to punish him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:30
verses.text: But as it is he doth not so; he rather challenges all at once.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:31
verses.text: And indeed, if they had written first, this is what he probably would have said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:32
verses.text: Since however so far from writing, they had even thrown the fault into the shade, on this account he orders his discourse more vehemently.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:33
verses.text: "That one of you should have his father's wife".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:34
verses.text: Wherefore said he not, "That he should abuse his father's wife?" The extreme foulness of the deed caused him to shrink.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:35
verses.text: He hurries by it accordingly, with a sort of scrupulousness as though it had been explicitly mentioned before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:36
verses.text: And hereby again he aggravates the charge, implying that such things are ventured on among them as even to speak plainly of was intolerable for Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:37
verses.text: Wherefore also, as he goes on, he uses the same mode of speech, saying, "Him who hath so done this thing:" and is again ashamed and blushes to speak out; which also we are wont to do in regard of matters extremely disgraceful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:38
verses.text: And he said not, "his step-mother," but, "his father's wife;" so as to strike much more severely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:39
verses.text: For when the mere terms are sufficient to convey the charge, he proceeds with them simply, adding nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:40
verses.text: And "tell me not," saith he, "that the fornicator is but one: the charge hath become common to all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:41
verses.text: Wherefore at once he added, "and ye are puffed up:" he said not, "with the sin;" for this would imply want of all reason: but with the doctrine you have heard from that person.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:42
verses.text: This however he set not down himself, but left it undetermined, that he might inflict a heavier blow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:43
verses.text: And mark the good sense of Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:44
verses.text: Having first overthrown the wisdom from without, and signified that it is nothing by itself although no sin were associated with it; then and not till then he discourses about the sin also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:45
verses.text: For if by way of comparison with the fornicator who perhaps was some wise one, he had maintained the greatness of his own spiritual gift; he had done no great thing: but even when unattended with sin to take down the heathen wisdom and demonstrate it to be nothing, this was indicating its extreme worthlessness indeed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:46
verses.text: Wherefore first, as I said, having made the comparison, he afterwards mentions the man's sin also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:47
verses.text: And with him indeed he condescends not to debate, and thereby signifies the exceeding greatness of his dishonor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:48
verses.text: But to the others he saith, "You ought to weep and wail, and cover your faces, but now ye do the contrary".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:49
verses.text: And this is the force of the next clause, "And ye are puffed up, and did not rather mourn".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:50
verses.text: "And why are we to weep?" some might say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:51
verses.text: Because the reproach hath made its way even unto the whole body of your Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:52
verses.text: "And what good are we to get by our weeping?" "That such an one should be taken away from you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:53
verses.text: Not even here doth he mention his name; rather, I should say, not any where; which in all monstrous things is our usual way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:54
verses.text: And he said not, "Ye have not rather cast him out," but, as in the case of any disease or pestilence, "there is need of mourning," saith he, "and of intense supplication, 'that he may be taken away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:55
verses.text: ' And you should have used prayer for this, and left nothing undone that he should be cut off".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:56
verses.text: Nor yet doth he accuse them for not having given him information, but for not having mourned so that the man should be taken away; implying that even without their Teacher this ought to have been done, because of the notoriety of the offence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:57
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:58
verses.text: "For I verily being absent in body, but present in spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:59
verses.text: Mark his energy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:60
verses.text: He suffers them not even to wait for his presence, nor to receive him first and then pass the sentence of binding: but as if on the point of expelling some contagion before that it have spread itself into the rest of the body, he hastens to restrain it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:61
verses.text: And therefore he subjoins the clause, "I have judged already, as though I were present".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:62
verses.text: These things moreover he said, not only to urge them unto the declaration of their sentence and to give them no opportunity of contriving something else, but also to frighten them, as one who knew what was to be done and determined there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:63
verses.text: For this is the meaning of being "present in spirit:" as Elisha was present with Gehazi, and said, "Went not my heart with thee? ( Kings v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:64
verses.text: ) Wonderful! How great is the power of the gift, in that it makes all to be together and as one; and qualifies them to know the things which are far off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:65
verses.text: "I have judged already as though I were present".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:66
verses.text: He permits them not to have any other device.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:67
verses.text: "Now I have uttered my decision as if I were present: let there be no delays and puttings off: for nothing else must be done".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:68
verses.text: Then lest he should be thought too authoritative and his speech sound rather self-willed, mark how he makes them also partners in the sentence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:69
verses.text: For having said, "I have judged," he adds, "concerning him that hath so wrought this thing, in the Name of our Lord Jesus Christ, ye being gathered together, and my spirit, with the power of our Lord Jesus Christ, to deliver such an one unto Satan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:70
verses.text: Now what means, "In the Name of our Lord Jesus Christ?" "According to God;" "not possessed with any human prejudice".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:71
verses.text: Some, however, read thus, "Him that hath so wrought this thing in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ," and putting a stop there or a break, then subjoin what follows, saying, "When you are gathered together and my spirit to deliver such an one unto Satan:" and they assert that the sense of this reading is as follows, "Him that hath done this thing in the Name of Christ," saith St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:72
verses.text: Paul, "deliver ye unto Satan;" that is, "him that hath done insult unto the Name of Christ, him that, after he had become a believer and was called after that appellation, hath dared to do such things, deliver ye unto Satan".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:73
verses.text: But to me the former exposition (ἐκδοσις.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:74
verses.text: It seems to mean "enunciation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:75
verses.text: ) appears the truer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:76
verses.text: What then is this? "When ye are gathered together in the Name of the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:77
verses.text: That is; His Name, in whose behalf ye have met, collecting you together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:78
verses.text: "And my spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:79
verses.text: Again he sets himself at their head in order that when they should pass sentence, they might no otherwise cut off the offender than as if he were present; and that no one might dare to judge him pardonable, knowing that Paul would be aware of the proceedings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:80
verses.text: Then making it yet more awful, he saith, "with the power of our Lord Jesus Christ;" that is, either that Christ is able to give you such grace as that you should have power to deliver him to the devil; or that He is Himself together with you passing that sentence against him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:81
verses.text: And he said not, "Give up" such an one to Satan, but "deliver;" opening unto him the doors of repentance, and delivering up such an one as it were to a schoolmaster.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:82
verses.text: And again it is, "such an one:" he no where can endure to make mention of his name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:83
verses.text: "For the destruction of the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:84
verses.text: As was done in the case of the blessed Job, but not upon the same ground.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:85
verses.text: For in that case it was for brighter crowns, but here for loosing of sins; that he might scourge him with a grievous sore or some other disease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:86
verses.text: True it is that elsewhere he saith, "Of the Lord are we judged, ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:87
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:88
verses.text: ) when we suffer these things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:89
verses.text: But here, desirous of making them feel it more severely, he "delivereth up unto Satan".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:90
verses.text: And so this too which God had determined ensued, that the man's flesh was chastised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:91
verses.text: For because inordinate eating and carnal luxuriousness are the parents of desires, it is the flesh which he chastises.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:92
verses.text: "That the spirit may be saved in the day of the Lord Jesus;" that is the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:93
verses.text: Not as though this were saved alone, but because it was a settled point that if that were saved, without all controversy the body too would partake in its salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:94
verses.text: For as it became mortal because of the soul's sinning: so if this do righteousness, that also on the other hand shall enjoy great glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:95
verses.text: But some maintain, that "the Spirit" is the Gracious Gift which is extinguished when we sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:96
verses.text: "In order then that this may not happen," saith he, "let him be punished; that thereby becoming better, he may draw down to himself God's grace, and be found having it safe in that day".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:97
verses.text: So that all comes as from one exercising a nurse's or a physician's office, not merely scourging nor punishing rashly and at random.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:98
verses.text: For the gain is greater than the punishment: one being but for a season, the other everlasting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:99
verses.text: And he said not simply, "That the spirit may be saved," but "in that day".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:100
verses.text: Well and seasonably doth he remind them of that day in order that both they might more readily apply themselves to the cure, and that the person censured might the rather receive his words, not as it were of anger, but as the forethought of an anxious father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:101
verses.text: For this cause also he said, "unto the destruction of the flesh:" proceeding to lay down regulations for the devil and not suffering him to go a step too far.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:102
verses.text: As in the instance of Job, God said, (Job ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:103
verses.text: ) "But touch not his life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:104
verses.text: Then, having ended his sentence, and spoken it in brief without dwelling on it, he brings in again a rebuke, directing himself against them;  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:105
verses.text: "Your glorying is not good:" signifying that it was they up to the present time who had hindered him from repenting, by taking pride in him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:106
verses.text: Next he shews that he is taking this step in order to spare not that person only, but also those to whom he writes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:107
verses.text: To which effect he adds,  "Know ye not, that a little leaven leaveneth the whole lump?" "For," saith he, "though the offence be his, yet if neglected it hath power to waste the rest of the body of the Church also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:108
verses.text: For when the first transgressor escapes punishment, speedily will others also commit the same faults".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:109
verses.text: In these words he indicates moreover that their struggle and their danger is for the whole Church, not for any one person.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:110
verses.text: For which purpose he needeth also the similitude of the leaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:111
verses.text: For "as that," saith he, "though it be but little, transforms unto its own nature the whole lump; so also this man, if he be let go unpunished and this sin turn out unavenged, will corrupt likewise all the rest".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:112
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:113
verses.text: "Purge out the old leaven," that is, this evil one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:114
verses.text: Not that he speaketh concerning this one only; rather he glances at others with him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:115
verses.text: For, "the old leaven" is not fornication only, but also sin of every kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:116
verses.text: And he said not, "purge," but "purge out;" "cleanse with accuracy so that there be not so much as a remnant nor a shadow of that sort".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:117
verses.text: In saying then, "purge out," he signifies that there was still iniquity among them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:118
verses.text: But in saying, "that ye may be a new lump, even as ye are unleavened," he affirms and declares that not over very many was the wickedness prevailing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:119
verses.text: But though he saith, "as ye are unleavened," he means it not as a fact that all were clean, but as to what sort of people you ought to be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:120
verses.text: "For our Passover also hath been sacrificed for us, even Christ; wherefore let us keep the feast: not with old leaven, nor with the leaven of malice and wickedness, but with the unleavened bread of sincerity and truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:121
verses.text: So also Christ called His doctrine Leaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:122
verses.text: And further he himself dwells upon the metaphor, reminding them of an ancient history, and of the Passover and unleavened bread, and of their blessings both then and now, and their punishments and their plagues.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:123
verses.text: It is festival, therefore, the whole time in which we live.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:124
verses.text: For though he said, "Let us keep the feast," not with a view to the presence of the Passover or of Pentecost did he say it; but as pointing out that the whole of time is a festival unto Christians, because of the excellency of the good things which have been given.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:125
verses.text: For what hath not come to pass that is good? The Son of God was made man for thee; He freed thee from death; and called thee to a kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:126
verses.text: Thou therefore who hast obtained and art still obtaining such things, how can it be less than thy duty to "keep the feast" all thy life? Let no one then be downcast about poverty, and disease, and craft of enemies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:127
verses.text: For it is a festival, even the whole of our time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:128
verses.text: Wherefore saith Paul, (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:129
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:130
verses.text: ) "Rejoice in the Lord always; again I say, Rejoice".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:131
verses.text: Upon the festival days no one puts on filthy garments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:132
verses.text: Neither then let us do so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:133
verses.text: For a marriage hath been made, a spiritual marriage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:134
verses.text: For, "the kingdom of Heaven," saith He, "is likened unto a certain king which would make (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:135
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:136
verses.text: xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:137
verses.text: ἠθέλησε ποιῆσαι, rec.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:138
verses.text: text ἐποίησε.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:139
verses.text: ) a marriage feast for his son".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:140
verses.text: Now where it is a king making a marriage, and a marriage for his son, what can be greater than this feast? Let no one then enter in clad in rags.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:141
verses.text: Not about garments is our discourse but about unclean actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:142
verses.text: For if where all wore bright apparel one alone, being found at the marriage in filthy garments, was cast out with dishonor, consider how great strictness and purity the entrance into that marriage feast requires.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:143
verses.text: However, not on this account only does he remind them of the "unleavened bread," but also to point out the affinity of the Old Testament with the New; and to point out also that it was impossible, after the "unleavened bread," again to enter into Egypt; but if any one chose to return, he would suffer the same things as did they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:144
verses.text: For those things were a shadow of these; however obstinate the Jew may be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:145
verses.text: Wherefore shouldest thou enquire of him, he will speak, no great thing, rather it is great which he will speak of, but nothing like what we speak of: because he knows not the truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:146
verses.text: For he for his part will say, "the Egyptians who detained us were so changed by the Almighty that they themselves urged and drave us out, who before held us forcibly; they did not suffer us so much as to leaven our dough".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:147
verses.text: But if a man asketh me, he shall hear not of Egypt nor of Pharaoh; but of our deliverance from the deceit of demons and the darkness of the devil: not of Moses but of the Son of God; not of a Red Sea but of a Baptism overflowing with ten thousand blessings, where the "old man" is drowned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:148
verses.text: Again, shouldest thou ask the Jew why he expels all leaven from all his borders; here he will even be silent and will not so much as state any reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:149
verses.text: And this is because, although some indeed of the circumstances were both types of things to come, and also due to things then happening; yet others were not so, that the Jews might not deal deceitfully; that they might not abide in the shadow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:150
verses.text: For tell me, what is the meaning of the Lamb's being a "Male," and "Unblemished," and a "year old," and of, "a bone shall not be broken?" and what means the command to call the neighbors also, (Exod.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:151
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:152
verses.text: ) and that it should be eaten "standing" and "in the evening;" or the fortifying the house with blood? He will have nothing else to say but over and over all about Egypt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:153
verses.text: But I can tell you the meaning both of the Blood, and of the Evening, and the Eating all together, and of the rule that all should be standing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:154
verses.text: But first let us explain why the leaven is cast out of all their borders.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:155
verses.text: What then is the hidden meaning? The believer must be freed from all iniquity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:156
verses.text: For as among them he perishes with whomsoever is found old leaven, so also with us wheresoever is found iniquity: since of course the punishment being so great in that which is a shadow, in our case it cannot choose but be much greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:157
verses.text: For if they so carefully clear their houses of leaven, and pry into mouse-holes; much more ought we to search through the soul so as to cast out every unclean thought.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:158
verses.text: This however was done by them of late; but now no longer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:159
verses.text: For every where there is leaven, where a Jew is found.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:160
verses.text: For it is in the midst of cities that the feast of unleavened bread is kept: a thing which is now rather a game at play than a law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:161
verses.text: For since the Truth is come, the Types have no longer any place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:162
verses.text: So that by means of this example also he mightily drives the fornicator out of the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:163
verses.text: For, saith he, so far from his presence profiting, he even doth harm, injuring the common estate of the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:164
verses.text: For one knows not whence is the evil savor while the corrupt part is concealed, and so one imputes it to the whole.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:165
verses.text: Wherefore he urges upon them strongly to "purge out the leaven, that ye may be," saith he, "a new lump, even as ye are unleavened".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:166
verses.text: "For our Passover hath been sacrificed for us even Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:167
verses.text: He said not, hath died, but more in point to the subject in hand, "hath been sacrificed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:168
verses.text: Seek not then unleavened bread of this kind, since neither hast thou a lamb of the same kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:169
verses.text: Seek not leaven of this description, seeing that thine unleavened bread is not such as this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:170
verses.text: Thus, in the case of material leaven, the unleavened might become leavened, but never the reverse; whereas here there is a chance of the direct contrary occuring.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:171
verses.text: This however he has not plainly declared: and observe his good sense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:172
verses.text: In the former Epistle he gives the fornicator no hope of return, but orders that his whole life should be spent in repentance, lest he should make him less energetic through the promise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:173
verses.text: For he said not, "Deliver him up to Satan," that having repented he might be commended again unto the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:174
verses.text: But what saith he? "That he may be saved in the last day".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:175
verses.text: For he conducts him on unto that time in order to make him full of anxiety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:176
verses.text: And what favors he intended him after the repentance, he reveals not, imitating his own Master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:177
verses.text: For as God saith, (Jonah iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:178
verses.text: lxx: rec.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:179
verses.text: text, "forty days".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:180
verses.text: ) "Yet three days, and Nineveh shall be overthrown," and added not, "but if she repent she shall be saved:" so also he did not say here, "But if he repent worthily, we will 'confirm our love towards him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:181
verses.text: '" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:182
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:184
verses.text: But he waits for him to do the work that so he may then receive the favor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:185
verses.text: For if he had said this at the beginning he might have set him free from the fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:186
verses.text: Wherefore he not only does not so, but by the instance of leaven allows him not even a hope of return, but reserves him unto that day: "Purge out (so he says) the old leaven;" and, "let us not keep the feast with old leaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:187
verses.text: But as soon as he had repented, he brought him in again with all earnestness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:188
verses.text: But why does he call it "old?" Either because our former life was of this sort, or because that which is old is "ready to vanish away," (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:189
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:190
verses.text: ) and is unsavory and foul; which is the nature of sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:191
verses.text: For He neither simply finds fault with the old, nor simply praises the new, but with reference to the subject matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:192
verses.text: And thus elsewhere He saith, (Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:193
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:194
verses.text: ) "New wine is as a new friend: but if it become old, then with pleasure shalt thou drink it:" in the case of friendship bestowing his praise rather upon the old than the new.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:195
verses.text: And again, "The Ancient of days sat," (Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:196
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:197
verses.text: ) here again, taking the term "ancient" as among those laudatory expressions which confer highest glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:198
verses.text: Elsewhere the Scripture takes the term "old" in the sense of blame; for seeing that the things are of various aspect as being composed of many parts, it uses the same words both in a good and an evil import, not according to the same shade of meaning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:199
verses.text: Of which you may see an instance in the blame cast elsewhere on the old: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:200
verses.text: xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:201
verses.text: ap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:202
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:203
verses.text: ) "They waxed old, and they halted from their paths".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:204
verses.text: And again, (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:205
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:206
verses.text: ap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:207
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:208
verses.text: ) "I have become old in the midst of all mine enemies".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:209
verses.text: And again, (Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:210
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:211
verses.text: Hist.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:212
verses.text: Susan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:213
verses.text: ) "O thou that art become old in evil days".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:214
verses.text: So also the "Leaven" is often taken for the kingdom of Heaven, although here found fault with.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:215
verses.text: But in that place it is used with one aspect, and in this with another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:216
verses.text: But I have a strong conviction that the saying about the leaven refers also to the priests who suffer a vast deal of the old leaven to be within, not purging out from their borders, that is, out of the Church, the covetous, the extortioners, and whatsoever would exclude from the kingdom of Heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:217
verses.text: For surely covetousness is an "old leaven;" and whenever it lights and into whatsoever house it enters, makes it unclean: and though you may gain but little by your injustice, it leavens the whole of your substance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:218
verses.text: Wherefore not seldom the dishonest gain being little, hath cast out the stock honestly laid up however abundant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:219
verses.text: For nothing is more rotten than covetousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:220
verses.text: You may fasten up that man's closet with key, and door, and bolt: you do all in vain, whilst you shut up within covetousness, the worst of robbers, and able to carry off all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:221
verses.text: "But what," say you, "if there are many covetous who do not experience this?" In the first place, they will experience it, though their experience come not immediately.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:222
verses.text: And should they now escape, then do thou fear it the more: for they are reserved for greater punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:223
verses.text: Add to this, that in the event of themselves escaping, yet those who inherit their wealth will have the same to endure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:224
verses.text: "But how can this be just," you will say? It is quite just.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:225
verses.text: For he that has succeeded to an inheritance; full of injustice, though he have committed no rapine himself, detains nevertheless the property of others; and is perfectly aware of this; and it is fair he should suffer for it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:226
verses.text: For if this or that person had robbed and you received a thing, and then the owner came and demanded it back; would it avail you in defence to say that you had not seized it? By no means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:227
verses.text: For what would be your plea when accused! tell me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:228
verses.text: That it was another who seized it? Well: but you are keeping possession.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:229
verses.text: That it was he who robbed? But you are enjoying it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:230
verses.text: Why these rules even the laws of the heathen recognise, which acquitting those who have seized and stolen, bid you demand satisfaction from those persons in whose possession you happen to find your things all laid up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:231
verses.text: If then you know who are the injured, restore and do what Zacchaeus did, with much increase.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:232
verses.text: But if you know not, I offer you another way yet; I do not preclude you from the remedy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:233
verses.text: Distribute all these things to the poor: and thus you will mitigate the evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:234
verses.text: But if some have transmitted these things even to children and descendants, still in retribution they have suffered other disasters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:235
verses.text: And why speak I of things in this present life? In that day at any rate will none of these things be said, when both appear naked, both the spoiled and the spoilers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:236
verses.text: Or rather not alike naked.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:237
verses.text: Of riches indeed both will be equally stripped; but the one will be full of the charges to which they gave occasion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:238
verses.text: What then shall we do on that day, when before the dread tribunal he that hath been evil entreated and lost his all is brought forward into the midst, and you have no one to speak a word for you? What will you say to the Judge? Now indeed you may be able even to corrupt the judgment, being but of men; but in that court and at that time, it will be no longer so: no, nor yet now will you be able.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:239
verses.text: For even at this moment that tribunal is present: since God both seeth our doings and is near unto the injured, though not invoked: it being certain that whoever suffers wrong, however in himself unworthy to obtain any redress, yet nevertheless seeing that what is done pleases not God, he hath most assuredly one to avenge him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:240
verses.text: "How then," you will say, "is such an one well off, who is wicked?" Nay, it will not be so unto the end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:241
verses.text: Hear what saith the Prophet; (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:242
verses.text: xxxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:244
verses.text: ) "Fret not thyself because of the evil doers, because as grass they shall quickly wither away".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:245
verses.text: For where, tell me, where is he who wrought rapine, after his departure hence? Where are his bright hopes! Where his august name? Are they not all passed and gone? Is it not a dream and a shadow, all that was his? And this you must expect in the case of every such person, both in his own person while living, and in that of him who shall come after him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:246
verses.text: But not such is the state of the saints, nor will it be possible for you to say the same things in their case also, that it is shadow and a dream and a tale, what belongs to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:247
verses.text: And if you please, he who spake these things, the tent-maker, the Cilician, the man whose very parentage is unknown, let him be the example we produce.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:248
verses.text: You will say, "How is it possible to become such as he was?" Do you then thoroughly desire it? Are you thoroughly anxious to become such? "Yes," you will say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:249
verses.text: Well then, go the same way as he went and they that were with him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:250
verses.text: Now what way went he? One saith, ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:251
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:252
verses.text: ) "In hunger, and thirst, and nakedness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:253
verses.text: Another, (Acts iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:254
verses.text: ) "Silver and gold I have none".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:255
verses.text: Thus they "had nothing and yet possessed all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:256
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:257
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:258
verses.text: ) What can be nobler than this saying? what more blessed or more abundant in riches? Others indeed pride themselves on the contrary things, saying, "I have this or that number of talents of gold, and acres of land without end, and houses, and slaves;" but this man on his being naked of all things; and he shrinks not from poverty, (which is the feeling of the unwise,) nor hides his face, but he even wears it as an ornament.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:259
verses.text: Where now be the rich men, they who count up their interest simple and compound, they who take from all men and are never satisfied? Have ye heard the voice of Peter, that voice which sets forth poverty as the mother of wealth? That voice which has nothing, yet is wealthier than those who wear diadems? For this is that voice, which having nothing, raised the dead, and set upright the lame, and drove away devils, and bestowed such gracious gifts, as those who are clad in the purple robe and lead the mighty and terrible legions never were able to bestow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:260
verses.text: This is the voice of those who are now removed into heaven, of those who have attained unto that height.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:261
verses.text: Thus it is possible that he who hath nothing may possess all men's goods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:262
verses.text: Thus may he who possesses nothing acquire the goods of all: whereas, were we to get all men's goods, we are bereft of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:263
verses.text: Perhaps this saying seems to be a paradox; but it is not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:264
verses.text: "But," you will say, "how does he who hath nothing possess all men's goods? Doth he not have much more who hath what belongs to all?" By no means: but the contrary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:265
verses.text: For he who hath nothing commands all, even as they did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:266
verses.text: And throughout the world all houses were open to them, and they who offered them took their coming as a favor, and they came to them as to friends and kindred.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:267
verses.text: For so they came to the woman who was a seller of purple, (Acts xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:268
verses.text: ) and she like a servant set before them what she had.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:269
verses.text: And to the keeper of the prison; and he opened to them all his house.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:270
verses.text: And to innumerable others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:271
verses.text: Thus they had all things and had nothing: for (Acts iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:272
verses.text: ) "they said that none of the things which they possessed was their own;" therefore all things were theirs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:273
verses.text: For he that considers all things to be common, will not only use his own, but also the things of others as if they belonged to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:274
verses.text: But he that parts things off and sets himself as master over his own only, will not be master even of these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:275
verses.text: And this is plain from an example.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:276
verses.text: He who possesses nothing at all, neither house, nor table, nor garment to spare, but for God's sake is bereft of all, uses the things which are in common as his own; and he shall receive from all whatsoever he may desire, and thus he that hath nothing possesses the things of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:277
verses.text: But he that hath some things, will not be master even of these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:278
verses.text: For first, no one will give to him that hath possessions; and, secondly, his property shall belong to robbers and thieves and informers and changing events and be any body's rather than his.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:279
verses.text: Paul, for instance, went up and down throughout all the world, carrying nothing with him, though he went neither unto friends nor kindred.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:280
verses.text: Nay, at first he was a common enemy to all: but nevertheless he had all men's goods after he had made good his entrance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:281
verses.text: But Ananias and Sapphira, hastening to gain a little more than their own, lost all together with life itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:282
verses.text: Withdraw then from thine own, that thou mayest use others' goods as thine own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:283
verses.text: But I must stop: I know not how I have been carried into such a transport in speaking such words as these unto men who think it a great thing to impart but ever so little of their own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:284
verses.text: Wherefore let these my words have been spoken to the perfect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:285
verses.text: But to the more imperfect, this is what we may say, Give of what you have unto the needy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:286
verses.text: Increase your substance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:287
verses.text: For, saith He, (Prov.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:288
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:289
verses.text: ) "He that giveth unto the poor, lendeth unto God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:290
verses.text: But if you are in a hurry and wait not for the time of recompense, think of those who lend money to men: for not even these desire to get their interest immediately; but they are anxious that the principal should remain a good long while in the hands of the borrower, provided only the repayment be secure and they have no mistrust of the borrower.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:291
verses.text: Let this be done then in the present case also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:292
verses.text: Leave them with God that He may pay thee thy wages manifold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:293
verses.text: Seek not to have the whole here; for if you recover it all here, how will you receive it back there? And it is on this account that God stores them up there, inasmuch as this present life is full of decay.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:294
verses.text: But He gives even here also; for, "Seek ye," saith He, "the kingdom of heaven, and all these things shall be added unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:295
verses.text: (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:296
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:297
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:298
verses.text: ) Well then, let us look towards the kingdom, and not be in a hurry for the repayment of the whole, lest we diminish our recompense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:299
verses.text: But let us wait for the fit season.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:300
verses.text: For the interest in these cases is not of that kind, but is such as is meet to be given to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 14:301
verses.text: This then having collected together in great abundance, so let us depart hence, that we may obtain both the present and the future blessings; through the grace and loving-kindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom unto the Father and the Holy Spirit be glory, power, honor, now, henceforth, and for evermore, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:1
verses.text: Homily XVI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:3
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:4
verses.text: –  I wrote unto you in my epistle to have no company with fornicators: yet not altogether with the fornicators of this world, or with the covetous and extortioners, or with idolaters, for then must ye needs go out of the world: but now I write unto you not to keep company, if any man that is named a brother be a fornicator, or covetous, or an idolater, or a drunkard, or a reviler, or an extortioner; with such an one no not to eat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:5
verses.text: For since he had said, "Ye have not rather mourned, that such an one should be taken away;" and, "Purge out the old leaven;" and it was likely that they would surmise it to be their duty to avoid all fornicators: for if he that has sinned imparts some of his own mischief to those who have not sinned, much more is it meet to keep one's self away from those without: (for if one ought not to spare a friend on account of such mischief arising from him, much less any others;) and under this impression, it was probable that they would separate themselves from the fornicators among the Greeks also, and the matter thus turning out impossible, they would have taken it more to heart: he used this mode of correction, saying, "I wrote unto you to have no company with fornicators, yet not altogether with the fornicators of this world:" using the word "altogether," as if it were an acknowledged thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:6
verses.text: For that they might not think that he charged not this upon them as being rather imperfect, and should attempt to do it under the erroneous impression that they were perfect, he shews that this were even impossible to be done, though they wished it ever so much.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:7
verses.text: For it would be necessary to seek another world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:8
verses.text: Wherefore he added, "For ye must needs then go out of the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:9
verses.text: Seest thou that he is no hard master, and that in his legislation he constantly regards not only what may be done, but also what may be easily done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:10
verses.text: For how is it possible, says he, for a man having care of a house and children, and engaged in the affairs of the city, or who is an artisan or a soldier, (the greater part of mankind being Greeks,) to avoid the unclean who are to be found every where? For by "the fornicators of the world," he means those who are among the Greeks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:11
verses.text: "But now I write unto you, If any brother" be of this kind, "with such an one no not to eat".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:12
verses.text: Here also he glances at others who were living in wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:13
verses.text: But how can one "that is a brother" be an idolater? As was the case once in regard to the Samaritans who chose piety but by halves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:14
verses.text: And besides he is laying down his ground beforehand for the discourse concerning things offered in sacrifice to idols, which after this he intends to handle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:15
verses.text: "Or covetous".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:16
verses.text: For with these also he enters into conflict.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:17
verses.text: Wherefore he said also, "Why not rather take wrong? Why not rather be defrauded? Nay, ye yourselves do wrong and defraud".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:18
verses.text: "Or a drunkard".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:19
verses.text: For this also he lays to their charge further on; as when he says, "One is hungry and another is drunken:" and, "meats for the belly and the belly for meats".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:20
verses.text: "Or a reviler, or an extortioner:" for these too he had rebuked before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:21
verses.text: Next he adds also the reason why he forbids them not to mix with heathens of that character, implying that it is not only impossible, but also superfluous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:22
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:23
verses.text: , "For what have I to do with judging them that are without?" Calling the Christians and the Greeks, "those within" and "those without," as also he says elsewhere, ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:24
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:25
verses.text: ) "He must also have a good report of them that are without".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:26
verses.text: And in the Epistle to the Thessalonians he speaks the same language, saying, ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:27
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:28
verses.text: ) "Have no intercourse with him to the end that he may be put to shame".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:29
verses.text: And, "Count him not as an enemy, but admonish him as a brother".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:30
verses.text: Here, however, he does not add the reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:31
verses.text: Why? Because in the other case he wished to soothe them, but in this, not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:32
verses.text: For the fault in this case and in that was not the same, but in the Thessalonians it was less.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:33
verses.text: For there he is reproving indolence; but here fornication and other most grievous sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:34
verses.text: And if any one wished to go over to the Greeks, he hinders not him from eating with such persons; this too for the same reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:35
verses.text: So also do we act; for our children and our brethren we leave nothing undone, but of strangers we do not make much account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:36
verses.text: How then? Did not Paul care for them that were without as well? Yes, he cared for them; but it was not till after they received the Gospel and he had made them subject to the doctrine of Christ, that he laid down laws for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:37
verses.text: But so long as they despised, it was superfluous to speak the precepts of Christ to those who knew not Christ Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:38
verses.text: "Do not ye judge them that are within, whereas them that are without, God judgeth?" For since he had said, "What have I to do with judging those without;" lest any one should think that these were left unpunished, there is another tribunal which he sets over them, and that a fearful one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:39
verses.text: And this he said, both to terrify those, and to console these; intimating also that this punishment which is for a season snatches them away from that which is undying and perpetual: which also he has plainly declared elsewhere, saying, ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:40
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:41
verses.text: ) "But now being judged, we are chastened, that we should not be condemned with the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:42
verses.text: "Put away from among yourselves the wicked person".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:43
verses.text: He used an expression found in the Old Testament, (Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:44
verses.text: xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:45
verses.text: ) partly hinting that they too will be very great gainers, in being freed as it were from some grievous plague; and partly to shew that this kind of thing is no innovation, but even from the beginning it seemed good to the legislator that such as these should be cut off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:46
verses.text: But in that instance it was done with more severity, in this with more gentleness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:47
verses.text: On which account one might reasonably question, why in that case he conceded that the sinner should be severely punished and stoned, but in the present instance not so; rather he leads him to repentance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:48
verses.text: Why then were the lines drawn in the former instance one way and in the latter another? For these two causes: one, because these were led into a greater trial and needed greater long-suffering; the other and truer one, because these by their impunity were more easily to be corrected, coming as they might to repentance; but the others were likely to go on to greater wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:49
verses.text: For if when they saw the first undergoing punishment they persisted in the same things, had none at all been punished, much more would this have been their feeling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:50
verses.text: For which reason in that dispensation death is immediately inflicted upon the adulterer and the manslayer; but in this, if through repentance they are absolved, they have escaped the punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:51
verses.text: However, both here one may see some instances of heavier punishment, and in the Old Testament some less severe, in order that it may be signified in every way that the covenants are akin to each other, and of one and the same lawgiver: and you may see the punishment following immediately both in that covenant and in this, and in both often after a long interval.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:52
verses.text: Nay, and oftentimes not even after a long interval, repentance alone being taken as satisfaction by the Almighty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:53
verses.text: Thus in the Old Testament, David, who had committed adultery and murder, was saved by means of repentance; and in the New, Ananias, who withdrew but a small portion of the price of the land, perished together with his wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:54
verses.text: Now if these instances are more frequent in the Old Testament, and those of the contrary kind in the New, the difference of the persons produces the difference in the treatment adopted in such matters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:55
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:56
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:57
verses.text: ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:58
verses.text: "Dare any one of you, having a matter against his brother, (τὸν ἀδελφὸν, rec.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:59
verses.text: text τὁν ἓτερον.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:60
verses.text: ) go to law before the unrighteous, and not before the saints?"  Here also he again makes his complaint upon acknowledged grounds; for in that other place he says, "It is actually reported that there is fornication among you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:61
verses.text: And in this place, "Dare any one of you?" From the very first outset giving signs of his anger, and implying that the thing spoken of comes of a daring and lawless spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:62
verses.text: Now wherefore did he bring in by the way that discourse about covetousness and about the duty of not going to law without the Church? In fulfilment of his own rule.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:63
verses.text: For it is a custom with him to set to right things as they fall in his way; just as when speaking about the tables which they used in common, he launched out into the discourse about the mysteries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 15:64
verses.text: So here, you see, since he had made mention of covetous brethren, burning with anxiety to correct those in sin, he brooks not exactly to observe order; but he again corrects the sin which had been introduced out of the regular course, and so returns to the former subject.
