verses.text: "What then," say you, "does not the murderer stain his hand? What, of the covetous person and the extortioner?" I suppose it is plain to every one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:36
verses.text: But since it was not possible to mention anything worse than the fornicator, he amplifies the crime in another way, by saying that in the fornicator the entire body becomes defiled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:37
verses.text: For it is as polluted as if it had fallen into a vessel of filth, and been immersed in defilement.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:38
verses.text: And this too is our way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:39
verses.text: For from covetousness and extortion no one would make haste to go into a bath, but as if nothing had happened returns to his house.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:40
verses.text: Whereas from intercourse with a harlot, as having become altogether unclean, he goes to a bath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:41
verses.text: To such a degree does the conscience retain from this sin a kind of sense of unusual shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:42
verses.text: Both however are bad, both covetousness and fornication; and both cast into hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:43
verses.text: But as Paul doeth every thing with good management, so by whatever topics he had he magnified the sin of fornication.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:44
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:45
verses.text: "Know ye not that your body is a temple of the Holy Ghost which is in you?" He did not merely say, "of the Spirit," but, "which is in you;" which was the part of one who also was soothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:46
verses.text: And again, explaining himself still further, he added, "which ye have from God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:47
verses.text: He mentioned Him that gave also, both exalting the hearer and putting him in fear, both by the magnitude of the deposit, and by the munificence of Him that made it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:48
verses.text: "And ye are not your own".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:49
verses.text: This is not only to abash, but even to force men towards virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:50
verses.text: "For why," says he; "doest thou what thou wilt? thou art not thine own master".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:51
verses.text: But these things he said, not to take away free-will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:52
verses.text: For so in saying, "All things are lawful for me, but not all things are expedient," he does not take away our liberty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:53
verses.text: And here again, writing, "Ye are not your own;" he makes no infringement upon freedom of choice, but he leads away from vice and indicates the guardian care of the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:54
verses.text: And therefore he added, "For ye were bought with a price".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:55
verses.text: "But if I am not my own, upon what ground do you demand of me duties to be done? And why do you go on to say again, "Glorify God therefore in your body and in your spirit, which are God's?" What then is the meaning of, "ye are not your own?" And what does he wish to prove thereby? To settle them in a state of security against sin, and against following the improper desires of the mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:56
verses.text: For indeed we have many improper wishes: but we must repress them, for we can.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:57
verses.text: And if we could not, exhortation would be in vain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:58
verses.text: Mark, accordingly, how he secures his ground.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:59
verses.text: For having said, "Ye are not your own," he adds not, "But are under compulsion;" but, "Ye were bought with a price".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:60
verses.text: Why sayest thou this? Surely on another ground, one might say perhaps, you should have persuaded men, pointing out that we have a Master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:61
verses.text: But this is common to the Greeks also together with us: whereas the expression, "Ye were bought with a price," belongs to us peculiarly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:62
verses.text: For he reminds us of the greatness of the benefit and of the mode of our salvation, signifying that when we were alienated, we were "bought:" and not simply "bought," but, "with a price".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:63
verses.text: "Glorify then, take up and bear, God in your body, and in your spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:64
verses.text: Now these things he says, that we may not only flee fornication in the body, but also in the spirit of our mind abstain from every wicked thought, and from driving away grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:65
verses.text: "Which are God's".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:66
verses.text: For as he had said "your," he added therefore, "which are God's:" continually reminding us that all things belong to the Lord, both body and soul and spirit: For some say, that the words "in the spirit" mean the gracious Gift; for if That be in us, God is glorified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:67
verses.text: And this will be, if we have a clean heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:68
verses.text: But He has spoken of these things as God's, not only because He brought them into being, but also because, when they were alienated, He won them again a second time, paying as the price, the blood of the Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:69
verses.text: Mark how He brought the whole to completion in Christ, how He raised us up into heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:70
verses.text: "Ye are members of Christ," saith he, "ye are a temple of the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:71
verses.text: Become not then "members of a harlot:" for it is not your body which is insulted; since it is not your body at all, but Christ's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:72
verses.text: And these things he spake, both to make manifest His loving-kindness in that our body is His, and to withdraw us from all evil license.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:73
verses.text: For if the body be another's, "you have no authority," says he, "to insult another's body; and especially when it is the Lord's; nor yet to pollute a temple of the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:74
verses.text: For if any one who invades a private house and makes his way revelling into it, must answer for it most severely; think what dreadful things he shall endure who makes a temple of the King a robber's lurking place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:75
verses.text: Considering these things therefore, reverence thou Him that dwelleth within.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:76
verses.text: For the Paraclete is He.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:77
verses.text: Thrill before Him that is enfolded and cleaves unto thee; for Christ is He.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:78
verses.text: Hast thou indeed made thyself members of Christ? Think thus, and continue chaste; whose members they were, and Whose they have become.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:79
verses.text: Erewhile they were members of an harlot, and Christ hath made them members of His own Body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:80
verses.text: Thou hast therefore henceforth no authority over them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:81
verses.text: Serve Him that hath set thee free.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:82
verses.text: For supposing you had a daughter, and in extreme madness had let her out to a procurer for hire, and made her live a harlot's life, and then a king's son were to pass by, and free her from that slavery, and join her in marriage to himself; you could have no power thenceforth to bring her into the brothel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:83
verses.text: For you gave her up once for all, and sold her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:84
verses.text: Such as this is our case also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:85
verses.text: We let out our own flesh for hire unto the Devil, that grievous procurer: Christ saw and set it free, and withdrew it from that evil tyranny; it is not then ours any more but His who delivered it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:86
verses.text: If you be willing to use it as a King's bride, there is none to hinder; but if you bring it where it was before, you will suffer just what they ought who are guilty of such outrages.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:87
verses.text: Wherefore you should rather adorn instead of disgracing it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:88
verses.text: For you have no authority over the flesh in the wicked lusts, but in those things alone which God may enjoin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:89
verses.text: Let the thought enter your mind at least from what great outrage God hath delivered it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:90
verses.text: For in truth never did any harlot expose herself so shamefully as our nature before this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:91
verses.text: For robberies, murders, and every wicked thought entered in and lay with the soul, and for a small and vulgar hire, the present pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:92
verses.text: For the soul, being mixed up with all wicked devices and deeds, reaped this reward and no other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:93
verses.text: However, in the time before this, bad though it were to be such as these, it was not so bad: but after heaven, after the King's courts, after partaking of the tremendous Mysteries, again to be contaminated, what pardon shall this have? Or, dost thou not think that the covetous too, and all those whom he recounted before, have the Devil to lie with them? And dost thou not judge that the women who beautify themselves for pollution have intercourse with him? Why, who shall gainsay this word? But if any be contentious, let him uncover the soul of the women who behave in this unseemly manner, and he will surely see that the wicked demon closely entwined with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:94
verses.text: For it is hard, brethren, it is hard, perchance even impossible, when the body is thus beautified, for the soul to be beautified at the same time: but one must needs be neglected, while the other is cared for.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:95
verses.text: For nature does not allow these to take place together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:96
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, "He that is joined to a harlot is one body; but he that is joined to the Lord is one Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:97
verses.text: For such an one becomes thenceforth Spirit, although a body envelope him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:98
verses.text: For when nothing corporeal nor gross nor earthly is around him, the body doth but merely envelope him; since the whole government of him is in the soul and the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:99
verses.text: In this way God is glorified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:100
verses.text: Wherefore both in the Prayer we are commanded to say, "Hallowed be Thy Name:" and Christ saith also, "Let your light shine before men, that they may see your good works, and glorify your Father which is in heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:101
verses.text: So do the heavens also glorify Him, uttering no voice, but by the view of them attracting wonder and referring the glory unto the Great Artificer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:102
verses.text: So let us glorify Him also, or rather more than they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:103
verses.text: For we can if we will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:104
verses.text: For not so much do the heaven nor day nor night glorify God, as a holy soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:105
verses.text: For as one that gazeth upon the beauty of the heaven, saith, "Glory be to Thee, O God! How fair a work hast thou formed!" so too when beholding virtue in any man: nay, and much more so in the latter instance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:106
verses.text: For from these works of creation all do not glorify God; but many even assert that the things which exist are self-moving: and others impute to demons the workmanship of the world and providence; and these indeed greatly and unpardonably err: but in regard to the virtue of man, no one shall have power to hold these shameless opinions, but shall assuredly glorify God when he seeth him that serveth Him living in goodness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:107
verses.text: For who shall help being astonished when one being a man, and partaking of our common nature, and living among other men, like adamant yields not at all to the swarm of passions? When being in the midst of fire and iron and wild beasts, he is even harder than adamant and vanquishes all for the Word of godliness' sake? when he is injured, and blesses; when he is evil reported of, and praises; when he is despitefully used, and prays for those who injure him; when he is plotted against, and does good to those that fight with him and lay snares for him? For these things, and such as these, will glorify God far more than the heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:108
verses.text: For the Greeks when they behold the heavens feel no awe; but when they see a holy man exhibiting a severe course of life with all strictness, they shrink away and condemn themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:109
verses.text: Since when he that partakes of the same nature as themselves is so much above them, a great deal more so than the heaven is above the earth, even against their inclination they think that it is a Divine power which works these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:110
verses.text: Wherefore He saith, "And glorify your Father which is in heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:111
verses.text: Wilt thou learn also from another place how by the life of His servants God is glorified, and how by miracles? Nebuchadnezzar once threw the Three Children into the furnace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:112
verses.text: Then when he saw that the fire had not prevailed over them, he saith, (Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:113
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:114
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:115
verses.text: ἐκ τῆς καμίνου added.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:116
verses.text: ) "Blessed be God, who hath sent His Angel, and delivered his servants out of the furnace, because they trusted in Him and have changed the word of the king".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:117
verses.text: "How sayest thou? Hast thou been despised, and dost thou admire those who have spit upon you?" "Yes," saith he, "and for this very reason, that I was despised".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:118
verses.text: And of the marvel he gives this reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:119
verses.text: So that not because of the miracle alone was glory given to God at that time, but also because of the purpose of those who have been thrown in.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:120
verses.text: Now if any one would examine this point and the other, as they are in themselves, this will appear not less than that: for to persuade souls to brave a furnace is not less in respect of the wonder than to deliver from a furnace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:121
verses.text: For how can it be otherwise than astonishing for the Emperor of the world, with so many arms around him, and legions, and generals, and viceroys, and consuls, and land and sea subject to his sway, to be despised by captive children; for the bound to overcome the binder and conquer all that army? Neither was there any power in the king and his company to do what they would, no, not even with the furnaces for an ally.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:122
verses.text: But they who were naked, and slaves, and strangers, and few, (for what number could be more contemptible than three?) being in chains, vanquished an innumerable army.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:123
verses.text: For already now was death despised, since Christ was henceforth about to sojourn in the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:124
verses.text: And as when the sun is on the point of rising, even before his rays appear the light of the day groweth bright; so also when then the Sun of Righteousness was about to come, death henceforth began to withdraw himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:125
verses.text: What could be more splendid than that theatre? What more conspicuous than that victory? What more signal than those new trophies of theirs?  The same thing is done in our time also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:126
verses.text: Even now is there a king of the Babylonish furnace, even now he kindles a flame fiercer than that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:127
verses.text: There is even now such an image, and one who giveth command to admire it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:128
verses.text: At his side are satraps and soldiers and bewitching music.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:129
verses.text: And many gaze in admiration upon this image, so varied, so great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:130
verses.text: For somewhat of the same kind of thing as that image is covetousness, which doth not despise even iron, but unlike as the materials are whereof it is composed, it giveth command to admire all, both brass and iron, and things much more ordinary than they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:131
verses.text: But as these things are, so also even now are there some who are emulous of these children: who say, "thy gods we serve not, and thine images we worship not;" but both the furnace of poverty we endure and all other distress, for the sake of God's laws".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:132
verses.text: And the wealthy for their part, even as those at that time, oftentimes, worship this image too and are burnt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:133
verses.text: But those who possess nothing despite even this, and although in poverty, are more in the dew than those who live in affluence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:134
verses.text: Even as at that time they who cast into the fire were burnt up; but those in the midst of it found themselves in dew as it were rain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:135
verses.text: Then also that tyrant was more burnt up with the flame, his wrath kindling him violently, than those children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:136
verses.text: As to them, the fire had no power even to touch the ends of their hair: but more fiercely than that fire did wrath burn up his mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:137
verses.text: For consider what a thing it was that with so many to look on, he should be scorned by captive children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:138
verses.text: And it was a sign that his taking their city also had not been through his own might, but by reason of the sin of the multitude among them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:139
verses.text: Since if he had not the power to overcome these men in chains, and that when they were cast into a furnace, how could he have overcome the Jews in regular warfare, had they been all such as these? From which it is plain that the sins of the multitude betrayed the city.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:140
verses.text: But mark also the children's freedom from vain-glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:141
verses.text: For they did not leap into the furnace, but they kept beforehand the commandment of Christ where he says, (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:142
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:143
verses.text: xxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:144
verses.text: ) "Pray that ye enter not into temptation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:145
verses.text: Neither did they shrink when they were brought to it; but stood in the midst nobly, neither contending without a summons, nor yet when summoned playing the coward: but ready for everything, and noble, and full of all boldness of speech.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:146
verses.text: But let us hear also what they say, that from this also we may learn their lofty spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:147
verses.text: (Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:148
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:149
verses.text: ) "There is a God in heaven able to deliver us:" they take no care for themselves, but even when about to be burned the glory of God is all their thought.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:150
verses.text: For what they say comes to this, "Lest perchance if we are burnt thou shouldest charge God with weakness, we now declare unto thee accurately our whole doctrine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:151
verses.text: "There is a God in heaven," not such as this image here on earth, this lifeless and mute thing, but able to snatch even from the midst of the burning fiery furnace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:152
verses.text: Condemn him not then of weakness for permitting us to fall into it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:153
verses.text: So powerful is He that after our fall, He is able to snatch us out again out of the flame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:154
verses.text: "But if not, be it known unto thee, O king, that we will not serve thy gods, nor worship the golden image which thou hast set up".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:155
verses.text: Observe that they by a special dispensation are ignorant of the future: for if they had foreknown, there would have been nothing wonderful in their doing what they did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:156
verses.text: For what marvel is it if when they had a guarantee for safety, they defied all terrors? Then God indeed would have been glorified in that He was able to deliver from the furnace: but they would not have been wondered at, inasmuch as they would not have cast themselves into any dangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:157
verses.text: For this cause He suffered them to be ignorant of the future that He might glorify them the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:158
verses.text: And as they cautioned (ἠσψαλίξοντο) the king that he was not to condemn God of weakness though they might be burnt, so God accomplished both purposes; the shewing forth His own power and the causing the zeal of the children to appear more conspicuous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:159
verses.text: From whence then arose their doubting and their not feeling confident that they should at all events be preserved? Because they esteemed themselves assuredly too mean, and unworthy of such a benefit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:160
verses.text: And to prove that I say not this upon conjecture; when they fell into the furnace, they bewailed themselves after this sort, saying, (Song of the three Children vv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:162
verses.text: ) "We have sinned, we have done iniquity, we cannot open our mouth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:163
verses.text: And therefore they said, "But if not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:164
verses.text: But if they did not plainly say this, namely, "God is able to deliver us; but if he deliver us not, for our sin's sake He will not deliver us;" wonder not at it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:165
verses.text: For they would have seemed to the barbarians to be sheltering the weakness of God under the pretext of their own sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:166
verses.text: Wherefore His power only is what they speak of: the reason they allege not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:167
verses.text: And besides, they were well disciplined not to be over-curious about the judgments of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:168
verses.text: With these words then, they entered into the fire; and they neither cast insult upon the king, nor overturned the statue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:169
verses.text: For such should the courageous man be, temperate and mild; and that especially in dangers; that he may not seem to go forth to such contests in wrath and vain-glory; but with fortitude and self-possession.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:170
verses.text: For whoso deals insolently undergoes the suspicion of those faults: but he that endures, and is forced into the struggle, and goes through the trial with meekness, is not only admired as brave, but his self-possession also and consideration cause him to be no less extolled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:171
verses.text: And this is what they did at that time; shewing forth all fortitude and gentleness, and doing nothing for reward nor for recompense or return.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:172
verses.text: "'Though He be not willing 'so it stands' to deliver us, we will not serve thy gods:' for we have already our recompense in that we are counted worthy to be kept from all impiety, and for that end to give our bodies to be burned".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:173
verses.text: We then also having already our recompense, (for indeed we have it in that we have been vouchsafed the full knowledge of Him, vouch-safed to be made members of Christ,) let us take care that we make them not members of an harlot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:174
verses.text: For with this most tremendous saying we must conclude our discourse, in order that having the fear of the threat in full efficacy, we may remain purer than gold, this fear helping to make us so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:175
verses.text: For so shall we be able, delivered from all fornication, to see Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 17:176
verses.text: Whom God grant us all to behold with boldness at that day, through the grace and loving-kindness of our Lord Jesus Christ; to Whom be the glory, for evermore, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:1
verses.text: Homily XIX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:3
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:4
verses.text: ,  Now concerning the things whereof ye wrote to me: it is good for a man not to touch a woman.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:5
verses.text: But because of fornications, let each man have his own wife; and let each woman have her own husband.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:6
verses.text: Having corrected the three heaviest things laid to their charge, one, the distraction of the Church, another, about the fornicator, a third, about the covetous person, he thenceforth uses a milder sort of speech.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:7
verses.text: And he interposes some exhortation and advice about marriage and virginity, giving the hearers some respite from more unpleasant subjects.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:8
verses.text: But in the second Epistle he does the contrary; he begins from the milder topics, and ends with the more distressing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:9
verses.text: And here also, after he has finished his discourse about virginity, he again launches forth into matter more akin to reproof; not setting all down in regular order, but varying his discourse in either kind, as the occasion required and the exigency of the matters in hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:10
verses.text: Wherefore he says, "Now concerning the things whereof ye wrote unto me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:11
verses.text: For they had written to him, "Whether it was right to abstain from one's wife, or not:" and writing back in answer to this and giving rules about marriage, he introduces also the discourse concerning virginity: "It is good for a man not to touch a woman".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:12
verses.text: "For if," says he, "thou enquire what is the excellent and greatly superior course, it is better not to have any connection whatever with a woman: but if you ask what is safe and helpful to thine own infirmity, be connected by marriage".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:13
verses.text: But since it was likely, as also happens now, that the husband might be willing but the wife not, or perhaps the reverse, mark how he discusses each case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:14
verses.text: Some indeed say that this discourse was addressed by him to priests.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:15
verses.text: But I, judging from what follows, could not affirm that it was so: since he would not have given his advice in general terms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:16
verses.text: For if he were writing these things only for the priests, he would have said, "It is good for the teacher not to touch a woman".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:17
verses.text: But now he has made it of universal application, saying, "It is good for a man;" not for priest only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:18
verses.text: And again, "Art thou loosed from a wife? Seek not a wife".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:19
verses.text: He said not, "You who are a priest and teacher," but indefinitely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:20
verses.text: And the whole of his speech goes on entirely in the same tones.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:21
verses.text: And in saying, "Because of fornications, let every man have his own wife" by the very cause alleged for the concession he guides men to continence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:22
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:23
verses.text: "Let the husband pay the wife the honor due to her: in like manner the wife the husband".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:24
verses.text: Now what is the meaning of "the due honor? The wife hath not power over her own body;" but is both the slave and the mistress of the husband.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:25
verses.text: And if you decline the service which is due, you have offended God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:26
verses.text: But if thou wish to withdraw thyself, it must be with the husband's permission, though it be but a for short time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:27
verses.text: For this is why he calls the matter a debt, to shew that no one is master of himself but that they are servants to each other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:28
verses.text: When therefore thou seest an harlot tempting thee, say, "My body is not mine, but my wife's".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:29
verses.text: The same also let the woman say to those who would undermine her chastity, "My body is not mine, but my husband's".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:30
verses.text: Now if neither husband nor wife hath power even over their own body, much less have they over their property.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:31
verses.text: Hear ye, all that have husbands and all that have wives: that if you must not count your body your own, much less your money.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:32
verses.text: Elsewhere I grant He gives to the husband abundant precedence, both in the New Testament, and the Old saying, (ἡ ἀποστρόφή σου, LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:33
verses.text: Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:34
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:35
verses.text: ) "Thy turning shall be towards thy husband, and he shall rule over thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:36
verses.text: Paul doth so too by making a distinction thus, and writing, (Ephes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:37
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:39
verses.text: ) "Husbands, love your wives; and let the wife see that she reverence her husband".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:40
verses.text: But in this place we hear no more of greater and less, but it is one and the same right.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:41
verses.text: Now why is this? Because his speech was about chastity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:42
verses.text: "In all other things," says he, "let the husband have the prerogative; but not so where the question is about chastity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:43
verses.text: "The husband hath no power over his own body, neither the wife".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:44
verses.text: There is great equality of honor, and no prerogative.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:45
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:46
verses.text: "Defraud ye not one the other, except it be by consent".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:47
verses.text: What then can this mean? "Let not the wife," says he, "exercise continence, if the husband be unwilling; nor yet the husband without the wife's consent".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:48
verses.text: Why so? Because great evils spring from this sort of continence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:49
verses.text: For adulteries and fornications and the ruin of families have often arisen from hence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:50
verses.text: For if when men have their own wives they commit fornication, much more if you defraud them of this consolation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:51
verses.text: And well says he, "Defraud not; fraud" here, and "debt" above, that he might shew the strictness of the right of dominion in question.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:52
verses.text: For that one should practice continence against the will of the other is "defrauding;" but not so, with the other's consent: any more than I count myself defrauded, if after persuading me you take away any thing of mine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:53
verses.text: Since only he defrauds who takes against another's will and by force.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:54
verses.text: A thing which many women do, working sin rather than righteousness, and thereby becoming accountable for the husband's uncleanness, and rending all asunder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:55
verses.text: Whereas they should value concord above all things, since this is more important than all beside.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:56
verses.text: We will, if you please, consider it with a view to actual cases.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:57
verses.text: Thus, suppose a wife and husband, and let the wife be continent, without consent of her husband; well then, if hereupon he commit fornication, or though abstaining from fornication fret and grow restless and be heated and quarrel and give all kind of trouble to his wife; where is all the gain of the fasting and the continence, a breach being made in love? There is none.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:58
verses.text: For what strange reproaches, how much trouble, how great a war must of course arise! since when in an house man and wife are at variance, the house will be no better off than a ship in a storm when the master is upon ill terms with the man at the head.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:59
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, "Defraud not one another, unless it be by consent for a season, that ye may give yourselves unto prayer".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:60
verses.text: It is prayer with unusual earnestness which he here means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:61
verses.text: For if he is forbidding those who have intercourse with one another to pray, how could "pray without ceasing" have any place? It is possible then to live with a wife and yet give heed unto prayer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:62
verses.text: But by continence prayer is made more perfect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:63
verses.text: For he did not say merely, "That ye may pray;" but, "That ye may give yourselves unto it;" as though what he speaks of might cause not uncleanness but much occupation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:64
verses.text: "And may be together again, that Satan tempt you not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:65
verses.text: Thus lest it should seem to be a matter of express enactment, he adds the reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:66
verses.text: And what is it? "That Satan tempt you not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:67
verses.text: And that you may understand that it is not the devil only who causeth this crime, I mean adultery, he adds, "because of your incontinency".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:68
verses.text: "But this I say by way of permission, not of commandment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:69
verses.text: For I would that all men were even as I myself; in a state of continence".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:70
verses.text: This he doth in many places when he is advising about difficult matters; he brings forward himself, and says, "Be ye imitators of me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:71
verses.text: "Howbeit each man hath his own gift from God, one after this manner, and another after that".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:72
verses.text: Thus since he had heavily charged them saying, "for your incontinence," he again comforteth them by the words, "each one hath his own gift of God;" not declaring that towards that virtue there is no need of zeal on our part, but, as I was saying before, to comfort them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:73
verses.text: For if it be a "gift," and man contributes nothing thereunto, how sayest thou, "But (v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:74
verses.text: ) I say to the unmarried and to widows, it is good for them if they abide even as I: (v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:75
verses.text: ) but if they have not continency let them marry?" Do you see the strong sense of Paul how he both signifies that continence is better, and yet puts no force on the person who cannot attain to it; fearing lest some offence arise?  "For it is better to marry than to burn".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:76
verses.text: He indicates how great is the tyranny of concupiscence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:77
verses.text: What he means is something like this: "If you have to endure much violence and burning desire, withdraw yourself from your pains and toils, lest haply you be subverted".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:78
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:79
verses.text: "But to the married I give charge, yet not I, but the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:80
verses.text: Because it is a law expressly appointed by Christ which he is about to read to them about the "not putting away a wife without fornication; "(S.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:81
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:82
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:83
verses.text: , xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:85
verses.text: Mark x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:87
verses.text: Luke xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:88
verses.text: ) therefore he says, "Not I".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:89
verses.text: True it is what was before spoken though it were not expressly stated, yet it also is His decree.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:90
verses.text: But this, you see, He had delivered in express words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:91
verses.text: So that the words "I and not I" have this difference of meaning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:92
verses.text: For that you might not imagine even his own words to be human, therefore he added, "For I think that I also have the Spirit of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:93
verses.text: Now what is that which "to the married the Lord commanded? That the wife depart not from her husband: (v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:94
verses.text: ) but if she depart, let her remain unmarried, or be reconciled unto her husband".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:95
verses.text: Here, seeing that both on the score of continence and other pretexts, and because of infirmities of temper, (μικροψυχίας.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:96
verses.text: ) it fell out that separations took place: it were better, he says, that such things should not be at all; but however if they take place, let the wife remain with her husband, if not to cohabit with him, yet so as not to introduce any other to be her husband.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:97
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:98
verses.text: "But to the rest speak I, not the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:99
verses.text: If any brother have a wife that believeth not, and she is content to dwell with him, let him not leave her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:100
verses.text: And if any woman hath an husband that believeth not, and he is content to dwell with her, let her not leave him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:101
verses.text: For as when discoursing about separating from fornicators, he made the matter easy by the correction which he applied to his words, saying, "Howbeit, not altogether with the fornicators of this world;" so also in this case he provideth for the abundant easiness of the duty, saying, "If any wife have a husband, or husband a wife, that believeth not, let him not leave her".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:102
verses.text: What sayest thou? "If he be an unbeliever, let him remain with the wife, but not if he be a fornicator? And yet fornication is a less sin than unbelief".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:103
verses.text: I grant, fornication is a less sin: but God spares thine infirmities extremely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:104
verses.text: And this is what He doth about the sacrifice, saying, (S.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:105
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:106
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:107
verses.text: ) "Leave the sacrifice, and be reconciled to thy brother".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:108
verses.text: This also in the case of the man who owed ten thousand talents.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:109
verses.text: For him too He did not punish for owing him ten thousand talents, but for demanding back a hundred pence from his fellow-servant He took vengeance on him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:110
verses.text: Then lest the woman might fear, as though she became unclean because of intercourse with her husband, he says, "For the unbelieving husband is sanctified in the wife, and the unbelieving wife is sanctified in the husband".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:111
verses.text: And yet, if "he that is joined to an harlot is one body," it is quite clear that the woman also who is joined to an idolater is one body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:112
verses.text: Well: it is one body; nevertheless she becomes not unclean, but the cleanness of the wife overcomes the uncleanness of the husband; and again, the cleanness of the believing husband overcomes the uncleanness of the unbelieving wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:113
verses.text: How then in this case is the uncleanness overcome, and therefore the intercourse allowed; while in the woman who prostitutes herself, the husband is not condemned in casting her out? Because here there is hope that the lost member may be saved through the marriage; but in the other case the marriage has already been dissolved; and there again both are corrupted; but here the fault is in one only of the two.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:114
verses.text: I mean something like this: she that has been guilty of fornication is utterly abominable: if then "he that is joined to an harlot is one body," he also becomes abominable by having connection with an harlot; wherefore all the purity flits away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:115
verses.text: But in the case before us it is not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:116
verses.text: But how? The idolater is unclean but the woman is not unclean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:117
verses.text: For if indeed she were a partner with him in that wherein he is unclean, I mean his impiety, she herself would also become unclean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:118
verses.text: But now the idolater is unclean in one way, and the wife holds communion with him in another wherein he is not unclean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:119
verses.text: For marriage and mixture of bodies is that wherein the communion consists.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:120
verses.text: Again, there is a hope that this man may be reclaimed by his wife for she is made completely his own: but for the other it is not very easy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:121
verses.text: For how will she who dishonored him in former times and became another's and destroyed the rights of marriage, have power to reclaim him whom she had wronged; him, moreover, who still remains to her as an alien?  Again in that case, after the fornication the husband is not a husband: but here, although the wife be an idolatress, the husband's rights are not destroyed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:122
verses.text: However, he doth not simply recommend cohabitation with the unbeliever, but with the qualification that he wills it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:123
verses.text: Wherefore he said, "And he himself be content to dwell with her".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:124
verses.text: For, tell me, what harm is there when the duties of piety remain unimpaired and there are good hopes about the unbeliever, that those already joined should so abide and not bring in occasions of unnecessary warfare? For the question now is not about those who have never yet come together, but about those who are already joined.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:125
verses.text: He did not say, If any one wish to take an unbelieving wife, but, "If any one hath an unbelieving wife".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:126
verses.text: Which means, If any after marrying or being married have received the word of godliness, and then the other party which had continued in unbelief still yearn for them to dwell together, let not the marriage be broken off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:127
verses.text: "For," saith he, "the unbelieving husband is sanctified in the wife".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:128
verses.text: So great is the superabundance of thy purity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:129
verses.text: What then, is the Greek holy? Certainly not: for he said not, He is holy; but, "He is sanctified in his wife".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:130
verses.text: And this he said, not to signify that he is holy, but to deliver the woman as completely as possible from her fear and lead the man to desire the truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:131
verses.text: For the uncleanness is not in the bodies wherein there is communion, but in the mind and the thoughts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:132
verses.text: And here follows the proof; namely, that if thou continuing unclean have offspring, the child, not being of thee alone, is of course unclean or half clean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:133
verses.text: But now it is not unclean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:134
verses.text: To which effect he adds, "else were your children unclean; but now are they holy;" that is, not unclean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:135
verses.text: But the Apostle calls them, "holy," by the intensity of the expression again casting out the dread arising from that sort of suspicion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:136
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:137
verses.text: "Yet if the unbelieving departeth, let him depart," for in this case the matter is no longer fornication.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:138
verses.text: But what is the meaning of, "if the unbelieving departeth?" For instance, if he bid thee sacrifice and take part in his ungodliness on account of thy marriage, or else part company; it were better the marriage were annulled, and no breach made in godliness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:139
verses.text: Wherefore he adds, "A brother is not under bondage, nor yet a sister, in such cases".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:140
verses.text: If day by day he buffet thee and keep up combats on this account, it is better to separate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:141
verses.text: For this is what he glances at, saying, "But God hath called us in peace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:142
verses.text: For it is the other party who furnished the ground of separation, even as he did who committed uncleanness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:143
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:144
verses.text: "For how knowest thou, O wife, whether thou shalt save thine husband?" This again refers to that expression, "let her not leave him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:145
verses.text: That is, "if he makes no disturbance, remain," saith he, "for there is even profit in this; remain and advise and give counsel and persuade".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:146
verses.text: For no teacher will have such power to prevail (Reg.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:147
verses.text: πεῖσαι.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:148
verses.text: Bened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:149
verses.text: ἰσχὺσαι.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:150
verses.text: ) as a wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:151
verses.text: And neither, on one hand, doth he lay any necessity upon her and absolutely demand the point of her, that he may not again do what would be too painful; nor, on the other, doth he tell her to despair: but he leaves the matter in suspense through the uncertainty of the future, saying, "For how knowest thou, O wife, whether thou shalt save thy husband? or how knowest thou, O husband whether thou shalt save thy wife?"   And again, ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:152
verses.text: "Only as God hath distributed to each man, as the Lord hath called each, so let him walk.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:153
verses.text: Was any one called being circumcised? let him not become uncircumcised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:154
verses.text: Was any called in uncircumcision? let him not be circumcised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:155
verses.text: Circumcision is nothing, and uncircumcision is nothing; but the keeping of the commandments of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:156
verses.text: Let each man abide in that calling wherein he was called.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:157
verses.text: Wast thou called, being a slave? Care not for it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:158
verses.text: These things contribute nothing unto faith, saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:159
verses.text: Be not then contentious neither be troubled; for the faith hath cast out all these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:160
verses.text: "Let each man abide in that calling wherein he was called.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:161
verses.text: Hast thou been called, having an unbelieving wife? Continue to have her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:162
verses.text: Cast not out thy wife for the faith's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:163
verses.text: Hast thou been called, being a slave? Care not for it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:164
verses.text: Continue to be a slave.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:165
verses.text: Hast thou been called, being in uncircumcision? Remain uncircumcised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:166
verses.text: Being circumcised, didst thou become a believer? Continue circumcised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:167
verses.text: For this is the meaning of, "As God hath distributed unto each man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:168
verses.text: For these are no hindrances to piety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:169
verses.text: Thou art called, being a slave; another, with an unbelieving wife; another, being circumcised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:170
verses.text: Astonishing! where has he put slavery? As circumcision profits not: and uncircumcision does no harm; so neither doth slavery, nor yet liberty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:171
verses.text: And that he might point out this with surpassing clearness, he says, "But even (Αλλ' εὶ καὶ δυνάσαι) if thou canst become free, use it rather:" that is, rather continue a slave.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:172
verses.text: Now upon what possible ground does he tell the person who might be set free to remain a slave? He means to point out that slavery is no harm but rather an advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:173
verses.text: Now we are not ignorant that some say, the words, "use it rather," are spoken with regard to liberty: interpreting it, "if thou canst become free, become free".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:174
verses.text: But the expression would be very contrary to Paul's manner if he intended this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:175
verses.text: For he would not, when consoling the slave and signifying that he was in no respect injured, have told him to get free.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:176
verses.text: Since perhaps some one might say, "What then, if I am not able? I am an injured and degraded person".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:177
verses.text: This then is not what he says: but as I said, meaning to point out that a man gets nothing by being made free, he says, "Though thou hast it in thy power to be made free, remain rather in slavery".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:178
verses.text: Next he adds also the cause; "For he that was called in the Lord being a bondservant, is the Lord's free man: likewise he that was called, being free, is Christ's bondservant".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:179
verses.text: "For," saith he, "in the things that relate to Christ, both are equal: and like as thou art the slave of Christ, so also is thy master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:180
verses.text: How then is the slave a free man? Because He has freed thee not only from sin, but also from outward slavery while continuing a slave.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:181
verses.text: For he suffers not the slave to be a slave, not even though he be a man abiding in slavery: and this is the great wonder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:182
verses.text: But how is the slave a free man while continuing a slave? When he is freed from passions and the diseases of the mind: when he looks down upon riches and wrath and all other the like passions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:183
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:184
verses.text: "Ye were bought with a price: become not bondservants of men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:185
verses.text: This saying is addressed not to slaves only but also to free men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:186
verses.text: For it is possible for one who is a slave not to be a slave; and for one who is a freeman to be a slave.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:187
verses.text: "And how can one be a slave and not a slave?" When he doeth all for God: when he feigns nothing, and doeth nothing out of eye-service towards men: that is how one that is a slave to men can be free.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:188
verses.text: Or again, how doth one that is free become a slave? When he serves men in any evil service, either for gluttony or desire of wealth or for office' sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:189
verses.text: For such an one, though he be free, is more of a slave than any man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:190
verses.text: And consider both these points.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:191
verses.text: Joseph was a slave but not a slave to men: wherefore even in slavery he was freer than all that are free.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:192
verses.text: For instance, he yielded not to his mistress; yielded not to the purposes which she who possessed him desired.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:193
verses.text: Again she was free; yet none ever so like a slave, courting and beseeching her own servant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:194
verses.text: But she prevailed not on him, who was free, to do what he would not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:195
verses.text: This then was not slavery; but it was liberty of the most exalted kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:196
verses.text: For what impediment to virtue had he from his slavery? Let men hear, both slaves and free.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:197
verses.text: Which was the slave? He that was entreated or she that did entreat? She that besought or he that despised her supplication?  In fact, there are limits set to slaves by God Himself; and up to what point one ought to keep them, has also been determined, and to transgress them is wrong.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:198
verses.text: Namely, when your master commands nothing which is unpleasing to God, it is right to follow and to obey; but no farther.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:199
verses.text: For thus the slave becomes free.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:200
verses.text: But if you go further, even though you are free you are become a slave.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:201
verses.text: At least he intimates this, saying, "Be not ye the servants of men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:202
verses.text: But if this be not the meaning, if he bade them forsake their masters and strive contentiously to become free, in what sense did he exhort them, saying, "Let each one remain in the calling in which he is called?" And in another place, ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:203
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:205
verses.text: ) "As many servants as are under the yoke, let them count their own masters worthy of all honor; and those that have believing masters, let them not despise them, because they are brethren who partake of the benefit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:206
verses.text: And writing to the Ephesians also and to the Colossians, he ordains and exacts the same rules.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:207
verses.text: Whence it is plain that it is not this slavery which he annuls, but that which caused as it is by vice befalls free men also: and this is the worst kind of slavery, though he be a free man who is in bondage to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:208
verses.text: For what profit had Joseph's brethren of their freedom? Were they not more servile than all slaves; both speaking lies to their father, and to the merchants using false pretences, as well as to their brother? But not such was the free man: rather every where and in all things he was true.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:209
verses.text: And nothing had power to enslave him, neither chain nor bondage nor the love of his mistress nor his being in a strange land.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:210
verses.text: But he abode free every where.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:211
verses.text: For this is liberty in the truest sense when even in bondage it shines through.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:212
verses.text: Such a thing is Christianity; in slavery it bestows freedom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:213
verses.text: And as that which is by nature an invulnerable body then shews itself to be invulnerable when having received a dart it suffers no harm; so also he that is strictly free then shows himself, when even under masters he is not enslaved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:214
verses.text: For this cause his bidding is, "remain a slave".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:215
verses.text: But if it is impossible for one who is a slave to be a Christian such as he ought to be, the Greeks will condemn true religion of great weakness: whereas if they can be taught that slavery in no way impairs godliness, they will admire our doctrine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:216
verses.text: For if death hurt us not, nor scourges, nor chains, much less slavery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:217
verses.text: Fire and iron and tyrannies innumerable and diseases and poverty and wild beasts and countless things more dreadful than these, have not been able to injure the faithful; nay, they have made them even mightier.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:218
verses.text: And how shall slavery be able to hurt? It is not slavery itself, beloved, that hurts; but the real slavery is that of sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:219
verses.text: And if thou be not a slave in this sense, be bold and rejoice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:220
verses.text: No one shall have power to do thee any wrong, having the temper which cannot be enslaved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:221
verses.text: But if thou be a slave to sin, even though thou be ten thousand times free thou hast no good of thy freedom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:222
verses.text: For, tell me, what profit is it when, though not in bondage to a man, thou liest down in subjection to thy passions? Since men indeed often know how to spare; but those masters are never satiated with thy destruction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:223
verses.text: Art thou in bondage to a man? Why, thy master also is slave to thee, in arranging about thy food, in taking care of thy health and in looking after thy shoes and all the other things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:224
verses.text: And thou dost not fear so much less thou shouldest offend thy master, as he fears lest any of those necessaries should fail thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:225
verses.text: "But he sits down, while thou standest".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:226
verses.text: And what of that? Since this may be said of thee as well as of him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:227
verses.text: Often, at least, when thou art lying down and sleeping sweetly, he is not only standing, but undergoing endless discomforts in the market-place; and he lies awake more painfully than thou.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:228
verses.text: For instance; what did Joseph suffer from his mistress to be compared with what she suffered from her evil desire? For he indeed did not the things which she wished to put upon him; but she performed every thing which her mistress ordered her, I mean her spirit of unchastity: which left not off until it had put her to open shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:229
verses.text: What master commands such things? what savage tyrant? "Intreat thy slave," that is the word: "flatter the person bought with thy money, supplicate the captive; even if he reject thee with disgust, again besiege him: even if thou speakest to him oftentimes, and he consent not, watch for his being alone, and force him, and become an object of derision".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:230
verses.text: What can be more dishonorable, what more shameful, than these words? "And if even by these means you make no progress, why, accuse him falsely and deceive your husband".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:231
verses.text: Mark how mean, how shameful are the commands, how unmerciful and savage and frantic.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:232
verses.text: What command does the master ever lay on his slave, such as those which her wantonness then laid upon that royal woman? And yet she dare not disobey.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:233
verses.text: But Joseph underwent nothing of this sort, but every thing on the contrary which brought glory and honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:234
verses.text: Would you like to see yet another man under severe orders from a hard mistress, and without spirit to disobey any of them? Consider Cain, what commands were laid on him by his envy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:235
verses.text: She ordered him to slay his brother, to lie unto God, to grieve his father, to cast off shame; and he did it all, and in nothing refused to obey.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:236
verses.text: And why marvel that over a single person so great should be the power of this mistress? She hath often destroyed entire nations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:237
verses.text: For instance, the Midianitish women took the Jews, and all but bound them in captivity; their own beauty kindling desire, was the means of their vanquishing that whole nation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:238
verses.text: Paul then to cast out this sort of slavery, said, "Become not servants of men;" that is, "Obey not men commanding unreasonable things: nay, obey not yourselves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:239
verses.text: Then having raised up their mind and made it mount on high, he says,   Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:240
verses.text: "Now concerning virgins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:241
verses.text: I have no commandment of the Lord; but I give my judgment, as one that hath obtained mercy of the Lord to be faithful".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:242
verses.text: Advancing on his way in regular order, he proceeds next to speak concerning virginity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:243
verses.text: For after that he had exercised and trained them, in his words concerning continence, he goes forth towards what is greater, saying, "I have no commandment, but I esteem it to be good".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:244
verses.text: For what reason? For the self-same reason as he had mentioned respecting continence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:245
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:246
verses.text: "Art thou bound unto a wife? Seek not to be loosed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:247
verses.text: Art thou loosed from a wife? Seek not a wife".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:248
verses.text: These words carry no contradiction to what had been said before but rather the most entire agreement with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:249
verses.text: For he says in that place also, "Except it be by consent:" as here he says, "Art thou bound unto a wife? Seek not separation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:250
verses.text: This is no contradiction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:251
verses.text: For its being against consent makes a dissolution: but if with consent both live continently, it is no dissolution.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:252
verses.text: Then, lest this should seem to be laying down a law, he subjoins, (v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:253
verses.text: ) "but if thou marry, thou hast not sinned".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:254
verses.text: He next alleges the existing state of things, "the present distress, the shortness of the time," and "the affliction".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:255
verses.text: For marriage draws along with it many things, which indeed he hath glanced at, as well here as also in the discourse about continence: there, by saying, "the wife hath not power over herself;" and here, by the expression, "Thou art bound".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:256
verses.text: "But if and thou marry, thou hast not sinned".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:257
verses.text: He is not speaking about her who hath made choice of virginity, for if it comes to that, she hath sinned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:258
verses.text: Since if the widows are condemned for having to do with second marriages after they have once chosen widowhood, much more the virgins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:259
verses.text: "But such shall have trouble in the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:260
verses.text: "And pleasure too," you will say: but observe how he curtails this by the shortness of the time, saying, (v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:261
verses.text: ) "the time is shortened;" that is, "we are exhorted to depart now and go forth, but thou art running further in".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:262
verses.text: And yet even although marriage had no troubles, even so we ought to press on towards things to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:263
verses.text: But when it hath affliction too, what need to draw on one's self an additional burden.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:264
verses.text: What occasion to take up such a load, when even after taking it you must use it as having it not? For "those even that have wives must be," he saith, "as though they had none".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:265
verses.text: Then, having interposed something about the future, he brings back his speech to the present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:266
verses.text: For some of his topics are spiritual; as that, "the one careth about the things which be her husband's, the other about those which be God's".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:267
verses.text: Others relate to this present life; as, "I would have you to be free from cares".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:268
verses.text: But still with all this he leaves it to their own choice: inasmuch as he who after proving what is best goes back to compulsion, seems as if he did not trust his own statements.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:269
verses.text: Wherefore he rather attracts them by concession, and checks them as follows:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:270
verses.text: "And this I say for your own profit, not that I may cast a snare upon you, but for that which is seemly, and that ye may attend upon the Lord without distraction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:271
verses.text: Let the virgins hear that not by that one point is virginity defined; for she that is careful about the things of the world cannot be a virgin, nor seemly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:272
verses.text: Thus, when he said, "There is difference between a wife and a virgin," he added this as the difference, and that wherein they are distinguished from each other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:273
verses.text: And laying down the definition of a virgin and her that is not a virgin, he names, not marriage nor continence but leisure from engagements and multiplicity of engagements.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:274
verses.text: For the evil is not in the cohabitation, but in the impediment to the strictness of life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:275
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:276
verses.text: "But if any man think that he behaveth himself unseemly toward his virgin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:277
verses.text: Here he seems to be talking about marriage; but all that he says relates to virginity; for he allows even a second marriage, saying, "only in the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:278
verses.text: Now what means, "in the Lord?" With chastity, with honor: for this is needed every where, and must be pursued for else we cannot see God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:279
verses.text: Now if we have passed lightly by what he says of virginity, let no one accuse us of negligence; for indeed an entire book hath been composed by us upon this topic and as we have there with all the accuracy which we could, gone through every branch of the subject, we considered it a waste of words to introduce it again here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:280
verses.text: Wherefore, referring the hearer to that work as concerns these things, we will say this one thing here: We must follow after continence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:281
verses.text: For, saith he, "follow after peace, and the sanctification without which no one shall see the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 18:282
