verses.text: Therefore that we may be accounted worthy to see Him, whether we be in virginity or in the first marriage or the second, let us follow after this that we may obtain the kingdom of heaven, through the grace and loving-kindness of our Lord Jesus Christ; to Whom with the Father and the Holy Spirit, be glory, power, honor, now, henceforth, and for everlasting ages, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:1
verses.text: Homily XX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:3
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:4
verses.text: Now concerning things sacrificed to idols: we know that we all have knowledge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:5
verses.text: Knowledge puffeth up, but love edifieth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:6
verses.text: It is necessary first to say what the meaning of this passage is: for so shall we readily comprehend the Apostle's discourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:7
verses.text: For he that sees a charge brought against any one, except he first perceive the nature of the offence will not understand what is said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:8
verses.text: What then is it of which he was then accusing the Corinthians? A heavy charge and the cause of many evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:9
verses.text: Well, what is it? Many among them, having learnt that (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:10
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:11
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:12
verses.text: ) "not the things which enter in defile the man, but the things which proceed out," and that idols of wood and stone, and demons, have no power to hurt or help, had made an immoderate use of their perfect knowledge of this to the harm both of others and of themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:13
verses.text: They had both gone in where idols were and had partaken of the tables there, and were producing thereby great and ruinous evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:14
verses.text: For, on the one hand, those who still retained the fear of idols and knew not how to contemn them, took part in those meals, because they saw the more perfect sort doing this; and hence they got the greatest injury: since they did not touch what was set before them with the same mind as the others, but as things offered in sacrifice to idols; and the thing was becoming a way to idolatry.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:15
verses.text: On the other hand, these very persons who pretended to be more perfect were injured in no common way, partaking in the tables of demons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:16
verses.text: This then was the subject of complaint.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:17
verses.text: Now this blessed man being about to correct it, did not immediately begin to speak vehemently; for that which was done came more of folly than of wickedness: wherefore in the first instance there was need rather of exhortation than of severe rebuke and wrath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:18
verses.text: Now herein observe his good sense, how he immediately begins to admonish.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:19
verses.text: "Now concerning things sacrificed to idols, we know that we all have knowledge".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:20
verses.text: Leaving alone the weak, which he always doth, he discourses with the strong first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:21
verses.text: And this is what he did also in the Epistle to the Romans, saying, (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:22
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:23
verses.text: ) "But thou, why dost thou judge thy brother?" for this is the sort of person that is able to receive rebuke also with readiness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:24
verses.text: Exactly the same then he doth here also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:25
verses.text: And first he makes void their conceit by declaring that this very thing which they considered as peculiar to themselves, the having perfect knowledge, was common to all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:26
verses.text: Thus, "we know," saith he, "that we all have knowledge".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:27
verses.text: For if allowing them to have high thoughts, he had first pointed out how hurtful the thing was to others, he would not have done them so much good as harm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:28
verses.text: For the ambitious soul when it plumes itself upon any thing, even though the same do harm to others, yet strongly adheres to it because of the tyranny of vain-glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:29
verses.text: Wherefore Paul first examines the matter itself by itself: just as he had done before in the case of the wisdom from without, demolishing it with a high hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:30
verses.text: But in that case he did it as we might have expected: for the whole thing was altogether blameworthy and his task was very easy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:31
verses.text: Wherefore he signifies it to be not only useless, but even contrary to the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:32
verses.text: But in the present case it was not possible to do this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:33
verses.text: For what was done was of knowledge, and perfect knowledge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:34
verses.text: Nor was it safe to overthrow it, and yet in no other way was it possible to cast out the conceit which had resulted from it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:35
verses.text: What then doeth he? First, by signifying that it was common, he curbs that swelling pride of theirs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:36
verses.text: For they who possess something great and excellent are more elated, when they alone have it; but if it be made out that they possess it in common with others, they no longer have so much of this feeling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:37
verses.text: First then he makes it common property, because they considered it to belong to themselves alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:38
verses.text: Next, having made it common, he does not make himself singly a sharer in it with them; for in this way too he would have rather set them up; for as to be the only possessor elates, so to have one partner or two perhaps among leading persons has this effect just as much.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:39
verses.text: For this reason he does not mention himself but all: he said not, "I too have knowledge," but, "we know that we all have knowledge".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:40
verses.text: This then is one way, and the first, by which he cast down their pride; the next hath greater force.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:41
verses.text: What then is this? In that he shews that not even this thing itself was in all points complete, but imperfect, and extremely so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:42
verses.text: And not only imperfect, but also injurious, unless there were another thing joined together with it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:43
verses.text: For having said that "we have knowledge," he added, "Knowledge puffeth up, but love edifieth:" so that when it is without love, it lifts men up to absolute arrogance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:44
verses.text: "And yet not even love," you will say, "without knowledge hath any advantage".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:45
verses.text: Well: this he did not say; but omitting it as a thing allowed by all, he signifies that knowledge stands in extreme need of love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:46
verses.text: For he who loves, inasmuch as he fulfils the commandment which is most absolute of all, even though he have some defects, will quickly be blest with knowledge because of his love; as Cornelius and many others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:47
verses.text: But he that hath knowledge but hath not love, not only shall gain nothing more, but shall also be cast out of that which he hath, in many cases falling into arrogance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:48
verses.text: It seems then that knowledge is not productive of love, but on the contrary debars from it him that is not on his guard, puffing him up and elating him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:49
verses.text: For arrogance is wont to cause divisions: but love both draws together and leads to knowledge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:50
verses.text: And to make this plain he saith, "But if any man loveth God, the same is known of Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:51
verses.text: So that "I forbid not this," saith he, "namely, your having perfect knowledge; but your having it with love, that I enjoin; else is it no gain, but rather loss".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:52
verses.text: Do you see how he already sounds the first note of his discourse concerning love? For since all these evils were springing from the following root, i-e:, not from perfect knowledge, but from their not greatly loving nor sparing their neighbors; whence ensued both their variance and their self-satisfaction, and all the rest which he had charged them with; both before this and after he is continually providing for love; so correcting the fountain of all good things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:53
verses.text: "Now why," saith he, "are ye puffed up about knowledge? For if ye have not love, ye shall even be injured thereby.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:54
verses.text: For what is worse than boasting? But if the other be added, the first also will be in safety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:55
verses.text: For although you may know something more than your neighbor, if you love him you will not set yourself up but lead him also to the same".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:56
verses.text: Wherefore also having said, "Knowledge puffeth up," he added, "but love edifieth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:57
verses.text: He did not say, "Behaveth itself modestly," but what is much more, and more gainful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:58
verses.text: For their knowledge was not only puffing them up but also distracting them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:59
verses.text: On this account he opposes the one to the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:60
verses.text: And then he adds a third consideration, which was of force to set them down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:61
verses.text: What then is this? that although charity be joined with it, yet not even in that case is this our knowledge perfect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:62
verses.text: And therefore he adds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:63
verses.text: "But if any man think that he knoweth any thing, he knoweth nothing yet as he ought to know".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:64
verses.text: This is a mortal blow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:65
verses.text: "I dwell not," saith he, "on the knowledge being common to all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:66
verses.text: I say not that by hating your neighbor and by arrogance, you injure yourself most.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:67
verses.text: But even though you have it by yourself alone, though you be modest, though you love your brother, even in this case you are imperfect in regard of knowledge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:68
verses.text: "For as yet thou knowest nothing as thou oughtest to know," Now if we possess as yet exact knowledge of nothing, how is it that some have rushed on to such a pitch of frenzy as to say that they know God with all exactness? Whereas, though we had an exact knowledge of all other things, not even so were it possible to possess this knowledge to such an extent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:69
verses.text: For how far He is apart from all things, it is impossible even to say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:70
verses.text: And mark how he pulls down their swelling pride: for he said not, "of the matters before us ye have not the proper knowledge," but, "about every thing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:71
verses.text: And he did not say, "ye," but, "no one whatever," be it Peter, be it Paul, be it any one else.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:72
verses.text: For by this he both soothed them and carefully kept them under.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:73
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:74
verses.text: "But if any man love God, the same," he doth not say, "knoweth Him," but, "is known of Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:75
verses.text: For we have not known Him, but He hath known us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:76
verses.text: And therefore did Christ say, "Ye have not chosen Me, but I have chosen you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:77
verses.text: And Paul elsewhere, "Then shall I know fully, even as also I have been known".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:78
verses.text: Observe now, I pray, by what means he brings down their high-mindedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:79
verses.text: First, he points out that not they alone knew the things which they knew; for "we all," he saith," have knowledge".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:80
verses.text: Next, that the thing itself was hurtful so long as it was without love; for "knowledge," saith he, "puffeth up".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:81
verses.text: Thirdly, that even joined with love it is not complete nor perfect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:82
verses.text: "For if any man thinketh that he knoweth any thing, he knoweth nothing as yet as he ought to know," so he speaks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:83
verses.text: In addition to this, that they have not even this from themselves, but by gift from God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:84
verses.text: For he said not, "hath known God," but, "is known of Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:85
verses.text: Again, that this very thing comes of love which they have not as they ought.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:86
verses.text: For, "if any man," saith he, "love God, the same is known of Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:87
verses.text: Having then so much at large allayed their irritation, he begins to speak doctrinally, saying thus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:88
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:89
verses.text: "Concerning therefore the eating of things sacrificed to idols, we know that no idol is anything in the world, and that there is no God but one".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:90
verses.text: Look what a strait he hath fallen into! For indeed his mind is to prove both; that one ought to abstain from this kind of banquet, and that it hath no power to hurt those who partake of it: things which were not greatly in agreement with each other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:91
verses.text: For when they were told that they had no harm in them, they would naturally run to them as indifferent things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:92
verses.text: But when forbidden to touch them, they would suspect, on the contrary, that their having power to do hurt occasioned the prohibition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:93
verses.text: Wherefore, you see, he puts down their opinion about idols, and then states as a first reason for their abstaining the scandals which they place in the way of their brethren; in these words: "Now concerning the eating of things sacrificed to idols, we know that no idol is anything in the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:94
verses.text: Again he makes it common property and doth not allow this to be theirs alone, but extends the knowledge all over the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:95
verses.text: For "not among you alone," says he, "but every where on earth this doctrine prevails".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:96
verses.text: What then is it? "That no idol is anything in the world; that there is no God but one".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:97
verses.text: What then? are there no idols? no statues? Indeed there are; but they have no power: neither are they gods, but stones and demons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:98
verses.text: For he is now setting himself against both parties; both the grosser sort among them, and those who were accounted lovers of wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:99
verses.text: Thus, seeing that the former know of no more than the mere stones, the others assert that certain powers reside in them, which they also call gods; to the former accordingly he says, that "no idol is anything in the world," to the other, that "there is no God but one".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:100
verses.text: Do you mark how he writes these things, not simply as laying down doctrine, but in opposition to those without? A thing indeed which we must at all times narrowly observe, whether he says anything abstractedly, or whether he is opposing any persons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:101
verses.text: For this contributes in no ordinary way to the accuracy of our doctrinal views, and to the exact understanding of his expressions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:102
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:103
verses.text: "For though there be that are called gods, whether in heaven or on earth, as there are gods many and lords many; yet to us there is one God, the Father, of Whom are all things, and we unto Him; and one Lord Jesus Christ, through Whom are all things, and we through Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:104
verses.text: Since he had said, that "an idol is nothing" and that "there is no other God;" and yet there were idols and there were those that were called gods; that he might not seem to be contradicting plain facts, he goes on to say, "For though there be that are called gods, as indeed there are;" not absolutely, "there are;" but, "called," not in reality having this but in name: "be it in heaven or on earth:—in heaven," meaning the sun and the moon and the remainder of the choir of stars; for these too the Greeks worshipped: but upon the earth demons, and all those who had been made gods of men:—"yet to us there is One God, the Father".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:105
verses.text: In the first instance having expressed it without the word "Father," and said, "there is no God but one," he now adds this also, when he had utterly cast out the others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:106
verses.text: Next, he adduces what indeed is the greatest token of divinity; "of Whom are all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:107
verses.text: For this implies also that those others are not gods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:108
verses.text: For it is said (Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:109
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:110
verses.text: ), "Let the gods who made not the heaven and the earth perish".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:111
verses.text: Then he subjoins what is not less than this, "and we unto Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:112
verses.text: For when he saith, "of Whom are all things," he means the creation and the bringing of things out of nothing into existence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:113
verses.text: But when he saith, "and we unto Him," he speaks of the word of faith and mutual appropriation (οἰκειώσεως), as also he said before ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:114
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:115
verses.text: ), "but of Him are ye also in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:116
verses.text: In two ways we are of Him, by being made when we were not, and by being made believers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:117
verses.text: For this also is a creation: a thing which he also declares elsewhere; (Ephes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:118
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:119
verses.text: ) "that He might create in Himself of the twain one new man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:120
verses.text: "And there is one Lord, Jesus Christ, through Whom are all things, and we through Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:121
verses.text: And in regard to Christ again, we must conceive of this in like manner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:122
verses.text: For through Him the race of men was both produced out of nothing into existence, and returned from error to truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:123
verses.text: So that as to the phrase "of Whom," it is not to be understood apart from Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:124
verses.text: For of Him, through Christ, were we created.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:125
verses.text: Nor yet, if you observe, hath he distributed the names as if belonging exclusively, assigning to the Son the name Lord, and to the Father, God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:126
verses.text: For the Scripture useth also often to interchange them; as when it saith, (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:127
verses.text: cx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:128
verses.text: ) "The Lord saith unto My Lord;" and again, (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:129
verses.text: lxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:130
verses.text: ) "Wherefore God Thy God hath appointed Thee;" and, (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:131
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:132
verses.text: ) "Of Whom is Christ according to the flesh, Who is God over all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:133
verses.text: And in many instances you may see these names changing their places.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:134
verses.text: Besides, if they were allotted to each nature severally, and if the Son were not God, and God as the Father, yet continuing a Son: after saying, "but to us there is but One God," it would have been superfluous, his adding the word "Father," with a view to declare the Unbegotten.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:135
verses.text: For the word of God was sufficient to explain this, if it were such as to denote Him only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:136
verses.text: And this is not all, but there is another remark to make: that if you say, "Because it is said 'One God,' therefore the word God doth not apply to the Son;" observe that the same holds of the Son also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:137
verses.text: For the Son also is called "One Lord," yet we do not maintain that therefore the term Lord applies to Him alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:138
verses.text: So then, the same force which the expression "One" has, applied to the Son, it has also, applied to the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:139
verses.text: And as the Father is not thrust out from being the Lord, in the same sense as the Son is the Lord, because He, the Son, is spoken of as one Lord; so neither does it cast out the Son from being God, in the same sense as the Father is God, because the Father is styled One God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:140
verses.text: Now if any were to say, "Why did he make no mention of the Spirit?" our answer might be this: His argument was with idolaters, and the contention was about "gods many and lords many".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:141
verses.text: And this is why, having called the Father, God, he calls the Son, Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:142
verses.text: If now he ventured not to call the Father Lord together with the Son, lest they might suspect him to be speaking of two Lords; nor yet the Son, God, with the Father, lest he might be supposed to speak of two Gods: why marvel at his not having mentioned the Spirit? His contest was, so far, with the Gentiles: his point, to signify that with us there is no plurality of Gods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:143
verses.text: Wherefore he keeps hold continually of this word, "One;" saying, "There is no God but One; and, to us there is One God, and One Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:144
verses.text: From which it is plain, that to spare the weakness of the hearers he used this mode of explanation, and for this reason made no mention at all of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:145
verses.text: For if it be not this, neither ought he to make mention of the Spirit elsewhere, nor to join Him with the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:146
verses.text: For if He be rejected from the Father and Son, much more ought He not to be put in the same rank with them in the matter of Baptism; where most especially the dignity of the Godhead appears and gifts are bestowed which pertain to God alone to afford.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:147
verses.text: Thus then I have assigned the cause why in this place He is passed over in silence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:148
verses.text: Now do thou if this be not the true reason, tell me, why He is ranked with Them in Baptism? But thou canst not give any other reason but His being of equal honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:149
verses.text: At any rate, when he has no such constraint upon him, he puts Him in the same rank, saying thus: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:150
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:151
verses.text: ) "The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, and the love of God and the Father, and the fellowship of the Holy Ghost, be with you all:" and again, (ch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:152
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:153
verses.text: ) "There are diversities of gifts, but the same Spirit: and there are diversities of administrations, but the same Lord; and there are diversities of workings but the same God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:154
verses.text: But because now his speech was with Greeks and the weaker sort of the converts from among Greeks, for this reason he husbands it (ταμιεύεται) so far.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:155
verses.text: And this is what the prophets do in regard of the Son; no where making mention of Him plainly because of the infirmity of the hearers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:156
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:157
verses.text: "But not in all is knowledge," saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:158
verses.text: What knowledge doth he mean? about God, or about things offered in sacrifice to idols? For either he here glances at the Greeks who say that there are many gods and lords, and who know not Him that is truly God; or at the converts from among Greeks who were still rather infirm, such as did not yet know clearly that they ought not to fear idols and that "an idol is nothing in the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:159
verses.text: But in saying this, he gently soothes and encourages the latter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:160
verses.text: For there was no need of mentioning all he had to reprove, particularly as he intended to visit them again with more severity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:161
verses.text: "But some being used to the idol eat as of a thing sacrificed to an idol, and their conscience being weak is defiled".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:162
verses.text: They still tremble at idols, he saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:163
verses.text: For tell me not of the present establishment, and that you have received the true religion from your ancestors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:164
verses.text: But carry back your thoughts to those times, and consider when the Gospel was just set on foot, and impiety was still at its height, and altars burning, and sacrifices and libations offering up, and the greater part of men were Gentiles; think, I say, of those who from their ancestors had received impiety, and who were the descendants of fathers and grandfathers and great-grandfathers like themselves, and who had suffered great miseries from the demons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:165
verses.text: How must they have felt after their sudden change! How would they face and tremble at the assaults of the demons! For their sake also he employs some reserve, saying, "But some with conscience of the things sacrificed to an idol".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:166
verses.text: Thus he neither exposed them openly, not to strike them hard; nor doth he pass by them altogether: but makes mention of them in a vague manner, saying, "Now some with conscience of the idol even until now eat as of a thing sacrificed to an idol; that is, with the same thoughts as they did in former times: 'and their conscience being weak is defiled;'" not yet being able to despise and once for all laugh them to scorn, but still in some doubt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:167
verses.text: Just as if a man were to think that by touching a dead body he should pollute himself according to the Jewish custom, and then seeing others touching it with a clear conscience, but not with the same mind touching it himself, would be polluted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:168
verses.text: This was their state of feeling at that time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:169
verses.text: "For some," saith he, "with conscience of the idol do it even until now".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:170
verses.text: Not without cause did he add, "even until now;" but to signify that they gained no ground by their refusing to condescend.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:171
verses.text: For this was not the way to bring them in, but in some other way persuading them by word and by teaching.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:172
verses.text: "And their conscience being weak is defiled".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:173
verses.text: No where as yet doth he state his argument about the nature of the thing, but turns himself this way and that as concerning the conscience of the person partaking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:174
verses.text: For he was afraid lest in his wish to correct the weak person, he should inflict a heavy blow upon the strong one, and make him also weak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:175
verses.text: On which account he spares the one no less than the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:176
verses.text: Nor doth he allow the thing itself to be thought of any consequence, but makes his argument very full to prevent any suspicion of the kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:177
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:178
verses.text: "But meat doth not commend us to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:179
verses.text: For neither if we eat are we the better, nor if we eat not are we the worse".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:180
verses.text: Do you see how again he takes down their high spirit? in that, after saying that "not only they but all of us have knowledge," and that "no one knoweth any thing as he ought to know," and that "knowledge puffeth up;" then having soothed them, and said that "this knowledge is not in all," and that "weakness is the cause of these being defiled," in order that they might not say, "And what is it to us, if knowledge be not in all? Why then has not such an one knowledge? Why is he weak?"—I say, in order that they might not rejoin in these terms, he did not proceed immediately to point out clearly that for fear of the other's harm one ought to abstain: but having first made but a sort of skirmish upon mention of him, he points out what is more than this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:181
verses.text: What then is this? That although no one were injured nor any perversion of another ensued, not even in this case were it right so to do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:182
verses.text: For the former topic by itself is laboring in vain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:183
verses.text: Since he that hears of another being hurt while himself has the gain, is not very apt to abstain; but then rather he doth so, when he finds out that he himself is no way advantaged by the thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:184
verses.text: Wherefore he sets this down first, saying, "But meat commendeth us not to God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:185
verses.text: See how cheap he holds that which was accounted to spring from perfect knowledge! "For neither if we eat are we the better," (that is, stand higher in God's estimation, as if we had done any thing good or great:) "nor if we eat not are we the worse," that is, fall in any way short of others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:186
verses.text: So far then he hath signified that the thing itself is superfluous, and as nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:187
verses.text: For that which being done profits not, and which being left undone injures not, must be superfluous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:188
verses.text: But as he goes on, he discloses all the harm which was likely to arise from the matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:189
verses.text: For the present, however, that which befel the brethren is his subject.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:190
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:191
verses.text: "For take heed," saith he, "lest by any means this liberty of yours become a stumbling-block to the weak among the brethren".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:192
verses.text: (τῶν ἀδελφῶν not in rec.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:193
verses.text: text.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:194
verses.text: )  He did not say, "Your liberty is become a stumbling-block," nor did he positively affirm it that he might not make them more shameless; but how? "Take heed;" frightening them, and making them ashamed, and leading them to disavow any such conduct.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:195
verses.text: And he said not, "This your knowledge," which would have sounded more like praise; nor "this your perfectness;" but, "your liberty;" a thing which seemed to savor more of rashness and obstinacy and arrogance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:196
verses.text: Neither said he, "To the brethren," but, "To those of the brethren who are weak;" enhancing his accusation from their not even sparing the weak, and those too their brethren.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:197
verses.text: For let it be so that you correct them not, nor arouse them: yet why trip them up, and make them to stumble, when you ought to stretch out the hand? but for that you have no mind: well then, at least avoid casting them down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:198
verses.text: Since if one were wicked, he required punishment; if weak, healing: but now he is not only weak, but also a brother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:199
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:200
verses.text: "For if a man see thee who hast knowledge, sitting at meat in an idol's temple, will not his conscience if he is weak, be emboldened to eat things sacrificed to idols?"  After having said, "Take heed lest this your liberty become a stumbling-block," he explains how and in what manner it becomes so: and he continually employs the term "weakness," that the mischief may not be thought to arise from the nature of the thing, nor demons appear formidable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:201
verses.text: As thus: "At present," saith he, "a man is on the point of withdrawing himself entirely from all idols; but when he sees you fond of loitering about them, he takes the circumstance for a recommendation and abides there himself also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:202
verses.text: So that not only his weakness, but also your ill-timed behavior, helps to further the plot against him; for it is you who make him weaker".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:203
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:204
verses.text: "And through thy meat he that is weak perisheth, the brother for whose sake Christ died".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:205
verses.text: For there are two things which deprive you of excuse in this mischief; one, that he is weak, the other, that he is thy brother: rather, I should say, there is a third also, and one more terrible than all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:206
verses.text: What then is this? That whereas Christ refused not even to die for him, thou canst not bear even to accommodate thyself to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:207
verses.text: By these means, you see, he reminds the perfect man also, what he too was before, and that for him He died.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:208
verses.text: And he said not, "For whom even to die was thy duty;" but what is much stronger, that even Christ died for his sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:209
verses.text: "Did thy Lord then not refuse to die for him, and dost thou so make him of none account as not even to abstain from a polluted table for his sake? Yea, dost thou permit him to perish, after the salvation so wrought, and, what is still more grievous, 'for a morsel of meat?' "For he said not, "for thy perfectness," nor "for thy knowledge," but "for thy meat".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:210
verses.text: So that the charges are four, and these extremely heavy: that it was a brother, that he was weak, and one of whom Christ made so much account as even to die for him, and that after all this for a "morsel of meat" he is destroyed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:211
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:212
verses.text: "And thus sinning against the brethren, and wounding their weak conscience, ye sin against Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:213
verses.text: Do you observe how quietly and gradually he hath brought their offence up to the very summit of iniquity? And again, he makes mention of the infirmity of the other sort: and so, the very thing which these considered to make for them, that he every where turns round upon their own head.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:214
verses.text: And he said not, "Putting stumbling-blocks in their way," but, "wounding;" so as by the force of his expression to indicate their cruelty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:215
verses.text: For what can be more savage than a man who wounds the sick? and yet no wound is so grievous as making a man to stumble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:216
verses.text: Often, in fact, is this also the cause of death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:217
verses.text: But how do they "sin against Christ?" In one way, because He considers the concerns of His servants as His own; in another, because those who are wounded go to make up His Body and that which is part of Him: in a third way, because that work of His which He built up by His own blood, these are destroying for their ambition's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:218
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:219
verses.text: "Wherefore, if meat make my brother to stumble, I will eat no flesh for ever".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:220
verses.text: This is like the best of teachers, to teach in his own person the things which he speaks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:221
verses.text: Nor did he say whether justly or unjustly; but in any case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:222
verses.text: "I say not," (such is his tone,) "meat offered in sacrifice to an idol, which is already prohibited for another reason; but if any even of those things which are within license and are permitted causes stumbling, from these also will I abstain: and not one or two days, but all the time of my life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:223
verses.text: For he saith, "I will eat no flesh for ever".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:224
verses.text: And he said not, "Lest I destroy my brother," but simply, "That I make not my brother to stumble".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:225
verses.text: For indeed it comes of folly in the extreme that what things are greatly cared for by Christ, and such as He should have even chosen to die for them, these we should esteem so entirely beneath our notice as not even to abstain from meats on their account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:226
verses.text: Now these things might be seasonably spoken not to them only, but also to us, apt as we are to esteem lightly the salvation of our neighbors and to utter those satanical words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:227
verses.text: I say, satanical: for the expression, "What care I, though such an one stumble, and such another perish?" savors of his cruelty and inhuman mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:228
verses.text: And yet in that instance, the infirmity also of those who were offended had some share in the result: but in our case it is not so, sinning as we do in such a way as to offend even the strong.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:229
verses.text: For when we smite, and raven, and overreach, and use the free as if they were slaves, whom is not this enough to offend? Tell me not of such a man's being a shoemaker, another a dyer, another a brazier: but bear in mind that he is a believer and a brother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:230
verses.text: Why these are they whose disciples we are; the fishermen, the publicans, the tent-makers, of Him who was brought up in the house of a carpenter; and who deigned to have the carpenter's betrothed wife for a mother; and who was laid, after His swaddling clothes, in a manger; and who had not where to lay His head;—of Him whose journeys were so long that His very journeying was enough to tire Him down; of Him who was supported by others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:231
verses.text: Think on these things, and esteem the pride of man to be nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:232
verses.text: But count the tent-maker as well as thy brother, as him that is borne upon a chariot and hath innumerable servants and struts in the market-place: nay, rather the former than the latter; since the term brother would more naturally be used where there is the greater resemblance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:233
verses.text: Which then resembles the fisherman? He who is supported by daily labor and hath neither servant nor dwelling, but is quite beset with privations; or that other who is surrounded with such vast pomp, and who acts contrary to the laws of God? Despise not then him that is more of the two thy brother, for he comes nearer to the Apostolic pattern.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:234
verses.text: "Not however," say you, "of his own accord, but by compulsion; for he doeth not this of his own mind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:235
verses.text: How comes this? Hast thou not heard, "Judge not, that ye be not judged?" But, to convince thyself that he doeth it not against his inclination, approach and give him ten thousand talents of gold, and thou shalt see him putting it away from him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:236
verses.text: And thus, even though he have received no wealth by inheritance from his ancestors, yet when it is in his power to take it, and he lets it not come near him neither adds to his goods, he exhibits a mighty proof of his contempt of wealth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:237
verses.text: For so John was the son of Zebedee that extremely poor man: yet I suppose we are not therefore to say that his poverty was forced upon him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:238
verses.text: Whensoever then thou seest one driving nails, smiting with a hammer, covered with soot, do not therefore hold him cheap, but rather for that reason admire him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:239
verses.text: Since even Peter girded himself, and handled the dragnet, and went a fishing after the Resurrection of the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:240
verses.text: And why say I Peter? For this same Paul himself, after his incessant runnings to and fro and all those vast miracles, standing in a tent-maker's shop, sewed hides together: while angels were reverencing him and demons trembling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:241
verses.text: And he was not ashamed to say, (Acts xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:242
verses.text: ) "Unto my necessities, and to those who were with me, these hands ministered".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:243
verses.text: What say I, that he was not ashamed? Yea, he gloried in this very thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:244
verses.text: But you will say, "Who is there now to be compared with the virtue of Paul?" I too am aware that there is no one, yet not on this account are those who live now to be despised: for if for Christ's sake thou give honor, though one be last of all, yet if he be a believer he shall justly be honored.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:245
verses.text: For suppose a general and a common soldier both present themselves before you, being friends of the king, and you open your house to both: in which of their persons would you seem to pay most honor to the king? Plainly in that of a soldier.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:246
verses.text: For there were in the general, beside his loyalty to the king, many other things apt to win such a mark of respect from you: but the soldier had nothing else but his loyalty to the king.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:247
verses.text: Wherefore God bade us call to our suppers and our feasts the lame, and the maimed, and those who cannot repay us; for these are most of all properly called good deeds which are done for God's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:248
verses.text: Whereas if thou entertain some great and distinguished man, it is not such pure mercy, what thou doest: but some portion many times is assigned to thyself also, both by vain-glory, and by the return of the favor, and by thy rising in many men's estimation on account of thy guest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:249
verses.text: At any rate, I think I could point out many who with this view pay court to the more distinguished among the saints, namely, that by their means they may enjoy a greater intimacy with rulers, and that they may find them thenceforth more useful in their own affairs and to their families.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:250
verses.text: And many such favors do they ask in recompense from those saints; a thing which mars the repayment of their hospitality, they seeking it with such a mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:251
verses.text: And why need I say this about the saints? Since he who seeks, even from God, the reward of his labors in the present life and follows after virtue for this world's good, is sure to diminish his recompense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:252
verses.text: But he that asks for all his crowns wholly there, is found far more admirable; like that Lazarus, who even now is "receiving" (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:253
verses.text: Luke xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:254
verses.text: ) there all "his good things;" like those Three Children, who when they were on the point of being thrown into the furnace said, (Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:255
verses.text: xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:257
verses.text: ) "There is a God in heaven able to deliver us; and if not, be it known unto thee, O king, that we serve not thy gods, nor worship the golden image which thou hast set up:" like Abraham, who even offered his son and slew him; and this he did, not for any reward, but esteeming this one thing the greatest recompense, to obey the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:258
verses.text: These let us also imitate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:259
verses.text: For so shall we be visited with a return of all our good deeds and that abundantly, because we do all with such a mind as this: so shall we obtain also the brighter crowns.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 19:260
verses.text: And God grant that we may all obtain them, through the grace and loving-kindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom, to the Father and the Holy Spirit, be glory, power, honor, now, henceforth, and for everlasting ages, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:1
verses.text: Homily XXI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:3
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:4
verses.text: Am I not an Apostle? am I not free? have I not seen Jesus Christ our Lord? are not ye my work in the Lord?  Inasmuch as he had said, "If meat make my brother to stumble I will eat no flesh forever;" a thing which he had not yet done, but professed he would do if need require: lest any man should say, "Thou vauntest thyself at random, and art severe in discourse, and utterest words of promise, a thing easy to me or to any body; but if these sayings come from thy heart, shew by deeds something which thou hast slighted in order to avoid making thy brother stumble:" for this cause, I say, in what follows he is compelled to enter on the proof of this also, and to point out how he was used to forego even things permitted that he might not give offence, although without any law to enforce his doing so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:5
verses.text: And we are not yet come to the admirable part of the matter: though it be admirable that he abstain even from things lawful to avoid offence: but it is his habit of doing so at the cost of so much trouble and danger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:6
verses.text: "For why," saith he, "speak of the idol sacrifices? Since although Christ had enjoined that those who preach the Gospel should live at the charge of their disciples, I did not so, but chose, if need were, to end my life with famine and die the most grievous of deaths, so I might avoid receiving of those whom I instruct".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:7
verses.text: Not because they would otherwise be made to stumble, but because his not receiving would edify them: a much greater thing for him to do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:8
verses.text: And to witness this he summons themselves, among whom he was used to live in toil and in hunger, nourished by others, and put to straits, in order not to offend them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:9
verses.text: And yet there was no ground for their taking offence, for it would but have been a law which he was fulfilling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:10
verses.text: But for all this, by a sort of supererogation he used to spare them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:11
verses.text: Now if he did more than was enacted lest they should take offence, and abstained from permitted things to edify others; what must they deserve who abstain not from idol sacrifices? and that, when many perish thereby? a thing which even apart from all scandal one ought to shrink from, as being "the table of demons".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:12
verses.text: The sum therefore of this whole topic is this which he works out in many verses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:13
verses.text: But we must resume it and make a fresh entrance on what he hath alleged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:14
verses.text: For neither hath he set it down thus expressly as I have worded it; nor doth he leap at once upon it; but begins from another topic, thus speaking;   "Am I not an Apostle?" For besides all that hath been said, this also makes no small difference that Paul himself is the person thus conducting himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:15
verses.text: As thus: To prevent their alleging, "You may taste of the sacrifices, sealing at the same time:" for a while he withstands not that statement, but argues, "Though it were lawful, your brethren's harm should keep you from doing so;" and afterwards he proves that it is not even lawful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:16
verses.text: In this particular place, however, he establishes the former point from circumstances relating to himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:17
verses.text: And intending presently to say that he had received nothing from them, he sets it not down at once, but his own dignity is what he first affirms: "Am I not an Apostle? am I not free?"  Thus, to hinder their saying, "True; thou didst not receive, but the reason thou didst not was its not being lawful;" he sets down therefore first the causes why he might reasonably have received, had he been willing to do so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:18
verses.text: Further: that there might not seem to be any thing invidious in regard of Peter and such as Peter, in his saying these things, (for they did not use to decline receiving;) he first shows that they had authority to receive, and then that no one might say, "Peter had authority to receive but thou hadst not," he possesses the hearer beforehand with these encomiums of himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:19
verses.text: And perceiving that he must praise himself, (for that was the way to correct the Corinthians,) yet disliking to say any great thing of himself, see how he hath tempered both feelings as the occasion required: limiting his own panegyric, not by what he knew of himself, but by what the subject of necessity required.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:20
verses.text: For he might have said, "I most of all had a right to receive, even more than they, because 'I labored more abundantly than they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:21
verses.text: '" But this he omits, being a point wherein he surpassed them; and those points wherein they were great and which were just grounds for their receiving, those only he sets down: as follows:  "Am I not an Apostle? am I not free?" i-e: "have I not authority over myself? am I under any, to overrule me and forbid my receiving?"  "But they have an advantage over you, in having been with Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:22
verses.text: "Nay, neither is this denied me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:23
verses.text: With a view to which he saith,  "Have I not seen Jesus Christ our Lord?" For "last of all," (c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:24
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:25
verses.text: ) saith he, "as unto one born out of due time, He appeared unto me also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:26
verses.text: Now this likewise was no small dignity: since "many Prophets," (S.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:27
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:28
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:29
verses.text: ) saith He, "and righteous men have desired to see the things which ye see, and have not seen them:" and, "Days will come when ye shall desire to see one of these days".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:31
verses.text: Luke xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:32
verses.text: )  "What then, though thou be 'an Apostle,' and 'free,' and hast 'seen Christ,' if thou hast not exhibited any work of an Apostle; how then can it be right for thee to receive?" Wherefore after this he adds,  "Are not ye my work in the Lord?" For this is the great thing; and those others avail nothing, apart from this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:33
verses.text: Even Judas himself was "an Apostle," and "free," and "saw Christ;" but because he had not "the work of an Apostle," all those things profited him not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:34
verses.text: You see then why he adds this also, and calls themselves to be witnesses of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:35
verses.text: Moreover, because it was a great thing which he had uttered, see how he chastens it, adding, "In the Lord:" i-e:, "the work is God's, not mine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:36
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:37
verses.text: "If to others I am not an Apostle, yet at least I am to you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:38
verses.text: Do you see how far he is from enlarging here without necessity? And yet he had the whole world to speak of, and barbarous nations, and sea and land.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:39
verses.text: However, he mentions none of these things, but carries his point by concession, and even granting more than he need.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:40
verses.text: As if he had said, "Why need I dwell on things over and above, since these even alone are enough for my present purpose? I speak not, you will observe, of my achievements in other quarters, but of those which have you for witnesses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:41
verses.text: Upon which it follows that if from no other quarter, yet from you I have a right to receive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:42
verses.text: Nevertheless, from whom I had most right to receive, even you whose teacher I was, from those I received not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:43
verses.text: "If to others I am not an Apostle, yet at least I am to you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:44
verses.text: Again, he states his point by concession.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:45
verses.text: For the whole world had him for its Apostle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:46
verses.text: "However," saith he, "I say not that, I am not contending nor disputing, but what concerns you I lay down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:47
verses.text: 'For the seal of mine Apostleship are ye:'" i-e:, its proof.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:48
verses.text: "Should any one, moreover, desire to learn whence I am an Apostle, you are the persons whom I bring forward: for all the signs of an Apostle have I exhibited among you, and not one have I failed in".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:49
verses.text: As also he speaks in the Second Epistle, saying, ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:50
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:51
verses.text: ) "Though I am nothing, truly the signs of an Apostle were wrought among you in all patience, by signs and wonders and mighty works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:52
verses.text: For what is there wherein ye were made inferior to the rest of the Churches?" Wherefore he saith, "The seal of mine Apostleship are ye".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:53
verses.text: "For I both exhibited miracles, and taught by word, and underwent dangers, and shewed forth a blameless life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:54
verses.text: And these topics you may see fully set forth by these two Epistles, how he lays before them the demonstration of each with all exactness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:55
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:56
verses.text: "My defence to them that examine me is this".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:57
verses.text: What is, "My defence to them that examine me is this?" "To those who seek to know whereby I am proved to be an Apostle, or who accuse me as receiving money, or inquire the cause of my not receiving, or would fain shew that I am not an Apostle: to all such, my instruction given to you and these things which I am about to say, may stand for a full explanation and defence".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:58
verses.text: What then are these?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:60
verses.text: "Have we no right to eat and to drink? Have we no right to lead about a wife that is a believer?" Why, how are these sayings a defence? "Because, when it appears that I abstain even from things which are allowed, it cannot be just to look suspiciously on me as a deceiver or one acting for gain".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:61
verses.text: Wherefore, from what was before alleged and from my having instructed you and from this which I have now said, I have matter sufficient to make my defence to you: and all who examine me I meet upon this ground, alleging both what has gone before and this which follows: "Have we no right to eat and to drink? have we no right to lead about a wife that is a believer? "Yet for all this, having it I abstain?"  What then? did he not use to eat or to drink? It were most true to say that in many places he really did not eat nor drink: for (c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:62
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:63
verses.text: ) "in hunger," saith he, "and in thirst, and in nakedness" we were abiding".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:64
verses.text: Here, however, this is not his meaning; but what? "We eat not nor drink, receiving of those whom we instruct, though we have a right so to receive".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:65
verses.text: "Have we no right to lead about a wife that is a believer, even as the rest of the Apostles, and the brethren of the Lord, and Cephas?" Observe his skilfulness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:66
verses.text: The leader of the choir stands last in his arrangement: since that is the time for laying down the strongest of all one's topics.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:67
verses.text: Nor was it so wonderful for one to be able to point out examples of this conduct in the rest, as in the foremost champion and in him who was entrusted with the keys of heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:68
verses.text: But neither does he mention Peter alone, but all of them: as if he had said, Whether you seek the inferior sort or the more eminent, in all you find patterns of this sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:69
verses.text: For the brethren too of the Lord, being freed from their first unbelief (vid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:70
verses.text: S.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:71
verses.text: John vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:72
verses.text: ), had come to be among those who were approved, although they attained not to the Apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:73
verses.text: And accordingly the middle place is that which he hath assigned to them, setting down those who were in the extremes before and after.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:74
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:75
verses.text: "Or I only and Barnabas, have we not a right to forbear working?"  (See his humility of mind and his soul pure from envy, how he takes care not to conceal him whom he knew to be a partaker with himself in this perfection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:76
verses.text: ) For if the other things be common, how is not this common? Both they and we are apostles and are free, and have seen Christ, and have exhibited the works of Apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:77
verses.text: Therefore we likewise have a right both to live without working and to be supported by our disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:78
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:79
verses.text: "What soldier ever serveth at his own charges?" For since, which was the strongest point, he had proved from the Apostles that it is lawful to do so, he next comes to examples and to the common practice; as he uses to do: "What soldier serveth at his own charges?" saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:80
verses.text: But do thou consider, I pray, how very suitable are the examples to his proposed subject, and how he mentions first that which is accompanied with danger; viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:81
verses.text: soldiership and arms and wars.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:82
verses.text: For such a kind of thing was the Apostolate, nay rather much more hazardous than these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:83
verses.text: For not with men alone was their warfare, but with demons also, and against the prince of those beings was their battle array.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:84
verses.text: What he saith therefore is this: "Not even do heathen governors, cruel and unjust as they are, require their soldiers to endure service and peril and live on their own means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:85
verses.text: How then could Christ ever have required this?"  Nor is he satisfied with one example.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:86
verses.text: For to him who is rather simple and dull, this also is wont to come as a great refreshment, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:87
verses.text: their seeing the common custom also going along with the laws of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:88
verses.text: Wherefore he proceeds to another topic also and says, "Who planteth a vineyard, and eateth not of the fruit thereof?" For as by the former he indicated his dangers, so by this his labor and abundant travail and care.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:89
verses.text: He adds likewise a third example, saying, "Who feedeth a flock, and eateth not of the milk thereof?" He is exhibiting the great concern which it becomes a teacher to show for those who are under his rule.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:90
verses.text: For, in fact, the Apostles were both soldiers and husbandmen and shepherds, not of the earth nor of irrational animals, nor in such wars as are perceptible by sense; but of reasonable souls and in battle array with the demons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:91
verses.text: It also must be remarked how every where he preserves moderation, seeking the useful only, not the extraordinary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:92
verses.text: For he said not, "What soldier serveth and is not enriched?" but, "What soldier ever serveth at his own charges?" Neither did he say, "Who planteth a vineyard, and gathereth not gold, or spareth to collect the whole fruit?" but, "Who eateth not of the fruit thereof?" Neither did he say, "Who feedeth a flock, and maketh not merchandize of the lambs?" But what? "And eateth not of the milk thereof?" Not of the lambs, but of the milk; signifying, that a little relief should be enough for the teacher, even his necessary food alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:93
verses.text: (This refers to those who would devour all and gather the whole of the fruit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:94
verses.text: ) "So likewise the Lord ordained," saying, "The laborer is worthy of his food".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:95
verses.text: (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:96
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:97
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:98
verses.text: )  And not this only doth he establish by his illustrations, but he shows also what kind of man a priest ought to be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:99
verses.text: For he ought to possess both the courage of a soldier and the diligence of a husbandman and the carefulness of a shepherd, and after all these, to seek nothing more than necessaries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:100
verses.text: Having shewn, as you see, both from the Apostles, that it is not forbidden the teacher to receive, and from illustrations found in common life, he proceeds also to a third head, thus saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:101
verses.text: "Do I speak these things after the manner of men? or saith not the law also the same?"  For since he had hitherto alleged nothing out of the Scriptures, but put forward the common custom; "think not," saith he, "that I am confident in these alone, nor that I go to the opinions of men for the ground of these enactments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:102
verses.text: For I can shew that these things are also well-pleasing to God, and I read an ancient law enjoining them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:103
verses.text: Wherefore also he carries on his discourse in the form of a question, which is apt to be done in things fully acknowledged; thus saying, "Say I these things after the manner of men?" i-e: "do I strengthen myself only by human examples?" "or saith not the law also the same?"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:104
verses.text: "For it is written in the law of Moses, Thou shalt not muzzle the ox when he treadeth out the corn".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:105
verses.text: And on what account hath he mentioned this, having the example of the priests? Wishing to establish it far beyond what the case required.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:106
verses.text: Further, lest any should say, "And what have we to do with the saying about the oxen?" he works it out more exactly, saying, "Is it for the oxen that God careth;" Doth God then, tell me, take no care for oxen? Well, He doth take care of them, but not so as to make a law concerning such a thing as this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:107
verses.text: So that had he not been hinting at something important, training the Jews to mercy in the case of the brutes, and through these, discoursing with them of the teachers also; he would not have taken so much interest as even to make a law to forbid the muzzling of oxen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:108
verses.text: Wherein he points out another thing likewise, that the labor of teachers both is and ought to be great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:109
verses.text: And again another thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:110
verses.text: What then is this? That whatever is said by the Old Testament respecting care for brutes, in its principal meaning bears on the instruction of human beings: as in fact do all the rest: the precepts, for example, concerning various garments; and those concerning vineyards and seeds and not making the ground bear divers crops, and those concerning leprosy; and, in a word, all the rest: for they being of a duller sort He was discoursing with them from these topics, advancing them by little and little.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:111
verses.text: And see how in what follows he doth not even confirm it, as being clear and self-evident.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:112
verses.text: For having said, "Is it for the oxen that God careth?" he added, "or saith he it altogether for our sake?" Not adding even the "altogether" at random, but that he might not leave the hearer any thing whatever to reply.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:113
verses.text: And he dwells upon the metaphor, saying and declaring, "Yea for our sakes it was written, because he who ploweth ought to plow in hope;" i-e:, the teacher ought to enjoy the returns of his labors; "and he that thresheth ought to thresh in hope of partaking".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:114
verses.text: And observe his wisdom in that from the seed he transferred the matter to the threshing floor; herein also again manifesting the many toils of the teachers, that they in their own persons both plough and tread the floor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:115
verses.text: And of the ploughing, because there was nothing to reap, but labor only, he used the word, "hope;" but of treading the floor he presently allows the fruit, saying, "He that thresheth is a partaker of his hope".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:116
verses.text: Further, lest any should say, "Is this then the return for so many toils," he adds, "in hope," i-e:, "which is to come".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:117
verses.text: No other thing therefore doth the mouth of this animal being unmuzzled declare than this; that the teachers who labor ought also to enjoy some return.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:118
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:119
verses.text: "If we sowed unto you spiritual things, is it a great matter if we shall reap your carnal things?"  Lo, he adds also a fourth argument for the duty of yielding support.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:120
verses.text: For since he had said, "What soldier ever serveth at his own charges?" and, "who planteth a vineyard?" and, "who feedeth a flock?" and introduced the ox that treadeth the corn; he points out likewise another most reasonable cause on account of which they might justly receive; viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:121
verses.text: having bestowed much greater gifts, no more as having labored only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:122
verses.text: What is it then? "if we sowed unto you spiritual things, is it a great matter if we shall reap your carnal things?" Seest thou a most just allegation and fuller of reason than all the former? for "in those instances," says he, "carnal is the seed, carnal also is the fruit; but here not so, but the seed is spiritual, the return carnal".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:123
