verses.text: Thus, to prevent high thoughts in those who contribute to their teachers, he signified that they receive more than they give.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:124
verses.text: As if he had said, "Husbandmen, whatsoever they sow, this also do they receive; but we, sowing in your souls spiritual things, do reap carnal".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:125
verses.text: For such is the kind of support given by them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:126
verses.text: Further, and still more to put them to the blush.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:127
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:128
verses.text: "If others partake of this right over you, do not we yet more?"  See also again another argument, and this too from examples though not of the same kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:129
verses.text: For it is not Peter whom he mentions here nor the Apostles, but certain other spurious ones, with whom he afterwards enters into combat, and concerning whom he says, ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:130
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:131
verses.text: ) "If a man devour you, if he take you captive, if he exalt himself, if he smite you on the face," and already he is sounding the prelude to the fight with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:132
verses.text: Wherefore neither did he say, "If others take of you," but pointing out their insolence and tyranny and trafficking, he says, "if others partake of this right over you," i-e:, "rule you, exercise authority, use you as servants, not taking you captive only, but with much authority".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:133
verses.text: Wherefore he added "do not we yet more?" which he would not have said if the discourse were concerning the Apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:134
verses.text: But it is evident that he hints at certain pestilent men, and deceivers of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:135
verses.text: "So that besides the law of Moses even ye yourselves have made a law in behalf of the duty of contribution".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:136
verses.text: And having said, "do not we yet more?" he does not prove why yet more, but leaves it to their consciences to convince them of that, wishing at the same time both to alarm and to abash them more thoroughly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:137
verses.text: Nevertheless, we did not use this right;" i-e:, "did not receive".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:138
verses.text: Do you see, when he had by so many reasons before proved that receiving is not unlawful, how he next says, "we receive not," that he might not seem to abstain as from a thing forbidden? "For not because it is unlawful," saith he, "do I not receive; for it is lawful and this we have many ways shown: from the Apostles; from the affairs of life, the soldier, the husbandman, and the shepherd; from the law of Moses; from the very nature of the case, in that we have sown unto you spiritual things; from what yourselves have done to others".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:139
verses.text: But as he had laid down these things, lest he should seem to put to shame the Apostles who were in the habit of receiving; abashing them and signifying that not as from a forbidden thing doth he abstain from it: so again, lest by his large store of proof and the examples and reasonings by which he had pointed out the propriety of receiving, he should seem to be anxious to receive himself and therefore to say these things; he now corrects it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:140
verses.text: And afterwards he laid it down more clearly where he says, "And I wrote not these things, that it may be so done in my case;" but here his words are, "we did not use this right".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:141
verses.text: And what is a still greater thing, neither could any have this to say, that being in abundance we declined using it; rather, when necessity pressed upon us we would not yield to the necessity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:142
verses.text: Which also in the second Epistle he says; "I robbed other Churches, taking wages of them that I might minister unto you; and when I was present with you, and was in want, I was not a burden on any man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:143
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:144
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:146
verses.text: ) And in this Epistle again, "We both hunger, and thirst, and are naked, and are buffeted".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:147
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:148
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:149
verses.text: ) And here again he hints the same thing, saying, "But we bear all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:150
verses.text: For by saying, "we bear all things," he intimates both hunger and great straits and all the other things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:151
verses.text: "But not even thus have we been compelled," saith he, "to break the law which we laid down for ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:152
verses.text: Wherefore? "that we may cause no hinderance to the Gospel of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:153
verses.text: For since the Corinthians were rather weak-minded, "lest we should wound you," saith he "by receiving, we chose to do even more than was commanded rather than hinder the Gospel," i-e:, your instruction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:154
verses.text: Now if we in a matter left free to us, and when we were both enduring much hardship and having Apostles for our pattern, used abstinence lest we should give hindrance, (and he did not say, "subversion," but "hindrance;" nor simply "hindrance," but "any" hindrance,) that we might not, so to speak, cause so much as the slightest suspense and delay to the course of the Word: "If now," saith he, "we used so great care, how much more ought you to abstain, who both come far short of the Apostles and have no law to mention, giving you permission: but contrariwise are both putting your hand to things forbidden and things which tend to the great injury of the Gospel, not to its hindrance only; and not even having any pressing necessity in view".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:155
verses.text: For all this discussion he had moved on account of these Corinthians, who were making their weaker brethren to stumble by eating of things sacrificed to idols.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:156
verses.text: These things also let us listen to, beloved; that we may not despise those who are offended, nor, "cause any hindrance to the Gospel of Christ;" that we may not betray our own salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:157
verses.text: And say not thou to me when thy brother is offended, "this or that, whereby he is offended, hath not been forbidden; it is permitted".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:158
verses.text: For I have something greater to say to thee: "although Christ Himself have permitted it, yet if thou seest any injured, stop and do not use the permission".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:159
verses.text: For this also did Paul; when he might have received, Christ having granted permission, he received not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:160
verses.text: Thus hath our Lord in His mercy mingled much gentleness with His precepts that it might not be all merely of commandment, but that we might do much also of our own mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:161
verses.text: Since it was in His power, had He not been so minded, to extend the commandments further and to say, "he who fasts not continually, let him be chastised; he who keeps not his virginity, let him be punished; he that doth not strip himself of all that he hath, let him suffer the severest penalty".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:162
verses.text: But he did not so, giving thee occasion, if thou wilt, to be forward in doing more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:163
verses.text: Wherefore both when He was discoursing about virginity, He said, "He that is able to receive, let him receive it:" and in the case of the rich man, some things He commanded, but some He left to the determination of his mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:164
verses.text: For He said not, "Sell what thou hast," but, "If thou wilt be perfect, sell".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:165
verses.text: But we are not only not forward to do more, and to go beyond the precepts, but we fall very short even of the measure of things commanded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:166
verses.text: And whereas Paul suffered hunger that he might not hinder the Gospel; we have not the heart even to touch what is in our own stores, though we see innumerable souls overthrown.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:167
verses.text: "Yea" saith one, "let the moth eat, and let not the poor eat; let the worm devour, and let not the naked be clothed; let all be wasted away with time, and let not Christ be fed; and this when He hungereth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:168
verses.text: "Why, who said this?" it will be asked.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:169
verses.text: Nay, this is the very grievance, that not in words but in deeds these things are said: for it were less grievous uttered in words than done in deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:170
verses.text: For is not this the cry, day by day, of the inhuman and cruel tyrant, Covetousness, to those who are led captive by her? "Let your goods be set before informers and robbers and traitors for luxury, and not before the hungry and needy for their sustenance".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:171
verses.text: Is it not ye then who make robbers? Is it not ye who minister fuel to the fire of the envious? Is it not ye who make vagabonds and traitors, putting your wealth before them for a bait? What madness is this? (for a madness it is, and plain distraction,) to fill your chests with apparel, and overlook him that is made after God's image and similitude, naked and trembling with cold, and with difficulty keeping himself upright.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:172
verses.text: "But he pretends," saith one, "this tremor and weakness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:173
verses.text: And dost thou not fear lest a thunderbolt from heaven, kindled by this word, should fall upon thee? (For I am bursting with wrath: bear with me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:174
verses.text: ) Thou, I say, pampering and fattening thyself and extending thy potations to the dead of night and comforting thyself in soft coverlets, dost not deem thyself liable to judgment, so lawlessly using the gifts of God: (for wine was not made that we should be drunken; nor food, that we should pamper our appetites; nor meats, that we should distend the belly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:175
verses.text: ) But from the poor, the wretched, from him that is as good as dead, from him demandest thou strict accounts, and dost thou not fear Christ's tribunal, so full of all awfulness and terror? Why, if he do play the hypocrite, he doth it of necessity and want, because of thy cruelty and inhumanity, requiring the use of such masks and refusing all inclination to mercy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:176
verses.text: For who is so wretched and miserable as without urgent necessity, for one loaf of bread, to submit to such disgrace, and to bewail himself and endure so severe a punishment? So that this hypocrisy of his goeth about, the herald of thine inhumanity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:177
verses.text: For since by supplicating and beseeching and uttering piteous expressions and lamenting and weeping and going about all day, he doth not obtain even necessary food, he devised perhaps even this contrivance also, the disgrace and blame whereof falls not so much on himself as on thee: for he indeed is meet to be pitied because he hath fallen into so great necessity; but we are worthy of innumerable punishments because we compel the poor to suffer such things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:178
verses.text: For if we would easily give way, never would he have chosen to endure such things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:179
verses.text: And why speak I of nakedness and trembling? For I will tell a thing yet more to be shuddered at, that some have been compelled even to deprive their children of sight at an early age in order that they might touch our insensibility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:180
verses.text: For since when they could see and went about naked, neither by their age nor by their misfortunes could they win favor of the unpitying, they added to so great evils another yet sterner tragedy, that they might remove their hunger; thinking it to be a lighter thing to be deprived of this common light and that sunshine which is given to all, than to struggle with continual famine and endure the most miserable of deaths.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:181
verses.text: Thus, since you have not learned to pity poverty, but delight yourselves in misfortunes, they satisfy your insatiable desire, and both for themselves and for us kindle a fiercer flame in hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:182
verses.text: And to convince you that this is the reason why these and such like things are done, I will tell you of an acknowledged proof which no man can gainsay.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:183
verses.text: There are other poor men, of light and unsteady minds and not knowing how to bear hunger, but rather enduring every thing than it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:184
verses.text: These having often tried to deal with us by piteous gestures and words and finding that they availed nothing, have left off those supplications and henceforward our very wonder-workers are surpassed by them, some chewing the skins of worn-out shoes, and some fixing sharp nails into their heads, others lying about in frozen pools with naked stomachs, and others enduring different things yet more horrid than these, that they may draw around them the ungodly spectators.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:185
verses.text: And thou, while these things are going on, standest laughing and wondering the while and making a fine show of other men's miseries, our common nature disgracing itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:186
verses.text: And what could a fierce demon do more? Next, you give him money in abundance that he may do these things more promptly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:187
verses.text: And to him that prays and calls on God and approaches with modesty, you vouchsafe neither an answer nor a look: rather you utter to him, continually teazing you, those disgusting expressions, "Ought this fellow to live? or at all to breathe and see this sun?" whereas to the other sort you are both cheerful and liberal, as though you were appointed to dispense the prize of that ridiculous and Satanic unseemliness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:188
verses.text: Wherefore with more propriety to those who appoint these sports and bestow nothing till they see others punishing themselves, might these words be addressed, "Ought these men to live, to breathe at all, or see the sun, who transgress against our common nature, who insult God?" For whereas God saith, "Give alms, and I give thee the kingdom of heaven," thou hearest not: but when the Devil shews thee a head pierced with nails, on a sudden thou hast become liberal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:189
verses.text: And the contrivance of the evil spirit pregnant with so much mischief, hath wrought upon thee more than the promise of God bringing innumerable blessings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:190
verses.text: If gold were to be laid down to prevent the doing of these things or the looking upon them when done, there is nothing which thou oughtest not to practise and endure, to get rid of so excessive madness; but ye contrive every thing to have them done, and look on the doing of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:191
verses.text: Still askest thou then, tell me, to what end is hell-fire? Nay, ask not that any more, but how is there one hell only? For of how many punishments are not they worthy, who get up this cruel and merciless spectacle and laugh at what both they and yourselves ought to weep over; yea, rather of the two, ye who compel them to such unseemly doings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:192
verses.text: "But I do not compel them," say you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:193
verses.text: What else but compelling is it, I should like to know? Those who are more modest and shed tears and invoke God, thou art impatient even of listening to; but for these thou both findest silver in abundance and bringest around thee many to admire them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:194
verses.text: "Well, let us leave off," say you, "pitying them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:195
verses.text: And dost thou too enjoin this?" Nay, it is not pity, O man, to demand so severe a punishment for a few pence, to order men to maim themselves for necessary food and cut into many pieces the skin of their head so mercilessly and pitifully.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:196
verses.text: "Gently," say you, "for it is not we who pierce those heads".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:197
verses.text: Would it were thou, and the horror would not be so horrible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:198
verses.text: For he that slays a man does a much more grievous thing than he who bids him slay himself, which indeed happens in the case of these persons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:199
verses.text: For they endure more bitter pains when they are bidden to be themselves the executors of these wicked commands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:200
verses.text: And all this in Antioch, where men were first called Christians, wherein are bred the most civilized of mankind, where in old time the fruit of charity flourished so abundantly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:201
verses.text: For not only to those at hand but also to those very far off, they used to send, and this when famine was expected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:202
verses.text: What then ought we to do? say you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:203
verses.text: To cease from this savage practice: and to convince all that are in need that by doing these things they will gain nothing, but if they modestly approach they shall find your liberality great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:204
verses.text: Let them be once aware of this, even though they be of all men most miserable, they will never choose to punish themselves so severely, I pledge myself; nay, they will even give you thanks for delivering them both from the mockery and the pain of that way of life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:205
verses.text: But as it is, for charioteers you would let out even your own children, and for dancers you would throw away your very souls, while for Christ an hungered you spare not the smallest portion of your substance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:206
verses.text: But if you give a little silver, you think as much of it as if you had laid out all you have, not knowing that not the giving but the giving liberally, this is true almsgiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:207
verses.text: Wherefore also it is not those simply who give whom the prophet proclaims and calls happy, but those who bestow liberally.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:208
verses.text: For he doth not say simply, He hath given, but what? (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:209
verses.text: cxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:210
verses.text: ) "he hath dispersed abroad, he hath given to the poor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:211
verses.text: For what profit is it, when out of it thou givest as it were a glass of water out of the sea, and even a widow's magnanimity is beyond thy emulation? And how wilt thou say, "Pity me, O Lord, according to thy great pity, and according to the multitude of thy mercies blot out my transgression," thyself not pitying according to any great pity, nay, haply not according to any little.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:212
verses.text: For I am greatly ashamed, I own, when I see many of the rich riding upon their golden-bitted chargers with a train of domestics clad in gold, and having couches of silver and other and more pomp, and yet when there is need to give to a poor man, becoming more beggarly than the very poorest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:213
verses.text: But what is their constant talk? "He hath," they say, "the common church-allowance".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:214
verses.text: And what is that to thee? For thou wilt not be saved because I give; nor if the Church bestow hast thou blotted out thine own sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:215
verses.text: For this cause givest thou not, because the Church ought to give to the needy? Because the priests pray, wilt thou never pray thyself? And because others fast, wilt thou be continually drunken? Knowest thou not that God enacted not almsgiving so much for the sake of the poor as for the sake of the persons themselves who bestow?  But dost thou suspect the priest? Why this thing itself, to begin with, is a grievous sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:216
verses.text: However, I will not examine the matter too nicely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:217
verses.text: Do thou it all in thine own person, and so shalt thou reap a double reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:218
verses.text: Since in fact, what we say in behalf of almsgiving, we say not, that thou shouldest offer to us, but that thou shouldest thyself minister by thine own hands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:219
verses.text: For if thou bringest thine alms to me, perhaps thou mayest even be led captive by vain-glory, and oftentimes likewise thou shalt go away offended through suspicion of something evil: but if ye do all things by yourselves, ye shall both be rid of offences and of unreasonable suspicion, and greater is your reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:220
verses.text: Not therefore to compel you to bring your money hither, do I say these things; nor from indignation on account of the priests being ill-reported of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:221
verses.text: For if one must be indignant and grieve, for you should be our grief, who say this ill.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:222
verses.text: Since to them who are spoken ill of falsely and vainly the reward is greater, but to the speakers the condemnation and punishment is heavier.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:223
verses.text: I say not these things therefore in their behalf, but in solicitude and care for you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:224
verses.text: For what marvel is it if some in our generation are suspected, when in the case of those holy men who imitated the angels, who possessed nothing of their own, I mean the Apostles, there was a murmuring in the ministration to the widows (Acts vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:225
verses.text: ) that the poor were overlooked? when "not one said that aught of the things he possessed was his own, but they had all things common?" (Acts iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:226
verses.text: )  Let us not then put forward these pretexts, nor account it an excuse that the Church is wealthy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:227
verses.text: But when you see the greatness of her substance, bear in mind also the crowds of poor who are on her list, the multitudes of her sick, her occasions of endless expenses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:228
verses.text: Investigate, scrutinize, there is none to forbid, nay, they are even ready to give you an account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:229
verses.text: But I wish to go much farther.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:230
verses.text: Namely, when we have given in our accounts and proved that our expenditure is no less than our income, nay, sometimes more, I would gladly ask you this further question: When we depart hence and shall hear Christ saying, "Ye saw me hungry, and gave me no meat; naked, and ye clothed me not;" what shall we say? what apology shall we make? Shall we bring forward such and such a person who disobeyed these commands? or some of the priests who were suspected? "Nay, what is this to thee? for I accuse thee," saith He, "of those things wherein thou hast thyself sinned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:231
verses.text: And the apology for these would be, to have washed away thine own offences, not to point to others whose errors have been the same as thine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:232
verses.text: In fact, the Church through your meanness is compelled to have such property as it has now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:233
verses.text: Since, if men did all things according to the apostolical laws, its revenue should have been your good will, which were both a secure chest and an inexhaustible treasury.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:234
verses.text: But now when ye lay up for yourselves treasures upon the earth and shut up all things in your own stores, while the Church is compelled to be at charges with bands of widows, choirs of virgins, sojournings of strangers, distresses of foreigners, the misfortunes of prisoners, the necessities of the sick and maimed, and other such like causes, what must be done? Turn away from all these, and block up so many ports? Who then could endure the shipwrecks that would ensue; the weepings, the lamentations, the wailings which would reach us from every quarter?  Let us not then speak at random what comes into our mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:235
verses.text: For now, as I have just said, we are really prepared to render up our accounts to you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:236
verses.text: But even if it were the reverse, and ye had corrupt teachers plundering and grasping at every thing, not even so were their wickedness an apology for you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:237
verses.text: For the Lover of mankind and All-wise, the Only-Begotten Son of God, seeing all things, and knowing the chance that in so great length of time and in so vast a world there would be many corrupt priests; lest the carelessness of those under their rule should increase through their neglect, removing every excuse for indifference; "In Moses' seat," saith He, "sit the Scribes and the Pharisees; all things, therefore, whatsoever they bid you, these do ye, but do not ye after their works:" implying, that even if thou hast a bad teacher, this will not avail thee, shouldest thou not attend to the things which are spoken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:238
verses.text: For not from what thy teacher hath done but from what thou hast heard and disobeyed, from that, I say, doth God pass his sentence upon thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:239
verses.text: So that if thou doest the things commanded, thou shalt then stand with much boldness: but if thou disobey the things spoken, even though thou shouldest show ten thousand corrupt priests, this will not plead for thee at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:240
verses.text: Since Judas also was an apostle, but nevertheless this shall never be any apology for the sacrilegious and covetous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:241
verses.text: Nor will any be able when accused to say, "Why the Apostle was a thief and sacrilegious, and a traitor;" yea, this very thing shall most of all be our punishment and condemnation that not even by the evils of others were we corrected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:242
verses.text: For this cause also these things were written that we might shun all emulation of such things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:243
verses.text: Wherefore, leaving this person and that, let us take heed to ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:244
verses.text: For "each of us shall give account of himself to God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:245
verses.text: In order therefore that we may render up this account with a good defence, let us well order our own lives and stretch out a liberal hand to the needy, knowing that this only is our defence, the showing ourselves to have rightly done the things commanded; there is no other whatever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 20:246
verses.text: And if we be able to produce this, we shall escape those intolerable pains of hell, and obtain the good things to come; unto which may we all attain, by the grace and mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom, to the Father and the Holy Ghost, be glory, power, and honor, now and ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:1
verses.text: Homily XXII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:3
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:4
verses.text: ,  Know ye not that they which minister about sacred things eat of the temple? and they which wait upon the altar have their portion with the altar? Even so did the Lord ordain that they which proclaim the Gospel should live of the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:5
verses.text: He takes great care to show that the receiving was not forbidden.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:6
verses.text: Whereupon having said so much before, he was not content but proceeds also to the Law, furnishing an example closer to the point than the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:7
verses.text: For it was not the same thing to bring forward the oxen and to adduce the law expressly given concerning priests.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:8
verses.text: But consider, I pray, in this also the wisdom of Paul, how he mentions the matter in a way to give it dignity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:9
verses.text: For he did not say, "They which minister about sacred things receive of those who offer them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:10
verses.text: But what? "They eat of the temple:" so that neither they who receive may be blamed nor they who give may be lifted up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:11
verses.text: Wherefore also what follows he hath set down in the same way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:12
verses.text: For neither did he say, "They which wait upon the altar receive of them which sacrifice," but, "have their portion with the altar".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:13
verses.text: For the things offered now no longer belonged to those who offered them, but to the temple and the altar.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:14
verses.text: And he said not, "They receive the holy things," but, they "eat of the temple," indicating again their moderation, and that it behoves them not to make money nor to be rich.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:15
verses.text: And though he say that they have their portion "with the altar," he doth not speak of equal distribution but of relief given them as their due.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:16
verses.text: And yet the case of the Apostles was much stronger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:17
verses.text: For in the former instance the priesthood was an honor, but in the latter it was dangers and slaughters and violent deaths.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:18
verses.text: Wherefore all the other examples together did not come up to the saying, "If we sowed unto you spiritual things:" since in saying, "we sowed," he points out the storms, the danger, the snares, the unspeakable evils, which they endured in preaching.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:19
verses.text: Nevertheless, though the superiority was so great, he was unwilling either to abase the things of the old law or to exalt the things which belong to himself: nay he even contracts his own, reckoning the superiority not from the dangers, but from the greatness of the gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:20
verses.text: For he said not, "if we have jeoparded ourselves" or "exposed ourselves to snares" but "if we sowed unto you spiritual things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:21
verses.text: And the part of the priests, as far as possible, he exalts, saying, "They which minister about sacred things," and "they that wait upon the altar," thereby intending to point out their continual servitude and patience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:22
verses.text: Again, as he had spoken of the priests among the Jews, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:23
verses.text: both the Levites and the Chief Priests, so he hath expressed each of the orders, both the inferior and the superior; the one by saying, "they which minister about sacred things," and the other by saying, "they which wait upon the altar".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:24
verses.text: For not to all was one work commanded; but some were entrusted with the coarser, others with the more exalted offices.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:25
verses.text: Comprehending therefore all these, lest any should say, "why talk to us of the old law? knowest thou not that ours is the time of more perfect commandments?" after all those topics he placed that which is strongest of all, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:26
verses.text: "Even so did the Lord ordain that they who proclaim the Gospel should live of the Gospel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:27
verses.text: Nor doth he even here say that they are supported by men, but as in the case of the priests, of "the temple" and "of the altar," so likewise here, "of the Gospel;" and as there he saith, "eat," so here, "live," not make merchandize nor lay up treasures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:28
verses.text: "For the laborer," saith He, "is worthy of his hire".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:29
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:30
verses.text: "But I have used none of these things:"  What then if thou hast not used them now, saith one, but intendest to use them at a future time, and on this account sayest these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:31
verses.text: Far from it; for he speedily corrected the notion, thus saying;  "And I write not these things that it may be so done in my case".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:32
verses.text: And see with what vehemence he disavows and repels the thing:  "For it were good for me rather to die, than that any man should make my glorying void".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:33
verses.text: And not once nor twice, but many times he uses this expression.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:34
verses.text: For above he said, "We did not use this right:" and after this again, "that I abuse not my right:" and here, "but I have used none of these things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:35
verses.text: "These things;" what things? The many examples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:36
verses.text: That is to say, many things giving me license; the soldier, the husbandman, the shepherd, the Apostles, the law, the things done by us unto you, the things done by you unto the others, the priests, the ordinance of Christ; by none of these have I been induced to abolish my own law, and to receive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:37
verses.text: And speak not to me of the past: (although I could say, that I have endured much even in past times on this account,) nevertheless I do not rest on it alone, but likewise concerning the future I pledge myself, that I would choose rather to die of hunger than be deprived of these crowns.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:38
verses.text: "For it were good for me rather to die," saith he, "than that any man should make my glorying void".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:39
verses.text: He said not, "that any man should abolish my law," but, "my glorying".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:40
verses.text: For lest any should say, "he doth it indeed but not cheerfully, but with lamentation and grief," willing to show the excess of his joy and the abundance of his zeal, he even calls the matter "glorying".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:41
verses.text: So far was he from vexing himself that he even glories, and chooses rather to die than to fall from this "glorying".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:42
verses.text: So much dearer to him even than life itself was that proceeding of his.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:43
verses.text: Next, he exalts it from another consideration also, and signifies that it was a great thing, not that he might show himself famous, (for far was he from that disposition,) but to signify that he rejoices, and with a view more abundantly to take away all suspicion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:44
verses.text: For on this account, as I before said, he also called it a glorying: and what saith he?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:46
verses.text: "For if I preach the Gospel, I have nothing to glory of; for necessity is laid upon me; for woe is unto me, if I preach not the Gospel! For if I do this of mine own will, I have a reward: but if not of mine own will, I have a stewardship entrusted to me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:47
verses.text: What then is my reward? That when I preach the Gospel, I may make the Gospel of Christ without charge, so as not to use to the full my right in the Gospel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:48
verses.text: What sayest thou? tell me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:49
verses.text: "If thou preach the Gospel, it is nothing for thee to glory of, but it is, if thou make the Gospel of Christ without charge?" Is this therefore greater than that? By no means; but in another point of view it hath some advantage, inasmuch as the one is a command, but the other is a good deed of my own free-will: for what things are done beyond the commandment, have a great reward in this respect: but such as are in pursuance of a commandment, not so great: and so in this respect he says, the one is more than the other; not in the very nature of the thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:50
verses.text: For what is equal to preaching; since it maketh men vie even with the angels themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:51
verses.text: Nevertheless since the one is a commandment and a debt, the other a forwardness of free-will, in this respect this is more than that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:52
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, explaining the same, what I just now mentioned:  "For if I do this of mine own will, I have a reward, but if not of mine own will, a stewardship is entrusted to me;" taking the words of mine own "will" and "not of mine own will," of its being committed or not committed to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:53
verses.text: And thus we must understand the expression, "for necessity is laid upon me;" not as though he did aught of these things against his will, God forbid, but as though he were bound by the things commanded, and for contradistinction to the liberty in receiving before mentioned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:54
verses.text: Wherefore also Christ said to the disciples, (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:55
verses.text: Luke xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:56
verses.text: ) "When ye have done all, say, We are unprofitable servants; for we have done that which was our duty to do".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:57
verses.text: "What then is my reward? That when I preach the Gospel, I may make the Gospel without charge".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:58
verses.text: What then, tell me, hath Peter no reward? Nay, who can ever have so great an one as he? And what shall we say of the other Apostles? How then said he, "If I do this of mine own will I have a reward, but if not of mine own will, a stewardship is entrusted to me?" Seest thou here also his wisdom? For he said not, "But if not of mine own will," I have no reward, but, "a stewardship is committed unto me:" implying that even thus he hath a reward, but such as he obtains who hath performed what was commanded, not such as belongs to him who hath of his own resources been generous and exceeded the commandment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:59
verses.text: "What then is the reward? That, when I preach the Gospel," saith he, "I may make the Gospel without charge, so as not to use to the full my right in the Gospel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:60
verses.text: See how throughout he uses the term "right," intimating this, as I have often observed; that neither are they who receive worthy of blame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:61
verses.text: But he added, "in the Gospel," partly to show the reasonableness of it, partly also to forbid our carrying the matter out into every case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:62
verses.text: For the teacher ought to receive, but not the mere drone also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:63
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:64
verses.text: "For though I was free from all men, I brought myself under bondage to all, that I might gain the more".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:65
verses.text: Here again he introduces another high step in advance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:66
verses.text: For a great thing it is even not to receive, but this which he is about to mention is much more than that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:67
verses.text: What then is it that he says? "Not only have I not received," saith he," not only have I not used this right, but I have even made myself a slave, and in a slavery manifold and universal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:68
verses.text: For not in money alone, but, which was much more than money, in employments many and various have I made good this same rule: and I have made myself a slave when I was subject to none, having no necessity in any respect, (for this is the meaning of, "though I was free from all men;") and not to any single person have I been a slave, but to the whole world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:69
verses.text: Wherefore also he subjoined, "I brought myself under bondage to all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:70
verses.text: That is, "To preach the Gospel I was commanded, and to proclaim the things committed to my trust; but the contriving and devising numberless things beside, all that was of my own zeal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:71
verses.text: For I was only under obligation to invest the money, whereas I did every thing in order to get a return for it, attempting more than was commanded".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:72
verses.text: Thus doing as he did all things of free choice and zeal and love to Christ, he had an insatiable desire for the salvation of mankind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:73
verses.text: Wherefore also he used to overpass by a very great deal the lines marked out, in every way springing higher than the very heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:74
verses.text: Next, having mentioned his servitude, he describes in what follows the various modes of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:75
verses.text: And what are these?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:76
verses.text: "And I became," says he, "to the Jews as a Jew, that I might gain Jews".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:77
verses.text: And how did this take place? When he circumcised that he might abolish circumcision.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:78
verses.text: Wherefore he said not, "a Jew," but, "as a Jew," which was a wise arrangement.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:79
verses.text: What sayest thou? The herald of the world and he who touched the very heavens and shone so bright in grace, doth he all at once descend so low? Yea.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:80
verses.text: For this is to ascend.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:81
verses.text: For you are not to look to the fact only of his descending, but also to his raising up him that was bowed down and bringing him up to himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:82
verses.text: "To them that are under the law, as under the law, not being myself under the law, that I might gain them that are under the law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:83
verses.text: Either it is the explanation of what went before, or he hints at some other thing besides the former: calling those Jews, who were such originally and from the first: but "under the law," the proselytes, or those who became believers and yet adhered to the law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:84
verses.text: For they were no longer as Jews, yet 'under the law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:85
verses.text: ' And when was he under the law? When he shaved his head; when he offered sacrifice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:86
verses.text: Now these things were done, not because his mind changed, (since such conduct would have been wickedness,) but because his love condescended.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:87
verses.text: For that he might bring over to this faith those who were really Jews, he became such himself not really, showing himself such only, but not such in fact nor doing these things from a mind so disposed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:88
verses.text: Indeed, how could he, zealous as he was to convert others also, and doing these things only in order that he might free others who did them from that degradation?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:89
verses.text: "To them that are without law, as without law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:90
verses.text: These were neither Jews, nor Christians, nor Greeks; but 'outside of the Law,' as was Cornelius, and if there were any others like him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:91
verses.text: For among these also making his appearance, he used to assume many of their ways.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:92
verses.text: But some say that he hints at his discourse with the Athenians from the inscription on the altar, and that so he saith, "to them that are without law, as without law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:93
verses.text: Then, lest any should think that the matter was a change of mind, he added, "not being without law to God, but under law to Christ;" i-e:, "so far from being without law, I am not simply under the Law, but I have that law which is much more exalted than the older one, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:94
verses.text: that of the Spirit and of grace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:95
verses.text: Wherefore also he adds, "to Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:96
verses.text: Then again, having made them confident of his judgment, he states also the gain of such condescension, saying, "that I might gain them that are without law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:97
verses.text: And every where he brings forward the cause of his condescension, and stops not even here, but says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:98
verses.text: "To the weak became I weak, that I might gain the weak:" in this part coming to their case, with a view to which also all these things have been spoken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:99
verses.text: However, those were much greater things, but this more to the purpose; whence also he hath placed it after them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:100
verses.text: Indeed he did the same thing likewise in his Epistle to the Romans, when he was finding fault about meats; and so in many other places.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:101
verses.text: Next, not to waste time by naming all severally, he saith, "I am become all things to all men, that I may by all means save some".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:102
verses.text: Seest thou how far it is carried? "I am become all things to all men," not expecting, however, to save all, but that I may save though it be but a few.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:103
verses.text: And so great care and service have I undergone, as one naturally would who was about saving all, far however from hoping to gain all: which was truly magnanimous and a proof of burning zeal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:104
verses.text: Since likewise the sower sowed every where, and saved not all the seed, notwithstanding he did his part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:105
verses.text: And having mentioned the fewness of those who are saved, again, adding, "by all means," he consoled those to whom this was a grief.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:106
verses.text: For though it be not possible that all the seed should be saved, nevertheless it cannot be that all should perish.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:107
verses.text: Wherefore he said, "by all means," because one so ardently zealous must certainly have some success.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:108
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:109
verses.text: "And I do all things for the Gospel's sake, that I may be a joint partaker thereof".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:110
verses.text: "That is, that I may seem also myself to have added some contribution of mine own, and may partake of the crowns laid up for the faithful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:111
verses.text: For as he spake of "living of the Gospel," i-e:, of the believers; so also here, "that I may be a joint partaker in the Gospel, that I may be able to partake with them that have believed in the Gospel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:112
verses.text: Do you perceive his humility, how in the recompense of rewards he places himself as one of the many, though he had exceeded all in his labors? whence it is evident that he would in his reward also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:113
verses.text: Nevertheless, he claims not to enjoy the first prize, but is content if so be he may partake with the others in the crowns laid up for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:114
verses.text: But these things he said, not because he did this for any reward, but that hereby at least he might draw them on, and by these hopes might induce them to do all things for their brethren's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:115
verses.text: Seest thou his wisdom! Seest thou the excellency of his perfection? how he wrought beyond the things commanded, not receiving when it was lawful to receive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:116
verses.text: Seest thou the exceeding greatness of his condescension? how he that was "under law to Christ," and kept that highest law, "to them that were without law," was "as one without law," to the Jews, as a Jew, in either kind showing himself preeminent, and surpassing all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:117
verses.text: This also do thou, and think not being eminent, that thou lowerest thyself, when for thy brother's sake thou submittest to some abasement.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:118
verses.text: For this is not to fall, but to descend.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:119
verses.text: For he who falls, lies prostrate, hardly to be raised up again; but he who descends shall also rise again with much advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:120
verses.text: As also Paul descended indeed alone, but ascended with the whole world: not acting a part, for he would not have sought the gain of them that are saved had he been acting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:121
verses.text: Since the hypocrite seeks men's perdition, and feigns, that he may receive, not that he may give.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:122
verses.text: But the apostle not so: as a physician rather, as a teacher, as a father, the one to the sick, the other to the disciple, the third to the son, condescends for his correction, not for his hurt; so likewise did he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:123
verses.text: To show that the things which have been stated were not pretence; in a case where he is not compelled to do or say any such thing but means to express his affection and his confidence; hear him saying, (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:124
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:125
verses.text: ) "neither life, nor death, nor angels, nor principalities, nor powers, nor things present, nor things to come, nor height, nor depth, nor any other creature, shall be able to separate us from the love of God which is in Christ Jesus our Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:126
verses.text: Seest thou a love more ardent than fire? So let us also love Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:127
verses.text: For indeed it is easy, if we will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:128
verses.text: For neither was the Apostle such by nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:129
verses.text: On this account, you see, his former life was recorded, so contrary to this, that we may learn that the work is one of choice, and that to the willing all things are easy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:130
verses.text: Let us not then despair, but even though thou be a reviler, or covetous, or whatsoever thou art, consider that Paul was ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:132
verses.text: ) "a blasphemer, and persecutor, and injurious, and the chief of sinners," and suddenly rose to the very summit of virtue, and his former life proved no hindrance to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:133
verses.text: And yet none with so great frenzy clings to vice as he did to the war against the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:134
verses.text: For at that time he put his very life into it; and because he had not ten thousand hands that he might stone Stephen with all of them, he was vexed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:135
verses.text: Notwithstanding, even thus he found how he might stone him with more hands, to wit, those of the false witnesses whose clothes he kept.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:136
verses.text: And again, when he entered into houses like a wild beast and no otherwise did he rush in, haling, tearing men and women, filling all things with tumult and confusion and innumerable conflicts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:137
verses.text: For instance, so terrible was he that the Apostles, (Acts ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:138
verses.text: ) even after his most glorious change, did not yet venture to join themselves to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:139
verses.text: Nevertheless, after all those things he became such as he was: for I need not say more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:140
verses.text: Where now are they who build up the necessity of fate against the freedom of the will? Let them hear these things, and let their mouths be stopped.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:141
verses.text: For there is nothing to hinder him that willeth to become good, even though before he should be one of the vilest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:142
verses.text: And in fact we are more aptly disposed that way, inasmuch as virtue is agreeable to our nature, and vice contrary to it, even as sickness and health.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:143
verses.text: For God hath given us eyes, not that we may look wantonly, but that, admiring his handi-work, we may worship the Creator.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:144
verses.text: And that this is the use of our eyes is evident from the things which are seen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:145
verses.text: For the lustre of the sun and of the sky we see from an immeasurable distance, but a woman's beauty one cannot discern so far off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:146
verses.text: Seest thou that for this end our eye was chiefly given? Again, he made the ear that we should entertain not blasphemous words, but saving doctrines.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:147
verses.text: Wherefore you see, when it receives any thing dissonant, both our soul shudders and our very body also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:148
verses.text: "For," saith one, (Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:149
verses.text: xxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:150
verses.text: ) "the talk of him that sweareth much maketh the hair stand upright".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:151
verses.text: And if we hear any thing cruel or merciless, again our flesh creeps; but if any thing decorous and kind, we even exult and rejoice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:152
verses.text: Again, if our mouth utter base words, it causes us to be ashamed and hide ourselves, but if grave words, it utters them with ease and all freedom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:153
verses.text: Now for those things which are according to nature no one would blush, but for those which are against nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:154
verses.text: And the hands when they steal hide themselves, and seek excuses; but if they give alms, they even glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:155
verses.text: So that if we will, we have from every side a great inclination towards virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:156
verses.text: But if thou talk to me of the pleasure which arises from vice, consider that this also is a thing which we reap more of from virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:157
verses.text: For to have a good conscience and to be looked up to by all and to entertain good hopes, is of all things most pleasant to him that hath seen into the nature of pleasure, even as the reverse is of all things the most grievous to him that knows the nature of pain; such as to be reproached by all, to be accused by our own conscience, to tremble and fear both at the future and the present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:158
verses.text: And that what I say may become more evident, let us suppose for argument's sake one man having a wife, yet defiling the marriage-bed of his neighbor and taking pleasure in this wicked robbery, enjoying his paramour.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:159
verses.text: Then let us again oppose to him another who loves his own spouse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:160
verses.text: And that the victory may be greater and more evident, let the man who enjoys his own wife only, have a fancy also for the other, the adulteress, but restrain his passion and do nothing evil: (although neither is this pure chastity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:161
verses.text: ) However, granting more than is necessary, that you may convince yourself how great is the pleasure of virtue, for this cause have we so framed our story.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:162
verses.text: Now then, having brought them together, let us ask them accordingly, whose is the pleasanter life: and you will hear the one glorying and exulting in the conquest over his lust: but the other—or rather, there is no need to wait to be informed of any thing by him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:163
verses.text: For thou shalt see him, though he deny it times without number, more wretched than men in a prison.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:164
verses.text: For he fears and suspects all, both his own wife and the husband of the adulteress and the adulteress herself, and domestics, and friends, and kinsmen, and walls, and shadows, and himself, and what is worst of all, he hath his conscience crying out against him, barking aloud every day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:165
verses.text: But if he should also bring to mind the judgment-seat of God, he will not be able even to stand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:166
verses.text: And the pleasure is short: but the pain from it unceasing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:167
verses.text: For both at even, and in the night, in the desert and the city and every where, the accuser haunts him, pointing to a sharpened sword and the intolerable punishment, and with that terror consuming and wasting him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:168
verses.text: But the other, the chaste person, is free from all these things, and is at liberty, and with comfort looks upon his wife, his children, his friends, and meets all with unembarrassed eyes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:169
verses.text: Now if he that is enamored but is master of himself enjoy so great pleasure, he that indulges no such passion but is truly chaste, what harbor, what calm will be so sweet and serene as the mind which he will attain? And on this account you may see few adulterers but many chaste persons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:170
verses.text: But if the former were the pleasanter, it would be preferred by the greater number.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:171
verses.text: And tell me not of the terror of the laws.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:172
verses.text: For this is not that which restrains them, but the excessive unreasonableness, and the fact that the pains of it are more than the pleasures, and the sentence of conscience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:173
verses.text: Such then is the adulterer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:174
verses.text: Now, if you please, let us bring before you the covetous, laying bare again another lawless passion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:175
verses.text: For him too we shall see afraid of the same things and unable to enjoy real pleasure: in that calling to mind both those whom he hath wronged, and those who sympathize with them, and the public sentence of all concerning himself, he hath ten thousand agitations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:176
verses.text: And this is not his only vexation, but not even his beloved object can he enjoy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:177
verses.text: For such is the way of the covetous; not that they may enjoy do they possess, but that they may not enjoy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:178
verses.text: But if this seem to thee a riddle, hear next what is yet worse than this and more perplexing; that not in this way only are they deprived of the pleasure of their goods, by their not venturing to use them as they would, but also by their never being filled with them but living in a continual thirst: than which what can be more grievous? But the just man is not so, but is delivered both from trembling and hatred and fear and this incurable thirst: and as all men curse the one, even so do all men conspire to bless the other: and as the one hath no friend, so hath the other no enemy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:179
verses.text: What now, these things being so acknowledged, can be more unpleasing than vice or more pleasant than virtue? Nay, rather, though we should speak for ever, no one shall be able to represent in discourse either the pain of this, or the pleasure of the other, until we shall experience it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:180
verses.text: For then shall we find vice more bitter than gall, when we shall have fully tasted the honey of virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:181
verses.text: Not but vice is even now unpleasant, and disgusting, and burdensome, and this not even her very votaries gainsay; but when we withdraw from her, then do we more clearly discern the bitterness of her commands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:182
verses.text: But if the multitude run to her, it is no marvel; since children also oftentimes, choosing things less pleasant, despise those which are more delightful and the sick for a momentary gratification lose the perpetual and more certain joy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:183
verses.text: But this comes of the weakness and folly of those who are possessed with any fondness, not of the nature of the things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:184
verses.text: For it is the virtuous man who lives in pleasure; he who is rich indeed and free indeed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:185
verses.text: But if any one would grant the rest to virtue,—liberty, security, freedom from cares, the fearing no man, the suspecting no man,—but would not grant it pleasure; to laugh, and that heartily, occurs to me, I confess, as the only course to be taken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:186
verses.text: For what else is pleasure, but freedom from care and fear and despondency, and the not being under the power of any? And who is in pleasure, tell me, the man in frenzy and convulsion, who is goaded by divers lusts, and is not even himself; or he who is freed from all these waves, and is settled in the love of wisdom, as it were in a harbor? Is it not evident, the latter? But this would seem to be a thing peculiar to virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:187
verses.text: So that vice hath merely the name of pleasure, but of the substance it is destitute.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:188
verses.text: And before the enjoyment, it is madness, not pleasure: but after the enjoyment, straightway this also is extinguished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:189
verses.text: Now then if neither at the beginning nor afterwards can one discern the pleasure of it, when will it appear, and where?  And that thou mayest more clearly understand what I say, let us try the force of the argument in an example.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:190
verses.text: Now consider.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:191
verses.text: One is enamored of a fair and lovely woman: this man as long as he cannot obtain his desire is like unto men beside themselves and frantic; but after that he hath obtained it, he hath quenched his appetite.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:192
verses.text: If therefore neither at the beginning doth he feel pleasure, (for the affair is madness,) nor in the end, (for by the indulgence of his lust he cools down his wild fancy,) where after all are we to find it? But our doings are not such, but both at the beginning they are freed from all disturbance, and to the end the pleasure remains in its bloom: nay rather there is no end of our pleasure, nor have our good things a limit, nor is this pleasure ever done away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 21:193
verses.text: Upon all these considerations, then, if we love pleasure, let us lay hold on virtue that we may win good things both now and hereafter: unto which may we all attain, through the grace and mercy, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:1
verses.text: Homily XXIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:3
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:4
verses.text: Know ye not that they which run in a race run all, but one receiveth the prize?  Having pointed out the manifold usefulness of condescension and that this is the highest perfectness, and that he himself having risen higher than all towards perfection, or rather having gone beyond it by declining to receive, descended lower than all again; and having made known to us the times for each of these, both for the perfectness and for the condescension; he touches them more sharply in what follows, covertly intimating that this which was done by them and which was counted a mark of perfectness, is a kind of superfluous and useless labor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:5
verses.text: And he saith it not thus out clearly, lest they should become insolent; but the methods of proof employed by him makes this evident.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:6
verses.text: And having said that they sin against Christ and destroy the brethren, and are nothing profited by this perfect knowledge, except charity be added; he again proceeds to a common example, and saith,  "Know ye not that they which run in a race run all, but one receiveth the prize?" Now this he saith, not as though here also one only out of many would be saved; far from it; but to set forth the exceeding diligence which it is our duty to use.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:7
verses.text: For as there, though many descend into the course not many are crowned, but this befalls one only; and it is not enough to descend into the contest, nor to anoint one's self and wrestle: so likewise here it is not sufficient to believe, and to contend in any way; but unless we have so run as unto the end to show ourselves unblameable, and to come near the prize, it will profit us nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:8
verses.text: For even though thou consider thyself to be perfect according to knowledge, thou hast not yet attained the whole; which hinting at, he said, "so run, that ye may obtain".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:9
verses.text: They had not then yet, as it seems, attained.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:10
verses.text: And having said thus, he teaches them also the manner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:11
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:12
verses.text: "And every man that striveth in the games is temperate in all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:13
verses.text: What is, "all things?" He doth not abstain from one and err in another, but he masters entirely gluttony and lasciviousness and drunkenness and all his passions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:14
verses.text: "For this," saith he, "takes place even in the heathen games.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:15
verses.text: For neither is excess of wine permitted to those who contend at the time of the contest, nor wantonness, lest they should weaken their vigor, nor yet so much as to be busied about any thing else, but separating themselves altogether from all things they apply themselves to their exercise only".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:16
verses.text: Now if there these things be so where the crown falls to one, much more here, where the incitement in emulation is more abundant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:17
verses.text: For here neither is one to be crowned alone, and the rewards also far surpass the labors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:18
verses.text: Wherefore also he puts it so as to shame them, saying, "Now they do it receive to a corruptible crown, but we an incorruptible".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:19
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:20
verses.text: "I therefore so run, as not uncertainly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:21
verses.text: Thus having shamed them from those that are without, he next brings forward himself also, which kind of thing is a most excellent method of teaching: and accordingly we find him every where doing so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:22
verses.text: But what is, "not uncertainly?" "Looking to some mark," saith he, "not at random and in vain, as ye do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:23
verses.text: For what profit have ye of entering into idol-temples, and exhibiting for-sooth that perfectness? None.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:24
verses.text: But not such am I, but all things whatsoever I do, I do for the salvation of my neighbor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:25
verses.text: Whether I show forth perfectness, it is for their sake; or condescension, for their sake again: whether I surpass Peter in declining to receive compensation, it is that they may not be offended; or descend lower than all, being circumcised and shaving my head, it is that they may not be subverted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:26
verses.text: This is, "not uncertainly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:27
verses.text: But thou, why dost thou eat in idol-temples, tell me? Nay, thou canst not assign any reasonable cause.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:28
verses.text: For "meat commendeth thee not to God; neither if thou eat art thou the better, nor if thou eat not art thou the worse".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:29
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:30
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:31
verses.text: ) Plainly then thou runnest at random: for this is, "uncertainly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:32
verses.text: "So fight I, as not beating the air".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:33
verses.text: This he saith, again intimating that he acted not at random nor in vain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:34
verses.text: "For I have one at whom I may strike, i-e:, the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:35
verses.text: But thou dost not strike him, but simply throwest away thy strength".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:36
verses.text: Now so far then, altogether bearing with them, he thus speaks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:37
verses.text: For since he had dealt somewhat vehemently with them in the preceding part, he now on the contrary keeps back his rebuke, reserving for the end of the discourse the deep wound of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:38
verses.text: Since here he says that they act at random and in vain; but afterwards signifies that it is at the risk of no less than utter ruin to their own soul, and that even apart from all injury to their brethren, neither are they themselves guiltless in daring so to act.
