verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:39
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:40
verses.text: "But I buffet my body, and bring it into bondage lest by any means, after that I have preached to others, I myself should be rejected".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:41
verses.text: Here he implies that they are subject to the lust of the belly and give up the reins to it, and under a pretence of perfection fulfil their own greediness; a thought which before also he was travailing to express, when he said, "meats for the belly, and the belly for meats".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:42
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:43
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:44
verses.text: ) For since both fornication is caused by luxury, and it also brought forth idolatry, he naturally oftentimes inveighs against this disease; and pointing out how great things he suffered for the Gospel, he sets this also down among them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:45
verses.text: "As I went," saith he, "beyond the commands, and this when it was no light matter for me:" ("for we endure all things," it is said,) "so also here I submit to much labor in order to live soberly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:46
verses.text: Stubborn as appetite is and the tyranny of the belly, nevertheless I bridle it and give not myself up to the passion, but endure all labor not to be drawn aside by it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:47
verses.text: "For do not, I pray you, suppose that by taking things easily I arrive at this desirable result.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:48
verses.text: For it is a race and a manifold struggle, and a tyrannical nature continually rising up against me and seeking to free itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:49
verses.text: But I bear not with it but keep it down, and bring it into subjection with many struggles".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:50
verses.text: Now this he saith that none may despairingly withdraw from the conflicts in behalf of virtue because the undertaking is laborious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:51
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, "I buffet and bring into bondage".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:52
verses.text: He said not, "I kill:" nor, "I punish" for the flesh is not to be hated, but, "I buffet and bring into bondage;" which is the part of a master not of an enemy, of a teacher not of a foe, of a gymnastic master not of an adversary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:53
verses.text: "Lest by any means, having preached to others, I myself should be a rejected".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:54
verses.text: Now if Paul feared this who had taught so many, and feared it after his preaching and becoming an angel and undertaking the leadership of the whole world; what can we say?  For, "think not," saith he, "because ye have believed, that this is sufficient for your salvation: since if to me neither preaching nor teaching nor bringing over innumerable persons, is enough for salvation unless I exhibit my own conduct also unblameable, much less to you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:55
verses.text: Then he comes to other illustrations again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:56
verses.text: And as above he alleged the examples of the Apostles and those of common custom and those of the priests, and his own, so also here having set forth those of the Olympic games and those of his own course, he again proceeds to the histories of the Old Testament.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:57
verses.text: And because what he has to say will be somewhat unpleasing he makes his exhortation general, and discourses not only concerning the subject before him, but also generally concerning all the evils among the Corinthians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:58
verses.text: And in the case of the heathen games, "Know ye not?" saith he: but here,  Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:59
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:60
verses.text: ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:61
verses.text: "For I would not, brethren, have you ignorant".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:62
verses.text: Now this he said, implying that they were not very well instructed in these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:63
verses.text: And what is this which thou wouldest not have us ignorant of?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:65
verses.text: "That our fathers," saith he, "were all under the cloud, and all passed through the sea; and were all baptized unto Moses in the cloud and in the sea; and did all eat the same spiritual meat; and did all drink the same spiritual drink; for they drank of a spiritual Rock that followed them: and the Rock was Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:66
verses.text: Howbeit with most of them God was not well pleased".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:67
verses.text: And wherefore saith he these things? To point out that as they were nothing profited by the enjoyment of so great a gift, so neither these by obtaining Baptism and partaking of spiritual Mysteries, except they go on and show forth a life worthy of this grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:68
verses.text: Wherefore also he introduces the types both of Baptism and of the Mysteries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:69
verses.text: But what is, "They were baptized into Moses?" Like as we, on our belief in Christ and His resurrection, are baptized, as being destined in our own persons to partake in the same mysteries; for, "we are baptized," saith he, "for the dead," i-e:, for our own bodies; even so they putting confidence in Moses, i-e:, having seen him cross first, ventured also themselves into the waters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:70
verses.text: But because he wishes to bring the Type near the Truth; he speaks it not thus, but uses the terms of the Truth even concerning the Type.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:71
verses.text: Further: this was a symbol of the Font, and that which follows, of the Holy Table.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:72
verses.text: For as thou eatest the Lord's Body, so they the manna: and as thou drinkest the Blood, so they water from a rock.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:73
verses.text: For though they were things of sense which were produced, yet were they spiritually exhibited, not according to the order of nature, but according to the gracious intention of the gift, and together with the body nourished also the soul, leading it unto faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:74
verses.text: On this account, you see, touching the food he made no remark, for it was entirely different, not in mode only but in nature also; (for it was manna;) but respecting the drink, since the manner only of the supply was extraordinary and required proof, therefore having said that "they drank the same spiritual drink," he added, "for they drank of a spiritual Rock that followed them," and he subjoined, "and the Rock was Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:75
verses.text: For it was not the nature of the rock which sent forth the water, (such is his meaning,) else would it as well have gushed out before this time: but another sort of Rock, a spiritual One, performed the whole, even Christ who was every where with them and wrought all the wonders.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:76
verses.text: For on this account he said, "that followed them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:77
verses.text: Perceivest thou the wisdom of Paul, how in both cases he points cut Him as the Giver, and thereby brings the Type nigh to the Truth? "For He who set those things before them," saith he, "the same also hath prepared this our Table: and the same Person both brought them through the sea and thee through Baptism; and before them set manna, but before thee His Body and Blood".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:78
verses.text: As touching His gift then, such is the case: now let us observe also what follows, and consider, whether when they showed themselves unworthy of the gift, He spared them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:79
verses.text: Nay, this thou canst not say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:80
verses.text: Wherefore also he added, "Howbeit with most of them God was not well-pleased;" although He had honored them with so great honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:81
verses.text: Yea, it profited them nothing, but most of them perished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:82
verses.text: The truth is, they all perished, but that he might not seem to prophesy total destruction to these also, therefore he said, "most of them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:83
verses.text: And yet they were innumerable, but their number profited them nothing: and these were all so many tokens of love; but not even did this profit them, inasmuch as they did not themselves show forth the fruits of love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:84
verses.text: Thus, since most men disbelieve the things said of hell, as not being present nor in sight; he alleges the things heretofore done as a proof that God doth punish all who sin, even though He have bestowed innumerable benefits upon them: "for if ye disbelieve the things to come," so he speaks, "yet surely the things that are past ye will not disbelieve".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:85
verses.text: Consider, for example, how great benefits He bestowed on them: from Egypt and the slavery there He set them free, the sea He made their path, from heaven he brought down manna, from beneath He sent forth strange and marvellous fountains of waters; He was with them every where, doing wonders and fencing them in on every side: nevertheless since they showed forth nothing worthy of this gift, He spared them not, but destroyed them all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:86
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:87
verses.text: "For they were overthrown," saith he, "in the wilderness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:88
verses.text: Declaring by this word both the sweeping destruction, and the punishments and the vengeance inflicted by God, and that they did not so much as attain to the rewards proposed to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:89
verses.text: Neither were they in the land of promise when He did these things unto them, but without and afar somewhere, and wide of that country; He thus visiting them with a double vengeance, both by not permitting them to see the land, and this too though promised unto them, and also by actual severe punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:90
verses.text: And what are these things to us? say you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:91
verses.text: To thee surely they belong.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:92
verses.text: Wherefore also he adds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:93
verses.text: "Now these things were figures of us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:94
verses.text: For as the gifts are figures, even so are the punishments figures: and as Baptism and the Table were sketched out prophetically, so also by what ensued, the certainty of punishment coming on those who are unworthy of this gift was proclaimed beforehand for our sake that we by these examples might learn soberness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:95
verses.text: Wherefore also he adds,  "To the intent we should not lust after evil things, as they also lusted".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:96
verses.text: For as in the benefits the types went before and the substance followed, such shall be the order also in the punishments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:97
verses.text: Seest thou how he signifies not only the fact that these shall be punished, but also the degree, more severely than those ancients? For if the one be type, and the other substance, it must needs be that the punishments should as far exceed as the gifts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:98
verses.text: And see whom he handles first: those who eat in the idol-temples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:99
verses.text: For having said, "that we should not lust after evil things," which was general, he subjoins that which is particular, implying that each of their sins arose from evil lusting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:100
verses.text: And first he said this,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:101
verses.text: "Neither be ye idolaters, as were some of them; as it is written, 'the people sat down to eat and to drink, and rose up to play.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:102
verses.text: '"  Do you hear how he even calls them "idolaters?" here indeed making the declaration, but afterwards bringing the proof.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:103
verses.text: And he assigned the cause too wherefore they ran to those tables; and this was gluttony.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:104
verses.text: Wherefore having said, "to the intent that we should not lust after evil things," and having added, nor "be idolaters," he names the cause of such transgression; and this was gluttony.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:105
verses.text: "For the people sat down," saith he, "to eat and to drink," and he adds the end thereof, "they rose up to play".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:106
verses.text: "For even as they," saith he, "from sensuality passed into idolatry; so there is a fear lest ye also may fall from the one into the other".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:107
verses.text: Do you see how he signifies that these, perfect men forsooth, were more imperfect than the others whom they censured? Not in this respect only, their not bearing with their brethren throughout, but also in that the one sin from ignorance, but the others from gluttony.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:108
verses.text: And from the ruin of the former he reckons the punishment to these, but allows not these to lay upon another the cause of their own sin but pronounces them responsible both for their injury, and for their own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:109
verses.text: "Neither let us commit fornication, as some of them committed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:110
verses.text: Wherefore doth he here make mention of fornication again, having so largely discoursed concerning it before? It is ever Paul's custom when he brings a charge of many sins, both to set them forth in order and separately to proceed with his proposed topics, and again in his discourses concerning other things to make mention also of the former: which thing God also used to do in the Old Testament, in reference to each several transgression, reminding the Jews of the calf and bringing that sin before them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:111
verses.text: This then Paul also does here, at the same time both reminding them of that sin, and teaching that the parent of this evil also was luxury and gluttony.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:112
verses.text: Wherefore also he adds, "Neither let us commit fornication, as some of them committed, and fell in one day three and twenty thousand".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:113
verses.text: And wherefore names he not likewise the punishment for their idolatry? Either because it was clear and more notorious, or because the plague was not so great at that time, as in the matter of Balaam, when they joined themselves to Baalpeor, the Midianitish women appearing in the camp and alluring them to wantonness according to the counsel of Balaam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:114
verses.text: For that this evil counsel was Balaam's Moses sheweth after this, in the following statement at the end of the Book of Numbers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:115
verses.text: (Numb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:116
verses.text: xxxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:118
verses.text: in our translation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:119
verses.text: ) "Balaam also the son of Beor they slew in the war of Midian with the sword and they brought the spoils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:120
verses.text: And Moses was wroth, and said, Wherefore have ye saved all the women alive? For these were to the children of Israel for a stumbling-block, according to the word of Balaam, to cause them to depart from and despise the word of the Lord for Peor's sake".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:121
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:122
verses.text: "Neither let us tempt Christ, as some of them also tempted, and perished by serpents".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:123
verses.text: By this he again hints at another charge which he likewise states at the end, blaming them because they contended about signs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:124
verses.text: And indeed they were destroyed on account of trials, saying, "when will the good things come? when the rewards?" Wherefore also he adds, on this account correcting and alarming them,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:125
verses.text: "Neither murmur ye, as some of them murmured, and perished by the destroyer".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:126
verses.text: For what is required is not only to suffer for Christ, but also nobly to bear the things that come on us, and with all gladness: since this is the nature of every crown.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:127
verses.text: Yea, and unless this be so, punishment rather will attend men who take calamity with a bad grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:128
verses.text: Wherefore, both the Apostles when they were beaten rejoiced, and Paul gloried in his sufferings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:129
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:130
verses.text: "Now all these things happened unto them by way of example; and they were written for our admonition, upon whom the ends of the ages are come".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:131
verses.text: Again he terrifies them speaking of the "ends," and prepares them to expect things greater than had already taken place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:132
verses.text: "For that we shall suffer punishment is manifest," saith he, "from what hath been said, even to those who disbelieve the statements concerning hell-fire; but that the punishment also will be most severe, is evident, from the more numerous blessings which we have enjoyed, and from the things of which those were but figures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:133
verses.text: Since, if in the gifts one go beyond the other, it is most evident that so it will be in the punishment likewise".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:134
verses.text: For this cause he both called them types, and said that they were "written for us" and made mention of an "end" that he might remind them of the consummation of all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:135
verses.text: For not such will be the penalties then as to admit of a termination and be done away, but the punishment will be eternal; for even as the punishments in this world are ended with the present life, so those in the next continually remain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:136
verses.text: But when he said, "the ends of the ages," he means nothing else than that the fearful judgment is henceforth nigh at hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:137
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:138
verses.text: "Wherefore let him that thinketh he standeth take heed lest he fall".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:139
verses.text: Again, he casts down their pride who thought highly of their knowledge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:140
verses.text: For if they who had so great privileges suffered such things; and some for murmuring alone were visited with such punishment, and others for tempting, and neither their multitude moved God to repent, nor their having attained to such things; much more shall it be so in our case, except we be sober.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:141
verses.text: And well said he, "he that thinketh he standeth:" for this is not even standing as one ought to stand, to rely on yourself: for quickly will such an one fall: since they too, had they not been high-minded and self-confident, but of a subdued frame of mind, would not have suffered these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:142
verses.text: Whence it is evident, that chiefly pride, and carelessness from which comes gluttony also, are the sources of these evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:143
verses.text: Wherefore even though thou stand, yet take heed lest thou fall.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:144
verses.text: For our standing here is not secure standing, no not until we be delivered out of the waves of this present life and have sailed into the tranquil haven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:145
verses.text: Be not therefore high-minded at thy standing, but guard against thy falling; for if Paul feared who was firmer than all, much more ought we to fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:146
verses.text: Now the Apostle's word, as we have seen, was, "Wherefore let him that thinketh he standeth take heed lest he fall;" but we cannot say even this; all of us, so to speak, having fallen, and lying prostrate on the ground.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:147
verses.text: For to whom am I to say this? To him that committeth extortion every day? Nay, he lies prostrate with a mighty fall.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:148
verses.text: To the fornicator? He too is cast down to the ground.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:149
verses.text: To the drunkard? He also is fallen, and knoweth not even that he is fallen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:150
verses.text: So that it is not the season for this word, but for that saying of the prophet which he spake even to the Jews, (Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:151
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:152
verses.text: )—"He that falleth, doth he not rise again?" For all are fallen, and to rise again they have no mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:153
verses.text: So that our exhortation is not concerning the not falling, but concerning the ability of them that are fallen to arise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:154
verses.text: Let us rise again then, late though it be, beloved, let us rise again, and let us stand nobly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:155
verses.text: How long do we lie prostrate? How long are we drunken, besotted with the excessive desire of the things of this life? It is a meet opportunity now to say, (Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:156
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:157
verses.text: ) "To whom shall I speak and testify?" So deaf are all men become even to the very instruction of virtue, and thence filled with abundance of evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:158
verses.text: And were it possible to discern their souls naked; as in armies when the battle is ended one may behold some dead, and some wounded, so also in the Church we might see.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:159
verses.text: Wherefore I beseech and implore you, let us stretch out a hand to each other and thoroughly raise ourselves up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:160
verses.text: For I myself am of them that are smitten, and require one to apply some remedies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:161
verses.text: Do not however despair on this account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:162
verses.text: For what if the wounds be severe? yet are they not incurable; such is our physician: only let us feel our wounds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:163
verses.text: Although we be arrived at the very extreme of wickedness, many are the ways of safety which He strikes out for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:164
verses.text: Thus, if thou forbear to be angry with thy neighbor, thine own sins shall be forgiven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:165
verses.text: "For if ye forgive men," saith He, "your heavenly Father will also forgive you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:166
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:167
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:168
verses.text: ) And if thou give alms, He will remit thee thy sins; for, "break off thy sins," saith He, "by alms".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:169
verses.text: (Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:170
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:171
verses.text: ) And if thou pray earnestly, thou shalt enjoy forgiveness: and this the widow signifieth who prevailed upon that cruel judge by the importunity of her prayer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:172
verses.text: And if thou accuse thine own sins, thou hast relief: for "declare thou thine iniquities first, that thou mayest be justified:" (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:173
verses.text: xlvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:174
verses.text: ) and if thou art sorrowful on account of these things, this too will be to thee a powerful remedy: "for I saw," saith He, "that he was grieved and went sorrowful, and I healed his ways".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:175
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:176
verses.text: lvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:177
verses.text: ) And if, when thou sufferest any evil, thou bear it nobly, thou hast put away the whole.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:178
verses.text: For this also did Abraham say to the rich man, that "Lazarus received his evil things, and here he is comforted".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:179
verses.text: And if thou hast pity on the widow, thy sins are washed away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:180
verses.text: For, "Judge," saith He, "the orphan, and plead for the widow, and come and let us reason together, saith the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:181
verses.text: And if your sins be as scarlet, I will make them white as snow; and if they be as crimson, I will make them white as wool".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:182
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:183
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:184
verses.text: ) For not even a single scar of the wounds doth He suffer to appear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:185
verses.text: Yea, and though we be come to that depth of misery into which he fell, who devoured his father's substance and fed upon husks, and should repent, we are undoubtedly saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:186
verses.text: And though we owe ten thousand talents, if we fall down before God and bear no malice, all things are forgiven us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:187
verses.text: Although we have wandered away to that place whither the sheep strayed from his keeper, even thence He recovers us again: only let us be willing, beloved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:188
verses.text: For God is merciful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:189
verses.text: Wherefore both in the case of him that owed ten thousand talents, He was content with His falling down before Him; and in the case of him who had devoured his father's goods, with his return only; and in the case of the sheep, with its willingness to be borne.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:190
verses.text: Considering therefore the greatness of His mercy, let us here make Him propitious unto us, and "let us come before His face by a full confession," (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:191
verses.text: xcv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:192
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:193
verses.text: ) that we may not depart hence without excuse, and have to endure the extreme punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:194
verses.text: For if in the present life we exhibit even an ordinary diligence, we shall gain the greatest rewards: but if we depart having become nothing better here, even though we repent ever so earnestly there it will do us no good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:195
verses.text: For it was our duty to strive while yet remaining within the lists, not after the assembly was broken up idly to lament and weep: as that rich man did, bewailing and deploring himself, but to no purpose and in vain, since he overlooked the time in which he ought to have done these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:196
verses.text: And not he alone, but many others there are like him now among the rich; not willing to despise wealth, but despising their own souls for wealth's sake: at whom I cannot but wonder, when I see men continually interceding with God for mercy, whilst they are doing themselves incurable harm, and unsparing of their very soul as if it were an enemy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:197
verses.text: Let us not then trifle, beloved, let us not trifle nor delude ourselves, beseeching God to have mercy upon us, whilst we ourselves prefer both money and luxury, and, in fact, all things to this mercy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:198
verses.text: For neither, if any one brought before thee a case and said in accusation of such an one, that being to suffer ten thousand deaths and having it in his power to rid himself of the sentence by a little money, he chose rather to die than to give up any of his property, would you say that he was worthy of any mercy or compassion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:199
verses.text: Now in this same way do thou also reason touching thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:200
verses.text: For we too act in this way, and making light of our own salvation, we are sparing of our money.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:201
verses.text: How then dost thou beseech God to spare thee, when thou thyself art so unsparing of thyself, and honorest money above thy soul?  Wherefore also I am greatly astonished to see, how great witchery lies hid in wealth, or rather not in wealth, but in the souls of those that are beguiled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:202
verses.text: For there are, there are those that utterly derided this sorcery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:203
verses.text: For which among the things therein is really capable of bewitching us? Is it not inanimate matter? is it not transitory? is not the possession thereof unworthy of trust? is it not full of fears and? dangers? nay, of murders and conspiracy? of enmity and hatred? of carelessness and much vice? is it not dust and ashes? what madness have we here? what disease?  "But," say you, "we ought not merely to bring such accusations against those that are so diseased, but also to destroy the passion".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:204
verses.text: And in what other way shall we destroy it, except by pointing out its baseness and how full it is of innumerable evils?  But of this it is not easy to persuade a lover concerning the objects of his love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:205
verses.text: Well then, we must set before him another sort of beauty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:206
verses.text: But incorporeal beauty he sees not, being yet in his disease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:207
verses.text: Well then, let us show him some beauty of a corporeal kind, and say to him, Consider the meadows and the flowers therein, which are more sparkling than any gold, and more elegant and transparent than all kinds of precious stones.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:208
verses.text: Consider the limpid streams from their fountains, the rivers which like oil flow noiselessly out of the earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:209
verses.text: Ascend to heaven and behold the lustre of the sun, the beauty of the moon, the stars that cluster like flowers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:210
verses.text: "Why, what is this," say you, "since we do not, I suppose, make use of them as of wealth?" Nay, we use them more than wealth, inasmuch as the use thereof is more needful, the enjoyment more secure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:211
verses.text: For thou hast no fear, lest, like money, any one should take them and go off: but you may be ever confident of having them, and that without anxiety or care.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:212
verses.text: But if thou grieve because thou enjoyest them in common with others, and dost not possess them alone like money; it is not money, but mere covetousness, which thou seemest to me to be in love with: nor would even the money be an object of thy desire, if it had been placed within reach of all in common.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:213
verses.text: Therefore, since we have found the beloved object, I mean Covetousness, come let me show thee how she hates and abhors thee, how many swords she sharpens against thee, how many pits she digs, how many nooses she ties, how many precipices she prepares; that thus at any rate thou mayest do away with the charm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:214
verses.text: Whence then are we to obtain this knowledge? From the highways, from the wars, from the sea, from the courts of justice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:215
verses.text: For she hath both filled the sea with blood, and the swords of the judges she often reddens contrary to law, and arms those who on the highway lie in wait day and night, and persuades men to forget nature, and makes parricides and matricides, and introduces all sorts of evils into man's life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:216
verses.text: Which is the reason why Paul entitles her "a root of these things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:217
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:218
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:219
verses.text: ) She suffers not her lovers to be in any better condition than those who work in the mines.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:220
verses.text: For as they, perpetually shut up in darkness and in chains, labor unprofitably; so also these buried in the caves of avarice, no one using any force with them, voluntarily draw on their punishment, binding on themselves fetters that cannot be broken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:221
verses.text: And those condemned to the mines at least when even comes on, are released from their toils; but these both by day and night are digging in these wretched mines.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:222
verses.text: And to those there is a definite limit of that hard labor, but these know no limit, but the more they dig so much the greater hardship do they desire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:223
verses.text: And what if those do it unwillingly, but these of their own will? in that thou tellest me of the grievous part of the disease, that it is even impossible for them to be rid of it, since they do not so much as hate their wretchedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:224
verses.text: But as a swine in mud, so also do these delight to wallow in the noisome mire of avarice, suffering worse things than those condemned ones.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:225
verses.text: As to the fact that they are in a worse condition, hear the circumstances of the one, and then thou wilt know the state of the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:226
verses.text: Now it is said that that soil which is impregnated with gold has certain clefts and recesses in those gloomy caverns.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:227
verses.text: The malefactor then condemned to labor in that place, taking for that purpose a lamp and a mattock, so, we are told, enters within, and carries with him a cruse to drop oil from thence into the lamp, because there is darkness even by day, without a ray of light, as I said before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:228
verses.text: Then when the time of day calls him to his wretched meal, himself, they say, is ignorant of the time, but his jailor from above striking violently on the cave, by that clattering sound declares to those who are at work below the end of the day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:229
verses.text: Do ye not shudder when ye hear all this? Let us see now, whether there be not things more grievous than these in the case of the covetous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:230
verses.text: For these too, in the first place, have a severer jailor, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:231
verses.text: avarice, and so much severer, as that besides their body he chains also their soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:232
verses.text: And this darkness also is more awful than that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:233
verses.text: For it is not subject to sense, but they producing it within, whithersoever they go, carry it about with themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:234
verses.text: For the eye of their soul is put out: which is the reason why more than all Christ calls them wretched, saying, "But if the light that is in thee be darkness, how great is that darkness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:236
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:237
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:238
verses.text: ) And they for their part have at least a lamp shining, but these are deprived even of this beam of light; and therefore every day they fall into countless pitfalls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:239
verses.text: And the condemned when night overtakes them have a respite, sailing into that calm port which is common to all the unfortunate, I mean the night: but against the covetous even this harbor is blocked up by their own avarice: such grievous thoughts have they even at night, since then, without disturbance from any one, at full leisure they cut themselves to pieces.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:240
verses.text: Such are their circumstances in this world; but those in the next, what discourse shall exhibit? the intolerable furnaces, the rivers burning with fire, the gnashing of teeth, the chains never to be loosed, the envenomed worm, the rayless gloom, the never-ending miseries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:241
verses.text: Let us fear them, beloved, let us fear the fountain of so great punishments, the insatiate madness, the destroyer of our salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:242
verses.text: For it is impossible at the same time to love both money and your soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:243
verses.text: Let us be convinced that wealth is dust and ashes, that it leaves us when we depart hence, or rather that even before our departure it oftentimes darts away from us, and injures us both in regard of the future and in respect of the present life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:244
verses.text: For before hell fire, and before that punishment, even here it surrounds us with innumerable wars, and stirs up strifes and contests.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:245
verses.text: For nothing is so apt to cause war as avarice: nothing so apt to produce beggary, whether it show itself in wealth or in poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:246
verses.text: For in the souls of poor men also this grievous disease ariseth, and aggravates their poverty the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:247
verses.text: And if there be found a poor covetous man, such an one suffers not punishment in money, but in hunger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:248
verses.text: For he allows not himself to enjoy his moderate means with comfort, but both racks his belly with hunger and punishes his whole body with nakedness and cold, and every where appears more squalid and filthy than any prisoners; and is always wailing and lamenting as though he were more wretched than all, though there be ten thousand poorer than he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:249
verses.text: This man, whether he go into the market-place, goes away with many a stripe; or into the bath, or into the theatre, he will still be receiving more wounds, not only from the spectators, but also from those upon the stage, where he beholds not a few of the unchaste women glittering in gold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:250
verses.text: This man again, whether he sail upon the sea, regarding the merchants and their richly-freighted ships and their enormous profits, will not even count himself to live: or whether he travel by land, reckoning up the fields, the suburban farms, the inns, the baths, the revenues arising out of them, will count his own life thenceforth not worth living; or whether thou shut him up at home, he will but rub and fret the wounds received in the market, and so do greater despite to his own soul: and he knows only one consolation for the evils which oppress him; death and deliverance from this life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:251
verses.text: And these things not the poor man only, but the rich also, will suffer, who falls into this disease, and so much more than the poor, inasmuch as the tyranny presses more vehemently on him, and the intoxication is greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:252
verses.text: Wherefore also he will account himself poorer than all; or rather, he is poorer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:253
verses.text: For riches and poverty are determined not by the measure of the substance, but by the disposition of the mind: and he rather is the poorest of all, who is always hangering after more and is never able to stay this wicked lust.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 22:254
verses.text: On all these accounts then let us flee covetousness, the maker of beggars, the destroyer of souls, the friend of hell, the enemy of the kingdom of heaven, the mother of all evils together; and let us despise wealth that we may enjoy wealth, and with wealth may enjoy also the good things laid up for us; unto which may we all attain, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:1
verses.text: Homily XXIV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:3
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:4
verses.text: There hath no temptation taken you, but such as man can bear: but God is faithful, Who will not suffer you to be tempted above that ye are able; but will with the temptation make also the way of escape, that ye may be able to endure it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:5
verses.text: Thus, because he terrified them greatly, relating the ancient examples, and threw them into an agony, saying, "Let him that thinketh he standeth take heed lest he fall; "though they had borne many temptations, and had exercised themselves many times therein; for "I was with you," saith he, "in weakness, and in fear, and in much trembling:" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:6
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:7
verses.text: ) lest they should say, "Why terrify and alarm us? we are not unexercised in these troubles, for we have been both driven and persecuted, and many and continual dangers have we endured:" repressing again their pride, he says, "there hath no temptation taken you but such as man can bear," i-e:, small, brief, moderate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:8
verses.text: For he uses the expression "man can bear," in respect of what is small; as when he says, "I speak after the manner of men because of the infirmity of your flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:9
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:10
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:11
verses.text: ) "Think not then great things," saith he, "as though ye had overcome the storm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:12
verses.text: For never have ye seen a danger threatening death nor a temptation intending slaughter:" which also he said to the Hebrews, "ye have not yet resisted unto blood, striving against sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:13
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:14
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:15
verses.text: )  Then, because he terrified them, see how again he raises them up, at the same time recommending moderation; in the words, "God is faithful, Who will not suffer you to be tempted above that ye are able".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:16
verses.text: There are therefore temptations which we are not able to bear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:17
verses.text: And what are these? All, so to speak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:18
verses.text: For the ability lies in God's gracious influence; a power which we draw down by our own will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:19
verses.text: Wherefore that thou mayest know and see that not only those which exceed our power, but not even these which are "common to man" is it possible without assistance from God easily to bear, he added,  "But will with the temptation also make the way of escape, that ye may be able to endure it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:20
verses.text: For, saith he, not even those moderate temptations, as I was remarking, may we bear by our own power: but even in them we require aid from Him in our warfare that we may pass through them, and until we have passed, bear them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:21
verses.text: For He gives patience and brings on a speedy release; so that in this way also the temptation becomes bearable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:22
verses.text: This he covertly intimates, saying, "will also make the way of escape, that ye may be able to bear it:" and all things he refers to Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:23
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:24
verses.text: "Wherefore, my brethren, flee from idolatry".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:25
verses.text: Again he courts them by the name of kindred, and urges them to be rid of this sin with all speed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:26
verses.text: For he did not say, simply, depart, but "flee;" and he calls the matter "idolatry," and no longer bids them quit it merely on account of the injury to their neighbor, but signifies that the very thing of itself is sufficient to bring a great destruction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:27
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:28
verses.text: "I speak as to wise men: judge ye what I say".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:29
verses.text: Because he hath cried out aloud and heightened the accusation, calling it idolatry; that he might not seem to exasperate them and to make his speech disgusting, in what follows he refers the decision to them, and sets his judges down on their tribunal with an encomium.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:30
verses.text: "For I speak as to wise men," saith he: which is the mark of one very confident of his own rights, that he should make the accused himself the judge of his allegations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:31
verses.text: Thus also he more elevates the hearer, when he discourses not as commanding nor as laying down the law, but as advising with them and as actually pleading before them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:32
verses.text: For with the Jews, as more foolishly and childishly disposed, God did not so discourse, nor did He in every instance acquaint them with the reasons of the commands, but merely enjoined them; but here, because we have the privilege of great liberty, we are even admitted to be counsellors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:33
verses.text: And he discourses as with friends, and says, "I need no other judges, do ye yourselves pass this sentence upon me, I take you for arbiters".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:34
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:35
verses.text: "The cup of blessing which we bless, is it not a communion of the Blood of Christ?"  What sayest thou, O blessed Paul? When thou wouldest appeal to the hearer's reverence, when thou art making mention of awful mysteries, dost thou give the title of "cup of blessing" to that fearful and most tremendous cup? "Yea," saith he; "and no mean title is that which was spoken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:36
verses.text: For when I call it 'blessing,' I mean thanksgiving, and when I call it thanksgiving I unfold all the treasure of God's goodness, and call to mind those mighty gifts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:37
verses.text: Since we too, recounting over the cup the unspeakable mercies of God and all that we have been made partakers of, so draw near to Him, and communicate; giving Him thanks that He hath delivered from error the whole race of mankind; that being afar off, He made them nigh; that when they had no hope and were without God in the world, He constituted them His own brethren and fellow-heirs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:38
verses.text: For these and all such things, giving thanks, thus we approach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:39
verses.text: "How then are not your doings inconsistent," saith he, "O ye Corinthians; blessing God for delivering you from idols, yet running again to their tables?"  "The cup of blessing which we bless, is it not a communion of the Blood of Christ?" Very persuasively spake he, and awfully.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:40
verses.text: For what he says is this: "This which is in the cup is that which flowed from His side, and of that do we partake".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:41
verses.text: But he called it a cup of blessing, because holding it in our hands, we so exalt Him in our hymn, wondering, astonished at His unspeakable gift, blessing Him, among other things, for the pouring out of this self-same draught that we might not abide in error: and not only for the pouring it out, but also for the imparting thereof to us all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:42
verses.text: "Wherefore if thou desire blood," saith He, "redden not the altar of idols with the slaughter of brute beasts, but My altar with My blood".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:43
verses.text: Tell me, What can be more tremendous than this? What more tenderly kind? This also lovers do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:44
verses.text: When they see those whom they love desiring what belongs to strangers and despising their own, they give what belongs to themselves, and so persuade them to withdraw themselves from the gifts of those others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:45
verses.text: Lovers, however, display this liberality in goods and money and garments, but in blood none ever did so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:46
verses.text: Whereas Christ even herein exhibited His care and fervent love for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:47
verses.text: And in the old covenant, because they were in an imperfect state, the blood which they used to offer to idols He Himself submitted to receive, that He might separate them from those idols; which very thing again was a proof of His unspeakable affection: but here He transferred the service to that which is far more awful and glorious, changing the very sacrifice itself, and instead of the slaughter of irrational creatures, commanding to offer up Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:48
verses.text: "The bread which we break, is it not a communion of the Body of Christ?" Wherefore said he not, the participation? Because he intended to express something more and to point out how close was the union: in that we communicate not only by participating and partaking, but also by being united.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:49
verses.text: For as that body is united to Christ, so also are we united to him by this bread.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:50
verses.text: But why adds he also, "which we break?" For although in the Eucharist one may see this done, yet on the cross not so, but the very contrary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:51
verses.text: For, "A bone of Him," saith one, "shall not be broken".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:52
verses.text: But that which He suffered not on the cross, this He suffers in the oblation for thy sake, and submits to be broken, that he may fill all men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:53
verses.text: Further, because he said, "a communion of the Body," and that which communicates is another thing from that whereof it communicates; even this which seemeth to be but a small difference, he took away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:54
verses.text: For having said, "a communion of the Body," he sought again to express something nearer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:55
verses.text: Wherefore also he added,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:56
verses.text: "For we, who are many, are one bread, one body".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:57
verses.text: "For why speak I of communion?" saith he, "we are that self-same body".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:58
verses.text: For what is the bread? The Body of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:59
verses.text: And what do they become who partake of it? The Body of Christ: not many bodies, but one body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:60
verses.text: For as the bread consisting of many grains is made one, so that the grains no where appear; they exist indeed, but their difference is not seen by reason of their conjunction; so are we conjoined both with each other and with Christ: there not being one body for thee, and another for thy neighbor to be nourished by, but the very same for all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:61
verses.text: Wherefore also he adds,  "For we all partake of the one bread".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:62
verses.text: Now if we are all nourished of the same and all become the same, why do we not also show forth the same love, and become also in this respect one? For this was the old way too in the time of our forefathers: "for the multitude of them that believed," saith the text, "were of one heart and soul".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:63
verses.text: (Acts iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:64
verses.text: ) Not so, however, now, but altogether the reverse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:65
verses.text: Many and various are the contests betwixt all, and worse than wild beasts are we affected towards each other's members.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:66
verses.text: And Christ indeed made thee so far remote, one with himself: but thou dost not deign to be united even to thy brother with due exactness, but separatest thyself, having had the privilege of so great love and life from the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:67
verses.text: For he gave not simply even His own body; but because the former nature of the flesh which was framed out of earth, had first become deadened by sin and destitute of life; He brought in, as one may say, another sort of dough and leaven, His own flesh, by nature indeed the same, but free from sin and full of life; and gave to all to partake thereof, that being nourished by this and laying aside the old dead material, we might be blended together unto that which is living and eternal, by means of this table.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:68
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:69
verses.text: "Behold Israel after the flesh: have not they which eat the sacrifices communion with the altar?"  Again, from the old covenant he leads them unto this point also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:70
verses.text: For because they were far beneath the greatness of the things which had been spoken, he persuades them both from former things and from those to which they were accustomed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:71
verses.text: And he says well, "according to the flesh," as though they themselves were according to the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:72
verses.text: And what he says is of this nature: "even from persons of the grosser sort ye may be instructed that they who eat the sacrifices, have communion with the altar".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:73
verses.text: Dost thou see how he intimates that they who seemed to be perfect have not perfect knowledge, if they know not even this, that the result of these sacrifices to many oftentimes is a certain communion and friendship with devils, the practice drawing them on by degrees? For if among men the fellowship of salt and the table becomes an occasion and token of friendship, it is possible that this may happen also in the case of devils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:74
verses.text: But do thou, I pray, consider, how with regard to the Jews he said not, "they are par-takers with God," but, "they have communion with the altar;" for what was placed thereon was burnt: but in respect to the Body of Christ, not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:75
verses.text: But how? It is "a Communion of the Lord's Body".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:76
verses.text: For not with the altar, but with Christ Himself, do we have communion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:77
verses.text: But having said that they have "communion with the altar," afterwards fearing lest he should seem to discourse as if the idols had any power and could do some injury, see again how he overthrows them, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:78
verses.text: "What say I then? That an idol is any thing? or that a thing sacrificed to idols is any thing?"  As if he had said, "Now these things I affirm, and try to withdraw you from the idols, not as though they could do any injury or had any power: for an idol is nothing; but I wish you to despise them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:79
verses.text: "And if thou wilt have us despise them," saith one, "wherefore dost thou carefully withdraw us from them?" Because they are not offered to thy Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:80
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:81
verses.text: "For that which the Gentiles sacrifice," saith he, "they sacrifice to demons, and not to God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:82
verses.text: Do not then run to the contrary things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:83
verses.text: For neither if thou wert a king's son, and having the privilege of thy father's table, shouldest leave it and choose to partake of the table of the condemned and the prisoners in the dungeon, would thy father permit it, but with great vehemence he would withdraw thee; not as though the table could harm thee, but because it disgraces thy nobility and the royal table.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:84
verses.text: For verily these too are servants who have offended; dishonored, condemned, prisoners reserved for intolerable punishment, accountable for ten thousand crimes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:85
verses.text: How then art thou not ashamed to imitate the gluttonous and vulgar crew, in that when these condemned persons set out a table, thou runnest thither and partakest of the viands? Here is the cause why I seek to withdraw thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:86
verses.text: For the intention of the sacrificers, and the person of the receivers, maketh the things set before thee unclean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:87
verses.text: "And I would not that ye should have communion with demon".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:88
verses.text: Perceivest thou the kindness of a careful father? Perceivest thou also the very word, what force it hath to express his feeling? "For it is my wish," saith he, "that you have nothing in common with them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:89
verses.text: Next, because he brought in the saying by way of exhortation, lest any of the grosser sort should make light of it as having license, because he said, "I would not," and, "judge ye;" he positively affirms in what follows and lays down the law, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:90
verses.text: "Ye cannot drink the cup of the Lord, and the cup of demons: ye cannot partake of the Lord's table, and of the table of demons".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:91
verses.text: And he contents himself with the mere terms, for the purpose of keeping them away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:92
verses.text: Then, speaking also to their sense of shame,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:93
verses.text: "Do we provoke the Lord to jealousy? are we stronger than He?" i-e:, "Are we tempting Him, whether He is able to punish us, and irritating Him by going over to the adversaries and taking our stand with His enemies?" And this he said, reminding them of an ancient history and of their fathers' transgression.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:94
verses.text: Wherefore also he makes use of this expression, which Moses likewise of old used against the Jews, accusing them of idolatry in the person of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:95
verses.text: "For they," saith He, "moved Me to jealousy with that which is not God; they provoked Me to anger with their idols".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:96
verses.text: (Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:97
verses.text: xxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:98
verses.text: )  "Are we stronger than He?" Dost thou see how terribly, how awfully he rebukes them, thoroughly shaking their very nerves, and by his way of reducing them to an absurdity, touching them to the quick and bringing down their pride? "Well, but why," some one will say, "did he not set down these things at first, which would be most effectual to withdraw them?" Because it is his custom to prove his point by many particulars, and to place the strongest last, and to prevail by proving more than was necessary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:99
verses.text: On this account then, he began from the lesser topics, and so made his way to that which is the sum of all evils: since thus that last point also became more easily admitted, their mind having been smoothed down by the things said before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:100
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:102
verses.text: "All things are lawful for me, but all things are not expedient: all things are lawful for me, but all things edify not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:103
verses.text: Let no man seek his own, but each his neighbor's good".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:104
verses.text: Seest thou his exact wisdom? Because it was likely that they might say, "I am perfect and master of myself, and it does me no harm to partake of what is set before me;" "Even so," saith he, "perfect thou art and master of thyself; do not however look to this, but whether the result involve not injury, nay subversion".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:105
verses.text: For both these he mentioned, saying, "All things are not expedient, all things edify not;" and using the former with reference to one's self, the latter, to one's brother: since the clause, "are not expedient," is a covert intimation of the ruin of the person to whom he speaks; but the clause, "edify not," of the stumbling block to the brother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:106
verses.text: Wherefore also he adds, "Let no man seek his own;" which he every where through the whole Epistle insists upon and in that to the Romans; when he says, "For even Christ pleased not Himself:" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:107
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:108
verses.text: ) and again, "Even as I please all men in all things, not seeking mine own profit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:109
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:110
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:111
verses.text: ) And again in this place; he does not, however, fully work it out here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:112
verses.text: That is, since in what had gone before he had established it at length, and shown that he no where "seeks his own," but both "to the Jews became as a Jew and to them that are without law as without law," and used not his own "liberty" and "right" at random, but to the profit of all, serving all; he here broke off, content with a few words, by these few guiding them to the remembrance of all which had been said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:113
verses.text: These things therefore knowing, let us also, beloved, consult for the good of the brethren and preserve unity with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:114
verses.text: For to this that fearful and tremendous sacrifice leads us, warning us above all things to approach it with one mind and fervent love, and thereby becoming eagles, so to mount up to the very heaven, nay, even beyond the heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:115
verses.text: "For wheresoever the carcase is," saith He, "there also will be the eagles," (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:116
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:117
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:118
verses.text: ) calling His body a carcase by reason of His death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:119
verses.text: For unless He had fallen, we should not have risen again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:120
verses.text: But He calls us eagles, implying that he who draws nigh to this Body must be on high and have nothing common with the earth, nor wind himself downwards and creep along; but must ever be soaring heavenwards, and look on the Sun of Righteousness, and have the eye of his mind quick-sighted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:121
verses.text: For eagles, not daws, have a right to this table.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:122
verses.text: Those also shall then meet Him descending from heaven, who now worthily have this privilege, even as they who do so unworthily, shall suffer the extremest torments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:123
verses.text: For if one would not inconsiderately receive a king—(why say I a king? nay were it but a royal robe, one would not inconsiderately touch it with unclean hands;)—though he should be in solitude, though alone, though no man were at hand: and yet the robe is nought but certain threads spun by worms: and if thou admirest the dye, this too is the blood of a dead fish; nevertheless, one would not choose to venture on it with polluted hands: I say now, if even a man's garment be what one would not venture inconsiderately to touch, what shall we say of the Body of Him Who is God over all, spotless, pure, associate with the Divine Nature, the Body whereby we are, and live; whereby the gates of hell were broken down and the sanctuaries of heaven opened? how shall we receive this with so great insolence? Let us not, I pray you, let us not slay ourselves by our irreverence, but with all awfulness and purity draw nigh to It; and when thou seest It set before thee, say thou to thyself, "Because of this Body am I no longer earth and ashes, no longer a prisoner, but free: because of this I hope for heaven, and to receive the good things therein, immortal life, the portion of angels, converse with Christ; this Body, nailed and scourged, was more than death could stand against; this Body the very sun saw sacrificed, and turned aside his beams; for this both the veil was rent in that moment, and rocks were burst asunder, and all the earth was shaken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:124
verses.text: This is even that Body, the blood-stained, the pierced, and that out of which gushed the saving fountains, the one of blood, the other of water, for all the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:125
verses.text: Wouldest thou from another source also learn its power? Ask of her diseased with an issue of blood, who laid hold not of Itself, but of the garment with which It was clad; nay not of the whole of this, but of the hem: ask of the sea, which bare It on its back: ask even of the Devil himself, and say, "Whence hast thou that incurable stroke? whence hast thou no longer any power? Whence art thou captive? By whom hast thou been seized in thy flight?" And he will give no other answer than this, "The Body that was crucified".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:126
verses.text: By this were his goads broken in pieces; by this was his head crushed; by this were the powers and the principalities made a show of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:127
verses.text: "For," saith he, "having put off from himself principalities and powers, He made a show of them openly, triumphing over them in it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:128
verses.text: (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:129
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:130
verses.text: )  Ask also Death, and say, "whence is it that thy sting hath been taken away? thy victory abolished? thy sinews cut out? and thou become the laughing-stock of girls and children, who wast before a terror even to kings and to all righteous men?" And he will ascribe it to this Body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:131
verses.text: For when this was crucified, then were the dead raised up, then was that prison burst, and the gates of brass were broken, and the dead were loosed, and the keepers of hell-gate all cowered in fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:132
verses.text: And yet, had He been one of the many, death on the contrary should have become more mighty; but it was not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:133
verses.text: For He was not one of the many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:134
verses.text: Therefore was death dissolved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:135
verses.text: And as they who take food which they are unable to retain, on account of that vomit up also what was before lodged in them; so also it happened unto death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:136
verses.text: That Body, which he could not digest, he received: and therefore had to cast forth that which he had within him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:137
verses.text: Yea, he travailed in pain, whilst he held Him, and was straitened until He vomited Him up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:138
verses.text: Wherefore saith the Apostle, "Having loosed the pains of death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:139
verses.text: (Acts xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:140
verses.text: ) For never woman labouring of child was so full of anguish as he was torn and racked in sunder, while he held the Body of the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:141
verses.text: And that which happened to the Babylonian dragon, when, having taken the food it burst asunder in the midst, this also happened unto him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:142
verses.text: For Christ came not forth again by the mouth of death, but having burst asunder and ripped up in the very midst, the belly of the dragon, thus from His secret chambers (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:143
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:144
verses.text: ) right gloriously He issued forth and flung abroad His beams not to this heaven alone, but to the very throne most high.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:145
verses.text: For even thither did He carry it up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:146
verses.text: This Body hath He given to us both to hold and to eat; a thing appropriate to intense love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:147
verses.text: For those whom we kiss vehemently, we oft-times even bite with our teeth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:148
verses.text: Wherefore also Job, indicating the love of his servants towards him, said, that they ofttimes, out of their great affection towards him, said, "Oh! that we were filled with his flesh!" (Job xxxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:149
verses.text: ) Even so Christ hath given to us to be filled with His flesh, drawing us on to greater love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:150
verses.text: Let us draw nigh to Him then with fervency and with inflamed love, that we may not have to endure punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:151
verses.text: For in proportion to the greatness of the benefits bestowed on us, so much the more exceedingly are we chastised when we show ourselves unworthy of the bountifulness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:152
verses.text: This Body, even lying in a manger, Magi reverenced.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:153
verses.text: Yea, men profane and barbarous, leaving their country and their home, both set out on a long journey, and when they came, with fear and great trembling worshipped Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:154
verses.text: Let us, then, at least imitate those Barbarians, we who are citizens of heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:155
