verses.text: For they indeed when they saw Him but in a manger, and in a hut, and no such thing was in sight as thou beholdest now, drew nigh with great awe; but thou beholdest Him not in the manger but on the altar, not a woman holding Him in her arms, but the priest standing by, and the Spirit with exceeding bounty hovering over the gifts set before us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:156
verses.text: Thou dost not see merely this Body itself as they did, but thou knowest also Its power, and the whole economy, and art ignorant of none of the holy things which are brought to pass by It, having been exactly initiated into all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:157
verses.text: Let us therefore rouse ourselves up and be filled with horror, and let us show forth a reverence far beyond that of those Barbarians; that we may not by random and careless approaches heap fire upon our own heads.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:158
verses.text: But these things I say, not to keep us from approaching, but to keep us from approaching without consideration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:159
verses.text: For as the approaching at random is dangerous, so the not communicating in those mystical suppers is famine and death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:160
verses.text: For this Table is the sinews of our soul, the bond of our mind, the foundation of our confidence, our hope, our salvation, our light, our life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:161
verses.text: When with this sacrifice we depart into the outer world, with much confidence we shall tread the sacred threshold, fenced round on every side as with a kind of golden armor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:162
verses.text: And why speak I of the world to come? Since here this mystery makes earth become to thee a heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:163
verses.text: Open only for once the gates of heaven and look in; nay, rather not of heaven, but of the heaven of heavens; and then thou wilt behold what I have been speaking of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:164
verses.text: For what is there most precious of all, this will I show thee lying upon the earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:165
verses.text: For as in royal palaces, what is most glorious of all is not walls, nor golden roofs, but the person of the king sitting on the throne; so likewise in heaven the Body of the King.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:166
verses.text: But this, thou art now permitted to see upon earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:167
verses.text: For it is not angels, nor archangels, nor heavens and heavens of heavens, that I show thee, but the very Lord and Owner of these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:168
verses.text: Perceivest thou how that which is more precious than all things is seen by thee on earth; and not seen only, but also touched; and not only touched, but likewise eaten; and after receiving It thou goest home?  Make thy soul clean then, prepare thy mind for the reception of these mysteries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:169
verses.text: For if thou wert entrusted to carry a king's child with the robes, the purple, and the diadem, thou wouldest cast away all things which are upon the earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:170
verses.text: But now that it is no child of man how royal soever, but the only-begotten Son of God Himself, Whom thou receivedst; dost thou not thrill with awe, tell me, and cast away all the love of all worldly things, and have no bravery but that wherewith to adorn thyself? or dost thou still look towards earth, and love money, and pant after gold? What pardon then canst thou have? what excuse? Knowest thou not that all this worldly luxury is loathsome to thy Lord? Was it not for this that on His birth He was laid in a manger, and took to Himself a mother of low estate? Did He not for this say to him that was looking after gain, "But the Son of Man hath not where to lay His head?" (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:171
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:172
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:173
verses.text: )  And what did the disciples? Did they not observe the same law, being taken to houses of the poor and lodged, one with a tanner, another with a tent-maker, and with the seller of purple? For they inquired not after the splendor of the house, but for the virtues of men's souls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:174
verses.text: These therefore let us also emulate, hastening by the beauty of pillars and of marbles, and seeking the mansions which are above; and let us tread under foot all the pride here below with all love of money, and acquire a lofty mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:175
verses.text: For if we be sober-minded, not even this whole world is worthy of us, much less porticoes and arcades.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 23:176
verses.text: Wherefore, I beseech you, let us adorn our souls, let us fit up this house which we are also to have with us when we depart; that we may attain even to the eternal blessings, through the grace and mercy, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:1
verses.text: Homily XXV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:3
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:4
verses.text: Whatsoever is sold in the shambles, eat, asking no question for conscience sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:5
verses.text: Having said that "they could not drink the cup of the Lord and the cup of the devils," and having once for all led them away from those tables, by Jewish examples, by human reasonings, by the tremendous Mysteries, by the rites solemnized among the idols; and having filled them with great fear; that he might not by this fear drive again to another extreme, and they be forced, exercising a greater scrupulosity than was necessary, to feel alarm, lest possibly even without their knowledge there might come in some such thing either from the market or from some other quarter; to release them from this strait, he saith, "Whatsoever is sold in the shambles, eat, asking no question".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:6
verses.text: "For," saith he, "if thou eat in ignorance and not knowingly, thou art not subject to the punishment: it being thenceforth a matter not of greediness, but of ignorance".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:7
verses.text: Nor doth he free the man only from this anxiety, but also from another, establishing them in thorough security and liberty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:8
verses.text: For he doth not even suffer them to "question;" i-e:, to search and enquire, whether it be an idol-sacrifice or no such thing; but simply to eat every thing which comes from the market, not even acquainting one's self with so much as this, what it is that is set before us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:9
verses.text: So that even he that eateth, if in ignorance, may be rid of anxiety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:10
verses.text: For such is the nature of those things which are not in their essence evil, but through the man's intention make him unclean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:11
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, "asking no question".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:12
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:13
verses.text: "For to the Lord belongeth the earth and the fulness thereof".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:14
verses.text: Not to the devils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:15
verses.text: Now if the earth and the fruits and the beasts be all His, nothing is unclean: but it becomes unclean otherwise, from our intention and our disobedience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:16
verses.text: Wherefore he not only gave permission, but also,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:17
verses.text: "If one of them that believe not biddeth you," saith he, "to a feast, and you are disposed to go; whatsoever is set before you, eat, asking no question for conscience sake".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:18
verses.text: See again his moderation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:19
verses.text: For he did not command and make a law that they should withdraw themselves, yet neither did he forbid it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:20
verses.text: And again, should they depart, he frees them from all suspicion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:21
verses.text: Now what may be the account of this? That so great curiousness might not seem to arise from any fear and cowardice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:22
verses.text: For he who makes scrupulous enquiry doth so as being in dread: but he who, on hearing the fact, abstains, abstains as out of contempt and hatred and aversion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:23
verses.text: Wherefore Paul, purposing to establish both points, saith, "Whatsoever is set before you, eat".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:24
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:25
verses.text: "But if any man say unto you, This hath been offered in sacrifice unto idols; eat not, for his sake that showed it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:26
verses.text: Thus it is not at all for any power that they have but as accursed, that he bids abstain from them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:27
verses.text: Neither then, as though they could injure you, fly from them, (for they have no strength;) nor yet, because they have no strength, indifferently partake: for it is the table of beings hostile and degraded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:28
verses.text: Wherefore he said, "eat not for his sake that showed it, and for conscience sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:29
verses.text: For the earth is the Lord's and the fulness thereof".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:30
verses.text: Seest thou how both when he bids them eat and when they must abstain, he brings forward the same testimony? "For I do not forbid," saith he, "for this cause as though they belonged to others: ("for the earth is the Lord's:") but for the reason I mentioned, for conscience sake; i-e:, that it may not be injured".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:31
verses.text: Ought one therefore to inquire scrupulously? "Nay" saith he "for I said not thy conscience, but his.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:32
verses.text: For I have already said, 'for his sake that showed it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:33
verses.text: '" And again, v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:34
verses.text: , "Conscience, I say, not thine own, but the other's".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:35
verses.text: But perhaps some one may say, "The brethren indeed, as is natural, thou sparest, and dost not suffer us to taste for their sakes, lest their conscience being weak might be emboldened to eat the idol sacrifices.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:36
verses.text: But if it be some heathen, what is this man to thee? Was it not thine own word, 'What have I to do with judging them that are without?' ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:37
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:38
verses.text: ) Wherefore then dost thou on the contrary care for them?" "Not for him is my care," he replies, "but in this case also for thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:39
verses.text: To which effect also he adds,  "For why is my liberty judged by another conscience?" meaning by "liberty," that which is left without caution or prohibition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:40
verses.text: For this is liberty, freed from Jewish bondage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:41
verses.text: And what he means is this: "God hath made me free and above all reach of injury, but the Gentile knoweth not how to judge of my rule of life, nor to see into the liberality of my Master, but will condemn and say to himself, 'Christianity is a fable; they abstain from the idols, they shun demons, and yet cleave to the things offered to them: great is their gluttony.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:42
verses.text: '" "And what then?" it may be said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:43
verses.text: "What harm is it to us, should he judge us unfairly?" But how much better to give him no room to judge at all! For if thou abstain, he will not even say this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:44
verses.text: "How," say you, "will he not say it? For when he seeth me not making these inquiries, either in the shambles or in the banquet; what should hinder him from using this language and condemning me, as one who partakes without discrimination?" It is not so at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:45
verses.text: For thou partakest, not as of idol-sacrifices, but as of things clean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:46
verses.text: And if thou makest no nice enquiry, it is that thou mayest signify that thou fearest not the things set before thee; this being the reason why, whether thou enterest a house of Gentiles or goest into the market, I suffer thee not to ask questions; viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:47
verses.text: lest thou become timid and perplexed, and occasion thyself needless trouble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:48
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:49
verses.text: "If I by grace partake, why am I evil spoken of for that for which I give thanks?" "Of what dost thou 'by grace partake?' tell me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:50
verses.text: Of the gifts of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:51
verses.text: For His grace is so great, as to render my soul unstained and above all pollution.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:52
verses.text: For as the sun sending down his beams upon many spots of pollution, withdraws them again pure; so likewise and much more, we, living in the midst of the world remain pure, if we will, by how much the power we have is even greater than his.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:53
verses.text: "Why then abstain?" say you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:54
verses.text: Not as though I should become unclean, far from it; but for my brother's sake, and that I may not become a partaker with devils, and that I may not be judged by the unbeliever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:55
verses.text: For in this case it is no longer now the nature of the thing, but the disobedience and the friendship with devils which maketh me unclean, and the purpose of heart worketh the pollution.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:56
verses.text: But what is, "why am I evil spoken of for that for which I give thanks? "I, for my part," saith he, "give thanks to God that He hath thus set me on high, and above the low estate of the Jews, so that from no quarter am I injured.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:57
verses.text: But the Gentiles not knowing my high rule of life will suspect the contrary, and will say, 'Here are Christians indulging a taste for our customs; they are a kind of hypocrites, abusing the demons and loathing them, yet running to their tables; than which what can be more senseless? We conclude that not for truth's sake, but through ambition and love of power they have betaken themselves to this doctrine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:58
verses.text: ' What folly then would it be that in respect of those things whereby I have been so benefited as even to give solemn thanks, in respect of these I should become the cause of evil-speaking?" "But these things, even as it is," say you, "will the Gentile allege, when he seeth me not making enquiry".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:59
verses.text: In no wise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:60
verses.text: For all things are not full of idol-sacrifices so that he should suspect this: nor dost thou thyself taste of them as idol-sacrifices.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:61
verses.text: But not then scrupulous overmuch, nor again, on the other hand, when any say that it is an idol-sacrifice, do thou partake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:62
verses.text: For Christ gave thee grace and set thee on high and above all injury from that quarter, not that thou mightest be evil spoken of, nor that the circumstance which hath been such a gain to thee as to be matter of special thanksgiving, should so injure others as to make them even blaspheme.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:63
verses.text: "Nay, why," saith he, "do I not say to the Gentile, 'I eat, I am no wise injured, and I do not this as one in friendship with the demons'?" Because thou canst not persuade him, even though thou shouldst say it ten thousand times: weak as he is and hostile.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:64
verses.text: For if thy brother hath not yet been persuaded by thee, much less the enemy and the Gentile.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:65
verses.text: If he is possessed by his consciousness of the idol-sacrifice, much more the unbeliever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:66
verses.text: And besides, what occasion have we for so great trouble?  "What then? whereas we have known Christ and give thanks, while they blaspheme, shall we therefore abandon this custom also?" Far from it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:67
verses.text: For the thing is not the same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:68
verses.text: For in the one case, great is our gain from bearing the reproach; but in the other, there will be no advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:69
verses.text: Wherefore also he said before, "for neither if we eat, are we the better; nor if we eat not, are we the worse".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:71
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:72
verses.text: ) And besides this too he showed that the thing was to be avoided, so that even on another ground ought they to be abstained from, not on this account only but also for the other reasons which he assigned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:73
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:74
verses.text: "Whether therefore ye eat, or drink, or whatsoever ye do, do all to the glory of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:75
verses.text: Perceivest thou how from the subject before him, he carried out the exhortation to what was general, giving us one, the most excellent of all aims, that God in all things should be glorified?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:76
verses.text: "Give no occasion of stumbling, either to Jews, or to Greeks, or to the Church of God:" i-e:, give no handle to anyone: since in the case supposed, both thy brother is offended, and the Jew will the more hate and condemn thee, and the Gentile in like manner deride thee even as a gluttonous man and a hypocrite.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:77
verses.text: Not only, however, should the brethren receive no hurt from us, but to the utmost of our power not even those that are without.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:78
verses.text: For if we are "light," and "leaven," and "luminaries," and "salt," we ought to enlighten, not to darken; to bind, not to loosen; to draw to ourselves the unbelievers, not to drive them away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:79
verses.text: Why then puttest thou to flight those whom thou oughtest to draw to thee? Since even Gentiles are hurt, when they see us reverting to such things: for they know not our mind nor that our soul hath come to be above all pollution of sense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:80
verses.text: And the Jews too, and the weaker brethren, will suffer the same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:81
verses.text: Seest thou how many reasons he hath assigned for which we ought to abstain from the idol-sacrifices? Because of their unprofitableness, because of their needlessness, because of the injury to our brother, because of the evil-speaking of the Jew, because of the reviling of the Gentile, because we ought not to be partakers with demons, because the thing is a kind of idolatry.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:82
verses.text: Further, because he had said, "give no occasion of stumbling," and he made them responsible for the injury done, both to the Gentiles and to the Jews; and the saying was grievous; see how he renders it acceptable and light, putting himself forward, and saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:83
verses.text: "Even as I also please all men in all things, not seeking mine own profit, but the profit of the many, that they may be saved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:84
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:85
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:86
verses.text: ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:87
verses.text: "Be ye imitators of me, even as I also am of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:88
verses.text: This is a rule of the most perfect Christianity, this is a landmark exactly laid down, this is the point that stands highest of all; viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:89
verses.text: the seeking those things which are for the common profit: which also Paul himself declared, by adding, "even as I also am of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:90
verses.text: For nothing can so make a man an imitator of Christ as caring for his neighbors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:91
verses.text: Nay, though thou shouldest fast, though thou shouldest lie upon the ground, and even strangle thyself, but take no thought for thy neighbor; thou hast wrought nothing great, but still standest far from this Image, while so doing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:92
verses.text: However, in the case before us, even the very thing itself is naturally useful, viz; the abstaining from idol-sacrifices.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:93
verses.text: But "I," saith he, "have done many of those things which were unprofitable also: e.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:94
verses.text: g.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:95
verses.text: , when I used circumcision, when I offered sacrifice; for these, were any one to examine them in themselves, rather destroy those that follow after them and cause them to fall from salvation: nevertheless, I submitted even to these on account of the advantage therefrom: but here is no such thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:96
verses.text: For in that case, except there accrue a certain benefit and except they be done for others' sake, then the thing becomes injurious: but in this, though there be none made to stumble, even so ought one to abstain from the things forbidden.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:97
verses.text: But not only to things hurtful have I submitted, but also to things toilsome.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:98
verses.text: For, "I robbed other Churches," saith he, "taking wages of them; ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:99
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:100
verses.text: ) and when it was lawful to eat and not to work, I sought not this, but chose to perish of hunger rather than offend another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:101
verses.text: This is why he says, "I please all men in all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:102
verses.text: "Though it be against the law, though it be laborious and hazardous, which is to be done, I endure all for the profit of others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:103
verses.text: So then, being above all in perfection, he became beneath all in condescension".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:104
verses.text: For no virtuous action can be very exalted, when it doth not distribute its benefit to others also: as is shown by him who brought the one talent safe, and was cut in sunder because he had not made more of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:105
verses.text: And thou then, brother, though thou shouldest remain without food, though thou shouldest sleep upon the ground, though thou shouldest eat ashes and be ever wailing, and do good to no other; thou wilt do no great work.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:106
verses.text: For so also those great and noble persons who were in the beginning made this their chiefest care: examine accurately their life, and thou wilt see clearly that none of them ever looked to his own things, but each one to the things of his neighbor, whence also they shone the brighter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:107
verses.text: For so Moses (to mention him first) wrought many and great wonders and signs; but nothing made him so great as that blessed voice which he uttered unto God, saying, "If Thou wilt forgive their sin," forgive; "but if not, blot me also out".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:108
verses.text: (Exod.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:109
verses.text: xxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:110
verses.text: ) Such too was David: wherefore also he said, "I the shepherd have sinned, and I have done wickedly, but these, the flock, what have they done? Let Thine hand be upon me and upon my father's house".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:111
verses.text: ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:112
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:113
verses.text: ) So likewise Abraham sought not his own profit, but the profit of many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:114
verses.text: Wherefore he both exposed himself to dangers and besought God for those who in no wise belonged to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:115
verses.text: Well: these indeed so became glorious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:116
verses.text: But as for those who sought their own, consider what harm too they received.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:117
verses.text: The nephew, for instance, of the last mentioned, because he listened to the saying, "If thou wilt go to the right, I will go to the left;" (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:118
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:119
verses.text: ) and accepting the choice, sought his own profit, did not even find his own: but this region was burned up, while that remained untouched.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:120
verses.text: Jonah again, not seeking the profit of many, but his own, was in danger even of perishing: and while the city stood fast, he himself was tossed about and overwhelmed in the sea.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:121
verses.text: But when he sought the profit of many, then he also found his own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:122
verses.text: So likewise Jacob among the flocks, not seeking his own gain, had exceeding riches for his portion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:123
verses.text: And Joseph also, seeking the profit of his brethren, found his own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:124
verses.text: At least, being sent by his father, (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:125
verses.text: xxxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:126
verses.text: ) he said not, "What is this? Hast thou not heard that for a vision and certain dreams they even attempted to tear me in pieces, and I was held responsible for my dreams, and suffer punishment for being beloved of thee? What then will they not do when they get me in the midst of them?" He said none of these things, he thought not of them, but prefers the care of his brethren above all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:127
verses.text: Therefore he enjoyed also all the good things which followed, which both made him very brilliant and declared him glorious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:128
verses.text: Thus also Moses,—for nothing hinders that we should a second time make mention of him, and behold how he overlooked his own things and sought the things of others:—I say this Moses, being conversant in a king's court, because he "counted the reproach of Christ (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:129
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:130
verses.text: ) greater riches than the treasures of Egypt;" and having cast them even all out of his hands, became a partaker of the afflictions of the Hebrews;—so far from being himself enslaved, he liberated them also from bondage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:131
verses.text: Well: these surely are great things and worthy of an angelical life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:132
verses.text: But the conduct of Paul far exceeds this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:133
verses.text: For all the rest leaving their own blessings chose to be partakers in the afflictions of others: but Paul did a thing much greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:134
verses.text: For it was not that he consented to be a partaker in others' misfortunes, but he chose himself to be at all extremities that other men might enjoy blessings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:135
verses.text: Now it is not the same for one who lives in luxury to cast away his luxury and suffer adversity, as for one himself alone suffering adversity, to cause others to be in security and honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:136
verses.text: For in the former case, though it be a great thing to exchange prosperity for affliction for your neighbor's sake, nevertheless it brings some consolation to have partakers in the misfortune.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:137
verses.text: But consenting to be himself alone in the distress that others may enjoy their good things,—this belongs to a much more energetic soul, and to Paul's own spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:138
verses.text: And not by this only, but by another and greater excellency doth he surpass all those before mentioned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:139
verses.text: That is, Abraham and all the rest exposed themselves to dangers in the present life, and all these were but asking for this kind of death once for all: but Paul prayed (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:140
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:141
verses.text: ) that he might fall from the glory of the world to come for the sake of others' salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:142
verses.text: I may mention also a third point of superiority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:143
verses.text: And what is this? That some of those, though they interceded for the persons who conspired against them, nevertheless it was for those with whose guidance they had been entrusted: and the same thing happened as if one should stand up for a wild and lawless son, but still a son: whereas Paul wished to be accursed in the stead of those with whose guardianship he was not entrusted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:144
verses.text: For to the Gentiles was he sent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:145
verses.text: Dost thou perceive the greatness of his soul and the loftiness of his spirit, transcending the very heaven? This man do thou emulate: but if thou canst not, at least follow those who shone in the old covenant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:146
verses.text: For thus shalt thou find thine own profit, if thou seekest that of thy neighbor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:147
verses.text: Wherefore when thou feelest backward to care for thy brother, considering that no otherwise canst thou be saved, at least for thine own sake stand thou up for him and his interests.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:148
verses.text: And although what hath been said is sufficient to convince thee that no otherwise is it possible to secure our own benefit: yet if thou wouldst also assure thyself of it by the examples of common life, conceive a fire happening any where to be kindled in a house, and then some of the neighbors with a view to their own interest refusing to confront the danger but shutting themselves up and remaining at home, in fear lest some one find his way in and purloin some part of the household goods; how great punishment will they endure? Since the fire will come on and burn down likewise all that is theirs; and because they looked not to the profit of their neighbor, they lose even their own besides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:149
verses.text: For so God, willing to bind us all to each other, hath imposed upon things such a necessity, that in the profit of one neighbor that of the other is bound up; and the whole world is thus constituted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:150
verses.text: And therefore in a vessel too, if a storm come on, and the steersman, leaving the profit of the many, should seek his own only, he will quickly sink both himself and them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:151
verses.text: And of each several art too we may say that should it look to its own profit only, life could never stand, nor even the art itself which so seeketh its own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:152
verses.text: Therefore the husbandman sows not so much corn only as is sufficient for himself, since he would long ago have famished both himself and others; but seeks the profit of the many: and the soldier takes the field against dangers, not that he may save himself, but that he may also place his cities in security: and the merchant brings not home so much as may be sufficient for himself alone, but for many others also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:153
verses.text: Now if any say, "each man doeth this, not looking to my interest, but his own, for he engages in all these things to obtain for himself money and glory and security, so that in seeking my profit he seeks his own:" this also do I say and long since wished to hear from you, and for this have I framed all my discourse; viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:154
verses.text: to signify that thy neighbor then seeks his own profit, when he looks to thine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:155
verses.text: For since men would no otherwise make up their mind to seek the things of their neighbor, except they were reduced to this necessity; therefore God hath thus joined things together, and suffers them not to arrive at their own profit except they first travel through the profit of others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:156
verses.text: Well then, this is natural to man, thus to follow after his neighbors' advantage; but one ought to be persuaded not from this reason, but from what pleases God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:157
verses.text: For it is not possible to be saved, wanting this; but though thou shouldest exercise the highest perfection of the work and neglect others who are perishing, thou wilt gain no confidence towards God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:158
verses.text: Whence is this evident? From what the blessed Paul declared.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:159
verses.text: "For if I bestow my goods to feed the poor, and give my body to be burned, and have not love, it profiteth me nothing," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:160
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:161
verses.text: ) saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:162
verses.text: Seeth thou how much Paul requireth of us? And yet he that bestowed his goods to feed the poor, sought not his own good, but that of his neighbor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:163
verses.text: But this alone is not enough, he saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:164
verses.text: For he would have it done with sincerity and much sympathy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:165
verses.text: For therefore also God made it a law that he might bring us into the bond of love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:166
verses.text: When therefore He demands so large a measure, and we do not render even that which is less, of what indulgence shall we be worthy?  "And how," saith one, "did God say to Lot by the Angels, 'Escape for thy life?'" (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:167
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:168
verses.text: ) Say, when, and why.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:169
verses.text: When the punishment was brought near, not when there was an opportunity of correction but when they were condemned and incurably diseased, and old and young had rushed into the same passions, and henceforth they must needs be burned up, and in that day when the thunderbolts were about to be launched.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:170
verses.text: And besides, this was not spoken of vice and virtue but of the chastisement inflicted by God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:171
verses.text: For what was he to do, tell me? Sit still and await the punishment, and without at all profiting them, be burned up? Nay, this were the extremest folly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:172
verses.text: For I do not affirm this, that one ought to bring chastisement on one's self without discrimination and at random, apart from the will of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:173
verses.text: But when a man tarries long in sin, then I bid thee push thyself forward and correct him: if thou wilt, for thy neighbor's sake: but if not, at least for thine own profit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:174
verses.text: It is true, the first is the better course: but if thou reachest not yet unto that height, do it even for this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 24:175
verses.text: And let no man seek his own that he may find his own; and bearing in mind that neither voluntary poverty nor martyrdom, nor any other thing, can testify in our favor, unless we have the crowning virtue of love; let us preserve this beyond the rest, that through it we may also obtain all other, both present and promised blessings; at which may we all arrive through the grace and mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ; Whom be the glory world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:1
verses.text: Homily XXVI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:3
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:4
verses.text: Now I praise you that ye remember me in all things, and hold fast the traditions, even as I delivered them to you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:5
verses.text: Having completed the discourse concerning the idol-sacrifices as became him, and having rendered it most perfect in all respects, he proceeds to another thing, which also itself was a complaint, but not so great a one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:6
verses.text: For that which I said before, this do I also now say, that he doth not set down all the heavy accusations continuously, but after disposing them in due order, he inserts among them the lighter matters, mitigating what the readers would else feel offensive in his discourse on account of his continually reproving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:7
verses.text: Wherefore also he set the most serious of all last, that relating to the resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:8
verses.text: But for the present he goes to another, a lighter thing, saying, "Now I praise you that ye remember me in all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:9
verses.text: Thus when the offence is admitted, he both accuses vehemently and threatens: but when it is questioned, he first proves it and then rebukes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:10
verses.text: And what was admitted, he aggravates: but what was likely to be disputed, he shows to be admitted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:11
verses.text: Their fornication, for instance, was a thing admitted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:12
verses.text: Wherefore there was no need to show that there was an offence; but in that case he proved the magnitude of the transgression, and conducted his discourse by way of comparison.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:13
verses.text: Again, their going to law before aliens was an offence, but not so great a one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:14
verses.text: Wherefore he considered by the way, and proved it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:15
verses.text: The matter of the idol-sacrifices again was questioned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:16
verses.text: It was however, a most serious evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:17
verses.text: Wherefore he both shows it to be an offence, and amplifies it by his discourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:18
verses.text: But when he doeth this, he not only withdraws them from the several crimes, but invites them also to their contraries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:19
verses.text: Thus he said not only that one must not commit fornication, but likewise that one ought to exhibit great holiness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:20
verses.text: Wherefore he added, "Therefore glorify God in your body, and in your spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:22
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:23
verses.text: ) And having said again that one ought not to be wise with the wisdom that is without, he is not content with this, but bids him also to "become a fool".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:25
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:26
verses.text: ) And where he advises them not to go to law before them that are without, and to do no wrong; he goeth further, and takes away even the very going to law, and counsels them not only to do no wrong, but even to suffer wrong.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:28
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:30
verses.text: )  And discoursing concerning the idol-sacrifices, he said not that one ought to abstain from things forbidden only, but also from things permitted when offence is given: and not only not to hurt the brethren, but not even Greeks, nor Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:31
verses.text: Thus, "give no occasion of stumbling," saith he, "either to Jews, or to Greeks, or to the Church of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:33
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:34
verses.text: )   Having finished therefore all the discourses concerning all these things, he next proceeds also to another accusation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:35
verses.text: And what was this? Their women used both to pray and prophesy unveiled and with their head bare, (for then women also used to prophesy;) but the men went so far as to wear long hair as having spent their time in philosophy, and covered their heads when praying and prophesying, each of which was a Grecian custom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:36
verses.text: Since then he had already admonished them concerning these things when present, and some perhaps listened to him and others disobeyed; therefore in his letter also again, he foments the place, like a physician, by his mode of addressing them, and so corrects the offence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:37
verses.text: For that he had heretofore admonished them in person is evident from what he begins with.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:38
verses.text: Why else, having said nothing of this matter any where in the Epistle before, but passing on from other accusations, doth he straightway say, "Now I praise you that ye remember me in all things, and hold fast the traditions, even as I delivered them to you?"  Thou seest that some obeyed, whom he praises; and others disobeyed, whom he corrects by what comes afterwards, saying, "Now if any man seem to be contentious, we have no such custom".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:39
verses.text: (ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:40
verses.text: ) For if after some had done well but others disobeyed, he had included all in his accusation, he would both have made the one sort bolder, and have caused the others to become more remiss; whereas now by praising and approving the one, and rebuking the other, he both refreshes the one more effectually, and causes the other to shrink before him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:41
verses.text: For the accusation even by itself was such as might well wound them; but now that it takes place in contrast with others who have done well and are praised, it comes with a sharper sting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:42
verses.text: However, for the present he begins not with accusation, but with encomiums and great encomiums, saying, "Now I praise you that ye remember me in all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:43
verses.text: For such is the character of Paul; though it be but for small matters he weaves a web of high praise; nor is it for flattery that he doth so: far from it; how could he so act to whom neither money was desirable, nor glory, nor any other such thing? but for their salvation he orders all his proceedings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:44
verses.text: And this is why he amplifies the encomium, saying, "Now I praise you that ye remember me in all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:45
verses.text: All what things? For hitherto his discourse was only concerning their not wearing long hair and not covering their heads; but, as I said, he is very bountiful in his praises, rendering them more forward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:46
verses.text: Wherefore he saith,  "That ye remember me in all things, and hold fast the traditions, even as I delivered them to you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:47
verses.text: It appears then that he used at that time to deliver many things also not in writing, which he shows too in many other places.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:48
verses.text: But at that time he only delivered them, whereas now he adds an explanation of their reason: thus both rendering the one sort, the obedient, more steadfast, and pulling down the others' pride, who oppose themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:49
verses.text: Further, he doth not say, "ye have obeyed, whilst others disobeyed," but without exciting suspicion, intimates it by his mode of teaching in what follows, where he saith,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:50
verses.text: "But I would have ye know, that the head of every man is Christ; and the head of every woman is the man; and the head of Christ is God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:51
verses.text: This is his account of the reason of the thing, and he states it to make the weaker more attentive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:52
verses.text: He indeed that is faithful, as he ought to be, and steadfast, doth not require any reason or cause of those things which are commanded him, but is content with the ordinance alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:53
verses.text: But he that is weaker, when he also learns the cause, then both retains what is said with more care and obeys with much readiness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:54
verses.text: Wherefore neither did he state the cause until he saw the commandment transgressed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:55
verses.text: What then is the cause? "The head of every man is Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:56
verses.text: Is He then Head of the Gentile also? In no wise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:57
verses.text: For if "we are the Body of Christ, and severally members thereof," (c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:58
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:59
verses.text: ) and in this way He is our head, He cannot be the head of them who are not in the Body and rank not among the members.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:60
verses.text: So that when he says, "of every man," one must understand it of the believer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:61
verses.text: Perceivest thou how every where he appeals to the hearer's shame by arguing from on high? Thus both when he was discoursing on love, and when on humility, and when on alms-giving, it was from thence that he drew his examples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:62
verses.text: "But the head of the woman is the man; and the head of Christ is God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:63
verses.text: Here the heretics rush upon us with a certain declaration of inferiority, which out of these words they contrive against the Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:64
verses.text: But they stumble against themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:65
verses.text: For if "the man be the head of the woman," and the head be of the same substance with the body, and "the head of Christ is God," the Son is of the same substance with the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:66
verses.text: "Nay," say they, "it is not His being of another substance which we intend to show from hence, but that He is under subjection".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:67
verses.text: What then are we to say to this? In the first place, when any thing lowly is said of him conjoined as He is with the Flesh, there is no disparagement of the Godhead in what is said, the Economy admitting the expression.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:68
verses.text: However, tell me how thou intendest to prove this from the passage? "Why, as the man governs the wife, saith he, "so also the Father, Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:69
verses.text: Therefore also as Christ governs the man, so likewise the Father, the Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:70
verses.text: "For the head of every man," we read, "is Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:71
verses.text: And who could ever admit this? For if the superiority of the Son compared with us, be the measure of the Father's compared with the Son, consider to what meanness thou wilt bring Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:72
verses.text: So that we must not try all things by like measure in respect of ourselves and of God, though the language used concerning them be similar; but we must assign to God a certain appropriate excellency, and so great as belongs to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:73
verses.text: For should they not grant this, many absurdities will follow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:74
verses.text: As thus; "the head of Christ is God:" and, "Christ is the head of the man, and he of the woman".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:75
verses.text: Therefore if we choose to take the term, "head," in the like sense in all the clauses, the Son will be as far removed from the Father as we are from Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:76
verses.text: Nay, and the woman will be as far removed from us as we are from the Word of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:77
verses.text: And what the Son is to the Father, this both we are to the Son and the woman again to the man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:78
verses.text: And who will endure this?  But dost thou understand the term "head" differently in the case of the man and the woman, from what thou dost in the case of Christ? Therefore in the case of the Father and the Son, must we understand it differently also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:79
verses.text: "How understand it differently?" saith the objector.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:80
verses.text: According to the occasion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:81
verses.text: For had Paul meant to speak of rule and subjection, as thou sayest, he would not have brought forward the instance of a wife, but rather of a slave and a master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:82
verses.text: For what if the wife be under subjection to us? it is as a wife, as free, as equal in honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:83
verses.text: And the Son also, though He did become obedient to the Father, it was as the Son of God, it was as God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:84
verses.text: For as the obedience of the Son to the Father is greater than we find in men towards the authors of their being, so also His liberty is greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:85
verses.text: Since it will not of course be said that the circumstances of the Son's relation to the Father are greater and more intimate than among men, and of the Father's to the Son, less.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:86
verses.text: For if we admire the Son that He was obedient so as to come even unto death, and the death of the cross, and reckon this the great wonder concerning Him; we ought to admire the Father also, that He begat such a son, not as a slave under command, but as free, yielding obedience and giving counsel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:87
verses.text: For the counsellor is no slave.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:88
verses.text: But again, when thou hearest of a counsellor, do not understand it as though the Father were in need, but that the Son hath the same honor with Him that begat Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:89
verses.text: Do not therefore strain the example of the man and the woman to all particulars.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:90
verses.text: For with us indeed the woman is reasonably subjected to the man: since equality of honor causeth contention.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:91
verses.text: And not for this cause only, but by reason also of the deceit ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:92
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:93
verses.text: ) which happened in the beginning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:94
verses.text: Wherefore you see, she was not subjected as soon as she was made; nor, when He brought her to the man, did either she hear any such thing from God, nor did the man say any such word to her: he said indeed that she was "bone of his bone, and flesh of his flesh:" (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:95
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:96
verses.text: ) but of rule or subjection he no where made mention unto her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:97
verses.text: But when she made an ill use of her privilege and she who had been made a helper was found to be an ensnarer and ruined all, then she is justly told for the future, "thy turning shall be to thy husband".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:98
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:99
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:100
verses.text: )  To account for which; it was likely that this sin would have thrown our race into a state of warfare; (for her having been made out of him would not have contributed any thing to peace, when this had happened, nay, rather this very thing would have made the man even the harsher, that she made as she was out of him should not have spared even him who was a member of herself:) wherefore God, considering the malice of the Devil, raised up the bulwark of this word and what enmity was likely to arise from his evil device, He took away by means of this sentence and by the desire implanted in us: thus pulling down the partition-wall, i-e:, the resentment caused by that sin of hers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:101
verses.text: But in God and in that undefiled Essence, one must not suppose any such thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:102
verses.text: Do not therefore apply the examples to all, since elsewhere also from this source many grievous errors will occur.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:103
verses.text: For so in the beginning of this very Epistle, he said, ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:104
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:106
verses.text: ) "All are yours, and ye are Christ's, and Christ is God's".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:107
verses.text: What then? Are all in like manner ours, as "we are Christ's, and Christ is God's?" In no wise, but even to the very simple the difference is evident, although the same expression is used of God, and Christ, and us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:108
verses.text: And elsewhere also having called the husband "head of the wife," he added, (Ephes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:109
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:110
verses.text: ) "Even as Christ is Head and Saviour and Defender of the Church, so also ought the man to be of his own wife".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:111
verses.text: Are we then to understand in like manner the saying in the text, both this, and all that after this is written to the Ephesians concerning this subject? Far from it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:112
verses.text: It is impossible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:113
verses.text: For although the same words are spoken of God and of men, they do not have the same force in respect to God and to men, but in one way those must be understood, and in another these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:114
verses.text: Not however on the other hand all things diversely: since contrariwise they will seem to have been introduced at random and in vain, we reaping no benefit from them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:115
verses.text: But as we must not receive all things alike, so neither must we absolutely reject all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:116
verses.text: Now that what I say may become clearer, I will endeavor to make it manifest in an example.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:117
verses.text: Christ is called "the Head of the Church".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:118
verses.text: If I am to take nothing from what is human in the idea, why, I would know, is the expression used at all? On the other hand, if I understand all in that way, extreme absurdity will result.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:119
verses.text: For the head is of like passions with the body and liable to the same things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:120
verses.text: What then ought we to let go, and what to accept? We should let go these particulars which I have mentioned, but accept the notion of a perfect union, and the first principle; and not even these ideas absolutely, but here also we must form a notion, as we may by ourselves, of that which is too high for us and suitable to the Godhead: for both the union is surer and the beginning more honorable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:121
verses.text: Again, thou hearest the word "Son;" do not thou in this case admit all particulars; yet neither oughtest thou to reject all: but admitting whatever is meet for God, e.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:122
verses.text: g.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:123
verses.text: that He is of the same essence, that He is of God; the things which are incongruous and belong to human weakness, leave thou upon the earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:124
verses.text: Again, God is called "Light".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:125
verses.text: Shall we then admit all circumstances which belong to natural light? In no wise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:126
verses.text: For this light yields to darkness, and is circumscribed by space, and is moved by another power, and is overshadowed; none of which it is lawful even to imagine of That Essence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:127
verses.text: We will not however reject all things on this account, but will reap something useful from the example.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:128
verses.text: The illumination which cometh to us from God, the deliverance from darkness, this will be what we gather from it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:129
verses.text: Thus much in answer to the heretics: but we must also orderly go over the whole passage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:130
verses.text: For perhaps some one might here have doubt also, questioning with himself, what sort of a crime it was for the woman to be uncovered, or the man covered? What sort of crime it is, learn now from hence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:131
verses.text: Symbols many and diverse have been given both to man and woman; to him of rule, to her of subjection: and among them this also, that she should be covered, while he hath his head bare.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:132
verses.text: If now these be symbols you see that both err when they disturb the proper order, and transgress the disposition of God, and their own proper limits, both the man falling into the woman's inferiority, and the woman rising up against the man by her outward habiliments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:133
verses.text: For if exchange of garments be not lawful, so that neither she should be clad with a cloak, nor he with a mantle or a veil: ("for the woman," saith He, "shall not wear that which pertaineth to a man, neither shall a man put on a woman's garments:") much more is it unseemly for these (Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:134
verses.text: xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:135
verses.text: ) things to be interchanged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:136
verses.text: For the former indeed were ordained by men, even although God afterwards ratified them: but this by nature, I mean the being covered or uncovered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:137
verses.text: But when I say Nature, I mean God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:138
verses.text: For He it is Who created Nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:139
verses.text: When therefore thou overturnest these boundaries, see how great injuries ensue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:140
verses.text: And tell me not this, that the error is but small.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:141
verses.text: For first, it is great even of itself: being as it is disobedience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:142
verses.text: Next, though it were small, it became great because of the greatness of the things whereof it is a sign.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:143
verses.text: However, that it is a great matter, is evident from its ministering so effectually to good order among mankind, the governor and the governed being regularly kept in their several places by it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:144
verses.text: So that he who transgresseth disturbs all things, and betrays the gifts of God, and casts to the ground the honor bestowed on him from above; not however the man only, but also the woman.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:145
verses.text: For to her also it is the greatest of honors to preserve her own rank; as indeed of disgraces, the behavior of a rebel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:146
verses.text: Wherefore he laid it down concerning both, thus saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:147
verses.text: "Every man praying or prophesying having his head covered, dishonoreth his head.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:148
verses.text: But every woman praying or prophesying with her head unveiled dishonoreth her head".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:149
verses.text: For there were, as I said, both men who prophesied and women who had this gift at that time, as the daughters of Philip, (Acts xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:150
verses.text: ) as others before them and after them: concerning whom also the prophet spake of old: "your sons shall prophesy, and your daughters shall see visions".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:151
verses.text: (Joel ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:152
verses.text: Acts ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:153
verses.text: )  Well then: the man he compelleth not to be always uncovered, but only when he prays.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:154
verses.text: "For every man," saith he, "praying or prophesying, having his head covered, dishonoreth his head".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:155
verses.text: But the woman he commands to be at all times covered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:156
verses.text: Wherefore also having said, "Every woman that prayeth or prophesieth with her head unveiled, dishonoreth her head," he stayed not at this point only, but also proceeded to say, "for it is one and the same thing as if she were shaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:157
verses.text: But if to be shaven is always dishonorable, it is plain too that being uncovered is always a reproach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:158
verses.text: And not even with this only was he content, but added again, saying, "The woman ought to have a sign of authority on her head, because of the angels".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:159
verses.text: He signifies that not at the time of prayer only but also continually, she ought to be covered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:160
verses.text: But with regard to the man, it is no longer about covering but about wearing long hair, that he so forms his discourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:161
verses.text: To be covered he then only forbids, when a man is praying; but the wearing long hair he discourages at all times.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:162
verses.text: Wherefore, as touching the woman, he said, "But if she be not veiled, let her also be shorn;" so likewise touching the man, "If he have long hair, it is a dishonor unto him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:163
verses.text: He said not, "if he be covered" but, "if he have long hair".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:164
verses.text: Wherefore also he said at the beginning, "Every man praying or prophesying, having any thing on his head, dishonoreth his head".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:165
verses.text: He said not, "covered," but "having any thing on his head;" signifying that even though he pray with the head bare, yet if he have long hair, he is like to one covered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:166
verses.text: "For the hair," saith he, "is given for a covering".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:167
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:168
verses.text: "But if a woman is not veiled, let her also be shorn: but if it be a shame for a woman to be shorn or shaven, let her be veiled".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:169
verses.text: Thus, in the beginning he simply requires that the head be not bare: but as he proceeds he intimates both the continuance of the rule, saying, "for it is one and the same thing as if she were shaven," and the keeping of it with all care and diligence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:170
verses.text: For he said not merely covered, but "covered over," meaning that she be carefully wrapped up on every side.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:171
verses.text: And by reducing it to an absurdity, he appeals to their shame, saying by way of severe reprimand, "but if she be not covered, let her also be shorn".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:172
verses.text: As if he had said, "If thou cast away the covering appointed by the law of God, cast away likewise that appointed by nature".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:173
verses.text: But if any say, "Nay, how can this be a shame to the woman, if she mount up to the glory of the man?" we might make this answer; "She doth not mount up, but rather falls from her own proper honor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:174
verses.text: Since not to abide within our own limits and the laws ordained of God, but to go beyond, is not an addition but a diminuation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:175
verses.text: For as he that desireth other men's goods and seizeth what is not his own, hath not gained any thing more, but is diminished, having lost even that which he had, (which kind of thing also happened in paradise:) so likewise the woman acquireth not the man's dignity, but loseth even the woman's decency which she had.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:176
verses.text: And not from hence only is her shame and reproach, but also on account of her covetousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:177
verses.text: Having taken then what was confessedly shameful, and having said, "but if it be a shame for a woman to be shorn or shaven," he states in what follows his own conclusion, saying, "let her be covered".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:178
verses.text: And he said not, "let her have long hair," but, "let her be covered," ordaining both these to be one, and establishing them both ways, from what was customary and from their contraries: in that he both affirms the covering and the hair to be one, and also that she again who is shaven is the same with her whose head is bare.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:179
verses.text: "For it is one and the same thing," saith he, "as if she were shaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:180
verses.text: But if any say, "And how is it one, if this woman have the covering of nature, but the other who is shaven have not even this?" we answer, that as far as her will goes, she threw that off likewise by having the head bare.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:181
verses.text: And if it be not bare of tresses, that is nature's doing, not her own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:182
verses.text: So that as she who is shaven hath her head bare, so this woman in like manner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:183
verses.text: For this cause He left it to nature to provide her with a covering, that even of it she might learn this lesson and veil herself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:184
verses.text: Then he states also a cause, as one discoursing with those who are free: a thing which in many places I have remarked.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:185
verses.text: What then is the cause?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:186
verses.text: "For a man indeed ought not to have his head veiled, forasmuch as he is the image and glory of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:187
verses.text: This is again another cause.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:188
verses.text: "Not only," so he speaks, "because he hath Christ to be His Head ought he not to cover the head, but because also he rules over the woman".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:189
verses.text: For the ruler when he comes before the king ought to have the symbol of his rule.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:190
verses.text: As therefore no ruler without military girdle and cloak, would venture to appear before him that hath the diadem: so neither do thou without the symbols of thy rule, (one of which is the not being covered,) pray before God, lest thou insult both thyself and Him that hath honored thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:191
verses.text: And the same thing likewise one may say regarding the woman.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:192
verses.text: For to her also is it a reproach, the not having the symbols of her subjection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:193
verses.text: "But the woman is the glory of the man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:194
verses.text: Therefore the rule of the man is natural.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:195
verses.text: Then, having affirmed his point, he states again other reasons and causes also, leading thee to the first creation, and saying thus:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:196
verses.text: "For the man is not of the woman, but the woman of the man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:197
verses.text: But if to be of any one, is a glory to him of whom one is, much more the being an image of him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:198
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:199
verses.text: "For neither was the man created for the woman, but the woman for the man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:200
verses.text: This is again a second superiority, nay, rather also a third, and a fourth, the first being, that Christ is the head of us, and we of the woman; a second, that we are the glory of God, but the woman of us; a third, that we are not of the woman, but she of us; a fourth, that we are not for her, but she for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:201
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:202
verses.text: "For this cause ought the woman to have a sign of authority on her head".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:203
verses.text: "For this cause:" what cause, tell me? "For all these which have been mentioned," saith he; or rather not for these only, but also "because of the angels".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:204
verses.text: "For although thou despise thine husband," saith he, "yet reverence the angels".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:205
verses.text: It follows that being covered is a mark of subjection and authority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:206
verses.text: For it induces her to look down and be ashamed and preserve entire her proper virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:207
