verses.text: For the virtue and honor of the governed is to abide in his obedience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:208
verses.text: Again: the man is not compelled to do this; for he is the image of his Lord: but the woman is; and that reasonably.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:209
verses.text: Consider then the excess of the transgression when being honored with so high a prerogative, thou puttest thyself to shame, seizing the woman's dress.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:210
verses.text: And thou doest the same as if having received a diadem, thou shouldest cast the diadem from thy head, and instead of it take a slave's garment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:211
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:212
verses.text: "Nevertheless, neither is the man without the woman, nor the woman without the man, in the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:213
verses.text: Thus, because he had given great superiority to the man, having said that the woman is of him and for him and under him; that he might neither lift up the men more than was due nor depress the women, see how he brings in the correction, saying, "Howbeit neither is the man without the woman, nor the woman without the man, in the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:214
verses.text: "Examine not, I pray," saith he, "the first things only, and that creation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:215
verses.text: Since if thou enquire into what comes after, each one of the two is the cause of the other; or rather not even thus each of the other, but God of all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:216
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, "neither is the man without the woman, nor the woman without the man, in the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:217
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:218
verses.text: "For as the woman is of the man, so is the man also by the woman".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:219
verses.text: He said not, "of the woman," but he repeats the expression, (from v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:220
verses.text: ) "of the man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:221
verses.text: For still this particular prerogative remains entire with the man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:222
verses.text: Yet are not these excellencies the property of the man, but of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:223
verses.text: Wherefore also he adds, "but all things of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:224
verses.text: If therefore all things belong to God, and he commands these things, do thou obey and gainsay not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:225
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:226
verses.text: "Judge ye in yourselves: is it seemly that a woman pray unto God veiled?" Again he places them as judges of the things said, which also he did respecting the idol-sacrifices.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:227
verses.text: For as there he saith, "judge ye what I say:" (c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:228
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:229
verses.text: ) so here, "judge in yourselves:" and he hints something more awful here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:230
verses.text: For he says that the affront here passes on unto God: although thus indeed he doth not express himself, but in something of a milder and more enigmatical form of speech: "is it seemly that a woman pray unto God unveiled?"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:231
verses.text: "Doth not even nature itself teach you, that if a man have long hair, it is a dishonor unto him?"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:232
verses.text: "But if a woman have long hair, it is a glory to her; for her hair is given her for a covering".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:233
verses.text: His constant practice of stating commonly received reasons he adopts also in this place, betaking himself to the common custom, and greatly abashing those who waited to be taught these things from him, which even from men's ordinary practice they might have learned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:234
verses.text: For such things are not unknown even to Barbarians: and see how he every where deals in piercing expressions: "every man praying having his head covered dishonoreth his head;" and again, "but if it be a shame for a woman to be shorn or shaven, let her be veiled:" and here again, "if a man have long hair, it is a shame unto him; but if a woman have long hair, it is a glory to her, for her hair is given her for a covering".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:235
verses.text: "And if it be given her for a covering," say you, "wherefore need she add another covering?" That not nature only, but also her own will may have part in her acknowledgment of subjection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:236
verses.text: For that thou oughtest to be covered nature herself by anticipation enacted a law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:237
verses.text: Add now, I pray, thine own part also, that thou mayest not seem to subvert the very laws of nature; a proof of most insolent rashness, to buffet not only with us, but with nature also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:238
verses.text: This is why God accusing the Jews said, (Ezek.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:239
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:241
verses.text: ) "Thou hast slain thy sons and thy daughters: this is beyond all thy abominations".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:242
verses.text: And again, Paul rebuking the unclean among the Romans thus aggravates the accusation, saying, that their usage was not only against the law of God, but even against nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:243
verses.text: "For they changed the natural use into that which is against nature".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:244
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:245
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:246
verses.text: ) For this cause then here also he employs this argument signifying this very thing, both that he is not enacting any strange law and that among Gentiles their inventions would all be reckoned as a kind of novelty against nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:247
verses.text: So also Christ, implying the same, said, "Whatsoever ye would that men should do to you, do ye also so them;" showing that He is not introducing any thing new.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:248
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:249
verses.text: "But if any man seems to be contentious, we have no such custom, neither the Churches of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:250
verses.text: It is then contentiousness to oppose these things, and not any exercise of reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:251
verses.text: Notwithstanding, even thus it is a measured sort of rebuke which he adopts, to fill them the more with self-reproach; which in truth rendered his saying the more severe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:252
verses.text: "For we," saith he, "have no such custom," so as to contend and to strive and to oppose ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:253
verses.text: And he stopped not even here, but also added, "neither the Churches of God;" signifying that they resist and oppose themselves to the whole world by not yielding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:254
verses.text: However, even if the Corinthians were then contentious, yet now the whole world hath both received and kept this law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:255
verses.text: So great is the power of the Crucified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:256
verses.text: But I fear lest having assumed the dress, yet in their deeds some of our women should be found immodest and in other ways uncovered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:257
verses.text: For therefore also writing to Timothy Paul was not content with these things, but added others, saying, "that they adorn themselves in modest apparel, with shamefacedness and sobriety; not with braided hair, or gold".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:258
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:259
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:260
verses.text: ) For if one ought not to have the head bare, but everywhere to carry about the token of authority, much more is it becoming to exhibit the same in our deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:261
verses.text: Thus at any rate the former women also used both to call their husbands lords, ( Pet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:262
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:263
verses.text: ) and to yield the precedence to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:264
verses.text: "Because they for their part," you say, "used to love their own wives".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:265
verses.text: I know that as well as you: I am not ignorant of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:266
verses.text: But when we are exhorting thee concerning thine own duties, let not theirs take all thine attention.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:267
verses.text: For so, when we exhort children to be obedient to parents, saying, that it is written, "honor thy father and thy mother," they reply to us, "mention also what follows, 'and ye fathers, provoke not your children to wrath,'" (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:268
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:270
verses.text: ) And servants when we tell them that it is written that they should "obey their masters, and not serve with eye-service," they also again demand of us what follows, bidding us also give the same advice to masters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:271
verses.text: For Paul bade them also, they saw, "to forbear threatening".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:272
verses.text: But let us not do thus nor enquire into the things enjoined on others, when we are charged with regard to our own: for neither will thy obtaining a partner in the charges free thee from the blame: but look to one thing only, how thou mayest rid thyself of those charges which lie against thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:273
verses.text: Since Adam also laid the blame on the woman, and she again on the serpent, but this did in no wise deliver them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:274
verses.text: Do not thou, therefore, for thy part, say this to me now, but be careful with all consideration to render what thou owest to thy husband: since also when I am discoursing with thy husband, advising him to love and cherish thee, I suffer him not to bring forward the law that is appointed for the woman, but I require of him that which is written for himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:275
verses.text: And do thou therefore busy thyself with those things only which belong to thee, and show thyself tractable to thy consort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:276
verses.text: And accordingly if it be really for God's sake that thou obeyest thy husband, tell me not of the things which ought to be done by him, but for what things thou hast been made responsible by the lawgiver, those perform with exactness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:277
verses.text: For this is especially to obey God, not to transgress the law even when suffering things contrary to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:278
verses.text: And by the same rule, he that being beloved loves, is not reckoned to do any great thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:279
verses.text: But he that waits upon a person who hateth him, this above all is the man to receive a crown.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:280
verses.text: In the same manner then do thou also reckon that if thy husband give thee disgust, and thou endure it, thou shalt receive a glorious crown: but if he be gentle and mild, what will there be for God to reward in thee? And these things I say, not bidding the husbands be harsh; but persuading the wives to bear even with harshness in their husbands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:281
verses.text: Since when each is careful to fulfil his own duty, his neighbor's part also will quickly follow: as when the wife is prepared to bear even with rough behavior in the husband, and the husband refrains from abusing her in her angry mood; then all is a calm and a harbor free from waves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:282
verses.text: So also was it with those of old time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:283
verses.text: Each was employed in fulfilling his own duty, not in exacting that of his neighbor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:284
verses.text: Thus, if you mark it, Abraham took his brother's son: his wife found no fault with him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:285
verses.text: He commanded her to travel a long journey; she spake not even against this but followed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:286
verses.text: Again, after those many miseries and labors and toils having become lord of all, he yielded the precedency to Lot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:287
verses.text: And so far from Sarah being offended at this, she did not even open her mouth, nor uttered any such thing as many of the women of these days utter, when they see their own husbands coming off inferior in such allotments, and especially in dealing with inferiors; reproaching them, and calling them fools and senseless and unmanly and traitors and stupid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:288
verses.text: But no such thing did she say or think, but was pleased with all things that were done by him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:289
verses.text: And another thing, and that a greater: after that Lot had the choice put in his power, and had thrown the inferior part upon his uncle, a great danger fell upon him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:290
verses.text: Whereof the patriarch hearing, armed all his people, and set himself against the whole army of the Persians with his own domestics only, and not even then did she detain him, nor say, as was likely, "O man, whither goest thou, thrusting thyself down precipices, and exposing thyself to so great hazards; for one who wronged thee and seized on all that was thine, shedding thy blood? Yea, and even if thou make light of thyself, yet have pity on me which have left house and country and friends and kindred, and have followed thee in so long a pilgrimage; and involve me not in widowhood, and in the miseries of widowhood".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:291
verses.text: None of these things she said: she thought not of them but bore all in silence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:292
verses.text: After this, her womb continuing barren, she herself suffers not the grief of women nor laments: but he complains, though not to his wife, but to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:293
verses.text: And see how each preserves his own appropriate part: for he neither despised Sarah as childless, nor reproached her with any such thing: and she again was anxious to devise some consolation to him for her childlessness by means of the handmaid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:294
verses.text: For these things had not yet been forbidden then as now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:295
verses.text: For now neither is it lawful for women to indulge their husbands in such things, nor for the men, with or without the wife's knowledge, to form such connexions, even though the grief of their childlessness should infinitely harass them: since they also shall hear the sentence, "their worm shall not die, neither shall their fire be quenched".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:296
verses.text: For now it is not permitted, but then it had not been forbidden.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:297
verses.text: Wherefore both his wife commanded this, and he obeyed, yet not even thus for pleasure's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:298
verses.text: But "behold," it will be said, "how he cast Hagar out again at her bidding".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:299
verses.text: Well, this is what I want to point out, that both he obeyed her in all things, and she him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:300
verses.text: But do not thou give heed to these things only, but examine, thou who urgest this plea, into what had gone before also, Hagar's insulting her, her boasting herself against her mistress; than which what can be more vexatious to a free and honorable woman?   Let not then the wife tarry for the virtue of the husband and then show her own, for this is nothing great; nor, on the other hand, the husband, for the obedience of the wife and then exercise self-command; for neither would this any more be his own well-doing; but let each, as I said, furnish his own share first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:301
verses.text: For if to the Gentiles smiting us on the right, we must turn the other cheek; much more ought one to bear with harsh behavior in a husband.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:302
verses.text: And I say not this for a wife to be beaten; far from it: for this is the extremest affront, not to her that is beaten, but to him who beateth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:303
verses.text: But even if by some misfortune thou have such a yokefellow allotted thee, take it not ill, O woman, considering the reward which is laid up for such things and their praise too in this present life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:304
verses.text: And to you husbands also this I say: make it a rule that there can be no such offence as to bring you under the necessity of striking a wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:305
verses.text: And why say I a wife? since not even upon his handmaiden could a free man endure to inflict blows and lay violent hands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:306
verses.text: But if the shame be great for a man to beat a maidservant, much more to stretch forth the right hand against her that is free.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:307
verses.text: And this one might see even from heathen legislatures who no longer compel her that hath been so treated to live with him that beat her, as being unworthy of her fellowship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:308
verses.text: For surely it comes of extreme lawlessness when thy partner of life, she who in the most intimate relations and in the highest degree, is united with thee; when she, like a base slave, is dishonored by thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:309
verses.text: Wherefore also such a man, if indeed one must call him a man and not rather a wild beast, I should say, was like a parricide and a murderer of his mother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:310
verses.text: For if for a wife's sake we were commanded to leave even father and mother, not wronging them but fulfilling a divine law; and a law so grateful to our parents themselves that even they, the very persons whom we are leaving, are thankful, and bring it about with great eagerness; what but extreme frenzy can it be to insult her for whose sake God bade us leave even our parents?  But we may well ask, Is it only madness? There is the shame too: I would fain know who can endure it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:311
verses.text: And what description can set it before us; when shrieks and wailings are borne along the alleys, and there is a running to the house of him that is so disgracing himself, both of the neighbors and the passers by, as though some wild beast were ravaging within? Better were it that the earth should gape asunder for one so frantic, than that he should be seen at all in the forum after it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:312
verses.text: "But the woman is insolent," saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:313
verses.text: Consider nevertheless that she is a woman, the weaker vessel, whereas thou art a man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:314
verses.text: For therefore wert thou ordained to be ruler; and wert assigned to her in place of a head, that thou mightest bear with the weakness of her that is set under thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:315
verses.text: Make then thy rule glorious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:316
verses.text: And glorious it will be when the subject of it meets with no dishonor from thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:317
verses.text: And as the monarch will appear so much the more dignified, as he manifests more dignity in the officer under him; but if he dishonor and depreciate the greatness of that rank, he is indirectly cutting off no small portion of his own glory likewise: so also thou dishonor her who governs next to thyself, wilt in no common degree mar the honor of thy governance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:318
verses.text: Considering therefore all these things, command thyself: and withal think also of that evening on which the father having called thee, delivered thee his daughter as a kind of deposit, and having separated her from all, from her mother, from himself, from the family, intrusted her entire guardianship to thy right hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:319
verses.text: Consider that (under God) through her thou hast children and hast become a father, and be thou also on that account gentle towards her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:320
verses.text: Seest thou not the husbandmen, how the earth which hath once received the seed, they tend with all various methods of culture, though it have ten thousand disadvantages; e.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:321
verses.text: g.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:322
verses.text: , though it be an unkindly soil or bear ill weeds, or though it be vexed with excessive rain through the nature of its situation? This also do thou.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:323
verses.text: For thus shalt thou be first to enjoy both the fruit and the calm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:324
verses.text: Since thy wife is to thee both a harbor, and a potent healing charm to rejoice thy heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:325
verses.text: Well then: if thou shalt free thy harbor from winds and waves, thou shalt enjoy much tranquility on thy return from the market-place: but if thou fill it with clamor and tumult, thou dost but prepare for thyself a more grievous shipwreck.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:326
verses.text: In order then to prevent this, let what I advise be done: When any thing uncomfortable happens in the household, if she be in the wrong console her and do not aggravate the discomfort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:327
verses.text: For even if thou shouldest lose all, nothing is more grievous than to have a wife without good-will sharing thine abode.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:328
verses.text: And whatever offence thou canst mention, thou wilt tell me of nothing so very painful as being at strife with her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:329
verses.text: So that if it were only for such reasons as these, let her love be more precious than all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:330
verses.text: For if one another's burdens are to be borne, much more our own wife's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:331
verses.text: Though she be poor do not upbraid her: though she be foolish, do not trample on her, but train her rather: because she is a member of thee, and ye are become one flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:332
verses.text: "But she is trifling and drunken and passionate".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:333
verses.text: Thou oughtest then to grieve over these things, not to be angry; and to beseech God, and exhort her and give her advice, and do every thing to remove the evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:334
verses.text: But if thou strike her thou dost aggravate the disease: for fierceness is removed by moderation, not by rival fierceness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:335
verses.text: With these things bear in mind also the reward from God: that when it is permitted thee to cut her off, and thou doest not so for the fear of God, but bearest with so great defects, fearing the law appointed in such matters which forbids to put away a wife whatsoever disease she may have: thou shalt receive an unspeakable reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:336
verses.text: Yea, and before the reward thou shalt be a very great gainer, both rendering her more obedient and becoming thyself more gentle thereby.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:337
verses.text: It is said, for instance, that one of the heathen philosophers, who had a bad wife, a trifler and a brawler, when asked, "Why, having such an one, he endured her;" made reply, "That he might have in his house a school and training-place of philosophy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:338
verses.text: For I shall be to all the rest meeker," saith he, "being here disciplined every day".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:339
verses.text: Did you utter a great shout? Why, I at this moment am greatly mourning, when heathens prove better lovers of wisdom than we; we who are commanded to imitate angels, nay rather who are commanded to follow God Himself in respect of gentleness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:340
verses.text: But to proceed: it is said that for this reason the philosopher having a bad wife, cast her not out; and some say that this very thing was the reason of his marrying her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:341
verses.text: But I, because many men have dispositions not exactly reasonable, advise that at first they do all they can, and be careful that they take a suitable partner and one full of all virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:342
verses.text: Should it happen, however, that they miss their end, and she whom they have brought into the house prove no good or tolerable bride, then I would have them at any rate try to be like this philosopher, and train her in every way, and consider nothing more important than this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:343
verses.text: Since neither will a merchant, until he have made a compact with his partner capable of procuring peace, launch the vessel into the deep, nor apply himself to the rest of the transaction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:344
verses.text: And let us then use every effort that she who is partner with us in the business of life and in this our vessel, may be kept in all peace within.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:345
verses.text: For thus shall our other affairs too be all in calm, and with tranquility shall we run our course through the ocean of the present life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:346
verses.text: Compared with this, let house, and slaves, and money, and lands, and the business itself of the state, be less in our account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:347
verses.text: And let it be more valuable than all in our eyes that she who with us sits at the oars should not be in mutiny and disunion with us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 25:348
verses.text: For so shall our other matters proceed with a favoring tide, and in spiritual things also we shall find ourselves much the freer from hindrance, drawing this yoke with one accord; and having done all things well, we shall obtain the blessings laid up in store; unto which may we all attain, through the grace and mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father, with the Holy Ghost, be glory, power, and honor, now and ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:1
verses.text: Homily XXVII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:3
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:4
verses.text: But in giving you this charge, I praise you not, that ye come together not for the better, but for the worse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:5
verses.text: It is necessary in considering the present charge to state also first the occasion of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:6
verses.text: For thus again will our discourse be more intelligible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:7
verses.text: What then is this occasion?  As in the case of the three thousand who believed in the beginning, all had eaten their meals in common and had all things common; such also was the practice at the time when the Apostle wrote this: not such indeed exactly; but as it were a certain outflowing of that communion which abode among them descended also to them that came after.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:8
verses.text: And because of course some were poor, but others rich, they laid not down all their goods in the midst, but made the tables open on stated days, as it should seem; and when the solemn service was completed, after the communion of the Mysteries, they all went to a common entertainment, the rich bringing their provisions with them, and the poor and destitute being invited by them, and all feasting in common.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:9
verses.text: But afterward this custom also became corrupt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:10
verses.text: And the reason was, their being divided and addicting themselves, some to this party, and others to that, and saying, "I am of such a one," and "I of such a one;" which thing also to correct he said in the beginning of the Epistle, "For it hath been signified unto me concerning you, my brethren, by them which are of the household of Chloe, that there are contentions among you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:11
verses.text: Now this I mean, that each one of you saith, I am of Paul; and I of Apollos; and I of Cephas".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:12
verses.text: Not that Paul was the person to whom they were attaching themselves; for he would not have borne it: but wishing by concession to tear up this custom from the root, he introduced himself, indicating that if any one had inscribed upon himself even his name when breaking off from the common body, even so the thing done was profane and extreme wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:13
verses.text: And if in his case it were wickedness, much more in the case of those who were inferior to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:14
verses.text: Since therefore this custom was broken through, a custom most excellent and most useful; (for it was a foundation of love, and a comfort to poverty, and a corrective of riches, and an occasion of the highest philosophy, and an instruction of humility:) since however he saw so great advantages in a way to be destroyed, he naturally addresses them with severity, thus saying: "But in giving you this charge, I praise you not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:15
verses.text: For in the former charge, as there were many who kept (the ordinances), he began otherwise, saying thus: "Now I praise you that ye remember me in all things:" but here contrariwise, "But in giving you this charge, I praise you not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:16
verses.text: And here is the reason why he placed it not after the rebuke of them that eat the idol-sacrifices.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:17
verses.text: But because that was unusually harsh he interposes the discourse about wearing of long hair, that he might not have to pass from one set of vehement reproofs to others again of an invidious kind and so appear too harsh: and then he returns to the more vehement tone, and says, "But in giving you this charge, I praise you not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:18
verses.text: What is this? That which I am about to tell you of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:19
verses.text: What is, "giving you this charge, I praise you not?" "I do not approve you," saith he, "because ye have reduced me to the necessity of giving advice: I do not praise you, because ye have required instruction in regard to this, because ye have need of an admonition from me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:20
verses.text: Dost thou perceive how from his beginning he signifieth that what was done was very profane? For when he that errs ought not to require so much as a hint to prevent his erring, the error would seem to be unpardonable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:21
verses.text: And why dost thou not praise? Because "ye come together," saith he, "not for the better but for the worse;" i-e:, because ye do not go forward unto virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:22
verses.text: For it were meet that your liberality should increase and become manifold, but ye have taken rather from the custom which already prevailed, and have so taken from it as even to need warning from me, in order that ye may return to the former order.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:23
verses.text: Further, that he might not seem to say these things on account of the poor only, he doth not at once strike in to the discourse concerning the tables, lest he render his rebuke such as they might easily come to think slightly of, but he searches for an expression most confounding and very fearful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:24
verses.text: For what saith he?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:25
verses.text: "For first of all, when ye come together in the Church, I hear that divisions exist among you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:26
verses.text: And he saith not, "For fear that you do not sup together in common;" "for I hear that you feast in private, and not with the poor:" but what was most calculated thoroughly to shake their minds, that he set down, the name of division, which was the cause of this mischief also: and so he reminded them again of that which was said in the beginning of the Epistle, and was "signified by them of the house of Chloe".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:28
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:29
verses.text: ) "And I partly believe it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:30
verses.text: Thus, lest they should say, "But what if the accusers speak falsely?" he neither saith, "I believe it," lest he should rather make them reckless; nor again, on the other hand, "I disbelieve it," lest he should seem to reprove without cause, but, "I partly believe it," saith he, i-e:, "I believe it in a small part;" making them anxious and inviting them to return to correction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:31
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:32
verses.text: "For there must be also factions among you, that they which are approved may be made manifest among you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:33
verses.text: By "factions," here he means those which concern not the doctrines, but these present divisions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:34
verses.text: But even if he had spoken of the doctrinal heresies, not even thus did he give them any handle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:35
verses.text: For Christ Himself said, "it must needs be that occasions of stumbling come," (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:36
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:37
verses.text: ) not destroying the liberty of the will nor appointing any necessity and compulsion over man's life, but foretelling what would certainly ensue from the evil mind of men; which would take place, not because of his prediction, but because the incurably disposed are so minded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:38
verses.text: For not because he foretold them did these things happen: but because they were certainly about to happen, therefore he foretold them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:39
verses.text: Since, if the occasions of stumbling were of necessity and not of the mind of them that bring them in, it was superfluous His saying, "Woe to that man by whom the occasion cometh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:40
verses.text: But these things we discussed more at length when we were upon the passage itself; now we must proceed to what is before us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:41
verses.text: Now that he said these things of these factions relating to the tables, and that contention and division, he made manifest also from what follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:42
verses.text: For having said, "I hear that there are divisions among you," he stopped not here, but signifying what divisions he means he goes on to say, "each one taketh before other his own supper;" and again, "What? have ye not houses to eat and to drink in? or despise ye the Church of God?" However, that of these he was speaking is evident.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:43
verses.text: And if he call them divisions, marvel not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:44
verses.text: For, as I said, he wishes to touch them by the expression: whereas had they been divisions of doctrine, he would not have discoursed with them thus mildly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:45
verses.text: Hear him, for instance, when he speaks of any such thing, how vehement he is both in assertion and in reproof: in assertion, as when he says, "If even an angel preach any other gospel unto you than that ye have received, let him be accursed;" (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:46
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:47
verses.text: ) but in reproof, as when he says, "Whosoever of you would be justified by the law, ye are fallen away from grace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:48
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:49
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:50
verses.text: ) And at one time he calls the corrupters "dogs," saying, "Beware of dogs:" (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:51
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:52
verses.text: ) at another, "having their consciences seared with a hot iron".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:53
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:54
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:55
verses.text: ) And again, "angels of Satan:" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:56
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:58
verses.text: ) but here he said no such thing, but spoke in a gentle and subdued tone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:59
verses.text: But what is, "that they which are approved may be made manifest among you?" That they may shine the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:60
verses.text: And what he intends to say is this, that those who are unchangeable and firm are so far from being at all injured hereby, but even shows them the more, and that it makes them more glorious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:61
verses.text: For the word, "that," is not every where indicative of cause, but frequently also of the event of things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:62
verses.text: Thus Christ Himself uses it, when He saith, "For judgement I am come into this world; that they which see not may see, and that they which see may be made blind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:63
verses.text: (John ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:64
verses.text: ) So likewise Paul in another place, when discoursing of the law, he writes, "And the Law came in beside, that the trespass might abound".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:65
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:66
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:67
verses.text: ) But neither was the law given to this end that the trespasses of the Jews might be increased: (though this did ensue:) nor did Christ come for this end that they which see might be made blind, but for the contrary; but the result was such.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:68
verses.text: Thus then also here must one understand the expression, "that they which are approved may be made manifest".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:69
verses.text: For not at all with this view came heresies into being, that "they which are approved may be made manifest," but on these heresies taking place such was the result.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:70
verses.text: Now these things he said to console the poor, those of them who nobly bore that sort of contempt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:71
verses.text: Wherefore he said not, "that they may become approved," but, "that they which are approved may be made manifest; showing that before this also they were such, but they were mixed up with the multitude, and while enjoying such relief as was afforded them by the rich, they were not very conspicuous: but now this strife and contentiousness made them manifest, even as the storm shows the pilot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:72
verses.text: And he said not, "that ye may appear approved," but, "that they which are approved may be made manifest, those among you who are such".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:73
verses.text: For neither when he is accusing doth he lay them open, that he may not render them more reckless; nor when praising, that he may not make them more boastful; but he leaves both this expression and that in suspense, allowing each man's own conscience to make the application of what he saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:74
verses.text: Nor doth he here seem to me to be comforting the poor only, but those also who were not violating the custom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:75
verses.text: For it was likely that there were among them also those that observed it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:76
verses.text: And this is why he said, "I partly believe it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:77
verses.text: Justly then doth he call these "approved," who not only with the rest observed the custom, but even without them kept this good law undisturbed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:78
verses.text: And he doth this, studying by such praises to render both others and these persons themselves more forward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:79
verses.text: Then at last he adds the very form of offence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:80
verses.text: And what is it?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:81
verses.text: "When ye assemble yourselves together," saith he, "it is not possible to eat the Lord's Supper".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:82
verses.text: Seest thou how effectually appealing to their shame, even already by way of narrative he contrives to give them his counsel? "For the appearance of your assembly," saith he, "is different.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:83
verses.text: It is one of love and brotherly affection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:84
verses.text: At least one place receives you all, and ye are together in one flock.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:85
verses.text: But the Banquet, when you come to that, bears no resemblance to the Assembly of worshippers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:86
verses.text: And he said not, "When ye come together, this is not to eat in common; "this is not to feast with one another;" but otherwise again and much more fearfully he reprimands them, saying, "it is not possible to eat the Lord's Supper," sending them away now from this point to that evening on which Christ delivered the awful Mysteries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:87
verses.text: Therefore also he called the early meal "a supper".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:88
verses.text: For that supper too had them all reclining at meat together: yet surely not so great was the distance between the rich and the poor as between the Teacher and the disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:89
verses.text: For that is infinite.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:90
verses.text: And why say I the Teacher and the disciples? Think of the interval between the Teacher and the traitor: nevertheless, the Lord Himself both sat at meat with them and did not even cast him out, but both gave him his portion of salt and made him partaker of the Mysteries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:91
verses.text: Next he explains how "it is not possible to eat the Lord's Supper".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:92
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:93
verses.text: "For in your eating, each one taketh before other his own supper," saith he, "and one is hungry, and another is drunken".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:94
verses.text: Perceivest thou how he intimates that they were disgracing themselves rather? For that which is the Lord's, they make a private matter: so that themselves are the first to suffer indignity, depriving their own table of its greatest prerogative.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:95
verses.text: How and in what manner? Because the Lord's Supper, i-e: the Master's, ought to be common.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:96
verses.text: For the property of the master belongs not to this servant without belonging to that, but in common to all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:97
verses.text: So that by "the Lord's" Supper he expresses this, the "community" of the feast.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:98
verses.text: As if he had said, "If it be thy master's, as assuredly it is, thou oughtest not to withdraw it as private, but as belonging to thy Lord and Master to set it in common before all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:99
verses.text: For this is the meaning of, 'the Lord's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:100
verses.text: ' But now thou dost not suffer it to be the Lord's, not suffering it to be common but feasting by thyself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:101
verses.text: Wherefore also he goes on to say,  "For each one taketh before other his own supper".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:102
verses.text: And he said not, "cutteth off," but "taketh before," tacitly censuring them both for greediness and for precipitancy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:103
verses.text: This at least the sequel also shows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:104
verses.text: For having said this, he added again, "and one is hungry, and another is drunken," each of which showed a want of moderation, both the craving and the excess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:105
verses.text: See also a second fault again whereby those same persons are injured: the first, that they dishonor their supper: the second, that they are greedy and drunken; and what is yet worse, even when the poor are hungry.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:106
verses.text: For what was intended to be set before all in common, that these men fed on alone, and proceeded both to surfeiting and to drunkenness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:107
verses.text: Wherefore neither did he say, "one is hungry, and another is filled:" but, "is drunken".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:108
verses.text: Now each of these, even by itself, is worthy of censure: for it is a fault to be drunken even without despising the poor; and to despise the poor without being drunken, is an accusation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:109
verses.text: When both then are joined together at the same time, consider how exceeding great is the transgression.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:110
verses.text: Next, having pointed out their profaneness, he adds his reprimand in what follows, with much anger, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:111
verses.text: "What? have ye not houses to eat and to drink in? Or despise ye the Church of God, and put them to shame that have not?"  Seest thou how he transferred the charge from the indignity offered to the poor to the Church, that his words might make a deeper impression of disgust? Here now you see is yet a fourth accusation, when not the poor only, but the Church likewise is insulted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:112
verses.text: For even as thou makest the Lord's Supper a private meal, so also the place again, using the Church as a house.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:113
verses.text: For it was made a Church, not that we who come together might be divided, but that they who are divided might be joined: and this act of assembling shows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:114
verses.text: "And put them to shame that have not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:115
verses.text: He said not, "and kill with hunger them that have not," but so as much more to put them to the blush, "shame them;" to point out that it is not food which he cares for so much as the wrong done unto them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:116
verses.text: Behold again a fifth accusation, not only to overlook the poor but even to shame them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:117
verses.text: Now this he said, partly as treating with reverence the concerns of the poor, and intimating that they grieve not so for the belly as for the shame; and partly also drawing the hearer to compassion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:118
verses.text: Having therefore pointed out so great impieties, indignity to the Supper, indignity to the Church, the contempt practised towards the poor; he relaxes again the tones of his reproof, saying, all of a sudden, "Shall I praise you? In this I praise you not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:119
verses.text: Wherein one might especially marvel at him that when there was need to strike and chide more vehemently after the proof of so great offences, he doeth the contrary rather, gives way, and permits them to recover breath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:120
verses.text: What then may the cause be? He had touched more painfully than usual in aggravating the charge, and being a most excellent physician, he adapts the incision to the wounds, neither cutting superficially those parts which require a deep stroke; (for thou hast heard him how he cut off among those very persons him that had committed fornication;) nor delivering over to the knife those things which require the milder sort of remedies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:121
verses.text: For this cause then here also he conducts his address more mildly, and in another point of view likewise, he sought especially to render them gentle to the poor: and this is why he discourses with them rather in a subdued tone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:122
verses.text: Next, wishing also from another topic to shame them yet more, he takes again the points which were most essential and of them weaves his discourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:123
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:124
verses.text: "For I received of the Lord," saith he, "that which also I delivered unto you: how that the Lord Jesus in the night in which He was betrayed, took bread:"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:125
verses.text: "And when He had given thanks, He brake it, and said, Take, eat: this is My Body, which is broken for you: this do in remembrance of me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:126
verses.text: Wherefore doth he here make mention of the Mysteries? Because that argument was very necessary to his present purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:127
verses.text: As thus: "Thy Master," saith he, "counted all worthy of the same Table, though it be very awful and far exceeding the dignity of all: but thou considerest them to be unworthy even of thine own, small and mean as we see it is; and while they have no advantage over thee in spiritual things, thou robbest them in the temporal things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:128
verses.text: For neither are these thine own".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:129
verses.text: However, he doth not express himself thus, to prevent his discourse becoming harsh: but he frames it in a gentler form, saying, that "the Lord Jesus in the night in which He was betrayed, took bread".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:130
verses.text: And wherefore doth he remind us of the time, and of that evening, and of the betrayal? Not indifferently nor without some reason, but that he might exceedingly fill them with compunction, were it but from consideration of the time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:131
verses.text: For even if one be a very stone, yet when he considers that night, how He was with His disciples, "very heavy," how He was betrayed, how He was bound, how He was led away, how He was judged, how He suffered all the rest in order, he becometh softer than wax, and is withdrawn from earth and all the pomp of this world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:132
verses.text: Therefore he leads us to the remembrance of all those things, by His time, and His table, and His betrayal, putting us to shame and saying, "Thy Master gave up even Himself for thee: and thou dost not even share a little meat with thy brother for thine own sake".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:133
verses.text: But how saith he, that "he received it from the Lord?" since certainly he was not present then but was one of the persecutors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:134
verses.text: That thou mayest know that the first table had no advantage above that which cometh after it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:135
verses.text: For even to-day also it is He who doeth all, and delivereth it even as then.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:136
verses.text: And not on this account only doth he remind us of that night, but that he may also in another way bring us to compunction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:137
verses.text: For as we particularly remember those words which we hear last from those who are departing; and to their heirs if they should venture to transgress their commands, when we would put them to shame we say, "Consider that this was the last word that your father uttered to you, and until the evening when he was just about to breathe his last he kept repeating these injunctions:" just so Paul, purposing hence also to make his argument full of awfulness; "Remember," saith he, "that this was the last mysterious rite He gave unto you, and in that night on which He was about to be slain for us, He commanded these things, and having delivered to us that Supper after that He added nothing further".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:138
verses.text: Next also he proceeds to recount the very things that were done, saying, "He took bread, and, when He had given thanks, He brake it, and said, Take, eat: this is My Body, which is broken for you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:139
verses.text: If therefore thou comest for a sacrifice of thanksgiving, do thou on thy part nothing unworthy of that sacrifice: by no means either dishonor thy brother, or neglect him in his hunger; be not drunken, insult not the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:140
verses.text: As thou comest giving thanks for what thou hast enjoyed: so do thou thyself accordingly make return, and not cut thyself off from thy neighbor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:141
verses.text: Since Christ for His part gave equally to all, saying, "Take, eat".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:142
verses.text: He gave His Body equally, but dost not thou give so much as the common bread equally? Yea, it was indeed broken for all alike, and became the Body equally for all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:143
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:144
verses.text: "In like manner also the cup after supper, saying, This cup is the New Covenant in My Blood: this do, as oft as ye drink of it, in remembrance of Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:145
verses.text: What sayest thou? Art thou making a remembrance of Christ, and despisest thou the poor and tremblest not? Why, if a son or brother had died and thou wert making a remembrance of him, thou wouldst have been smitten by thy conscience, hadst thou not fulfilled the custom and invited the poor: and when thou art making remembrance of thy Master, dost thou not so much as simply give a portion of the Table?  But what is it which He saith, "This cup is the New Covenant?" Because there was also a cup of the Old Covenant; the libations and the blood of the brute creatures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:146
verses.text: For after sacrificing, they used to receive the blood in a chalice and bowl and so pour it out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:147
verses.text: Since then instead of the blood of beasts He brought in His own Blood; lest any should be troubled on hearing this, He reminds them of that ancient sacrifice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:148
verses.text: Next, having spoken concerning that Supper, he connects the things present with the things of that time, that even as on that very evening and reclining on that very couch and receiving from Christ himself this sacrifice, so also now might men be affected; and he saith,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:149
verses.text: "For as often as ye eat this bread, and drink this cup, ye proclaim the Lord's death till He come".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:150
verses.text: For as Christ in regard to the bread and the cup said, "Do this in remembrance of Me," revealing to us the cause of the giving of the Mystery, and besides what else He said, declaring this to be a sufficient cause to ground our religious fear upon:—(for when thou considerest what thy Master hath suffered for thee, thou wilt the better deny thyself:)—so also Paul saith here: "as often as ye eat ye do proclaim His death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:151
verses.text: And this is that Supper.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:152
verses.text: Then intimating that it abides unto the end, he saith, "till He come".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:153
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:154
verses.text: "Wherefore whosoever shall eat this bread and drink the cup of the Lord unworthily, shall be guilty of the Body and the Blood of the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:155
verses.text: Why so? Because he poured it out, and makes the thing appear a slaughter and no longer a sacrifice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:156
verses.text: Much therefore as they who then pierced Him, pierced Him not that they might drink but that they might shed His blood: so likewise doth he that cometh for it unworthily and reaps no profit thereby.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:157
verses.text: Seest thou how fearful he makes his discourse, and inveighs against them very exceedingly, signifying that if they are thus to drink, they partake unworthily of the elements? For how can it be other than unworthily when it is he who neglects the hungry? who besides overlooking him puts him to shame? Since if not giving to the poor casteth one out of the kingdom, even though one should be a virgin; or rather, not giving liberally: (for even those virgins too had oil, only they had it not abundantly:) consider how great the evil will prove, to have wrought so many impieties?  "What impieties?" say you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:158
verses.text: Why sayest thou, what impieties? Thou hast partaken of such a Table and when thou oughtest to be more gentle than any and like the angels, none so cruel as thou art become.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:159
verses.text: Thou hast tasted the Blood of the Lord, and not even thereupon dost thou acknowledge thy brother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:160
verses.text: Of what indulgence then art thou worthy? Whereas if even before this thou hadst not known him, thou oughtest to have come to the knowledge of him from the Table; but now thou dishonorest the Table itself; he having been deemed worthy to partake of it and thou not judging him worthy of thy meat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:161
verses.text: Hast thou not heard how much he suffered who demanded the hundred pence? how he made void the gift vouchsafed to him? Doth it not come into thy mind what thou wert and what thou hast become? Dost thou not put thyself in remembrance that if this man be poor in possessions, thou wast much more beggarly in good works, being full of ten thousand sins? Notwithstanding, God delivered thee from all those and counted thee worthy of such a Table: but thou art not even thus become more merciful: therefore of course nothing else remaineth but that thou shouldest be "delivered to the tormentors".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:162
verses.text: These words let us also listen to, all of us, as many as in this place approach with the poor to this holy Table, but when we go out, do not seem even to have seen them, but are both drunken and pass heedlessly by the hungry; the very things whereof the Corinthians were accused.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:163
verses.text: And when is this done? say you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:164
verses.text: At all times indeed, but especially at the festivals, where above all times it ought not so to be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:165
verses.text: Is it not so, that at such times, immediately after Communion, drunkenness succeeds and contempt of the poor? And having partaken of the Blood, when it were a time for thee to fast and watch, thou givest thyself up to wine and revelling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:166
verses.text: And yet if thou hast by chance made thy morning meal on any thing good, thou keepest thyself lest by any other unsavory viand thou spoil the taste of the former: and now that thou hast been feasting on the Spirit thou bringest in a satanical luxury.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:167
verses.text: Consider, when the Apostles partook of that holy Supper, what they did: did they not betake themselves to prayers and singing of hymns? to sacred vigils? to that long work of teaching, so full of all self-denial? For then He related and delivered to them those great and wonderful things, when Judas had gone out to call them who were about to crucify Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:168
verses.text: Hast thou not heard how the three thousand also who partook of the Communion continued even in prayer and teaching, not in drunken feasts and revellings? But thou before thou hast partaken fastest, that in a certain way thou mayest appear worthy of the Communion: but when thou hast partaken, and thou oughtest to increase thy temperance, thou undoest all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:169
verses.text: And yet surely it is not the same to fast before this and after it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:170
verses.text: Since although it is our duty to be temperate at both times, yet most particularly after we have received the Bridegroom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:171
verses.text: Before, that thou mayest become worthy of receiving: after, that thou mayest not be found unworthy of what thou hast received.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:172
verses.text: "What then? ought we to fast after receiving?" I say not this, neither do I use any compulsion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:173
verses.text: This indeed were well: however, I do not enforce this, but I exhort you not to feast to excess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:174
verses.text: For if one never ought to live luxuriously, and Paul showed this when he said, "she that giveth herself to pleasure is dead while she liveth" ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:175
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:176
verses.text: ); much more will she then be dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:177
verses.text: And if luxury be death to a woman, much more to a man: and if this done at another time is fatal, much more after the communion of the Mysteries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:178
verses.text: And dost thou having taken the bread of life, do an action of death and not shudder? Knowest thou not how great evils are brought in by luxury? Unseasonable laughter, disorderly expressions, buffoonery fraught with perdition, unprofitable trifling, all the other things, which it is not seemly even to name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:179
verses.text: And these things thou doest when thou hast enjoyed the Table of Christ, on that day on which thou hast been counted worthy to touch His flesh with thy tongue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:180
verses.text: What then is to be done to prevent these things? Purify thy right hand, thy tongue, thy lips, which have become a threshold for Christ to tread upon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:181
verses.text: Consider the time in which thou didst draw near and set forth a material table, raise thy mind to that Table, to the Supper of the Lord, to the vigil of the disciples, in that night, that holy night.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:182
verses.text: Nay, rather should one accurately examine, this very present state is night.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:183
verses.text: Let us watch then with the Lord, let us be pricked in our hearts with the disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:184
verses.text: It is the season of prayers, not of drunkenness; ever indeed, but especially during a festival.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:185
verses.text: For a festival is therefore appointed, not that we may behave ourselves unseemly, not that we may accumulate sins, but rather that we may blot out those which exist.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:186
verses.text: I know, indeed, that I say these things in vain, yet will I not cease to say them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:187
verses.text: For if ye do not all obey, yet surely ye will not all disobey; or rather, even though ye should all be disobedient, my reward will be greater, though yours will be more condemnation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:188
verses.text: However, that it may not be more, to this end I will not cease to speak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:189
verses.text: For perchance, perchance, by my perseverance I shall be able to reach you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:190
verses.text: Wherefore I beseech you that we do not this to condemnation; let us nourish Christ, let us give Him drink, let us clothe Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:191
verses.text: These things are worthy of that Table.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:192
verses.text: Hast thou heard holy hymns? Hast thou seen a spiritual marriage? Hast thou enjoyed a royal Table? Hast thou been filled with the Holy Ghost? Hast thou joined in the choir of the Seraphim? Hast thou become partaker of the powers above? Cast not away so great a joy, waste not the treasure, bring not in drunkenness, the mother of dejection, the joy of the devil, the parent of ten thousand evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:193
verses.text: For hence is a sleep like unto death, and heaviness of head, and disease, and obliviousness, and an image of dead men's condition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:194
verses.text: Further, if thou wouldst not choose to meet with a friend when intoxicated, when thou hast Christ within, durst thou, tell me, to thrust in upon Him so great an excess?  But dost thou love enjoyment? Then, on this very account cease being drunken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:195
verses.text: For I, too, would have thee enjoy thyself, but with the real enjoyment, that which never fadeth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:196
verses.text: What then is the real enjoyment, ever blooming? Invite Christ to sup (Rev.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:197
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:198
verses.text: ) with thee; give Him to partake of thine, or rather of His own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:199
verses.text: This bringeth pleasure without limit, and in its prime everlastingly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:200
verses.text: But the things of sense are not such; rather as soon as they appear they vanish away; and he that hath enjoyed them will be in no better condition than he who hath not, or rather in a worse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:201
verses.text: For the one is settled as it were in a harbor, but the other exposes himself to a kind of torrent, a besieging army of distempers, and hath not even any power to endure the first swell of the sea.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:202
verses.text: That these things be therefore not so, let us follow after moderation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 26:203
verses.text: For thus we shall both be in a good state of body, and we shall possess our souls in security, and shall be delivered from evils both present and future: from which may we all be delivered, and attain unto the kingdom, through the grace and mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father, together with the Holy Spirit, be glory, power, and honor, now and ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:1
verses.text: Homily XXVIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:3
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:4
verses.text: But let a man prove himself, and so let him eat of the bread, and drink of the cup.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:5
verses.text: What mean these words, when another object is proposed to us? This is Paul's custom, as also I said before, not only to treat of those things which he had proposed to himself, but also if an argument incidental to his purpose occur, to proceed upon this also with great diligence, and especially when it relates to very necessary and urgent matters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:6
verses.text: Thus, when he was discoursing with married persons, and the question about the servants fell in his way, he handled it very strenuously and at great length.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:7
verses.text: Again, when he was speaking of the duty of not going to law before those courts, then also having fallen upon the admonition respecting covetousness, he discoursed at length concerning this subject likewise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:8
verses.text: Now the same thing he hath also done here: in that having once found occasion to remind them of the Mysteries, he judged it necessary to proceed with that subject.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:9
verses.text: For indeed it was no ordinary one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:10
verses.text: Wherefore also he discoursed very awfully concerning it, providing for that which is the sum of all good things, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:11
verses.text: their approaching those Mysteries with a pure conscience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:12
verses.text: Whence neither was he content with the things said before alone, but adds these also, saying,  "But let a man prove himself:" which also he saith in the second Epistle: "try your own selves, prove your own selves:" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:13
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:14
verses.text: ) not as we do now, approaching because of the season rather than from any earnestness of mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:15
verses.text: For we do not consider how we may approach prepared, with the ills that were within us purged out, and full of compunction, but how we may come at festivals and whenever all do so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:16
verses.text: But not thus did Paul bid us come: he knoweth only one season of access and communion, the purity of a man's conscience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:17
verses.text: Since if even that kind of banquet which the senses take cognizance of cannot be partaken of by us when feverish and full of bad humors, without risk of perishing: much more is it unlawful for us to touch this Table with profane lusts, which are more grievous than fevers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:18
verses.text: Now when I say profane lusts, I mean both those of the body, and of money, and of anger, and of malice, and, in a word, all that are profane.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:19
verses.text: And it becomes him that approacheth, first to empty himself of all these things and so to touch that pure sacrifice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:20
verses.text: And neither if indolently disposed and reluctantly ought he to be compelled to approach by reason of the festival; nor, on the other hand, if penitent and prepared, should any one prevent him because it is not a festival.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:21
verses.text: For a festival is a showing forth of good works, and a reverence of soul, and exactness of deportment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:22
verses.text: And if thou hast these things, thou mayest at all times keep festival and at all times approach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:23
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, "But let each man prove himself, and then let him approach".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:24
verses.text: And he bids not one examine another, but each himself, making the tribunal not a public one and the conviction without a witness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:25
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:26
