verses.text: "For he that eateth and drinketh unworthily, eateth and drinketh judgment to himself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:27
verses.text: What sayest thou, tell me? Is this Table which is the cause of so many blessings and teeming with life, become judgment? Not from its own nature, saith he, but from the will of him that approaches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:28
verses.text: For as His presence, which conveyed to us those great and unutterable blessings, condemned the more them that received it not: so also the Mysteries become provisions of greater punishment to such as partake unworthily.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:29
verses.text: But why doth he eat judgment to himself? "Not discerning the Lord's body:" i-e:, not searching, not bearing in mind, as he ought, the greatness of the things set before him; not estimating the weight of the gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:30
verses.text: For if thou shouldest come to know accurately Who it is that lies before thee, and Who He is that gives Himself, and to whom, thou wilt need no other argument, but this is enough for thee to use all vigilance; unless thou shouldest be altogether fallen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:31
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:32
verses.text: "For this cause many among you are weak and sickly, and not a few sleep".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:33
verses.text: Here he no longer brings his examples from others as he did in the case of the idol-sacrifices, relating the ancient histories and the chastisements in the wilderness, but from the Corinthians themselves; which also made the discourse apt to strike them more keenly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:34
verses.text: For whereas he was saying, "he eateth judgment to himself," and, "he is guilty;" that he might not seem to speak mere words, he points to deeds also and calls themselves to witness; a kind of thing which comes home to men more than threatening, by showing that the threat has issued in some real fact.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:35
verses.text: He was not however content with these things alone, but from these he also introduced and confirmed the argument concerning hell-fire, terrifying them in both ways; and solving an inquiry which is handled everywhere.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:36
verses.text: I mean, since many question one with another, "whence arise the untimely deaths, whence the long diseases of men;" he tells them that these unexpected events are many of them conditional upon certain sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:37
verses.text: "What then? They who are in continual health," say you, "and come to a green old age, do they not sin?" Nay, who durst say this? "How then," say you, "do they not suffer punishment?" Because there they shall suffer a severer one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:38
verses.text: But we, if we would, neither here nor there need suffer it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:39
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:40
verses.text: "For if we discerned ourselves," saith he, "we should not be judged".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:41
verses.text: And he said not, "if we punished ourselves, if we were revenged on ourselves," but if we were only willing to acknowledge our offence, to pass sentence on ourselves, to condemn the things done amiss, we should be rid of the punishment both in this world and the next.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:42
verses.text: For he that condemns himself propitiates God in two ways, both by acknowledging his sins, and by being more on his guard for the future.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:43
verses.text: But since we are not willing to do even this light thing, as we ought to do it, not even thus doth He endure to punish us with the world, but even thus spareth us, exacting punishment in this world, where the penalty is for a season and the consolation great; for the result is both deliverance from sins, and a good hope of things to come, alleviating the present evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:44
verses.text: And these things he saith, at the same time comforting the sick and rendering the rest more serious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:45
verses.text: Wherefore he saith,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:46
verses.text: "But when we are judged, we are chastened of the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:47
verses.text: He said not, we are punished, he said not, we have vengeance taken on us, but, "we are chastened".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:48
verses.text: For what is done belongs rather to admonition than condemnation, to healing than vengeance, to correction than punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:49
verses.text: And not so only but by the threat of a greater evil he makes the present light, saying, "that we may not be condemned with the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:50
verses.text: Seest thou how he brings in hell also and that tremendous judgment-seat, and signifies that that trial and punishment is necessary and by all means must be? for if the faithful, and such as God especially cares for, escape not without punishment in whatsoever things they offend, (and this is evident from things present,) much more the unbelieving and they who commit the unpardonable and incurable sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:51
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:52
verses.text: "Wherefore when ye come together to eat, wait one for another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:53
verses.text: Thus, while their fear was yet at its height and the terror of hell remained, he chooses again to bring in also the exhortation in behalf of the poor, on account of which he said all these things; implying that if they do not this they must partake unworthily.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:54
verses.text: But if the not imparting of our goods excludes from that Table, much more the violently taking away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:55
verses.text: And he said not, "wherefore, when ye come together, impart to them that need," but, which has a more reverential sound, "wait one for another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:56
verses.text: For this also prepared the way for and intimated that, and in a becoming form introduced the exhortation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:57
verses.text: Then further to shame them,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:58
verses.text: "And if any man is hungry, let him eat at home".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:59
verses.text: By permitting, he hinders it, and more strongly than by an absolute prohibition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:60
verses.text: For he brings him out of the church and sends him to his house, hereby severely reprimanding and ridiculing them, as slaves to the belly and unable to contain themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:61
verses.text: For he said not, "if any despise the poor," but, "if any hunger," discoursing as with impatient children; as with brute beasts which are slaves to appetite.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:62
verses.text: Since it would be indeed very ridiculous, if, because they were hungry they were to eat at home.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:63
verses.text: Yet he was not content with this, but added also another more fearful thing, saying, "that your coming together be not unto judgment:" that ye come not unto chastisement, unto punishment, insulting the Church, dishonoring your brother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:64
verses.text: "For for this cause ye come together," saith he, "that ye may love one another, that ye may profit and be profited.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:65
verses.text: But if the contrary happen, it were better for you to feed yourselves at home".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:66
verses.text: This, however, he said, that he might attract them to him the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:67
verses.text: Yea, this was the very purpose both of his pointing out the injury that would arise from hence, and of his saying that condemnation was no trifling one, and terrifying them in every way, by the Mysteries, by the sick, by those that had died, by the other things before mentioned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:68
verses.text: Then also he alarms them again in another way, saying, "and the rest will I set in order whensoever I come:" with reference either to some other things, or to this very matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:69
verses.text: For since it was likely that they would yet have some reasons to allege, and it was not possible to set all to rights by letter, "the things which I have charged you, let them be observed for the present," saith he; "but if ye have any thing else to mention, let it be kept for my coming;" speaking either of this matter, as I said, or of some other things not very urgent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:70
verses.text: And this he doth that hence too he may render them more serious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:71
verses.text: For being anxious about his coming, they would correct the error.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:72
verses.text: For the sojourning of Paul in any place was no ordinary thing: and to signify this he said, "some are puffed up, as though I would not come to you;" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:73
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:74
verses.text: ) and elsewhere again, "not as in my presence only, but now much more in my absence, work out your own salvation with fear and trembling".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:75
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:76
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:77
verses.text: ) And therefore neither did he merely promise that he would come, lest they should disbelieve him and become more negligent; but he also states a necessary cause for his sojourning with them, saying, "the rest I will set in order when I come; which implies, that the correction of the things that remained, even had he not in any case been desirous, would have drawn him thither.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:78
verses.text: Hearing therefore all these things, let us both take great care of the poor, and restrain our appetite, and rid ourselves of drunkenness, and be careful worthily to partake of the Mysteries; and whatsoever we suffer, let us not take it bitterly, neither for ourselves nor for others; as when untimely death happen or long diseases.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:79
verses.text: For this is deliverance from punishment, this is correction, this is most excellent admonition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:80
verses.text: Who saith this? He that hath Christ speaking in him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:81
verses.text: But nevertheless even after this many of our women are so foolishly disposed as even to go beyond the unbelievers in the excess of their grief.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:82
verses.text: And some do this blinded by their passion, but others for ostentation, and to avoid the censures of them that are without: who most of all are deprived of excuse, to my mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:83
verses.text: For, "lest such a one accuse me," saith she, "let God be my accuser: lest men more senseless than the brute beasts condemn me, let the law of the King of all be trampled under foot".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:84
verses.text: Why, how many thunderbolts do not these sayings deserve?  Again; If any one invite you to a funeral supper after your affliction there is no one to say any thing against it, because there is a law of men which enjoins such things: but when God by His law forbids your mourning, all thus contradict it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:85
verses.text: Doth not Job come into thy mind, O woman? Rememberest thou not his words at the misfortune of his children, which adorned that holy head more than ten thousand crowns, and made proclamation louder than many trumpets? Dost thou make no account of the greatness of his misfortunes, of that unprecedented shipwreck, and that strange and portentous tragedy? For thou possibly hast lost one, or a second, or third: but he so many sons and daughters: and he that had many children suddenly became childless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:86
verses.text: And not even by degrees were his bowels wasted away: but at one sweep all the fruit of his body was snatched from him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:87
verses.text: Nor was it by the common law of nature, when they had come to old age, but by a death both untimely and violent: and all together, and when he was not present nor sitting by them, that at least by hearing their last words he might have some consolation for so bitter an end of theirs: but contrary to all expectation and without his knowing any thing of what took place, they were all at once overwhelmed, and their house became their grave and their snare.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:88
verses.text: And not only their untimely death, but many things besides there were to grieve him; such as their being all in the flower of their age, all virtuous and loving, all together, that not one of either sex was left, that it befel them not by the common law of nature, that it came after so great a loss, that when he was unconscious of any sin on his own part or on theirs, he suffered these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:89
verses.text: For each of these circumstances is enough even by itself to disturb the mind: but when we find them even concurring together, imagine the height of those waves, how great the excess of that storm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:90
verses.text: And what in particular is greater and worse than his bereavement, he did not even know wherefore all these things happened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:91
verses.text: On this account then, having no cause to assign for the misfortune, he ascends to the good pleasure of God, and saith, "The Lord gave, the Lord hath taken away:" as it pleased the Lord, even so it happened; "blessed be the name of the Lord for ever".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:92
verses.text: (Job ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:93
verses.text: ) And these things he said, when he saw himself who had followed after all virtue in the last extremity; but evil men and impostors, prospering, luxurious, revelling on all sides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:94
verses.text: And he uttered no such word as it is likely that some of the weaker sort would have uttered, "Was it for this that I brought up my children and trained them with all exactness? For this did I open my house to all that passed by, that after those many courses run in behalf of the needy, the naked, the orphans, I might receive this recompense?" But instead of these, he offered up those words better than all sacrifice, saying, "Naked came I out of my mother's womb, and naked shall I return thither".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:95
verses.text: If however he rent his clothes and shaved his head, marvel not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:96
verses.text: For he was a father and a loving father: and it was meet that both the compassion of his nature should be shown, and also the self-command of his spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:97
verses.text: Whereas, had he not done this, perhaps one would have thought this self-command to be of mere insensibility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:98
verses.text: Therefore he indicates both his natural affection and the exactness of his piety, and in his grief he was not overthrown.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:99
verses.text: Yea, and when his trial proceeded further, he is again adorned with other crowns on account of his reply to his wife, saying, "If we have received good at the hand of the Lord, shall we not endure evil?" (Job ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:100
verses.text: ) For in fact his wife was by this time the only one left, all his having been clean destroyed, both his children and his possessions and his very body, and she reserved to tempt and to ensnare him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:101
verses.text: And this indeed was the reason why the devil did not destroy her with the children, nor asked her death, because he expected that she would contribute much towards the ensnaring of that holy man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:102
verses.text: Therefore he left her as a kind of implement, and a formidable one, for himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:103
verses.text: "For if even out of paradise," saith he, "I cast mankind by her means, much more shall I be able to trip him up on the dunghill".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:104
verses.text: And observe his craft.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:105
verses.text: He did not apply this stratagem when the oxen or the asses or the camels were lost, nor even when the house fell and the children were buried under it, but so long looking on the combatant, he suffers her to be silent and quiet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:106
verses.text: But when the fountain of worms gushed forth, when the skin began to putrify and drop off, and the flesh wasting away to emit most offensive discharge, and the hand of the devil was wearing him out with sharper pain than gridirons and furnaces and any flame, consuming on every side and eating away his body more grievously than any wild beast, and when a long time had been spent in this misery; then he brings her to him, seasoned and worn down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:107
verses.text: Whereas if she had approached him at the beginning of his misfortune, neither would she have found him so unnerved, nor would she have had it in her power so to swell out and exaggerate the misfortune by her words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:108
verses.text: But now when she saw him through the length of time thirsting for release, and desiring the termination of what pressed on him vehemently then doth she come upon him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:109
verses.text: For to show that he was quite worn down, and by this time had become unable even to draw breath, yea, and desired even to die, hear what he saith; "For I would I could lay hands on myself, or could request another and he should do it for me;" And observe, I pray, the wickedness of his wife, from what topic she at once begins: namely, from the length of time, saying, "How long wilt thou hold out?"  Now, if often even when there were no realities words alone have prevailed to unman a person, consider what it was likely he then should feel, when, besides these words, the things themselves also were galling him; and what, as it should seem, was worst of all, it was a wife also who spake thus, and a wife who had sunk down utterly and was giving herself up, and on this account was seeking to cast him also into desperation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:110
verses.text: However, that we may see more clearly the engine which was brought against that adamantine wall, let us listen to the very words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:111
verses.text: What then are these? "How long wilt thou hold out? saying, Lo! I wait a short time longer, expecting the hope of my salvation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:112
verses.text: "Nay," saith she, "the time hath exposed the folly of thy words, while it is protracted, yet shows no mode of escape".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:113
verses.text: And these things she said, not only thrusting him into desperation, but also reproaching and jesting upon him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:114
verses.text: For he, ever consoling her as she pressed upon him, and putting her off, would speak as follows: "Wait a little longer, and there will soon be an end of these things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:115
verses.text: Reproaching him therefore, she speaks: "Wilt thou now again say the same thing? For a long time hath now run by, and no end of these things hath appeared".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:116
verses.text: And observe her malice, that she makes no mention of the oxen, the sheep or the camels, as knowing that he was not very much vexed about these; but she goes at once to nature, and reminds him of his children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:117
verses.text: For on their death she saw him both rending his clothes and shaving off his hair.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:118
verses.text: And she said not, "thy children are dead," but very pathetically, "thy memorial is perished from the earth," "the thing for which thy children were desirable".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:119
verses.text: For if, even now after that the resurrection hath been made known children are longed for because they preserve the memory of the departed; much more then.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:120
verses.text: Wherefore also her curse becomes from that consideration more bitter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:121
verses.text: For in that case, he that cursed, said not, "Let his children be utterly rooted out," but, "his memorial from the earth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:122
verses.text: "Thy sons and thy daughters".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:123
verses.text: Thus whereas she said, "the memorial," she again accurately makes mention of either sex.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:124
verses.text: "But if thou," saith she, "carest not for these, at least consider what is mine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:125
verses.text: "The pains of my womb, and labors which I have endured in vain with sorrow".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:126
verses.text: Now what she means is this: "I, who endured the more, am wronged for thy sake, and having undergone the toils I am deprived of the fruits".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:127
verses.text: And see how she neither makes express mention of his loss of property, nor is silent about it and hurries by; but in that point of view in which it also might be most pathetically narrated, in that she covertly refers to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:128
verses.text: For when she says, "I too am a vagabond and a slave, going about from place to place, from house to house," she both hints at the loss and indicates her great distress: these expressions being such as even to enhance that misfortune.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:129
verses.text: "For I come to the doors of others," saith she; "nor do I beg only, but am a wanderer also and serve a strange and unusual servitude, going round everywhere and carrying about the tokens of my calamity, and teaching all men of my woes;" which is most piteous of all, to change house after house.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:130
verses.text: And she stayed not even at these lamentations, but proceeded to say, "Waiting for the sun when it will set, and I shall rest from my miseries and the pains that encompass me, by which I am now straitened".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:131
verses.text: "Thus, that which is sweet to others," saith she, "to behold the light, this to me is grievous: but the night and the darkness is a desirable thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:132
verses.text: For this only gives me rest from my toils, this becometh a comfort to my miseries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:133
verses.text: But speak somewhat against the Lord, and die".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:134
verses.text: Perceivest thou here too her crafty wickedness? how she did not even in the act of advising at once introduce the deadly counsel, but having first pitifully related her misfortunes and having drawn out the tragedy at length, she couches in a few words what she would recommend, and doth not even declare it plainly, but throwing a shade over that, she holds out to him the deliverance which he greatly longed for, and promises death, the thing which he then most of all desired.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:135
verses.text: And mark from this also the malice of the devil: that because he knew the longing of Job towards God, he suffers not his wife to accuse God, lest he should at once turn away from her as an enemy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:136
verses.text: For this cause she no where mentions Him, but the actual calamities she is continually harping on.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:137
verses.text: And do thou, besides what has been said, add the circumstance that it was a woman who gave this counsel, a wonderful orator to beguile the heedless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:138
verses.text: Many at least even without external accidents have been cast down by the counsel of woman alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:139
verses.text: What then did the blessed saint, and firmer than adamant? Looking bitterly upon her, by his aspect even before he spake, he repelled her devices: since she no doubt expected to excite fountains of tears; but he became fiercer than a lion, full of wrath and indignation, not on account of his sufferings, but on account of her diabolical suggestions; and having signified his anger by his looks in a subdued tone he gives his rebuke; for even in misfortune he kept his self-command.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:140
verses.text: And what saith he? "Why speakest thou as one of the foolish women?" "I have not so taught thee," saith he, "I did not so nurture thee; and this is why I do not now recognize even mine own consort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:141
verses.text: For these words are the counsel of a 'foolish woman,' and of one beside herself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:142
verses.text: Seest thou not here an instance of wounding in moderation, and inflicting a blow just sufficient to cure the disease?  Then, after the infliction, he brings in advice sufficient on the other hand to console her, and very rational, thus speaking: "if we have received our good things at the hand of the Lord, shall we not endure our evils?" "For remember," saith he, "those former things and make account of the Author of them, and thou wilt bear even these nobly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:143
verses.text: Seest thou the modesty of the man? that he doth not at all impute his patience to his own courage, but saith it was part of the natural result of what happened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:144
verses.text: "For in return for what did God give us these former things? What recompense did he repay? None, but from mere goodness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:145
verses.text: For they were a gift, not a recompense; a grace, not a reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:146
verses.text: Well then, let us bear these also nobly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 27:147
verses.text: This discourse let us, both men and women, have recorded, and let us engrave the words in our minds, both these and those before them: and by sketching upon our minds as in picture the history of their sufferings, I mean the loss of wealth, the bereavement of children, the disease of body, the reproaches, the mockings, the devices of his wife, the snare of the devil, in a word, all the calamities of that righteous man, and that with exactness, let us provide ourselves with a most ample port of refuge: that, enduring all things nobly and thankfully, we may both in the present life cast off all despondency, and receive the rewards that belong to this good way of taking things; by the grace and mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father, with the Holy Ghost, be glory, power, and honor, now and forever, world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:1
verses.text: Homily XXIX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:3
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:4
verses.text: ,  Now concerning spiritual gifts, brethren, I would not have you ignorant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:5
verses.text: Ye know that when ye were Gentiles, ye were led away unto those dumb idols, howsoever ye might be led.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:6
verses.text: This whole place is very obscure: but the obscurity is produced by our ignorance of the facts referred to and by their cessation, being such as then used to occur but now no longer take place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:7
verses.text: And why do they not happen now? Why look now, the cause too of the obscurity hath produced us again another question: namely, why did they then happen, and now do so no more?  This however let us defer to another time, but for the present let us state what things were occurring then.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:8
verses.text: Well: what did happen then? Whoever was baptized he straightway spake with tongues and not with tongues only, but many also prophesied, and some also performed many other wonderful works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:9
verses.text: For since on their coming over from idols, without any clear knowledge or training in the ancient Scriptures, they at once on their baptism received the Spirit, yet the Spirit they saw not, for It is invisible; therefore God's grace bestowed some sensible proof of that energy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:10
verses.text: And one straightway spake in the Persian, another in the Roman, another in the Indian, another in some other such tongue: and this made manifest to them that were without that it is the Spirit in the very person speaking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:11
verses.text: Wherefore also he so calls it, saying, "But to each one the manifestation of the Spirit is given to profit withal;" (v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:12
verses.text: ) calling the gifts "a manifestation of the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:13
verses.text: For as the Apostles themselves had received this sign first, so also the faithful went on receiving it, I mean, the gift of tongues; yet not this only but also many others: inasmuch as many used even to raise the dead and to cast out devils and to perform many other such wonders: and they had gifts too, some less, and some more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:14
verses.text: But more abundant than all was the gift of tongues among them: and this became to them a cause of division; not from its own nature but from the perverseness of them that had received it: in that on the one hand the possessors of the greater gifts were lifted up against them that had the lesser: and these again were grieved, and envied the owners of the greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:15
verses.text: And Paul himself as he proceeds intimates this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:16
verses.text: Since then herefrom they were receiving a fatal blow in the dissolution of their charity, he takes great care to correct it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:17
verses.text: For this happened indeed in Rome also, but not in the same way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:18
verses.text: And this is why in the Epistle to the Romans he moots it indeed, but obscurely and briefly, saying thus: "For even as we have many members in one body, and all the members have not the same office; so we, who are many, are one body in Christ, and severally members one of another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:19
verses.text: And having gifts differing according to the grace that was given to us, whether prophecy, let us prophesy according to the proportion of our faith; or ministry, let us give ourselves to our ministry; or he that teacheth to his teaching".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:20
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:21
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:23
verses.text: ) And that the Romans also were falling into wilfulness hereby, this he intimates in the beginning of that discourse, thus saying: "For I say through the grace given unto me, to every man that is among you, not to think of himself more highly than he ought to think; but so to think as to think soberly, according as God hath dealt to each man a measure of faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:24
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:25
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:26
verses.text: ) With these, however, (for the disease of division and pride had not proceeded to any length,) he thus discoursed: but here with great anxiety; for the distemper had greatly spread.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:27
verses.text: And this was not the only thing to disturb them, but there were also in the place many soothsayers, inasmuch as the city was more than usually addicted to Grecian customs, and this with the rest was tending to offence and disturbance among them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:28
verses.text: This is the reason why he begins by first stating the difference between soothsaying and prophecy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:29
verses.text: For this cause also they received discerning of spirits, so as to discern and know which is he that speaketh by a pure spirit, and which by an impure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:30
verses.text: For because it was not possible to supply the evidence of the things uttered from within themselves at the moment; (for prophecy supplies the proof of its own truth not at the time when it is spoken, but at the time of the event;) and it was not easy to distinguish the true prophesier from the pretender; (for the devil himself, accursed as he is, had entered into them that prophesied, See  Kings xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:31
verses.text: bringing in false prophets, as if forsooth they also could foretell things to come;) and further, men were easily deceived, because the things spoken could not for the present be brought to trial, ere yet the events had come to pass concerning which the prophecy was; (for it was the end that proved the false prophet and the true:)—in order that the hearers might not be deceived before the end, he gives them a sign which even before the event served to indicate the one and the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:32
verses.text: And hence taking his order and beginning, he thus goes on also to the discourse concerning the gifts and corrects the contentiousness that arose from hence likewise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:33
verses.text: For the present however he begins the discourse concerning the soothsayers, thus saying,   "Now concerning spiritual gifts, brethren, I would not have you ignorant;" calling the signs "spiritual," because they are the works of the Spirit alone, human effort contributing nothing to the working such wonders.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:34
verses.text: And intending to discourse concerning them, first, as I said, he lays down the difference between soothsaying and prophecy, thus saying,  "Ye know that when ye were Gentiles, ye were led away unto those dumb idols, howsoever ye might be led".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:35
verses.text: Now what he means is this: "In the idol-temples," saith he, "if any were at any time possessed by an unclean spirit and began to divine, even as one dragged away, so was he drawn by that spirit in chains: knowing nothing of the things which he utters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:36
verses.text: For this is peculiar to the soothsayer, to be beside himself, to be under compulsion, to be pushed, to be dragged, to be haled as a madman.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:37
verses.text: But the prophet not so, but with sober mind and composed temper and knowing what he is saying, he uttereth all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:38
verses.text: Therefore even before the event do thou from this distinguish the soothsayer and the prophet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:39
verses.text: And consider how he frees his discourse of all suspicion; calling themselves to witness who had made trial of the matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:40
verses.text: As if he had said, "that I lie not nor rashly traduce the religion of the Gentiles, feigning like an enemy, do ye yourselves bear me witness: knowing as ye do, when ye were Gentiles, how ye were pulled and dragged away then".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:41
verses.text: But if any should say that these too are suspected as believers, come, even from them that are without will I make this manifest to you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:42
verses.text: Hear, for example, Plato saying thus: (Apol.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:43
verses.text: Soc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:44
verses.text: c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:45
verses.text: ) "Even as they who deliver oracles and the soothsayers say many and excellent things, but know nothing of what they utter".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:46
verses.text: Hear again another, a poet, giving the same intimation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:47
verses.text: For whereas by certain mystical rites and witchcrafts a certain person had imprisoned a demon in a man, and the man divined, and in his divination was thrown down and torn, and was unable to endure the violence of the demon, but was on the point of perishing in that convulsion; he saith to the persons who were practicing such mystical arts,  Loose me, I pray you:  The mighty God no longer mortal flesh  Can hold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:48
verses.text: And again,  Unbind my wreaths, and bathe my feet in drops  From the pure stream; erase these mystic lines,  And let me go.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:49
verses.text: For these and such like things, (for one might mention many more,) point out to us both of these facts which follow; the compulsion which holds down the demons and makes them slaves; and the violence to which they submit who have once given themselves up to them, so as to swerve even from their natural reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:50
verses.text: And the Pythoness too: (for I am compelled now to bring forward and expose another disgraceful custom of theirs, which it were well to pass by, because it is unseemly for us to mention such things; but that you may more clearly know their shame it is necessary to mention it, that hence at least ye may come to know the madness and exceeding mockery of those that make use of the soothsayers:) this same Pythoness then is said, being a female, to sit at times upon the tripod of Apollo astride, and thus the evil spirit ascending from beneath and entering the lower part of her body, fills the woman with madness, and she with dishevelled hair begins to play the bacchanal and to foam at the mouth, and thus being in a frenzy to utter the words of her madness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:51
verses.text: I know that you are ashamed and blush when you hear these things: but they glory both in the disgrace and in the madness which I have described.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:52
verses.text: These then and all such things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:53
verses.text: Paul was bringing forward when he said, "Ye know that when ye were Gentiles, ye were led away unto those dumb idols, howsoever ye might be led".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:54
verses.text: And because he was discoursing with those who knew well, he states not all things with exact care, not wishing to be troublesome to them, but having reminded them only and brought all into their recollection, he soon quits the point, hastening to the subject before him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:55
verses.text: But what is, "unto those dumb idols?" These soothsayers used to be led and dragged unto them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:56
verses.text: But if they be themselves dumb, how did they give responses to others? And wherefore did the demon lead them to the images? As men taken in war, and in chains, and rendering at the same time his deceit plausible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:57
verses.text: Thus, to keep men from the notion that it was just a dumb stone, they were earnest to rivet the people to the idols that their own style and title might be inscribed upon them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:58
verses.text: But our rites are not such.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:59
verses.text: He did not however state ours, I mean the prophesyings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:60
verses.text: For it was well known to them all, and prophecy was exercised among them, as was meet for their condition, with understanding and with entire freedom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:61
verses.text: Therefore, you see, they had power either to speak or to refrain from speaking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:62
verses.text: For they were not bound by necessity, but were honored with a privilege.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:63
verses.text: For this cause Jonah fled; (Jonah i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:64
verses.text: ) for this cause Ezekiel delayed; (Ezek.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:65
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:66
verses.text: ) for this cause Jeremiah excused himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:67
verses.text: (Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:68
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:69
verses.text: ) And God thrusts them not on by compulsion, but advising, exhorting, threatening; not darkening their mind; for to cause distraction and madness and great darkness, is the proper work of a demon: but it is God's work to illuminate and with consideration to teach things needful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:70
verses.text: This then is the first difference between a soothsayer and a prophet; but a second and a different one is that which he next states, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:71
verses.text: "Wherefore I give you to understand, that no man speaking in the Spirit of God calleth Jesus accursed:" and then another: "and that no man can say that Jesus is the Lord, but in the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:72
verses.text: "When thou seest," saith he, "any one not uttering His name, or anathematizing Him, he is a soothsayer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:73
verses.text: Again, when thou seest another speaking all things with His Name, understand that he is spiritual".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:74
verses.text: "What then," say you, "must we say concerning the Catechumens? For if, no man can say that Jesus is the Lord but by the Holy Ghost, what must we say of them who name indeed His Name, but are destitute of His Spirit? But his discourse at this time was not concerning these for there were not at that time Catechumens, but concerning believers and unbelievers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:75
verses.text: What then, doth no demon call upon God's Name? Did not the demoniacs say, "We know Thee who Thou art, the Holy One of God? (Mark i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:76
verses.text: ) Did they not say to Paul, "these men are the servants of the Most High God? (Acts xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:77
verses.text: ) They did, but upon scourging, upon compulsion; never of their own will and without being scourged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:78
verses.text: But here it is proper to enquire, both why the demon uttered these things and why Paul rebuked him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:79
verses.text: In imitation of his Teacher; for so Christ did also rebuke: since it was not his will to have testimony from them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:80
verses.text: And wherefore did the devil also practise this? Intending to confound the order of things, and to seize upon the dignity of the Apostles, and to persuade many to pay attention to them: which had it happened, they would easily have made themselves appear from hence worthy of credit, and have brought in their own designs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:81
verses.text: That these things then might not be, and the deceit might not have a beginning, he stops their mouths even when speaking the truth, so that in their falsehoods men should not at all give heed unto them, but stop their ears altogether against the things said by them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:82
verses.text: Having therefore made manifest the soothsayers and the prophets both by the first sign and also by the second, he next discourses of the wonders; not passing without reason to this topic, but so as to remove the dissension which had thence arisen, and to persuade both those that had the less portion not to grieve and those who had the greater not to be elated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:83
verses.text: Wherefore also he thus began.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:84
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:85
verses.text: "Now there are diversities of gifts, but the same Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:86
verses.text: And first he attends on him that had the lesser gift, and was grieved on this account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:87
verses.text: "For wherefore," saith he, "art thou dejected? because thou hast not received as much as another? Still, consider that it is a free gift and not a debt, and thou wilt be able to soothe thy pain".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:88
verses.text: For this cause he spake thus in the very beginning: "but there are diversities of gifts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:89
verses.text: And he said not "of signs," nor "of wonders," but of "gifts," by the name of free gifts prevailing on them not only not to grieve but even to be thankful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:90
verses.text: "And withal consider this also," saith he, "that even if thou art made inferior in the measure of what is given; in that it hath been vouchsafed thee to receive from the same source as the other who hath received more, thou hast equal honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:91
verses.text: For certainly thou canst not say that the Spirit bestowed the gift on him, but an angel on thee: since the Spirit bestowed it both on thee and him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:92
verses.text: Wherefore he added, "but the same Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:93
verses.text: So that even if there be a difference in the gift, yet is there no difference in the Giver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:94
verses.text: For from the same Fountain ye are drawing, both thou and he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:95
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:96
verses.text: "And there are diversities of ministrations, but the same Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:97
verses.text: Thus, enriching the consolation, he adds mention of the Son also, and of the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:98
verses.text: And again, he calls these gifts by another name, designing by this also an increase of consolation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:99
verses.text: Wherefore also he thus said: "there are diversities of ministrations, but the same Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:100
verses.text: For he that hears of "a gift," and hath received a less share, perhaps might grieve; but when we speak of "a ministration," the case is different.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:101
verses.text: For the thing implies labor and sweat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:102
verses.text: "Why grievest thou then," saith he, "if he hath bidden another labor more, sparing thee?"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:103
verses.text: "And there are diversities of workings, but the same God who worketh all things in all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:104
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:105
verses.text: "But to each one is given the manifestation of the Spirit to profit withal".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:106
verses.text: "And what," saith one, "is a working?" and what "a gift?" and what "a ministration?" They are mere differences of names, since the things are the same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:107
verses.text: For what "a gift" is, that is "a ministration," that he calls "an operation" also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:108
verses.text: Thus fulfil thy ministry; ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:109
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:110
verses.text: ministry.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:111
verses.text: ) and, "I magnify my ministration:" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:112
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:113
verses.text: office.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:114
verses.text: ) and writing to Timothy, he says, "Therefore I put thee in remembrance that thou stir up the gift of God, which is in thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:115
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:116
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:117
verses.text: ) And again, writing to the Galatians, he said, "for he that wrought in Peter to the Apostleship, the same was mighty in me toward the Gentiles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:118
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:119
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:120
verses.text: ) Seest thou that he implies that there is no difference in the gifts of the Father, and the Son, and the Holy Ghost? Not confounding the Persons, God forbid! but declaring the equal honor of the Essence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:121
verses.text: For that which the Spirit bestows, this he saith that God also works; this, that the Son likewise ordains and grants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:122
verses.text: Yet surely if the one were inferior to the other, or the other to it, he would not have thus set it down nor would this have been his way of consoling the person who was vexed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:123
verses.text: Now after this, he comforts him also in another kind of way; by the consideration that the measure vouchsafed is profitable to him, even though it be not so large.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:124
verses.text: For having said, that it is "the same Spirit," and "the same Lord," and "the same God," and having thereby recovered him, he brings in again another consolation, thus saying, "but to each one is given the manifestation of the Spirit to profit withal".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:125
verses.text: For lest one should say, "what if there be the same Lord, the same Spirit, the same God? yet I have received less:" he saith, that thus it was profitable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:126
verses.text: But he calls miracles a "manifestation of the Spirit," with evident reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:127
verses.text: For to me who am a believer, he that hath the Spirit is manifest from his having been baptized: but to the unbeliever this will in no wise be manifest, except from the miracles: so that hence also again there is no small consolation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:128
verses.text: For though there be a difference of gifts, yet the evidence is one: since whether thou hast much or little, thou art equally manifest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:129
verses.text: So that if thou desirest to show this, that thou hast the Spirit, thou hast a sufficient demonstration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:130
verses.text: Wherefore, now that both the Giver is one and the thing given a pure favor, and the manifestation takes place thereby, and this is more profitable for thee; grieve not as if despised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:131
verses.text: For not to dishonor thee hath God done it, nor to declare thee inferior to another, but to spare thee and with a view to thy welfare.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:132
verses.text: To receive more than one has ability to bear, this rather is unprofitable, and injurious, and a fit cause of dejection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:133
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:134
verses.text: "For to one is given through the Spirit the word of wisdom; to another the word of knowledge according to the same Spirit;"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:135
verses.text: "To another, faith in the same Spirit; to another gifts of healing in the one Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:136
verses.text: Seest thou how he every where makes this addition, saying, "through the same Spirit, and according to the same Spirit?" For he knew that the comfort from thence was great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:137
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:138
verses.text: "To another working of miracles; to another prophecies; to another discernings of spirits; to another divers kind of tongues; to another the interpretation of tongues".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:139
verses.text: Thus, since they boasted themselves in this, therefore he placed it last, and added,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:140
verses.text: "But all these worketh one and the same Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:141
verses.text: The universal medicine in which his consolation consists is that out of the same root, out of the same treasures, out of the same streams, they all receive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:142
verses.text: And accordingly, from time to time dwelling on this expression, he levels the apparent inequality, and consoles them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:143
verses.text: And above indeed he points out both the Spirit, and the Son, and the Father, as supplying the gifts, but here he was content to make the Spirit, that even hence again thou mayest understand their dignity to be the same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:144
verses.text: But what is "the word of wisdom?" That which Paul had, which John had, the son of thunder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:145
verses.text: And what is "the word of knowledge?" That which most of the faithful had, possessing indeed knowledge, but not thereupon able to teach nor easily to convey to another what they knew.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:146
verses.text: "And to another, faith:" not meaning by this faith the faith of doctrines, but the faith of miracles; concerning which Christ saith, "If ye have faith as a grain of mustard-seed, ye shall say to this mountain, Remove, and it shall remove".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:148
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:149
verses.text: xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:150
verses.text: ) And the Apostles too concerning this besought Him, saying, "Increase our faith:" (S.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:151
verses.text: Luke xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:152
verses.text: ) for this is the mother of the miracles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:153
verses.text: But to possess the power of working miracles and gifts of healing, is not the same thing: for he that had a gift of healing used only to do cures: but he that possessed powers for working miracles used to punish also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:154
verses.text: For a miracle is not the healing only, but the punishing also: even as Paul inflicted blindness: as Peter slew.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:155
verses.text: "To another prophecies; and to another discernings of spirits".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:156
verses.text: What is, "discernings of spirits?" the knowing who is spiritual, and who is not: who is a prophet, and who a deceiver: as he said to the Thessalonians, "despise not prophesyings:" ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:157
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:159
verses.text: ) but proving all things, hold fast that which is good".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:160
verses.text: For great was at that time the rush of the false prophets, the devil striving underhand to substitute falsehood for the truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:161
verses.text: "To another divers kinds of tongues; to another the interpretation of tongues".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:162
verses.text: For one person knew what he spake himself, but was unable to interpret to another; while another had acquired both these or the other of the two.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:163
verses.text: Now this seemed to be a great gift because both the Apostles received it first, and the most among the Corinthians had obtained it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:164
verses.text: But the word of teaching not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:165
verses.text: Wherefore that he places first, but this last: for this was on account of that, and so indeed were all the rest; both prophecies, and working of miracles, and divers kinds of tongues, and interpretation of tongues.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:166
verses.text: For none is equal to this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:167
verses.text: Wherefore also he said, "Let the elders that rule well be counted worthy of double honor, especially they who labor in the word and in teaching".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:168
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:169
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:170
verses.text: ) And to Timothy he wrote, saying, "Give attendance to reading, to exhortation, to teaching; neglect not the gift that is in thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:171
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:172
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:174
verses.text: ) Seest thou how he calls it also a gift?   Next, the comfort which he before gave, when he said, "the same Spirit," this also he here sets before us, saying, "But all these worketh the one and the same Spirit, dividing to each one severally even as he will".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:175
verses.text: And he not only gives consolation but also stops the mouth of the gainsayer, saying here, "dividing to each one severally even as he will".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:176
verses.text: For it was necessary to bind up also, not to heal only, as he doth also in the Epistle to the Romans, when he saith, "But who art thou that repliest against God? (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:177
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:178
verses.text: ) So likewise here, "dividing to each one severally as he will".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:179
verses.text: And that which was of the Father, this he signifieth to be of the Spirit also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:180
verses.text: For as concerning the Father, he saith, "but it is the same God who worketh all things in all;" so also concerning the Spirit, "but all these things worketh one and the same Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:181
verses.text: But, it will be said, "He doth it, actuated by God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:182
verses.text: Nay, he no where said this, but thou feignest it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:183
verses.text: For when he saith, "who actuateth all things in all," he saith this concerning men: thou wilt hardly say that among those men he numbers also the Spirit, though thou shouldst be ever so manifold in thy doting and madness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:184
verses.text: For because he had said "through the Spirit," that thou mightest not suppose this word, "through," to denote inferiority or the being actuated, he adds, that "the Spirit worketh," not "is worked," and worketh "as he will," not as he is bidden.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:185
verses.text: For as concerning the Father, the Son saith that "He raiseth up the dead and quickeneth;" in like manner also, concerning Himself, that "He quickeneth whom He will:" (S.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:186
verses.text: John v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:187
verses.text: ) thus also of the Spirit, in another place, that He doeth all things with authority and that there is nothing that hinders Him; (for the expression, "bloweth where it listeth" S.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:188
verses.text: John iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:189
verses.text: , though it be spoken of the wind is apt to establish this;) but here, that "He worketh all things as He will".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:190
verses.text: And from another place to learn that He is not one of the things actuated, but of those that actuate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:191
verses.text: "For who knoweth," says he, "the things of a man, but the spirit of the man? even so the things of God none knoweth save the Spirit of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:192
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:193
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:194
verses.text: ) Now that "the spirit of a man," i-e:, the soul, requires not to be actuated that it may know the things of itself, is, I suppose, evident to every one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:195
verses.text: Therefore neither doth the Holy Ghost, that he may "know the things of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:196
verses.text: For his meaning is like this, "the secret things of God" are known to the Holy Spirit as to the soul of man the secret things of herself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:197
verses.text: But if this be not actuated for that end, much less would That which knoweth the depths of God and needs no actuation for that knowledge, require any actuating Power in order to the giving gifts to the Apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:198
verses.text: But besides these things, that also, which I before spake of, I will mention again now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:199
verses.text: What then is this? That if the Spirit were inferior and of another substance, there would have been no avail in his consolation, nor in our hearing the words, "of the same Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:200
verses.text: For he who hath received from the king, I grant, may find it a very soothing circumstance, that he himself gave to him; but if it be from the slave, he is then rather vexed, when one reproaches him with it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:201
verses.text: So that even hence is it evident, that the Holy Spirit is not of the substance of the servant, but of the King.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:202
verses.text: Wherefore as he comforted them, when he said, that "there are diversities of ministrations, but the same Lord; and diversities of operations, but the same God;" so also when he said above, "there are diversities of gifts, but the same Spirit;" and after this again when he said, "But all these worketh the one and the same Spirit, dividing to every man severally as he will".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:203
verses.text: "Let us not, I pray you, be at a loss," saith he; "neither let us grieve, saying, 'Why have I received this and not received that?' neither let us demand an account of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:204
verses.text: For if thou knowest that he vouchsafed it from providential care, consider that from the same care he hath given also the measure of it, and be content and rejoice in what thou hast received: but murmur not at what thou hast not received; yea, rather confess God's favor that thou hast not received things beyond thy power".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:205
verses.text: And if in spiritual things one ought not to be over-curious, much more in temporal things; but to be quiet and not nicely enquire why one is rich and another poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:206
verses.text: For, first of all, not every single rich man is rich from God, but many even of unrighteousness, and rapine, and avarice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:207
verses.text: For he that forbade to be rich, how can he have granted that which he forbade to receive?  But that I may, far above what the case requires, stop the mouths of those who concerning these things gainsay us, come, let us carry our discourse higher up, to the time when riches used to be given by God; and answer me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:208
verses.text: Wherefore was Abraham rich whereas Jacob wanted even bread? Were not both the one and the other righteous? Doth He not say concerning the three alike, "I am the God of Abraham, and of Isaac, and of Jacob?" (Exod.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:209
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:210
verses.text: ) Wherefore then was the one a rich man, and the other a hired servant? Or rather, why was Esau rich, who was unrighteous and a murderer of his brother, while Jacob was in bondage for so long a time? Wherefore again did Isaac live in ease all his time, but Jacob in toils and miseries? For which cause also he said, "Few and evil are my days".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:211
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:212
verses.text: xlvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:213
verses.text: )  Wherefore did David, who was both a prophet and a king, himself also live all his time in toils? whereas Solomon his son spent forty years in security above all men, in the enjoyment of profound peace, glory, and honor, and going through every kind of deliciousness? What again could be the reason, that among the prophets also one was afflicted more, and another less? Because so it was expedient for each.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:214
verses.text: Wherefore upon each our remark must be, "Thy judgments are a great deep".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:215
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:216
verses.text: xxxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:217
verses.text: ) For if those great and wonderful men were not alike exercised by God, but one by poverty, and another by riches; one by ease, and another by trouble; much more ought we now to bear these things in mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:218
verses.text: But besides this, it becomes one to consider also that many of the things which happen do not take place according to His mind, but arise from our wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:219
verses.text: Say not then, "Why is one man rich who is wicked, and another poor who is righteous?" For first of all, one may give an account of these things also, and say that neither doth the righteous receive any harm from his poverty, nay, even a greater addition of honor; and that the bad man in his riches possesseth but a store of punishment on his future road, unless he be changed: and, even before punishment, often-times his riches become to him the cause of many evils, and lead him into ten thousand pitfalls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:220
verses.text: But God permits it, at the same to signify the free choice of the will, and also to teach all others not to be mad nor rave after money.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:221
verses.text: "How is it then, when a man being wicked is rich, and suffers nothing dreadful?" say you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:222
verses.text: "Since if being good he hath wealth, he hath it justly: but if bad, what shall we say?" That even therein he is to be pitied.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:223
verses.text: For wealth added to wickedness aggravates the mischief.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:224
verses.text: But is he a good man, and poor? Yet is he nothing injured.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:225
verses.text: Is he then a bad man, and poor? This is he so justly and by desert, or rather even with advantage to himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:226
verses.text: "But such an one," say you, "received his riches from his ancestors and lavishes it upon harlots and parasites, and suffers no evil".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:227
verses.text: What sayest thou? Doth he commit whoredom, and sayest thou, "he suffers no evils?" Is he drunken, and thinkest thou that he is in luxury? Doth he spend for no good, and judgest thou that he is to be envied? Nay what can be worse than this wealth which destroys the very soul? But thou, if the body were distorted and maimed, wouldest say that his was a case for great lamentation; and seest thou his whole soul mutilated, yet countest him even happy? "But he doth not perceive it," say you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:228
verses.text: Well then, for this very reason again is he to be pitied, as all frantic persons are.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:229
verses.text: For he that knows he is sick will of course both seek the physician and submit to remedies; but he that is ignorant of it will have no chance at all of deliverance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:230
verses.text: Dost thou call such an one happy, tell me?  But it is no marvel: for the more part are ignorant of the true love of wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:231
verses.text: Therefore do we suffer the extremest penalty, being chastised and not even withdrawing ourselves from the punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:232
verses.text: For this cause are angers, dejections, and continual tumults; because when God hath shown us a life without sorrow, the life of virtue, we leave this and mark out another way, the way of riches and money, full of infinite evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:233
verses.text: And we do the same, as if one, not knowing how to discern the beauty of men's bodies but attributing the whole to the clothes and the ornaments worn, when he saw a handsome woman and possessed of natural beauty, should pass quickly by her, but when he beheld one ugly, ill-shaped, and deformed, but clothed in beautiful garments, should take her for his wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:234
verses.text: Now also in some such way are the multitude affected about virtue and vice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:235
verses.text: They admit the one that is deformed by nature on account of her external ornaments, but turn away from her that is fair and lovely, on account of her unadorned beauty, for which cause they ought especially to choose her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:236
verses.text: Therefore am I ashamed that among the foolish heathen there are those that practise this philosophy, if not in deeds, yet so far at least as judgment goes; and who know the perishable nature of things present: whereas amongst us some do not even understand these things, but have their very judgment corrupted: and this while the Scripture is ever and anon sounding in our ears, and saying, "In his sight the vile person is contemned, but he honoreth them that fear the Lord: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:237
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:238
verses.text: ) the fear of the Lord excelleth every thing; fear God, and keep His commandments; for this is the whole of man: (Eccles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:239
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:240
verses.text: ;) be not thou envious of evil men; (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:241
verses.text: xlix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:242
verses.text: ;) all flesh is grass, and all the glory of man as the flower of grass;" (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:243
verses.text: xl.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:244
verses.text: ) For these and such-like things though we hear every day, we are yet nailed to earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:245
verses.text: And as ignorant children, who learn their letters continuously, if they be examined concerning their order when they are disarranged, naming one instead of another, make much laughter: so also ye, when here we recount them in order, follow us in a manner; but when we ask you out of doors and in no set order, what we ought to place first and what next among things, and which after which; not knowing how to answer, ye become ridiculous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:246
verses.text: Is it not a matter of great laughter, tell me, that they who expect immortality and the good "things which eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, neither have entered into the heart of man," should strive about things which linger here and count them enviable? For if thou hast need yet to learn these things that riches are no great thing, that things present are a shadow and a dream, that like smoke they are dissolved and fly away: stand for the present without the sanctuary: abide in the vestibule: since thou art not yet worthy of the entrance to the palace-courts on high.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 28:247
