verses.text: For not so thoroughly are timber and wool wont to be eaten through by moth and worm abiding therein, as doth the fever of envy devour the very bones of the envious and destroy all self-command in their soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 30:169
verses.text: In order then that we may deliver both ourselves and others from these innumerable woes, let us expel from within us this evil fever, this that is more grievous than any gangrene: that having regained spiritual strength, we may both finish the present course and obtain the future crowns; unto which may we all attain, by the grace and mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father, with the Holy Ghost, be glory, power, honor, now and ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:1
verses.text: Homily XXXII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:3
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:4
verses.text: Now ye are the body of Christ and severally members thereof.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:5
verses.text: For lest any should say, "What is the example of the body to us? since the body is a slave to nature but our good deeds are of choice;" he applies it to our own concerns; and to signify that we ought to have the same concord of design as they have from nature, he saith, "Now ye are the body of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:6
verses.text: But if our body ought not to be divided, much less the body of Christ, and so much less as grace is more powerful than nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:7
verses.text: But what is the expression, "severally?" "So far at least as appertaineth to you; and so far as naturally a part should be built up from you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:8
verses.text: For because he had said, "the body," whereas the whole body was not the Corinthian Church, but the Church in every part of the world, therefore he said, "severally:" i-e:, the Church amongst you is a part of the Church existing every where and of the body which is made up of all the Churches: so that not only with yourselves alone, but also with the whole Church throughout the world, ye ought to be at peace, if at least ye be members of the whole body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:9
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:10
verses.text: "And God hath set some in the Church: first apostles, secondly prophets, thirdly teachers, then miracles, then gifts of healings, helps, governments, divers kinds of tongues".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:11
verses.text: Thus what I spake of before, this also he now doth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:12
verses.text: Because they thought highly of themselves in respect of the tongues he sets it last every where.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:13
verses.text: For the terms, "first" and "secondly," are not used by him here at random, but in order by enumeration to point out the more honorable and the inferior.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:14
verses.text: Wherefore also he set the apostles first who had all the gifts in themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:15
verses.text: And he said not, "God hath set certain in the Church, apostles" simply, "or prophets," but he employs "first, second," and "third," signifying that same thing which I told you of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:16
verses.text: "Secondly, prophets".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:17
verses.text: For they used to prophesy, as the daughters of Philip, as Agabus, as these very persons among the Corinthians, of whom he saith, "Let the prophets speak, two or three".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:19
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:20
verses.text: ) And writing also to Timothy, he said, "Neglect not the gift that is in thee, which was given thee by prophecy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:21
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:22
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:23
verses.text: ) And they were much more many that prophesied.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:24
verses.text: And if Christ saith, "The Law and the Prophets prophesied until John," (S.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:25
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:26
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:27
verses.text: ) He saith it of those prophets who before proclaimed His coming.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:28
verses.text: "Thirdly, teachers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:29
verses.text: For he that prophesieth speaks all things from the Spirit; but he that teacheth sometimes discourses also out of his own mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:30
verses.text: Wherefore also he said, "Let the elders that rule well be counted worthy of double honor, especially they who labor in the word and in teaching:" ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:31
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:32
verses.text: ) whereas he that speaks all things by the Spirit doth not labor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:33
verses.text: This accordingly is the reason why he set him after the prophet, because the one is wholly a gift but the other is also man's labor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:34
verses.text: For he speaks many things of his own mind, agreeing however with the sacred Scriptures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:35
verses.text: "Then miracles, then gifts of healings".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:36
verses.text: Seest thou how he again divides the healings from the power, which also he did before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:37
verses.text: For the power is more than the healing: since he that hath power both punishes and heals, but he that hath the gift of healings doeth cures only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:38
verses.text: And observe how excellent the order he made use of, when he set the prophecy before the miracles and the healings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:39
verses.text: For above when he said, "To one is given by the Spirit the word of wisdom, and to another the word of knowledge," he spake, not setting them in order, but indifferently.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:40
verses.text: Here, on the other hand, he sets a first and a second rank.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:41
verses.text: Wherefore then doth he set prophecy first? Because even in the old covenant the matter has this order.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:42
verses.text: For example, when Isaiah was discoursing with the Jews, and exhibiting a demonstration of the power of God, and bringing forward the evidence of the worthlessness of the demons, he stated this also as the greater evidence of his divinity, his foretelling things to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:43
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:44
verses.text: xli.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:46
verses.text: ) And Christ Himself after working so many signs saith that this was no small sign of His divinity: and continually adds, "But these things have I told you, that when it is come to pass, ye may believe that I am He".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:48
verses.text: John xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:49
verses.text: ; xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:50
verses.text: ; xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:51
verses.text: )  "Well then; the gifts of healing are justly inferior to prophecy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:52
verses.text: But why likewise to teaching?" Because it is not the same thing to declare the word of preaching and sow piety in the hearts of the hearers, as it is to work miracles: since these are done merely for the sake of that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:53
verses.text: When therefore any one teaches both by word and life, he is greater than all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:54
verses.text: For those he calls emphatically teachers, who both teach by deeds and instruct in word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:55
verses.text: For instance: this made the Apostles themselves to become Apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:56
verses.text: And those gifts certain others also, of no great worth, received in the beginning, as they who said, "Lord, did we not prophesy by Thy Name, and do mighty works?" and after this were told, "I never knew you; depart from Me, ye that work iniquity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:58
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:59
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:60
verses.text: ) But this twofold mode of teaching, I mean that by deeds and by words, no bad man would ever undertake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:61
verses.text: As to his setting the prophets first marvel not at it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:62
verses.text: For he is not speaking of prophets simply, but of those who by prophecy do also teach and say every thing to the common benefit: which in proceeding he makes more clear to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:63
verses.text: "Helps, governments".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:64
verses.text: What is, "helps?" To support the weak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:65
verses.text: Is this then a gift, tell me? In the first place, this too is of the Gift of God, aptness for a patron's office; the dispensing spiritual things; besides which he calls many even of our own good deeds, "gifts;" not meaning us to lose heart, but showing that in every case we need God's help, and preparing them to be thankful, and thereby making them more forward and stirring up their minds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:66
verses.text: "Divers kind of tongues".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:67
verses.text: Seest thou where he hath set this gift, and how he every where assigns it the last rank?   Further, since again by this catalogue he had pointed out a great difference, and stirred up the afore-mentioned distemper of those that had lesser gifts, he darts upon them in what follows with great vehemence, because he had already given them those many proofs of their not being left much inferior.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:68
verses.text: What I mean is; because it was likely that on hearing these things they would say, "And why were we not all made Apostles?"—whereas above he had made use of a more soothing tone of discourse, proving at length the necessity of this result, even from the image of the body; for "the body," saith he, "is not one member;" and again, "but if all were one member, where were the body?" and from the fact that they were given for use; for to each one is given "the manifestation of the Spirit," saith he, "to profit withal:" and from all being watered from the same Spirit: and from what is bestowed being a free gift and not a debt; "for there are," saith he, "diversities of gifts, but the same Spirit:" and from the manifestation of the Spirit being made alike through all; for "to each one," saith he, "is given the manifestation through the Spirit:" and from the fact that these things were shaped according to the pleasure of the Spirit and of God; "for all these," saith he, "worketh the one and the same Spirit, dividing to each one severally even as he will:" and, "God hath set the members each one of them in the body, even as it pleased Him:" and from the inferior members also being necessary; "for those which seem," saith he, "to be more feeble are necessary:" from their being alike necessary, in that they "from the greater too needing the less: "for the head," saith he, "cannot say to the feet, I have no need of you:" from these latter enjoying even more honor; for "to that which lacketh," saith he, "He hath given more abundant honor:" from the care of them being common and equal; for "for all the members have the same care one for another:" and from there being one honor and one grief of them all; for "whether," saith he, "one member suffereth, all the members suffer with it; or one member is honored, all the members rejoice with it:"—whereas, I say, he had above exhorted them by these topics, here and henceforth he uses language so as to bear them down and rebuke them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:69
verses.text: For, as I said, it behoves us neither always to exhort people nor always to silence them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:70
verses.text: Therefore also Paul himself, because he at length exhorted them, doth henceforth vehemently attack them, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:71
verses.text: "Are all apostles? are all prophets? have all gifts of healing?"  And he doth not stop at the first and the second gift, but proceeds to the last, either meaning this that all cannot be all things, (even as he there saith, "if all were one member, where were the body?") or establishing some other point also along with these, which may tell in the way of consolation again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:72
verses.text: What then is this? His signifying that even the lesser gifts are contended for equally with the greater, from the circumstance that not even these were given absolutely to all? For "why," saith he, "dost thou grieve that thou hast not gifts of healing? consider that what thou hast, even though it be less, is oftentimes not possessed by him that hath the greater".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:73
verses.text: Wherefore he saith,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:74
verses.text: "Do all speak with tongues? do all interpret?"  For even as the great gifts God hath not vouchsafed all to all men, but to some this, and to others that, so also did He in respect of the less, not proposing these either to all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:75
verses.text: And this He did, procuring thereby abundant harmony and love, that each one standing in need of the other might be brought close to his brother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:76
verses.text: This economy He established also in the arts, this also in the elements, this also in the plants, and in our members, and absolutely in all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:77
verses.text: Then he subjoins further the most powerful consolation, and sufficient to recover them and quiet their vexed souls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:78
verses.text: And what is this?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:79
verses.text: "Desire earnestly," saith he, "the better gifts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:80
verses.text: And a still more excellent way show I unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:81
verses.text: Now by saying this, he gently hinted that they were the cause of their own receiving the lesser gifts, and had it in their power, if they would, to receive the greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:82
verses.text: For when he saith, "desire earnestly," he demands from them all diligence and desire for spiritual things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:83
verses.text: And he said not, the greater gifts, but "the better," i-e:, the more useful, those which would profit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:84
verses.text: And what he means is this: "continue to desire gifts; and I point out to you a fountain of gifts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:85
verses.text: For neither did he say, "a gift," but "a way," that he might the more extol that which he intends to mention.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:86
verses.text: As if he said, It is not one, or two, or three gifts that I point out to you, but one way which leadeth to all these: and not merely a way, but both "a more excellent way" and one that is open in common to all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:87
verses.text: For not as the gifts are vouchsafed, to some these, to others those, but not all to all; so also in this case: but it is an universal gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:88
verses.text: Wherefore also he invites all to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:89
verses.text: "Desire earnestly," saith he, "the better gifts and yet show I unto you a more excellent way;" meaning love towards our neighbor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:90
verses.text: Then intending to proceed to the discourse concerning it and the encomium of this virtue, he first lowereth these by comparison with it, intimating that they are nothing without it; very considerately.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:91
verses.text: For if he had at once discoursed of love, and having said, "I show unto you a way," had added, "but this is love," and had not conducted his discourse by way of comparison; some might possibly have scoffed at what was said, not understanding clearly the force of the thing spoken of but still gaping after these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:92
verses.text: Wherefore he doth not at once unfold it, but first excites the hearer by the promise, and saith, "I show unto you a more excellent way," and so having led him to desire it, he doth not even thus straightway proceed to it, but augmenting still further and extending their desire, he discourses first of these very things, and shows that without it they are nothing; reducing them to the greatest necessity of loving one another; seeing also that from neglect of it sprang that which caused all their evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:93
verses.text: So that in this respect also it might justly appear great, if the gifts not only brought them not together, but divided them even when united: but this, when many were so divided, would reunite them by virtue of its own and make them one body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:94
verses.text: This however he doth not say at once, but what they chiefly longed for, that he sets down; as that the thing was a gift and a most excellent way to all the gifts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:95
verses.text: So that, even if thou wilt not love thy brother on the score of friendship, yet for the sake of obtaining a better sign and an abundant gift, cherish love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:96
verses.text: And see whence he first begins; from that which was marvellous in their eyes and great, the gift of tongues.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:97
verses.text: And in bringing forward that gift, he mentions it not just in the degree they had it in, but far more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:98
verses.text: For he did not say, "if I speak with tongues," but,  Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:99
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:100
verses.text: ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:101
verses.text: "If I speak with the tongues of men,—"  What is, "of men?" Of all nations in every part of the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:102
verses.text: And neither was he content with this amplification, but he likewise uses another much greater, adding the words, "and of angels,—and have not love, I am become sounding brass, or a clanging cymbal".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:103
verses.text: Dost thou see to what point he first exalted the gift, and to what afterwards he lowered and cast it down? For neither did he simply say, "I am nothing," but, "I am become sounding brass," a thing senseless and inanimate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:104
verses.text: But how "sounding brass?" Emitting a sound indeed, but at random and in vain, and for no good end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:105
verses.text: Since besides my profiting nothing, I am counted by most men as one giving impertinent trouble, an annoying and wearisome kind of person.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:106
verses.text: Seest thou how one void of love is like to things inanimate and senseless?  Now he here speaks of the "tongues of angels," not investing angels with a body, but what he means is this: "should I even so speak as angels are wont to discourse unto each other, without this I am nothing, nay rather a burden and an annoyance".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:107
verses.text: Thus (to mention one other example) where he saith, "To Him every knee shall bow, of things in heaven and things on earth, and things under the earth," (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:108
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:109
verses.text: ) he doth not say these things as if he attributed to angels knees and bones, far from it, but it is their intense adoration which he intends to shadow out by the fashion amongst us: so also here he calls it "a tongue" not meaning an instrument of flesh, but intending to indicate their converse with each other by the manner which is known amongst us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:110
verses.text: Then, in order that his discourse may be acceptable, he stops not at the gift of tongues, but proceeds also to the remaining gifts; and having depreciated all in the absence of love, he then depicts her image.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:111
verses.text: And because he preferred to conduct his argument by amplification, he begins from the less and ascends to the greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:112
verses.text: For whereas, when he indicated their order, he placed the gift of tongues last, this he now numbers first; by degrees, as I said, ascending to the greater gifts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:113
verses.text: Thus having spoken of tongues, he proceeds immediately to prophecy; and saith;  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:114
verses.text: "And if I have the gift of prophecy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:115
verses.text: And this gift again with an excellency.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:116
verses.text: For as in that case he mentioned not tongues, but the tongues of all mankind, and as he proceeded, those of angels, and then signified that the gift was nothing without love: so also here he mentions not prophecy alone but the very highest prophecy: in having said, "If I have prophecy," he added, "and know all mysteries and all knowledge;" expressing this gift also with intensity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:117
verses.text: Then after this also he proceeds to the other gifts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:118
verses.text: And again, that he might not seem to weary them, naming each one of the gifts, he sets down the mother and fountain of all, and this again with an excellency, thus saying, "And if I have all faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:119
verses.text: Neither was he content with this, but even that which Christ spake of as greatest, this also he added, saying, "so as to remove mountains and have not love, I am nothing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:120
verses.text: And consider how again here also he lowers the dignity of the tongues.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:121
verses.text: For whereas in regard of prophecy he signifies the great advantage arising from it, "the understanding mysteries, and having all knowledge;" and in regard of faith, no trifling work, even "the removing mountains;" in respect of tongues, on the other hand, having named the gift itself only, he quits it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:122
verses.text: But do thou, I pray, consider this also, how in brief he comprehended all gifts when he named prophecy and faith: for miracles are either in words or deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:123
verses.text: And how doth Christ say, that the least degree of faith is the being able to remove a mountain? For as though he were speaking something very small, did He express Himself when He said, "If ye have faith as a grain of mustard-seed, ye shall say to this mountain, Remove, and it shall remove;" (S.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:124
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:125
verses.text: xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:126
verses.text: ) whereas Paul saith that this is "all faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:127
verses.text: What then must one say? Since this was a great thing, the removing a mountain, therefore also he mentioned it, not as though "all faith" were only able to do this, but since this seemed to be great to the grosser sort because of the bulk of the outward mass, from this also he extols his subject.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:128
verses.text: And what he saith is this:  "If I have all faith, and can remove mountains, but have not love, I am nothing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:129
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:130
verses.text: "And if I bestow all my goods to feed the poor, and if I give my body to be burned, but have not love, it profiteth me nothing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:131
verses.text: Wonderful amplification! For even these things too he states with another addition: in that he said not, "if I give to the poor the half of my goods," or "two or three parts," but, "though I give all my goods".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:132
verses.text: And he said not, "give," but, "distribute in morsels," so that to the expense may be added the administering also with all care.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:133
verses.text: But not even yet have I pointed out the whole of the excellency, until I bring forward the testimonies of Christ which were spoken concerning almsgiving and death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:134
verses.text: What then are His testimonies? To the rich man He saith, "If thou wouldest be perfect, sell what thou hast and give to the poor, and come, follow me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:136
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:137
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:138
verses.text: ) And discoursing likewise of love to one's neighbor, He saith, "Greater love hath no man than this, that a man may lay down his life for his friends".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:140
verses.text: John xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:141
verses.text: ) Whence it is evident, that even before God this is greatest of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:142
verses.text: But, "I declare," said Paul, "that even if we should lay down life for God's sake, and not merely lay it down, but so as even to be burned, (for this is the meaning of, "if I give my body to be burned,") we shall have no great advantage if we love not our neighbor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:143
verses.text: Well then, the saying that the gifts are of no great profit without charity is no marvel: since our gifts are a secondary consideration to our way of life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:144
verses.text: At any rate, many have displayed gifts, and yet on becoming vicious have been punished: as those who "prophesied in His name, and cast out many demons, and wrought many mighty works;" as Judas the traitor: while others, exhibiting as believers a pure life, have needed nothing else in order to their salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:145
verses.text: Wherefore, that the gifts should, as I said, require this, is no marvel: but that an exact life even should avail nothing without it, this is what brings the intensity of expression strongly out and causes great perplexity: especially too when Christ appears to adjudge His great rewards to both these, I mean to the giving up our possessions, and to the perils of martyrdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:146
verses.text: For both to the rich man He saith, as I before observed, "If thou wilt be perfect, sell thy goods, and give to the poor, and come, follow me:" and discoursing with the disciples, of martyrdom He saith, "Whosoever shall lose his life for My sake, shall find it;" and, "Whosoever shall confess Me before men, him will I also confess before My Father which is in heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:147
verses.text: For great indeed is the labor of this achievement, and well nigh surpassing nature itself, and this is well known to such as have had these crowns vouchsafed to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:148
verses.text: For no language can set it before us: so noble a soul doth the deed belong to and so exceedingly wonderful is it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:149
verses.text: But nevertheless, this so wonderful thing Paul said was of no great profit without love, even though it have the giving up of one's goods joined with it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:150
verses.text: Wherefore then hath he thus spoken? This will I now endeavor to explain, first having enquired of this, How is it possible that one who gives all his goods to feed the poor can be wanting in love? I grant, indeed, he that is ready to be burned and hath the gifts, may perhaps possibly not have love: but he who not only gives his goods, but even distributes them in morsels; how hath not he love? What then are we to say? Either that he supposed an unreal case as real; which kind of thing he is ever wont to do, when he intends to set before us something in excess; as when writing to the Galatians he saith, "If we or an angel from heaven preach any other gospel unto you than that ye receive let him be accursed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:151
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:152
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:153
verses.text: ) And yet neither was himself nor an angel about to do so; but to signify that he meant to carry the matter as far as possible, he set down even that which could never by any means happen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:154
verses.text: And again, when he writes to the Romans, and saith, "Neither angels, nor principalities, nor powers, shall be able to separate us from the love of God;" for neither was this about to be done by any angels: but here too he supposes a thing which was not; as indeed also in what comes next, saying, "nor any other creature," whereas there is no other creature, for he had comprehended the whole creation, having spoken of all things both above and below.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:155
verses.text: Nevertheless here also he mentions that which was not, by way of hypothesis, so as to show his exceeding desire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:156
verses.text: Now the same thing he doth here also, saying, "If a man give all, and have not love, it profits him nothing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:157
verses.text: Either then we may say this, or that his meaning is for those who give to be also joined closely to those who retire, and not merely to give without sympathy, but in pity and condescension, bowing down and grieving with the needy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:158
verses.text: For therefore also hath almsgiving been enacted by God: since God might have nourished the poor as well without this, but that he might bind us together unto charity and that we might be thoroughly fervent toward each other, he commanded them to be nourished by us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:159
verses.text: Therefore one saith in another place also; "a good word is better than a gift;" (Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:160
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:162
verses.text: ) and, "behold, a word is beyond a good gift".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:163
verses.text: (Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:164
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:166
verses.text: ) And He Himself saith, "I will have mercy, and not sacrifice".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:168
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:169
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:170
verses.text: ; Hos.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:171
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:172
verses.text: ) For since it is usual, both for men to love those who are benefited by them, and for those who receive benefits to be more kindly affected towards their benefactors; he made this law, constituting it a bond of friendship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:173
verses.text: But the point proposed for enquiry above is, How, after Christ had said that both these belong to perfection, Paul affirms, that these without charity are imperfect? Not contradicting Him, God forbid: but harmonizing with Him, and that exactly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:174
verses.text: For so in the case of the rich man, He said, not merely, "sell thy goods, and give to the poor," but He added, "and come, follow Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:175
verses.text: Now not even the following Him proves any man a disciple of Christ so completely as the loving one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:176
verses.text: For, "by this shall all men know," saith He, "that ye are My disciples, if ye have love one to another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:178
verses.text: John xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:179
verses.text: ) And also when He saith, "Whosoever loseth his life for My sake, shall find it;" (S.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:180
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:181
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:183
verses.text: ) and, "whosoever shall confess Me before men, him will I also confess before My Father which is in heaven;" He means not this, that it is not necessary to have love, but He declares the reward which is laid up for these labors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:184
verses.text: Since that along with martyrdom He requires also this, is what He elsewhere strongly intimates, thus saying, "Ye shall indeed drink of My cup, and be baptized with the baptism that I am baptized with;" (S.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:185
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:186
verses.text: xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:187
verses.text: ) i-e:, ye shall be martyrs, ye shall be slain for My sake; "but to sit on My right hand, and on My left, (not as though any sit on the right hand and the left, but meaning the highest precedency and honor) "is not Mine to give," saith He, "but to those for whom it is prepared".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:188
verses.text: Then signifying for whom it is prepared, He calls them and saith, "whosoever among you will be chief, let him be servant to you all;" (S.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:189
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:190
verses.text: xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:191
verses.text: ) setting forth humility and love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:192
verses.text: And the love which He requires is intense; wherefore He stopped not even at this, but added, "even as the Son of Man came not to be ministered unto, but to minister, and to give His life a ransom for many;" pointing out that we ought so to love as even to be slain for our beloved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:193
verses.text: For this above all is to love Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:194
verses.text: Wherefore also He saith to Peter, "If thou lovest Me, feed My sheep".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:196
verses.text: John xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:197
verses.text: )   And that ye may learn how great a work of virtue it is, let us sketch it out in word, since in deeds we see it no where appearing; and let us consider, if it were every where in abundance, how great benefits would ensue: how there were no need then of laws, or tribunals or punishments, or avenging, or any other such things since if all loved and were beloved, no man would injure another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:198
verses.text: Yea, murders, and strifes, and wars, and divisions, and rapines, and frauds, and all evils would be removed, and vice be unknown even in name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:199
verses.text: Miracles, however, would not have effected this; they rather puff up such as are not on their guard, unto vain-glory and folly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:200
verses.text: Again: what is indeed the marvellous part of love; all the other good things have their evils yoked with them: as he that gives up his possessions is oftentimes puffed up on this account: the eloquent is affected with a wild passion for glory; the humble-minded, on this very ground, not seldom thinks highly of himself in his conscience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:201
verses.text: But love is free from every such mischief.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:202
verses.text: For none could ever be lifted up against the person whom he loves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:203
verses.text: And do not, I pray, suppose one person only loving but all alike; and then wilt thou see its virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:204
verses.text: Or rather, if thou wilt, first suppose one single person beloved, and one loving; loving, however, as it is meet to love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:205
verses.text: Why, he will so live on earth as if it were heaven, every where enjoying a calm and weaving for himself innumerable crowns.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:206
verses.text: For both from envy, and wrath, and jealousy, and pride, and vain-glory, and evil concupiscence, and every profane love, and every distemper, such a man will keep his own soul pure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:207
verses.text: Yea, even as no one would do himself an injury so neither would this man his neighbors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:208
verses.text: And being such, he shall stand with Gabriel himself, even while he walks on earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:209
verses.text: Such then is he that hath love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:210
verses.text: But he that works miracles and hath perfect knowledge, without this, though he raises ten thousand from the dead, will not be much profited, broken off as he is from all and not enduring to mix himself up with any of his fellow-servants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:211
verses.text: For no other cause than this did Christ say that the sign of perfect love towards Him is the loving one's neighbors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:212
verses.text: For, "if thou lovest Me," saith He, "O Peter, more than these, feed My sheep".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:214
verses.text: John xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:215
verses.text: ) Dost thou see how hence also He again covertly intimates, in what case this is greater than martyrdom? For if any one had a beloved child in whose behalf he would even give up his life, and some one were to love the father, but pay no regard whatever to the son, he would greatly incense the father; nor would he feel the love for himself, because of the overlooking his son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:216
verses.text: Now if this ensue in the case of father and son, much more in the case of God and men: since surely God is more loving than any parents.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:217
verses.text: Wherefore, having said, "The first and great commandment is, Thou shalt love the Lord thy God," he added, "and the second—(He leaves it not in silence, but sets it down also)—is like unto it, Thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:218
verses.text: And see how with nearly the same excellency He demands also this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:219
verses.text: For as concerning God, He saith, "with all thy heart:" so concerning thy neighbor, "as thyself," which is tantamount to, "with all thy heart".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:220
verses.text: Yea, and if this were duly observed, there would be neither slave nor free, neither ruler nor ruled, neither rich nor poor, neither small nor great; nor would any devil then ever have been known: I say not, Satan only, but whatever other such spirit there be, nay, rather were there a hundred or ten thousand such, they would have no power, while love existed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:221
verses.text: For sooner would grass endure the application of fire than the devil the flame of love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:222
verses.text: She is stronger than any wall, she is firmer than any adamant; or if thou canst name any material stronger than this the firmness of love transcends them all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:223
verses.text: Her, neither wealth nor poverty overcometh: nay, rather there would be no poverty, no unbounded wealth, if there were love, but the good parts only from each estate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:224
verses.text: For from the one we should reap its abundance, and from the other its freedom from care: and should neither have to undergo the anxieties of riches, nor the dread of poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:225
verses.text: And why do I mention the advantages arising from it? Yea, rather consider how great a blessing it is of itself to exercise love; what cheerfulness it produces, in how great grace it establishes the soul; a thing which above all is a choice quality of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:226
verses.text: For the other parts of virtue have each their troubles yoked with them; as fasting, temperance, watching, have envy, concupiscence, and contempt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:227
verses.text: But love along with the gain hath great pleasure, too, and no trouble, and like an industrious bee, gathering the sweets from every flower, deposits them in the soul of him who loveth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:228
verses.text: Though any one be a slave, it renders slavery sweeter that liberty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:229
verses.text: For he who loveth rejoices not so much in commanding, as in being commanded, although to command is sweet: but love changes the nature of things and presents herself with all blessings in her hands, gentler than any mother, wealthier than any queen, and makes difficulties light and easy, causing our virtues to be facile, but vice very bitter to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:230
verses.text: As thus: to expend seems grievous, yet love makes it pleasant: to receive other men's goods, pleasant, but love suffers it not to appear pleasant, but frames our minds to avoid it as an evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:231
verses.text: Again, to speak evil seems to be pleasant to all; but love, while she makes this out to be bitter, causeth speaking well to be pleasant; for nothing is so sweet to us as to be praising one whom we love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:232
verses.text: Again, anger hath a kind of pleasure; but in this case no longer, rather all its sinews are taken away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:233
verses.text: Though he that is beloved should grieve him who loves him, anger no where shows itself; but tears and exhortations, and supplications; so far is love from being exasperated: and should she behold one in error, she mourns and is in pain; yet even this pain itself brings pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:234
verses.text: For the very tears and the grief of love, are sweeter than any mirth and joy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:235
verses.text: For instance: they that laugh are not so refreshed as they that weep for their friends.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:236
verses.text: And if thou doubt it, stop their tears; and they repine at it not otherwise than as persons intolerably ill-used.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:237
verses.text: "But there is," said one, "an unbecoming pleasure in love".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:238
verses.text: Avaunt, and hold thy peace, whoever thou art.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:239
verses.text: For nothing is so pure from such pleasure as genuine love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:240
verses.text: For tell me not of this ordinary sort, the vulgar and low-minded, and a disease rather than love, but of this which Paul seeks after, which considers the profit of them that are loved; and thou shalt see that no fathers are so affectionate as persons of this stamp.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:241
verses.text: And even as they who love money cannot endure to spend money, but would with more pleasure be in straits than see their wealth diminishing: so too, he that is kindly affected towards any one, would choose to suffer ten thousand evils than see his beloved one injured.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:242
verses.text: "How then," saith one, "did the Egyptian woman who loved Joseph wish to injure him?" Because she loved with this diabolical love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:243
verses.text: Joseph however not with this, but with that which Paul requires.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:244
verses.text: Consider then how great a love his words were tokens of, and the action which she was speaking of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:245
verses.text: "Insult me and make me an adulteress, and wrong my husband, and overthrow all my house, and cast thyself out from thy confidence towards God:" which were expressions of one who so far from loving him did not even love herself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:246
verses.text: But because he truly loved, he sought to avert her from all these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:247
verses.text: And to convince you that it was in anxiety for her, learn the nature of it from his advice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:248
verses.text: For he not only thrust her away, but also introduced an exhortation capable of quenching every flame: namely "if on my account, my master," saith he, "knoweth not any thing which is in his house".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:249
verses.text: He at once reminds her of her husband that he might put her to shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:250
verses.text: And he said not, "thy husband," but "my master," which was more apt to restrain her and induce her to consider who she was, and of whom she was enamored,—a mistress, of a slave.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:251
verses.text: "For if he be lord, then art thou mistress.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:252
verses.text: Be ashamed then of familiarity with a servant, and consider whose wife thou art, and with whom thou wouldst be connected, and towards whom thou art becoming thankless and inconsiderate, and that I repay him greater good-will".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:253
verses.text: And see how he extols his benefits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:254
verses.text: For since that barbarous and abandoned woman could entertain no lofty sentiment, he shames her from human considerations, saying, "He knoweth nothing through me," i-e:, "he is a great benefactor to me, and I cannot strike my patron in a vital part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:255
verses.text: He hath made me a second lord of his house, and no one hath been kept back from me, but thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:256
verses.text: Here he endeavors to raise her mind, that so at any rate he might persuade her to be ashamed, and might signify the greatness of her honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:257
verses.text: Nor did he stop even here, but likewise added a name sufficient to restrain her, saying, "Because thou art his wife; and how shall I do this wickedness? But what sayest thou? That thy husband is not present, nor knoweth that he is wronged? But God will behold it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:258
verses.text: She however profited nothing by his advice, but still sought to attract him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:259
verses.text: For desiring to satiate her own frenzy, not through love of Joseph, she did these things; and this is evident from what she did afterwards.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:260
verses.text: As that she institutes a trial, and brings in accusation, and bears false witness, and exposes to a wild beast him that had done no wrong, and casts him into a prison; or rather for her part, she even slew him, in such a manner did she arm the judge against him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:261
verses.text: What then? Was then Joseph too such as she was? Nay, altogether the contrary, for he neither contradicted nor accused the woman.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:262
verses.text: "Yes," it may be said: "for he would have been disbelieved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:263
verses.text: And yet he was greatly beloved; and this is evident not only from the beginning but also from the end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:264
verses.text: For had not his barbarian master loved him greatly, he would even have slain him in his silence, making no defence: being as he was an Egyptian and a ruler, and wronged in his marriage-bed as he supposed, and by a servant, and a servant to whom he had been so great a benefactor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:265
verses.text: But all these things gave way to his regard for him, and the grace which God poured down upon him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:266
verses.text: And together with this grace and love, he had also other no small proofs, had he been minded to justify himself; the garments themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:267
verses.text: For if it were she to whom violence was done, her own vest should have been torn, her face lacerated, instead of her retaining his garments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:268
verses.text: But "he heard," saith she, "that I lifted up my voice, and left his garments, and went out".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:269
verses.text: And wherefore then didst thou take them from him? since unto one suffering violence, the one thing desirable is to be rid of the intruder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:270
verses.text: But not from hence alone, but also from the subsequent events, shall I be able to point out his good-will and his love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:271
verses.text: Yea even when he fell into a necessity of mentioning the cause of his imprisonment, and his remaining there, he did not even then declare the whole course of the story.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:272
verses.text: But what saith he? "I too have done nothing: but indeed I was stolen out of the land of the Hebrews;" and he no where mentioned the adulteress nor doth he plume himself on the matter, which would have been any one's feeling, if not for vain-glory, yet so as not to appear to have been cast into that cell for an evil cause.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:273
verses.text: For if men in the act of doing wrong by no means abstain even so from blaming the same things, although to do so brings reproach; of what admiration is not he worthy, because, pure as he was he did not mention the woman's passion nor make a show of her sin; nor when he ascended the throne and became ruler of all Egypt, remember the wrong done by the woman nor exact any punishment?  Seest thou how he cared for her? but her's was not love, but madness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:274
verses.text: For it was not Joseph that she loved, but she sought to fulfil her own lust.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:275
verses.text: And the very words too, if one would examine them accurately, were accompanied with wrath and great blood-thirstiness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:276
verses.text: For what saith she? "Thou hast brought in a Hebrew servant to mock us:" upbraiding her husband for the kindness; and she exhibited the garments, having become herself more savage than any wild beast: but not so he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:277
verses.text: And why speak I of his good-will to her, when he was such, we know, towards his brethren who would slay him; and never said one harsh thing of them, either within doors or without?   Therefore Paul saith, that the love which we are speaking of is the mother of all good things, and prefers it to miracles and all other gifts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:278
verses.text: For as where there are vests and sandals of gold, we require also some other garments whereby to distinguish the king: but if we see the purple and the diadem, we require not to see any other sign of his royalty: just so here likewise, when the diadem of love is upon our head, it is enough to point out the genuine disciple of Christ, not to ourselves only, but also to the unbelievers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:279
verses.text: For, "by this," saith He, "shall all men know that ye are My disciples, if ye have love one to another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:281
verses.text: John xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:282
verses.text: ) So that this sign is greater surely than all signs, in that the disciple is recognised by it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:283
verses.text: For though any should work ten thousand signs, but be at strife one with another, they will be a scorn to the unbelievers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:284
verses.text: Just as if they do no sign, but love one another exactly, they will continue both reverenced and inviolable by all men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:285
verses.text: Since Paul himself we admire on this account, not for the dead whom he raised, nor for the lepers whom he cleansed, but because he said, "who is weak, and I am not weak? who is made to stumble, and I burn not?" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:286
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:287
verses.text: ) For shouldest thou have ten thousand miracles to compare with this, thou wilt have nothing equal to it to say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:288
verses.text: Since Paul also himself said, that a great reward was laid up for him, not because he wrought miracles, but because "to the weak he became as weak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:289
verses.text: For what is my reward?" saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:290
verses.text: "That, when I preach the Gospel, I may make the Gospel without charge".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:291
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:292
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:293
verses.text: ) And when he puts himself before the Apostles, he saith not, "I have wrought miracles more abundant than they," but, "I have labored more abundantly than they".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:294
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:295
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:296
verses.text: ) And even by famine was he willing to perish for the salvation of the disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:297
verses.text: "For it were better for me to die," saith he, "than that any man should make my glorying void:" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:298
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:299
verses.text: ) not because he was glorying, but that he might not seem to reproach them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:300
verses.text: For he no where is wont to glory in his own achievements, when the season doth not call to it; but even if he be compelled so to do he calleth himself "a fool".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:301
verses.text: But if he ever glory it is "in infirmities," in wrongs, in greatly sympathizing with those who are injured: even as here also he saith, "who is weak, and I am not weak?" These words are greater even than perils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:302
verses.text: Wherefore also he sets them last, amplifying his discourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:303
verses.text: Of what then must we be worthy compared with him, who neither contemn wealth for our own sake, nor give up the superfluities of our goods? But not so Paul; rather both soul and body did he use to give up, that they who stoned and beat him with rods, might obtain the kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:304
verses.text: "For thus," saith he, "hath Christ taught me to love;" who left behind Him the new commandment concerning love, which also Himself fulfilled in deed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:305
verses.text: For being Lord of all, and of that Blessed Nature; from men, whom He created out of nothing and on whom He had bestowed innumerable benefits, from these, insulting and spitting on Him, He turned not away, but even became man for their sakes, and conversed with harlots and publicans, and healed the demoniacs, and promised heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:306
verses.text: And after all these things they apprehended and beat him with rods, bound, scourged, mocked, and at last crucified Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:307
verses.text: And not even so did He turn away, but even when He was on high upon the cross, He saith, "Father, forgive them their sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:308
verses.text: But the thief who before this reviled Him, He translated into very paradise; and made the persecutor Paul, an Apostle; and gave up His own disciples, who were His intimates and wholly devoted to Him, unto death for the Jews' sake who crucified Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 31:309
verses.text: Recollecting therefore in our minds all these things, both those of God and of men, let us emulate these high deeds, and possess ourselves of the love which is above all gifts, that we may obtain both the present and the future blessings: the which may we all obtain, through the grace and mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father, with the Holy Ghost, be glory, power, honor, now and ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:1
verses.text: Homily XXXIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:3
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:4
verses.text: Love suffereth long, and is kind; love envieth not; love vaunteth not itself, is not puffed up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:5
verses.text: Thus, whereas he had showed, that both faith and knowledge and prophecy and tongues and gifts and healing and a perfect life and martyrdom, if love be absent, are no great advantage; of necessity he next makes an outline of its matchless beauty, adorning its image with the parts of virtue as with a sort of colors, and putting together all its members with exactness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:6
verses.text: But do not thou hastily pass by, beloved, the things spoken, but examine each one of them with much care, that thou mayest know both the treasure which is in the thing and the art of the painter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:7
verses.text: Consider, for example, from what point he at once began, and what he set first, as the cause of all its excellence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:8
verses.text: And what is this? Long-suffering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:9
verses.text: This is the root of all self-denial.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:10
verses.text: Wherefore also a certain wise man said, "A man that is long-suffering is of great understanding; but he that is hasty of spirit is mightily foolish".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:11
verses.text: And comparing it too with a strong city, he said that it is more secure than that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:12
verses.text: For it is both an invincible weapon and a sort of impregnable tower, easily beating off all annoyances.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:13
verses.text: And as a spark falling into the deep doth it no injury, but is itself easily quenched: so upon a long-suffering soul whatever unexpected thing falls, this indeed speedily vanishes, but the soul it disturbs not: for of a truth there is nothing so impenetrable as long-suffering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:14
verses.text: You may talk of armies, money, horses, walls, arms, or any thing else whatsoever; you will name nothing like long-suffering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:15
verses.text: For he that is encompassed with those, oftentimes, being overcome by anger, is upset like a worthless child, and fills all with confusion and tempest: but this man, settled as it were in a harbor, enjoys a profound calm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:16
verses.text: Though thou surround him with loss, thou hast not moved the rock; though thou bring insult upon him, thou hast not shaken the tower: and though thou bruise him with stripes, thou hast not wounded the adamant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:17
verses.text: Yea, and therefore is he called long-suffering, because he hath a kind of long and great soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:18
verses.text: For that which is long is also called great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:19
verses.text: But this excellence is born of love, both to them who possess and to them who enjoy it contributing no small advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:20
verses.text: For tell me not of those abandoned wretches, who, doing evil and suffering none, become worse: since here, not from his long-suffering, but from those who abuse it, this result arises.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:21
verses.text: Tell me not therefore of these, but of those gentler persons, who gain great benefit therefrom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:22
verses.text: For when, having done ill, they suffer none, admiring the meekness of the sufferer, they reap thereby a very great lesson of self command.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:23
verses.text: But Paul doth not stop here, but adds also the other high achievements of love, saying, "is kind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:24
verses.text: For since there are some who practise their long-suffering with a view not to their own self-denial, but to the punishment of those who have provoked them, to make them burst with wrath; he saith that neither hath charity this defect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:25
verses.text: Wherefore also he added, "is kind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:26
verses.text: For not at all with a view to light up the fire, in those who are inflamed by anger, do they deal more gently with them, but in order to appease and extinguish it: and not only by enduring nobly, but also by soothing and comforting, do they cure the sore and heal the wound of passion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:27
verses.text: "Envieth not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:28
verses.text: For it is possible for one to be both long-suffering and envious, and thereby that excellency is spoiled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:29
verses.text: But love avoids this also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:30
verses.text: "Vaunteth not itself;" i-e:, is not rash.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:31
verses.text: For it renders him who loves both considerate, and grave, and steadfast.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:32
verses.text: In truth, one mark of those who love unlawfully is a defect in this point.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:33
verses.text: Whereas he to whom this love is known, is of all men the most entirely freed from these evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:34
verses.text: For when there is no anger within, both rashness and insolence are clean taken away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:35
verses.text: Love, like some excellent husbandman, taking her seat inwardly in the soul and not suffering any of these thorns to spring up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:36
verses.text: "Is not puffed up".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:37
verses.text: For so we see many who think highly of themselves on the score of these very excellencies; for example, on not being envious, nor grudging, nor mean-spirited, nor rash: these evils being incidental not to wealth and poverty only, but even to things naturally good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:38
verses.text: But love perfectly purges out all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:39
verses.text: And consider: he that is long-suffering is not of course also kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:40
verses.text: But if he be not kind, the thing becomes a vice, and he is in danger of falling into malice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:41
verses.text: Therefore she supplies a medicine, I mean kindness, and preserves the virtue pure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:42
verses.text: Again, the kind person often becomes over-complaisant; but this also she corrects.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:43
verses.text: For "love," saith he, "vaunteth not itself, is not puffed up:" the kind and long-suffering is often ostentatious; but she takes away this vice also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:44
verses.text: And see how he adorns her not only from what she hath, but also from what she hath not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:45
verses.text: For he saith that she both brings in virtue, and extirpates vice, nay rather she suffers it not to spring up at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:46
verses.text: Thus he said not, "She envieth, indeed, but overcometh envy;" nor, "is arrogant, but chastiseth that passion;" but, "envieth not, vaunteth not itself, is not puffed up;" which truly is most to be admired, that even without toil she accomplishes her good things, and without war and battle-array her trophy is set up: she not permitting him that possesseth her to toil and so to attain the crown, but without labor conveying to him her prize.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:47
verses.text: For where there is not passion to contend against sober reason, what labor can there be?   "Doth not behave itself unseemly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:48
verses.text: "Nay, why," saith he, "do I say, she 'is not puffed up,' when she is so far from that feeling, that in suffering the most shameful things for him whom she loves, she doth not even count the thing an unseemliness?" Again, he did not say, "she suffereth unseemliness but beareth the shame nobly," but, "she doth not even entertain any sense at all of the shame".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:49
verses.text: For if the lovers of money endure all manner of reproaches for the sake of that sordid traffic of theirs, and far from hiding their faces, do even exult in it: much more he that hath this praiseworthy love will refuse nothing whatsoever for the safety's sake of those whom he loves: nay, nor will any thing that he can suffer shame him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:50
verses.text: And that we may not fetch our example from any thing base, let us examine this same statement in its application to Christ, and then we shall see the force of what hath been said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:51
verses.text: For our Lord Jesus Christ was both spit upon and beaten with rods by pitiful slaves; and not only did He not count it an unseemliness, but He even exulted and called the thing glory; and bringing in a robber and murderer with Himself before the rest into paradise, and discoursing with a harlot, and this when the standers-by all accused Him, He counted not the thing to be disgraceful, but both allowed her to kiss His feet, and to bedew His body with her tears, and to wipe them away with her hair, and this amid a company of spectators who were foes and enemies; "for love doeth nothing unseemly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:52
verses.text: Therefore also fathers, though they be the first of philosophers and orators, are not ashamed to lisp with their children; and none of those who see them find fault with them, but the thing is esteemed so good and right as to be even worthy of prayer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:53
verses.text: And again, should they become vicious, the parents keep on correcting, caring for them, abridging the reproaches they incur, and are not ashamed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:54
verses.text: For love "doth nothing unseemly," but as it were with certain golden wings covereth up all the offences of the beloved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:55
verses.text: Thus also Jonathan loved David; and hearing his father say, ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:56
verses.text: xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:57
verses.text: ) "Thou son of damsels that have run away from their homes, thou womanly bred," he was not ashamed, though the words be full of great reproach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:58
verses.text: For what he means is this: "Thou son of mean harlots who are mad after men, who run after the passers-by, thou unnerved and effeminate wretch, who hast nothing of a man, but livest to the shame of thyself and the mother who bare thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:59
verses.text: What then? Did he grieve at these things, and hide his face, and turn away from his beloved? Nay, quite the contrary; he displayed his fondness as an ornament.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:60
verses.text: And yet the one was at that time a king, and a king's son, even Jonathan; the other a fugitive and a wanderer, I mean, David.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:61
verses.text: But not even thus was he ashamed of his friendship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:62
verses.text: "For love doth not behave itself unseemly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:63
verses.text: Yea, this is its wonderful quality that not only it suffers not the injured to grieve and feel galled, but even disposes him to rejoice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:64
verses.text: Accordingly, he too, of whom we are speaking, after all these things, just as though he had a crown put on him, went away and fell on David's neck.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:65
verses.text: For love knows not what sort of thing shame may be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:66
verses.text: Therefore it glories in those things for which another hides his face.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:67
verses.text: Since the shame is, not to know how to love; not, when thou lovest, to incur danger and endure all for the beloved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:68
verses.text: But when I say, "all," do not suppose I mean things injurious also; for example, assisting a youth in a love affair, or whatsoever hurtful thing any one may beseech another to do for him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:69
verses.text: For such a person doth not love, and this I showed you lately from the Egyptian woman: since in truth he only is the lover who seeks what is profitable to the beloved: so that if any pursue not this, even what is right and good, though he make ten thousand professions of love, he is more hostile than any enemies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:70
verses.text: So also Rebecca aforetime, because she exceedingly clung to her son, both perpetrated a theft, and was not ashamed of detection, neither was she afraid, though the risk was no common one; but even when her son raised scruples to her, "upon me be thy curse, my son," she said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:71
verses.text: Dost thou see even in a woman the soul of the Apostle how, even as Paul chose, (if one may compare a small thing with a great,) to be anathema for the Jews' sake, (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:72
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:73
verses.text: ) so also she, that her son might be blessed, chose to be no less than accursed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:74
verses.text: And the good things she gave up to him, for she was not, it seems, to be blessed with him, but the evils she was prepared to endure herself alone: nevertheless, she rejoiced, and hasted, and this where so great a danger lay before her, and she was grieved at the delay of the business: for she feared lest Esau might anticipate them and render her wisdom vain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:75
verses.text: Wherefore also she cuts short the conversation and urges on the young man, and just permitting him to answer what had been said, states a reason sufficient to persuade him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:76
verses.text: For she said not, "thou sayest these things without reason, and in vain thou fearest, thy father having grown old and being deprived of clearness of sight:" but what? "upon me be thy curse, my son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:77
verses.text: Only do thou not mar the plot, nor lose the object of our chase, nor give up the treasure".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:78
verses.text: And this very Jacob, served he not for wages with his kinsmen twice seven years? Was he not together with the bondage subject to mockery in respect of that trick? What then? Did he feel the mockery?
