Did he count it behaving himself unseemly, that being a freeman, and free born, and well brought up, he endured slaves' treatment among his own kinsmen: a thing which is wont to be most vexing, when one receives opprobrious treatment from one's friends? In no wise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:79
verses.text: And the cause was his love, which made the time, though long, appear short.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:80
verses.text: "For they were," saith he, (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:81
verses.text: xxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:82
verses.text: ) "in his sight as a few days".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:83
verses.text: So far was he from being galled and blushing for this his bondage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:84
verses.text: Justly then said the blessed Paul, "Love doth not behave itself unseemly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:85
verses.text: "Seeketh not its own, is not provoked".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:86
verses.text: Thus having said, "doth not behave itself unseemly," he showeth also the temper of mind, on account of which she doth not behave herself unseemly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:87
verses.text: And what is that temper? That she "seeketh not her own".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:88
verses.text: For the beloved she esteems to be all, and then only "behaveth herself unseemly," when she cannot free him from such unseemliness; so that if it be possible by her own unseemliness to benefit her beloved, she doth not so much as count the thing unseemliness; for the other party thereafter is yourself, when you love: since this is friendship, that the lover and the beloved should no longer be two persons divided, but in a manner one single person; a thing which no how takes place except from love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:89
verses.text: Seek not therefore thine own, that thou mayest find thine own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:90
verses.text: For he that seeks his own, finds not his own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:91
verses.text: Wherefore also Paul said, "Let no man seek his own, but each his neighbor's good".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:92
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:93
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:94
verses.text: ) For your own profit lies in the profit of your neighbor, and his in yours.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:95
verses.text: As therefore one that had his own gold buried in the house of his neighbor, should he refuse to go and there seek and dig it up, will never seek it; so likewise here, he that will not seek his own profit in the advantage of his neighbor, will not attain unto the crowns due to this: God Himself having therefore so disposed of it, in order that we should be mutually bound together: and even as one awakening a slumbering child to follow his brother, when he is of himself unwilling, places in the brother's hand that which he desires and longs for, that through desire of obtaining it he may pursue after him that holds it, and accordingly so it takes place: thus also here, each man's own profit hath he given to his neighbor, that hence we may run after one another, and not be torn asunder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:96
verses.text: And if thou wilt, see this also in our case who address you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:97
verses.text: For my profit depends on thee, and thy advantage on me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:98
verses.text: Thus, on the one hand it profits thee to be taught the things that please God, but with this have I been entrusted, that thou mightest receive it from me, and therefore mightest be compelled to run unto me; and on the other hand it profits me that thou shouldest be made better: for the reward which I shall receive for this will be great; but this again lieth in thee; and therefore am I compelled to follow after thee that thou mayest be better, and that I may receive my profit from thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:99
verses.text: Wherefore also Paul saith, "For what is my hope? are not even ye?" And again, "My hope, and my joy, and the crown of my rejoicing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:100
verses.text: ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:101
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:102
verses.text: ) So that the joy of Paul was the disciples, and his joy they had.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:103
verses.text: Therefore he even wept when he saw them perishing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:104
verses.text: Again their profit depended on Paul: wherefore he said, "For the hope of Israel I am bound with this chain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:105
verses.text: (Acts xxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:106
verses.text: ) And again, "These things I endure for the elect's sakes that they may obtain eternal life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:107
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:108
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:109
verses.text: ) And this one may see in worldly things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:110
verses.text: "For the wife," saith he, "hath not power over her own body, nor yet the husband; but the wife over the husband's, and the husband over the wife's".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:111
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:112
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:113
verses.text: ) So likewise we, when we wish to bind any together, do this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:114
verses.text: We leave neither of them in his own power, but extending a chain between them, we cause the one to be holden of the other, and the other of the one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:115
verses.text: Wilt thou also see this in the case of governors? He that judges sits not in judgment for himself, but seeking the profit of his neighbor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:116
verses.text: The governed on the other hand, seek the profit of the governor by their attendance, by their ministry, by all the other things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:117
verses.text: Soldiers take up their arms for us, for on our account they peril themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:118
verses.text: We for them are in straits; for from us are their supplies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:119
verses.text: But if thou sayest, "each one doth this seeking his own," this also say I, but I add, that by the good of another one's own is won.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:120
verses.text: Thus both the soldier, unless he fight for them that support him, hath none that ministers to him for this end: and this same on the other hand, unless he nourish the soldier, hath none to arm himself in his behalf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:121
verses.text: Seest thou love, how it is everywhere extended and manages all things? But be not weary, until thou have thoroughly acquainted thyself with this golden chain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:122
verses.text: For having said, "seeketh not her own," he mentions again the good things produced by this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:123
verses.text: And what are these?  "Is not easily provoked, thinketh no evil".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:124
verses.text: See love again not only subduing vice, but not even suffering it to arise at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:125
verses.text: For he said not, "though provoked, she overcomes," but, "is not provoked".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:126
verses.text: And he said not, "worketh no evil," but, "not even thinketh;" i-e:, so far from contriving any evil, she doth not even suspect it of the beloved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:127
verses.text: How then could she work any, or how be provoked? who doth not even endure to admit an evil surmise; whence is the fountain of wrath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:128
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:129
verses.text: "Rejoiceth not in unrighteousness:" i-e:, doth not feel pleasure over those that suffer ill: and not this only, but also, what is much greater, "rejoiceth with the truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:130
verses.text: "She feels pleasure," saith he, "with them that are well spoken of," as Paul saith, "Rejoice with them that rejoice, and weep with them that weep".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:131
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:132
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:133
verses.text: )  Hence, she "envieth not," hence she "is not puffed up:" since in fact she accounts the good things of others her own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:134
verses.text: Seest thou how by degrees love makes her nursling an angel? For when he is void of anger, and pure from envy, and free from every tyrannical passion, consider that even from the nature of man he is delivered from henceforth, and hath arrived at the very serenity of angels.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:135
verses.text: Nevertheless, he is not content with these, but hath something even more than these to say: according to his plan of stating the stronger points later.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:136
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, "beareth all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:137
verses.text: From her long-suffering, from her goodness; whether they be burdensome, or grievous, or insults, or stripes, or death, or whatsoever else.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:138
verses.text: And this again one may perceive from the case of blessed David.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:139
verses.text: For what could be more intolerable than to see a son rising up against him, and aiming at the usurpation, and thirsting for a father's blood? Yet this did that blessed one endure, nor even so could he bear to throw out one bitter expression against the parricide; but even when he left all the rest to his captains, gave a strong injunction respecting his safety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:140
verses.text: For strong was the foundation of his love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:141
verses.text: Wherefore also it "beareth all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:142
verses.text: Now its power the Apostle here intimates, but its goodness, by what follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:143
verses.text: For, "it hopeth all things," saith he, "believeth all things, endureth all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:144
verses.text: What is, "hopeth all things?" It doth not despair," saith he, "of the beloved, but even though he be worthless, it continues to correct, to provide, to care for him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:145
verses.text: "Believeth all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:146
verses.text: "For it doth not merely hope," saith he, "but also believeth from its great affection".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:147
verses.text: And even if these good things should not turn out according to its hope, but the other person should prove yet more intolerable, it bears even these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:148
verses.text: For, saith he, it "endureth all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:149
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:150
verses.text: "Love never faileth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:151
verses.text: Seest thou when he put the crown on the arch, and what of all things is peculiar to this gift? For what is, "faileth not?" it is not severed, is not dissolved by endurance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:152
verses.text: For it puts up with everything: since happen what will, he that loves never can hate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:153
verses.text: This then is the greatest of its excellencies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:154
verses.text: Such a person was Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:155
verses.text: Wherefore also he said, "If by any means I may provoke to emulation them which are my flesh;" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:156
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:157
verses.text: ) and he continued hoping.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:158
verses.text: And to Timothy he gave a charge, saying, "And the Lord's servant must not strive, but be gentle towards all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:159
verses.text: …in meekness correcting those that oppose themselves, if God peradventure may give them the knowledge of the truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:160
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:161
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:163
verses.text: )  "What then," saith one, "if they be enemies and heathens, must one hate them?" One must hate, not them but their doctrine: not the man, but the wicked conduct, the corrupt mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:164
verses.text: For the man is God's work, but the deceit is the devil's work.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:165
verses.text: Do thou not therefore confound the things of God and the things of the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:166
verses.text: Since the Jews were both blasphemers, and persecutors, and injurious, and spake ten thousand evil things of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:167
verses.text: Did Paul then hate them, he who of all men most loved Christ? In no wise, but he both loved them, and did everything for their sakes: and at one time he saith, "My heart's desire and my supplication to God is for them that they may be saved:" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:168
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:169
verses.text: ; ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:170
verses.text: ) and at another, "I could wish that myself were anathema from Christ for their sakes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:171
verses.text: Thus also Ezekiel seeing them slain saith, "Alas, O Lord, dost Thou blot out the remnant of Israel?" (Ezek.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:172
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:173
verses.text: ) And Moses, "If Thou wilt forgive their sin, forgive".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:174
verses.text: (Exod.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:175
verses.text: xxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:176
verses.text: )  Why then saith David, "Do not I hate them, O Lord, that hate Thee, and against Thine enemies did I not pine away? I hate them with perfect hatred".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:177
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:178
verses.text: cxxxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:180
verses.text: )  Now, in the first place, not all things spoken in the Psalms by David, are spoken in the person of David.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:181
verses.text: For it is he himself who saith, "I have dwelt in the tents of Kedar;" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:182
verses.text: cxx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:183
verses.text: ) and, "By the waters of Babylon, there we sat down and wept:" (cxxxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:184
verses.text: ) yet he neither saw Babylon, nor the tents of Kedar.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:185
verses.text: But besides this, we require now a completer self-command.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:186
verses.text: Wherefore also when the disciples besought that fire might come down, even as in the case of Elias, "Ye know not," saith Christ, "what manner of spirit ye are of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:187
verses.text: (Luke ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:188
verses.text: ) For at that time not the ungodliness only, but also the ungodly themselves, they were commanded to hate, in order that their friendship might not prove an occasion of transgression unto them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:189
verses.text: Therefore he severed their connections, both by blood and marriage, and on every side he fenced them off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:190
verses.text: But now because he hath brought us to a more entire self-command and set us on high above that mischief, he bids us rather admit and soothe them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:191
verses.text: For we get no harm from them, but they get good by us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:192
verses.text: What then doth he say? we must not hate, but pity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:193
verses.text: Since if thou shalt hate, how wilt thou easily convert him that is in error? how wilt thou pray for the unbeliever? for that one ought to pray, hear what Paul saith: "I exhort therefore, first of all, that supplications, prayer, intercessions, thanksgivings be made for all men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:194
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:195
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:196
verses.text: ) But that all were not then believers, is, I suppose, evident unto every one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:197
verses.text: And again, "for kings and all that are in high place".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:198
verses.text: But that these were ungodly and transgressors, this also is equally manifest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:199
verses.text: Further, mentioning also the reason for the prayer, he adds, "for this is good and acceptable in the sight of God our Saviour; who willeth that all men should be saved, and come to the knowledge of the truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:200
verses.text: Therefore, if he find a Gentile wife consorting with a believer, he dissolves not the marriage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:201
verses.text: Yet what is more closely joined than a man to his wife? "For they two shall be one flesh," (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:202
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:203
verses.text: ) and great in that instance is the charm, and ardent the desire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:204
verses.text: But if we are to hate ungodly and lawless men, we shall go on to hate also sinners; and thus in regular process thou wilt be broken off from the most even of thy brethren, or rather from all: for there is not one, no, not one, without sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:205
verses.text: For if it be our duty to hate the enemies of God, one must not hate the ungodly only, but also sinners: and thus we shall be worse than wild beasts, shunning all, and puffed up with pride; even as that Pharisee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:206
verses.text: But not thus did Paul command us, but how? "Admonish the disorderly, encourage the faint-hearted, support the weak, be long suffering toward all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:207
verses.text: ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:208
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:209
verses.text: )   What then doth he mean when he saith, "If any obeyeth not our word by this epistle, note that man, that ye have no company with him?" ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:210
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:211
verses.text: ) In the first place, he saith this of brethren, however not even so without limitation, but this too with gentleness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:212
verses.text: For do not thou cut off what follows, but subjoin also the next clause: how, having said, "keep no company," he added, "yet count him not as an enemy, but admonish him as a brother".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:213
verses.text: Seest thou how he bade us hate the deed that is evil, and not the man? For indeed it is the work of the devil to tear us asunder from one another, and he hath ever used great diligence to take away love that he may cut off the way of correction, and may retain him in error and thee in enmity, and thus block up the way of his salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:214
verses.text: For when both the physician hates the sick man and flies from him, and the sick man turns away from the physician, when will the distempered person be restored, seeing that neither the one will call in the other's aid, nor will the other go to him?  But wherefore, tell me, dost thou at all turn away from him and avoid him? Because he is ungodly? Truly for this cause oughtest thou to welcome and attend him, that thou mayest raise him up in his sickness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:215
verses.text: But if he be incurably sick, still thou hast been bidden to do thy part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:216
verses.text: Since Judas also was incurably diseased, yet God left not off attending upon him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:217
verses.text: Wherefore, neither do thou grow weary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:218
verses.text: For even if after much labor thou fail to deliver him from his ungodliness, yet shalt thou receive the deliverer's reward, and wilt cause him to wonder at thy gentleness, and so all this praise will pass on to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:219
verses.text: For though thou shouldest work wonders, and raise the dead, and whatsoever work thou doest, the Heathen will never wonder at thee so much, as when they see thee displaying a meek, gentle, mild disposition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:220
verses.text: And this is no small achievement: since many will even be entirely delivered from their evil way; there being nothing that hath such power to allure men as love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:221
verses.text: For in respect of the former they will rather be jealous of thee, I mean the signs and wonders; but for this they will both admire and love thee: and if they love, they will also lay hold of the truth in due course.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:222
verses.text: If however he become not all at once a believer, wonder not nor hurry on, neither do thou require all things at once, but suffer him for the present to praise, and love, and unto this in due course he will come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:223
verses.text: And that thou mayest clearly know how great a thing this is, hear how even Paul, going before an unbelieving judge, made his defence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:224
verses.text: "I think myself happy," saith he, "That I am to make my defence before thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:225
verses.text: (Acts xxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:226
verses.text: ) And these things he said, not to flatter him, far from it; but wishing to gain him by his gentleness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:227
verses.text: And he did in part gain him, and he that was till then considered to be condemned took captive his judge, and the victory is confessed by the person himself who was made captive, with a loud voice in the presence of all, saying, "With but little persuasion thou wouldst fain make me a Christian".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:228
verses.text: (Acts xxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:230
verses.text: ) What then saith Paul? He spread his net the wider, and saith, "I would to God, that not only thou, but also all that hear me this day, might become such as I am, except these bonds".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:231
verses.text: What sayest thou, O Paul? "except these bonds?" And what confidence remains for thee, if thou art ashamed of these things, and fliest from them, and this before so great a multitude? Dost thou not every where in thy Epistles boast of this matter, and call thyself a prisoner? Dost thou not every where carry about this chain in our sight as a diadem? What then hath happened now that thou deprecatest these bonds? "I myself deprecate them not," saith he, "nor am I ashamed of them, but I condescend to their weakness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:232
verses.text: For they are not yet able to receive my glorying; and I have learned from my Lord not to put 'a piece of undressed cloth upon an old garment:' (S.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:233
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:234
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:235
verses.text: ) therefore did I thus speak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:236
verses.text: For, in fact, unto this time they have heard ill reports of our doctrine, and abhor the cross.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:237
verses.text: If therefore I should add also bonds, their hatred becometh greater; I removed these, therefore, that the other might be made acceptable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:238
verses.text: So it is, that to them it seems disgraceful to be bound, because they have not as yet tasted of the Glory which is with us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:239
verses.text: One must therefore condescend: and when they shall have learned of the true life, then will they know the beauty also of this iron, and the lustre which comes of these bonds".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:240
verses.text: Furthermore, discoursing with others, he even calls the thing a free gift, saying, "It hath been granted in the behalf of Christ, not only to believe on Him, but also to suffer in His behalf".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:241
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:242
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:243
verses.text: ) But for the time then present, it was a great thing for the hearers not to be ashamed of the cross: for which cause he goes on gradually.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:244
verses.text: Thus, neither doth any one introducing a person to a palace, before that he beholds the vestibule, compel him, yet standing without, to survey what is within: since in that way it will not even seem admirable, unless one enter in and so acquaint one's self with all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:245
verses.text: So then let us also deal with the heathen sort: with condecension, with love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:246
verses.text: For love is a great teacher, and able both to withdraw men from error, and to reform the character, and to lead them by the hand unto self-denial, and out of stones to make men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:247
verses.text: And if thou wouldest learn her power, bring me a man timid and fearful of every sound, and trembling at shadows; or passionate, and harsh, and a wild beast rather than a man; or wanton and licentious; or wholly given to wickedness; and deliver him into the hands of love, and introduce him into this school; and thou wilt speedily see that cowardly and timid creature made brave and magnanimous, and venturing upon all things cheerfully.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:248
verses.text: And what is wonderful, not from any change in nature do these things result, but in the coward soul itself love manifests her peculiar power; and it is much the same as if one should cause a leaden sword, not turned into steel but continuing in the nature of lead, to do the work of steel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:249
verses.text: As thus: Jacob was a "plain man, (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:250
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:251
verses.text: ) dwelling in a house, and unpracticed in toils and dangers, living a kind of remiss and easy life, and like a virgin in her chamber, so also he was compelled for the most part to sit within doors and keep the house; withdrawn from the forum and all tumults of the forum, and from all such matters, and even continuing in ease and quietness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:252
verses.text: What then? After that the torch of love had set him on fire, see how it made this plain and home-keeping man strong to endure and fond of toil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:253
verses.text: And of this hear not what I say, but what the patriarch himself saith: how finding fault with his kinsman, his words are, "These twenty years am I with thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:254
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:255
verses.text: xxxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:256
verses.text: ) And how wert thou these twenty years? (For this also he adds,) "Consumed by the heat in the day time, and with the frost by night, and sleep departed from mine eyes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:257
verses.text: Thus speaks that "plain man, keeping at home," and living that easy life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:258
verses.text: Again, that he was timid is evident, in that, expecting to see Esau, he was dead with fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:259
verses.text: But see again, how this timid man became bolder than a lion under the influence of love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:260
verses.text: For putting himself forward like some champion before the rest, he was ready to be first in receiving that savage and slaughter-breathing brother as he supposed him to be, and with his own body to purchase the safety of his wives: and him whom he feared and shuddered at, he desired to behold himself foremost in the array.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:261
verses.text: For this fear was not so strong as his affection for his wives.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:262
verses.text: Seest thou how, being timid, he became suddenly adventurous, not by changing his character, but being invigorated by love? For that after this also he was timid, is evident by his changing from place to place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:263
verses.text: But let no man consider what has been said to be a charge against that righteous man: since being timid is no reproach, for this is a man's nature; but the doing any thing unseemly for timidity's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:264
verses.text: For it is possible for one that is timid by nature to become courageous through piety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:265
verses.text: What did Moses? Did he not, through fear of a single Egyptian, fly, and go away into banishment? Nevertheless, this fugitive who could not endure the menace of a single man, after that he tasted of the honey of love, nobly and without compulsion from any man, was forward to perish together with them whom he loved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:266
verses.text: "For if thou wilt forgive their sin," saith he, "forgive; and if not, blot me, I pray thee, out of Thy book which thou hast written.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:267
verses.text: (Exod.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:268
verses.text: xxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:269
verses.text: )   Moreover, that love makes also the fierce moderate, and the wanton chaste, we have no longer need of any examples: this being evident to all men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:270
verses.text: Though a man be more savage than any wild beast, no sheep so gentle as he is rendered by love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:271
verses.text: Thus, what could be more savage and frantic than Saul? But when his daughter let his enemy go, he uttered not against her even a bitter word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:272
verses.text: And he that unsparingly put to the sword all the priests for David's sake, seeing that his daughter had sent him away from the house, was not indignant with her even as far as words; and this when so great a fraud had been contrived against him: because he was restrained by the stronger bridle of love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:273
verses.text: Now as moderation, so chastity, is an ordinary effect of love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:274
verses.text: If a man love his own wife as he ought to love, even though he be never so much inclined to wantoness, he will not endure to look upon another woman, on account of his affection for her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:275
verses.text: "For love," (Cant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:276
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:277
verses.text: ) saith one, "is strong as death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:278
verses.text: So that from no other source doth wanton behavior arise than from want of love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:279
verses.text: Since then love is the Artificer of all virtue, let us with all exactness implant her in our own souls, that she may produce for us many blessings, and that we may have her fruit continually abounding, the fruit which is ever fresh and never decays.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 32:280
verses.text: For thus shall we obtain no less than eternal blessings: which may we all obtain, through the grace and mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father, and also the Holy Ghost, be glory, power, and honor, now and for ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:1
verses.text: Homily XXXIV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:3
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:4
verses.text: But whether there be prophecies, they shall be done away; whether there be tongues, they shall cease; whether there be knowledge, it shall be done away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:5
verses.text: Having shown the excellency of love from its being requisite both to the spiritual gifts, and to the virtues of life; and from rehearsal of all its good qualities, and by showing it to be the foundation of exact self-denial; from another, a third head, again he points out its worth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:6
verses.text: And this he doth, first from a wish to persuade those who seemed to be accounted inferior that it is in their power to have the chief of all signs, and that they will be no worse off than the possessors of the gifts, if they have this, but rather much better: secondly, with regard on the other hand to them that had the greater gifts and were lifted up thereby, studying to bring them down and to show that they have nothing unless they have this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:7
verses.text: For thus they would both love one another, envy as well as pride being hereby taken away; and reciprocally, loving one another, they would still further banish these passions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:8
verses.text: "For love envieth not, is not puffed up".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:9
verses.text: So that on every side he throws around them an impregnable wall, and a manifold unanimity, which first removes all their disorders, and thereby again waxes stronger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:10
verses.text: Therefore also he put forward innumerable reasons which might comfort their dejection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:11
verses.text: As thus: both "the same Spirit," saith he, is the giver; and He "giveth to profit withal; and divideth as he will," and it is a gift which He divideth, not a debt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:12
verses.text: Though thou receive but a little, thou dost equally contribute to the body, and even thus thou enjoyest much honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:13
verses.text: And he that hath the greater, needs thee who hast the less.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:14
verses.text: And, "Love is the greatest gift, and 'the more excellent way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:15
verses.text: '"  Now all this he said doubly to bind them to each other, both by their not considering themselves disparaged while they had this; and because, after pursuit and attainment of it, they henceforth would not feel human infirmity; both as having the root of all gifts, and as no longer capable of contentiousness even though they had nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:16
verses.text: For he that is once led captive by love is freed from contentiousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:17
verses.text: And this is why, pointing out to them how great advantages they shall thence reap, he sketched out its fruits; by his praises of it repressing their disorders: inasmuch as each one of the things mentioned by him was a sufficient medicine to heal their wounds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:18
verses.text: Wherefore also he said, "suffereth long," to them that are at strife one with another; "is kind," to them that stand mutually aloof, and bear a secret grudge; "envieth not," to them that look grudgingly on their superiors; "vaunteth not itself," to them that are separated; "is not puffed up," to them that boast themselves against others; "doth not behave itself unseemly," to them that do not think it their duty to condescend; "seeketh not her own," to them that overlook the rest; "is not provoked, taketh not account of evil," to them that are insolent; "rejoiceth not in unrighteousness, but rejoiceth with the truth," to them again that are envious; "beareth all things," to them that are treacherous; "hopeth all things," to the despairing; "endureth all things, never faileth," to them that easily separate themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:19
verses.text: Now then after that in every way he had shown her to be very exceedingly great, again he doth so from another most important head, by a fresh comparison exalting her dignity, and saying thus; "but whether there be prophecies, they shall be done away; whether there be tongues, they shall cease".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:20
verses.text: For if both these were brought in in order to the faith; when that is every where sown abroad, the use of these is henceforth superfluous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:21
verses.text: But the loving one another shall not cease, rather it shall even advance further, both here and hereafter, and then more than now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:22
verses.text: For here there are many things that weaken our love; wealth, business, passions of the body, disorders of the soul; but there none of these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:23
verses.text: But although it be no marvel that prophecies and tongues should be done away, that knowledge should be done away, this is what may cause some perplexity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:24
verses.text: For this also he added, "Whether there be knowledge, it shall be done away".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:25
verses.text: What then? are we then to live in ignorance? Far from it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:26
verses.text: Nay, then specially it is probable that our knowledge is made intense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:27
verses.text: Wherefore also he said, "Then shall I know, even as also I am known".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:28
verses.text: For this reason, if you mark it, that you might not suppose this to be done away equally with the prophecy and the tongues, having said, "Whether there be knowledge, it shall be done away," he was not silent, but added also the manner of its vanishing away, immediately subjoining the saying,  Ver "We know in part, and we prophesy in part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:29
verses.text: But when that which is perfect is come, then that which is in part shall be done away".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:30
verses.text: It is not therefore knowledge that is done away, but the circumstance that our knowledge is in part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:31
verses.text: For we shall not only know as much but even a great deal more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:32
verses.text: But that I may also make it plain by example; now we know that God is every where, but how, we know not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:33
verses.text: That He made out of things that are not the things that are we know; but of the manner we are ignorant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:34
verses.text: That He was born of a virgin, we know; but how, we know not yet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:35
verses.text: But then shall we know somewhat more and clearer concerning these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:36
verses.text: Next he points out also how great is the distance between the two, and that our deficiency is no small one, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:37
verses.text: "When I was a child, I spake as a child, I felt as a child, I thought as a child; but now that I am become a man, I have put away childish things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:38
verses.text: And by another example too he manifests the same thing again, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:39
verses.text: "For now we see in a mirror".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:40
verses.text: Further, because the glass sets before us the thing seen indefinitely, he added, "darkly," to show very strongly that the present knowledge is most partial.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:41
verses.text: "But then face to face".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:42
verses.text: Not as though God hath a face, but to express the notion of greater clearness and perspicuity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:43
verses.text: Seest thou how we learn all things by gradual addition?  "Now I know in part; but then shall I know even as also I have been known".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:44
verses.text: Seest thou how in two ways he pulls down their pride? Both because their knowledge is in part, and because not even this have they of themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:45
verses.text: "For I knew Him not, but He made Himself known to me," saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:46
verses.text: Wherefore, even as now He first knew me, and Himself hastened towards me, so shall I hasten towards Him then much more than now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:47
verses.text: For so he that sits in darkness, as long as he sees not the sun doth not of himself hasten to meet the beauty of its beam, which indeed shows itself as soon as it hath begun to shine: but when he perceives its brightness, then also himself at length follows after its light: This then is the meaning of the expression, "even as also I have been known".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:48
verses.text: Not that we shall so know him as He is, but that even as He hastened toward us now, so also shall we cleave unto Him then, and shall know many of the things which are now secret, and shall enjoy that most blessed society and wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:49
verses.text: For if Paul who knew so much was a child, consider what those things must be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:50
verses.text: If these be "a glass" and "a riddle," do thou hence again infer, God's open Face, how great a thing It is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:51
verses.text: But that I may open out to thee some small part of this difference, and may impart some faint ray of this thought to thy soul, I would have thee recall to mind things as they were in the Law, now after that grace hath shone forth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:52
verses.text: For those things too, that came before grace, had a certain great and marvellous appearance: nevertheless, hear what Paul saith of them after grace came: "That which was made glorious had no glory in this respect, by reason of the glory that surpasseth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:53
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:54
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:55
verses.text: )  But that what I say may be made yet clearer, let us apply the argument to some one of the rites then performed, and then thou wilt see how great is the difference.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:56
verses.text: And if thou wilt, let us bring forward that passover and this, and then shalt thou be aware of our superiority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:57
verses.text: For the Jews indeed celebrated it, but they celebrated it "so as in a mirror, and darkly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:58
verses.text: But these hidden mysteries they never at any time did even conceive in their mind, nor what things they prefigured.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:59
verses.text: They saw a lamb slain, and the blood of a beast, and door-posts sprinkled with it; but that the Son of God incarnate shall be slain, and shall set free the whole world, and shall grant both to Greeks and Barbarians to taste of this Blood, and shall open heaven to all, and shall offer what is there to the whole human race, and having taken His blood-stained flesh shall exalt it above the heaven, and the heaven of heavens, and, in a word, above all the hosts on high, of the angels and archangels and all the other powers, and shall cause it shining in unspeakable glory,—to sit down upon the throne itself of the King, on the right hand of the Father these things, I say, no one, either of them or of the rest of mankind, either foreknew or was able ever to conceive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:60
verses.text: But what say those who shrink from nothing? That the expression, "now I know in part," is spoken in dispensations; for that the Apostle had the perfect knowledge of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:61
verses.text: And now he calls himself a child? How sees he "in a mirror?" How "darkly," if he hath the sum of knowledge? And why doth he refer to it as something peculiar to the Spirit, and to no other power in the creation, saying, "For who among men knoweth the things of a man, save the spirit of the man which is in him? Even so the things of God none knoweth, save the Spirit of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:62
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:63
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:64
verses.text: ) And Christ again sayeth that this belongs to Himself alone, thus saying, "Not that any man hath seen the Father, save He which is from God, He hath seen the Father," (John vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:65
verses.text: ) giving the name, "sight," to the most clear and perfect knowledge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:66
verses.text: And how shall he who knoweth the Essence, be ignorant of the dispensations? since that knowledge is greater than this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:67
verses.text: "Are we then," saith he, "ignorant of God?" Far from it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:68
verses.text: That He is, we know, but what He is, as regards His Essence, we know not yet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:69
verses.text: And that thou mayst understand that not concerning the dispensations did he speak the words, "now I know in part," hear what follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:70
verses.text: He adds then, "but then shall I know, even as also I have been known".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:71
verses.text: He was surely known not by the dispensations, but by God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:72
verses.text: Let none therefore consider this to be a small or simple transgression, but twofold, and threefold, yea and manifold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:73
verses.text: For not only is there this impiety that they boast of knowing those things which belong to the Spirit alone; and to the only-begotten Son of God, but also that when Paul could not acquire even this knowledge "which is in part" without the revelation from above, these men say that they have obtained the whole from their own reasonings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:74
verses.text: For neither are they able to point out that the Scripture hath any where discoursed to us of these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:75
verses.text: But however, leaving their madness, let us give heed to the words which follow concerning love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:76
verses.text: For he was not content with these things, but adds again, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:77
verses.text: "And now abideth, faith, hope, love, these three; and the greatest of these is love".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:78
verses.text: For faith indeed and hope, when the good things believed and hoped for are come, cease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:79
verses.text: And to show this Paul said, "For hope that is seen is not hope; for who hopeth for that which he seeth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:80
verses.text: Again, "Now faith is the assurance of things hoped for, the proving of things not seen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:81
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:82
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:83
verses.text: ; Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:84
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:85
verses.text: ) So that these cease when those appear; but love is then most elevated, and becomes more vehement.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:86
verses.text: Another encomium of love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:87
verses.text: For neither is he content with those before mentioned, but he strives to discover yet another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:88
verses.text: And observe: he hath said that it is a great gift, and a still more excellent way to these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:89
verses.text: He hath said, that without it there is no great profit in our gifts; he hath shadowed out its image at length; he intends again and in another manner to exalt it, and to show that it is great from its abiding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:90
verses.text: Wherefore also he said, "But now abideth faith, hope, love, these three; but the greatest of these is love".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:91
verses.text: How then is love the greater? In that those pass away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:92
verses.text: If now so great is the virtue of love, with good reason doth he add and say, "Follow after love".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:93
verses.text: For there is surely need of "following," and a kind of vehement running after her: in such sort doth she fly from us, and so many are the things which trip us up in that direction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:94
verses.text: Wherefore we have ever need of great earnestness in order to overtake her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:95
verses.text: And to point out this, Paul said not, "follow love," but, "pursue" her; stirring us up, and inflaming us to lay hold on her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:96
verses.text: For so God from the beginning contrived ten thousand ways for implanting her in us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:97
verses.text: Thus, first, He granted one head to all, Adam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:98
verses.text: For why do we not all spring out of the earth? Why not full grown, as he was? In order that both the birth and the bringings up of children, and the being born of another, might bind us mutually together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:99
verses.text: For this cause neither made He woman out of the earth: and because the thing of the same substance was not equally sufficient to shame us into unanimity, unless we had also the same progenitor, He provided also for this: since, if now, being only separated by place, we consider ourselves alien from one another; much more would this have happened if our race had had two originals.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:100
verses.text: For this cause therefore, as it were from some one head, he bound together the whole body of the human race.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:101
verses.text: And because from the beginning they seemed to be in a manner two, see how he fastens them together again, and gathers them into one by marriage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:102
verses.text: For, "therefore," saith He, "shall a man leave his father and his mother, and shall cleave unto his wife; and they shall be for one flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:103
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:104
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:105
verses.text: ) And he said not, "the woman," but, "the man," because the desire too is stronger in him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:106
verses.text: Yea, and for this cause He made it also stronger, that it might bow the superior party to the absolute sway of this passion, and might subjugate it to the weaker.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:107
verses.text: And since marriage also must needs be introduced, him from whom she sprang He made husband to the woman.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:108
verses.text: For all things in the eye of God are second to love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:109
verses.text: And if when things had thus begun, the first man straightway became so frantic, and the devil sowed among them so great warfare and envy; what would he not have done, had they not sprung from one root?  Further, in order that the one might be subject, and the other rule; (for equality is wont oftentimes to bring in strife;) he suffered it not to be a democracy, but a monarchy; and as in an army, this order one may see in every family.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:110
verses.text: In the rank of monarch, for instance, there is the husband; but in the rank of lieutenant and general, the wife; and the children too are allotted a third station in command.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:111
verses.text: Then after these a fourth order, that of the servant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:112
verses.text: For these also bear rule over their inferiors, and some one of them is oftentimes set over the whole, keeping ever the post of the master, but still as a servant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:113
verses.text: And together with this again another command, and among the children themselves again another, according to their age and sex; since among the children the female doth not possess equal sway.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:114
verses.text: And every where hath God made governments at small distances and thick together, that all might abide in concord and much good order.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:115
verses.text: Therefore even before the race was increased to a multitude, when the first two only were in being, He bade him govern, and her obey.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:116
verses.text: And in order again that He might not despise her as inferior, and separate from her, see how He honored her, and made them one, even before her creation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:117
verses.text: For, "Let us make for man," saith He, "a help meet," implying that she was made for his need, and thereby drawing him unto her who was made for his sake: since to all those things are we more kindly disposed, which are done for our sakes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:118
verses.text: But that she, on the other hand, might not be elated, as being granted him for help, nor might burst this bond, He makes her out of his side, signifying that she is a part of the whole body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:119
verses.text: And that neither might the man be elated therefore, He no longer permits that to belong to him alone which before was his alone, but effected the contrary to this, by bringing in procreation of children, and herein too giving the chief honor unto the man, not however allowing the whole to be his.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:120
verses.text: Seest thou how many bonds of love God hath wrought? And these indeed by force of nature He hath lodged in us as pledges of concord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:121
verses.text: For both our being of the same substance leads to this; (for every animal loves its like;) and the woman being produced from the man, and again the children from both.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:122
verses.text: Whence also many kinds of affection arise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:123
verses.text: For one we love as a father, another as a grandfather; one as a mother, another as a nurse; and one as a son or grandson or great-grandson again, and another as a daughter, or grand-daughter; and one as a brother, another as a nephew; and one as a sister, another as a niece.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:124
verses.text: And why need one recount all the names of consanguinity?  And He devised also another foundation of affection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:125
verses.text: For having forbidden the marriage of kindred, he led us out unto strangers and drew them again unto us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:126
verses.text: For since by this natural kindred it was not possible that they should be connected with us, he connected us anew by marriage, uniting together whole families by the single person of the bride, and mingling entire races with races.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:127
verses.text: For, "marry not," saith the Lord, (Lev.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:128
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:129
verses.text: ) "thy sister, nor thy father's sister, nor any damsel which hath such consanguinity with thee," as utterly hinders the marriage;" naming the degrees of such relationship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:130
verses.text: It is enough for thine affection towards them that ye were the fruit of the same birth-pangs, and that the others are in a different relation to thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:131
verses.text: Why dost thou narrow the breadth of love? Why dost thou idly throw away a ground of affection towards her, such as that thou mightest thereby provide thyself with distinct source for affection to spring from; I mean, by taking a wife from another family, and through her a chain of kinsmen, both mother, and father, and brethren, and their connexions!   Seest thou by how many ways He hath bound us together? Nevertheless, not even this sufficed Him, but He likewise made us to stand in need of one another, that thus also He might bring us together, because necessities above all create friendships.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:132
verses.text: For no other reason neither suffered He all things to be produced in every place, that hence also He might compel us to mix with one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:133
verses.text: But having set us in need of one another, He on the other hand made the intercourse easy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:134
verses.text: Since if this were not so, the matter would have turned out painful and difficult in another way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:135
verses.text: For if one that wanted a physician, or a carpenter, or any other workman, had need to set off on a long foreign sojourn, the whole had come to nought.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:136
verses.text: Here then is why He founded cities also, and brought all into one place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:137
verses.text: And accordingly that we might easily keep up intercourse with distant countries, He spread the level of the sea between us, and gave us the swiftness of winds, thereby making our voyages easy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:138
verses.text: And at the beginning He even gathered all men together in one spot, and did not disperse them until they who first received the gift abused their concord unto sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:139
verses.text: However, He hath drawn us together in every way; both by nature, and by consanguinity, and by language, and by place; and as he willed not that we should fall from paradise; (for had He willed it, He would not have placed there at all "the man whom He had formed," but he that disobeyed was the cause;) so neither was it His will that men should have divers tongues; since otherwise He would have made it so from the beginning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:140
verses.text: But now "the whole earth was of one language, and all had one speech".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:141
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:142
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:143
verses.text: )  Here is the reason why, when it was needful that the earth should be destroyed, not even then did He make us of other matter, nor did He translate the righteous man, but leaving him in the midst of the deluge, like a kind of spark of the world, He rekindled our race from thence, even by the blessed Noah.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:144
verses.text: And from the beginning He made one sovereignty only, setting the man over the woman.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:145
verses.text: But after that our race ran headlong into extreme disorder, He appointed other sovereignties also, those of Masters, and those of Governors, and this too for love's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:146
verses.text: That is, since vice was a thing apt to dissolve and subvert our race, He set those who administer justice in the midst of our cities as a kind of physicians, that driving away vice, as it were a plague to love, they might gather together all in one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:147
verses.text: And that not only in cities, but also in each family there might be great unanimity, He honored the man with rule and superiority; the woman on the other hand He armed with desire: and the gift also of procreation of children, He committed in common to both, and withal He furnished also other things apt to conciliate love: neither entrusting all to the man, nor all to the woman; but "dividing these things also severally to each;" to her entrusting the house, and to him the market; to him the work of feeding, for he tills the ground; to her that of clothing, for loom and distaff are the woman's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:148
verses.text: For it is God Himself who gave to woman-kind skill in woven work.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:149
verses.text: Woe be to covetousness, which suffers not this difference to appear! For the general effeminacy hath gone so far as to introduce our men to the looms, and put shuttles into their hands, and the woof, and threads.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:150
verses.text: Nevertheless, even thus the forethought of the divine economy shines out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:151
verses.text: For we still greatly need the woman in other more necessary things, and we require the help of our inferiors in those things which keep our life together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:152
verses.text: And so strong is the compulsion of this need that though one be richer than all men, not even thus is he rid of this close conjunction, and of his want of that which is inferior to himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:153
verses.text: For it is not, we see, the poor only who need the rich, but the rich also the poor; and these require those more than the others them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:154
verses.text: And that thou mayest see it more clearly, let us suppose, if it seem good, two cities, the one of rich only, but the other of poor; and neither in that of the rich let there be any poor man, nor in that of the poor any rich; but let us purge out both thoroughly, and see which will be the more able to support itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:155
verses.text: For if we find that of the poor able, it is evident that the rich will more stand in need of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:156
verses.text: Now then, in that city of the affluent there will be no manufacturer, no builder, no carpenter, no shoe-maker, no baker, no husbandman , no brazier, no rope-maker, nor any other such trade.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:157
verses.text: For who among the rich would ever choose to follow these crafts, seeing that the very men who take them in hand, when they become rich, endure no longer the discomfort caused by these works? How then shall this our city stand? "The rich," it is replied, "giving money, will buy these things of the poor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:158
verses.text: Well then, they will not be sufficient for themselves, their needing the others proves that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:159
verses.text: But how will they build houses? Will they purchase this too? But the nature of things cannot admit this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:160
verses.text: Therefore they must needs invite the artificers thither, and destroy the law, which we made at first when we were founding the city.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:161
verses.text: For you remember, that we said, "let there be no poor man within it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:162
verses.text: But, lo, necessity, even against our will, hath invited and brought them in.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:163
verses.text: Whence it is evident that it is impossible without poor for a city to subsist: since if the city were to continue refusing to admit any of these, it will be no longer a city but will perish.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:164
verses.text: Plainly then it will not support itself, unless it shall collect the poor as a kind of preservers, to be within itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:165
verses.text: But let us look also upon the city of the poor, whether this too will be in a like needy condition, on being deprived of the rich.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:166
verses.text: And first let us in our discourse thoroughly clear the nature of riches, and point them out plainly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:167
verses.text: What then may riches be? Gold, and silver, and precious stones, and garments silken, purple, and embroidered with gold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:168
verses.text: Now then that we have seen what riches are, let us drive them away from our city of the poor: and if we are to make it purely a city of poor persons, let not any gold appear there, no not in a dream, nor garments of such quality; and if you will, neither silver, nor vessels of silver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:169
verses.text: What then? Because of this will that city and its concerns live in want, tell me? Not at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:170
verses.text: For suppose first there should be need to build; one does not want gold and silver and pearls, but skill, and hands, and hands not of any kind, but such as are become callous, and fingers hardened, and great strength, and wood, and stones: suppose again one would weave a garment, neither here have we need of gold and silver, but, as before, of hands and skill, and women to work.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:171
verses.text: And what if one require husbandry, and digging the ground? Is it rich men who are wanted, or poor? It is evident to every one, poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:172
verses.text: And when iron too is to be wrought, or any such thing to be done, this is the race of men whereof we most stand in need.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:173
verses.text: What respect then remains wherein we may stand in need of the rich? except the thing required be, to pull down this city.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:174
verses.text: For should that sort of people make an entrance, and these philosophers, for (for I call them philosophers, who seek after nothing superfluous,) should fall to desiring gold and jewels, giving themselves up to idleness and luxury; they will ruin everything from that day forward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:175
verses.text: "But unless wealth be useful," saith one, "wherefore hath it been given by God?" And whence is it evident, that being rich is from God? "The Scripture saith, 'The silver is Mine, and the gold is Mine,' and to whomsoever I will, I will give it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:176
verses.text: (Hag.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:177
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:178
verses.text: ) Here, if I were not doing an unseemly thing, I could at this moment laugh loudly, in derision of those who say these things: because as little children admitted to a King's table, together with that food they thrust into their mouth everything that comes to hand; so also do these together with the divine Scriptures privily bring in their own notions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:179
verses.text: For this, "the silver is Mine, and the gold is Mine," I know to have been spoken by the Prophet; but that, "to whomsoever I will, I will give it," is not added, but is brought in by these offscourings of the people.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:180
verses.text: And as to the former, why it was said, I will explain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:181
verses.text: The Prophet Haggai, because he was continually promising to the Jews after their return from Babylon, that he would show the temple in its former appearance, and some doubted of the thing spoken, and considered it to be well nigh impossible that after being reduced to dust and ashes, the house should appear again such as it was;—he, to remove their unbelief, in the person of God saith these things; as if he said, "Why are ye afraid? and why do ye refuse to believe? 'The silver is Mine, and the gold is Mine,' and I need not to borrow from others, and so to beautify the house".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:182
verses.text: And to show that this is the meaning he adds, "and the glory of this house, the latter glory shall be greater than the glory of the former".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:183
verses.text: Let us not then bring in spiders' webs upon the royal robe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:184
verses.text: For if any person, detected in weaving a counterfeit thread in a purple vest, is to suffer the severest punishment, much more in spiritual things; since neither is it an ordinary sin, which is hereby committed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:185
verses.text: And why say I, by adding and taking away? By a mere point, and by a mere circumstance of delivery in the reading, many impious thoughts have not seldom been brought into being.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:186
verses.text: "Whence then the rich," saith one? "for it hath been said, 'Riches and poverty are from the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:187
verses.text: '" Let us then ask those who object these things against us, whether all riches and all poverty are from the Lord? Nay, who would say this? For we see that both by rapine, and by wickedly breaking open of tombs, and by witchcraft, and by other such devices, great wealth is gathered by many, and the possessors are not worthy even to live.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:188
verses.text: What then, tell me, do we say that this wealth is from God? Far from it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:189
verses.text: Whence then? From sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:190
verses.text: For so the harlot by doing indignity to her own body grows rich, and a handsome youth oftentimes selling his bloom with disgrace brings himself gold, and the tomb-spoiler by breaking open men's sepulchres gathers together unjust wealth, and the robber by digging through walls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:191
verses.text: All wealth therefore is not from God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:192
verses.text: "What then," saith one, "shall we say to this expression?" Acquaint thyself first with a kind of poverty which proceeds not from God, and then we will proceed to the saying itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:193
verses.text: I mean, that when any dissolute youth spends his wealth either on harlots, or on conjurors, or on any other such evil desires, and becomes poor, is it not very evident that this hath not come from God, but from his own profligacy? Again, if any through idleness become poor, if any through folly be brought down to beggary, if any, by taking in hand perilous and unlawful practices; is it not quite evident, that neither hath any one of these and other such persons been brought down to this their poverty by God?  "Doth then the Scripture speak falsely?" God forbid! but they do foolishly, who neglect to examine with due exactness all things written.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:194
verses.text: For if this on the one hand be acknowledged, that the Scriptures cannot lie; and this on the other hand proved, that not all wealth is from God; the weakness of inconsiderate readers is the cause of the difficulty.
