verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:195
verses.text: Now it were right for us to dismiss you, having herein exculpated the Scripture, that ye may suffer this punishment at our hands for your negligence concerning the Scriptures: but because I greatly spare you and cannot any longer bear to look on you confused and disturbed, let us also add the solution, having first mentioned the speaker, and when it was spoken, and to whom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:196
verses.text: For not alike to all doth God speak, as neither do we deal alike with children and men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:197
verses.text: When then was it spoken, and by whom, and to whom? By Solomon in the Old Testament to the Jews, who knew no other than things of sense, and by these proved the power of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:198
verses.text: For these are they who say, "Can He give bread also?" and, "What sign showest Thou unto us? Our fathers did eat manna in the desert:—whose God is their belly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:199
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:200
verses.text: lxxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:201
verses.text: ; Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:202
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:203
verses.text: ; John vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:204
verses.text: ; Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:205
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:206
verses.text: ) Since then they were proving Him by these things, He saith to them, "This is also possible with God to make both rich and poor;" not that it is of course He Himself who maketh them, but that He can, when He will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:207
verses.text: Just as when he saith, "Who rebuketh the sea, and maketh it dry, and drieth up all the rivers," (Nahum i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:208
verses.text: ) and yet this was never done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:209
verses.text: How then doth the prophet say so? Not as though it were a doing always, but as a thing that was possible for Him to do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:210
verses.text: What kind of poverty then doth He give, and what kind of wealth? Remember the patriarch, and thou shalt know the kind of wealth that is given by God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:211
verses.text: For He made both Abraham rich, and after him Job, even as Job himself saith; "If we have received good from the Lord, shall we not also receive evil?" (Job ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:212
verses.text: ) And the wealth of Jacob thence had its beginning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:213
verses.text: There is also a poverty which cometh from Him, that which is commended, such as He once would have introduced to the knowledge of that rich man, saying, "If thou wouldest be perfect, sell thy goods, and give to the poor, and come, follow Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:214
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:215
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:216
verses.text: ) And to the disciples again, making a law and saying, "Provide neither gold, nor silver, nor two coats".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:217
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:218
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:219
verses.text: ) Say not then that all wealth is His gift: seeing that cases have been pointed out of its being collected both by murderers, and by rapine, and by ten thousand other devices.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:220
verses.text: But again the discourse reverts to our former question: viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:221
verses.text: "if the rich are no way useful to us, wherefore are they made rich?" What then must we say? That these are not useful who so make themselves rich; whereas those surely who are made so by God are in the highest degree useful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:222
verses.text: And do thou learn this from the very things done by those whom we just now mentioned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:223
verses.text: Thus Abraham possessed wealth for all strangers, and for all in need.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:224
verses.text: For he who on the approach of three men, as he supposed, sacrificed a calf and kneaded three measures of fine flour, and that while sitting in his door in the heat of the day; consider with what liberality and readiness he used to spend his substance on all, together with his goods giving also the service of his body, and this at such an advanced age; being a harbor to strangers, to all who had come to any kind of want, and possessing nothing as his own, not even his son: since at God's command he actually delivered up even him; and along with his son he gave up also himself and all his house, when he hastened to snatch his brother's son out of danger; and this he did not for lucre's sake, but of mere humanity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:225
verses.text: When, for instance, they who were saved by him would put the spoils at his disposal, he rejected all, even to "a thread and a shoe-latchet".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:226
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:227
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:228
verses.text: )  Such also was the blessed Job.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:229
verses.text: "For my door," saith, "was open to every one who came: (Job xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:230
verses.text: ) "I was eyes to the blind, and feet to the lame: I was a father of the helpless, the stranger lodged not without, and the helpless, whatever need they had, failed not of it, neither suffered I one helpless man to go out of my door with a empty bosom".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:231
verses.text: And much more too than these, that we may not now recount all, he continued to do, spending all his wealth on the needy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:232
verses.text: Wilt thou also look upon those who have become rich but not of God, that thou mayest learn how they employed their wealth? Behold him in the parable of Lazarus, how he imparted not so much as a share of his crumbs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:233
verses.text: Behold Ahab, how not even the vineyard is free from his extortion: behold Gehazi: behold all such.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:234
verses.text: Thus they on the one hand who make just acquisitions, as having received from God, spend on the commands of God: but they who in act of acquiring offend God, in the expending also do the same: consuming it on harlots and parasites, or burying and shutting it up, but laying out nothing upon the poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:235
verses.text: "And wherefore," saith one, "doth God suffer such men to be rich?" Because He is long-suffering: because He would bring us to repentance; because He hath prepared hell; because "He hath appointed a day in which He is to judge the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:236
verses.text: (Acts xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:237
verses.text: ) Whereas did He use at once to punish them that are rich and not virtuously, Zacchaeus would not have had an appointed time for repentance, so as even to restore fourfold whatever he had unjustly taken, and to add half of his goods; nor Matthew, to be converted and become an Apostle, taken off as he would have been before the due season; nor yet many other such.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:238
verses.text: Therefore doth He bear with them, calling all to repentance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:239
verses.text: But if they will not, but continue in the same, they shall hear Paul saying that "after their hardness and impenitent heart they treasure up unto themselves wrath against the day of wrath, and revelation, and righteous judgment of God: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:240
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:241
verses.text: ) which wrath that we may escape, let us become rich with the riches of heaven, and follow after the laudable sort of poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 33:242
verses.text: For thus shall we obtain also the good things to come: the which may we all obtain through the grace and mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father, with the Holy Ghost, be glory, power, and honor, now and for ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:1
verses.text: Homily XXXV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:3
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:4
verses.text: Follow after love, yet desire earnestly spiritual gifts; but rather that ye may prophesy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:5
verses.text: Thus, inasmuch as he had with exactness rehearsed unto them all the excellence of love, he exhorts them in what follows, with alacrity to lay hold of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:6
verses.text: Wherefore also he said, "Follow after:" for he that is in chase beholds that only which is chased, and towards that he strains himself, and leaves not off until he lay hold of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:7
verses.text: He that is in chase, when by himself he cannot, by those that are before him he doth overtake the fugitive, beseeching those who are near with much eagerness to seize and keep it so seized for him until he shall come up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:8
verses.text: This then let us also do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:9
verses.text: When of ourselves we do not reach unto love, let us bid them that are near her to hold her, till we come up with her, and when we have apprehended, no more let her go, that she may not again escape us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:10
verses.text: For continually she springs away from us, because we use her not as we ought, but prefer all things unto her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:11
verses.text: Therefore we ought to make every effort, so as perfectly to retain her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:12
verses.text: For if this be done, we require not henceforth much labor, nay rather scarce any; but taking our ease, and keeping holiday, we shall march on in the narrow path of virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:13
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, "Follow after her".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:14
verses.text: Then that they might not suppose that for no other end he brought in the discourse of charity, except that he might extinguish the gifts, he subjoins as follows;  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:15
verses.text: "Yet desire earnestly spiritual gifts; but rather that ye may prophesy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:16
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:17
verses.text: "For he that speaketh in a tongue, speaketh not unto men, but unto God: for no man understandeth; but in the Spirit he speaketh mysteries".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:18
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:19
verses.text: "But he that prophesieth speaketh unto men edification, and exhortation, and comfort".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:20
verses.text: At this point he makes a comparison between the gifts, and lowers that of the tongues, showing it to be neither altogether useless, nor very profitable by itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:21
verses.text: For in fact they were greatly puffed up on account of this, because the gift was considered to be a great one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:22
verses.text: And it was thought great because the Apostles received it first, and with so great display; it was not however therefore to be esteemed above all the others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:23
verses.text: Wherefore then did the Apostles receive it before the rest? Because they were to go abroad every where.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:24
verses.text: And as in the time of building the tower the one tongue was divided into many; so then the many tongues frequently met in one man, and the same person used to discourse both in the Persian, and the Roman, and the Indian, and many other tongues, the Spirit sounding within him: and the gift was called the gift of tongues because he could all at once speak divers languages.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:25
verses.text: See accordingly how he both depresses and elevates it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:26
verses.text: Thus, by saying, "He that speaketh with tongues, speaketh not unto men, but unto God, for no man understandeth," he depressed it, implying that the profit of it was not great; but by adding, "but in the Spirit he speaketh mysteries" he again elevated it, that it might not seem to be superfluous and useless and given in vain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:27
verses.text: "But he that prophesieth speaketh unto men edification, and exhortation, and comfort".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:28
verses.text: Seest thou by what he signifies the choice nature of this gift? i-e:, by the common benefit? and how every where he gives the higher honor to that which tends to the profit of the many? For do not the former speak unto men also? tell me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:29
verses.text: But not so much "edification, and exhortation, and comfort".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:30
verses.text: So that the being powered by the Spirit is common to both, as well to him that prophesieth, as to him that speaketh with tongues; but in this, the one (he, I mean, who prophesieth) hath the advantage in that he is also profitable unto the hearers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:31
verses.text: For they who with tongues were not understood by them that had not the gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:32
verses.text: What then? Did they edify no man? "Yes," saith he, "themselves alone:" wherefore also he adds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:33
verses.text: "He that speaketh in tongue edifieth himself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:34
verses.text: And how, if he know not what he saith? Why, for the present, he is speaking of them who understand what they say;—understand it themselves, but know not how to render it unto others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:35
verses.text: "But he that prophesieth edifieth the Church".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:36
verses.text: Now as great as is the difference between a single person and the Church, so great is the interval between these two.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:37
verses.text: Seest thou his wisdom, how he doth not thrust out the gift and make nothing of it, but signifies it to have some advantage, small though it be, and such as to suffice the possessor only?   Next, lest they should suppose that in envy to them he depresses the tongues, (for the more part had this gift,) to correct their suspicion he saith,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:38
verses.text: "I would have you all speak with tongues, but rather that ye should prophesy: for greater is he that prophesieth than he that speaketh with tongues, except he interpret, that the Church may receive edifying".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:39
verses.text: But "rather" and "greater," do not mark opposition, but superiority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:40
verses.text: So that hence also it is evident that he is not disparaging the gift, but leading them to better things, displaying both his carefulness on their behalf, and a spirit free from all envy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:41
verses.text: For neither did he say, "I would that two or three," but, "that ye all spake with tongues" and not this only, but also, "that ye prophesied;" and this rather than that; "for greater is he that prophesieth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:42
verses.text: For since he hath established and proved it, he next proceeds also to assert it; not however simply, but with a qualification.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:43
verses.text: Accordingly he adds, "except he interpret;" since if he be able to do this, I mean the interpreting, "he hath become equal unto the prophet," so he speaks, "because then there are many who reap the advantage of it;" a thing to be especially observed, how this throughout, before all else, is his object,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:44
verses.text: "But now, brethren, if I come unto you speaking with tongues, what shall I profit you, unless I speak to you either by way of revelation, or of knowledge, or of prophesying, or of teaching?"  "And why speak I," saith he, "of the rest? Nay, let the person who speaketh with tongues be Paul: for not even so will any good come to the hearers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:45
verses.text: And these things he saith to signify that he is seeking their profit, not bearing any grudge against them that have the gift; since not even in his own person doth he shrink from pointing out its unprofitableness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:46
verses.text: And indeed it is his constant way to work out the disagreeable topics in his own person: as in the beginning of the Epistle he said, "Who then is Paul? and who is Apollos? and who is Cephas?" This same then he doth also here, saying, "Not even I shall profit you, except I speak to you either by way of revelation, or of prophesying, or of knowledge, or of teaching".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:47
verses.text: And what he means is, "if I say not somewhat that can be made intelligible to you and that may be clear, but merely make display of my having the gift of tongues;—tongues which ye do not understand, ye will go away with no sort of profit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:48
verses.text: For how should you profit by a voice which ye understand not?"   Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:49
verses.text: "Even things without life, giving a voice, whether pipe or harp, if they give not a distinction in the sounds, how shall it be known what is piped?"  "And why do I say," saith he, "that in our case this is unprofitable, and that only useful which is clear and easy to be apprehended by the hearers? Since even in musical instruments without life one may see this: for whether it be pipe or harp, yet if it be struck or blown confusedly and unskilfully, without proper cadence or harmony, it will captivate none of the hearers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:50
verses.text: For even in these inarticulate sounds there is need of some distinctness: and if thou strike not or breathe into the pipe according to art, thou hast done nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:51
verses.text: Now if from things without life we require so much distinctness, and harmony, and appropriateness, and into those inarticulate sounds we strive and contend to infuse so much meaning, much more in men indued with life and reason, and in spiritual gifts, ought one to make significancy an object.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:52
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:53
verses.text: "For if the trumpet give an uncertain voice, who shall prepare himself for war?"  Thus from things merely ornamental he carries on his argument to those which are more necessary and useful; and saith that not in the harp alone, but in the trumpet also one may see this effect produced.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:54
verses.text: For in that also there are certain measures; and they give out at one time a warlike note, and at another one that is not so; and again sometimes it leads out to line of battle and at others recalls from it: and unless one know this, there is great danger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:55
verses.text: Which is just what he means, and the mischief of it what he is manifesting, when he saith, "who shall prepare himself for war?" So then, if it have not this quality, it is the ruin of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:56
verses.text: "And what is this to us," saith one? Truly it concerns you very especially; wherefore also he adds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:57
verses.text: "So also ye, unless ye utter by the tongue, speech easy to be understood, ye will be speaking into the air:" i-e:, calling to nobody, speaking unto no one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:58
verses.text: Thus every where he shows its unprofitableness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:59
verses.text: "But if it be unprofitable, why was it given?" saith one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:60
verses.text: So as to be useful to him that hath received it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:61
verses.text: But if it is to be so to others also, there must be added interpretation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:62
verses.text: Now this he saith, bringing them near to one another; that if a person himself have not the gift of interpretation, he may take unto him another that hath it, and make his own gift useful through him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:63
verses.text: Wherefore he every where points out its imperfection, that so he may bind them together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:64
verses.text: Any how, he that accounts it to be sufficient for itself, doth not so much commend it as disparage it, not suffering it to shine brightly by the interpretation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:65
verses.text: For excellent indeed and necessary is the gift, but it is so when it hath one to explain what is spoken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:66
verses.text: Since the finger too is a necessary thing, but when you separate it from the other members, it will not be equally useful: and the trumpet is necessary, but when it sounds at random, it is rather an annoyance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:67
verses.text: Yea, neither shall any art come to light, without matter subject to it; nor is matter put into shape, if no form be assigned to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:68
verses.text: Suppose then the voice to be as the subject-matter, but the distinctness as that form, which not being present, there will be no use in the material.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:69
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:70
verses.text: "There are, it may be, so many kinds of voices in the world, and no kind is without signification:" i-e:, so many tongues, so many voices of Scythians, Thracians, Romans, Persians, Moors, Indians, Egyptians, innumerable other nations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:71
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:72
verses.text: "If then I know not the meaning of the voice, I shall be to him that speaketh a barbarian".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:73
verses.text: "For suppose not," saith he, "that this happens only in our case; rather in all one may see this taking place: so that I do not say this to disparage the voice, but to signify that to me it is useless, as long as it is not intelligible".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:74
verses.text: Next, that he may not render the accusation unpalatable, he makes his charge alike for the two, saying, "He shall be unto me a barbarian, and I to him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:75
verses.text: Not from the nature of the voice, but from our ignorance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:76
verses.text: Seest thou how by little and little he draws men to that which is akin to the subject.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:77
verses.text: Which is his use to do, to fetch his examples from afar, and to end with what more properly belongs to the matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:78
verses.text: For having spoken of a pipe and harp, wherein is much that is inferior and unprofitable, he comes to the trumpet, a thing more useful; next, from that he proceeds to the very voice itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:79
verses.text: So also before, when he was discoursing to show that it was not forbidden the Apostles to receive, beginning first with husbandmen, and shepherds, and soldiers, then he brought the discourse on to that which is nearer to the subject, the priests in the old covenant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:80
verses.text: But do thou, I pray, consider, how every where he hath given diligence to free the gift from censure, and to bring round the charge to the receivers of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:81
verses.text: For he said not, "I shall be a barbarian," but, "unto him that speaketh, a barbarian".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:82
verses.text: And again, he did not say, "he that speaketh shall be a barbarian," but "he that speaketh shall be a barbarian unto me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:83
verses.text: "What then must be done?" saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:84
verses.text: Why, so far from disparaging, one ought to recommend and to teach it; as indeed himself also doth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:85
verses.text: Since after he had accused and rebuked it and shown its unprofitableness, he proceeds to counsel them; saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:86
verses.text: "So also ye, since as ye are zealous of spiritual gifts, seek that ye may abound unto the edifying of the Church".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:87
verses.text: Seest thou his aim every where, how he looks to one thing continually and in all cases, the general utility, the profiting the Church; laying this down as a kind of rule? And he did not say, "that ye may obtain the gifts" but, "that ye may abound," i-e:, that ye may even possess them in great plenitude.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:88
verses.text: Thus, so far am I from wishing you not to possess them, that I even wish you to abound in them, only so that ye handle them with a view to the common advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:89
verses.text: And how is this to be done? This he adds, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:90
verses.text: "Wherefore let him that speaketh in a tongue pray that he may interpret".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:91
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:92
verses.text: "For if I pray in a tongue, my spirit prayeth, but my understanding is unfruitful".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:93
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:94
verses.text: "What is it then? I will pray with the spirit, and I will pray with the understanding also; I will sing with the spirit, and I will sing with the understanding also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:95
verses.text: Here he shows that it is in their power to obtain the gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:96
verses.text: For, "let him pray," saith he, i-e:, "let him contribute his own part," since if thou ask diligently, thou wilt surely receive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:97
verses.text: Ask accordingly not to have the gift of tongue only, but also of interpretation, that thou mayest become useful unto all, and not shut up thy gift in thyself alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:98
verses.text: "For if I pray in a tongue," saith he, "my spirit prayeth, but my understanding is unfruitful".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:99
verses.text: Seest thou how by degrees bringing his argument to a point, he signifies that not to others only is such an one useless, but also to himself; if at least "his understanding is unfruitful?" For if a man should speak only in the Persian, or any other foreign tongue, and not understand what he saith, then of course to himself also will he be thenceforth a barbarian, not to another only, from not knowing the meaning of the sound.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:100
verses.text: For there were of old many who had also a gift of prayer, together with a tongue; and they prayed, and the tongue spake, praying either in the Persian or Latin language, but their understanding knew not what was spoken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:101
verses.text: Wherefore also he said, "If I pray in a tongue, my spirit prayeth," i-e:, the gift which is given me and which moves my tongue, "but my understanding is unfruitful".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:102
verses.text: What then may that be which is best in itself, and doth good? And how ought one to act, or what request of God? To pray, "both with the spirit," i-e:, the gift, and "with the understanding".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:103
verses.text: Wherefore also he said, "I will pray with the spirit, and I will pray with the understanding also: I will sing with the spirit, and I will sing with the understanding also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:104
verses.text: He signifieth the same thing here also, that both the tongue may speak, and the understanding may not be ignorant of the things spoken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:105
verses.text: For except this be so, there will also be another confusion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:106
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:107
verses.text: "Else," saith he, "if thou bless with the spirit, how shall he that filleth the place of the unlearned say the Amen at thy giving of thanks, seeing he knoweth not what thou sayest?"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:108
verses.text: "For thou verily givest thanks well, but the other is not edified".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:109
verses.text: Observe how again here he brings his stone to the plumb-line, every where seeking the edification of the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:110
verses.text: Now by the "unlearned" he means the laymen, and signifies that he also suffers no little loss when he is unable to say the Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:111
verses.text: And what he saith is this: "if thou shalt bless in a barbarian tongue, not knowing what thou sayest, nor able to interpret, the layman cannot respond the Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:112
verses.text: For not hearing the words, 'forever and ever,' which are at the end, he doth not say the Amen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:113
verses.text: Then again, comforting him concerning this, that he might not seem to hold the gift too cheap; the same kind of remark as he made above, that "he speaketh mysteries," and "speaketh unto God," and "edifieth himself," and "prayeth with the spirit," intending no little comfort from these things, this also he utters here, saying, "for thou indeed givest thanks well," since thou speakest being moved by the Spirit: but the other hearing nothing nor knowing what is said, stands there, receiving no great advantage by it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:114
verses.text: Further, because he had run down the possessors of this gift, as though they had no such great thing; that he might not seem to hold them cheap, as being himself destitute of it, see what he saith:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:115
verses.text: "I thank God, speaking with tongues more than ye all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:116
verses.text: And this he doth also in another place intending, namely, to take away the advantages of Judaism and to show that henceforth they are nothing, he begins by declaring that himself had been endowed with them, yea, and that in very great excess; and then he calls them "loss," thus saying, "If any man thinketh to have confidence in the flesh, I more: circumcised the eighth day, of the stock of Israel, of the tribe of Benjamin, a Hebrew of Hebrews; as touching the law, a Pharisee; as touching zeal, persecuting the Church; as touching the righteousness which is the law, found blameless".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:117
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:118
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:120
verses.text: ) And then, having signified himself to have the advantage of all, he saith, "Howbeit what things were gain to me, those have I counted loss for Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:121
verses.text: So also he doth here, saying, "I speak with tongues more than ye all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:122
verses.text: Do not ye therefore glory as though ye only had the gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:123
verses.text: For I also possess it, yea more than ye.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:124
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:125
verses.text: "Howbeit in the Church I had rather speak five words with my understanding, that I might instruct others also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:126
verses.text: What is that, "speak with my understanding, that I might instruct others also?" "Understanding what I say," and "words which I can both interpret to others, and speak intelligently, and teach the hearers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:127
verses.text: "Than ten thousand words in a tongue".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:128
verses.text: Wherefore? "That I may instruct others," saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:129
verses.text: For the one hath but display only; the other, great utility: this being what he everywhere seeks, I mean the common profit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:130
verses.text: And yet the gift of tongues was strange, but that of prophecy familiar and ancient and heretofore given to many; this on the contrary then first given: howbeit it was not much cared for by him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:131
verses.text: Wherefore neither did he employ it; not because he had it not, but because he always sought the more profitable things: being as he was free from all vain-glory, and considering one thing only, how he might render the hearers better.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:132
verses.text: And here is the reason of the faculty he had of looking to the expedient both to himself and to others: viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:133
verses.text: because he was free from vain-glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:134
verses.text: Since he assuredly that is enslaved by it, so far from discerning what is good to others, will not even know his own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:135
verses.text: Such was Simon, who, because he looked to vain-glory, did not even see his own advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:136
verses.text: Such also were the Jews, who because of this sacrificed their own salvation to the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:137
verses.text: Hence also did idols spring, and by this madness did the heathen philosophers excite themselves, and make shipwreck in their false doctrines.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:138
verses.text: And observe the perverseness of this passion: how because of it some of them also made themselves poor, others were eager for wealth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:139
verses.text: So potent is its tyranny that it prevails even in direct contraries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:140
verses.text: Thus one man is vain of chastity, and contrariwise another of adultery; and this man of justice, and another of injustice; so of luxury and fasting, modesty and rashness, riches and poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:141
verses.text: I say poverty: since some of them that were with out, when it was in their power to receive, for admiration's sake forbore to receive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:142
verses.text: But not so the Apostles: that they were pure from vainglory, they showed by their doings: in that, when some were calling them Gods and were ready to sacrifice-unto them oxen with garlands, they did not merely just forbid what was doing, but they even rent their clothes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:143
verses.text: (Acts xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:145
verses.text: ) And after they had set the lame man upright, when all with open mouths were gazing at them, they said, "Why look ye so earnestly on us, as though by our own power we had made this man to walk?" And those, among men who admired poverty, chose to themselves a state of poverty: but these among persons who despised poverty and gave praise to wealth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:146
verses.text: And these, if they received aught, ministered to the needy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:147
verses.text: Thus, not vain-glory but benevolence, was the motive of all they did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:148
verses.text: But those quite the reverse; as enemies and pests of our common nature, and no otherwise, did they such things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:149
verses.text: Thus one sunk all his goods in the sea for no good purpose, imitating fools and madmen: and another let all his land go to sheep common.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:150
verses.text: Thus they did every thing for vain-glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:151
verses.text: But not so the Apostles; rather they both received what was given them, and distributed to the needy with so great liberality that they even lived in continual hunger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:152
verses.text: But if they had been enamored of glory, they would not have practiced this, the receiving and distributing, for fear of some suspicion arising against them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:153
verses.text: For he who throws away his own for glory, will much more refuse to receive the things of others, that he may not be accounted to stand in need of others nor incur any suspicion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:154
verses.text: But these thou seest both ministering to the poor, and themselves begging for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:155
verses.text: So truly were they more loving than any fathers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:156
verses.text: And observe also their laws, how moderate and freed from all vain-glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:157
verses.text: Thus: "Having" saith he," food and covering, let us therewith be content".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:158
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:159
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:160
verses.text: ) Not like him of Sinope, who clothed in rags and living in a cask to no good end, astonished many, but profited none: whereas Paul did none of these things; (for neither had he an eye to ostentation;) but was both clothed in ordinary apparel with all decency, and lived in a house continually, and displayed all exactness in the practice of all other virtue; which the cynic despised, living impurely and publicly disgracing himself, and dragged away by his mad passion for glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:161
verses.text: For if any one ask the reason of his living in a cask, he will find no other but vain-glory alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:162
verses.text: But Paul also paid rent for the house wherein he abode at Rome.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:163
verses.text: Although he who was able to do things far severer, could much more have had strength for this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:164
verses.text: But he looked not to glory, that savage monster, that fearful demon, that pest of the world, that poisonous viper.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:165
verses.text: Since, as that animal tears through the womb of her parent with her teeth, so also this passion tears in pieces him that begets it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:166
verses.text: By what means then may one find a remedy for this manifold distemper? By bringing forward those that have trodden it under foot, and with an eye to their image so ordering one's own life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:167
verses.text: For so the patriarch Abraham.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:168
verses.text: —nay, let none accuse me of tautology if I often make mention of him, and on all occasions: this being that which most of all shows him wonderful, and deprives them that refuse to imitate him of all excuse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:169
verses.text: For, if we exhibit one doing well in this particular, and another in that, some one might say that virtue is hardly to be attained; for that it is scarcely possible to succeed in all those things together, whereof each one of the saints hath performed only a part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:170
verses.text: But when one and the same person is found to possess all, what excuse will they have, who after the law and grace are not able to attain unto the same measure with them that were before the law and grace? How then did this Patriarch overcome and subdue this monster, when he had a dispute with his nephew? (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:171
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:172
verses.text: ) For so it was, that coming off worst and losing the first share, he was not vexed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:173
verses.text: But ye know that in such matters the shame is worse than the loss to the vulgar-minded, and particularly when a person having all in his own power, as he had then, and having been the first to give honor, was not honored in return.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:174
verses.text: Nevertheless, none of these things vexed him, but he was content to receive the second place, and when wronged by the young man, himself old, an uncle by a nephew, he was not indignant nor took it ill, but loved him equally and ministered to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:175
verses.text: Again, having been victorious in that great and terrible fight, and having mightily put to flight the Barbarians (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:176
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:177
verses.text: ) he doth not add show to victory, nor erect a trophy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:178
verses.text: For he wished to save only, not to exhibit himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:179
verses.text: Again, he entertained strangers, yet did he not here act vain-gloriously, but himself both ran to them and bowed down to them, not as though he were giving, but receiving a benefit, and he calleth them lords, without knowing who they are who are come to him, and presents his wife in the place of a handmaiden.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:180
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:181
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:182
verses.text: ) And in Egypt too before this, when he had appeared so extraordinary a person, and had received back this very woman, his wife, and had enjoyed so great honor (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:183
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:184
verses.text: ) he showeth it to no man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:185
verses.text: And though the inhabitants of the place called him prince, he himself even laid down the price of the sepulchre.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:186
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:187
verses.text: xxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:188
verses.text: ) And when he sent to betroth a wife for his son, he gave no command to speak in high and dignified terms of him, (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:189
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:190
verses.text: ) but merely to bring the bride.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:191
verses.text: Wilt thou examine also the conduct of those under grace, when from every side great was the glory of the teaching flowing round them, and wilt thou see then also this passion cast out? Consider, I pray, this same Apostle who speaks these things, how he ever ascribes the whole to God, how of his sins he makes mention continually, but of his good deeds never, unless perchance it should be needful to correct the disciples; and even if he be compelled to do this, he calls the matter folly, and yields the first place to Peter, and is not ashamed to labor with Priscilla and Aquila, and every where he is eager to show himself lowly, not swaggering in the market place, nor carrying crowds with him, but setting himself down among the obscure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:192
verses.text: Wherefore also he said, "but his bodily presence is weak".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:193
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:194
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:195
verses.text: ) i-e:, easy to be despised, and not at all accompanied with display.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:196
verses.text: And again, "I pray that ye do no evil, not that we may appear approved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:197
verses.text: And what marvel if he despise this glory? seeing that he despises the glory of heaven, and the kingdom, and hell, for that which was pleasing unto Christ: for he wishes himself to be accursed from Christ for the glory of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:198
verses.text: For if he saith that he is willing to suffer this for the Jews' sake, he saith it on this account that none of those without understanding might think to take to himself the promises made to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:199
verses.text: If therefore he were ready to pass by those things, what marvel is it if he despise human things?   But the men of our time are overwhelmed by all things, not by desire of glory only, but also, on the other hand, by insult and fear of dishonor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:200
verses.text: Thus, should any one praise, it would puff thee up, and if he blame, it would cast thee down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:201
verses.text: And as weak bodies are by common accidents injured, so also souls which grovel on earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:202
verses.text: For such not poverty alone, but even wealth destroys, not grief only, but likewise joy, and prosperity more than adversity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:203
verses.text: For poverty compels to be wise, but wealth leads on oftentimes into some great evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:204
verses.text: And as men in a fever are hard to be pleased in any thing, so also they that are depraved in mind on every side receive hurt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:205
verses.text: Knowing therefore these things, let us not shun poverty, let us not admire riches: but prepare our soul to be sufficient for all estates.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:206
verses.text: For so any one building an house doth not consider how neither rain may descend, nor sunbeam light on it, (for this were impossible,) but how it may be made capable of enduring all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:207
verses.text: And he again that builds a ship doth not fashion and design any thing to keep waves from breaking against it, or any tempest from rising in the sea: (for this too were impossible:) but that the sides of the ship may be ready to meet all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:208
verses.text: And again, he that cares for the body doth not look to this that there may be no inequality in the temperature, but that the body may easily endure all these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:209
verses.text: So accordingly let us act in respect of the soul, and neither be anxious to fly poverty nor to become rich, but to regulate each of them for our own safety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:210
verses.text: Wherefore, letting alone these things, let us render our soul meet both for wealth and poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:211
verses.text: For although no calamity, such as man is subject to, befall, which is for the most part impossible, even thus, better is he that seeks not wealth, but knows how to bear all things easily than he that is always rich.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:212
verses.text: And why? First, such an one hath his safety from within, but the other from without.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:213
verses.text: And as he is a better soldier who trusts to his bodily powers and skill in fighting, than he that hath his strength in his armor only; so he that relies on his wealth, compared with him that is fenced in by his virtue, is inferior.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:214
verses.text: Secondly, because even if he do not fall into poverty, it is impossible that he should be without trouble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:215
verses.text: For wealth hath many storms and troubles; but not so virtue, but pleasure only and safety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:216
verses.text: Yea, and it puts a man out of the reach of them that lay snares for him, but wealth quite the contrary, rendering him easy to be attacked and taken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:217
verses.text: And as among animals, stags and hares are of all most easily taken through their natural timidity, but the wild boar, and the bull, and the lion, would not easily fall in the way of the liers-in-wait; just so one may see in the case of the rich, and of them that live voluntarily in poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:218
verses.text: The one is like the lion and the bull, the other like the stag and the hare.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:219
verses.text: For whom doth not the rich man fear? Are there not robbers, potentates, enviers, informers? And why speak I of robbers and informers, in a case where a man suspects his very domestics?   And why say I, "when he is alive?" Not even when dead is he freed from the villainy of the robbers, nor hath death power to set him in safety, but the evil doers despoil him even when dead, so dangerous a thing is wealth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:220
verses.text: For not only do they dig into houses, but they even burst open tombs and coffins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:221
verses.text: What then can be more wretched than this man, since not even death can furnish him with this security, but that wretched body, even when deprived of life, is not freed from the evils of life, those that commit such wickedness hastening to war even with dust and ashes, and much more grievously than when it was alive? For then, it might be, entering his storehouse, they would remove his chests, but abstain from his person, and would not take so much as to strip the body itself but now the accursed hands of the tombbreakers do not even abstain from these, but move and turn it about, and with much cruelty insult it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:222
verses.text: For after it hath been committed to the ground, having stripped it both of its covering of earth and of that which its grave-clothes constitute, they leave it thus to be cast out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:223
verses.text: What foe then so deadly as wealth, which destroys both the soul of the living, and insults the body of the dead, not suffering it even to lie buried in the ground, which is common even to the condemned and to them that have been taken in the vilest crimes? For of them the legislators having exacted the punishment of death, inquire no further; but of these, wealth even after death exacts a most bitter punishment, exposing them naked and unburied, a dreadful and pitiable spectacle: since even those who suffer this after sentence and by the anger of their judges, do not suffer so grievously as these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:224
verses.text: For they indeed remain unburied the first and second day, and so are committed to the ground; but these, when they have been committed to the ground, are then stripped naked and insulted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:225
verses.text: And if the robbers depart without taking the coffin too, there is still no thanks to their wealth, but in this case also to their poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:226
verses.text: For she it is that guards it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:227
verses.text: Whereas most assuredly, had we intruded wealth with even so much as this, and leaving off to form it of stone, had forged it of gold, we should have lost this also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:228
verses.text: So faithless a thing is wealth; which belongs not so much to them that have it, as to them that endeavor to seize it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:229
verses.text: So that it is but a superfluous argument which aims to show that wealth is irresistible, seeing that not even on the day of their death do its possessors obtain security.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:230
verses.text: And yet who is not reconciled with the departed, whether it be wild beast, or demon, or whatever else? The very sight being enough to bend even one who is altogether iron, and quite past feeling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:231
verses.text: Wherefore, you know, when one sees a corpse, though it be an enemy public or private whom he sees, yet he weeps for him in common with his dearest friends; and his wrath is extinguished with life, and pity is brought in.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:232
verses.text: And it would be impossible, in time of mourning and carrying out of burial, to distinguish an enemy from him who is not such.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:233
verses.text: So greatly do all men revere their common nature, and the customs which have been introduced respecting it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:234
verses.text: But wealth not even on obtaining this, remits her anger against her possessors; nay, it renders them that have been no way wronged enemies of the dead; if at least to strip the dead body be an act of persons very bitter and hostile.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:235
verses.text: And nature for her part reconciles even his enemies to him then: but wealth makes foes of them that have nothing to accuse him of, and cruelly intreats the body in its utter desolation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:236
verses.text: And yet in that case there are many things which might lead one to pity, the fact of its being a corpse, its inability to move, and tending to earth and corruption, the absence of any one to help: but none of these things soften those accursed wretches, because of the tyranny they are under from their base cupidity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:237
verses.text: For the passion of covetousness, like some ruthless tyrant, is at hand, enjoining those inhuman commands and having made wild beasts of them, so brings them to the tombs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:238
verses.text: Yea, like wild beasts attacking the dead, they would not even abstain from their flesh, if their limbs were any way useful unto them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:239
verses.text: Such is our enjoyment of wealth; to be insulted even after death, and deprived of sepulture which even the most desperate criminals obtain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:240
verses.text: Are we still then, tell me, to be fond of so grievous an enemy? Nay, I beseech you, nay, my brethren! but let us fly from it without turning to look: and if it come into our hands, let us not keep it within, but bind it fast by the hands of the poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:241
verses.text: For these are the bonds which have more power to hold it, and from those treasuries it will never more escape; and so this faithless one abides for the time to come faithful, tractable, tame, the right hand of Mercy producing this effect on it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:242
verses.text: As I have said then, if it ever come to us, let us hand it over to her; but if it come not, let us not seek after it, nor fret ourselves, nor count its possessors happy; for what sort of a notion of happiness is this? Unless thou wouldest also say that those who fight with beasts are to be envied, because those high-priced animals are shut up and reserved by the proposers of such contests for themselves: who however not daring themselves to approach or to touch them, but fearing and trembling because of them, hand over others to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:243
verses.text: Something like this, I say, is the case of the wealthy, when they have shut up their wealth in their treasuries as if it were some savage beast, and day by day receive from it innumerable wounds: in this latter unlike to the beasts: since they, when thou leadest them out, then, and not till then, hurt such as meet them: but this, when it is shut up and preserved, then destroys its possessors and hoarders.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:244
verses.text: But let us make this beast tame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:245
verses.text: And it will be tame, if we do not shut it up, but give it into the hands of all who are in need.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 34:246
verses.text: So shall we reap from this quarter the greatest blessings, both living in the present life with safety and a good hope, and in the day that is to come standing with boldness: to which may we all attain, through the grace and mercy, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:1
verses.text: Homily XXXVI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:3
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:4
verses.text: Brethren, be not children in mind; howbeit in malice be ye babes, but in mind be men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:5
verses.text: As might be expected, after his long argument and demonstration he adopts a more vehement style and abundance of rebuke; and mentions an example suited to the subject.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:6
verses.text: For children too are wont to gape after trifles and to be fluttered, but of things very great they have not so much admiration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:7
verses.text: Since then these also having the gift of tongues, which was the lowest of all, thought they had the whole; therefore he saith, "Be not children," i-e:, be not without understanding where ye ought to be considerate, but there be ye childlike and simple, where unrighteousness is, where vain-glory, where pride.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:8
verses.text: For he that is a babe in wickedness ought also to be wise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:9
verses.text: Since as wisdom with wickedness would not be wisdom, so also simplicity with folly would not be simplicity, it being requisite both in simplicity to avoid folly, and in wisdom wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:10
verses.text: For as neither bitter nor sweet medicines in excess do good, so neither doth simplicity by itself, nor wisdom: and this is why Christ enjoining us to mix both said, "Be ye wise as serpents, and harmless as doves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:11
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:12
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:13
verses.text: )  But what is it to be a babe in wickedness? Not even to know what wickedness is: yea, such he willed them to be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:14
verses.text: Wherefore also he said, "It is actually reported that there is fornication among you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:15
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:16
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:17
verses.text: ) He said not, "is done," but is "reported:" as if he said, "ye are not without knowledge of the thing; ye have heard of it some time".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:18
verses.text: I say, he would have them both to be men and children; the one however in wickedness, but the other in wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:19
verses.text: For so even the man may become a man, if he be also a child: but as long as he is not a child in wickedness, neither will he be a man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:20
verses.text: For the wicked, instead of being mature, will be but a fool.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:21
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:22
verses.text: "In the law it is written, By men of strange tongues and by the lips of strangers will I speak unto this people; and not even thus will they hear me, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:23
verses.text: Yet surely it is no where written in the Law, but as I said before, he calls always the whole of the Old Testament, the Law: both the prophets and the historical books.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:24
verses.text: And he brings forward his testimony from Esaias the prophet, again covertly detracting from the glory of the gift, for their profit; nevertheless, even thus he states it with praise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:25
verses.text: For the expression, "not even thus," hath force to point out that the miracle was enough to astonish them; and if they did not believe, the fault was theirs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:26
verses.text: And wherefore did God work it, if they were not to believe? That He might in every case appear to do His part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:27
verses.text: Having shown then even from the prophecy, that the sign in question is not of great use, he adds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:28
verses.text: "Wherefore tongues are for a sign, not to them that believe, but to the unbelieving: but prophesying is for a sign not to the unbelieving, but to them that believe".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:29
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:30
verses.text: "If therefore the whole Church be assembled together, and all speak with tongues, and there come in men unlearned or unbelieving, will they not say that ye are mad?"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:31
verses.text: "But if all prophesy, and there come in one unbelieving or unlearned, he is reproved by all, he is judged by all:"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:32
verses.text: "And thus the secrets of his heart are made manifest; and so he will fall down on his face and worship God, declaring that God is among you indeed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:33
verses.text: Great in this place is the difficulty which one seems to find arising from what is said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:34
verses.text: For if tongues are for a sign to them that believe not, how saith he, if they that believe not should see you speaking with tongues, they will say that "ye are mad?" And if prophecy be "not for the unbelieving, but for them that believe," how shall also the unbelievers gain thereby?  "For if there come in," saith he, "when ye are prophesying, one that believeth not, he is reproved by all, and judged".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:35
verses.text: And not only this, but also after this another question hence springs up: since the tongue will appear on the contrary greater than the prophecy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:36
verses.text: For if the tongues are for a sign to the unbelieving, but prophecy to them that believe, that which draws in aliens and makes of the household, is greater than that which regulates those of the household.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:37
verses.text: What then is the meaning of that expression? Nothing difficult nor obscure, nor contrary to what went before, but rather very agreeable to it, if we give heed: viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:38
verses.text: , that prophecy is suitable to both, but then tongue not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:39
verses.text: Wherefore having said of the tongue, "it is for a sign," he adds, "not to them that believe, but to the unbelievers," and to them "for a sign," i-e:, for astonishment, not so much for instruction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:40
verses.text: "But in the case of prophecy too," saith some one, "he did the very same thing, saying, 'but prophesying serveth not for the unbelieving, but for them which believe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:41
verses.text: ' For the believer hath no need to see a sign, but requires only teaching and catechizing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:42
verses.text: How then sayest thou," saith he, "that prophecy is of use to both, when Paul saith 'not to the unbelieving, but to them which believe?'" If thou wilt accurately examine, thou wilt understand what is said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:43
verses.text: For he said not, "prophecy is not useful to them unbelieving," but, "is not for a sign," as the tongue," i-e:, a mere sign without profit: nor is the tongue any way useful to believers; for its only work is to astonish and to confound; the word "sign" being one of those which may be taken two ways: as when he saith, "show me a sign," (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:44
verses.text: lxxxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:45
verses.text: ) and adds, "for good:" and again, "I am become as a wonder unto many," (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:46
verses.text: lxxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:47
verses.text: ) i-e:, a sign.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:48
verses.text: And to show thee that he introduced the term "sign" here, not as a thing which of course did some good, he added that which resulted from it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:49
verses.text: And what was this? "They will say," saith he, "that ye are mad".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:50
verses.text: This however not from the nature of the sign, but from their folly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:51
verses.text: But when thou hearest of unbelievers, do not suppose that the same persons are in every case intended, but at one time they which are incurably diseased and abide uncorrected, and at another they which may be changed; such as were they who in the times of the Apostles admire the mighty things of God which they hear of; such as in the case of Cornelius.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:52
verses.text: His meaning accordingly is this; that prophecy avails both among the unbelieving and among them that believe: as to the tongue, when heard by the unbelieving and inconsiderate, instead of profiting by it, they rather deride the utterers as madmen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:53
verses.text: For, in fact, it is to them but for a sign, i-e:, in order to astonish them merely; whereas they who had understanding used also to profit by it: with a view to which the sign was given.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:54
verses.text: Even as then there were not only certain who accused them of drunkenness, but many also admired them as relating the wonderful works of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:55
verses.text: It appears then that the mockers were those without understanding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:56
verses.text: Wherefore also Paul did not simply say, "they will say that ye are mad," but added, "unlearned and unbelievers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:57
verses.text: But prophecy is not for a sign merely, but is also suitable and useful for faith and for profit unto both classes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:58
verses.text: And this, if not directly, yet in the sequel he more clearly explained, saying, "he is reproved by all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:59
verses.text: For, if all prophesy," saith he, "and there come in one unbelieving or unlearned, he is reproved by all; he is judged by all; and thus are the secrets of his heart made manifest; and so he will fall down on his face and worship God, declaring that God is among you indeed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:60
verses.text: So that not in this only is prophecy greater, in its availing with each class, but also in its attracting the more shameless of the unbelievers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:61
verses.text: For it was not the same wonder, when Peter convicted Sapphira, which was a work of prophecy, and when he spake with tongues: but in the former case all shrank into themselves; whereas, when he spake with tongues, he got the credit of being even beside himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:62
verses.text: Having said then, that a tongue profited not, and having again qualified this statement by turning the charge upon the Jews, he proceeds to signify that it even doth injury.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:63
verses.text: "And wherefore was it given?" That it might go forth with interpretation: since without this, it hath even the contrary effect among them that are without understanding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:64
verses.text: "For if," saith he, "all speak with tongues, and there come in unbelievers or unlearned, they will say that ye are mad;" as indeed even the Apostles incurred the suspicion of being drunken: for "these men," it saith, "are filled with new wine: (Acts ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:65
verses.text: ) but it is not the fault of the sign, but of their unskilfulness; therefore he added, "unlearned and unbelievers," to show that the notion belongs to their ignorance and want of faith; for, as I before said, his object is to rank that gift not among things that are disparaged, but among those which do not greatly profit, and this, in order to repress them, and bring them to a necessity of seeking for an interpreter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:66
verses.text: For since the greater part looked not to this, but made use of it for display and rivalry, this is what he especially withdraws them from, intimating that their credit is injured, they bringing on themselves a suspicion of madness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:67
verses.text: And this especially is what Paul continually attempts to establish, when he wants to lead men away from any thing: he shows that the person suffers loss in respect of those very things which he desires.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:68
verses.text: And do thou accordingly likewise: if thou wouldest lead men away from pleasure, show that the thing is bitter: if thou wouldest withdraw them from vain-glory, show that the thing is full of dishonor: thus also was Paul used to do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:69
verses.text: When he would tear away the rich from their love of money, he said not merely that wealth is a hurtful thing, but also that it casts into temptations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:70
verses.text: "For they that desire to be rich," saith he," fall into a temptation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:71
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:72
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:73
verses.text: ) Thus, since it seems to deliver from temptations, he attributes to it the contrary of that which the rich supposed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:74
verses.text: Others again held fast by the wisdom that is without, as though by it establishing Christ's doctrine; he signifies that not only it gives no aid to the cross, but even makes it void.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:75
verses.text: They held to going to law before strangers, thinking it unmeet to be judged by their own, as if those without were wiser: he points out that going to law before them that are without is shameful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:76
verses.text: They clave to things offered in sacrifice to idols, as displaying perfect knowledge: he intimates that this is a mark of imperfect knowledge, not to know how to manage in the things which concern our neighbors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:77
verses.text: So also here, because they were wild about this gift of tongues, through their love of glory, he signifies that this on the other hand more than any thing brings shame upon them, not only depriving them of glory, but also involving them in a suspicion of madness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:78
verses.text: But he did not at once say this, but having spoken very many things before, when he had made his discourse acceptable, then he brings in that topic so very contrary to their opinion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:79
verses.text: And this in fact is no more than the common rule; that he who intends thoroughly to shake a deep-rooted opinion and to turn men round to its contrary, must not at once state the opposites: otherwise he will be ridiculous in the eyes of them that are preoccupied by the contrary conviction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:80
verses.text: Since that which is very much beside expectation cannot be from the beginning easily received, but you must first well undermine by other arguments, and then give it the contrary turn.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:81
