verses.text: Thus for example he did when discoursing of marriage: I mean, since many regarded it as a thing which brings ease, and he wished to intimate that the abstaining from marriage was ease; if he had said this at once he would not so easily have made it acceptable: whereas now, having stated it after much other matter and timing its introduction exactly, he strongly touched the hearers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:82
verses.text: This also he did in respect of virginity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:83
verses.text: For before this having said much, and after this again, at last he saith, "I spare you," and, "I would have you to be free from cares".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:84
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:85
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:87
verses.text: )  This then he doth in respect of the tongues, showing that they not only deprive of glory, but also bring shame upon those who have them in the eyes of the unbelievers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:88
verses.text: But prophecy, on the contrary, is both free from reproach among the unbelievers, and hath very great credit and usefulness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:89
verses.text: For none will say in regard to prophesying, "they are mad;" nor will any one deride them that prophesy; but, on the contrary, will be astonished at and admire them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:90
verses.text: For "he is reproved by all," i-e:, the things which he hath in his heart, are brought forward and shown unto all: now it is not the same thing for any one to come in and see one speaking in Persian and another in Syriac, and to come in and hear the secrets of his own mind; as whether he cometh in as a tempter and with evil mind, or sincerely; or that such and such a thing hath been done by him, and such another designed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:91
verses.text: For this is much more awful and more profitable than the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:92
verses.text: For this cause therefore, whereas of the tongues he saith, "ye are mad;" not however affirming this of himself, but of their judgment: i-e:, "they will say," saith he, "that ye are mad;" here, on the contrary, he makes use both of the verdict of the facts, and that of those who are the objects of the benefit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:93
verses.text: "For he is reproved by all," saith he, "he is judged by all; and thus are the secrets of his heart made manifest; and so he will fall down on his face and worship God, declaring that God is around you indeed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:94
verses.text: Seest thou that this is not capable of two interpretations: how in the former case what is done may be doubted of, and here and there an unbeliever might ascribe it to madness? whereas here there will be no such thing, but he will both wonder and worship, first making a confession by his deeds, and then by his words also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:95
verses.text: Thus also Nebuchadnezzar worshipped God, saying, "Of a truth, your God, He is the God that revealeth secrets, seeing thou couldest reveal this secret".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:96
verses.text: (Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:97
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:98
verses.text: ) Seest thou the might of prophecy, how it changed that savage one and brought him under instruction and introduced him to faith?   Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:99
verses.text: "What is it then, brethren? When ye come together, each one hath a psalm, hath a teaching, hath a tongue, hath a revelation, hath an interpretation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:100
verses.text: Let all things be done unto edifying".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:101
verses.text: Seest thou the foundation and the rule of Christianity? how, as it is the artificer's work to build, so it is the Christian's to profit his neighbors in all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:102
verses.text: But since he had vehemently run down the gift; lest it might seem to be superfluous, for with a view to pull down their pride and no more, he did this:—again he reckons it with the other gifts, saying, "hath a psalm, hath a teaching, hath a tongue".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:103
verses.text: For of old they used also to make psalms by a gift and to teach by a gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:104
verses.text: Nevertheless, "let all these look to one thing," saith he, "the correction of their neighbor: let nothing be done at random.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:105
verses.text: For if thou comest not to edify thy brother, why dost thou come here at all? In fact, I do not make much account of the difference of the gifts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:106
verses.text: One thing concerns me, one thing is my desire, to do all things "unto edifying".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:107
verses.text: Thus also he that hath the lesser gift will outrun him that hath the greater, if this be not wanting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:108
verses.text: Yea, therefore are the gifts bestowed, that each might be edified; since unless this take place, the gift will rather turn to the condemnation of the receiver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:109
verses.text: For what, tell me, is the use of prophesying? What is the use of raising the dead, when there is none who profits by it? But if this be the end of the gifts, and if it be possible to effect it in another way without gifts, boast not thyself on the score of the signs, nor do thou bewail thyself to whom the gifts are denied.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:110
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:111
verses.text: "And if any man speaketh in a tongue, let it be by two, or at the most by three, and that in turn; and let one interpret".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:112
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:113
verses.text: "But if there be no interpreter, let him keep silence in the Church; and let him speak to himself, and to God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:114
verses.text: What sayest thou, tell me? Having spoken so much of tongues, that the gift is a thing unprofitable, a thing superfluous, if it have no interpreter, dost thou command again to speak with tongues? I do not command, saith he, neither do I forbid; as when he saith, "if any of them that believe not bid you to a feast and ye be disposed to go," he saith it not laying down a law for them to go, but not hindering them: so likewise here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:115
verses.text: "And let him speak to himself and to God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:116
verses.text: If he endure not to be silent, saith he, but is so ambitious and vain-glorious, "let him speak by himself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:117
verses.text: And thus, by the very fact of so permitting, he greatly checked and put them to shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:118
verses.text: Which he doth also elsewhere, discoursing of converse with a wife and saying, "But this I say because of your incontinency".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:119
verses.text: But not so did he speak, when he was discoursing of prophecy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:120
verses.text: How then? In a tone of command and legislation: "Let the prophets speak, two or three".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:121
verses.text: And he no where here seeks the interpreter, nor doth he stop the mouth of him that prophesies as under the former head, saying, "If there be no interpreter, let him keep silence;" because in fact he who speaks in a tongue is not sufficient of himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:122
verses.text: Wherefore if any hath both gifts, let him speak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:123
verses.text: But if he hath not, yet wish to speak, let him do so with the interpreter's aid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:124
verses.text: For the prophet is an interpreter, but of God; whereas thou art of man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:125
verses.text: "But if there be no interpreter, let him keep silence:" for nothing ought to be done superfluously, nothing for ambition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:126
verses.text: Only "let him speak to himself and to God;" i-e:, mentally, or quietly and without noise: at least, if he will speak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:127
verses.text: For this is surely not the tone of one making a law, but it may be of one who shames them more even by his permission; as when he saith, "but if any hunger, let him eat at home:" and seeming to give permission, he touches them hereby the more sharply.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:128
verses.text: "For ye come not together for this purpose," saith he, "that ye may show that ye have a gift, but that ye may edify the hearers;" which also he before said, "Let all things be done unto edifying".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:129
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:130
verses.text: "Let the prophets speak by two or three, and let the others discern".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:131
verses.text: No where hath he added, "at the most," as in the case of the tongues.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:132
verses.text: And how is this, one saith? For he makes out that neither is prophesy sufficient in itself, if at least he permitteth the judgment to others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:133
verses.text: Nay, surely it is quite sufficient; and this is why he did not stop the mouth of the prophet, as of the other, when there is no interpreter; nor, as in his case he said, "if there be no interpreter let him keep silence," so also in the case of the prophet, "if there be none to discern, let him not prophesy;" but he only secured the hearer; since for the satisfaction of the hearers he said this, that no diviner might throw himself in among them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:134
verses.text: For of this also at the beginning he bade them beware, when he introduced a distinction between divination and prophecy, and now he bids them discriminate and spy out the matter, so that no Satanic teacher might privily enter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:135
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:136
verses.text: "But if a revelation be made to another sitting by, let the first keep silence".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:137
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:138
verses.text: "For ye all can prophesy one by one, that all may learn, and all may be comforted".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:139
verses.text: What may this be which is spoken? "If when thou prophesiest," saith he, "and art speaking, the spirit of another stir him up, be silent thenceforth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:140
verses.text: For that which he said in the case of the tongues, this also here he requires, that it should be done "in turn," only in a diviner way here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:141
verses.text: For he made not use of the very expression, "in turn?" but "if a revelation be made to another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:142
verses.text: Since what need was there further, that when the second was moved to prophesy the first should speak? Ought they then both? Nay, this were profane and would produce confusion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:143
verses.text: Ought the first? This too were out of place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:144
verses.text: For to this end when the one was speaking, the Spirit moved the other, in order that he too might say somewhat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:145
verses.text: So then, comforting him that had been silenced, he saith, "For ye all can prophesy one by one, that all may learn, and all may be comforted".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:146
verses.text: Seest thou how again he states the reason wherefore he doeth all things? For if him that speaks with tongues he altogether forbid to speak, when he hath not an interpreter, because of the unprofitableness; reasonably also he bids restrain prophecy, if it have not this quality, but createth confusion and disturbance and unseasonable tumult.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:147
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:148
verses.text: "And the spirits of the prophets are subject to the prophets".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:149
verses.text: Seest thou how he put him to shame earnestly and fearfully? For that the man might not strive nor be factious, he signifies that the gift itself was under subjection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:150
verses.text: For by "spirit" here, he means its actual working.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:151
verses.text: But if the spirit be subject, much more thou its possessor canst not justly be contentious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:152
verses.text: Then he signifies that this is pleasing also to God, subjoining and saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:153
verses.text: "For God is not a God of confusion, but of peace, as I teach in all the Churches of the saints".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:154
verses.text: Seest thou by how many reasons he leads him to silence and soothes him, in the act of giving way to the other? By one thing and that the chief, that he was not shut up by such a proceeding; "for ye all can prophesy," saith he, "one by one".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:155
verses.text: By a second, that this seems good to the Spirit Himself; "for the spirits of the prophets are subject to the prophets".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:156
verses.text: Besides these, that this is according to the mind of God; "for God," saith he, "is not a God of confusion, but of peace:" and by a fourth, that in every part of the world this custom prevails, and no strange thing is enjoined upon them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:157
verses.text: For thus, saith he, "I teach in all the Churches of the saints".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:158
verses.text: What now can be more awful than these things? For in truth the Church was a heaven then, the Spirit governing all things, and moving each one of the rulers and making him inspired.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:159
verses.text: But now we retain only the symbols of those gifts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:160
verses.text: For now also we speak two or three, and in turn, and when one is silent, another begins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:161
verses.text: But these are only signs and memorials of those things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:162
verses.text: Wherefore when we begin to speak, the people respond, "with thy Spirit," indicating that of old they thus used to speak, not of their own wisdom, but moved by the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:163
verses.text: But not so now: (I speak of mine own case so far.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:164
verses.text: ) But the present Church is like a woman who hath fallen from her former prosperous days, and in many respects retains the symbols only of that ancient prosperity; displaying indeed the repositories and caskets of her golden ornaments, but bereft of her wealth: such an one doth the present Church resemble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:165
verses.text: And I say not this in respect of gifts: for it were nothing marvelous if it were this only: but in respect also of life and virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:166
verses.text: Thus the list of her widows, and the choir of her virgins, then gave great ornament to the churches: but now she is made desolate and void, and the tokens only remain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:167
verses.text: There are indeed widows now, there are also virgins; but they retain not that adornment which women should have who prepare themselves for such wrestlings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:168
verses.text: For the special distinction of the virgin is the caring for the things of God alone, and the waiting on Him without distraction: and the widow's mark too should be not so much the not engaging in a second marriage, as the other things, charity to the poor, hospitality, continuing instant in prayers, all those other things, which Paul writing to Timothy requires with great exactness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:169
verses.text: One may see also the married women exhibiting among us great seemliness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:170
verses.text: But this is not the only thing required, but rather that sedulous attention to the needy, through which those women of old shone out most brightly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:171
verses.text: Not as the generality now-a-days.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:172
verses.text: For then instead of gold they were clothed with the fair array of almsgiving: but now, having left off this, they are decked out on every side with cords of gold woven of the chain of their sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:173
verses.text: Shall I speak of another repository too emptied of its hereditary splendor? They all met together in old time and sang psalms in common.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:174
verses.text: This we do also now: but then among all was there one soul and one heart: but now not in one single soul can one see that unanimity, rather great is the warfare every where.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:175
verses.text: "Peace," even now, "to all," he that presides in the Church prays for, entering as it were into his Father's house: but of this peace the name is frequent, but the reality no where.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:176
verses.text: Then the very houses were churches: but now the church itself is a house, or rather worse than any house.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:177
verses.text: For in a house one may see much good order: since both the mistress of the house is seated on her chair with all seemliness, and the maidens weave in silence, and each of the domestics hath his appointed task in hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:178
verses.text: But here great is the tumult, great the confusion, and our assemblies differ in nothing from a vintner's shop, so loud is the laughter, so great the disturbance; as in baths, as in markets, the cry and tumult is universal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:179
verses.text: And these things are here only: since elsewhere it is not permitted even to address one's neighbor in the church, not even if one have received back a long absent friend, but these things are done without, and very properly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:180
verses.text: For the church is no barber's or perfumer's shop, nor any other merchant's warehouse in the market-place, but a place of angels, a place of archangels, a palace of God, heaven itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:181
verses.text: As therefore if one had parted the heaven and had brought thee in thither, though thou shouldest see thy father or thy brother, thou wouldest not venture to speak; so neither here ought one to utter any other sound but these which are spiritual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:182
verses.text: For, in truth, the things in this place are also a heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:183
verses.text: And if thou believest not, look to this table, call to mind for Whose sake it is set, and why: consider Who it is that is coming forth here; tremble with awe even before the time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:184
verses.text: For so, when one sees the throne only of a king, in heart he rises up, expecting the king's coming forth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:185
verses.text: And do thou accordingly thrill with awe even before that thrilling moment: raise up thyself, and before thou seest the veils drawn aside and the choir of angels marching forth, ascend thou to the very heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:186
verses.text: But the uninitiated knows not these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:187
verses.text: Well then, it is necessary with a view to him also to introduce other topics.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:188
verses.text: For neither towards him shall we want reasons able to stir him up thoroughly and cause him to soar.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:189
verses.text: Thou then who knowest not these things, when thou shalt hear the prophet saying, "Thus saith the Lord," quit the earth, ascend thou also unto heaven, consider who it is that by him discourses with thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:190
verses.text: But as things are, for a buffoon who is moving laughter or for a whorish and abandoned woman, so vast an assemblage of spectators is set, listening in entire quietness to what is spoken, and this when none commands silence; and there is neither tumult, nor cry, nor any the least noise: but when God is speaking from heaven on subjects so awful, we behave ourselves more impudently than dogs, and even to the harlot women we pay greater respect than to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:191
verses.text: Doth it make your flesh creep to be told of these things? Nay then, much rather let it creep when ye do them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:192
verses.text: That which Paul said of them that despised the poor and feasted alone, "What, have ye not houses to eat and to drink in? or despise ye the Church of God, and shame them that have not?" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:193
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:194
verses.text: )—the same allow me also to say of those who make a disturbance and hold conversations in this place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:195
verses.text: "What? have ye not houses to trifle in? or despise ye the Church of God, and corrupt those even who would be modest and quiet?" "But it is sweet and pleasant for you to converse with your friends".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:196
verses.text: I do not forbid this, but let it be done in the house, in the market, in the baths.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:197
verses.text: For the church is not a place of conversation, but of teaching.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:198
verses.text: But now it differs not from the market; nay, if it be not too bold a word, haply, not even from the stage; in such sort do the women who assemble here adorn themselves more wantonly than the unchaste who are to be found there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:199
verses.text: Accordingly we see that even hither many profligates are enticed by them; and if any one is trying or intending to corrupt a woman, there is no place, I suppose, that seems to him more suitable than the church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:200
verses.text: And if anything be to be sold or bought, the church appears more convenient than the market.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:201
verses.text: For on such subjects also there is more talk here than in the shops themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:202
verses.text: Or if any wish to say or to hear any scandal, you will find that this too is to be had here more than in the forum without.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:203
verses.text: And if you wish to hear any thing of political matters, or the affairs of private families, or the camp, go not to the judgment-hall, nor sit in the apothecary's shop; for here, here I say are those who report all these things more accurately; and our assemblies are any thing rather than a church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:204
verses.text: Can it be that I have touched you to the quick? I for my part think not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:205
verses.text: For while ye continue in the same practices, how am I to know that you are touched by what hath been said? Therefore I must needs handle the same topics again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:206
verses.text: Are these things then to be endured? Are these things to be borne? We weary and distract ourselves every day that ye may not depart without having learned something useful: and none of you go away at all the better, but rather injured the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:207
verses.text: Yea, and "ye come together unto judgment," having no longer any cloak for your sin, and ye thrust out the more modest, disturbing them with your fooleries on every side.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:208
verses.text: But what do the multitude say? "I do not hear what is read," saith one, "nor do I know what the words are which are spoken".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:209
verses.text: Because thou makest a tumult and confusion, because thou comest not with a reverent soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:210
verses.text: What sayest thou? "I know not what things are said".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:211
verses.text: Well then, for this very reason oughtest thou to give heed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:212
verses.text: But if not even the obscurity stir up thy soul, much more if things were clear wouldest thou hurry them by.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:213
verses.text: Yea, this is the reason why neither all things are clear, lest thou shouldest indulge indolence; nor obscure, lest thou shouldest be in despair.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:214
verses.text: And whereas that eunuch and barbarian (Acts viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:215
verses.text: ) said none of these things, but surrounded as he was with a crowd of so important affairs and on his journey, had a book in his hands and was reading: dost thou, both abounding in teachers, and having others to read to thee privately, allege to me thine excuses and pretexts? Knowest thou not what is said? Why then pray that thou mayest learn: but sure it is impossible to be ignorant of all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:216
verses.text: For many things are of themselves evident and clear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:217
verses.text: And further, even if thou be ignorant of all, even so oughtest thou to be quiet, not to put out them that are attentive; that God, accepting thy quietness and thy reverence, may make the obscure things also plain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:218
verses.text: But canst thou not be silent? Well then, go out, not to become a mischief to others also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:219
verses.text: For in truth there ought to be but one voice in the church always, even as there is but one body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:220
verses.text: Therefore both he that reads utters his voice alone, and the Bishop himself is content to sit in silence; and he who chants chants alone; and though all utter the response, the voice is wafted as from one mouth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:221
verses.text: And he that pronounces a homily pronounces it alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:222
verses.text: But when there are many conversing on many and diverse subjects, why do we disturb you for no good? since surely unless ye thought that we are but disturbing you for no good, ye would not in the midst of our speech on such high matters, discourse on things of no consequence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:223
verses.text: Therefore not in your conduct only, but in your very estimation of things, there is great perversion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:224
verses.text: And ye gape after superfluities, and leaving the truth pursue all sorts of shadows and dreams.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:225
verses.text: Are not all present things a shadow and dreams, and worse than a shadow? For both before they appear, they fly away; and before they are flown, the trouble they give is much, and more than the pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:226
verses.text: Let one acquire in this world and bury in the earth ever such abundance of wealth, yet when the night is past, naked he shall depart hence, and no wonder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:227
verses.text: Since they too who are rich but in a dream, on rising from their couch have nothing of what they seemed to have while sleeping.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:228
verses.text: So also are the greedy of gain: or rather not so, but in a much worse condition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:229
verses.text: For he that dreams of being rich, neither hath the money which he fancied he had, nor is any other mischief found to have accrued to him from this phantasy when he arises, but this man is both deprived of his riches, and hath also to depart, filled with the sins which arise out of them; and in his wealth having but enjoyed a phantasy, the evils resulting from his wealth he sees not in fancy any more, but in the very truth of things; and his pleasure was in dreams, but the punishment ensuing on his pleasure turns out no more a dream, but is matter of actual experience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:230
verses.text: Yea rather, even before that punishment, even here he pays the heaviest penalty, in the very collecting of his wealth wearing into himself innumerable sadnesses, anxieties, accusations, calumnies, tumults, perturbations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:231
verses.text: In order therefore that we may be delivered both from the dreams and from the evils that are not in dreams, instead of covetousness let us choose almsgiving, instead of rapine, mercy to mankind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 35:232
verses.text: For thus we shall obtain the good things both present and to come, through the grace and mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom, to the Father, with the Holy Ghost, be glory, power, honor, now and ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:1
verses.text: Homily XXXVII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:3
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:4
verses.text: Let your women keep silence in the churches: for it is not permitted unto them to speak; but let them be in subjection, as also saith the law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:5
verses.text: Having abated the disturbance both from the tongues and from the prophesyings; and having made a law to prevent confusion, that they who speak with tongues should do this in turn, and that they who prophesy should be silent when another begins; he next in course proceeds to the disorder which arose from the women, cutting off their unseasonable boldness of speech: and that very opportunely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:6
verses.text: For if to them that have the gifts it is not permitted to speak inconsiderately, nor when they will, and this, though they be moved by the Spirit; much less to those women who prate idly and to no purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:7
verses.text: Therefore he represses their babbling with much authority, and taking the law along with him, thus he sews up their mouths; not simply exhorting here or giving counsel, but even laying his commands on them vehemently, by the recitation of an ancient law on that subject.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:8
verses.text: For having said, "Let your women keep silence in the churches;" and "it is not permitted unto them to speak, but let them be in subjection;" he added, "as also saith the law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:9
verses.text: And where doth the law say this? "Thy desire shall be to thy husband, and he shall rule over thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:10
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:11
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:12
verses.text: ) Seest thou the wisdom of Paul, what kind of testimony he adduced, one that not only enjoins on them silence, but silence too with fear; and with as great fear as that wherewith a maid servant ought to keep herself quiet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:13
verses.text: Wherefore also having himself said, "it is not permitted unto them to speak," he added not, "but to be silent," but instead of "to be silent," he set down what is more, to wit, "the being in subjection".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:14
verses.text: And if this be so in respect of husbands, much more in respect of teachers, and fathers, and the general assembly of the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:15
verses.text: "But if they are not even to speak," saith one, "nor ask a question, to what end are they to be present?" That they may hear what they ought; but the points which are questioned let them learn at home from their husbands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:16
verses.text: Wherefore also he added,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:17
verses.text: "And if they would learn any thing, let them ask their own husbands at home".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:18
verses.text: Thus, "not only, as it seems, are they not allowed to speak," saith he, "at random, but not even to ask any question in the church".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:19
verses.text: Now if they ought not to ask questions, much more is their speaking at pleasure contrary to law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:20
verses.text: And what may be the cause of his setting them under so great subjection? Because the woman is in some sort a weaker being and easily carried away and light minded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:21
verses.text: Here you see why he set over them their husbands as teachers, for the benefit of both.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:22
verses.text: For so he both rendered the women orderly, and the husbands he made anxious, as having to deliver to their wives very exactly what they heard.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:23
verses.text: Further, because they supposed this to be an ornament to them, I mean their speaking in public; again he brings round the discourse to the opposite point, saying, "For it is shameful for a woman to speak in the church".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:24
verses.text: That is, first he made this out from the law of God, then from common reason and our received custom; even when he was discoursing with the women about long hair, he said, "Doth not even nature herself teach you?" (c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:25
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:26
verses.text: ) And everywhere thou mayest find this to be his manner, not only from the divine Scriptures, but also from the common custom, to put them to shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:27
verses.text: But besides these things, he also shames them by consideration of what all agreed on, and what was every where prescribed; which topic also here he hath set down, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:28
verses.text: "What? was it from you that the word of God went forth? or came it unto you alone?"  Thus he brings in the other Churches also as holding this law, both abating the disturbance by consideration of the novelty of the thing, and by the general voice making his saying acceptable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:29
verses.text: Wherefore also elsewhere he said, "Who shall put you in remembrance of my ways which be in Christ, even as I teach everywhere in all the Churches".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:30
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:31
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:32
verses.text: ) And again, "God is not a God of confusion, but of peace, as in all the Churches of the saints".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:34
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:35
verses.text: ) And here, "What? was it from you that the word of God went forth? or came it unto you alone?" i-e:, "neither first, nor alone are ye believers, but the whole world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:36
verses.text: Which also writing to the Colossians he said, "even as it is bearing fruit and increasing in all the world," (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:37
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:38
verses.text: ) speaking of the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:39
verses.text: But he turns it also at another time to the encouragement of his hearers; as when he saith that theirs were the first fruits, and were manifest unto all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:40
verses.text: Thus, writing to the Thessalonians he said, "For from you hath sounded forth the word of God," and, "in every place your faith to God-ward is gone forth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:41
verses.text: ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:42
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:43
verses.text: ) And again to the Romans, "Your faith is proclaimed throughout the whole world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:44
verses.text: For both are apt to shame and stir up, as well the being commended of others, as that they have others partakers in their judgment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:45
verses.text: Wherefore also here he saith; "What? was it from you that the word of God went forth? or came it unto you only?" "For neither can ye say this," saith he; "we were made teachers to the rest, and it cannot be right for us to learn of others;" nor, "the faith remained in this place only, and no precedents from other quarters ought to be received".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:46
verses.text: Seest thou by how many arguments he put them to shame? He introduced the law, he signified the shamefulness of the thing, he brought forward the other Churches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:47
verses.text: Next, what is strongest of all he puts last, saying, "God ordains these things even at this time by me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:48
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:49
verses.text: Thus: "if any man thinketh himself to be a prophet, or spiritual, let him take knowledge of the things which I write unto you that they are the commandments of the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:50
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:51
verses.text: "But if any man is ignorant, let him be ignorant".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:52
verses.text: And wherefore did he add this? Intimating that he is not using violence nor contention, which is a sign of them who wish not to set up their own things, but aim at what is profitable to others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:53
verses.text: Wherefore also in another place he saith, "But if any man seemeth to be contentious, we have no such custom".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:54
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:55
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:56
verses.text: ) But he doth not this everywhere, but only where the offences are not very great, and then rather as putting them to shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:57
verses.text: Since when he discourses of other sins, he speaks not thus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:58
verses.text: But how? "Be not deceived: neither fornicators, nor effeminate, shall inherit the kingdom of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:59
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:60
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:62
verses.text: ) And again, "Behold, I Paul say unto you, that if ye receive circumcision, Christ will profit you nothing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:63
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:64
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:65
verses.text: ) But here, since his discourse was of silence, he doth not very keenly inveigh against them, by this very thing attracting them the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:66
verses.text: Then, as he is ever wont to do, unto the former subject whence he digressed to say these things, he brings back his discourse as follows:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:67
verses.text: "Wherefore, brethren, desire earnestly to prophesy, and forbid not to speak with tongues".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:68
verses.text: For this too is his wont, not only to work out what is before him, but also starting from that to set right whatever seems to him in any way akin to it, and again to return to the former, so as not to appear to wander from the subject.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:69
verses.text: For so when he was discoursing of their concord in their banquets, he digressed to their Communion in the Mysteries, and having thence put them to shame, he returns again to the former, saying, "Wherefore, when ye come together to eat, wait one for another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:70
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:71
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:72
verses.text: )  And here, accordingly, having discoursed of good order in their gifts, and of its being a duty neither to faint in the lesser, nor to be puffed up on account of the greater; then having made an excursion from thence to the sobriety becoming women and having established it, he returns again to his subject, saying, "Wherefore, brethren, desire earnestly to prophesy, and forbid not to speak with tongues".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:73
verses.text: Seest thou how to the end he preserved the difference of these? And how he signifies that the one is very necessary, the other not so? Wherefore of the one he saith, "desire earnestly," but of the other, "forbid not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:74
verses.text: Then, as in brief summary, setting all things right, he adds the words,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:75
verses.text: "Let all things be done decently and in order".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:76
verses.text: Again giving a blow to them who chose to behave themselves unseemly without cause, and to incur the imputation of madness; and who keep not their proper rank.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:77
verses.text: For nothing doth so build up as good order, as peace, as love; even as their contraries tend to pull down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:78
verses.text: And not only in things spiritual, but also in all others one may observe this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:79
verses.text: Thus whether it be in a dance, or a ship, or in a chariot, or a camp, if thou shouldest confound the order, and casting the greater out of their proper place, shouldest bring in the lesser into their rank, thou destroyest all, and thus things are turned upside down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:80
verses.text: Neither let us then destroy our order, nor place the head below and the feet above: now this is done when we cast down right reason, and set our lusts, passions, and pleasure, over the rational part: whence violent are the billows, and great the confusion, and intolerable the tempest, all things being wrapt in darkness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:81
verses.text: And, if thou wilt, let us first examine the unseemliness which arises herefrom, and then the loss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:82
verses.text: How then may this be clear to us, and thoroughly known? Let us bring forward a man in that frame of mind; enamoured of a harlot and overcome by a dishonorable passion; and then we shall see the mockery which this comes to.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:83
verses.text: For what can be baser than a man watching the doors before the harlots' chambers, and beaten by a whorish woman, and weeping, and lamenting, and turning his glory into shame? And if thou wilt also see the loss, call to mind, I pray, the expenditure of money, the extreme risks, the contests with rival lovers, the wounds, the stripes received in such affrays.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:84
verses.text: Such also are they who are holden by the lust of wealth; or rather they behave themselves more unseemly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:85
verses.text: For whereas these are wholly occupied about one person; the covetous busy themselves about all men's substance alike, both poor and rich, and long for things that are not; a thing which above all denotes the wildness of their passion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:86
verses.text: For they say not, "I would fain have the substance of such a person or of such another," only, but they want the very mountains to be gold, and the houses and all that they see; and they go forth into another world, and this passion they feel to a boundless degree, and at no point cease from their lusting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:87
verses.text: What discourse can set before us the tempest of those thoughts, the waves, the darkness? And where the waves and tempest are so great, what pleasure can there be? There is not any; but tumult, and anguish, and black clouds which instead of rain bring great sorrow of heart: the kind of thing which is wont to happen in the case of those who are enamoured of beauty not their own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:88
verses.text: Wherefore they who have no passionate love at all are in more pleasure than any lovers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:89
verses.text: This however no man would gainsay.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:90
verses.text: But to me even he who loves, but restrains his passion, seems to live more pleasurably than he who continually enjoys his mistress.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:91
verses.text: For though the proof be rather difficult, nevertheless even at that disadvantage the argument must be ventured on: the cause of the increased difficulty not being the nature of the thing, but because of the want of meet hearers for this high morality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:92
verses.text: Thus: whether is it pleasanter, tell me, to the lover, to be despised by his beloved, or to be honored, and to look down upon her? Evidently the latter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:93
verses.text: Whom then, tell me, will the harlot value more? Him that is a slave to her and is already led captive at her will, or him that is above her nets and soareth higher than her arrows? Every one must see, the latter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:94
verses.text: And about whom will she take more thought, the fallen, or him that is not yet so? Him that is not yet so, of course.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:95
verses.text: And which will be more an object of desire, he who is subdued, or he who is not yet taken? He who up to this time is not yet taken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:96
verses.text: And if ye disbelieve it, I will produce my proof from what takes place within yourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:97
verses.text: As thus: of which woman would a man be more enamored; one that easily submits and gives herself up to him, or one that denies, and gives him trouble? Evidently of this last; since hereby the longing is more vehemently kindled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:98
verses.text: Of course then in the woman's case also exactly the same thing will happen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:99
verses.text: And him will they honor and admire more who looks down upon them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:100
verses.text: But if this be true, so likewise is the other, that he enjoys greater pleasure who is more honored and beloved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:101
verses.text: Since the general too lets alone the city that hath been once taken, but that which stands out and maintains the struggle he besets with all diligence: and the hunter, when the animal is caught, keeps it shut up in darkness as the harlot doth her lover, but pursues that which flies from him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:102
verses.text: But I shall be told, "the one enjoys his desire, the other not so".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:103
verses.text: But freedom from disgrace, and from being a slave under her tyrannical commands, the not being led and dragged about by her as a drudge, beaten, spit upon, pitched head foremost; dost thou consider this to be a small pleasure, tell me? Nay, if one would accurately examine these things, and were able to gather into one their insults, complaints, everlasting quarrels, some arising from their tempers, others from their wantonness, their enmities, and all the rest, such as they only that feel them know;—he will find that there is no war but hath more truces than this wretched life of theirs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:104
verses.text: What pleasure then meanest thou, tell me? The temporary and brief enjoyment of intercourse? But this speedily doth strife overtake, and storms, and rage, and the same madness again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:105
verses.text: And these things have been said by us, as one would speak discoursing with licentious youths, who do not very patiently submit to hear our discourses of the kingdom and of hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:106
verses.text: And now that we are bringing forward these topics also, it is not even possible to say how great is the pleasure of the continent; if one frame in one's own mind his crowns, his rewards, his converse with the angels, the proclaiming of him before the world, his boldness, those blessed and immortal hopes of his.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:107
verses.text: "But intercourse hath a certain pleasure:" for this they are continually repeating: "while the continent continually suffers pain contending with the tyranny of nature".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:108
verses.text: Nay, but one shall find just the contrary result.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:109
verses.text: For this violence and tumult is present with the unchaste rather: there being in his body a violent tempest, and no sea in a storm so grievously vexed as he; never withstanding his passion, but ever receiving blows from it; as the possessed and they that are continually rent in the midst by evil spirits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:110
verses.text: Whereas the temperate like a noble champion continually giving blows to it, reaps the best of pleasures, and sweeter than ten thousand of that kind; and this victory and his good conscience, and those illustrous trophies, are ornaments for him continually to deck himself withal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:111
verses.text: As to the other, if after his intercourse he hath a little respite, it must be counted nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:112
verses.text: For again the storm comes on, and again there are waves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:113
verses.text: But he that commands himself doth not suffer this tumult to lay hold of him at all, nor the sea to arise, nor the wild beast to roar.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:114
verses.text: And even if he endure some violence in restraining such an impulse, yet so doth the other also, continually receiving blows and stabs, and unable to endure the sting: and it is like as if there were a wild horse furious and struggling, and one should check with the bridle, and hold him in with all skill: while another giving him the rein to escape the trouble, were dragged along by him and carried hither and thither.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:115
verses.text: If I have spoken these things more plainly than is becoming, let no man blame me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:116
verses.text: For I desire not to make a brave show by a gravity of words, but to make my hearers grave.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:117
verses.text: Therefore also the prophets spare no such words, wishing to extirpate the licentiousness of the Jews, but do even more nakedly inveigh against them than we do now in the things we have spoken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:118
verses.text: For so a physician wishing to remove an ulcer doth not consider how he may keep his hands clean, but how he may rid the patient of the ulcer; and he who would raise on high the lowly, first makes himself lowly; and he who seeks to slay the conspirator stains himself with blood as well as the other, and this makes him the more brilliant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:119
verses.text: Since if one were to see a soldier returning from the war, stained with gore and blood and brains, he will not loathe him nor turn from him on this account, but will even admire him the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:120
verses.text: So then let us do, when we see any one returning, covered with blood after the slaughter of his evil desire, let us the more admire him and become partakers of his battle and victory, and say to those who indulge this wild love, "show us the pleasure you derive from lust; for the continent hath that which comes of his victory, but thou none from any quarter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:121
verses.text: But if ye should mention that which is connected with the criminal act, yet the other is more manifest and satisfactory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:122
verses.text: For thou hast from the enjoyment something brief and hardly apparent; but he from his conscience, hath both a greater and an enduring and a sweeter joy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:123
verses.text: The company of a woman hath surely no such power as self-command, to preserve the soul undisturbed and give it wings".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:124
verses.text: Well then: the continent man, as I said, thus evidently makes his pleasure out to us: but in thy case I see the dejection arising from defeat, but the pleasure, desiring to see, I find not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:125
verses.text: For what dost thou consider the moment of pleasure? That before the criminal action? Nay, it is not so, for it is a time of madness and delirium and frenzy: to grind the teeth and be beside one's self is not any pleasure: and if it were pleasure, it would not produce the same effects on you which they who are in pain endure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:126
verses.text: For they who strike with their fists and are stricken grind their teeth, and women in travail distracted with pains do the same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:127
verses.text: So that this is no pleasure, but frenzy rather, and confusion, and tumult.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:128
verses.text: Shall we say then, the time after the action? Nay, neither is this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:129
verses.text: For neither could we say that a woman just delivered is in pleasure, but in release from certain pains.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:130
verses.text: But this is by no means pleasure, but weakness rather and falling away: and there is a great difference between these two.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:131
verses.text: What then is the time of pleasure, tell me? There is none.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:132
verses.text: But if there be any, it is so brief as not even to be apparent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:133
verses.text: At least, having zealously sought in a great many ways to detect and apprehend it, we have not been able.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:134
verses.text: But the time of the chaste man's pleasure is not such, rather it is wider and evident to all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:135
verses.text: Or rather, all his life is in pleasure, his conscience crowned, the waves laid, no disturbance from any quarter arising within him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 36:136
verses.text: Since then this man's life is more in pleasure, while the life spent in love of pleasure is in dejection and disquiets; let us flee from licentiousness, let us keep hold on continence, that we may also obtain the good things to come, through the grace and mercy, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:1
verses.text: Homily XXXVIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:3
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:4
verses.text: ,  Now I make known unto you, brethren, the gospel which I preached unto you, which also ye received, wherein also ye stand; by which also ye are saved: in what words I preached it unto you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:5
verses.text: Having finished the discourse of spiritual gifts, he passes to that which is of all most necessary, the subject of the resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:6
verses.text: For in this too they were greatly unsound.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:7
verses.text: And as in men's bodies, when the fever lays actual hold of their solid parts, I mean the nerves and the veins and the primary elements, the mischief becomes incurable unless it receive much attention; just so at that time also it was like to happen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:8
verses.text: Since to the very elements of godliness the mischief was proceeding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:9
verses.text: Wherefore also Paul uses great earnestness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:10
verses.text: For not of morals was his discourse henceforth nor about one man's being a fornicator, another covetous, and another having his head covered; but about the very sum of all good things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:11
verses.text: For touching the resurrection itself they were at variance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:12
verses.text: Because this being all our hope, against this point did the devil make a vehement stand, and at one time he was wholly subverting it, at another his word was that it was "past already;" which also Paul writing to Timothy called a gangrene, I mean, this wicked doctrine, and those that brought it in he branded, saying, "Of whom is Hymenoeus and Philetus, who concerning the truth have erred, saying that the resurrection is past already, and overthrow the faith of some".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:13
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:14
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:16
verses.text: ) At one time then they said thus, but at another that the body rises not again but the purification of the soul is the resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:17
verses.text: But these things that wicked demon persuaded them to say, not wishing to overturn the resurrection only, but also to show that all the things done for our sakes are a fable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:18
verses.text: For if they were persuaded that there is no resurrection of bodies, he would have gradually persuaded them that neither was Christ raised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:19
verses.text: And thereupon he would introduce also this in due course, that He had not come nor had done what He did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:20
verses.text: For such is the craft of the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:21
verses.text: Wherefore also Paul calls it "cunning craftiness," because he doth not straightway signify what he intends to effect, for fear of being detected, but dressing himself up in a mask of one kind, he fabricates arts of another kind: and like a crafty enemy attacking a city with walls, he secretly undermines it from below: so as thereby to be hardly guarded against and to succeed in his endeavors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:22
verses.text: Therefore such snares on his part being continually detected, and these his crafty ambushes hunted out by this admirable and mighty man, he said, "For we are not ignorant of his devices".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:23
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:24
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:25
verses.text: ) So also here he unfolds his whole guile and points out all his stratagems, and whatsoever he would fain effect, Paul puts before us, with much exactness going over all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:26
verses.text: Yea, and therefore he put this head after the rest, both because it was extremely necessary and because it involves the whole of our condition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:27
verses.text: And observe his consideration: how first having secured his own, he then proceeds even beyond in his discourse, and them that are without he doth abundantly reduce to silence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:28
verses.text: Now he secures his own, not by reasonings, but by things which had already happened and which themselves had received and believed to have taken place: a thing which was most of all apt to shame them, and capable of laying hold on them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:29
verses.text: Since if they were unwilling to believe after this, it was no longer Paul but themselves they would disbelieve: which thing was a censure on those who had once for all received it and changed their minds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:30
verses.text: For this cause then he begins also from hence, implying that he needs no other witnesses to prove his speaking truth, but those very persons who were deceived.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:31
verses.text: But that what I say may become clearer, we must needs in what follows attend to the very words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:32
verses.text: What then are these? "I make known unto you, brethren," saith he, "the gospel which I preached unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:33
verses.text: Seest thou with what modesty he commences? Seest thou how from the beginning he points out that he is bringing in no new nor strange thing? For he who "maketh known" that which was already known but afterwards had fallen into oblivion, "maketh known" by recalling it into memory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:34
verses.text: And when he called them "brethren," even from hence he laid the foundation of no mean part of the proof of his assertions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:35
verses.text: For by no other cause became we "brethren," but by the dispensation of Christ according to the flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:36
verses.text: And this is just the reason why he thus called them, at the same time soothing and courting them, and likewise reminding them of their innumerable blessings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:37
verses.text: And what comes next again is demonstrative of the same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:38
verses.text: What then is this? "The gospel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:39
verses.text: For the sum of the gospels hath its original hence, from God having become man and having been crucified and having risen again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:40
verses.text: This gospel also Gabriel preached to the Virgin, this also the prophets to the world, this also the apostles all of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:41
verses.text: "Which I preached unto you, which also ye received, wherein also ye stand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:42
verses.text: By which also ye are saved, in what word I preached unto you; if ye hold it fast, except ye believed in vain".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:43
verses.text: Seest thou how he calls themselves to be witnesses of the things spoken? And he saith not, "which ye heard," but, "which ye received," demanding it of them as a kind of deposit, and showing that not in word only, but also by deeds and signs and wonders they received it, and that they should hold it safe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:44
verses.text: Next, because he was speaking of the things long past, he referred also to the present time, saying, "wherein also ye stand," taking the vantage ground of them that disavowal might be out of their power, though they wished it never so much.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:45
verses.text: And this is why at the beginning he said not, "I teach you," but, 'I make known unto you' what hath already been made manifest".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:46
verses.text: And how saith he that they who were so tossed with waves "stand?" He feigns ignorance to profit them; which also he doth in the case of the Galatians, but not in like manner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:47
verses.text: For inasmuch as he could not in that case affect ignorance, he frames his address in another way, saying, "I have confidence toward you in the Lord, that ye will be none otherwise minded".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:48
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:49
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:50
verses.text: ) He said not, "that ye were none otherwise minded," because their fault was acknowledged and evident, but he answers for the future; and yet this too was uncertain; but it was to draw them to him more effectually.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:51
verses.text: Here however he doth feign ignorance, saying, "wherein also ye stand".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:52
verses.text: Then comes the advantage; "by which also ye are saved, in what words I preached it unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:53
verses.text: "So then, this present exposition is for doctrine clearness and interpretation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:54
verses.text: For the doctrine itself ye need not," saith he, "to learn, but to be reminded of it and corrected".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:55
verses.text: And these things he saith, leaving them no room to plunge into recklessness once for all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:56
verses.text: But what is, "in what word I preached it unto you?" After what manner did I say," saith he, "that the resurrection takes place? For that there is a resurrection I would not say that ye doubt: but ye seek perhaps to obtain a clearer knowledge of that saying.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:57
verses.text: This then will I provide for you: for indeed I am well assured that ye hold the doctrine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:58
verses.text: Next, because he was directly affirming, "wherein also ye stand;" that he might not thereby make them more remiss, he alarms them again, saying, "If ye hold it fast, except ye believed in vain;" intimating that the stroke is on the chief head, and the contest for no common things but in behalf of the whole of the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:59
verses.text: And for the present he saith it with reserve, but as he goes on and waxes warm, he throws off the veil and proceeds to cry out, and say, "But if Christ hath not been raised then is our preaching vain, your faith also is vain: ye are yet in your sins:" but in the beginning not so: for thus it was expedient to proceed, gently and by degrees.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:60
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:61
verses.text: "For I delivered unto you first of all that which I also received".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:62
verses.text: Neither here doth he say, "I said unto you," nor, "I taught you," but uses the same expression again, saying, "I delivered unto you that which also I received:" nor again here doth he say, "I was taught," but, "I received:" establishing these two things; first, that one ought to introduce nothing from one's self; next, that by demonstration from his deeds they were fully persuaded, not by bare words: and by degrees while he is rendering his argument credible, he refers the whole to Christ, and signifies that nothing was of man in these doctrines.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:63
verses.text: But what is this, "For I delivered unto you first of all?" for that is his word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:64
verses.text: "In the beginning, not now".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:65
verses.text: And thus saying he brings the time for a witness, and that it were the greatest disgrace for those who had so long time been persuaded now to change their minds: and not this only, but also that the doctrine is necessary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:66
verses.text: Wherefore also it was "delivered" among "the first," and from the beginning straightway.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:67
verses.text: And what didst thou so deliver? tell me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:68
verses.text: But this he doth not say straightway, but first, "I received".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:69
verses.text: And what didst thou receive? "That Christ died for our sins".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:70
verses.text: He said not immediately that there is a resurrection of our bodies, yet this very thing in truth he doth establish, but afar off and by other topics saying that "Christ died," and laying before a kind of strong base and irrefragable foundation of the doctrine concerning the resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:71
verses.text: For neither did he simply say that "Christ died;" although even this were sufficient to declare the resurrection, but with an addition, "Christ died for our sins".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:72
verses.text: But first it is worth while to hear what those who are infected with the Manichaean doctrines say here, who are both enemies to the truth and war against their own salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:73
verses.text: What then do these allege? By death here, they say, Paul means nothing else than our being in sin; and by resurrection, our being delivered from our sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:74
verses.text: Seest thou how nothing is weaker than error? And how it is taken by its own wings, and needs not the warfare from without, but by itself it is pierced through? Consider, for instance, these men, how they too have pierced themselves through by their own statements.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:75
verses.text: Since if this be death, and Christ did not take a body, as ye suppose, and yet died, He was in sin according to you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:76
verses.text: For I indeed say that He took unto Himself a body and His death, I say, was that of the flesh; but thou denying this, wilt be compelled to affirm the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:77
verses.text: But if He was in sin, how saith He, "Which of you convinceth Me of sin?" and "The prince of this world cometh, and hath nothing in me?" (John viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:78
verses.text: ; xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:79
verses.text: ) and again, "Thus it becometh Us to fulfill all righteousness?" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:80
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:81
verses.text: ) Nay, how did He at all die for sinners, if Himself were in sin? For he who dies for sinners ought himself to be without sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:82
verses.text: Since if he himself also sin, how shall he die for other sinners? But if for others' sins He died, He died being without sin: and if being without sin He died, He died—not the death of sin; for how could He being without sin?—but the death of the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:83
verses.text: Wherefore also Paul did not simply say, "He died," but added, "for our sins:" both forcing these heretics against their will to the confession of His bodily death, and signifying also by this that before death He was without sin: for he that dies for others' sins, it followeth must himself be without sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:84
verses.text: Neither was he content with this, but added, "according to the Scriptures:" hereby both again making his argument credible, and intimating what kind of death he was speaking of: since it is the death of the body which the Scriptures everywhere proclaim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:85
verses.text: For, "they pierced My hands and My feet," (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:86
verses.text: xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:87
verses.text: ) saith He, and, "they shall look on Him Whom they pierced".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:88
verses.text: (John xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:89
verses.text: , Zech.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:90
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:91
verses.text: ) And many other instances, too not to name all one by one, partly in words and partly in types, one may see in them stored up, setting forth His slaughter in the flesh and that He was slain for our sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:92
verses.text: For, "for the sins of my people," saith one, "is He come to death:" and, "the Lord delivered Him up for our sins:" and, "He was wounded for our transgressions".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:93
verses.text: (Is.
