verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:94
verses.text: liii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:95
verses.text: ) But if thou dost not endure the Old Testament, hear John crying out and declaring both, as well His slaughter in the body as the cause of it: thus, "Behold," saith he, "the Lamb of God, Who taketh away the sin of the world:" (John i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:96
verses.text: ) and Paul saying, "For Him Who knew no sin, He made to be sin on our behalf, that we might become the righteousness of God in Him:" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:97
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:98
verses.text: ) and again, "Christ redeemed us from the curse of the law, having become a curse for us:" (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:99
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:100
verses.text: ) and again, "having put off from himself principalities and powers, He made a show of them openly, triumphing over them;" (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:101
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:102
verses.text: ) and ten thousand other sayings to show what happened at His death in the body, and because of our sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:103
verses.text: Yea, and Christ Himself saith, "for your sakes I sanctify Myself" and, "now the prince of this world hath been condemned;" showing that having no sin he was slain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:104
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:105
verses.text: "And that he was buried".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:106
verses.text: And this also confirms the former topics, for that which is buried is doubtless a body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:107
verses.text: And here he no longer adds, "according to the Scriptures".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:108
verses.text: He had wherewithal, nevertheless he adds it not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:109
verses.text: For what cause? Either because the burial was evident unto all, both then and now, or because the expression, "according to the Scriptures," is set down of both in common.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:110
verses.text: Wherefore then doth he add, "according to the Scriptures," in this place, "and that He rose on the third day according to the Scriptures," and is not content with the former clause, so spoken in common? Because this also was to most men obscure: wherefore here again he brings in "the Scriptures" by inspiration, having so conceived this thought so wise and divine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:111
verses.text: How is it then that he doth the same in regard of His death? Because in that case too, although the cross was evident unto all and in the sight of all He was stretched upon it; yet the cause was no longer equally so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:112
verses.text: The fact indeed of his death all knew, but that He suffered this for the sins of the world was no longer equally known to the multitude.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:113
verses.text: Wherefore he brings in the testimony from the Scriptures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:114
verses.text: This however hath been sufficiently proved by what we have said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:115
verses.text: But where have the Scriptures said that He was buried, and on the third day shall rise again? By the type of Jonah which also Himself alleges, saying, "As Jonah was three days and three nights in the whale's belly, so shall also the Son of Man be three days and three nights in the heart of the earth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:116
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:117
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:118
verses.text: ) By the bush in the desert.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:119
verses.text: For even as that burned, yet was not consumed, (Exod.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:120
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:121
verses.text: ) so also that body died indeed, but was not holden of death continually.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:122
verses.text: And the dragon also in Daniel shadows out this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:123
verses.text: For as the dragon having taken the food which the prophet gave, burst asunder in the midst; even so Hades having swallowed down that Body, was rent asunder, the Body of itself cutting asunder its womb and rising again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:124
verses.text: Now if thou desirest to hear also in words those things which thou hast seen in types, listen to Isaiah, saying, "His life is taken from the earth," (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:125
verses.text: liii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:127
verses.text: ) and," it pleaseth the Lord to cleanse Him from His wound…to show unto Him light:" and David before him, "Thou wilt not leave My soul to Hades, nor wilt Thou suffer Thy Holy One to see corruption".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:128
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:129
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:130
verses.text: )  Therefore Paul also sends thee on to the Scriptures, that thou mayest learn that not without cause nor at random were these things done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:131
verses.text: For how could they, when so many prophets are describing and proclaiming them beforehand? And no where doth the Scripture mean the death of sin, when it makes mention of our Lord's death, but that of the body, and a burial and resurrection of the same kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:132
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:133
verses.text: "And that He appeared to Cephas:" he names immediately the most credible of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:134
verses.text: "Then to the twelve".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:135
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:136
verses.text: "Then he appeared to above five hundred brethren at once; of whom the greater part remain until now, but some are fallen asleep".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:137
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:138
verses.text: "Then he appeared to James; then to all the Apostles".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:139
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:140
verses.text: "And last of all, as unto one born out of due time, he appeared to me also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:141
verses.text: Thus, since he had mentioned the proof from the Scriptures, he adds also that by the events, producing as witnesses of the resurrection, after the prophets, the apostles and other faithful men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:142
verses.text: Whereas if he meant that other resurrection, the deliverance from sin, it were idle for him to say, He appeared to such and such an one; for this is the argument of one who is establishing the resurrection of the body, not of one obscurely teaching deliverance from sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:143
verses.text: Wherefore neither said he once for all, "He appeared," although it were sufficient for him to do so, setting down the expression in common: but now both twice and thrice, and almost in each several case of them that had seen Him he employs it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:144
verses.text: For "He appeared," saith he, "to Cephas, He appeared to above five hundred brethren, He appeared to me also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:145
verses.text: Yet surely the Gospel saith the contrary, that He was seen of Mary first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:146
verses.text: (Mark xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:147
verses.text: ) But among men He was seen of him first who did most of all long to see Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:148
verses.text: But of what twelve apostles doth he here speak? For after He was received up, Matthias was taken into the number, not after the resurrection immediately.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:149
verses.text: But it is likely that He appeared even after He was received up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:150
verses.text: At any rate, this our apostle himself after His ascension was both called, and saw Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:151
verses.text: Therefore neither doth he set down the time, but simply and without defining recounts the appearance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:152
verses.text: For indeed it is probable that many took place; wherefore also John said, "This third time He was manifested".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:153
verses.text: (John xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:154
verses.text: )  "Then He appeared to above five hundred brethren".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:155
verses.text: Some say that "above," is above from heaven; that is, "not walking upon earth, but above and overhead He appeared to them:" adding, that it was Paul's purpose to confirm, not the resurrection only, but also the ascension.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:156
verses.text: Others say that the expression, "above five hundred," means, "more than five hundred".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:157
verses.text: "Of whom the greater part remain until now".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:158
verses.text: Thus, "though I relate events of old," saith he, "yet have I living witnesses".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:159
verses.text: "But some are fallen asleep".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:160
verses.text: He said not, "are dead," but, "are fallen asleep," by this expression also again confirming the resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:161
verses.text: "After that, He was seen of James".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:162
verses.text: I suppose, His brother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:163
verses.text: For the Lord is said to have Himself ordained him and made him Bishop in Jerusalem first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:164
verses.text: "Then to all the apostles".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:165
verses.text: For there were also other apostles, as the seventy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:166
verses.text: "And last of all he appeared unto me also, as unto one born out of due time".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:167
verses.text: This is rather an expression of modesty than any thing else.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:168
verses.text: For not because he was the least, therefore did he appear to him after the rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:169
verses.text: Since even if He did call him last, yet he appeared more illustrious than many which were before him, yea rather than all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:170
verses.text: And the five hundred brethren too were not surely better than James, because He appeared to them before him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:171
verses.text: Why did He not appear to all at the same time? That He might first sow the seeds of faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:172
verses.text: For he that saw Him first and was exactly and fully assured, told it unto the residue: then their report coming first placed the hearer in expectation of this great wonder, and made way before for the faith of sight.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:173
verses.text: Therefore neither did He appear to all together, nor in the beginning to many, but to one alone first, and him the leader of the whole company and the most faithful: since indeed there was great need of a most faithful soul to be first to receive this sight.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:174
verses.text: For those who saw him after others had seen him, and heard it from them, had in their testimony what contributed in no small degree to their own faith and tended to prepare their mind beforehand; but he who was first counted worthy to see Him, had need, as I have said, of great faith, not to be confounded by a sight so contrary to expectation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:175
verses.text: Therefore he appears to Peter first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:176
verses.text: For he that first confessed Him to be Christ was justly also counted worthy first to behold His resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:177
verses.text: And not on this account alone doth He appear to him first, but also because he had denied Him, more abundantly to comfort him and to signify that he is not despaired of, before the rest He vouchsafed him even this sight and to him first entrusted His sheep.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:178
verses.text: Therefore also He appeared to the women first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:179
verses.text: Because this sex was made inferior, therefore both in His birth and in His resurrection this first tastes of His grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:180
verses.text: But after Peter, He appears also to each at intervals, and at one time to fewer, at another to more, hereby making them witnesses and teachers of each other, and rendering His apostles trustworthy in all that they said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:181
verses.text: "And last of all, as unto one born out of due time, he appeared to me also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:182
verses.text: What mean here his expressions of humility, or wherein are they seasonable? For if he wishes to show himself worthy of credit and to enrol himself among the witnesses of the resurrection, he is doing the contrary of what he wishes: since it were meet that he exalt himself and show that he was great, which in many places he doth, the occasion calling for it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:183
verses.text: Well, the very reason why he here also speaks modestly is his being about to do this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:184
verses.text: Not straightway, however, but with his own peculiar good sense: in that having first spoken modestly and heaped up against himself many charges, he then magnifies the things concerning himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:185
verses.text: What may the reason be? That, when he comes to utter that great and lofty expression concerning himself, "I labored more abundantly than all," his discourse may be rendered more acceptable, both hereby, and by its being spoken as a consequence of what went before and not as a leading topic.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:186
verses.text: Therefore also writing to Timothy, and intending to say great things concerning himself, he first sets down his charges against himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:187
verses.text: For so all persons, when speaking in high terms of others, speak out freely and with boldness: but he that is compelled to praise himself, and especially when he also calls himself to witness, is disconcerted and blushes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:188
verses.text: Therefore also this blessed man first declares his own misery, and then utters that lofty expression.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:189
verses.text: This then he doth, partly to abate the offensiveness of speaking about himself, and partly that he might hereby recommend to their belief what he had to say afterwards.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:190
verses.text: For he that truly states what things are discreditable to him and conceals none of them, such as that he persecuted the Church, that he laid waste the faith, doth hereby cause the things that are honorable to him also to be above suspicion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:191
verses.text: And consider the exceeding greatness of his humility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:192
verses.text: For having said, "and last of all He appeared to me also," he was not content with this: "For many that are last shall be first," saith He, "and the first last".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:193
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:194
verses.text: xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:195
verses.text: ) Therefore he added, "as unto one born out of due time".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:196
verses.text: Neither did he stop here, but adds also his own judgment and with a reason, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:197
verses.text: "For I am the least of the apostles, that am not meet to be called an apostle, because I persecuted the Church of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:198
verses.text: And he said not, of the twelve alone, but also of all the other apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:199
verses.text: And all these things he spake, both as one speaking modestly and because he was really so disposed as I said, making arrangements also beforehand for what was intended to be spoken and rendering it more acceptable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:200
verses.text: For had he come forward and said, "Ye ought to believe me that Christ rose from the dead; for I saw Him and of all I am the most worthy of credit, inasmuch as I have labored more," the expression might have offended the hearers: but now by first dwelling on the humiliating topics and those which involve accusation, he both took off what might be grating in such a narrative, and prepared the way for their belief in his testimony.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:201
verses.text: On this account therefore neither doth he simply, as I said, declare himself to be the last and unworthy of the appellation of an apostle, but also states the reason, saying, "because I persecuted the Church".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:202
verses.text: And yet all those things were forgiven, but nevertheless he himself never forgot them, desiring to signify the greatness of God's favor: wherefore also he goes on to say,   Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:203
verses.text: "But by the grace of God I am what I am".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:204
verses.text: Seest thou again another excess of humility? in that the defects he imputes to himself, but of the good deeds nothing; rather he refers all to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:205
verses.text: Next, lest he might hereby render his hearer supine, he saith, "And His grace which was bestowed upon me was not found vain".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:206
verses.text: And this again with reserve: in that he said not, "I have displayed a diligence worthy of His grace," but, "it was not found vain".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:207
verses.text: "But I labored more abundantly than they all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:208
verses.text: He said not, "I was honored," but, "I labored;" and when he had perils and deaths to speak of, by the name of labor he again abates his expression.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:209
verses.text: Then again practicing his wonted humility, this also he speedily passes by and refers the whole to God, saying, "Yet not I, but the grace of God which was with me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:210
verses.text: What can be more admirable than such a soul? who having in so many ways depressed himself and uttered but one lofty word, not even this doth he call his own; on every side finding ways, both from the former things and from them that follow after, to contract this lofty expression, and that because it was of necessity that he came to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:211
verses.text: But consider how he abounds in the expressions of humility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:212
verses.text: For so, "to me last of all He appeared," saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:213
verses.text: Wherefore neither doth he with himself mention any other, and saith, "as of one born out of due time," and that himself is "the least of the apostles," and not even worthy of this appellation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:214
verses.text: And he was not content even with these, but that he might not seem in mere words to be humble-minded, he states both reasons and proofs: of his being "one born out of due time," his seeing Jesus last; and of his being unworthy even of the name of an apostle, "his persecuting the Church".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:215
verses.text: For he that is simply humble-minded doeth not this: but he that also sets down the reasons utters all from a contrite mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:216
verses.text: Wherefore also he elsewhere makes mention of these same things, saying, "And I thank him that enabled me; even Christ Jesus our Lord, for that He counted me faithful, appointing the to his service, though I was before a blasphemer, and a persecutor, and injurious".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:217
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:218
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:220
verses.text: )  But wherefore did he utter at all that same lofty expression, "I labored more abundantly than they?" He saw that the occasion compelled him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:221
verses.text: For had he not said this, had he only depreciated himself, how could he with boldness call himself to witness, and number himself with the rest, and say,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:222
verses.text: "Whether then it be I or they, so we preach".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:223
verses.text: For the witness ought to be trustworthy, and a great man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:224
verses.text: But how he "labored more abundantly than they," he indicated above, saying, "Have we no right to eat and to drink, as also the other Apostles?" And again, "to them that are without law as without law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:225
verses.text: Thus, both where exactness was to be displayed, he overshot all: and where there was need to condescend, he displayed again the same great superiority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:226
verses.text: But some cite his being sent to the Gentiles and his overrunning the larger part of the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:227
verses.text: Whence it is evident that he enjoyed more grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:228
verses.text: For if he labored more, the grace was also more: but he enjoyed more grace, because he displayed also more diligence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:229
verses.text: Seest thou how by those particulars whereby he contends and strives to throw into shade the things concerning himself, he is shown to be first of all?   And these things when we hear, let us also make open show of our defects, but of our excellencies let us say nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:230
verses.text: Or if the opportunity force it upon us, let us speak of them with reserve and impute the whole to God's grace: which accordingly the Apostle also doth, ever and anon putting a bad mark upon his former life, but his after-state imputing to grace, that he might signify the mercy of God from every circumstance: from His having saved him such as he was and when saved making him again such as he is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:231
verses.text: Let none accordingly of those who are in sin despair, let none of those in virtue be confident, but let the one be exceeding fearful and the other forward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:232
verses.text: For neither shall any slothful man be able to abide in virtue, nor one that is diligent be weak to escape from evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:233
verses.text: And of both these the blessed David is an example, who after he slumbered a little, had a great downfall: and when he was pricked in his heart, again hastened up to his former height.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:234
verses.text: Since in fact both are alike evils, both despair and slothfulness; the one quickly casting a man down from the very arch of the heavens; the other not suffering the fallen to rise again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:235
verses.text: Wherefore with respect to the one, Paul said, "Let him that thinketh he standeth take heed lest he fall:" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:236
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:237
verses.text: ) but unto the other, "To-day if ye will hear His voice, harden not your hearts: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:238
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:239
verses.text: ) and again, "Lift up the hands that hang down and the palsied knees".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:240
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:241
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:242
verses.text: ) And him too that had committed fornication but repented, he therefore quickly refreshes, "that such an one might not be swallowed up with his overmuch sorrow?" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:243
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:244
verses.text: )  Why then in regard of other griefs art thou cast down, O man? Since if for sins, where only grief is beneficial, excess works much mischief, much more for all other things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:245
verses.text: For wherefore grievest thou? That thou hast lost money? Nay, think of those that are not even filled with bread, and thou shalt very speedily obtain consolation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:246
verses.text: And in each of the things that are grievous to thee mourn not the things that have happened, but for the disasters that have not happened give thanks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:247
verses.text: Hadst thou money and didst thou lose it? Weep not for the loss, but give thanks for the time when thou didst enjoy it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:248
verses.text: Say like Job, "Have we received good at the hand of the Lord, and shall we not receive evil?" (Job ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:249
verses.text: ) And together with that use this argument also; that even if thou didst lose thy money, yet thy body thou hast still sound and hast not with thy poverty to grieve that it also is maimed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:250
verses.text: But hath thy body too endured some outrage? Yet is not this the bottom of human calamities, but in the middle of the cask thou art as yet carried along.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:251
verses.text: For many along with poverty and maiming, both wrestle with a demon and wander in deserts: others again endure other things more grievous than these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:252
verses.text: For may it never be our lot to suffer all that it is possible for one to bear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:253
verses.text: These things then ever considering, bear in mind them that suffer worse, and be vexed at none of those things: but when thou sinnest, only then sigh, then weep; I forbid thee not, nay I enjoin thee rather; though even then with moderation, remembering that there is returning, there is reconciliation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:254
verses.text: But seest thou others in luxury and thyself in poverty: and another in goodly robes, and in preeminence? Look not however on these things alone, but also on the miseries that arise out of these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:255
verses.text: And in thy poverty too, consider not the beggary alone, but the pleasure also thence arising do thou take into account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:256
verses.text: For wealth hath indeed a cheerful mask, but its inward parts are full of gloom; and poverty the reverse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:257
verses.text: And shouldest thou unfold each man's conscience, in the soul of the poor thou wilt see great security and freedom: but in that of the rich, confusions, disorders, tempests.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:258
verses.text: And if thou grievest, seeing him rich, he too is vexed much more than thou when he beholds one richer than himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:259
verses.text: And as thou fearest him, even so doth he another, and he hath no advantage over thee in this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:260
verses.text: But thou art vexed to see him in office, because thou art in a private station and one of the governed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:261
verses.text: Recollect however the day of his ceasing to hold office.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:262
verses.text: And even before that day the tumults, the perils, the fatigues, the flatteries, the sleepless nights, and all the miseries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:263
verses.text: And these things we say to those who have no mind for high morality: since if thou knowest this, there are other and greater things whereby we may comfort thee: but for the present we must use the coarser topics to argue with thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:264
verses.text: When therefore thou seest one that is rich, think of him that is richer than he, and thou wilt see him in the same condition with thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:265
verses.text: And after him look also on him that is poorer than thyself, consider how many have gone to bed hungry, and have lost their patrimony, and live in a dungeon, and pray for death every day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:266
verses.text: For neither doth poverty breed sadness, nor wealth pleasure, but both the one and the other our own thoughts are wont to produce in us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:267
verses.text: And consider, beginning from beneath: the scavenger grieves and is vexed that he cannot be rid of this his business so wretched and esteemed so disgraceful: but if thou rid him of this, and cause him, with security, to have plenty of the necessaries of life, he will grieve again that he hath not more than he wants: and if thou grant him more, he will wish to double them again, and will therefore vex himself no less than before: and if thou grant him twofold or threefold, he will be out of heart again because he hath no part in the state: and if you provide him with this also, he will count himself wretched because he is not one of the highest officers of state.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:268
verses.text: And when he hath obtained this honor, he will mourn that he is not a ruler; and when he shall be ruler, that it is not of a whole nation; and when of a whole nation, that it is not of many nations; and when of many nations, that it is not of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:269
verses.text: When he becomes a deputy, he will vex himself again that he is not a king; and if a king, that he is not so alone; and if alone, that he is not also of barbarous nations; and if of barbarous nations, that he is not of the whole world even: and if of the whole world, why not likewise of another world? And so his course of thought going on without end does not suffer him ever to be pleased.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:270
verses.text: Seest thou, how even if from being mean and poor thou shouldest make a man a king, thou dost not remove his dejection, without first correcting his turn of thought, enamored as it is of having more?  Come, let me show thee the contrary too, that even if from a higher station thou shouldest bring down to a lower one him that hath consideration, thou wilt not cast him into dejection and grief.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:271
verses.text: And if thou wilt, let us descend the same ladder, and do thou bring down the satrap from his throne and in supposition deprive him of that dignity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:272
verses.text: I say that he will not on this account vex himself, if he choose to bear in mind the things of which I have spoken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:273
verses.text: For he will not reckon up the things of which he hath been deprived, but what he hath still, the glory arising from his office.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:274
verses.text: But if thou take away this also, he will reckon up them who are in private stations and have never ascended to such sway, and for consolation his riches will suffice him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:275
verses.text: And if thou also cast him out again from this, he will look to them that have a moderate estate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:276
verses.text: And if thou shouldest take away even moderate wealth, and shouldest allow him to partake only of necessary food, he may think upon them that have not even this, but wrestle with incessant hunger and live in prison.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:277
verses.text: And even if thou shouldest bring him into that prison-house, when he reflects on them that lie under incurable diseases and irremediable pains, he will see himself to be in much better circumstances.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:278
verses.text: And as the scavenger before mentioned not even on being made a king will reap any cheerfulness, so neither will this man ever vex himself if he become a prisoner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:279
verses.text: It is not then wealth that is the foundation of pleasure, nor poverty of sadness, but our own judgment, and the fact, that the eyes of our mind are not pure, nor are fixed anywhere and abide, but without limit flutter abroad.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:280
verses.text: And as healthy bodies, if they be nourished with bread alone, are in good and vigorous condition: but those that are sickly, even if they enjoy a plentiful and varied diet, become so much the weaker; so also it is wont to happen in regard of the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:281
verses.text: The mean spirited, not even in a diadem and unspeakable honors can be happy: but the denying, even in bonds and fetters and poverty, will enjoy a pure pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:282
verses.text: These things then bearing in mind, let us ever look to them that are beneath us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:283
verses.text: There is indeed, I grant, another consolation, but of a high strain in morality, and mounting above the grossness of the multitude.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:284
verses.text: What is this? That wealth is naught, poverty is naught, disgrace is naught, honor is naught, but for a brief time and only in words do they differ from each other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:285
verses.text: And along with this there is another soothing topic also, greater than it; the consideration of the things to come, both evil and good, the things which are really evil and really good, and the being comforted by them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:286
verses.text: But since many, as I said, stand aloof from these doctrines, therefore were we compelled to dwell on other topics, that in course we might lead on to them the receivers of what had been said before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:287
verses.text: Let us then, taking all these things into account, by every means frame ourselves aright, and we shall never grieve at these unexpected things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:288
verses.text: For neither if we should see men rich in a picture, should we say they were to be envied, any more than on seeing poor men there depicted we should call them wretched and pitiable: although those are surely more abiding than they whom we reckon wealthy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:289
verses.text: Since one abides rich in the picture longer than in the nature itself of things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:290
verses.text: For the one often lasts, appearing such, even to a hundred years, but the other sometimes, not having had so much as a year to live at his ease in his possessions, hath been suddenly stripped of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 37:291
verses.text: Meditating then on all these things, let us from all quarters build up cheerfulness as an outwork against our irrational sorrow, that we may both pass the present life with pleasure, and obtain the good things to come, through the grace and mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father, with the Holy Ghost, be glory, power, honor, now and forever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:1
verses.text: Homily XXXIX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:3
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:4
verses.text: Whether then it be I or they, so we preach, and so ye believed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:5
verses.text: Having exalted the Apostles and abased himself, then again having exalted himself above them that he might make out an equality: (for he did effect an equality, when he showed that he had advantages over them as well as they over him,) and having thereby proved himself worthy of credit; neither so doth he dismiss them, but again ranks himself with them, pointing out their concord in Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:6
verses.text: Nevertheless he doth it not so as that he should seem to have been tacked on to them, but as himself also to appear in the same rank.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:7
verses.text: For so it was profitable for the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:8
verses.text: Wherefore also he was equally earnest, on the one hand, that he might not seem to overlook them; on the other, that he might not be on account of the honor paid to them held cheap by those that were under his authority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:9
verses.text: Therefore he also now makes himself equal again, saying,  "Whether then it be I or they, so we preach".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:10
verses.text: "From whomsoever," saith he, "ye choose to learn, learn; there is no difference between us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:11
verses.text: And he said not, "if ye will not believe me, believe them;" but while he makes himself worthy of credit and saith that he is of himself sufficient, he affirms the same also of them by themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:12
verses.text: For the difference of persons took no effect, their authority being equal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:13
verses.text: And in the Epistle to the Galatians he doth this, taking them with him, not as also standing in need of them, but saying indeed that even himself was sufficient: "For they who were of repute imparted nothing to me:" (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:14
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:15
verses.text: ) nevertheless, even so I follow after agreement with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:16
verses.text: "For they gave unto me," saith he, "their right hands".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:17
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:18
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:19
verses.text: ) For if the credit of Paul were always to depend on others and to be confirmed by testimony from others, the disciples would hence have received infinite injury.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:20
verses.text: It is not therefore to exalt himself that he doeth this, but fearing for the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:21
verses.text: Wherefore also he here saith, making himself equal, "Whether it be I or they, so we preach".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:22
verses.text: Well did he say, "we preach," indicating his great boldness of speech.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:23
verses.text: For we speak not secretly, nor in a corner, but we utter a voice clearer than a trumpet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:24
verses.text: And he said not, "we preached," but, "even now 'so we preach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:25
verses.text: '" "And so ye believed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:26
verses.text: Here he said not, "ye believe," but, "ye believed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:27
verses.text: Because they were shaken in mind, therefore he ran back to the former times, and proceeds to add the witness from themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:28
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:29
verses.text: "Now if Christ is preached that He hath been raised from the dead, how say some among you that there is no resurrection of the dead?"  Seest thou how excellently he reasons, and proves the resurrection from the fact of Christ's being raised, having first established the former in many ways? "For both the prophets spake of it," saith he, "and the Lord Himself showed it by His appearing, and we preach, and ye believed;" weaving thus his fourfold testimony; the witness of the prophets, the witness of the issue of events, the witness of the apostles, the witness of the disciples; or rather a fivefold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:30
verses.text: For this very cause too itself implies the resurrection; viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:31
verses.text: his dying for others' sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:32
verses.text: If therefore this hath been proved, it is evident that the other also follows, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:33
verses.text: that the other dead likewise are raised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:34
verses.text: And this is why, as concerning an admitted fact, he challenges and questions them, saying, "Now if Christ hath been raised, how say some among you that there is no resurrection of the dead?"  Hereby also again abating the boldness of the gainsayers: in that he said not, "how say, ye," but, "how say some among you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:35
verses.text: And neither doth he bring a charge against all nor declare openly the very persons whom he accuses, in order not to make them more reckless: neither on the other hand doth he conceal it wholly, that he may correct them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:36
verses.text: For this purpose accordingly, separating them from the multitude, he strips himself for the contest with them, by this both weakening and confounding them, and holding the rest in their conflicts with these firmer to the truth, nor suffering them to desert to those that were busy to destroy them: he being in fact prepared to adopt a vehement mode of speech.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:37
verses.text: Further, lest they should say, "this indeed is clear and evident unto all that Christ is raised, and none doubts it; this doth not however necessarily imply the other also, to wit, the resurrection of mankind:"—for the one was both before proclaimed and came to pass, and was testified of by his appearing; the fact, namely, of Christ's resurrection: but the other is yet in hope, i-e:, our own part:—see what he doeth; from the other side again he makes it out: which is a proof of great power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:38
verses.text: Thus, "why do some say," saith he, "that there is no resurrection of the dead?" Of course then the former also in its turn is subverted by this, the fact, namely, that Christ is raised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:39
verses.text: Wherefore also he adds, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:40
verses.text: "But if there is no resurrection of the dead, neither hath Christ been raised".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:41
verses.text: Seest thou Paul's energy, and his spirit for the combat, so invincible? how not only from what is evident he demonstrates what is doubted, but also from what is doubted, endeavors to demonstrate to gainsayers the former evident proposition? Not because what had already taken place required demonstration, but that he might signify this to be equally worthy of belief with that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:42
verses.text: "And what kind of consequence is this?" saith one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:43
verses.text: "For if Christ be not raised, that then neither should others be raised, doth follow: but that if others be not raised, neither should Christ be raised, what reason can there be in this?" Since then this doth not appear to be very reasonable, see how he works it out wisely, scattering his seeds beforehand from the beginning, even from the very groundwork of the Gospel: as, that "having died for our sins," He was raised; and that He is "the first-fruits of them that slept".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:44
verses.text: For the first-fruits—of what can He be the first-fruits, except of them that are raised? And how can He be first-fruits, if they rise not of whom He is first-fruits? How then are they not raised?  Again, if they be not raised, wherefore was Christ raised? Wherefore came He? Wherefore did He take upon Him flesh, if he were not about to raise flesh again? For He stood not in need of it Himself but for our sakes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:45
verses.text: But these things he afterwards set down as he goes on; for the present he saith, "If the dead be not raised, neither hath Christ been raised," as though that were connected with this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:46
verses.text: For had He not intended to raise Himself, He would not have wrought that other work.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:47
verses.text: Seest thou by degrees the whole economy overthrown by those words of theirs and by their unbelief in the resurrection? But as yet he saith nothing of the incarnation, but of the resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:48
verses.text: For not His having become incarnate, but His having died, took away death; since while He had flesh, the tyranny of death still had dominion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:49
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:50
verses.text: "And if Christ hath not been raised, then is our preaching vain, your faith also is vain".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:51
verses.text: Although what followed in due course would have been, "but if Christ be not risen, ye fight against things evident, and against so many prophets, and the truth of facts;" nevertheless he states what is much more fearful to them: "then is our preaching vain, your faith also is vain".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:52
verses.text: For he wishes to shake thoroughly their mind: "we have lost all," saith he, "all is over, if He be not risen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:53
verses.text: Seest thou how great is the mystery of the oeconomy? As thus: if after death He could not rise again, neither is sin loosed nor death taken away nor the curse removed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:54
verses.text: Yea, and not only have we preached in vain, but ye also have believed in vain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:55
verses.text: And not hereby alone doth he show the impiety of these evil doctrines, but he further contends earnestly against them, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:56
verses.text: "Yea, and we are found false witnesses of God: because we witnessed of Him that He raised up Christ; whom He raised not up, if so be that the dead are not raised".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:57
verses.text: But if this be absurd, (for it is a charge against God and a calumny,) and He raised Him not, as ye say, not only this, but other absurdities too will follow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:58
verses.text: And again he establishes it all, and takes it up again, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:59
verses.text: "For if the dead are not raised, neither hath Christ been raised".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:60
verses.text: For had He not intended to do this, He would not have come into the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:61
verses.text: And he names not this, but the end, to wit, His resurrection; through it drawing all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:62
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:63
verses.text: "And if Christ hath not been raised, your faith is vain".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:64
verses.text: With whatever is clear and confessed, he keeps on surrounding the resurrection of Christ, by means of the stronger point making even that which seems to be weak and doubtful, strong and clear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:65
verses.text: "Ye are yet in your sins".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:66
verses.text: For if He was not raised, neither did He die; and if He died not, neither did He take away sin: His death being the taking away of sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:67
verses.text: "For behold," saith one, "the Lamb of God, which taketh away the sin of the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:68
verses.text: (John i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:69
verses.text: ) But how "taketh away?" By His death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:70
verses.text: Wherefore also he called him a Lamb, as one slain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:71
verses.text: But if He rose not again, neither was He slain: and if He was not slain, neither was sin taken away: and if it was not taken away, ye are in it: and if ye are in it, we have preached in vain: and if we have preached in vain, ye have believed in vain that ye were reconciled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:72
verses.text: And besides, death remains immortal, if He did not arise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:73
verses.text: For if He too was holden of death and loosed not its pains, how released He all others, being as yet Himself holden of it? Wherefore also he adds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:74
verses.text: "Then they also which are fallen asleep in Christ have perished".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:75
verses.text: "And why speak I of you," saith he, "when all those also are perished, who have done all and are no longer subject to the uncertainty of the future?" But by the expression, "in Christ," he means either "in the faith," or "they who died for His sake, who endured many perils, many miseries, who walked in the narrow way".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:76
verses.text: Where are those foul-mouthed Manichees who say that by the resurrection here means the liberation from sin? For these compact and continuous syllogisms, holding as they do also conversely, indicate nothing of what they say, but what we affirm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:77
verses.text: It is true, "rising again" is spoken of one who has fallen: and this is why he keeps on explaining, and saith not only that He was raised, but adds this also, "from the dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:78
verses.text: And the Corinthians too doubted not of the forgiveness of sins, but of the resurrection of bodies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:79
verses.text: But what necessity is there at all, that except mankind be not without sin, neither should Christ Himself be so? Whereas, if He were not to raise men up, it were natural to say, "wherefore came He and took our flesh and rose again?" But on our supposition not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:80
verses.text: Yea, and whether men sin or do not sin, there is ever with God an impossibility of sinning, and what happens to us reaches not to Him, nor doth one case answer to the other by way of conversion, as in the matter of the resurrection of the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:81
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:82
verses.text: "If in this life only we have hoped in Christ, we are of all men most pitiable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:83
verses.text: What sayest thou, O Paul? How "in this life only have we hope," if our bodies be not raised, the soul abiding and being immortal? Because even if the soul abide, even if it be infinitely immortal, as indeed it is, without the flesh it shall not receive those hidden good things, as neither truly shall it be punished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:84
verses.text: For all things shall be made manifest before the judgment-seat of Christ, "that every one may receive the things done in the body, according to that he hath done, whether it be good or bad".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:85
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:86
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:87
verses.text: ) Therefore he saith, "if in this life only we have hope in Christ, we are of all men most pitiable".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:88
verses.text: For if the body rise not again, the soul abides uncrowned without that blessedness which is in heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:89
verses.text: And if this be so, we shall enjoy nothing then at all: and if nothing then, in the present life is our recompense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:90
verses.text: "What then in this respect can be more wretched than we?" saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:91
verses.text: But these things he said, as well to confirm them in the doctrine of the resurrection of the body, as to persuade them concerning that immortal life, in order that they might not suppose that all our concerns end with the present world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:92
verses.text: For having sufficiently established what he purposed by the former arguments, and having said, "if the dead are not raised, neither hath Christ been raised; but if Christ were not raised, we have perished, and we are yet in our sins;" again he also subjoins this, thoroughly demolishing their arrogance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:93
verses.text: For so when he intends to introduce any of the necessary doctrines, he first shakes thoroughly their hardness of heart by fear: which accordingly he did here, having both above scattered those seeds, and made them anxious, as those who had fallen from all: and now again after another manner, and so as they should most severely feel it, doing this same thing and saying, "'we are of all men most pitiable,' if after so great conflicts and deaths and those innumerable evils, we are to fall from so great blessings, and our happiness is limited by the present life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:94
verses.text: For in fact all depends on the resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:95
verses.text: So that even hence it is evident that his discourse was not of a resurrection from sins, but of bodies, and of the life present and to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:96
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:97
verses.text: "But now hath Christ been raised from the dead, the first-fruits of them that are asleep".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:98
verses.text: Having signified how great mischiefs are bred from not believing the resurrection, he takes up the discourse again, and says, "But now hath Christ been raised from the dead;" continually adding, "from the dead," so as to stop the mouths of the heretics.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:99
verses.text: "The first-fruits of them that slept".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:100
verses.text: But if their first-fruits, then themselves also, must needs rise again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:101
verses.text: Whereas if he were speaking of the resurrection from sins, and none is without sin;—for even Paul saith, "I know nothing against myself, yet am I not hereby justified;"—how shall there be any who rise again, according to you? Seest thou that his discourse was of bodies? And that he might make it worthy of credit, he continually brings forward Christ who rose again in the flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:102
verses.text: Next he also assigns a reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:103
verses.text: For, as I said, when one asserts but does not state the reason, his discourse is not easily received by the multitude.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:104
verses.text: What then is the reason?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:105
verses.text: "For since by man came death, by man came also the resurrection of the dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:106
verses.text: But if by a man, doubtless by one having a body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:107
verses.text: And observe his thoughtfulness, how on another ground also he makes his argument inevitable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:108
verses.text: As thus: "he that is defeated," saith he, "must in his own person also renew the conflict, the nature which was cast down must itself also gain the victory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:109
verses.text: For so the reproach was wiped away".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:110
verses.text: But let us see what kind of death he is speaking of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:111
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:112
verses.text: "For as in Adam all die, even so in Christ shall all be made alive".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:113
verses.text: What then? tell me; did all die in Adam the death of sin? How then was Noah righteous in his generation? and how Abraham? and how Job? and how all the rest? And what, I pray? shall all be made alive in Christ? Where then are those who are led away into hell fire? Thus, if this be said of the body, the doctrine stands: but if of righteousness and sin, it doth so no longer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:114
verses.text: Further, lest, on hearing that the making alive is common to all, thou shouldest also suppose that sinners are saved, he adds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:115
verses.text: "But every man in his own order".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:116
verses.text: For do not, because thou hearest of a resurrection, imagine that all enjoy the same benefits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:117
verses.text: Since if in the punishment all will not suffer alike but the difference is great; much more where there are sinners and righteous men shall the separation be yet wider.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:118
verses.text: "Christ the first-fruits, then they that are Christ's;" i-e:, the faithful and the approved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:119
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:120
verses.text: "Then cometh the end".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:121
verses.text: For when these shall have risen again, all things shall have an end, not as now when after Christ's resurrection things abide yet in suspense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:122
verses.text: Wherefore he added, "at His coming," that thou mayest learn that he is speaking of that time, "when He shall have delivered up the kingdom to God even the Father; when He shall have abolished all rule and all authority and power".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:123
verses.text: Here, give heed to me carefully, and see that no part escape you of what I say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:124
verses.text: For our contest is with enemies: wherefore we first must practice the reductio ad absurdum which also Paul often doeth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:125
verses.text: Since in this way shall we find what they say most easy of detection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:126
verses.text: Let us ask them then first, what is the meaning of the saying, "When he shall have delivered up the kingdom to God, even the Father?" For if we take this just as it stands and not in a sense becoming Deity, He will not after this retain it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:127
verses.text: For he that hath delivered up to another, ceases any longer to retain a thing himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:128
verses.text: And not only will there be this absurdity, but that also the other person who receives it will be found not to be possessor of it before he hath so received it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:129
verses.text: Therefore according to them, neither was the Father a King before, governing our affairs: nor will it seem that the Son after these things will be a King.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:130
verses.text: How then, first of all, concerning the Father doth the Son Himself say, "My Father worketh hitherto, and I work:" (John v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:131
verses.text: ) and of Him Daniel, "That His kingdom is an everlasting kingdom, which shall not pass away?" (Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:132
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:133
verses.text: ) Seest thou how many absurdities are produced, and repugnant to the Scriptures, when one takes the thing spoken after the manner of men?  But what "rule," then doth he here say, that Christ "putteth down?" That of the angels? Far from it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:134
verses.text: That of the faithful? Neither is it this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:135
verses.text: What rule then? That of the devils, concerning which he saith, "Our wrestling is not against flesh and blood, but against the principalities, against the powers, against the world-rulers of this darkness:" (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:136
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:137
verses.text: ) For now it is not as yet "put down" perfectly, they working in many places, but then shall they cease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:138
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:139
verses.text: "For He must reign, till He hath put all enemies under His feet".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:140
verses.text: Again from hence also another absurdity is produced, unless we take this also in a way becoming Deity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:141
verses.text: For the expression "until," is one of end and limitation: but in reference to God, this does not exist.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:142
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:143
verses.text: "The last enemy that shall be abolished is death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:144
verses.text: How the last? After all, after the devil, after all the other things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:145
verses.text: For so in the beginning also death came in last; the counsel of the devil having come first, and our disobedience, and then death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:146
verses.text: Virtually then indeed it is even now abolished: but actually, at that time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:147
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:148
verses.text: "For He hath put all things in subjection under His feet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:149
verses.text: But when He saith, All things are put in subjection, it is manifest that He is excepted who did subject all things unto Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:150
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:151
verses.text: "And when all things have been subjected unto Him, then shall the Son also Himself be subjected unto Him that did subject all things unto Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:152
verses.text: And yet before he said not that it was the Father who "put things under Him," but He Himself who "abolishes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:153
verses.text: For "when He shall have abolished," saith he, "all rule and authority:" and again, "for He must reign until He hath put all His enemies under His feet".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:154
verses.text: How then doth he here say, "the Father?"  And not only is there this apparent perplexity, but also that he is afraid with a very unaccountable fear, and uses a correction, saying, "He is excepted, who did subject all things unto Him," as though some would suspect, whether the Father might Himself not be subject unto the Son; than which what can be more irrational? nevertheless, he fears this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:155
verses.text: How then is it? for in truth there are many questions following one upon another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:156
verses.text: Well, give me then your earnest attention; since in fact it is necessary for us first to speak of the scope of Paul and his mind, which one may find everywhere shining forth, and then to subjoin our solution: this being itself an ingredient in our solution.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:157
verses.text: What then is Paul's mind, and what is his custom? He speaks in one way when he discourses of the Godhead alone, and in another when he falls into the argument of the economy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:158
verses.text: Thus having once taken hold of our Lord's Flesh, he freely thereafter uses all the sayings that humiliate Him; without fear as though that were able to bear all such expressions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:159
verses.text: Let us see therefore here also, whether his discourse is of the simple Godhead, or whether in view of the incarnation he asserts of Him those things which he saith: or rather let us first point out where he did this of which I have spoken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:160
verses.text: Where then did he this? Writing to the Philippians he saith, "Who, being in the form of God, counted it not a prize to be on an equality with God, but emptied Himself of no reputation, taking the form of a servant, being made in the likeness of men: and being found in fashion as a man, He humbled Himself, becoming obedient even unto death, yea, the death of the cross.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:161
verses.text: Wherefore hath God highly exalted Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:162
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:163
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:165
verses.text: )  Seest thou how when he was discoursing of the Godhead alone, he uttered those great things, that He "was in the form of God" and that He "was equal with" Him that begat Him, and to Him refers the whole? But when He showed Him to thee made flesh, he lowered again the discourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:166
verses.text: For except thou distinguish these things, there is great variance between the things spoken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:167
verses.text: Since, if He were "equal with God," how did He highly exalt one equal with Himself? If He were "in the form of God," how "gave" He Him "a name?" for he that giveth, giveth to one that hath not, and he that exalteth, exalteth one that is before abased.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:168
verses.text: He will be found then to be imperfect and in need, before He hath received the "exaltation" and "the Name;" and many other absurd corollaries will hence follow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:169
verses.text: But if thou shouldest add the incarnation, thou wilt not err in saying these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:170
verses.text: These things then here also consider, and with this mind receive thou the expressions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:171
verses.text: Now together with these we will state also other reasons why this pericope of Scripture was thus composed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:172
verses.text: But at present it is necessary to mention this: first, that Paul's discourse was of the resurrection, a thing counted to be impossible and greatly disbelieved: next, he was writing to Corinthians among whom there were many philosophers who mocked at such things always.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:173
verses.text: For although in other things wrangling one with another, in this they all, as with one mouth, conspired, dogmatically declaring that there is no resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:174
verses.text: Contending therefore for such a subject so disbelieved and ridiculed, both on account of the prejudice which had been formed, and on account of the difficulty of the thing; and wishing to demonstrate its possibility, he first effects this from the resurrection of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:175
verses.text: And having proved it both from the prophets, and from those who had seen, and from those who believed: when he had obtained an admitted reductio ad absurdum, he proves in what follows the resurrection of mankind also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:176
verses.text: "For if the dead rise not," saith he, "neither has Christ been raised".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:177
verses.text: Further; having closely urged these converse arguments in the former verses, he tries it again in another way, calling Him the "first-fruits," and pointing to His "abolishing all rule and authority and power, and death last".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:178
verses.text: "How then should death be put down," saith he, "unless he first loose the bodies which he held?" Since then he had spoken great things of the Only-Begotten, that He "gives up the kingdom," i-e:, that He Himself brings these things to pass, and Himself is victor in the war, and "putteth all things under His feet," he adds, to correct the unbelief of the multitude, "for He must reign till He hath put all His enemies under His feet".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:179
verses.text: Not as putting an end to the kingdom, did he use the expression "until," but to render what was said worthy of credit, and induce them to be confident.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:180
verses.text: For "do not," saith he, "because thou hast heard that He will abolish all rule, and authority and power," to wit, the devil, and the bands of demons, (many as there are,) and the multitudes of unbelievers, and the tyranny of death, and all evils: do not thou fear as though His strength was exhausted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:181
verses.text: For until He shall have done all these things, "He must reign;" not saying this, that after He hath brought it to pass He doth not reign; but establishing this other, that even if it be not now, undoubtedly it will be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:182
verses.text: For His kingdom is not cut off: yea, He rules and prevails and abides until He shall have set to right all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:183
verses.text: And this manner of speech one might find also in the Old Testament; as when it is said, "But the word of the Lord abideth for ever;" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:184
verses.text: cxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:185
verses.text: ) and, "Thou art the same, and Thy years shall not fail".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:186
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:187
verses.text: cii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:188
verses.text: ) Now these and such-like things the Prophet saith, when he is telling of things which a long space of time must achieve and which must by all means come to pass; casting out the fearfulness of the duller sort of hearers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:189
verses.text: But that the expression, "until," spoken of God, and "unto," do not signify an end, hear what one saith: "From everlasting unto everlasting Thou art God:" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:190
verses.text: xc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:191
verses.text: ) and again, "I am, I am," and "Even to your old age I am He".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:192
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:193
verses.text: xlvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:194
verses.text: )  For this cause indeed doth he set death last, that from the victory over the rest this also might be easily admitted by the unbeliever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:195
verses.text: For when He destroys the devil who brought in death, much more will He put an end to His work.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:196
verses.text: Since then he referred all to Him, the "abolishing rule and authority," the perfecting of His kingdom, (I mean the salvation of the faithful, the peace of the world, the taking away of evils, for this is to perfect His kingdom,) the putting an end to death; and he said not, "the Father by Him," but, "Himself shall put down, and Himself shall put under His feet," and he no where mentioned Him that begat Him; he was afraid afterward, lest on this account among some of the more irrational persons, either the Son might seem to be greater than the Father, or to be a certain distinct principle, unbegotten.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:197
verses.text: And therefore, gently guarding himself, he qualifies the magnitude of his expressions, saying, "for He put all things in subjection under His feet," again referring to the Father these high achievements; not as though the Son were without power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:198
