verses.text: For how could He be, of whom he testified so great things before, and referred to Him all that was said? But it was for the reason which I mentioned, and that he might show all things to be common to Father and Son which were done in our behalf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:199
verses.text: For that Himself alone was sufficient to "put all things in subjection under Him," hear again Paul saying, (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:200
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:201
verses.text: ) "Who shall fashion anew the body of our humiliation that it may be conformed to the body of His glory, according to the working whereby He is able even to subject all things unto Himself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:202
verses.text: Then also he uses a correction, saying, "But when He saith, all things are put in subjection, it is evident that He is excepted who did subject all things unto Him," testifying even thence no small glory to the Only-Begotten.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:203
verses.text: For if He were less and much inferior, this fear would never have been entertained by him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:204
verses.text: Neither is he content with this, but also adds another thing, as follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:205
verses.text: I say, lest any should doubtingly ask, "And what if the Father hath not been 'put under Him?' this doth not at all hinder the Son from being the more mighty;" fearing this impious supposition, because that expression was not sufficient to point out this also, he added, going very much beyond it, "But when all things have been subjected unto Him, then shall the Son also Himself be subjected;" showing His great concord with the Father, and that He is the principle of all other good things and the first Cause, who hath begotten One so great in power and in achievements.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:206
verses.text: But if he said more than the subject-matter demanded, marvel not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:207
verses.text: For in imitation of his Master he doeth this: since He too purposing to show His concord with Him that begat Him, and that He hath not come without His mind, descends so far, I say not, as the proof of concord demanded, but as the weakness of the persons present required.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:208
verses.text: For He prays to His Father for no other cause but this; and stating the reason He saith, "that they may believe that Thou hast sent Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:209
verses.text: (John xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:210
verses.text: ) In imitation therefore of Him, Paul here in his manner of speech goes beyond what was required; not that thou mightest have any suspicion of a forced servitude, far from it; but that he might the more entirely cast out those impious doctrines.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:211
verses.text: For so when he is minded to pull up any thing by the roots, he is wont to do it, and abundantly more with it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:212
verses.text: Thus too, for example, when he spake of a believing wife and an unbelieving husband, companying with one another by the law of marriage, that the wife might not consider herself defiled by that intercourse and the embraces of the unbeliever, he said not, "the wife is not unclean," nor, "she is no wise harmed by the unbeliever," but, which was much more, "the unbeliever is even 'sanctified' by her," not meaning to signify that the heathen was made holy through her, but by the very great strength of the expression anxious to remove her fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:213
verses.text: So also here, his zeal to take away that impious doctrine by a very strong utterance was the cause of his expressing himself as he did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:214
verses.text: For as to suspect the Son of weakness is extreme impiety: (wherefore he corrects it, saying, "He shall put all enemies under His feet:") so on the other hand is it more impious to consider the Father inferior to Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:215
verses.text: Wherefore he takes it also away with exceeding force.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:216
verses.text: And observe how he puts it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:217
verses.text: For he said not simply, "He is excepted which put all things under Him," but, "it is manifest," "for even if it be admitted," saith he, "nevertheless I make it sure".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:218
verses.text: And that thou mayest learn that this is the reason of the things spoken, I would ask thee this question: Doth an additional "subjection" at that time befal the Son? And how can this be other than impious and unworthy of God? For the greatest subjection and obedience is this, that He who is God took the form of a servant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:219
verses.text: How then will He be "subjected?" Seest thou, that to take away the impious notion, he used this expression? and this too in a suitable though reserved sense? For he becomes a Son and a divine Person, so He obeys; not humanly, but as one acting freely and having all authority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:220
verses.text: Otherwise how is he co-enthroned? How, "as the Father raiseth up, even so He, whom He will?" (John v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:221
verses.text: ) How are "all things that the Father hath His," and all that He hath, the Father's? (John xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:222
verses.text: ) For these phrases indicate to us an authority exactly measured by that of Him that begat Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:223
verses.text: But what is this, "When He shall deliver up the kingdom?" The Scripture acknowledges two kingdoms of God, the one by appropriation, the other by creation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:224
verses.text: Thus, He is King over all, both Greeks and Jews and devils and His adversaries, in respect of His creation: but He is King of the faithful and willing and subject, in respect of His making them His own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:225
verses.text: This is the kingdom which is said also to have a beginning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:226
verses.text: For concerning this He saith also in the second Psalm, "Ask of Me, and I shall give Thee the heathen for Thine inheritance".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:227
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:228
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:229
verses.text: ) Touching this also, He Himself said to His disciples, "All authority hath been given unto Me by My father," (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:230
verses.text: xxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:231
verses.text: ) referring all to Him that begat Him, not as though of Himself He were not sufficient, but to signify that He is a Son, and not unbegotten.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:232
verses.text: This kingdom then He doth "deliver up," i-e:, "bring to a right end".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:233
verses.text: "What then," saith one, "can be the reason why He spake nothing of the Spirit?" Because of Him he was not discoursing now, nor doth he confound all things together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:234
verses.text: Since also where he saith, "There is one God the Father, and one Lord Jesus," undoubtedly not as allowing the Spirit to be inferior, is he therefore silent, but because for the time it was not urgent, he so expressed himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:235
verses.text: For he is wont also to make mention of the Father only, yet we must not therefore cast out the Son: he is wont to speak also of the Son and of the Spirit only, yet not for this are we to deny the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:236
verses.text: But what is, "that God may be all in all?" That all things may be dependent upon Him, that none may suppose two authorities without a beginning, nor another kingdom separated off; that nothing may exist independent of him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:237
verses.text: For when the enemies shall be lying under the feet of the Son, and He having them cast under His feet be at no variance with His Father, but at concord with Him in entire perfection, then He shall Himself "be all in all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:238
verses.text: But some say that he spake this to declare the removal of wickedness, as though all would yield thenceforth and none would resist nor do iniquity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:239
verses.text: For when there is no sin, it is evident that "God shall be all in all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:240
verses.text: But if bodies do not rise again, how are these things true? For the worst enemy of all, death, remains, having wrought whatever he listed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:241
verses.text: "Nay," saith one, "for they shall sin no more".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:242
verses.text: And what of that? For he is not discoursing here of the death of the soul, but of that of the body? How then is he "put down?" For victory is this, the winning of those things which have been carried off and detained.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:243
verses.text: But if men's bodies are to be detained in the earth, it follows that the tyranny of death remains, these bodies for their part being holden, and there being no other body for him to be vanquished in.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:244
verses.text: But if this which Paul spake of, ensue, as undoubtedly it will ensue, God's victory will appear, and that a glorious one, in His being able to raise again the bodies which were holden thereby.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:245
verses.text: Since an enemy too is then vanquished, when a man takes the spoils, not when he suffers them to remain in the other's possession: but unless one venture to take what is his, how can we say that he is vanquished? After this manner of victory doth Christ Himself say in the Gospels that He hath been victorious, thus speaking, "When he shall bind the strong man, then shall he also spoil his goods".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:246
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:247
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:248
verses.text: ) Since if this were not so, it would not be at all a manifest victory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:249
verses.text: For as in the death of the soul, "he that hath died is justified from sin;" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:250
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:251
verses.text: ) (and yet we cannot say that this is a victory, for he is not the victor who adds no more to his wickedness, but he who hath done away the former captivity of his passions;) just so in this instance also, I should not call death's being stayed from feeding on the bodies of men a splendid victory, but rather that the bodies heretofore holden by him should be snatched away from him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:252
verses.text: But if they should still be contentious and should say that these things were spoken of the soul's death, how is this "destroyed last?" since in the case of each one at his Baptism it hath been destroyed perfectly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:253
verses.text: If however thou speakest of the body, the expression is admissible; I mean, such a saying as that it will be "last destroyed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:254
verses.text: But if any should doubt why discoursing of the resurrection, he did not bring forward the bodies which rose again in the time of our Lord, our answer might be the following: that this could not be alleged in behalf of the resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:255
verses.text: For to point out those who after rising died again, suited not one employed in proving that death is entirely destroyed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:256
verses.text: Yea, this is the very reason why he said that he is "destroyed last," that thou mightest never more suspect his rising again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:257
verses.text: For when sin is taken away, much more shall death cease: it being out of all reason when the fountain is dried up, that the stream flowing from it should still subsist; and when the root is annihilated, that the fruit should remain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:258
verses.text: Since then in the last day the enemies of God shall be destroyed, together with death and the devil and the evil spirits, let us not be dejected at the prosperity of the enemies of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:259
verses.text: For the enemies of the Lord in the moment of their glory and exaltation fail; "yea, like smoke have they failed away".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:260
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:261
verses.text: xxxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:262
verses.text: ) When thou seest any enemy of God wealthy, with armed attendants and many flatterers, be not cast down, but lament, weep, call upon God, that He may enrol him amongst His friends: and the more he prospers being God's enemy, so much the more do thou mourn for him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:263
verses.text: For sinners we ought always to bewail, but especially when they enjoy wealth and abundance of good days; even as one should the sick, when they eat and drink to excess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:264
verses.text: But there are some, who when they hear these words are of so unhappy a disposition, as to sigh bitterly thereupon, and say, "Tears are due to me who have nothing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:265
verses.text: Thou hast well said, "who have nothing," not because thou hast not what another hath, but because thou accountest the thing such as to be called happy; yea, for this cause art thou worthy of infinite lamentations: even as, if a person living in health should count happy him that is sick and lying on a soft couch, this latter is not near so wretched and miserable as he, because he hath no sense of his own advantages.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:266
verses.text: Just such a result one may observe in these men's case also: nay, and hereby our whole life is confounded and disordered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:267
verses.text: For these sayings have undone many, and betrayed them to the devil, and made them more pitiable than such as are wasted with famine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:268
verses.text: Yea, that those who long after more, are more wretched than mendicants, as being possessed with a greater and bitterer sorrow than they, is evident from what follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:269
verses.text: A drought once overtook our city, and all were trembling for the last of evils, and were beseeching God to rid them of this fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:270
verses.text: And one might see then that which was spoken of by Moses; (Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:271
verses.text: xxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:272
verses.text: ) "the heavens become brass," and a death, of all deaths the most horrible, waited for every day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:273
verses.text: But afterwards, when it seemed good to the merciful God, beyond all expectation there was wafted down from heaven a great and plentiful rain, and thenceforth all were in holiday and feasting, as having come up from the very gates of death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:274
verses.text: But in the midst of so great blessings and the common gladness of all, one of those exceedingly wealthy people went about with a gloomy and downcast countenance, quite dead with sorrow; and when many enquired the reason, wherefore in the common joy of all men he alone is sorrowful, he could not even keep within him his savage passion, but goaded by the tyranny of the disease, declared before them all the reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:275
verses.text: "Why," saith he, "having in my possession ten thousand measures of wheat, I have no means of disposing of them left".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:276
verses.text: Shall we then count him happy, tell me, for these words, for which he deserved to be stoned? Him that was more cruel than any wild beast, the common enemy? What sayest thou, man? Art thou sad because all did not perish, that thou mightest gather gold? Hast thou not heard what Solomon saith, (Prov.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:277
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:278
verses.text: ) "He that withholdeth corn, the people shall curse him?" but goest about a common enemy of the blessings of the world, and a foe to the liberality of the Lord of the world, and a friend of Mammon, or rather his slave? Nay, doth not that tongue deserve to be cut out, and the heart to be quenched, that brought forth these words?   Seest thou how gold doth not suffer men to be men, but wild beasts and fiends? For what can be more pitiful than this rich man, whose daily prayer is that there may be famine, in order that he may have a little gold? Yea, and his passion by this time is come round to the contrary of itself: he not even rejoicing in his abundant store of the fruits of the earth, but on this very account grieving the rather, (to such a pass is he come,) that his possessions are infinite.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:279
verses.text: Although one who hath much ought to be joyful: but this man on that very account is dejected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:280
verses.text: Seest thou that, as I said, the rich do not reap as much pleasure from what is present, as they endure sorrow for what hath not yet been added? For he that had innumerable quantities of wheat did more grieve and lament than he who suffered hunger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:281
verses.text: And while the one, on merely having his necessary food, was crowning himself and leaping for joy and giving thanks to God; the other, who had so much, was fretting and thought he was undone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:282
verses.text: It is not then the superfluity which causes our pleasure, but a self-controlling mind: since without this, though one obtain and have all, he will feel as one deprived of all and will mourn accordingly: inasmuch as this man too of whom we are now speaking, even if he had sold all he had for as large a sum as he wished, would again have grieved that it was not for more; and if he could have had more, he would again have sought another advance; and if he had disposed of the bushel for one pound, he would even then have been distracted for sorrow, that the half bushel could not be sold for as much.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:283
verses.text: And if the price were not set so high at first, marvel not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:284
verses.text: Since drunkards also are not at first inflamed, but when they have loaded themselves with much wine, then they kindle the flame into greater fierceness: so these men, by how much more they have grasped, in so much the greater poverty do they find themselves, and they who gain more than others, are the very persons to be the most in want.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:285
verses.text: But I say these things not only to this man, but also to each one of those who are so diseased: those, I say, who raise the price of their wares and make a traffic of the poverty of their neighbors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:286
verses.text: For of humanity none any where makes account: but every where the covetous desire brings out many at the time of sale.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:287
verses.text: And oil and wine is sold by one quicker, by another more slowly, but neither out of regard to others; rather the one seeks gain, the other to avoid loss by the spoiling of his produce.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:288
verses.text: Thus, because most men not making much account of the laws of God, shut up and keep all in doors, God by other means leading them to humanity,—that were it but of necessity they may do something kind,—hath infused into them the fear of greater loss, not allowing the fruits of the earth to keep any long time, in order that out of mere dread of the damage from their spoiling, they may expose for sale to the needy, even against their will, such things as they wickedly bury at home and keep.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:289
verses.text: However, after all this, some are so insatiable as not even thereby to be corrected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:290
verses.text: Many, for example, have gone so far as to empty whole casks, not giving even a cup-full to the poor man, nor a piece of money to the needy, but after it hath become vinegar, they dash it all upon the ground, and destroy their casks together with the fruit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:291
verses.text: Others again who would not give a part of a single cake to the hungry, have thrown whole granaries into some river: and because they listened not to God who bade them give to the needy, at the bidding of the moth, even unwillingly, they emptied out all they had in their houses, in utter destruction and waste; drawing down upon their own heads together with this loss much scorn and many a curse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:292
verses.text: And such is the course of their affairs here; but the hereafter, what words shall set before us? For as these men in this world cast their moth-eaten grain, become useless, into rivers; even so the doers of such things, on this very account become useless, God casts into the river of fire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:293
verses.text: Because as the grain by the moth and worm, so are their souls devoured by cruelty and inhumanity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:294
verses.text: And the reason of these things is their being nailed to things present, and gaping after this life only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:295
verses.text: Whence also such men are full of infinite sadness; for name whatever pleasure thou wilt, the fear of their end is enough to annihilate all, and such an one "is dead, while he is yet alive".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:296
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:297
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:298
verses.text: )  Now then that unbelievers should have these feelings, is no marvel; but when they who have partaken of so great mysteries and learned such high rules of self-denial concerning things to come, delight to dwell in things present, what indulgence do they deserve?   Whence then arises their loving to dwell in present things? From giving their mind to luxury, and fattening their flesh, and making their soul delicate, and rendering their burden heavy, and their darkness great, and their veil thick.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:299
verses.text: For in luxury the better part is enslaved, but the worse prevails; and the former is blinded on every side and dragged on in its maimed condition; while the other draws and leads men about every where, though it ought to be in the rank of things that are led.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:300
verses.text: Since great indeed is the bond between the soul and the body; the Maker having contrived this, lest any should induce us to abhor it as alien.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:301
verses.text: For God indeed bade us love our enemies; but the devil hath so far prevailed as to induce some even to hate their own body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:302
verses.text: Since when a man saith that it is of the devil, he proves nothing else than this; which is the extreme of dotage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:303
verses.text: For if it be of the devil, what is this so perfect harmony, such as to render it meet in every way for the energies of the self-controlling soul? "Nay," saith one, "if it be meet, how doth the body blind it?" It is not the body which blinds the soul; far from it, O man; but the luxury.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:304
verses.text: But whence do we desire the luxury? Not from our having a body, by no means; but from an evil choice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:305
verses.text: For the body requires feeding, not high feeding, the body needs nourishing, not breaking up and falling apart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:306
verses.text: You see that not to the soul only, but to the very body also which receives the nourishment, the luxury is hostile.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:307
verses.text: For it becomes weaker instead of strong, and softer instead of firm, and sickly instead of healthful, and heavier instead of light, and slighter instead of compact, and ill-favored instead of handsome, and unsavory instead of fragrant, and impure instead of clean, and full of pain instead of being at ease, and useless instead of useful, and old instead of young, and decaying instead of strong, and slow and dull instead of quick, and maimed instead of whole.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:308
verses.text: Whereas if it were of the devil, it ought not to receive injury from the things of the devil, I mean, from sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:309
verses.text: But neither is the body, nor food, of the devil, but luxury alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:310
verses.text: For by means of it that malignant fiend brings to pass his innumerable evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:311
verses.text: Thus did he make victims of a whole people.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:312
verses.text: "For the beloved waxed fat," saith one, "and grew thick, and was enlarged, and kicked".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:313
verses.text: (Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:314
verses.text: xxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:315
verses.text: ) And thence also was the beginning of those thunderbolts on Sodom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:316
verses.text: And to declare this, Ezekiel said, "But this was the iniquity of Sodom, in pride and fulness of bread and refinements they waxed wanton".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:317
verses.text: (Ezek.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:318
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:319
verses.text: ) Therefore also Paul said, ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:320
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:321
verses.text: ) "She that giveth herself to pleasure, is dead while she liveth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:322
verses.text: How should this be? Because as a sepulchre she bears about her body, bound close to innumerable evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:323
verses.text: And if the body so perish, how will the soul be affected; what disorder, what waves, what a tempest will she be filled with? Hereby, you see, she becomes unfitted for every duty, and will have no power easily to speak, or hear, or take counsel, or do anything that is needful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:324
verses.text: But as a pilot when the storm hath got the better of his skill, is plunged into the deep, vessels and sailors and all: so also the soul together with the body is drowned in the grievous abyss of insensibility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:325
verses.text: For, in fact, God hath set the stomach in our bodies as a kind of mill, giving it a proportionate power, and appointing a set measure which it ought to grind every day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:326
verses.text: If therefore one cast in more, remaining undigested it doth injury to the whole body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:327
verses.text: Hence diseases and weaknesses and deformities: since in truth luxury makes the beautiful woman not only sickly, but also foul to look upon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:328
verses.text: For when she is continually sending forth unpleasant exhalations, and breathes fumes of stale wine, and is more florid than she ought to be, and spoils the symmetry that beseems a woman, and loses all her seemliness, and her body becomes flabby, her eyelids bloodshot and distended, and her bulk unduly great, and her flesh an useless load; consider what a disgust it all produces.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:329
verses.text: Moreover, I have heard a physician say that many have been hindered from reaching their proper height by nothing so much as luxurious living.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:330
verses.text: For the breath being obstructed by the multitude of things which are cast in and being occupied in the digestion of such things, that which ought to serve for growth is spent on this digestion of superfluities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:331
verses.text: Why need one speak of gout, rheum dispersed every where, the other diseases hence arising, the whole abomination? For nothing is so disgusting as a woman pampering herself with much food.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:332
verses.text: Therefore among the poorer women one may see more of beauty: the superfluities being consumed and not cleaving to them, like some superfluous clay, of no use and benefit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:333
verses.text: For their daily exercise, and labors, and hardships, and their frugal table, and spare diet, minister unto them much soundness of body, and thence also much bloom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:334
verses.text: But if thou talkest of the pleasure of luxury, thou wilt find it to go no farther than the throat: since as soon as it hath passed the tongue, it is flown away, leaving behind in the body much that is disgusting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:335
verses.text: For do not I pray look on the voluptuaries at table only, but when you see them rise up, then follow them, and you will see bodies rather of wild beasts and irrational creatures than of human beings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:336
verses.text: You will see them with headache, distended, bound up, needing a bed and a couch and plenty of rest, and like men who are tossed in a great tempest and require others to save them, and long for that condition in which they were before they were swelled even to bursting: they carrying their bellies about with a burden like that of women with child, and can scarce step forward, and scarce see, and scarce speak, and scarce do any thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:337
verses.text: But if it should chance that they sleep a little, they see again strange dreams and full of all manner of fancies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:338
verses.text: What should one say of that other madness of theirs? the madness of lust, I mean, for this also hath its fountains from hence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:339
verses.text: Yea, as horses wild after the female, so they, goaded on by the sting of their drunkenness, leap upon all, more irrational than they, and more frantic in their boundings; and committing many more unseemlinesses which but to name is unlawful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:340
verses.text: For they know not in fact any longer what they suffer, nor what they do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:341
verses.text: But not so he that keeps from luxury: rather he sits in harbor, beholding other men's shipwrecks, and enjoys a pleasure pure and lasting, following after that life which becomes him that is free.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 38:342
verses.text: Knowing therefore these things, let us flee from the evil banquets of luxury and cleave to a spare table; that being of a good habit both of soul and body, we may both practice all virtue, and attain the good things to come, through the grace and mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father, with the Holy Ghost, be glory, power, and honor, now and ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:1
verses.text: Homily XL.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:3
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:4
verses.text: Else what shall they do which are baptized for the dead? if the dead are not raised at all, why then are they baptized for the dead?  He takes in hand again another topic, establishing what he said at one time from what God doeth, and at another from the very things which they practice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:5
verses.text: And this also is no small plea for the defence of any cause when a man brings forward the gainsayers themselves as witnessing by their own actions what he affirms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:6
verses.text: What then is that which he means? Or will ye that I should first mention how they who are infected with the Marcionite heresy pervert this expression? And I know indeed that I shall excite much laughter; nevertheless, even on this account most of all I will mention it that you may the more completely avoid this disease: viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:7
verses.text: , when any Catechumen departs among them, having concealed the living man under the couch of the dead, they approach the corpse and talk with him, and ask him if he wishes to receive baptism; then when he makes no answer, he that is concealed underneath saith in his stead that of course he should wish to be baptized; and so they baptize him instead of the departed, like men jesting upon the stage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:8
verses.text: So great power hath the devil over the souls of careless sinners.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:9
verses.text: Then being called to account, they allege this expression, saying that even the Apostle hath said, "They who are baptized for the dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:10
verses.text: Seest thou their extreme ridiculousness? Is it meet then to answer these things? I trow not; unless it were necessary to discourse with madmen of what they in their frenzy utter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:11
verses.text: But that none of the more exceedingly simple folk may be led captive, one must needs submit to answer even these men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:12
verses.text: As thus, if this was Paul's meaning wherefore did God threaten him that is not baptized? For it is impossible that any should not be baptized henceforth, this being once devised: and besides, the fault no longer lies with the dead, but with the living.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:13
verses.text: But to whom spake he, "Unless ye eat My flesh, and drink My blood, ye have no life in yourselves?" (John vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:14
verses.text: ) To the living, or to the dead, tell me? And again, "Unless a man be born again of water and of the Spirit, he cannot see the kingdom of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:15
verses.text: (John iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:16
verses.text: ) For if this be permitted, and there be no need of the mind of the receiver nor of his assent while he lives, what hinders both Greeks and Jews thus to become believers, other men after their decease doing these things in their stead?  But not to prolong fruitless toil in cutting asunder their petty spiders' webs, come let us unfold unto you the force of this expression.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:17
verses.text: What then is Paul speaking of?   But first I wish to remind you who are initiated of the response, which on that evening they who introduce you to the mysteries bid you make; and then I will also explain the saying of Paul: so this likewise will be clearer to you; we after all the other things adding this which Paul now saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:18
verses.text: And I desire indeed expressly to utter it, but I dare not on account of the uninitiated; for these add a difficulty to our exposition, compelling us either not to speak clearly or to declare unto them the ineffable mysteries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:19
verses.text: Nevertheless, as I may be able, I will speak as through a veil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:20
verses.text: As thus: after the enunciation of those mystical and fearful words, and the awful rules of the doctrines which have come down from heaven, this also we add at the end when we are about to baptize, bidding them say, "I believe in the resurrection of the dead," and upon this faith we are baptized.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:21
verses.text: For after we have confessed this together with the rest, then at last are we let down into the fountain of those sacred streams.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:22
verses.text: This therefore Paul recalling to their minds said, "if there be no resurrection, why art thou then baptized for the dead?" i-e:, the dead bodies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:23
verses.text: For in fact with a view to this art thou baptized, the resurrection of thy dead body, believing that it no longer remains dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:24
verses.text: And thou indeed in the words makest mention of a resurrection of the dead; but the priest, as in a kind of image, signifies to thee by very deed the things which thou hast believed and confessed in words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:25
verses.text: When without a sign thou believest, then he gives thee the sign also; when thou hast done thine own part, then also doth God fully assure thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:26
verses.text: How and in what manner? By the water.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:27
verses.text: For the being baptized and immersed and then emerging, is a symbol of the descent into Hades and return thence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:28
verses.text: Wherefore also Paul calls baptism a burial, saying, "Therefore we are buried with Him by baptism into death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:29
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:30
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:31
verses.text: ) By this he makes that also which is to come credible, I mean, the resurrection of our bodies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:32
verses.text: For the blotting out sins is a much greater thing than the raising up of a body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:33
verses.text: And this Christ declaring, said, "For whether is easier to say, Thy sins are forgiven, or to say, Take up thy bed, and walk?" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:34
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:35
verses.text: ) "The former is the more difficult," saith He, "but since ye disbelieve it as being hidden, and make the easier instead of the more difficult the demonstration of my power, neither will I refuse to afford you this proof".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:36
verses.text: Then saith He to the paralytic, "Arise, take up thy bed, and go unto thy house".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:37
verses.text: "And how is this difficult," saith one, "when it is possible to kings also and rulers? For they too forgive adulterers and homicides".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:38
verses.text: Thou art jesting, O man, who sayest these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:39
verses.text: For to forgive sins with God only is possible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:40
verses.text: But rulers and kings, whether it is adulterers whom they forgive or homicides, release them indeed from the present punishment; but their sin they do not purge out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:41
verses.text: Though they should advance to offices them that have been forgiven, though they should invest them with the purple itself, though they should set the diadem upon their heads, yet so they would only make them kings, but could not free them from their sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:42
verses.text: It being God alone who doeth this; which accordingly in the Laver of Regeneration He will bring to pass.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:43
verses.text: For His grace touches the very soul, and thence plucks up the sin by the root.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:44
verses.text: Here is the reason why he that hath been forgiven by the king may be seen with his soul yet impure, but the soul of the baptized no longer so, but purer than the very sun-beams, and such as it was originally formed, nay rather much better than that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:45
verses.text: For it is blessed with a Spirit, on every side enkindling it and making its holiness intense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:46
verses.text: And as when thou art recasting iron or gold thou makest it pure and new once more, just so the Holy Ghost also, recasting the soul in baptism as in a furnace and consuming its sins, causes it to glisten with more purity than all purest gold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:47
verses.text: Further, the credibility of the resurrection of our bodies he signifies to thee again from what follows: viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:48
verses.text: , that since sin brought in death, now that the root is dried up, one must not after that doubt of the destruction of the fruit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:49
verses.text: Therefore having first mentioned "the forgiveness of sins," thou dost next confess also "the resurrection of the dead;" the one guides thee as by hand on to the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:50
verses.text: Yet again, because the term Resurrection is not sufficient to indicate the whole: for many after rising have again departed, as those in the Old Testament, as Lazarus, as they at the time of the crucifixion: one is bid to say, "and the life everlasting," that none may any longer have a notion of death after that resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:51
verses.text: These words therefore Paul recalling to their minds, saith, "What shall they do which are baptized for the dead?" "For if there be no resurrection," saith he, "these words are but scenery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:52
verses.text: If there be no resurrection, how persuade we them to believe things which we do not bestow?" Just as if a person bidding another to deliver a document to the effect that he had received so much, should never give the sum named therein, yet after the subscription should demand of him the specified monies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:53
verses.text: What then will remain for the subscriber to do, now that he hath made himself responsible, without having received what he admitted he had received? This then he here saith of those who are baptized also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:54
verses.text: "What shall they do which are baptized," saith he, "having subscribed to the resurrection of dead bodies, and not receiving it, but suffering fraud? And what need was there at all of this confession, if the fact did not follow?"   Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:55
verses.text: "Why do we also stand in jeopardy every hour?"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:56
verses.text: "I protest by that glorying in you which I have in Christ Jesus our Lord, I die daily".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:57
verses.text: See again whence he endeavors to establish the doctrine, from his own suffrage: or rather not from his only, but from that also of the other apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:58
verses.text: And this too is no small thing; that the teachers whom you produce were full of vehement conviction and signified the same not by words only, but also by very deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:59
verses.text: Therefore, you see, he doth not say simply, "we are persuaded," for this alone was not sufficient to persuade them, but he also furnishes the proof by facts; as if he should say, "in words to confess these things haply seems to you no marvel; but if we should also produce unto you the voice which deeds send forth, what can ye have to say against that? Hear ye then, how by our perils also day by day we confess these things?" And he said not "I," but "we," taking along with him all the apostles together, and thereby at once speaking modestly and adding credibility to his discourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:60
verses.text: For what can ye have to say? that we are deceiving you when we preach these things, and that our doctrines come of vain-glory? Nay, our perils suffer you not to pass such a sentence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:61
verses.text: For who would choose to be in continual jeopardy to no purpose and with no effect? Wherefore also he said, "Why do we also stand in jeopardy every hour?" For if one should even choose it through vain-glory, such his choice will be but for once and again, not all his life long, like ours.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:62
verses.text: For we have assigned our whole life to this purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:63
verses.text: "I protest by that glorying in you which I have in Christ Jesus our Lord, I die daily:" by glorying here, meaning their advancement.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:64
verses.text: Thus since he had intimated that his perils were many, lest he might seem to say this by way of lamentation, "far from grieving," saith he, "I even glory in suffering this for your sake".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:65
verses.text: And doubly, he saith, he takes delight in it, both as being in jeopardy for their sakes and as beholding their proficiency.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:66
verses.text: Then doing what is usual with him, because he had uttered great things, he refers both to Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:67
verses.text: But how doth he "die daily?" by his readiness and preparation for that event.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:68
verses.text: And wherefore saith he these words? Again by these also to establish the doctrine of the resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:69
verses.text: "For who would choose," saith he, "to undergo so many deaths, if there be no resurrection nor life after this? Yea, if they who believe in the resurrection would scarcely put themselves in jeopardy for it except they were very noble of heart: much more would not the unbeliever (so he speaks) choose to undergo so many deaths and so terrible".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:70
verses.text: Thus, see by degrees how very high he mounts up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:71
verses.text: He had said, "we stand in jeopardy," he added, "every hour," then, "daily," then, "I not only 'stand in jeopardy,'" saith he, but "I even 'die:'" he concludes accordingly by pointing out also what kind of deaths they were; thus saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:72
verses.text: "If after the manner of men I fought with beasts at Ephesus, what doth it profit me?"  What is, "if after the manner of men?" "As far as pertains to men I fought with beasts: for what if God snatched me out of those dangers? So that I am he who ought most to be in care about these things; I, who endure so great dangers and have not yet received any return.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:73
verses.text: For if no time of recompense is at hand, but our reward is shut up in this present world, ours is the greater loss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:74
verses.text: For ye have believed without jeopardy, but we are slaughtered every day".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:75
verses.text: But all these things he said, not because he had no advantage even in the very suffering, but on account of the weakness of the many, and to establish them in the doctrine of the resurrection: not because he himself was running for hire; for it was a sufficient recompense to him to do that which was pleasing to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:76
verses.text: So that when he adds, "If in this life only we have hoped in Christ, we are of all men most pitiable," it is there again for their sakes, that he might by the fear of this misery overthrow their unbelief of the resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:77
verses.text: And in condescension to their weakness, he thus speaks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:78
verses.text: Since in truth, the great reward is to please Christ at all times: and apart from the recompense, it is a very great requital to be in jeopardy for His sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:79
verses.text: "If the dead are not raised, let us eat and drink for to-morrow we die".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:80
verses.text: This word, be sure, is spoken in mockery: wherefore neither did he bring it forward of himself, but summoned the prophet of loftiest sound, Isaiah, who discoursing of certain insensible and reprobate persons made use of these words, "Who slay oxen and kill sheep to eat flesh and drink wine; who say, Let us eat and drink, for to-morrow we die.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:81
verses.text: These things are revealed to the ears of the Lord of Hosts, and this iniquity shall not be forgiven you, till ye die".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:82
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:83
verses.text: xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:85
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:86
verses.text: ) Now if then they were deprived of pardon who spake thus, much more in the time of Grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:87
verses.text: Then that he might not make his discourse too rough, he dwells not long upon his "reductio ad absurdum," but again turns his discourse to exhortation, saying, Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:88
verses.text: "Be not deceived: evil company doth corrupt good manners".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:89
verses.text: And this he said, both to rebuke them as without understanding, (for here he by a charitable expression, calls "good" that which is easily deceived,) and also, as far as he could, to make some allowance to them for the past with a view to their return, and to remove from them and transfer to others the greater part of his charges, and so by this way also to allure them to repentance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:90
verses.text: Which he doth likewise in the Epistle to the Galatians, saying, "But he that troubleth you shall bear his judgment, whosoever he be".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:91
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:92
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:93
verses.text: )  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:94
verses.text: "Awake up righteously and sin not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:95
verses.text: As if he were speaking to drunkards and madmen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:96
verses.text: For suddenly to cast every thing out of their hands, was the part of drunkards and madmen, in not seeing any longer what they saw nor believing what they had before confessed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:97
verses.text: But what is, "righteously?" with a view to what is profitable and useful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:98
verses.text: For it is possible to awake up unrighteously, when a man is thoroughly roused up to the injury of his own soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:99
verses.text: And well did he add, "sin not," implying that hence were the sins of their unbelief.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:100
verses.text: And in many places he covertly signifies this, that a corrupt life is the parent of evil doctrines; as when he saith, "The love of money is a root of all kinds of evil, which some reaching after, have been led astray from the faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:101
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:102
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:103
verses.text: ) Yea, and many of those who are conscious of wickedness and would fain not pay its penalty are by this fear damaged also in their faith concerning the resurrection: even as they who do very virtuously desire even daily to behold it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:104
verses.text: "For some have no knowledge of God; I speak this to move you to shame".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:105
verses.text: See how again he transfers his accusations to others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:106
verses.text: For he said not, "Ye have no knowledge," but, "some have no knowledge".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:107
verses.text: Because disbelieving the resurrection is the temper of one not fully aware that the power of God is irresistable and sufficient for all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:108
verses.text: For if out of the things which are not He made the things that are, much more will He be able to raise again those which have been dissolved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:109
verses.text: And because he had touched them to the quick and exceedingly mocked them, accusing them of gluttony, of folly, of madness; mitigating those expressions, he saith, "I speak to move you to shame," that is, to set upright, to bring back, to make you better, by this shame of yours.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:110
verses.text: For he feared lest if he cut too deep, he should cause them to start away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:111
verses.text: But let us not consider these things as spoken to them only, but as addressed now also to all who labor under the same disease, and live a corrupt life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:112
verses.text: Since in truth not they who hold corrupt doctrines only, but they too who are holden of grievous sins, are both drunken and frantic.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:113
verses.text: Wherefore also to them may it be justly said, "Awake," and especially to those who are weighed down by the lethargy of avarice; who rob wickedly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:114
verses.text: For there is a robbery which is good, the robbery of Heaven, which injures not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:115
verses.text: And although in respect of money it is impossible for one to become rich, unless another first become poor: yet in spiritual things this is not so, but wholly the reverse: it is impossible that any should become rich without making another's store plentiful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:116
verses.text: For if thou help no one, thou wilt not be able to grow wealthy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:117
verses.text: Thus, whereas in temporal things imparting causes diminution: in spiritual things, on the contrary, imparting works increase, and the not imparting, this produces great poverty and brings on extreme punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:118
verses.text: And this is signified by him who buried the talent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:119
verses.text: Yea, and he too who hath a word of wisdom, by imparting to another increases his own abundance, by making many wise: but he that buries it at home, deprives himself of his abundance by neglecting to win the profit of the many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:120
verses.text: Again, he that had other gifts, by healing many augmented his own gift: and was neither himself emptied by the imparting, and filled many others with his own spiritual gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:121
verses.text: And in all spiritual things this rule abides unshaken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:122
verses.text: Thus also in the Kingdom, he that makes many partakers with himself of the Kingdom will hereby the more completely have the fruits of it in return: but he that studies not to have any partaker will himself be cast out of those many blessings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:123
verses.text: For if the wisdom of this world of sense is not spent, though ten thousand are forcibly seizing it; nor doth the artificer by making many artificers lose his own skill; much less doth he who seizes the Kingdom make it less, but then will our riches be increased when we call many to us for that purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:124
verses.text: Let us seize then the things which cannot be spent but increase whilst we seize them: let us seize the things which admit of none to defraud us of them by false accusation, none to envy us for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:125
verses.text: For so, if there were a place which had a fountain of gold gushing forth with continual flood, and flowing the more as more was drawn from it; and there were another place which had a treasure buried in the earth; from which wouldest thou desire to be enriched? Would it not be from the first? Plainly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:126
verses.text: But that this may not be a mere conception in words, consider the saying in reference to the air and the sun.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:127
verses.text: For these are seized by all, and satisfy all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:128
verses.text: These, however, whether men enjoy or do not enjoy them, abide the same undiminished: but what I spake of is a much greater thing; for spiritual wisdom abides not the same distributed or not distributed: but it rather increases in the distribution.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:129
verses.text: But if any endure not what I have said, but still cleave to the poverty of worldly things, snatching at the things which endure diminution: even in respect of those again, let him call to mind the food of manna (Exod.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:130
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:131
verses.text: ) and tremble at the example of that punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:132
verses.text: For what happened in that instance, this same result may one now also see in the case of covetous men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:133
verses.text: But what then happened in worms were bred from their covetousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:134
verses.text: This also now happens in their case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:135
verses.text: For the measure of the food is the same for all; we having but one stomach to fill; only thou who feedest luxuriously hast more to get rid of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:136
verses.text: And as in that case they who in their houses gathered more than the lawful quantity, gathered not manna, but more worms and rottenness; just so both in luxury and in covetousness, the gluttonous and drunken gather not more dainties but more corruption.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:137
verses.text: Nevertheless, so much worse than they are the men of our time, in that they experienced this once for all and received correction; but these every day bringing into their own houses this worm much more grievous than that, neither perceive it nor are satiated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:138
verses.text: For that these things do resemble those in respect of our useless labor on them: (for in regard of punishment these are much worse:) here is the proof for thee to consider.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:139
verses.text: Wherein, I ask, differs the rich man from the poor? Hath he not one body to clothe? one belly to feed? In what then hath he the advantage? In cares, in spending himself, in disobeying God, in corrupting the flesh, in wasting the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:140
verses.text: Yea, these are the things in which he hath the advantage of the poor: since if he had many stomachs to fill, perhaps he might have somewhat to say, as that his need was more and the necessity of expense greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:141
verses.text: But even "now they may," saith one, "reply, that they fill many bellies, those of their domestics, those of their hand-maidens".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:142
verses.text: But this is done, not through need nor for humanity's sake, but from mere pride: whence one cannot put up with their excuse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:143
verses.text: For why hast thou many servants? Since as in our apparel we ought to follow our need only, and in our table, so also in our servants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:144
verses.text: What need is there then? None at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:145
verses.text: For, in fact, one master need only employ one servant; or rather two or three masters one servant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:146
verses.text: But if this be grievous, consider them that have none and enjoy more prompt attendance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:147
verses.text: For God hath made men sufficient to minister unto themselves, or rather unto their neighbor also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:148
verses.text: And if thou believe it not, hear Paul saying, "These hands ministered unto my necessities, and to them that were with me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:149
verses.text: (Acts xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:150
verses.text: ) After that he, the teacher of the world and worthy of heaven, disdained not to serve innumerable others; dost thou think it a disgrace, unless thou carriest about whole herds of slaves, not knowing that this in truth is what most of all brings shame upon thee? For to that end did God grant us both hands and feet, that we might not stand in need of servants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:151
verses.text: Since not at all for need's sake was the class of slaves introduced, else even along with Adam had a slave been formed; but it is the penalty of sin and the punishment of disobedience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:152
verses.text: But when Christ came, He put an end also to this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:153
verses.text: "For in Christ Jesus there is neither bond nor free".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:154
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:155
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:156
verses.text: ) So that it is not necessary to have a slave: or if it be at all necessary, let it be about one only, or at the most two.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:157
verses.text: What mean the swarms of servants? For as the sellers of sheep and the slave-dealers, so do our rich men take their round, in the baths and in the forum.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:158
verses.text: However, I will not be too exact.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:159
verses.text: We will allow you to keep a second servant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:160
verses.text: But if thou collect many, thou dost it not for humanity's sake, but in self-indulgence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:161
verses.text: Since if it be in care for them, I bid thee occupy none of them in ministering to thyself, but when thou hast purchased them and hast taught them trades whereby to support themselves, let them go free.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:162
verses.text: But when thou scourgest, when thou puttest them in chains, it is no more a work of humanity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:163
verses.text: And I know that I am giving disgust to my hearers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:164
verses.text: But what must I do? For this I am set, and I shall not cease to say these things, whether any thing come of them or not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:165
verses.text: For what means thy clearing the way before thee in the market place? Art thou walking then among wild beasts that thou drivest away them that meet thee? Be not afraid; none of these bite who approach thee and walk near thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:166
verses.text: But dost thou consider it an insult to walk along side of other men? What madness is this, what prodigious folly, when a horse is following close after thee, to think not of his bringing on thee any insult; but if it be a man, unless he be driven an hundred miles off, to reckon that he disgraces thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:167
verses.text: And why hast thou also servants to carry fasces, employing freemen as slaves, or rather thyself living more dishonorably than any slave? For, in truth, meaner than any servant is he who bears about with him so much pride.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:168
verses.text: Therefore they shall not so much as have a sight of the real liberty, who have enslaved themselves to this grievous passion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:169
verses.text: Nay, if thou must drive and clear away, let it not be them that come nigh thee, but thine own pride which thou drivest away; not by thy servant, but by thyself: not with this scourge, but with that which is spiritual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:170
verses.text: Since now thy servant drives away them that walk by thy side, but thou art thyself driven from thine high place more disgracefully by thine own self-will than any servant can drive thy neighbor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:171
verses.text: But if, descending from thy horse, thou wilt drive away pride by humility, thou shalt sit higher and place thyself in greater honor, needing no servant to do this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:172
verses.text: I mean, that when thou art become modest and walkest on the ground, thou wilt be seated on the car of humility which bears thee up to the very heavens, that car which hath winged steeds: but if falling from it, thou pass into that of arrogance, thou wilt be in no better state than the beggars who are drawn along the ground, nay even much more wretched and pitiable than they: since them the imperfection of their bodies compels thus to be drawn, but thee the disease of thine own arrogance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:173
verses.text: "For every one that exalteth himself," saith He, "shall be abused".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:174
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:175
verses.text: xxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:176
verses.text: ) That we then may not be abused but exalted, let us approach towards that exaltation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 39:177
verses.text: For thus also shall we "find rest for our souls" according to the divine oracle, and shall obtain the true and most exalted honor; the which may we all obtain, through the grace and mercy, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:1
verses.text: Homily XLI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:3
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:4
verses.text: ,  But some one will say, How are the dead raised? and with what manner of body do they come? Thou foolish one, that which thou thyself sowest is not quickened, except it die.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:5
verses.text: Gentle and lowly as the apostle is to a great degree every where, he here adopts a style rather pungent, because of the impiety of the gainsayers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:6
verses.text: He is not however content with this, but he also employs reasons and examples, subduing thereby even the very contentious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:7
verses.text: And above he saith, "Since by man came death, by man came also the resurrection of the dead;" but here he solves an objection brought in by the Gentiles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:8
verses.text: And see how again he abates the vehemence of his censure; in that he said not, "but perhaps ye will say," but he set down the objector indefinitely, in order that, although employing his impetuous style with all freedom, he might not too severely wound his hearers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:9
verses.text: And he states two difficulties, one touching the manner of the resurrection, the other, the kind of bodies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:10
verses.text: For of both they on their part made a question, saying, "How is that which hath been dissolved raised up?" and, "with what manner of body do they come?" But what means, "with what manner of body?" It is as if they had said, "with this which hath been wasted, which hath perished, or with some other?"  Then, to point out that the objects of their enquiry are not questionable but admitted points, he at once meets them more sharply, saying, "Thou foolish one, that which thou thyself sowest is not quickened, except it die".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:11
verses.text: Which we also are wont to do in the case of those who gainsay things acknowledged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:12
verses.text: And wherefore did he not at once appeal to the power of God? Because he is discoursing with unbelievers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:13
verses.text: For when his discourse is addressed to believers, he hath not much need of reasons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:14
verses.text: Wherefore having said elsewhere, "He shall change the body of your humiliation, that it may be fashioned like to the body of his glory," (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:15
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:16
verses.text: ) and having indicated somewhat more than the resurrection, he stated no analogies, but instead of any demonstration, brought forward the power of God, going on to say, "according to the working whereby He is able to subject all things to Himself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:17
verses.text: But here he also urges reasons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:18
verses.text: That is, having established it from the Scriptures, he adds also in what comes after, these things over and above, with an eye to them who do not obey the Scriptures; and he saith, "O foolish one, that which Thou sowest:" i-e:, "from thyself thou hast the proof of these things, by what thou doest every day, and doubtest thou yet? Therefore do I call thee foolish because of the things daily done by thine own self thou art ignorant, and being thyself an artificer of a resurrection, thou doubtest concerning God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:19
verses.text: Wherefore very emphatically he said, "what Thou sowest," thou who art mortal and perishing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:20
verses.text: And see how he uses expressions appropriate to the purpose he had in view: thus, "it is not quickened," saith he, "except it die".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:21
verses.text: Leaving, you see, the terms appropriate to seed, as that "it buds," and "grows," and "is dissolved," he adopts those which correspond to our flesh, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:22
verses.text: "it is quickened," and, "except it die;" which do not properly belong to seeds, but to bodies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:23
verses.text: And he said not, "after it is dead it lives," but, which is a greater thing, "therefore it lives, because it dies".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:24
verses.text: Seest thou, what I am always observing, that he continually gives their argument the contrary turn? Thus what they made a sure sign of our not rising again, the same he makes a demonstration of our rising.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:25
verses.text: For they said, "the body rises not again, because it is dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:26
verses.text: What then doth he, retorting their argument, say? "Nay, but unless it died, it could not rise again: and therefore it rises again, because it died".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:27
verses.text: For as Christ more clearly signifies this very thing, in the words, "Except a grain of wheat fall into the ground and die, it abideth by itself alone: but if it die, it beareth much fruit:" (John xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:28
verses.text: ) thence also Paul, drawing this example, said not, "it doth not live," but, "is not quickened;" again assuming the power of God and showing that not the nature of the ground, but God Himself, brings it all to pass.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:29
verses.text: And what can be the reason that he did not bring that forward, which was more akin to the subject: I mean, the seed of mankind? (For our generation too begins from a sort of decay, even as that of the corn.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:30
verses.text: ) Because it was not of equal force, but the latter was a more complete instance: for he wants a case of something that perished entirely, whereas this was but a part; wherefore he rather alleges the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:31
verses.text: Besides, that proceeds from a living body and falls into a living womb; but here it is no flesh, but the earth into which the seed is cast, and into the same it is dissolved, like the body which is dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:32
verses.text: Wherefore on this account too the example was more appropriate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:33
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:34
verses.text: "And he who soweth, soweth not that body that shall be".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:35
