verses.text: For the things before spoken meet the question, "how they are raised;" but this, the doubt, "with what manner of body they come".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:36
verses.text: But what is, "thou sowest not that body which shall be?" Not an entire ear of corn, nor new grain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:37
verses.text: For here his discourse no longer regards the resurrection, but the manner of the resurrection, what is the kind of body which shall rise again; as whether it be of the same kind, or better and more glorious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:38
verses.text: And he takes both from the same analogy, intimating that it will be much better.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:39
verses.text: But the heretics, considering none of these things, dart in upon us and say, "one body falls and another body rises again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:40
verses.text: How then is there a resurrection? For the resurrection is of that which was fallen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:41
verses.text: But where is that wonderful and surprising trophy over death, if one body fall and another rise again? For he will no longer appear to have given back that which he took captive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:42
verses.text: And how can the alleged analogy suit the things before mentioned?" Why, it is not one substance that is sown, and another that is raised, but the same substance improved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:43
verses.text: Else neither will Christ have resumed the same body when He became the first-fruits of them that rise again: but according to you He threw aside the former body, although it had not sinned, and took another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:44
verses.text: Whence then is that other? For this body was from the Virgin, but that, whence was it? Seest thou to what absurdity the argument hath come round? For wherefore shows He the very prints of the nails? Was it not to prove that it is that same body which was crucified, and the same again that rose from the dead? And what means also His type of Jonah? For surely it was not one Jonah that was swallowed up and another that was cast out upon dry land.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:45
verses.text: And why did He also say, "Destroy this temple, and in three days I will raise it up?" For that which was destroyed, the same clearly He raised again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:46
verses.text: Wherefore also the Evangelist added, that "He spake of the temple of His body".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:47
verses.text: (John ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:49
verses.text: )  What is that then which he saith, "Thou sowest not the body that shall be?" i-e: not the ear of corn: for it is the same, and not the same; the same, because the substance is the same; but not the same, because this is more excellent, the substance remaining the same but its beauty becoming greater, and the same body rising up new.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:50
verses.text: Since if this were not so, there were no need of a resurrection, I mean if it were not to rise again improved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:51
verses.text: For why did He at all pull down His house, except He were about to build it more glorious?  This now, you see, he said to them who think that it is utter corruption.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:52
verses.text: Next, that none again might suspect from this place that another body is spoken of, he qualifies the dark saying, and himself interprets what he had spoken, not allowing the hearer to turn his thoughts from hence in any other direction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:53
verses.text: What need is there then of our reasonings? Hear himself speaking, and explaining the phrase, "Thou sowest not the body that shall be".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:54
verses.text: For he straightway adds, "but a bare grain, it may chance of wheat, or of some other kind;" i-e:, it is not the body that shall be; not so clothed, for instance; not having a stalk and beard, but "a bare grain, it may chance of wheat, or of some other kind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:55
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:56
verses.text: "But God giveth it a body even as it pleased Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:57
verses.text: "Yes," saith one, "but in that case it is the work of nature".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:58
verses.text: Of what nature, tell me? For in that case likewise God surely doeth the whole; not nature, nor the earth, nor the rain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:59
verses.text: Wherefore also he making these things manifest, leaves out both earth and rain, atmosphere, sun, and hands of husbandmen, and subjoins, "God giveth it a body as it pleased Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:60
verses.text: Do not thou therefore curiously inquire, nor busy thyself with the how and in what manner, when thou hearest of the power and will of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:61
verses.text: "And to each seed a body of its own".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:62
verses.text: Where then is the alien matter which they speak of? For He giveth to each "his own".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:63
verses.text: So that when he saith, "Thou sowest not that which shall be," he saith not this, that one substance is raised up instead of another, but that it is improved, that it is more glorious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:64
verses.text: For "to each of the seeds," saith he, "a body of its own".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:65
verses.text: From hence in what follows, he introducing also the difference of the resurrection which shall then be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:66
verses.text: For do not suppose, because grain is sown and all come up ears of corn, that therefore there is also in the resurrection an equality of honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:67
verses.text: For in the first place, neither in seeds is there only one rank, but some are more valuable, and some inferior.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:68
verses.text: Wherefore also he added, "to each seed a body of its own".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:69
verses.text: However, he is not content with this, but seeks another difference greater and more manifest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:70
verses.text: For that thou mayest not, when hearing, as I said, that all rise again, suppose that all enjoy the same reward; he laid before even in the preceding verses the seeds of this thought, saying, "But each in his own order".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:71
verses.text: But he brings it out here also more clearly, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:72
verses.text: "All flesh is not the same flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:73
verses.text: For why speak I, saith he, in respect of seeds? In respect of bodies let us agitate this point, concerning which we are discoursing now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:74
verses.text: Wherefore also he addeth, and saith,  "But there is one flesh of men, another flesh of beasts, another of birds, and another of fishes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:75
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:76
verses.text: "There are also celestial bodies, and bodies terrestrial; but the glory of the celestial is one, and the glory of the terrestrial is another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:77
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:78
verses.text: "There is one glory of the sun, and another glory of the moon, and another glory of the stars: for one star differeth from another star in glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:79
verses.text: And what means he by these expressions? Wherefore from the resurrection of the body did he throw himself into the discourse of the stars and the sun? He did not throw himself out, neither did he break off from his purpose; far from it: but he still keeps to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:80
verses.text: For whereas he had established the doctrine concerning the resurrection, he intimates in what follows that great will be then the difference of glory, though there be but one resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:81
verses.text: And for the present he divides the whole into two: into "bodies celestial," and "bodies terrestrial".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:82
verses.text: For that the bodies are raised again, he signified by the corn: but that they are not all in the same glory, he signifies by this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:83
verses.text: For as the disbelief of the resurrection makes men supine, so again it makes them indolent to think that all are vouchsafed the same reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:84
verses.text: Wherefore he corrects both.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:85
verses.text: And the one in the preceeding verses he had completed; but this he begins now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:86
verses.text: And having made two ranks, of the righteous and of sinners, these same two he subdivides again into many parts, signifying that neither righteous nor sinners shall obtain the same; neither righteous men, all of them, alike with other righteous, nor sinners with other sinners.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:87
verses.text: Now he makes, you see, first, one separation between righteous and sinners, where he says, "bodies celestial, and bodies terrestrial:" by the "terrestrial" intimating the latter, and by the "celestial," the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:88
verses.text: Then farther he introduces a difference of sinners from sinners, saying, "All flesh is not the same flesh, but there is one flesh of fishes, another of birds, and another of beasts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:89
verses.text: And yet all are bodies; but some are in more, and some in lesser vileness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:90
verses.text: And that in their manner of living too, and in their very constitution.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:91
verses.text: And having said this, he ascends again to the heaven, saying, "There is one glory of the sun, and another glory of the moon".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:92
verses.text: For as in the earthly bodies there is a difference, so also in the heavenly; and that difference no ordinary one, but reaching even to the uttermost: there being not only a difference between sun and moon, and stars, but also between stars and stars.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:93
verses.text: For what though they be all in the heaven? yet some have a larger, others a less share of glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:94
verses.text: What do we learn from hence? That although they be all in God's kingdom, all shall not enjoy the same reward; and though all sinners be in hell, all shall not endure the same punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:95
verses.text: Wherefore he added,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:96
verses.text: "So also is the resurrection of the dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:97
verses.text: "So," How? with considerable difference.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:98
verses.text: Then leaving this doctrine as sufficiently proved, he again comes to the proof itself of the resurrection and the manner of it, saying,   "It is sown in corruption, it is raised in incorruption".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:99
verses.text: And observe his consideration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:100
verses.text: As in the case of seeds, he used the term proper to bodies, saying, "it is not quickened, except it die:" so in the case of bodies, the expression belonging to seeds, saying, "it is sown in corruption, it is raised in incorruption".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:101
verses.text: He said not, "is produced," that thou mightest not think it a work of the earth, but is "raised".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:102
verses.text: And by sowing here, he means not our generation in the womb, but the burial in the earth of our dead bodies, their dissolution, their ashes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:103
verses.text: Wherefore having said, "it is sown in corruption, it is raised in incorruption," he adds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:104
verses.text: "It is sown in dishonor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:105
verses.text: For what is more unsightly than a corpse in dissolution? "It is raised in glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:106
verses.text: "It is sown in weakness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:107
verses.text: For before thirty days the whole is gone, and the flesh cannot keep itself together nor hold out for one day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:108
verses.text: "It is raised in power".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:109
verses.text: For there shall nothing prevail against it for all the future.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:110
verses.text: Here is why he stood in need of those former analogies, lest many on hearing of these things, that they are "raised in incorruption and glory and power," might suppose that there is no difference among those who rise again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:111
verses.text: For all indeed rise again, both in power and in incorruption; and in this glory of their incorruption yet are not all in the same state of honor and safety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:112
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:113
verses.text: "It is sown a natural body, it is raised a spiritual body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:114
verses.text: There is a natural body, and there is a spiritual body".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:115
verses.text: What sayest thou? Is not "this" body spiritual? It is indeed spiritual, but that will be much more so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:116
verses.text: For now oftentimes both the abundant grace of the Holy Ghost flies away on men's committing great sins; and again, the Spirit continuing present, the life of the flesh depends on the soul: and the result in such a case is a void, without the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:117
verses.text: But in that day not so: rather he abides continually in the flesh of the righteous, and the victory shall be His, the natural soul also being present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:118
verses.text: For either it was some such thing which he intimated by saying, "a spiritual body," or that it shall be lighter and more subtle and such as even to be wafted upon air; or rather he meant both these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:119
verses.text: And if thou disbelieve the doctrine, behold the heavenly bodies which are so glorious and (for this time) so durable, and abide in undecaying tranquillity; and believe thou from hence, that God can also make these corruptible bodies incorruptible and much more excellent than those which are visible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:120
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:121
verses.text: "So also it is written, (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:122
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:123
verses.text: ) the first man Adam became a living soul: the last Adam became a life-giving Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:124
verses.text: And yet the one indeed is written, but the other not written.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:125
verses.text: How then said he, "it is written?" He modified the expression according to the issue of events: as he is wont continually to do: and indeed as it is the way of every prophet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:126
verses.text: For so Jerusalem, the prophet said, should be "called a city of righteousness;" (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:127
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:128
verses.text: ) yet it was not so called.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:129
verses.text: What then? Did the prophet speak false? By no means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:130
verses.text: For he is speaking of the issue of events.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:131
verses.text: And that Christ too should be called Immanuel; (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:132
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:133
verses.text: ) yet was he not so called.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:134
verses.text: But the facts utter this voice; so also here, "the last Adam became a life-giving Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:135
verses.text: And these things he said that thou mayest learn that the signs and pledges both of the present life and of that which is to come have already come upon us; to wit, of the present life, Adam, and of the life to come, Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:136
verses.text: For since he sets down the better things as matters of hope, he signifies that their beginning hath already come to pass, and their root and their fountain been brought to light.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:137
verses.text: But if the root and the fountain be evident to all, there is no need to doubt of the fruits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:138
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, "The last Adam became a life-giving Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:139
verses.text: And elsewhere too, He "shall quicken your mortal bodies through His Spirit that dwelleth in you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:140
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:141
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:142
verses.text: ) It is the Spirit's work then to quicken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:143
verses.text: Further, lest any should say, "why are the worse things the elder? and why hath the one sort, to wit, the natural, come to pass not merely as far as the first-fruits, but altogether; the other as far as the first-fruits only?"—he signifies that the principles also of each were so ordered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:144
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:145
verses.text: "For that is not first," saith he, "which is spiritual, but that which is natural, then that which is spiritual".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:146
verses.text: And he saith not, why, but is content with the ordinance of God, having the evidence from the facts testifying to that most excellent oeconomy of God, and implying that our state is always going forward to the better; at the same time by this also adding credibility to his argument.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:147
verses.text: For if the lesser have come to pass, much more ought we to expect the better.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:148
verses.text: Since then we are to enjoy so great blessings, let us take our station in this array, and bewail not the departed, but rather those that have ended their life ill.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:149
verses.text: For so the husbandman, when he sees the grain dissolving, doth not mourn; rather, as long as he beholds it continuing solid in the ground he is in fear and trembling, but when he sees it dissolved rejoices.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:150
verses.text: For the beginning of the future crop is its dissolving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:151
verses.text: So let us also then rejoice when the corruptible house falls, when the man is sown.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:152
verses.text: And marvel not if he called the burial "a sowing;" for, in truth, this is the better sowing: inasmuch as that sowing is succeeded by deaths and labors and dangers and cares; but this, if we lived well, by crowns and rewards; and that, by corruption and death but this by incorruption and immortality, and those infinite blessings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:153
verses.text: To that kind of sowing there went embraces and pleasures and sleep: but to this, only a voice coming down from heaven, and all is at once brought to perfection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:154
verses.text: And he that rises again is no more led to a life full of toil, but to a place where anguish and sorrow and sighing are fled away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:155
verses.text: If thou requirest protection and therefore mournest thy husband, betake thyself to God, the common Protector and Saviour and Benefactor of all, to that irresistible alliance, to that ready aid, to that abiding shelter which is every where present, and is as a wall unto us on every side.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:156
verses.text: "But your intercourse was a thing desirable and lovely".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:157
verses.text: I too know it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:158
verses.text: But if thou wilt trust sound reason with this grief, and wilt consider with thyself who hath taken him away, and that by nobly bearing it thou offerest thy mind as a sacrifice to our God, even this wave will not be too strong for thee to stem.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:159
verses.text: And that which time brings to pass, the same do thou by thy self-command.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:160
verses.text: But if thou shalt yield to weakness, thine emotion will cease indeed in time, but it will bring thee no reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:161
verses.text: And together with these reasons collect also examples, some in the present life, some in the Holy Scriptures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:162
verses.text: Consider that Abraham slew his own son, and neither shed a tear nor uttered a bitter word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:163
verses.text: "But he," you say, "was Abraham".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:164
verses.text: Nay, thou surely hast been called to a nobler field of action.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:165
verses.text: And Job grieved indeed, but so much as was proper for a father who loved his children and was very solicitious for the departed; whereas what we now do, is surely the part of haters and enemies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:166
verses.text: For if when a man was taken up to court and crowned, thou wert smiting thyself and lamenting, I should not say that thou wast a friend of him who was crowned, but a great enemy and adversary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:167
verses.text: "Nay," say you, "not even as it is do I mourn for him, but for myself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:168
verses.text: Well, but this is not the part of an affectionate person, to wish for thine own sake that he were still in the conflict and subject to the uncertainty of the future, when he might be crowned and come to anchor; or that he should be tossed in mid ocean, when he might have been in port.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:169
verses.text: "But I know not whither he hath gone," say you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:170
verses.text: Wherefore knowest thou not, tell me? For according as he lived well or otherwise, it is evident whither he will go.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:171
verses.text: "Nay, on this very account I lament," say you, "because he departed being a sinner".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:172
verses.text: This is a mere pretext and excuse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:173
verses.text: For if this were the reason of thy mourning for the departed, thou oughtest to have formed and corrected him, when he was alive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:174
verses.text: The fact is thou dost every where look to what concerns thyself, not him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:175
verses.text: But grant that he departed with sin upon him, even on this account one ought to rejoice, that he was stopped short in his sins and added not to his iniquity; and help him as far as possible, not by tears, but by prayers and supplications and alms and offerings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:176
verses.text: For not unmeaningly have these things been devised, nor do we in vain make mention of the departed in the course of the divine mysteries, and approach God in their behalf, beseeching the Lamb Who is before us, Who taketh away the sin of the world;—not in vain, but that some refreshment may thereby ensue to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:177
verses.text: Not in vain doth he that standeth by the altar cry out when the tremendous mysteries are celebrated, "For all that have fallen asleep in Christ, and for those who perform commemorations in their behalf".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:178
verses.text: For if there were no commemorations for them, these things would not have been spoken: since our service is not a mere stage show, God forbid! yea, it is by the ordinance of the Spirit that these things are done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:179
verses.text: Let us then give them aid and perform commemoration for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:180
verses.text: For if the children of Job were purged by the sacrifice of their father, why dost thou doubt that when we too offer for the departed, some consolation arises to them? since God is wont to grant the petitions of those who ask for others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:181
verses.text: And this Paul signified saying, "that in a manifold Person your gift towards us bestowed by many may be acknowledged with thanksgiving on your behalf".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:182
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:183
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:184
verses.text: ) Let us not then be weary in giving aid to the departed, both by offering on their behalf and obtaining prayers for them: for the common Expiation of the world is even before us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:185
verses.text: Therefore with boldness do we then intreat for the whole world, and name their names with those of martyrs, of confessors, of priests.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:186
verses.text: For in truth one body are we all, though some members are more glorious than others; and it is possible from every source to gather pardon for them, from our prayers, from our gifts in their behalf, from those whose names are named with theirs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:187
verses.text: Why therefore dost thou grieve? Why mourn, when it is in thy power to gather so much pardon for the departed?   Is it then that thou art become desolate and hast lost a protector? Nay, never mention this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:188
verses.text: For thou hast not surely lost thy God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:189
verses.text: And so, as long as thou hast Him, He will be better to thee than husband and father and child and kinsman: since even when they were alive, He it was who did all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:190
verses.text: These things therefore think upon, and say with David, "The Lord is my light and my Saviour, whom shall I fear? (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:191
verses.text: xxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:192
verses.text: ) Say, Thou art a Father of the fatherless, and a Judge of the widows: "(Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:193
verses.text: lxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:194
verses.text: ) and draw down His aid, and thou shalt have Him to care for thee now more than before, by how much thou art in a state of greater difficulty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:195
verses.text: Or hast thou lost a child? Thou hast not lost it; say not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:196
verses.text: This thing is sleep, not death; removal, not destruction; a journeying from the worse unto the better.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:197
verses.text: Do not then provoke God to anger; but propitiate Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:198
verses.text: For if thou bearest it nobly, there will thence accrue some relief both to the departed and to thyself; but if the contrary, thou dost the more kindle God's anger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:199
verses.text: For if when a servant was chastised by his master, thou didst stand by and complain, thou wouldest the more exasperate the master against thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:200
verses.text: Do not then so; but give thanks, that hereby also this cloud of sadness may be scattered from thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:201
verses.text: Say with that blessed one, "the Lord gave, and the Lord hath taken away".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:202
verses.text: (Job i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:203
verses.text: ) Consider how many more well-pleasing in His sight have never received children at all, nor been called fathers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:204
verses.text: "Nor would I wish to have been so," say you, "for surely it were better not to have had experience than after having tasted the pleasure to fall from it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:205
verses.text: Nay, I beseech thee, say not so, provoke not thus also the Lord to wrath: but for what thou hast received, give Him thanks; and for what thou hast not to the end, give Him glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:206
verses.text: Job said not that which thou sayest unthankfully, "it were better not to have received," but both for the one he gave thanks, saying, "The Lord gave;" and for the other he blessed God, saying, "The Lord hath taken away, blessed be the name of the Lord for ever".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:207
verses.text: And his wife he thus silenced, justifying himself against her, and uttering those admirable words, "Have we received good at the hand of the Lord, and shall we not receive evil?" And yet after this a fiercer temptation befel him: yet was he not even thus unnerved, but in like manner bore it nobly and glorified God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:208
verses.text: This also do thou, and consider with thyself that man hath not taken him, but God who made him, who more than thyself cares for him and knows what is good for him: who is no enemy nor lier-in-wait.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:209
verses.text: See how many, living, have made life intolerable to their parents.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:210
verses.text: "But seest thou not the right-hearted ones?" say you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:211
verses.text: I see these too, but even these are not so safe as thy child is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:212
verses.text: For though they are now approved, yet it is uncertain what their end will be; but for him thou hast no longer any fear, nor dost thou tremble lest anything should happen to him or he experience any change.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:213
verses.text: These things also do thou consider respecting a good wife and guardian of thine house, and for all things give thanks unto God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:214
verses.text: And even if thou shalt lose a wife, give thanks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:215
verses.text: Perhaps God's will is to lead thee to continence, He calls thee to a nobler field of conflict, He was pleased to set thee free from this bond.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 40:216
verses.text: If we thus command ourselves, we shall both gain the joy of this life and obtain the crowns which are to come, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:1
verses.text: Homily XLII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:3
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:4
verses.text: The first man is of the earth, earthy: the second man is the Lord from heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:5
verses.text: Having said that "the natural was first," and "the spiritual afterward," he again states another difference, speaking of "the earthy" and "the heavenly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:6
verses.text: For the first difference was between the present life and that which is to come: but this between that before grace and that after grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:7
verses.text: And he stated it with a view to the most excellent way of life, saying,—(for to hinder men, as I said, from such confidence in the resurrection as would make them neglectful of their practice and of perfection, from this topic also again he renders them anxious and exhorts to virtue, saying,)—"The first man is of the earth, earthy; the second man is the Lord from heaven:" calling the whole by the name of "man," and naming the one from the better, and the other from the worst part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:8
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:9
verses.text: "As is the earthy, such are they also that are earthy:" so shall they perish and have an end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:10
verses.text: "As is the heavenly, such are they also that are heavenly:" so shall they abide immortal and glorious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:11
verses.text: What then? Did not This Man too die? He died indeed, but received no injury therefrom, yea rather by this He put an end to death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:12
verses.text: Seest thou how on this part of his subject also, he makes use of death to establish the doctrine of the resurrection? "For having, as I said before, the beginning and the head," so he speaks, "doubt not of the whole body".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:13
verses.text: Moreover also he frames hereby his advice concerning the best way of living, proposing standards of a lofty and severe life and of that which is not such, and bringing forward the principles of both these, of the one Christ, but of the other Adam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:14
verses.text: Therefore neither did he simply say, "of the earth," but "earthy," i-e:, "gross, nailed down to things present:" and again with respect to Christ the reverse, "the Lord from heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:15
verses.text: But if any should say, "therefore the Lord hath not a body because He is said to be "from heaven," although what is said before is enough to stop their mouths: yet nothing hinders our silencing them from this consideration also: viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:16
verses.text: what is, "the Lord from heaven?" Doth he speak of His nature, or His most perfect life? It is I suppose evident to every one that he speaks of His life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:17
verses.text: Wherefore also he adds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:18
verses.text: "As we have borne the image of the earthy," i-e:, as we have done evil, "let us also bear the image of the heavenly," i-e:, let us practise all goodness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:19
verses.text: But besides this, I would fain ask thee, is it of nature that it is said, "he that is of the earth, earthy," and, "the Lord from heaven?" "Yea," saith one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:20
verses.text: What then? Was Adam only "earthy," or had he also another kind of substance congenial with heavenly and incorporeal beings, which the Scripture calls "soul," and "spirit?" Every one sees that he had this also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:21
verses.text: Therefore neither was the Lord from above only although He is said to be "from heaven," but He had also assumed our flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:22
verses.text: But Paul's meaning is such as this: "as we have borne the image of the earthy," i-e:, evil deeds, "let us also bear the image of the heavenly," the manner of life which is in the heavens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:23
verses.text: Whereas if he were speaking of nature, the thing needed not exhortation nor advice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:24
verses.text: So that hence also it is evident that the expression relates to our manner of life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:25
verses.text: Wherefore also he introduces the saying in the manner of advice and calls it an "image," here too again showing that he is speaking of conduct, not of nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:26
verses.text: For therefore are we become earthy, because we have done evil: not because we were originally formed "earthy," but because we sinned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:27
verses.text: For sin came first, and then death and then the sentence, "Dust thou art, and unto dust shalt thou return".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:28
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:29
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:30
verses.text: ) Then also entered in the swarm of the passions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:31
verses.text: For it is not simply the being born "of earth" that makes a man "earthy," (since the Lord also was of this mass and lump,) but the doing earthly things, even as also he is made "heavenly" by performing things meet for heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:32
verses.text: But enough: for why need I labor overmuch in the proof of this, when the apostle himself goes on to unfold the thought to us, thus saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:33
verses.text: "Now this I say, brethren, that flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:34
verses.text: Seest thou how he explains himself again, relieving us of the trouble? which he often doth: for by flesh he here denotes men's evil deeds, which he hath done also elsewhere; as when he saith, "But ye are not in the flesh:" and again, "So then they that are in the flesh cannot please God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:35
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:36
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:38
verses.text: ) So that when he saith, "Now this I say," he means nothing else than this: "therefore said I these things that thou mayest learn that evil deeds conduct not to a kingdom".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:39
verses.text: Thus from the resurrection he straightway introduced also the doctrine of the kingdom also; wherefore also he adds, "neither doth corruption inherit incorruption," i-e:, neither shall wickedness inherit that glory and the enjoyment of the things incorruptible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:40
verses.text: For in many other places he calls wickedness by this name, saying, "He that soweth to the flesh, shall of the flesh reap corruption".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:41
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:42
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:43
verses.text: ) Now if he were speaking of the body and not of evil doing, he would not have said "corruption".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:44
verses.text: For he nowhere calls the body "corruption," since neither is it corruption, but a thing corruptible: wherefore proceeding to discourse also of it, he calls it not "corruption," but "corruptible," saying, "for this corruptible must put on incorruption".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:45
verses.text: Next, having completed his advice concerning our manner of life, according to his constant custom blending closely subject with subject, he passes again to the doctrine of the resurrection of the body: as follows:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:46
verses.text: "Behold, I tell you a mystery".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:47
verses.text: It is something awful and ineffable and which all know not, which he is about to speak of: which also indicates the greatness of the honor he confers on them; I mean, his speaking mysteries to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:48
verses.text: But what is this?  "We shall not all sleep, but we shall all be changed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:49
verses.text: He means as follows: "we shall not all die, 'but we shall all be changed,'" even those who die not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:50
verses.text: For they too are mortal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:51
verses.text: "Do not thou therefore because thou diest, on this account fear," saith he, "as if thou shouldest not rise again: for there are, there are some who shall even escape this, and yet this suffices them not for that resurrection, but even those bodies which die not must be changed and be transformed into incorruption".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:52
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:53
verses.text: "In a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trump".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:54
verses.text: After he had discoursed much of the resurrection, then opportunely he points out also its very marvellous character.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:55
verses.text: As thus: "not this only," saith he, "is wonderful that our bodies first turn to corruption, and then are raised; nor that the bodies which rise again after their corruption are better than these present ones; nor that they pass on to a much better state, nor that each receives back his own and none that of another; but that things so many and so great, and surpassing all man's reason and conception, are done "in a moment," i-e:, in an instant of time: and to show this more clearly, "in the twinkling of an eye," saith he, "while one can wink an eyelid".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:56
verses.text: Further, because he had said a great thing and full of astonishment; that so many and so great results should take place so quickly; he alleges, to prove it, the credibility of Him who performs it; as follows, "For the trumpet shall sound, and the dead shall be raised incorruptible, and we shall be changed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:57
verses.text: The expression, "we," he uses not of himself, but of them that are then found alive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:58
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:59
verses.text: "For this corruptible must put on incorruption".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:60
verses.text: Thus lest any, hearing that "flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God," should suppose that our bodies do not rise again; he adds, "this corruptible must put on incorruption, and this mortal must put on immortality".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:61
verses.text: Now the body is "corruptible," the body is "mortal:" so that the body indeed remains, for it is the body which is put on; but its mortality and corruption vanish away, when immortality and incorruption come upon it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:62
verses.text: Do not thou therefore question hereafter how it shall live an endless life, now that thou hast heard of its becoming incorruptible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:63
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:64
verses.text: "But when this corruptible shall have put on incorruption, and this moral shall have put on immortality, then shall come to pass the saying that is written, Death is swallowed up in victory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:65
verses.text: Thus, since he was speaking of great and secret things, he again takes prophecy (Hosea xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:66
verses.text: ) to confirm his word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:67
verses.text: "Death is swallowed up in victory:" i-e:, utterly; not so much as a fragment of it remains nor a hope of returning, incorruption having consumed corruption.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:68
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:69
verses.text: "O death, where is thy sting? O grave, where is thy victory?"  Seest thou his noble soul? how even as one who is offering sacrifices for victory, having become inspired and seeing already things future as things past, he leaps and tramples upon death fallen at his feet, and shouts a cry of triumph over its head where it lies, exclaiming mightily and saying, "O death, where is thy sting? O grave, where is thy victory?" It is clean gone, it is perished, it is utterly vanished away, and in vain hast thou done all those former things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:70
verses.text: For He not only disarmed death and vanquished it, but even destroyed it, and made it quite cease from being.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:71
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:72
verses.text: "Now the sting of death is sin; and the power of sin is the law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:73
verses.text: Seest thou how the discourse is of the death of the body? therefore also of the resurrection of the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:74
verses.text: For if these bodies do not rise again, how is death "swallowed up?" And not this only, but how is "the law the power of sin?" For that "sin" indeed is "the sting of death," and more bitter than it, and by it hath its power, is evident; but how is "the law also the power" thereof? Because without the law sin was weak, being practised indeed, but not able so entirely to condemn: since although the evil took place, it was not so clearly pointed out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:75
verses.text: So that it was no small change which the law brought in, first causing us to know sin better, and then enhancing the punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:76
verses.text: And if meaning to check sin it did but develop it more fearfully, this is no charge against the physician, but against the abuse of the remedy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:77
verses.text: Since even the presence of Christ made the Jews' burden heavier, yet must we not therefore blame it, but while we the more admire it, we must hate them the more, for having been injured by things which ought to have profited them? Yea, to show that it was not the law of itself which gives strength to sin, Christ Himself fulfilled it all and was without sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:78
verses.text: But I would have thee consider how from this topic also he confirms the resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:79
verses.text: For if this were the cause of death, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:80
verses.text: our committing sin, and if Christ came and took away sin, and delivered us from it through baptism, and together with sin put an end also to the law in the transgression of which sin consists, why doubtest thou any more of the resurrection? For whence, after all this, is death to prevail? Through the law? Nay, it is done away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:81
verses.text: Through sin? Nay, it is clean destroyed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:82
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:83
verses.text: "But thanks be to God, which giveth us the victory through our Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:84
verses.text: For the trophy He Himself erected, but the crowns He hath caused us also to partake of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:85
verses.text: And this not of debt, but of mere mercy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:86
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:87
verses.text: "Wherefore, brethren, be ye steadfast, unmoveable".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:88
verses.text: Just and seasonable is this exhortation after all that had gone before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:89
verses.text: For nothing so disquiets as the thought that we are buffeted without cause or profit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:90
verses.text: "Always abounding in the work of the Lord:" i-e:, in the pure life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:91
verses.text: And he said not, "working that which is good," but "abounding;" that we might do it abundantly, and might overpass the lists.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:92
verses.text: "Knowing that your labor is not in vain in the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:93
verses.text: What sayest thou? Labor again? But followed by crowns, and those above the heavens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:94
verses.text: For that former labor on man's expulsion from paradise, was the punishment of his transgressions; but this is the ground of the rewards to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:95
verses.text: So that it cannot in fact be labor, both on this account and by reason of the great help which it receives from above: which is the cause of his adding also, "in the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:96
verses.text: For the purpose of the former was that we might suffer punishment; but of this, that we might obtain the good things to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:97
verses.text: Let us not therefore sleep, my beloved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:98
verses.text: For it cannot, it cannot be that any one by sloth should attain to the kingdom of heaven, nor they that live luxuriously and softly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:99
verses.text: Yea it is a great thing, if straining ourselves and "keeping under the body" and enduring innumerable labors, we are able to reach those blessings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:100
verses.text: See ye not how vast this distance between heaven and earth? And how great a conflict is at hand? And how prone a thing to evil man is? And how easily sin "besets us?" And how many snares are in the way?  Why then do we draw upon ourselves so great cares over and above those of nature, and give ourselves more trouble, and make our burden greater? Is it not enough, our having to care for our food and clothing and houses? Is it not enough to take thought for things necessary? Although even from these Christ withdraws us, saying, "Be not anxious for your life what ye shall eat, neither for your body what ye shall put on".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:101
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:102
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:103
verses.text: ) But if one ought not to be anxious for necessary food and clothing, nor for to-morrow; they who bring on so great a mass of rubbish and bury themselves under it, when shall they shall have power to emerge? Hast thou not heard Paul saying, "No soldier on service entangleth himself in the affairs of this life?" ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:104
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:105
verses.text: ) But we even live luxuriously and eat and drink to excess and endure buffeting for external things, but in the things of heaven behave ourselves unmanly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:106
verses.text: Know ye not that the promise is too high for man? It cannot be that one walking on the ground should ascend the arches of heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:107
verses.text: But we do not even study to live like men, but are become worse than the brutes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:108
verses.text: Know ye not before what a tribunal we are to stand? Do ye not consider that both for our words and thoughts an account is demanded of us, and we take no heed even to our actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:109
verses.text: "For whosoever looketh on a woman," saith He, "to lust after her hath already committed adultery with her".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:110
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:111
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:112
verses.text: ) And yet they who must be accountable for a mere idle look, refuse not even to lie rotting in the sin itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:113
verses.text: "Whosoever shall say to his brother, Thou fool, shall be cast into hell fire".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:114
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:115
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:116
verses.text: ) But we even dishonor them with ten thousand reproaches and plot against them craftily.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:117
verses.text: "He that loveth one that loveth him is no better than the heathen:" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:118
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:120
verses.text: ) but we even envy them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:121
verses.text: What indulgence then shall we have, when commanded as we are to pass over the old lines, we weave ourselves a thread of life by a yet more scanty measure than theirs? What plea shall deliver us? Who will stand up and help us when we are punished? There is no one; but it must needs be that wailing and weeping and gnashing our teeth, we shall be led away tortured into that rayless gloom, the pangs which no prayer can avert, the punishments which cannot be assuaged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:122
verses.text: Wherefore I entreat and beseech, and lay hold of your very knees, that whilst we have this scant viaticum of life, you would be pricked in your hearts by what has been said, that you would be converted, that you would become better men; that we may not, like that rich man, lament to no purpose in that world after our departure, and continue thenceforth in incurable wailings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:123
verses.text: For though thou shouldest have father or son or friend or any soever who hath confidence towards God, none of these shall ever deliver thee, thine own works having destroyed thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:124
verses.text: For such is that tribunal: it judges by our actions alone, and in no other way is it possible there to be saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:125
verses.text: And these things I say, not to grieve you nor to throw you into despair, but lest nourished by vain and cold hopes, and placing confidence in this person or that, we should neglect our own proper goodness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 41:126
verses.text: For if we be slothful, there will be neither righteous man nor prophet nor apostle nor any one to stand by us; but if we have been earnest, having in sufficiency the plea which comes from each man's own works, we shall depart with confidence, and shall obtain the good things that are laid up for them that love God; to which may we all attain, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:1
verses.text: Homily XLIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:3
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:4
verses.text: Now concerning the collection for the saints, as I gave order to the Churches of Galatia, so also do ye.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:5
verses.text: Having completed his discourse concerning doctrines, and being about to enter upon that which belongs rather to morals, he dismisses every thing else and proceeds to the chief of good things, discoursing about alms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:6
verses.text: Nor does he discuss morals in general, but when he hath treated of this matter alone, he leaves off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:7
verses.text: A thing however obviously unlike what he did every where else; for of alms and of temperance and of meekness and of long-suffering and of all the rest, he treats in the other Epistles in the conclusion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:8
verses.text: For what reason then doth he handle here this part only of practical morality? Because the greater part also of what had been spoken before was of an ethical nature: I mean, where he chastised the fornicator; where he was correcting those who go to law among Gentiles; where he terrified the drunkards and the gluttons; where he condemned the seditious, the contentious, and those who loved to have the preeminence; where those who unworthily approach the Mysteries were delivered over by him unto that intolerable sentence; where he discoursed concerning love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:9
verses.text: For this cause, I say, the subject which most pressed on him, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:10
verses.text: the aid required for the saints, this alone he mentions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:11
verses.text: And observe his consideration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:12
verses.text: When he had persuaded them concerning the resurrection, and made them more earnest, then and not till then he discusses this point also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:13
verses.text: It is true indeed that on these matters he had spoken to them before, when he said, "If we sowed unto you spiritual things, is it a great matter if we shall reap your carnal things?" And, "Who planteth a vineyard, and eateth not of the fruit thereof?" But because he knew the greatness of this moral achievement, he refuses not to add a fresh mention at the end of his letter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:14
verses.text: And he calls the collection λογίαν (a "contribution,") immediately from the very first making out the things to be easy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:15
verses.text: For when contribution is made by all together, that becomes light which is charged upon each.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:16
verses.text: But having spoken about the collection, he did not say immediately, "Let every one of you lay up in store with himself;" although this of course was the natural consequence; but having first said, "As I gave order to the Churches of Galatia," he added this, kindling their emulation by the account of the well-doings of others, and putting it in the form of a narration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:17
verses.text: And this also he did when writing to the Romans; for to them also while appearing to narrate the reason why he was going away to Jerusalem, he introduces thereupon his discourse about alms; "But now I go unto Jerusalem, ministering unto the saints: for it hath been the good pleasure of Macedonia and Achaia to make a certain contribution for the poor among the saints".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:18
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:19
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:20
verses.text: ) Only those he stimulates by mention of Macedonians and Corinthians; these of Galatians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:21
verses.text: For he saith, "As I gave order to the Churches of Galatia, so also do ye:" for they would surely feel ashamed ever afterwards to be found inferior to Galatians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:22
verses.text: And he saith not, "I advised," and, "I counselled;" but, "I gave order," which is more authoritative.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:23
verses.text: And he doth not bring forward a single city, or two, or three, but an entire nation: which also he doth in his doctrinal instructions, saying, "Even as also in all the Churches of the saints".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:24
verses.text: For if this be potent for conviction of doctrines, much more for imitation of actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:25
verses.text: "What then, I ask, didst thou give order about?"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:26
verses.text: "On the first day of the week," that is, the Lord's day, "let each one of you lay by him in store, as he may prosper".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:27
verses.text: Mark how he exhorts them even from the time: for indeed the day was enough to lead them to almsgiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:28
verses.text: Wherefore "call to mind," saith he, "what ye attained to on this day: how all the unutterable blessings, and that which is the root and the beginning of our life took place on this day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:29
verses.text: But not in this regard only is the season convenient for a zealous benevolence, but also because it hath rest and immunity from toils: the souls when released from labors becoming readier and apter to show pity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:30
verses.text: Moreover, the communicating also on that day in Mysteries so tremendous and immortal instils great zealousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:31
verses.text: On it, accordingly, "let each one of you," not merely this or that individual, but "each one of you," whether poor or rich, woman or man, slave or free, "lay by him store".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:32
verses.text: He said not, "Let him bring it the church," lest they might feel ashamed because of the smallness of the sum; but "having by gradual additions swelled his contribution, let him then produce it, when I am come but for the present lay it up," saith he, "at home, and make thine house a church; thy little box a treasury.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:33
verses.text: Become a guardian sacred wealth, a self-ordained steward of the poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:34
verses.text: Thy benevolent mind assigns to thee this priesthood".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:35
verses.text: Of this our treasury even now is a sign: but the sign remains, the thing itself no where.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:36
verses.text: Now I am aware that many of this congregation will again find fault with me when I treat of these subjects, and say, "Be not, I beseech you, be not harsh and disagreeable to your audience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:37
verses.text: Make allowances for their disposition; give way to the mind of the hearers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:38
verses.text: For in this case you really do put us to shame; you make us blush".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:39
verses.text: But I may not endure such words: since neither was Paul ashamed to be continually troublesome upon such points as these and to speak words such as mendicants use.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:40
verses.text: I grant indeed that if I said, "give it me," and "lay it up in my house," there might perchance be something to be ashamed of in what I said: hardly however even in that case; for "they who wait upon the altar," we read, "have their portion with the altar".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:42
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:43
verses.text: ) However, some one perhaps might find fault as if he were framing an argument for his own interest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:44
verses.text: But now it is for the poor that I make my supplication; nay, not so much for the poor, as for your sake who bestow the gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:45
verses.text: Wherefore also I am bold to speak out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:46
verses.text: For what shame is it to say, Give unto thy Lord in His hunger: Put raiment on Him going about naked; Receive Him being a stranger? Thy Lord is not ashamed before the whole world to speak thus: "I was an hungred, and ye gave Me not to eat," He who is void of all want and requires nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:47
verses.text: And am I to be ashamed and hesitate? Away with this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:48
verses.text: This shame is of the snare of the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:49
verses.text: I will not then be ashamed, but will say, and that boldly, "Give to the needy;" I will say it with a louder voice than the needy themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:50
verses.text: True it is, if any one can show and prove that in saying these things we are drawing you over unto ourselves, and under the pretence of the poor are ourselves making gain, such a course would be worthy, I say not of shame, but even of ten thousand thunderbolts; and life itself would be more than persons so behaving would deserve.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:51
verses.text: If, on the contrary, by the grace of God, we are in nothing troublesome about ourselves, but "have made the Gospel without charge" to you; laboring indeed in no wise like Paul, but being contented with our own;—with all boldness of speech I will say, "Give unto the needy:" yea, and I will not leave off saying it, and of those who give not I will be a severe accuser.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:52
verses.text: For so, if I were a general and had soldiers, I should not feel ashamed at demanding food for my men: for I vehemently set my heart upon your salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:53
verses.text: But that my argument may both be more forcible and more effective, I will take Paul for my comrade, and like him will discourse and say, "Let each one of you lay by him in store, as he may prosper".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:54
verses.text: Now observe also how he avoids being burdensome.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:55
verses.text: He said not, "so much," or "so much," but "as he may prosper," whether much or little.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:56
verses.text: Neither said he, "what any one may have gained," but, "as he may prosper:" signifying that the supply is of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:57
verses.text: And not only so, but also by his not enjoining them to deposit all at once, he makes his counsel easy: since the gathering little by little hinders all perception of the burden and the cost.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:58
verses.text: Here you see the reason too for his not enjoining them to produce it immediately, but giving them a long day; whereof adding the cause, he saith, "That there be no gatherings when I come:" which means, that ye may not when the season is come for paying in contributions just then be compelled to collect them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:59
verses.text: And this too in no ordinary degree encouraged them again: the expectation of Paul being sure to make them more earnest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:60
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:61
verses.text: "And when I arrive, whomsoever ye shall approve, them will I send with letters to carry your bounty to Jerusalem".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:62
verses.text: He said not, "this person," and "that," but, "whomsoever ye shall approve," whomsoever you shall choose, thus freeing his ministration from suspicion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:63
verses.text: Wherefore to them he leaves the right of voting in the choice of those who are to convey it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:64
verses.text: He is far enough from saying, "The payment is yours, but the privilege of selecting those who are to carry it is not yours".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:65
verses.text: Next, that they might not think him quite absent, he adds his letters, saying, "Whomsoever you approve, I will send with letters".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:66
verses.text: As if he had said, I also will be with them and share in the ministration, by my letters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:67
verses.text: And he said not, "These will I send to bear your alms," but, "your bounty;" to signify that they were doing great deeds; to mark that they were gainers themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:68
verses.text: And elsewhere he calls it both "a blessing" and "a distribution".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:69
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:70
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:72
verses.text: ) The one that he might not make them less active, the other that he might not elate them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:73
verses.text: But in no case whatever hath he called it "alms".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:74
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:75
verses.text: "And if it be meet for me to go also, they shall go with me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:76
verses.text: Here again he exhorts them to liberality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:77
verses.text: As thus: "if it be so much," saith he, "as to require my presence also, neither will I decline this".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:78
verses.text: But he did not in the first instance promise this, nor say, "When I am come I will carry it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:79
verses.text: For he would not have made so much of it, if he had so set it down from the first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:80
verses.text: Afterwards however he adds it well and seasonably.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:81
verses.text: Here then you have the reason why he did not immediately promise, nor yet altogether hold his peace concerning it: but having said, "I will send," then at length he adds himself also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:82
verses.text: And here too again he leaves it to their own decision; in saying, "If it be meet for me to go also:" whereas this rested with them, namely, to make their collection large; so large even, as to affect his plans and cause him in person to make the journey.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:83
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:84
verses.text: "But I will come to you," saith he, "when I shall have passed through Macedonia".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:85
verses.text: This he had said also above; then however with anger: at least he added, (c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:86
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:87
verses.text: ) "And I will know not the speech of them that are puffed up, but the power:" but here, more mildly; that they might even long for his coming.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:88
verses.text: Then, that they might not say, "Why is it that you honor the Macedonians above us?" he said not, "When I depart," but, "When I shall have passed through Macedonia; for I do pass through Macedonia".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:89
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:90
verses.text: "But with you it may be that I shall abide, or even winter".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:91
verses.text: For I do not at all wish to take you merely in my way, but to continue among you and spend some time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:92
verses.text: For when he wrote this letter, he was in Ephesus, and it was winter; as you may know by his saying, "Until Pentecost I will tarry at Ephesus; but after this I shall go away to Macedonia, and after having gone through it, I will be with you in the summer; and perhaps I shall even spend the winter with you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:93
verses.text: And why did he say, "perhaps;" and did not positively affirm it? Because Paul did not foreknow all things; for good purposes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:94
verses.text: Wherefore neither doth he absolutely affirm, in order that if it came not to pass, he might have something to resort to; first, his previous mention of it having been indefinite; and next, the power of the Spirit leading him wheresoever It willed, not where he himself desired.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:95
verses.text: And this also he expresses in the second Epistle, when excusing himself on account of his delay, and saying, "Or the things which I purpose, do I purpose according to the flesh, that with me there should be the yea yea and the nay nay?" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:96
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:97
verses.text: )  "That ye may set me forward on my journey wheresoever I go".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:98
verses.text: This also is a mark of love, and great strength of affection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:99
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:100
verses.text: "For I do not wish to see you now by the way; for I hope to tarry awhile with you, if the Lord permit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:101
verses.text: Now these things he said, both to signify his love and also to terrify the sinners, not however openly, but with outward demonstration of friendship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:102
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:103
verses.text: "But I will tarry at Ephesus until Pentecost".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:104
verses.text: As we should expect, he tells them all exactly, informing them as friends.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:105
verses.text: For this too is a mark of friendship to say the reason why he was not with them, why he delayed, and where he was staying.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:106
