verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:107
verses.text: "For a great door and effectual is opened unto me, and there are many adversaries".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:108
verses.text: Now if it was "great," how could there be "adversaries?" Why on this very account the adversaries were many, because men's faith was great; because the entrance was great and wide.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:109
verses.text: But what means, "A great door?" There are many prepared to receive the faith, many ready to approach and be converted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:110
verses.text: There is a spacious entrance for me, things being now come to that point that the mind of those approaching is at its prime for the obedience of the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:111
verses.text: On this account, vehement was the blast of the breath of the devil, because he saw many turning away from him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:112
verses.text: You see then on both accounts it was needful for him to stay; both because the gain was abundant, and because the struggle was great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:113
verses.text: And herewith also he cheered them up, namely, by saying, that henceforth the word works every where and springs up readily.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:114
verses.text: And if there be many who plot against it, this also is a sign of the advance of the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:115
verses.text: For at no time doth that evil demon wax fierce, except on seeing his goods made spoil of abundantly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:116
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:117
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:118
verses.text: )   Let us then, when we desire to effect any thing great and noble, not regard this, the greatness of the labor which it brings, but let us rather look to the gain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:119
verses.text: Mark, for instance, Paul, not therefore lingering, not therefore shrinking back, because "there were many adversaries;" but because "there was a great door," pressing on and persevering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:120
verses.text: Yea, and as I was saying, this was a sign that the devil was being stripped, for it is not, depend on it, by little and mean achievements that men provoke that evil monster to wrath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:121
verses.text: And so when thou seest a righteous man performing great and excellent deeds, yet suffering innumerable ills, marvel not; on the contrary, one might well marvel, if the devil receiving so many blows were to keep quiet and bear the wounds meekly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:122
verses.text: Even as you ought not to be surprised were a serpent, continually goaded, to grow fierce and spring on the person that goaded it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:123
verses.text: Now no serpent steals on you so fierce as the devil, leaping up against all; and, like a scorpion with its sting raised, he raises himself upright.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:124
verses.text: Let not this then disturb you: since of course he that returns from war and victory and slaughter must needs be bloody, and oftentimes also have received wounds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:125
verses.text: Do thou, then, for thy part, when thou seest any one doing alms and performing numberless other good works and so curtailing the power of the devil, and then falling into temptations and perils; be not troubled thereupon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:126
verses.text: This is the very reason why he fell into temptations, because he mightily smote the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:127
verses.text: "And how did God permit it?" you will say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:128
verses.text: That he might be crowned more signally: that the other might receive a severer wound.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:129
verses.text: For when after benefits conferred a man suffers, and that grievously, and yet continually gives thanks, it is a blow to the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:130
verses.text: For it is a great thing, even when our affairs are flowing on prosperously, to show mercy and to adhere to virtue: but it is far greater in grievous calamity not to desist from this noble occupation; this is he who may be most truly said to do so for God's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:131
verses.text: So then, though we be in peril, beloved, though we suffer ever so greatly, let us with the greater zeal apply ourselves to our labors for virtue's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:132
verses.text: For this is not at all the season for retribution.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:133
verses.text: Here then let us not ask for our crowns, lest when the crowns come in their season, we diminish our recompense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:134
verses.text: For as in the case of artificers, they who support themselves and work receive higher pay; while those who have their maintenance with their employers, are curtailed in no small part of the wages; so also in regard to the saints: he that doth immense good and suffers extreme evil hath his reward unimpaired and a far more abundant recompense, not only for the good things which he hath done, but also for the evil which he hath suffered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:135
verses.text: But he that enjoys rest and luxury here, hath not such bright crowns there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:136
verses.text: Let us not then seek for our recompense here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:137
verses.text: But "then" of all times let us rejoice, when doing well we suffer ill.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:138
verses.text: For God hath in store for us in that world not only the reward of our good deeds, but that of our temptations also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:139
verses.text: But to explain myself more clearly: suppose two rich merciful men, and let them give to the poor: then let one continue in his riches and enjoy all prosperity: the other fall into poverty and diseases and calamities, and give God thanks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:140
verses.text: Now when these are gone away into the other world, which will receive the greater reward? Is it not quite plain that it will be he who is sick and in adversity, seeing that though he did well and suffered ill, he felt not according to human infirmity? I suppose this is plain to every one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:141
verses.text: And, in truth, this is the adamantine statue, this is the considerate servant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:142
verses.text: (See S.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:143
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:144
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:145
verses.text: ) But if we ought not to do any thing good for the hope of the kingdom, but because it so pleaseth God, which is more than any kingdom; what doth he deserve, who because he doth not receive his recompense here, is become more remiss concerning virtue?  Let us then not be troubled when we see that such an one who invited widows and made continual feasts lost his house by fire, or sustained some other such like disaster.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:146
verses.text: Yea, for this very thing he shall receive his reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:147
verses.text: For even Job was not so much admired for his alms-deeds as he was for his sufferings afterwards.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:148
verses.text: For this reason his friends also are little esteemed and deemed of no account; because they sought for the recompenses of the present world, and with a view to this gave sentence against the just man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:149
verses.text: Let us then not seek for our return here; let us not become poor and needy; since surely it is of extreme meanness, when heaven is proposed, and things which are above the heaven, to be looking round on the things which are here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:150
verses.text: Let us not by any means do so; but whichsoever of unexpected things come upon us, hold we fast the commands of God continually, and obey the blessed Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:151
verses.text: And let us make a little chest for the poor at home; and near the place at which you stand praying, there let it be put: and as often as you enter in to pray, first deposit your alms, and then send up your prayer; and as you would not wish to pray with unwashen hands, so neither do so without alms: since not even the Gospel hanging by our bed is more important than that alms should be laid up for you; for if you hang up the Gospel and do nothing, it will do you no such great good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:152
verses.text: But if you have this little coffer, you have a defence against the devil, you give wings to your prayer, you make your house holy, having meat for the King (S.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:153
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:154
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:155
verses.text: ) there laid up in store.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:156
verses.text: And for this reason let the little coffer be placed also near the bed, and the night will not be troubled with fantasies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:157
verses.text: Only let nothing be cast into it, which is the fruit of injustice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:158
verses.text: For this thing is charity; and it cannot be that charity should ever spring out of hardheartedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:159
verses.text: Will you have mention also of the resources out of which you should make your deposits, so as in this respect also to make this kind of contribution easy? The handicraft man, for instance, the sandal-maker, or the leather-cutter, or the brass-founder, or any other artificer,—when he sells any article of his trade, let him give the first-fruits of its price unto God: let him cast in a small portion here, and assign something to God out of his portion, though it be rather scanty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:160
verses.text: For neither do I ask any great thing; but so much as the childish ones among the Jews, full as they are of innumerable evils, just so much let us cast in, we who look forward to heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:161
verses.text: And this I say not as laying down a law, neither as forbidding more, but as recommending a deposit of not less than a tenth part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:162
verses.text: And this also do thou practise not in selling only, but also in buying and receiving a recompense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:163
verses.text: Let those also who possess land observe this law in regard to their rents: yea, let it be a law for all who gather their incomes in an honest way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:164
verses.text: For with those who demand usury I have no concern, neither with soldiers who do violence to others and turn to their own advantage their neighbors' calamities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:165
verses.text: Since from that quarter God will accept nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:166
verses.text: But these things I say to those who gather their substance by righteous labor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 42:167
verses.text: Yea, and if we establish ourselves in this kind of habit, we are ever after stung by our conscience if ever we omit this rule; and after a while we shall not even think it a hard thing; and by degrees we shall arrive at the greater things, and by practising how to despise wealth, and by pulling up the root of evils, we shall both pass the present life in peace, and obtain the life to come; which may it be the portion of us all to attain unto, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:1
verses.text: Homily XLIV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:3
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:4
verses.text: Now if Timothy come to you, see that he be with you without fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:5
verses.text: Perhaps some one may think there is something unworthy of Timothy's courage in this piece of advice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:6
verses.text: But not on Timothy's account is this said, but for the hearers' sake: lest by their design against him they should hurt themselves: since he for his part had his station always in the way of dangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:7
verses.text: "For as a child serveth a father," saith he, "so he served with me in furtherance of the Gospel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:8
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:9
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:10
verses.text: ) But lest from boldness towards the disciple they should proceed also to the teacher, and become worse, he checks them from afar off, saying, "that he may be with you without fear;" that is, that none of those desperate persons rise up against him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:11
verses.text: For he intended perhaps to rebuke them about the things concerning which Paul also had written: and indeed Paul professed to send him for this very reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:12
verses.text: "For I have sent Timothy unto you," saith he, (c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:13
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:14
verses.text: ) "who shall put you in remembrance of my ways in Christ even as I teach every where in every Church".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:15
verses.text: In order then that they might not through confidence in their high birth and wealth, and the support of the people, and the wisdom from without, attack him and spit upon him and plot against him, being grieved at the reproofs which came from him; or lest in revenge for the teacher's rebuke they should demand satisfaction of him, so punishing the other; therefore he saith, "that he be without fear with you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:16
verses.text: As if he had said, "Tell me not of those who are without, the Gentiles and unbelievers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:17
verses.text: It is your part that I require, you for whom also the whole Epistle was composed," the persons also whom in the beginning and the outset he had frightened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:18
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, "with you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:19
verses.text: Then in virtue of his ministry he sets him forth as a person to be fully trusted; saying "For the work of the Lord he worketh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:20
verses.text: That is; "look not," saith he, "to this, his not being rich, namely, nor highly educated, nor old: but what commands are laid upon him, what work he is doing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:21
verses.text: 'For the work of the Lord he worketh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:22
verses.text: '" And this serves him instead of all nobility and wealth and age and wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:23
verses.text: And he is not content with this, but adds, "Even as I also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:24
verses.text: And some way above, "Who is my beloved son and faithful in the Lord; he shall put you in remembrance of my ways in Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:25
verses.text: Seeing then that he was both young, and had been singly entrusted with the improvement of so numerous a people, both of which things tended to bring him into contempt, he adds, as we might expect,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:26
verses.text: "Let no one therefore despise him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:27
verses.text: And not this only doth he demand of them, but also greater honor; wherefore also he saith, "but set him forward in peace;" that is, without fear; causing no fightings or contentions, no enmities or hatreds, but rendering all subjection as to a teacher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:28
verses.text: "That he may come unto me: for I expect him with the brethren".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:29
verses.text: This also was the language of one that would alarm them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:30
verses.text: That is, in order that they might become more considerate, as knowing that all would be told him whatever Timothy's treatment might be, he adds therefore, "for I expect him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:31
verses.text: And besides, hereby he both shows that Timothy is worthy of their confidence; since being on the point of departing he waits for him; and also signifies the love which he hath towards them, it appearing that for their sakes he sent away one so useful to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:32
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:33
verses.text: "But as touching Apollos the brother, I besought him much to come unto you with the brethren".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:34
verses.text: This man appears to have been both well-educated and also older than Timothy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:35
verses.text: Lest they should say then, "For what possible reason did he not send the man grown, but the youth instead of him?" observe how he softens down this point also, both calling him a brother, and saying that he had besought him much.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:36
verses.text: For lest he should seem to have held Timothy in higher honor than him and to have exalted him more, and on this account not to have sent him, and cause their envy to burst out more abundantly, he adds, "I besought him much to come".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:37
verses.text: What then: did not the other yield nor consent? did he resist and show himself contentious? He saith not this, but that he might not excite prejudice against him, and also might make excuse for himself, he saith, "and it was not at all his will to come now".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:38
verses.text: Then to prevent their saying that all this was an excuse and pretence, he added, "but he will come to you when he shall have opportunity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:39
verses.text: This was both an excuse for him, and a refreshment to them who desired to see him, by the hope which it gave of his coming.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:40
verses.text: Afterwards indicating that not in the teachers but in themselves they ought to have their hopes of salvation, he saith,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:41
verses.text: "Watch ye, stand fast in the faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:42
verses.text: Not in the wisdom which is without: for there it is not possible to stand, but to be borne along; even as "in the faith" ye may "stand".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:43
verses.text: "Quit you like men, be strong".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:44
verses.text: "Let all that ye do be done in love".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:45
verses.text: Now in saying these things, he seems indeed to advise; but he is reprimanding them as indolent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:46
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, "Watch," as though they slept; "Stand," as though they were rocking to and fro: "Quit you like men," as though they were playing the coward: "Let all that ye do be done in love," as though they were in dissensions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:47
verses.text: And the first caution refers to the deceivers, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:48
verses.text: , "Watch," "stand:" the next, to those who plot against us, "Quit you like men:" the third, to those who make parties and endeavor to distract, "Let all that ye do be done in love;" which thing is "the bond of perfectness," and the root and fountain of all blessings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:49
verses.text: But what means, "All things in love?" "Whether any one rebuke," saith he, "or rule or be ruled, or learn or teach, let all be in love:" since in fact all the things which have been mentioned arose from neglect of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:50
verses.text: For if this had not been neglected, they would not have been puffed up, they would not have said, "I am of Paul, and I of Apollos".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:51
verses.text: If this had existed, they would not have gone to law before heathens, or rather they would not have gone to law at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:52
verses.text: If this had existed, that notorious person would not have taken his father's wife: they would not have despised the weak brethren; there would have been no factions among them; they would not have been vain-glorious about their gifts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:53
verses.text: Therefore it is that he saith, "Let all things be done in love".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:54
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:55
verses.text: "Now I beseech you, brethren;—ye know the house of Stephanas, that it is the first-fruits of Achaia, and that they have set themselves to minister unto the saints".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:56
verses.text: In the beginning too he mentions this man, saying, "I baptized also the home of Stephanas:" and now he speaks of him as "the first-fruits" not of Corinth only, but also of all Greece.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:57
verses.text: And this too is no small encomium that he was the first to come to Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:58
verses.text: Wherefore also in the Epistle to the Romans, praising certain persons on this account, he said, "Who also were in Christ before me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:59
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:60
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:61
verses.text: ) And he said not, that they were the first who believed, but were the "first-fruits;" implying that together with their faith they showed forth also a most excellent life, in every way proving themselves worthy, as in the case of fruits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:62
verses.text: For so the first-fruits ought to be better than the rest of those things whereof they are the first-fruits: a kind of praise which Paul hath attributed to these also by this expression: namely, that they not only had a genuine faith, as I was saying, but also they exhibited great piety, and the climax of virtue, and liberality in alms-giving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:63
verses.text: And not from hence only, but from another topic likewise he indicates their piety, i-e:, from their having filled their whole house also with godliness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:64
verses.text: And that they flourished in good works also, he declares by what follows, saying, "They have set themselves to minister unto the saints".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:65
verses.text: Hear ye, how vast are the praises of their hospitality? For he did not say, "they minister," but, "have set themselves:" this kind of life they have chosen altogether, this is their business in which they are always busy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:66
verses.text: "That ye also be in subjection unto such, that is, "that ye take a share with them both in expenditure of money, and in personal service: that ye be partakers with them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:67
verses.text: For both to them the labor will be light when they have comrades, and the results of their active benevolence will extend to more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:68
verses.text: And he said not merely, "be fellow-helpers," but added, "whatsoever directions they give, obey;" implying the strictest obedience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:69
verses.text: And that he might not appear to be favoring them, he adds, "and to every one that helpeth in the work and laboreth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:70
verses.text: "Let this," saith he, "be a general rule: for I do not speak about them individually, but if there be any one like them, let him also have the same advantages".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:71
verses.text: And therefore when he begins to commend, he calls upon themselves as witnesses, saying, "I beseech you, ye know the house of Stephanas".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:72
verses.text: "For ye also yourselves are aware," saith he, "how they labor, and have no need to learn from us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:73
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:74
verses.text: "But I was glad of the coming of Stephanas and Fortunatus and Achaicus, for that which was lacking on your part they supplied".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:75
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:76
verses.text: "For they refreshed my spirit and yours".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:77
verses.text: Thus, since it was natural for them to be greatly irritated against these persons, for it was they who had come and showed him all about the division, inasmuch as by them also they had written the questions about the virgins, and about the married persons:—mark how he softened them down; both in the beginning of his Epistle by saying, "For it hath been signified unto me by them which are of the house of Chloe;" thus at once concealing these and bringing forward the others: (for it should seem that the latter had given their information by means of the former:) and in this place again, "They have supplied your lack, and refreshed my spirit and yours:" signifying that they had come instead of all, and had chosen to undertake so great a journey on their behalf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:78
verses.text: How then may this, their peculiar praise, become common? "If you will solace me for what was wanting on your part by your kindness towards them; if you will honor, if you will receive, them, if you will communicate with them in doing good".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:79
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, "Acknowledge ye then them that are such".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:80
verses.text: And while praising those that came, he embraces also the others in his praise, the senders together with the sent: where he saith, "'They refreshed my spirit and yours, therefore acknowledge such as these,' because for your sakes they left country and home".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:81
verses.text: Dost thou perceive his consideration? He implies that they had obliged not Paul only, but the Corinthians likewise, in that they bore about in themselves the whole city.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:82
verses.text: A thing which both added credit to them, and did not allow the others to sever themselves from them, inasmuch as in their persons they had presented themselves to Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:83
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:84
verses.text: "All the Churches of Asia salute you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:85
verses.text: He is continually making the members combine and cleave together in one by means of the salutation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:86
verses.text: "Aquila and Priscilla salute you much in the Lord;"—for with them he was lodging, being a tent-maker—"with the Church which is in their house".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:87
verses.text: This thing too is no small excellency, that they had made their very house a Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:88
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:89
verses.text: "All the brethren salute you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:90
verses.text: Salute one another with an holy kiss".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:91
verses.text: This addition of the "holy kiss" he makes only here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:92
verses.text: What may the reason be? They had been widely at variance with one another on account of their saying, "I am of Paul, and I of Apollos, and I of Cephas, and I of Christ;" on account of "one being hungry, and another drunken;" on account of their having contentions and jealousies and suits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:93
verses.text: And from the gifts there was much envying and great pride.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:94
verses.text: Having then knit them together by his exhortation, he naturally bids them use the holy kiss also as a means of union: for this unites, and produces one body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:95
verses.text: This is holy, when free from deceit and hypocrisy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:96
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:97
verses.text: "The salutation of me Paul with mine own hand;" intimates that the Epistle was composed with great seriousness; and therefore he added,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:98
verses.text: "If any man love not our Lord Jesus Christ, let him be anathema".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:99
verses.text: By this one word he strikes fear into all: those who made their members the members of an harlot; those who put stumbling blocks in the way of their brethren by the things offered in sacrifice unto idols; those who named themselves after men; those who refuse to believe the resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:100
verses.text: And he not only strikes fear, but also points out the way of virtue and the fountain of vice, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:101
verses.text: that as when our love towards Him hath become intense, there is no kind of sin but is extinguished and cast out thereby; so when it is too weak, it causes the same to spring up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:102
verses.text: "Maran atha".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:103
verses.text: For what reason is this word used? And wherefore too in the Hebrew-tongue? Seeing that arrogance was the cause of all the evils, and this arrogance the wisdom from without produced, and this was the sum and substance of all the evils, a thing which especially distracted Corinth; in repressing their arrogance he did not even use the Greek tongue, but the Hebrew: signifying that so far from being ashamed of that sort of simplicity, he even embraces it with much warmth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:104
verses.text: But what is the meaning of "Maran atha?" "Our Lord is come".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:105
verses.text: For what reason then doth he use this phrase in particular? To confirm the doctrine of the Economy: out of which class of topics more than any other he hath put together those arguments which are the seeds of the Resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:106
verses.text: And not only this, but also to rebuke them; as if he had said, "The common Lord of all hath condescended to come down thus far, and are ye in the same state, and do ye abide in your sins? Are ye not thrilled with the excess of His love, the crown of His blessings? Yea, consider but this one thing," saith he, "and it will suffice thee for progress in all virtue, and thou shalt be able to extinguish all sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:107
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:108
verses.text: "The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:109
verses.text: This is like a teacher, to help not only with advice, but also with prayers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:110
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:111
verses.text: "My love be with you all in Christ Jesus, Amen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:112
verses.text: Thus to hinder them from thinking that in flattery to them he so ended, he saith, "In Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:113
verses.text: It having nothing in it human or carnal, but being of a sort of spiritual nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:114
verses.text: Wherefore it is thoroughly genuine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:115
verses.text: For indeed the expression was that of one who loves deeply.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:116
verses.text: As thus; because he was separated from them as regards place, as it were by the stretching out of a right hand he incloses them with the arms of his love, saying, "My love be with you all;" just as if he said, "With all of you I am".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:117
verses.text: Whereby he intimates that the things written came not of wrath or anger, but of provident care, seeing that after so heavy an accusation he doth not turn himself away, but rather loves them, and embraces them when they are afar off, by these epistles and writings throwing himself into their arms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:118
verses.text: For so ought he that corrects to do: since he at least, who acts merely from anger is but satisfying his own feeling; but he who after correcting the sinner renders also the offices of love, shows that those words also, whatsoever he spake in reproof, were words of fond affection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:119
verses.text: Just so let us too chasten one another; and let neither the corrector be angry, (for this belongs not to correction, but to passion,) nor let him that is corrected take it ill.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:120
verses.text: For what is done is healing, not despite.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:121
verses.text: Now if physicians use cautery and are not found fault with, and that too, frequently, though they quite miss their object; but even in their pain the subjects of the cautery and amputation esteem as benefactors those who excite this pain; much more ought he who receives reproof to be so disposed, and as to a physician so to give heed to the corrector, and not as to an enemy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:122
verses.text: And let us also who rebuke approach with great gentleness, with great prudence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:123
verses.text: And if thou seest a brother committing sin, as Christ commanded, make not your rebuke public, but "between thee and him alone:" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:124
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:125
verses.text: ) not reproaching nor insulting over him when down, but in pain and with a melting heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:126
verses.text: And show thyself ready also to receive reproof, if thou commit error in any thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:127
verses.text: Now that what I say may be plainer, let us put an imaginary case and so try our rule.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:128
verses.text: For God forbid that in very deed we should be provided with such an illustration of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:129
verses.text: Suppose any brother dwelling in the same house with a virgin, in honor and chastity, and yet not even so quite escaping evil report.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:130
verses.text: If then you should hear talk of this their dwelling together, be not contemptuous, nor say, "Why, hath he no understanding? Doth he not himself know what is for his good? Get love for nothing, but do not for nothing get hatred.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:131
verses.text: Why, what have I to do with taking up a gratuitous enmity?" These are the doting words of wild beasts, or rather of demons: for it is not so that he is hated for nothing who doth this for his brother's correction, rather it is for great blessings and crowns unutterable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:132
verses.text: But if thou sayest, "What? hath he no understanding?" thou shalt hear from me that he hath not: drunken as he is with his passion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:133
verses.text: For if in the heathen courts of justice, those who are injured must not speak for themselves while glowing with wrath; (although there be no fault in that kind of sympathy;) how much more those whom evil habit holds in subjection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:134
verses.text: Wherefore I say that manifold as his wisdom may be, he hath not his mind awake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:135
verses.text: For what can be wiser than David, the man who said, "The dark and the hidden things of Thy wisdom Thou hast made known unto me?" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:136
verses.text: li.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:137
verses.text: ap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:138
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:139
verses.text: l.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:140
verses.text: ) But when he looked on the wife of the soldier with unjust eyes, then according to what he himself said (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:141
verses.text: cvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:142
verses.text: ) of those who sail on the raging sea, "all his wisdom was swallowed up;" and he stood in need of others to correct him, and did not even perceive amidst what evils he was.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:143
verses.text: Wherefore also, bewailing his offences, he said, "As a heavy burden they weighed grievously upon me: my wounds stank and were corrupt because of my folly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:144
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:145
verses.text: xxxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:146
verses.text: ) He therefore that committeth sin hath no understanding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:147
verses.text: For he is drunken and is in darkness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:148
verses.text: Do not then say these things, neither add that other remark, "I care not at all about it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:149
verses.text: 'For each man shall bear his own burden.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:150
verses.text: '" (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:151
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:152
verses.text: ) Nay, against thyself also it grows up into a grievous accusation, that seeing one in error thou dost not restore him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:153
verses.text: For if it was not right according to the law of the Jews (Exod.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:154
verses.text: xxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:156
verses.text: ) to slight the beast of one's enemy; he who despises not the beast of burden nor yet the soul of an enemy perishing, but that of a friend, what pardon shall he obtain?  Yea, neither is it enough for our excuse that he hath understanding: since we too after our many and manifold exhortations have not been sufficient, nor proved useful, unto ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:157
verses.text: Bear this in mind then in regard to him also that is in error; that it is natural he should receive the best counsel rather from thee than from himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:158
verses.text: And say not, "But what care I about these things?" Fear thou him who first spoke this word; for the saying, "Am I my brother's keeper?" (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:159
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:160
verses.text: ) tends to the same point as this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:161
verses.text: This is the mother of all our evils that we esteem the concerns of our own body as foreign to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:162
verses.text: What sayest thou? Thou carest not for thy brother? Who then is to care for him? the unbeliever who rejoices over and reproaches and insults him? or the devil who urges him on and supplants him?  And whence comes this? "How do I know that I shall accomplish anything," saith he, "though I speak and advise what is right".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:163
verses.text: But how is it clear that thou wilt do no good? Why, this again is extreme folly, while the end remains in obscurity to incur the manifold blame of confessed indifference.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:164
verses.text: And yet God who foresees the future often speaks and doth no good; yet doth He not even so give up; and that, knowing that He shall not even persuade men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:165
verses.text: Now if He who knows beforehand that He shall win no advantage, ceases not from the work of correction, what excuse wilt thou have, who art completely ignorant of the future and yet faintest and art benumbed? Yea, and many have succeeded by frequent attempts: and when they most of all despaired, then did they most gain their point.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:166
verses.text: And though thou shouldest gain no advantage, thou hast done thine own part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:167
verses.text: Be not then inhuman, nor unmerciful, nor careless: for that these words come of cruelty and indifference is plain from what follows: viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:168
verses.text: What is the reason that when one of the members of thy body is in pain, thou sayest not, "What care I?" Yet whence is it plain, that if it be taken due care of, it is restored? And yet thou leavest nothing undone, that even although thou profit not, thou mayest not have to blame thyself for the omission of any thing which ought to have been done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:169
verses.text: Hereupon I ask, are we to take such care for the members of our body and to neglect those of Christ? Nay, how can such things deserve pardon? For if I make no impression upon thee by saying, "Have a care of thine own member;" in order that thou mayest become better were it only through fear, I put thee in mind of the body of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:170
verses.text: But how can it be other than a matter of horror to see His flesh putrefying, and neglect it? And if thou hadst a slave or an ass afflicted with a mortifying sore, thou couldest not have the heart to neglect it: but seest thou the Body of Christ full of scurvy, and hurriest by? and thinkest not that such things deserve innumerable thunder-bolts? For this cause all things are turned upside down, because of this our inhumanity, because of our indifference.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:171
verses.text: Wherefore now, I beseech you, let this cruelty be cast out from among us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:172
verses.text: Draw near to him whom I speak of, as dwelling with a virgin, and speak some small praise of thy brother, making it up from the other excellencies which he hath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:173
verses.text: And foment him with thy commendations as it were with warm water, and so mitigate the tumor of his wound.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:174
verses.text: Speak of thyself also as wretched; accuse the common race of mankind; point out that we are all in sins; ask for pardon, saying, that thou art undertaking things too great for thee, but love persuades thee to dare all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:175
verses.text: Then in giving thine advice, do it not imperiously, but in a brotherly way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:176
verses.text: And when by all these means thou hast reduced the swelling and soothed the pain arising from the cutting reproof which is in store for him, and when thou hast again and again deprecated and besought him not to be angry: when thou hast bound him down with these things, then use the knife; neither pressing the matter too close, nor yet undoing it; that he may neither fly off on the one hand, nor on the other think little of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:177
verses.text: For if thou strike not to the quick thou hast done no good, and if thy blow be violent, thou makest him start away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:178
verses.text: Wherefore, even after all this, being on the very point of the reproof, mix up again commendation with thy censures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:179
verses.text: And seeing that this proceeding considered in itself cannot be matter of praise, (for it is not commendable to keep house with a damsel that is a virgin;) let the purpose of him who doth so be thy topic for effecting this; and say, "I know indeed that thou doest it for God's sake, and that the desolation and unprotected state of that poor woman met thine eye, and caused thee to stretch out thine hand to her".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:180
verses.text: And although he may not be doing it with this intention, do thou speak so; and after this add what follows also; again excusing thyself and saying, "These things I speak not to direct but to remind thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:181
verses.text: Thou doest it for God's sake; I too know that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:182
verses.text: But let us see whether another evil be not produced thereby.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:183
verses.text: And if there be none, keep her in thine house, and cling to this excellent purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:184
verses.text: There is no one to hinder thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:185
verses.text: But if any mischief arise from hence exceeding the advantage, let us take care, I beseech you, lest while we are earnest to comfort one soul, we put a stumbling-block in the way of ten thousand".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:186
verses.text: And do not add immediately the punishments due to those who give offence, but take his own testimony also, saying, "Thou hast no need to learn these things from me: thou thyself knowest, 'if any one offend one of these little ones,' how great a penalty is threatened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:187
verses.text: And thus, having sweetened thy speech and smoothed down his wrath, apply the medicine of thy correction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:188
verses.text: And should he again urge her forlorn condition, do not thou even so expose his pretence, but say to him, "Let nothing of this sort make you afraid: thou wilt have an ample plea, the offence given to others: since not for indifference, but in care towards them, didst thou cease from this thy purpose".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:189
verses.text: And let the matter of thine advice be brief, for there is no need of much teaching; but let the expressions of forbearance on the other hand be many and close upon one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:190
verses.text: And continually have thou recourse to the topic of love; throwing into shade the painfulness of what thou sayest, and giving him his full power, and saying, "This is what I for my part advise and recommend; but about taking the advice thou art only judge: for I do not compel and force thee, but submit the whole thing to thine own discretion".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:191
verses.text: If we so manage our reproof, we shall easily be able in correct those in error: even as what we now do is surely more like the conduct of wild beasts or irrational creatures than of men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:192
verses.text: For if any persons now perceive any one committing errors of this kind, with the person himself they do not at all confer, but themselves, like silly old women who have drunk too much, whisper with another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:193
verses.text: And the saying, "Get love for nothing, but do not get hatred for nothing," hath not here any place in their opinion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:194
verses.text: But, when they have a fancy to speak evil, they mind not being "hated for nothing," rather I should say, "being punished;" since it is not hatred alone that is hereby produced, but also punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:195
verses.text: But when there is need of correction, they allege both this, and innumerable other pretexts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:196
verses.text: Whereas then would be the time to think of these things, when thou speakest evil, when thou calumniatest; I mean the saying, "Be not hated for nothing," and "I can do nothing," and "it is no care of mine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:197
verses.text: But as things are, in the former case, thou art vehemently and idly curious, and carest not for hatred and ills innumerable; but when thou shouldest be taking thought for the salvation of thy brother, then it is thy pleasure to be a sort of unofficious, inoffensive person.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:198
verses.text: And yet from evil speaking arises hatred both on God's part and on men's; and this is no great care to thee: but by giving advice privately, and reproofs of that kind, both he and God will be made thy friends.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:199
verses.text: And even should he hate thee, God goes on loving thee the rather on this account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:200
verses.text: Nay, in fact, not even so will he hate thee, as when his hatred came from thine evil speaking: but in that case he will avoid thee as a foe and an enemy, whereas now he will consider thee more venerable than any father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:201
verses.text: And if he apparently take it ill, inwardly and privately he will feel much obliged to thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:202
verses.text: Bearing in mind these things therefore let us have a care of our own members, and not sharpen the tongue against one another, nor speak words "which may do hurt," undermining the fame of our neighbor, and as in war and battle, giving and receiving blows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:203
verses.text: For what after all is the good of fasting or watching, when the tongue is drunken, and feasts itself at a table more unclean than of dog's flesh; when it is grown ravening after blood, and pours out filth, and makes the mouth a channel of a sewer, nay rather something more abominable than that? For that which proceeds from thence pollutes the body: but what comes from the tongue often suffocates the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:204
verses.text: These things I say, not in anxiety about those who have an ill report falsely: for they are worthy even of crowns, when they bear what is said nobly; but in anxiety for you that so speak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:205
verses.text: For him that is evil reported of falsely, the Scriptures pronounce "blessed;" but the evil-speaker they expel from the holy Mysteries, nay even from the very precincts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:206
verses.text: For it is said, (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:207
verses.text: ci.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:208
verses.text: ) "Him that privily speaketh against his neighbor, this man did I chase out".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:209
verses.text: And he saith too that such a one is unworthy to read the sacred books.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:210
verses.text: For, "Why," saith He, (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:211
verses.text: l.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:212
verses.text: ) "dost thou declare My righteous laws, and takest My covenant in thy mouth?" Then, annexing the cause He saith (v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:213
verses.text: ) "Thou satest and spakest against thy brother".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:214
verses.text: And here indeed he doth not distinctly add whether they be things true or false which he speaks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:215
verses.text: But elsewhere this too makes part of His prohibition: He implying, that even though thou speak truths, yet such things are not to be uttered by thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:216
verses.text: For, "Judge not," saith He," that ye be not judged:" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:217
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:218
verses.text: ) since he too who spoke evil of the publican was condemned, although it was true which he laid to his neighbor's charge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:219
verses.text: "What then," you will say, "if any one be daring and polluted, must we not correct him? must we not expose him?" We must both expose and correct: but in the way which I mentioned before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:220
verses.text: But if thou do it upbraiding him, take heed lest thine imitation of that Pharisee cause thee to fall into his state.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:221
verses.text: For no advantage accrues from hence; none to thee who speakest, none to him who hears thee, none to the person accused.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:222
verses.text: But the latter, for his part, becomes more reckless: since as long as he is unobserved, he is sensible of shame; but as soon as he becomes manifest and notorious, he casts off the curb also which that feeling imposed on him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:223
verses.text: And the hearer will in his turn be yet more injured.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:224
verses.text: For whether he be conscious to himself of good deeds, he becomes puffed and swoln up with the accusation brought against another; or of faults, he then becomes more eager for iniquity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:225
verses.text: Thirdly, the speaker too himself will both incur the bad opinion of the hearer, and will provoke God to more anger against himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:226
verses.text: Wherefore, I beseech you, let us cast from us every word that is unsavory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:227
verses.text: If there be any thing good unto edification, this let us speak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:228
verses.text: But hast thou a fancy to avenge thyself on the other person? Why then punish thyself instead of him? Nay, do thou, who art so earnestly seeking redress from those who have annoyed thee, avenge thyself as Paul recommended to take vengeance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:229
verses.text: "If thine enemy hunger, feed him; if he thirst, give him drink".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:230
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:231
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:232
verses.text: ) But if thou do not so, but only plot against him, thou pointest the sword against thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:233
verses.text: Wherefore if that other speak evil, answer him with praises and commendations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:234
verses.text: For so wilt thou be able both to take vengeance on him, and wilt deliver thyself from evil surmising.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:235
verses.text: Since he that feels pain at hearing ill of himself, is thought to be so affected because of some consciousness of evil: but he that laughs to scorn what is said, exhibits a most unquestionable token of his not being conscious to himself of any evil thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:236
verses.text: Seeing then that thou profitest neither thine hearer, nor thyself, nor him that is accused, and dost but point thy sword at thine own self, even from such considerations do thou learn more soberness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 1 Corinthians 43:237
verses.text: For one ought indeed to be moved by the thought of the kingdom of heaven, and of what pleases God: but since thou art of grosser disposition and bitest like a wild beast, hereby even be thou instructed; that these arguments having corrected thee, thou mayest be able to order thyself simply from consideration of what pleases God; and having come to be above every passion, mayest obtain the heavenly blessings:—which may God grant us all to obtain, through the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, and His mercy towards mankind; with Whom, to the Father and the Holy Spirit, be glory, power, honor, now and henceforth, and unto everlasting ages, Amen.
